>
> One could argue that the collapse of the tech sector was unnecessary.
> Steady growth could have happened. I was arguing vociferously, as far back
> as 1996, that the bubble was not based on anything approaching reality and
> that it was going to be dangerous for the economy of those fools kept
> playing the market like it was a craps table. And I'm fairly certain the
> million-dollar CEOs and investment bankers had to know it was a ponzi
> scheme too, so you'll have to excuse me if I have a hard time blaming the
> poor sap who saw it as an opportunity to pick up a book and make his life
> better.

You can bet your ass they know it's a Ponzi scheme. They don't loan you
their debts ( legal tender) and then ask for Lawful Money at a foreclosure
for no particular reason.

But how many of you realize that when you borrow money or use credit you are
contributing to the eventual collapse of a Ponzi scheme?
That you speed up the process by participating in Usury?
Can you really blame the banksters if you are part of the problem?

>
> > When I look to what I should do next, deciding between my choices is
> > complicated & confusing. Looking back at what I have done, it seems so
> > obvious & simple. I always thought life would get simpler the older I
> > became; the older I get, the more I know this to be wrong, but I still
> > hope that this may eventually be true.
>
> It will never be true. Capitalism may be the best system man has devised
> thus far, but it's a pretty crappy system. And unfortunately it rewards
> lying and stealing and cheating the system. It rewards laziness in many
> cases, as long as you can schmooze and have a bubbly personality. It's
> basically a joke. It's not a science by a long shot.

There is a better system,  it's called the Constitution of the United States
of America.
It was not capitalist and usury was not included in the social contract - it
was outlawed.

Please keep that in mind when you criticize the USA, because a lot of good
people are buried here who died fighting for a nation of law,  not of men.
For the first 140 years in this country,  a loaf of bread was the exact same
price,  two full generations.
There is a REASON for that.
It is time everyone understood why that is.
Perhaps if they did we wouldn't be in this current mess where the house of
cards is falling down hard.

 My advice is don't
> blame yourself, but don't blame the guy warming the chair, because he's
> just trying to make a living too.

Blame ignorance and not making a stand for the truth and for the law of the
land?
For participating in an unjust Ponzi scheme and not educating yourselves?
For not doing what's right but for looking the other way when lawmakers are
lawbreakers?
How many of you have the courage?
If you don't, aren't you getting what you deserve? What you agreed to?
What our parent's agreed to when they let Richard Nixon take away a silver
backing from your money without a peep?
Let's be honest,  shall we?

And those of you paying off mortgages,  how many of you are aware that only
the holder in due course can have an action against you if you default on
your loan? And that the holder in due course of that note is virtually NEVER
the bank you borrowed from?
And that you can pay off a loan with "like kind of money" by the
Constitutional common law?  Why is that important?
The bank loaned you nothing of real value, ( my deposits are not their
asset,  but their debt) yet would love to foreclose and own the land and the
house.
If you find yourself unable to pay off that mortgage,  do what's fair.  Give
the bank an IOU for the full amount of the note.
After all,  that's all they loaned you.   Nothing more.

And you can bet your sweet ass they know it full well.

Happy job hunting everyone.


jH

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Aug  2 10:24:35 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 2 Aug 2002 10:24:35 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] How to explain benefits of Linux for corporate
In-Reply-To: <200208021652.g72GqXf10282@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208021017210.10091-100000@critter.deatech.com>

> Alex inquired:
> > [snip]
> > What arguments other than cost and license fees can be made to
> > convence
> > executives to give Linux a try.
> > [snip]

The most important one of all (at least in my buying decisions it is)
-- stability.  When your product crashes, regardless of the reason, it
reflects badly on your company.  Customers don't want to know that it's
because of the MS product the platform was based on, they simply want it
to work!  If it crashes, they will blame your company, not MS, and when it
comes time to buy similar products again, they will be more likely to
look elsewhere if stability has been a problem.

> OTOH, in my field -- system administration -- there seem to me to be
> relatively few folks academically trained in computer science or
> engineering. Of the dozen or so sysadmins who've been my colleagues
> since I moved here to Oregon, only one has had a CS degree.
> 

meesa too!  BS Chemical Engineering, MS Environmental Sci. & Engineering.
... all my class-based computer education is either (a) programming
courses taken in the course of getting the engineering degrees,
(b) post-graduate PCC or OGI courses to learn/sharpen new skill sets,
or (c) technical training courses (e.g. Cisco ACRC) or conference 
tutorial sessions (Usenix and SANS conferences).
  

> I realize the plural of "anecdote" isn't "data," but similar
> discussions here on PLUG lead me to believe that other IT folks come
> from similarly dissimilar backgrounds.
> 
> I'd guess it's no different in other industries where there's a real
> distinction between design and implementation:
> 
> * how many automotive engineers are you likely to find in the local
>   repair garage?
> 
> * how many structural engineers or architects do you find wielding
>   tools on construction sites?
> 
> * how many trained mathematicians work as accountants?
> 

touche!

> There seems to be a continuum in each of these fields, just as in
> computers:
> 
>   Theoretical Research <-> Engineering <-> Construction/Maintenance
> 
> As you move further to the right you are on that continuum, the less
> you'll encounter formal academic training and the more you'll find
> people trained on the job.
> 
> Frankly, I have a feeling that has nothing to do with the quality (or
> lack thereof) of our educational system, and almost everything to do
> with the people drawn to those fields and the sort of tasks they do.
> 

Yup -- I found I had a knack for working with these beasts, and that
other people really appreciated the help when I did.  


> Just look at how indifferent many (perhaps most) sysadmins are to
> getting formal certification. Having an MSCE is almost a joke. Why?
> Because you'd rather have a sysadmin with loads of on-the-job
> experience than some guy with a newly minted certificate.
> 
> Here are some problems a sysadmin might encounter in any given day:
> 
> * a machine is stuck at the boot loader and won't go further
> * the CEO complains that application X causes application Y to crash
> * a new mail server needs to be brought online
> * Jim Bob in accounting lost a file
> * the network is dropping a larger-than-normal percentage of packets
> * OpenSSL needs patching on a variety of machines :-(
> 
> Speaking as a person with two (non-CS) Master's degrees, and meaning
> absolutely no disrespect to academic CS departments, let me ask you:
> Have your classes taught you how to deal with these things? Would you
> want them to?
> 

No university/college course I have taken has touched on these subjects.
(The Cisco ACRC course did talk about 'dropped packets'.)

Things that would be nice to have in a "sysadmin degree".  (Lab time
required!)

 * How systems boot up -- a multi-platform view.  There are fundamental
   similarities, and myriad technical differences.  I was fortunate 
   enough to begin with early MS-DOS systems -- you either had a valid
   boot sector and set of system files, or you didn't.  Sun hardware 
   is pretty straight-forward too.  Don't know much about Macs.  Intel
   hardware can be a real joy with the current mix of operating systems
   available:  Unix-like [LILO, grub, whatever BSD uses, Solaris], 
   Windows NT/2000/XP, Windows 95/98/Me (which will toast existing
   partitions if you're not careful during installation).  Booting from
   a network ...
   
   TTBOMK, all systems start execution at some predefined ROM location.
   It's what happens next that get's interesting.

 * Bring a new mail server on-line.  Can you say basic education on
   SPAM prevention (i.e. "no open relays"!)?  Directory management.  
   Lists.  Privacy issues.

 * Jim Bob lost a file.  Basic backup/restore principles and a survey
   of available. 

 * Network problems.  
    - required:  IP on ethernet LAN
       * fundamental wiring:  CAT ratings, IEEE standards, test equipment,
         stranded vs. solid core, building code issues (plenums), cross-over
         cables, grounding
       * Hubs/switches:  MAC addresses, 'managed' vs 'unmanaged', securing
         managed devices, the "repeater-rule", bridges and spanning tree
         (802.1d), VLAN configuration
       * IP:  addressing (network, host, netmask), network classes and
         'private' address blocks, ARP
       * basic network service protocols:  DHCP/BOOTP, NTP, DNS ...
       * routing:  "default route" is sufficient for most configurations,
         router discovery protocols, how does a host decide to ARP for the
         destination IP or the router?  [Survey of route exchange protocols
         (RIP, RIP2, OSPF, IGRP/EIGRP, BGP) and hands-on routing would be an
         advanced course.]

 * Patches.  Change/configuration (and sanity) management.  Available tools.  

 * Installations -- how to automate, and keep consistent.  (It will help with
   those future patching problems.)

 * User account practices.  Legal ramifications.  Working with HR departments.

 * The CEO -- well people skills are just constant practice.

 * Application troubleshooting ... tech support forums ....


... and I could spend a *lot* more time, but it would be best if I got back
to work here.  :-)

- Don

From verso at mac.com  Fri Aug  2 10:48:30 2002
From: verso at mac.com (Kelly Guimont)
Date: Fri, 02 Aug 2002 10:48:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How to explain benefits of Linux for corporate droids?
In-Reply-To: <200208021505.g72F5Jm25002@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <B97013FE.4252%verso@mac.com>

If you have to convince executives, speak their language: money. Give them
information in dollars and cents. Every time the server goes down, it's down
for approximately 15 minutes. During that time, there is zero productivity
in the company. Given that weekly payroll (if you can get that number) is X,
then every time we have to bring the server back up it costs us Y in lost
manhours. Total that up over the course of a typical month where we have to
bring the server up once a week, and you'll see that running windows costs
us Z each month, above and beyond the costs of licensing and hardware
upgrades.
(keep in mind I'm guessing here)

Now consider the new licensing MS is pushing, this 'software as service'
model. They want you to sign a three year contract which does not guarantee
that you will ever see so much as a security patch from them. Are you really
willing to pay them <some exorbitant sum> on spec?

We have another option: Linux. Look here <show them some sort of nice window
manager that makes everything pretty and easy to find>. This is Linux. We
can open Word documents, we can crunch number in excel spreadsheets, we can
create presentations, we can get email and view web pages, and we can
<something specific to the company here>. Not to mention that this system
will also run the <name the new sw for engineering apps here>. This
operating system is free. Fixes come out regularly. There are many resources
on the internet to help find answers to issues, so there is no need to call
someone. And if you need a real live person to assist you, there's probably
someone in the Portland Linux Users Group who has useful information or even
the fix itself. (ok, so I'm going a bit overboard here)

So there you go. With a bit of company related research you should be able
to convince them. I've seen more than one person wet their pants at the
sight of MacOS X since it's unix guts but it's really pretty and does all
the stuff people want a 'real' computer to do (office/photoshop/games).

Hope this helps,
-Kelly

Wookiee.  -The Pulp Fiction Menace

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Fri Aug  2 10:56:59 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 02 Aug 2002 10:56:59 -0700
Subject: Network configuration by hand HOWTO thread (Re: [PLUG] Broadband detection)
In-Reply-To: <200208012310.21620.satimis@writeme.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020801102003.009fbd20@pop.net-yan.com>
	<5.1.1.6.0.20020801144232.00a089f0@pop.net-yan.com>
	<1028207614.8029.704.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
	<200208012310.21620.satimis@writeme.com>
Message-ID: <87ado5ta8k.fsf_-_@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

[ Hopefully, this thread will remain locatable in our search engine... ]

Will someone please post reply containing a breif "HOWTO" for
reconfiguring the networking, first by using a text editor (call it
"editor"), then through the provided GUI interface(s) for Red Hat like
systems?


On a Debian GNU system, you edit "/etc/network/interfaces".  At the
top of the file, you'll find a comment pointing to the man pages:

  man interfaces
  man ifup

The file format is very simple and somewhat self explanatory.  For a
DHCP connection that should come up automaticly at boot, you write:

auto eth0
iface eth0 inet dhcp

That's it.  Now (as root) "ifup eth0" should bring up the interface
and launch the DHCP client.  "ifup" and "ifdown" read the "interfaces"
file, and use the information provided to run the low level commands
that configure the interface (ifconfig) and set up the routing table
(route, or ip route).

For a static IP interface, you'd write something like:

auto eth0
iface eth0 inet static
	address   192.168.0.1
	network   192.168.0.0
	broadcast 192.168.0.255
	netmask   255.255.255.0
        gateway   192.168.0.254

Your other option, again, on a Debian GNU system, is to "aptitude
install etherconf", and let it's debconf driven interface walk you
through configuration.  You can run it again with "dpkg-reconfigure
-plow etherconf".  (man dpkg-reconfigure) If you also install the
"configlets", you'll find a network configuration GUI in the Gnome
control center.


--

the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Fri Aug  2 11:03:50 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 02 Aug 2002 11:03:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Terminal Server...  too many open files?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208012136260.6862-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208012136260.6862-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <8765ytt9x5.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

I think that "lsof" is showing not only open files, but also open
network connections...  It seems to me that they are relevant also
though, since when you write a program, you work with a file handle
for a socket just as for a file.  All I/O is done through file
handles; it's a generic interface.

If you access:

http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/kernel-doc-2.4.18/Documentation/filesystems/proc.txt.gz

... and read that, you'll know a lot more about it.

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Fri Aug  2 11:10:27 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Fri, 2 Aug 2002 11:10:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Something funny going on...
In-Reply-To: <200208020116.g721Gj905312@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>; from flee@aracnet.com on Thu, Aug 01, 2002 at 06:16:44PM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208011310490.15161-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <200208020116.g721Gj905312@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <20020802111027.A6868@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, Aug 01, 2002 at 06:16:44PM -0700, Felix Lee wrote:
> On Thu, 1 Aug 2002, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> > [colink at rock ~]$ perl -V
> > syntax error at /dev/null line 1, near "=="
> > Execution of /dev/null aborted due to compilation errors.
> 
> if /dev/null is a file, then the problem will be evanescent
> because many things will write to /dev/null, so any program
> that relies on /dev/null having null input will have
> unpredictable behavior.
> 
> The answer mentioned everywhere:
>     sudo echo >/dev/null
> is not going to fix any underlying problem.  So the person
> who wrote the answer is either being dumb or is fucking
> around.  If you do find that your problem was that /dev/null
> was an ordinary file, please write the FAQ maintainer and
> have the answer fixed.

I think echo > /dev/null is only supposed to test /dev/null, not fix
it, in order to fix it, you have to delete and recreate the device,
according to this recipe:

  rm /dev/null
  mknod /dev/null c 1 3
  chmod a+rw /dev/null

In any case, at least now I can get around to getting the info I need for
my bug report for mod_perl.

Colin



From rseymour at spamcop.net  Fri Aug  2 11:13:18 2002
From: rseymour at spamcop.net (Richard Seymour)
Date: Fri, 02 Aug 2002 11:13:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A training cooperative?
References: <200208021652.g72Gqo7m025250@franka.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <3D4ACBBE.6090103@spamcop.net>

ptkwt at aracnet.com wrote:


> Then of course the question of 'where' comes up?  Maybe FreeGeek?  They've got
> bunches of machines on a network.


I was just about to pipe in on the "jobs" thread that when you're stuck 
between jobs, check out volunteer opportunities. FREE GEEK, PLUG, K-12 
Linux, and Personal Telco all come to mind as opportunities for people 
to get hands on experience. Here's a suggestion for folks between jobs:

* Figure out how much time you can commit to a volunteer group (on, say, 
a weekly basis). Leave enough time to (a) enjoy your time off, and (b) 
continue your job hunt.

* Contact a group (like those listed above) and offer your services.

* Talk with someone at the group. Explain what you know, what you'd like 
to learn, and what you kind of already know, but need experience in.

* Think about what kind of a project would both look good on your 
resume, and help said organization.

* Sketch out a time line for that project and offer to do it for the 
organization. Make certain that you'll be motivated to do it without the 
incentive of a paycheck.

* Make a backup plan for the organization in case you actually get a job 
mid project.

* Do the project, do it well. Document it. Show other volunteers what 
you did.

* Get a letter of recomendation from the group. Put the reference and 
the work on your resume.

This is a great way to get some hands on experience, plus help out the 
cause.

Another opportunity is to take what you already know and teach it. Think 
about being a speaker for PLUG (regular meetings or advanced topics), or 
coming down to FREE GEEK and offering to teach a class of some sort. 
(Talk to Laurel if you come down.)

FREE GEEK is what I know best, since I work there, so the following 
applies to FG, but can be adapted to other groups as well.

We've been talking about doing a series of seminars that, taken as a 
whole, would form a basis for understanding a broader aspect of system 
administration. For instance on the theme of networking, there could be 
seminars on:

* Boolean logic and binary math (needed for understanding how netmasks work)

* How do IPs work?

* What are the seven layers in the OSI Network Model and what are they for?

* How does DNS work?

* How does DHCP work?

* What about encryption and authentication? A security overview?

* Etc...

Anyone wanting to teach this sort of thing ought to come by FREE GEEK, 
open (currently) noon to eight Tuesday through Saturday, and find out 
how they can help.

Right now, FG has a lot going on, so we need self directed people to 
come in and make this kind of thing happen. There's also a not 
insurmountable, but nevertheless real, scheduling problem given that a 
lot is going on at FG.

Anyway, my point is: if you're stuck between jobs make the most of that 
time. Hunker down and do something you want to do. That's got to be 
better (in at least some ways) than ending up with a job you don't like 
anyway.

:-)


-- 
My! People have a way of coming and going so quickly here!
~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~
    Richard Seymour, the Man Behind the Curtain
CHEEP GEEKS      Anarchy Software       FREE GEEK




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Aug  2 11:28:03 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 2 Aug 2002 11:28:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Local resources for finding Linux/Unix/OS jobs?
In-Reply-To: <B96FE89A.4239%verso@mac.com>
References: <B96FE89A.4239%verso@mac.com>
Message-ID: <200208021128.03959.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I know how you feel. Hell I have a degree in computer science and up 
until the end of March I had been continuously employed as a software 
developer for the last 15 years. Now I don't see any prospects and 
things look pretty hopeless for me at this point. It's not like I 
haven't kept up with the changes either having done C++ and Java for a 
quite a few years now. I've been doing mostly Unix work for most of 
that time but now I'm starting to consider getting into Windows 
programming as their appears to be a number of jobs wanting C++ 
experience with Windows. 

Also .NET skills seem to be highly desirable so I may look at that as 
well. I can't say I really enjoy doing Windows development but I need 
to be able to pay the bills. The other side of the coin is that many 
places want web developers which is something I have never been given 
the chance to do much with since I always got put on the back-end 
server and DB stuff because of my strong Unix background. I got to do 
quite a bit of Java work with CORBA and JDBC because of that. About the 
closest I got to web development was one job I did where we used JSP 
and Java Servlets but now the Java landscape has changed greatly with 
J2EE. I've seen quite a few jobs wanting J2EE but I haven't been able 
to get my foot in the door yet.

In looking at J2EE it's a dream come true to finally have some standard 
APIs for distrubuted systems. Certainly CORBA helped here on past 
projects I worked on too. I've worked on a number of distrubuted 
systems before distributed transaction frameworks and other cool stuff 
existed and so a lot of time was spent building company brewed 
distributed infrastructures for projects. Sometimes this was done with 
simple socket programming sometimes more complex message type 
frameworks were built for this purpose. 

Now the tools are there so it's possible to spend time solving the task 
at hand rather than have to build up the infrastructure first. 
Unfortunately no employers seem to expect to have someone fully trained 
and and so not much if any consideration is give to a resume unless all 
required job skills appear on it. Back before the dot.com bubble 
started to fill I never found in any job I got that I was expected to 
know everything. Yes I had solid Unix and C/C++ development skills and 
all but it was assumed that for some of the other stuff that a 
developer would pick it up as required. Along with my Unix experience I 
became pretty good at programming on Tandem NonStop systems when I 
worked at a place where some parts of the distributed system ran on 
Tandem NonStop systems.

At least with Linux I can play with this some of this stuff for free and 
so lately I've been working with Servlets and JSP again on my own using 
Jakarta-Tomcat. 

Here's hoping for better times (soon),

Tony

From shahms at shahms.com  Fri Aug  2 13:30:32 2002

I finally understand why Microsoft seems to think Palladium is a good
idea: they'll finally be on par with Unix in that you can do everything
your computer is able to do from Windows, but they're getting there in a
typically Microsoftian fashion; rather than increasing the functionality
and usability of Windows, they're reducing the functionality of your
computer to better match that of Windows.  Silly me, this isn't about
copyrights at all, it's about getting Windows to use the computer to the
fullest extent possible!!!

--Shahms

From rsteff at attbi.com  Fri Aug  2 15:00:44 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Fri, 02 Aug 2002 15:00:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Transcription of Q/A sessions following PLUG speaker 
 presentations.
References: <20020802100608.38b87944.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D4B010C.A33C8AC6@attbi.com>

Eli Stair wrote:

> When a presentation is given, someone has the task of making sure the entirety
> is recorded (audio).
<snip>
> I would be willing to do the
> work of recording/transcribing the meeting, and anything else I'm capable of.

I think this is a great idea. I've been in a couple of meetings where a
transcription was made and they were very helpful later on. These would
be great for those who can't make it to the meeting.

There are some technical points of which to be aware. My wife
transcribes interviews captured on audio tape. If you've never done it
before you might be surprised that it turns out to be non-trivial to get
a recording that can be transcribed. Good microphones and their proper
placement are critical. The preferred medium is standard cassette as
opposed to mini cassette. It usually takes my wife 4 hours of typing to
transcribe 1 hour of audio, and that's at 85-95 words per minute. She
uses a special transcription tape player that has foot pedals for
forward and reverse. The playback speed on the machine is adjustable to
deal with low battery situations on the recording machine. There is also
a built-in backspace feature. When you're listening and typing sometimes
you need to stop listening to let your fingers catch up. When you start
listening again, the machine backs up an adjustable amount so you hear
the tail end of the part you just heard. That way you don't miss
something.

BTW, this is not a plug for the use of my wife's services, just some
observations from someone who does it for hire.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Aug  2 15:15:12 2002

Subject: [PLUG] procmail recipe syntax
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208021512460.13328-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  When grouping alternative headers in a procmail recipe, are they
surrounded by parentheses or brackets? That is, would I write:

* ^(To:|Cc:)

  or

* ^[To:|Cc:]

?

  Thanks,

Rich




From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Aug  2 15:39:23 2002

Subject: [PLUG] procmail recipe syntax

On Fri, 2 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   When grouping alternative headers in a procmail recipe, are they
> surrounded by parentheses or brackets? That is, would I write:
> 
> * ^(To:|Cc:)
> 
>   or
> 
> * ^[To:|Cc:]

Rich,

Take a look at the ^TO_ and ^TO shortcuts, detailed in the 
procmailrc(5) man page. My hunch is that you're trying to reinvent 
that wheel :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Aug  2 16:25:36 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 2 Aug 2002 16:25:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] procmail recipe syntax
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208021556060.13655-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208021623440.1220-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Fri, 2 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Thanks, Paul. Either I wasn't aware of that man page or I had
> completely forgotten about it. I kept looking on the Web for
> insight. Sigh.

For any application "foo," you can

* get a list of man pages

  rpm -ql $(rpm -qf $(which foo)) | grep /man/

* get a list of all documentation files

  rpm -qd $(rpm -qf $(which foo))

I love subshells :-)
  
--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Fri Aug  2 02:50:09 2002
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Fri, 2 Aug 2002 09:50:09 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] WYSWYG Programming environments for Linux?
In-Reply-To: <200208021518.g72FIOf25039@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200208021518.g72FIOf25039@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <200208021634.g72GYq412674@smtp.easystreet.com>

On Friday 02 August 2002 03:18 pm, you wrote:
> Hello Linux folkz,
> Could somebody point me to the sources of information on
> graphical Linux environments to program desktop interfaces
> or web interfaces in WYSWYG mode.
> The programming language doesn't matter at this moment.
>
> Many thanks in advance.
> Alex
>
> _______________________________________________

The big 3 are Qt, GTK+, and Kylix.

Qt and GTK+ are free, both are very nice. Kylix is expensive, comes with 
rafts of features the other two don't have, especially for the enterprise. 
Kylix has 30-day free trial, and a free edition, but only for GPL apps, not 
for commercial.

Qt and GTK+  run on different compilers, they are sophisticated widget sets. 
Kylix is complete environment. Kylix and Qt provide their own API. GTK+ uses 
X as its API.

Qt is C++, GTK C, Kylix Delphi. One very cool feature of Qt is translating 
apps into other languages, it does this better than any of the others.

All three can do cross-platform, the new magic mantra is "single source 
code". Their respective Websites are probably the best sources of 
information. A Google search for product reviews turns up some decent 
articles.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder, Bratgrrl Computing
Plain English Spoken Here
www.bratgrrl.com
this message brought to you by Kmail,
on Red Hat Linux 7.2
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~



From dgc at merrivale.dhs.org  Thu Aug  1 19:35:22 2002
From: dgc at merrivale.dhs.org (Dave Clemans)
Date: Thu, 01 Aug 2002 19:35:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix header_checks quandry 
In-Reply-To: Message from Rich Shepard <rshepard@appl-ecosys.com> 
   of "Thu, 01 Aug 2002 17:50:19 PDT." <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208011745230.9492-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <20020802023527.CA878CF9B7@dsl-209-162-216-78.easystreet.com>

One thing that it took me a while to realize; the postfix header check 
matches are case insensitive.  They are also regular expressions; watch out
for '.', etc. characters.

dgc

>   I have a bunch of entries in /etc/postfix/head_checks, some are from the
> postfix web site and some are ones I've added as spam comes in. However,
> legitimate mail (some from the PLUG list, others from other mail lists, and
> some from friends) is also being bounced and I have no idea why.
> 
>   Would anyone be willing to take a look at this file to see what there
> might be responsible for these unintended consequences? In the meantime I've
> deactivated it in /etc/postfix/main.cf. Quite puzzling for someone new to
> running his own mail server and building focused and effective UCE filters.
> (I've already removed the From: localhost at localdomain in case that was
> causing problems.)
> 
> TIA,
> 
> Rich
> 
>

> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

`spamfilter'? I don't see *any* link to "spamfilter". Did you mean
`junkfilter'? Both the "read the README file" and "Download the current
release" links just worked for me. http://www.zer0.org/junkfilter/ redirects
to http://www.zer0.org/junkfilter/ and the README and download links are...

http://www.zer0.org/junkfilter/pkg/current/README
http://www.zer0.org/junkfilter/pkg/junkfilter.tar.gz

Of course, since I've started using spamassassin, I've no use for
junkfilter (although you may learn something by looking at the recipes).

IMO, the best resources are Infinite Ink's tutorial, Jari Aalto's tips
collection, and the `procmail' Mailing List Archives.

Sandy

Yah, style sheet magic...

a               {
                text-decoration:        none;
                }

a:link          {
                color:                  #338855;
                }

a:visited       {
                color:                  #bb6655;
                }

a:active        {
                color:                  #ffffff;
                }

a:hover         {
                color:                  #447766;
                }

a.offsite       {
                }

Sandy

On Fri, 2002-08-02 at 16:54, ptkwt at aracnet.com wrote:

> 
> I tried Best Buy and they say they're out of them - the story I got there is
> that a new model is coming out and they're waiting for that one to become
> available before they stock it again.  
Don't believe everything those guys tell you. The real reason according
to the guys from Sharp on the Z message board was that BestBuy only
signed a contract for a limited quantity and chose not to renew. The new
model is the A300 and is only available in Japan with no US plans as of
yet. Also, it is missing the keyboard which is a huge disadvantage.
(that plus i don't read Japanese)
> 
> Anybody know of anyplace selling these for a decent price?
Amazon has them for $378 if you don't mind mail order which seems to be the best price around.
The Best price price was due to them deciding not to carry them so if
they are gone, you are out of luck I think.
I do highly recommend the unit and i think it is easy to get $400 of use
out of it.

Doug

No, and that's why I decided to save my money and just get a palm.  I love
linux...but I just couldn't afford the linux pda's.  The older palms you
can get for about $100+shipping.  I got the m130 from pcnation.com for
$225 after shipping.  Pretty nice and it does color.  It just doesn't run
linux.  If you can find one that runs linux in that price range power to
you.

Just because it doesn't run linux doesn't mean that you will be locked
into "their" software.  The palm developer's platform is free for
download.  So you can write your own programs or find them on freshmeat.

I hope that helps,
Jason

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Aug  2 21:42:46 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 2 Aug 2002 21:42:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A training cooperative?
In-Reply-To: <200208021652.g72Gqo7m025250@franka.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208022104090.11321-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 2 Aug 2002 ptkwt at aracnet.com wrote:

[snip]
> > I look in the newspapers & online I can't find jobs. People I talk to
> > are out of work & looking, too. It takes money to train yourself,
> > even if it reading books (they have to be obtained) or tinkering with
> > new hardware (they have to be bought). I could take on debt in pursuit
> > of these goals, but it's frightening to owe money when there's no money
> > coming in. I wish I had saved more money when times were flush, but

When times are bad, everyone will have trouble finding work,
over-qualified, under-qualified, or perfect matches.  Companies stop
hiring completely in times like this unless they have a funded project
that absolutely requires they bring someone new on board.  Just like
everyone else, they are afraid of the economic situation and will hold on
to as much cash as possible until they feel more confident in the economy.
It's like a giant game of musical chairs, and those of us who were left
standing when the music stops, lose (at least for the time being).
Evenutally a new game will start, and thats when you need to be ready,
because the first jobs will go to the best qualified and/or those who are
willing to work cheapest, so now is the time to pad the resume with
anything you can.  Self-study courses online, books can be obtained from
libraries (University libraries in particular) and friends, volunteer
work, giving presentations to your local Linux User Group :-) and if you
can afford it, course work at local Universities.  All of these things can
be valuable, some of them will help your resume, some will simply help
your skill set, but either way, they can help you land a job, not just
from the added skills, but also from getting out and meeting people who
might have need of your skills at their day job.

[snip]
> these informal surveys point to an unemployment rate among PLUGers that's
> somewhere in the 30% range.  Now, it's possible that if you're not working
> you're more likely to show up at a PLUG meeting because you've got the time, so
> maybe it's lower, but I'd guess it's at least 15 - 20%. Given the huge loss of

You missed an obvious reason for people to attend, networking!  If you're
out of work, the way to find it is to hang out with alot of people
involved in the type of work you do.  I expect that this may significantly
skew the numbers, though I wouldn't venture to guess by how much.

> capital in the stock market over the last two years (that continues to this day)
> I think it's safe to assume that all the talk of 'recovery' I hear every morning
> on the news is mostly propaganda to keep us from more panic selling. [When the

Actually, I think it is on the up swing (at least for what I do), the
search agents I use on the job boards have gone from no matches for weeks
at a stretch, to an average of at least one possible match each day.  Now
many of these are ridiculous (BSCS + 2 years min. exp., Masters preferred,
Active security clearance required, . . . , $15-$25/hr depending on
experience), but at least jobs are starting to be offered again.

[snip]
> there with time on their hands.  So, while we're waiting for things to improve
> how about setting up some kind of free training cooperative?  People who are
> knowledgable in a programming language or technique could train other people who
> want to learn that language or technique.  A teacher of one class could be a
[snip]

I am interested, though there might be some logistical problems given that
I live in Lebanon.  I even have some teaching experience.  Anyone want to
learn low level programming -- embedded systems, C, assembly, machine
code, ones and zeros.  In the old days, sometimes we didn't have any
zeros, so we had to program using only ones, and we felt lucky that we had
the ones,  . . .   :-)

From m at netpro.to  Fri Aug  2 22:00:45 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri, 2 Aug 2002 22:00:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Odd ping response behavior from private IP addresses
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208022145060.12184-100000@lukem.com>

I noticed something odd today.  There are several private IP addresses
that I'm able to ping from my home cable Internet connection, but the
responses come back from valid public IP addresses for two other cable
Internet users (I'm assuming they're users), but with "Time to live
exceeded" messages.

So for example, I can ping 172.16.1.5 and I'll get:

>From xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx icmp_seq=1 Time to live exceeded
>From xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx icmp_seq=2 Time to live exceeded

And pinging 172.16.1.6 will give me a different public IP:

>From yyy.yyy.yyy.yyy icmp_seq=1 Time to live exceeded
>From yyy.yyy.yyy.yyy icmp_seq=2 Time to live exceeded

Pinging other random private IP addresses results in responses from one of
these two computers.  I'm behind a firewall doing NAT for an internal
192.168.1.0/24 network, so the 172.16.x.x addresses shouldn't respond at
all (in theory).
Any ideas what's going on here?  Does someone on the cable network outside
my firewall have their boxes/routers misconfigured to answer for these
addresses?
Thanks,
~M

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Aug  2 22:39:36 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 2 Aug 2002 22:39:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Odd ping response behavior from private IP addresses
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208022145060.12184-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208022145060.12184-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <200208022239.36764.aschlemm@attbi.com>

It may be that the cable network has devices on it that are using 
private IPs or something. I've had on occasion IPs from 10.x.x.x/8 hit 
my firewall. I have my firewall setup to silently drop all incoming 
packets from private IPs as listed in RFC1918. I'm also careful to make 
sure my firewall will not route any private IPs to the outside network 
as well.

Tony

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Aug  2 22:46:44 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 2 Aug 2002 22:46:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Odd ping response behavior from private IP addresses
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208022145060.12184-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208022237001.11507-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 2 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

[snip]
> Internet users (I'm assuming they're users), but with "Time to live
> exceeded" messages.
[snip]
> Pinging other random private IP addresses results in responses from one of
> these two computers.  I'm behind a firewall doing NAT for an internal
> 192.168.1.0/24 network, so the 172.16.x.x addresses shouldn't respond at
> all (in theory).
[snip]

I think you are misunderstanding what is going on here, the "time to live
exceeded" means that the packets were being routed, but weren't able to
reach their destination within the maximum number of hops that were
specified by your computer when the packets were created (quite likely
because there is no such destination), sometimes, depending on how the
routers are (mis)configured, your packet may simply play ping-pong among
the routers until the TTL is exceeded and a response is generated back to
you.  As far as anyone being misconfigured, I think that you are
forgetting that you are on a private network (your ISP's), so they can
legitimately assign use and route packets for these IP blocks anywhere on
their network, they simply should not be forwarding these packets to the
internet at large.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From: dalefv at k-com.net (Dale F. Victor)
Date: Fri, 02 Aug 2002 23:45:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A training cooperative?
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208022221330.8412-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <3D4B7BF8.25D51860@k-com.net>

Hello!

I will probably get a lot of flack from this, but here is a thought that
works in another industry. There is surely a lot of tallent out there,
everyone has a computer (in this list at least) and knows how to hook
them together - so what would be the matter with forming a group and
getting some work and doing it. I am not in the computer industry, I am
a cabinet maker I have made a living from it for over 30 years, and in
times like these there is an opportunity. The problem becomes how do you
take advantage of it, how do you see it, and how do you develop it. With
all the talent out there there should be a project (s) that needs to be
done, there has to be a way to get paid to do it. I do not know the
industry well enought to be able to give a firm direction, but there has
to be one - how about the gov't and doing something with security or
some project that someone in Washington wants to see worked on. 

Now I hear that people want to get learning under their belts so they
can work for someone else, this is a good thing, but it seems to me that
you are all competing against each other for the same work, education is
a good thing but there is time to make some bucks. How about doing this
together - as a group.

Ok now you can start a long list of messages calling me everything you
want, but I see this as an oportunity - I am just not in a position to
do anything but build cabinets and furniture for you guys once you get
rich enought to afford it. 
  Food for at least a comment,

Dale

> > > > are out of work & looking, too. It takes money to train yourself,
> > > > even if it reading books (they have to be obtained) or tinkering with
> > > > new hardware (they have to be bought). I could take on debt in pursuit
> > > > of these goals, but it's frightening to owe money when there's no money
> > > > coming in. I wish I had saved more money when times were flush, but
> >
> > When times are bad, everyone will have trouble finding work,
> > over-qualified, under-qualified, or perfect matches.  Companies stop
> > hiring completely in times like this unless they have a funded project
> > that absolutely requires they bring someone new on board.  Just like
> > everyone else, they are afraid of the economic situation and will hold on
> > to as much cash as possible until they feel more confident in the economy.
> > It's like a giant game of musical chairs, and those of us who were left
> > standing when the music stops, lose (at least for the time being).
> > Evenutally a new game will start, and thats when you need to be ready,
> > because the first jobs will go to the best qualified and/or those who are
> > willing to work cheapest, so now is the time to pad the resume with
> > anything you can.  Self-study courses online, books can be obtained from
> > libraries (University libraries in particular) and friends, volunteer
> > work, giving presentations to your local Linux User Group :-) and if you
> > can afford it, course work at local Universities.  All of these things can
> > be valuable, some of them will help your resume, some will simply help
> > your skill set, but either way, they can help you land a job, not just
> > from the added skills, but also from getting out and meeting people who
> > might have need of your skills at their day job.

From satimis at writeme.com  Sat Aug  3 00:25:10 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Sat, 03 Aug 2002 15:25:10 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] How to explain benefits of Linux for corporate
  droids?
In-Reply-To: <B97013FE.4252%verso@mac.com>
References: <200208021505.g72F5Jm25002@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20020803135045.029f4b88@pop.net-yan.com>

Hi Folks,

It is my interest to follow this thread.  Although to push Linux overtaking 
the market share of Windoz is not my mission , it is always my pleasure to 
introduce this OS to my acquaintance.

Windoz has been existing for a prolonged time prior to Linux giving its 
birth.  If I am wrong please correct me.  Windoz OS has already been deep 
rooted in most people's mind which is not easy to erase.

I have been living/jumping between Linux and Windoz worlds.  This is not my 
wish but under compulsion of necessity.  I want to migrate to Linux 
completely.  Pushing Linux to business we have to breakthrough two 
hurdles,  A) Adminstration and  B) Technology.  I shall explain in seriatim 
hereinunder their details according to my the then experience.

A) Adminstration
To convince the decision-maker (executive) to consider switching to Linux 
OS is almost a miracle, if not completely impossible.  Most people are 
reluctant to learn, dislike us, the Linux folks, possessing of exploring 
character.  He may only possess some basic know-how on Linux.  There are 
two uncertainties laid before him.  a) Can I catch up this new 
technology???  b) Can my technology absorbed thereafter be on top of other 
staffs maintaining a higher potential???.  He is worrying his position 
insecure on turning to a new world.  He needs to stay in his position 
firmly until retire without much struggling.  Another obstacle comes from 
staffs.  They hold the same attitude as the decision-make.  They want to 
stay in their job peacefully enjoying their life, only performing 9 to 5 
routine duty.  The resistance created by the decision-make reinforced by 
their staffs is not easy to overcome, even the boss.  If we try to convince 
them from cash angle they won't listen to you.  Reality in life plays the 
most important role.

B) Technology
Most applications run on Windoz.  I am not talking about Office, PhotoShop, 
Internet browser, email, etc.  We have plenty substitutes in Linux 
world.  Most, if not 100%, CAD applications for Architect, Mechanical 
Engineering, Chemical Engineering, graphics development, etc. could not run 
on Linux, even the compilers.  They are designed to run on Windoz.  VMware, 
Win4Lin, Crossover, Wine, etc. can't help.  Besides it does not bear much 
sense to pay double licenses, one to Windoz and another to those simulator 
developers, because they need Windoz to run on them except Wine.  Why not 
go back to Windoz PC ?  Wine is a wonderful tool but unfortunately still 
under development.

The above are my observation drawn from my past experience.  I don't repel 
other folks' opinion.  But I do hope that some folks on the list can shed 
me some light how to overcome such barriers which I encounter periodically.

Stephen Liu



At 10:48 AM 8/2/2002 -0700, Kelly Guimont wrote:
>If you have to convince executives, speak their language: money. Give them
>information in dollars and cents. Every time the server goes down, it's down
>for approximately 15 minutes. During that time, there is zero productivity
>in the company. Given that weekly payroll (if you can get that number) is X,
>then every time we have to bring the server back up it costs us Y in lost
>manhours. Total that up over the course of a typical month where we have to
>bring the server up once a week, and you'll see that running windows costs
>us Z each month, above and beyond the costs of licensing and hardware
>upgrades.
>(keep in mind I'm guessing here)
>
>Now consider the new licensing MS is pushing, this 'software as service'
>model. They want you to sign a three year contract which does not guarantee
>that you will ever see so much as a security patch from them. Are you really
>willing to pay them <some exorbitant sum> on spec?
>
>We have another option: Linux. Look here <show them some sort of nice window
>manager that makes everything pretty and easy to find>. This is Linux. We
>can open Word documents, we can crunch number in excel spreadsheets, we can
>create presentations, we can get email and view web pages, and we can
><something specific to the company here>. Not to mention that this system
>will also run the <name the new sw for engineering apps here>. This
>operating system is free. Fixes come out regularly. There are many resources
>on the internet to help find answers to issues, so there is no need to call
>someone. And if you need a real live person to assist you, there's probably
>someone in the Portland Linux Users Group who has useful information or even
>the fix itself. (ok, so I'm going a bit overboard here)
>
>So there you go. With a bit of company related research you should be able
>to convince them. I've seen more than one person wet their pants at the
>sight of MacOS X since it's unix guts but it's really pretty and does all
>the stuff people want a 'real' computer to do (office/photoshop/games).
>
>Hope this helps,
>-Kelly
>Chewie Rocky Horror is a hairy mofo. What's a brother gonna do? He's a
>Wookiee.  -The Pulp Fiction Menace
>
>

From m at netpro.to  Sat Aug  3 10:20:34 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 10:20:34 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Odd ping response behavior from private IP addresses
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208022237001.11507-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208031017390.29693-100000@lukem.com>

On Fri, 2 Aug 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:

> I think you are misunderstanding what is going on here, the "time to live
> exceeded" means that the packets were being routed, but weren't able to
> reach their destination within the maximum number of hops that were
> specified by your computer when the packets were created (quite likely
> because there is no such destination), sometimes, depending on how the
> routers are (mis)configured, your packet may simply play ping-pong among
> the routers until the TTL is exceeded and a response is generated back to
> you.  As far as anyone being misconfigured, I think that you are
> forgetting that you are on a private network (your ISP's), so they can
> legitimately assign use and route packets for these IP blocks anywhere on
> their network, they simply should not be forwarding these packets to the
> internet at large.

Gotcha.  So, I'm assuming that one box has a route setup for 172.16.1.5,
for example, that points to the other box, but the other box has the same
route pointing back to the first box?
~M




From dealy at deatech.com  Sat Aug  3 10:19:24 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 10:19:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] How to explain benefits of Linux for corporate  droids?
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020803135045.029f4b88@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208030907070.13208-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sat, 3 Aug 2002, Stephen Liu wrote:

[snip]
> Windoz has been existing for a prolonged time prior to Linux giving its
> birth.  If I am wrong please correct me.  Windoz OS has already been deep
> rooted in most people's mind which is not easy to erase.

This really isn't correct, from the user perspective, Linux is really just
another version of UNIX, which predates the first release of Windows by
almost 15 years, and predates the first version of Windows that the public
actually heard of (version 3.0) by almost 20 years.  It's true that the
"Linux" implementation of UNIX came later, but only a couple years after
Windows 3.0 was released.

[snip]
> A) Adminstration
> To convince the decision-maker (executive) to consider switching to Linux
> OS is almost a miracle, if not completely impossible.  Most people are
> reluctant to learn, dislike us, the Linux folks, possessing of exploring
> character.  He may only possess some basic know-how on Linux.  There are
> two uncertainties laid before him.  a) Can I catch up this new
> technology???  b) Can my technology absorbed thereafter be on top of other
> staffs maintaining a higher potential???.  He is worrying his position
>[snip]
> their staffs is not easy to overcome, even the boss.  If we try to convince
> them from cash angle they won't listen to you.  Reality in life plays the
> most important role.

The reality of life in the hi-tech world is that change is the only
constant, no one can afford to simply sit and wait for retirement while
not bothering to learn anything new, unless they want to retire alot
earlier than they were planning.  Unless these people keep learning, and
regularly make the best possible technical choices for their companies,
(regardless of what products they would like to use or feel comfortable
with) they run the risk of leaving their company behind the competition,
and in business that is usually the begining of the end.  This isn't going
to convince these people to change, the reality is the odds favor their
company falling behind and possibly failing unless/until there is some
employee turnover and new people who are more open to better solutions
come on board.

> B) Technology
> Most applications run on Windoz.  I am not talking about Office, PhotoShop,
> Internet browser, email, etc.  We have plenty substitutes in Linux
> world.  Most, if not 100%, CAD applications for Architect, Mechanical
> Engineering, Chemical Engineering, graphics development, etc. could not run
> on Linux, even the compilers.  They are designed to run on Windoz.  VMware,
> Win4Lin, Crossover, Wine, etc. can't help.  Besides it does not bear much

I am not sure what you mean by can't help, between these environments, you
can run virtually any program ever written for windows.

> sense to pay double licenses, one to Windoz and another to those simulator
> developers, because they need Windoz to run on them except Wine.  Why not
> go back to Windoz PC ?  Wine is a wonderful tool but unfortunately still
> under development.

While you are probably right for people who only run one or two
applications at a time, and for whom word processing is the bulk of
their work, it actually makes far more sense to use the above approaches
such as VMware for any serious power user.  Every version of Windows and
most of it's applications are notoriously unstable, and typically when
anything goes wrong it takes the computer down, losing everything that was
going on at the time.  Though many managers don't realize it, problems
like this can easily waste 10% of a power user's working time.  Each crash
takes down all applications, the user must wait for the reboot, startup
all the applications, recover the lost/damaged files, reenter any lost
data, etc.  By using Linux as the base and something like VMware
(preferably running only one application in each virtual machine), the
computer stays up, and if an application crashes the user can keep right
on working on other applications while the virtual machine is rebooting.
I didn't even address in the above, the case of people running
computationally intensive programs on their computer, many types of
analysis software might take hours to run, and unless the program saves
it's state on a regular basis, when the computer crashes, it must start
over again from the begining, resulting in long delays for the completion
of the program.

It should be noted that the applications you were referencing above,
are the types of programs used primarily by heavy duty scientific and
engineering types, and these are exactly the kind of people and software
packages that are most likely to crash a Windows box and therefore will
have the greatest amount of wasted time.  Coincidentally, these people are
usually among the most expensive people on the payroll, so the added cost
of a license for VMware or other products, really shouldn't even be a
consideration once you look at how much time they will waste from not
using it or similar products/approaches.  Based on my personal experience
with Windows crashes and the time I save using VMware (which I have been
using since before the 1.0 release), I would estimate that it paid for
itself and the time I had to invest in getting it and the virtual machines
setup and configured, in less than one month.  If I hadn't had to spend
time setting up virtual machines and installing Windows on them, I think
it would have paid for itself in less than a week, and this doesn't even
touch on money/time saved by other capabilities that it provides which you
can't do in any other environment.

Based on my experience, for any computer user doing anything more serious
than word processing, it makes MORE sense (both from a time and financial
perspective) to run their Windows software on a Linux platform in some
sort of virtual or emulated environment than it does to run it on a
standard Windows based computer.  Of course if they are only doing word
processing, OpenOffice and Linux are alot cheaper and every bit as stable
as Windows and MS-Word.

NOTE: I am not claiming OpenOffice is stable here, only that it is no less
stable than MS-Word running on Windows.  The last time I used MS-Word
(just over a year ago) it crashed on me four times in two days, despite
the fact that the box had just arrived from Dell with Win 2000, MS Office
XP, and Norton anti-virus preinstalled.  No other software products
were installed on the machine, and only MS-Word was actually running at
the time of each of the crashes.

FWIW.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.

From dealy at deatech.com  Sat Aug  3 11:02:00 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 11:02:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Odd ping response behavior from private IP addresses
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208031017390.29693-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208031051200.13406-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sat, 3 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

> On Fri, 2 Aug 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
>
> > I think you are misunderstanding what is going on here, the "time to live
> > exceeded" means that the packets were being routed, but weren't able to
> > reach their destination within the maximum number of hops that were
> > specified by your computer when the packets were created (quite likely
> > because there is no such destination), sometimes, depending on how the
> > routers are (mis)configured, your packet may simply play ping-pong among
> > the routers until the TTL is exceeded and a response is generated back to
[snip]
> Gotcha.  So, I'm assuming that one box has a route setup for 172.16.1.5,
> for example, that points to the other box, but the other box has the same
> route pointing back to the first box?

Possibly, though I think it's more likely they each have a default routing
configuration that in essence says something like: if I don't have a
defined route for a given IP address/block, send it to router "x" in
case it has one.  Router "x" may in turn send it to router "y" and so on
through all the routers in a continuous loop over and over until the TTL
is exceeded.  Of course if there are only two routers, they would just
bounce it back and forth.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sat Aug  3 12:10:54 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 12:10:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sound - Creative Labs SB
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031155360.24165-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Hi Pluggers,

I've installed a Creative Labs SB Live soundcard but when I run mplayer or
xmms I still get errors such as "No Audio". The steps I took during
installation were:

1. recompiled kernel with SB Live module (emu10k1)
2. modconf'd SB Live module (success)
3. modprobe'd SB Live module (success)

Does anyone know the next step to take in getting sound support? Any
ideas?

PS:

When I try "cat demo.mp3 > /dev/audio" I get hissing output from the
speakers.

When I reboot, the card is detected correctly:
 Creative EMU10K1 PCI Audio Driver, version 0.18, 10:35:55 Aug  3 2002
 PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:0f.0
 emu10k1: EMU10K1 rev 7 model 0x8064 found, IO at 0xe000-0xe01f, IRQ 11
 ac97_codec: AC97 Audio codec, id: 0x454d:0x4328 (Unknown)
 emu10k1: SBLive! 5.1 card detected

Thanks!

Tyler




From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sat Aug  3 12:44:28 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 12:44:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sound - Creative Labs SB
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031155360.24165-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031229020.24165-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Some more details on my effort to get sound working:

I ran aumixer and turned up the volume.

Speaking into the microphone seems to echo back through the speakers
properly, however when I record my voice through the microphone I only get
static and hissing:

$ dd bs=8k count=4 </dev/audio >sample.au
$ cat sample.au > /dev/audio


Xmms still returns the error "Can't Open Audio" also... Any ideas?

Tyler

> xmms I still get errors such as "No Audio". The steps I took during
> installation were:
>

> 2. modconf'd SB Live module (success)
> 3. modprobe'd SB Live module (success)
>
> Does anyone know the next step to take in getting sound support? Any
> ideas?

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Aug  3 12:55:51 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 12:55:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sound - Creative Labs SB
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031155360.24165-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208031252490.26039-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 3 Aug 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

> Hi Pluggers,
> 
> I've installed a Creative Labs SB Live soundcard but when I run
> mplayer or xmms I still get errors such as "No Audio". The steps I
> took during installation were:
> 
> 1. recompiled kernel with SB Live module (emu10k1)
> 2. modconf'd SB Live module (success)
> 3. modprobe'd SB Live module (success)
> 
> Does anyone know the next step to take in getting sound support? Any
> ideas?

Did you update /etc/modules.conf? E.g.,

  alias sound-slot-0 emu10k1

I'm not sure what other module aliases have to be added...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sat Aug  3 13:44:38 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 13:44:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Transcription of Q/A sessions following PLUG speaker 
 presentations.
In-Reply-To: <3D4B010C.A33C8AC6@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208031006460.29132-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Fri, 2 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Eli Stair wrote:
>
> > When a presentation is given, someone has the task of making sure the entirety
> > is recorded (audio).
> <snip>
> > I would be willing to do the
> > work of recording/transcribing the meeting, and anything else I'm capable of.
>
> I think this is a great idea. I've been in a couple of meetings where a
> transcription was made and they were very helpful later on. These would
> be great for those who can't make it to the meeting.
>
> There are some technical points of which to be aware. My wife
> transcribes interviews captured on audio tape. If you've never done it
> before you might be surprised that it turns out to be non-trivial to get
> a recording that can be transcribed. Good microphones and their proper
> placement are critical. The preferred medium is standard cassette as
> opposed to mini cassette. It usually takes my wife 4 hours of typing to
> transcribe 1 hour of audio, and that's at 85-95 words per minute.

I think what Richard is proposing would be overkill for what we need.
If someone were to take notes on the Q&A at the end of meetings -- something
we supposedly learn to do in college -- & publish those, that would be
sufficient. After all, the accounts of the philosopher Wittgenstein's
lectures were recorded by people who were not trained professionals
like Richard's wife.

David Mandel used to keep & publish minutes for the PLUG meetings back
in 1995-97. Something like this is easily doable, & could be published
on the website. I do have an example online of this on the PLUG web site --
http://www.pdxlinux.org/index.php/meeting/letter14May1998.

Geoff





From rkurth at starband.net  Sat Aug  3 16:21:17 2002
From: rkurth at starband.net (Richard Kurth)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 16:21:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Help with finding hostid
Message-ID: <1326044040.20020803162117@starband.net>

Hello plug,

My server that is running RedHat version 6.1 does not have the program on
it that will get you the hostid . It says command not found. I have
done a search for it but it does not seam to be on the server. The man
page is not on the server ether. Is there someplace that I can download it.
Or is there another command that will get me the same info that hostid
does. gethostid is not on the server ether

  

-- 
Best regards,
 Richard                          mailto:rkurth at starband.net




From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sat Aug  3 16:20:19 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 16:20:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Help with finding hostid
In-Reply-To: <1326044040.20020803162117@starband.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031614490.24810-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

"hostid" is one of the GNU shell utilities. On Debian it is available in
the shellutils package. On RH it is available in the sh-utils rpm, for
example at:

http://at.rpmfind.net/opsys/linux/RPM/sh-utils.html

It doesn't seem likely this utility would be missing though...


Tyler

Two questions for the list's hardware hackers:

When I boot up, my dvd/cdrom drive yields this error:

hdd: no response (status = 0x80), resetting drive
hdd: no response (status = 0x80)

Also pressing the "eject" button on the drive doesn't do anything, yet the
light on the drive is on, indicating power. When I boot into Windows,
the drive isn't recognized either. Any ideas whats wrong with
this DVD drive? I just bought it at Fry's a few months ago...

Also one of my fans sometimes starts making a buzzing racket. When you
strike it forcefully it stops buzzing, but this gets old after a while.
Are there any permanent measures that can be taken to hush up this fan?

Thanks,

Tyler

From lemming at attbi.com  Sat Aug  3 17:16:14 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (lemming at attbi.com)
Date: Sun, 04 Aug 2002 00:16:14 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Dying DVD drive / irksome fan
Message-ID: <20020804001614.SFKP19356.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc57>

Tyler writes:
> Two questions for the list's hardware hackers:
> 
> When I boot up, my dvd/cdrom drive yields
> this error:
> 
> hdd: no response (status = 0x80), resetting drive
> hdd: no response (status = 0x80)
> 
> Also pressing the "eject" button on the drive
> doesn't do anything, yet the light on the drive is
> on, indicating power. When I boot into Windows,
> the drive isn't recognized either. Any ideas
> whats wrong with this DVD drive? I just bought it
> at Fry's a few months ago...

Have you checked all the cables.  Resetting them may
help.  Though the non-eject symptom doesn't bode well.

> Also one of my fans sometimes starts making a
> buzzing racket. When you strike it forcefully it
> stops buzzing, but this gets old after a while.
> Are there any permanent measures that can be
> taken to hush up this fan?

Sounds like something is brushing up against the fan.
Perhaps a DVD cable?  If it's something that is brushing
against the fan, easy to fix.  If not, it may mean a
bearing is going which means the fan should be replaced.
 They're easy to fix and you don't need to buy an entire
replacement power supply.

-Mark



From eli.stair.lists at attbi.com  Sat Aug  3 14:17:28 2002
From: eli.stair.lists at attbi.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 17:17:28 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Dying DVD drive / irksome fan
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031620250.24810-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031620250.24810-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20020803171728.41589b9a.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>

> When I boot up, my dvd/cdrom drive yields this error:
> 
> hdd: no response (status = 0x80), resetting drive
> hdd: no response (status = 0x80)
> 
> Also pressing the "eject" button on the drive doesn't do anything, yet the
> light on the drive is on, indicating power. When I boot into Windows,
> the drive isn't recognized either. Any ideas whats wrong with
> this DVD drive? I just bought it at Fry's a few months ago...

If the drive is seen by the bios, but it won't eject even before an OS takes
over, it's toast.  That error message is for your primary IDE HD though, 0x80.
 
> Also one of my fans sometimes starts making a buzzing racket. When you
> strike it forcefully it stops buzzing, but this gets old after a while.
> Are there any permanent measures that can be taken to hush up this fan?

If it stops when you whack it, it's probably your case fan.  If you're handy
with a soldering iron you could buy a new one for ~$3 and replace it yourself.
Or, buy a new PS for ~$15-30 depending on type and wattage.  Do yourself a 
favor and fix it somehow before it stops altogether and you flame out :)

/eli



From m at netpro.to  Sat Aug  3 17:23:11 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 17:23:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Show 'em Knoppix! (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208031722540.10053-100000@lukem.com>


---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 10:45:47 -0700
From: Dennis Kibbe <dennisk at sahuaro.f2s.com>
Reply-To: plug-discuss at lists.plug.phoenix.az.us
To: plug-discuss at lists.plug.phoenix.az.us
Subject: Show 'em Knoppix!

So, your over at a buddy's place on a Saturday night having a few brews and
pizza, when he asks you about Linux.

You pull out a CD, insert it into HIS computer and within two minutes he's
jivin' to some tunes and exploring the KDE3 desktop - dazzled by all the eye
candy! You leave him the CD, of course, so he can explore Open Office 1.01,
GIMP 1.2, Bluefish, Mozilla, Python, WINE, and lots more. And the next day
he's bragging 'cause he's running Linux, too!

What Knoppix is, is a Linux distro that runs entirely from the CD and a file
system created on a RAM disk nothing is put on the hard drive nor is the
installed OS disturbed at all.

This isn't new, of course, but what makes Knoppix different is that it is a
lot faster that SuSE LiveEval and much more modern than DemoLinux.

Lots and lots of current packages (over 900) lets you explore KOfiice, Open
Office, OCR software, scanners and digital cameras, development languages
like Python and KDevelop, too. Even if you run another distro now you can
explore some packages you before actullay installing them on your computer -
maybe Karbon 14 (vector graphics) or Scribus (DTP).

Knoppix is internationalized, too. Click the flag on the right side of the
panel to switch the keyboard from English to German to French!

And with lots of eye candy (less that a second after booting there's a
graphic) it dazzles!

Knoppix is useful for checking out the hardware before installing a distro
that has less thorough hardware detection.

Anyway, I think you get the picture. Knoppix is what I'm using to show off
Linux at its best!

You can find Knoppix at http://www.knopper.net/knoppix/ . There is a link at
the top of the page to the English language page, if you must. <g>


Dennis Kibbe
PS - Sorry, I'll in my "Madison Avenue" mode. <g>
________________________________________________
See http://PLUG.phoenix.az.us/navigator-mail.shtml if your mail doesn't post to the list quickly and you use Netscape to write mail.

PLUG-discuss mailing list  -  PLUG-discuss at lists.plug.phoenix.az.us
http://lists.PLUG.phoenix.az.us/mailman/listinfo/plug-discuss




From eli.stair.lists at attbi.com  Sat Aug  3 14:23:25 2002
From: eli.stair.lists at attbi.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Sat, 3 Aug 2002 17:23:25 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Dying DVD drive / irksome fan
In-Reply-To: <20020803171728.41589b9a.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031620250.24810-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
	<20020803171728.41589b9a.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020803172325.3b6dad54.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>

Come to think of it, after having re-read your problem, and my own response...
Check to see if you possibly have both your IDE hard disk and your IDE DVD drive
on the same cable, and both set to master.

Generally if that happens, nothing will work, but depending on the hard drive
it will sometimes take over and bump off the other device.  Just something
to check while you're in there.

/eli

On Sat, 3 Aug 2002 17:17:28 -0400

> > > work of recording/transcribing the meeting, and anything else I'm capable of.
> >
> > I think this is a great idea. I've been in a couple of meetings where a
> > transcription was made and they were very helpful later on. These would
> > be great for those who can't make it to the meeting.
> >
> > There are some technical points of which to be aware. My wife
> > transcribes interviews captured on audio tape. If you've never done it
> > before you might be surprised that it turns out to be non-trivial to get
> > a recording that can be transcribed. Good microphones and their proper
> > placement are critical. The preferred medium is standard cassette as
> > opposed to mini cassette. It usually takes my wife 4 hours of typing to
> > transcribe 1 hour of audio, and that's at 85-95 words per minute.
> 
> I think what Richard is proposing would be overkill for what we need.
> If someone were to take notes on the Q&A at the end of meetings -- something
> we supposedly learn to do in college -- & publish those, that would be
> sufficient. After all, the accounts of the philosopher Wittgenstein's
> lectures were recorded by people who were not trained professionals
> like Richard's wife.
> 
> David Mandel used to keep & publish minutes for the PLUG meetings back
> in 1995-97. Something like this is easily doable, & could be published
> on the website. I do have an example online of this on the PLUG web site --
> http://www.pdxlinux.org/index.php/meeting/letter14May1998.
> 
> Geoff
> 
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Their ability to lend out space/equipment may therefore be limited to that
arena. Their rules re: distributing equipment is certainly strict in that
regard.

From hapibeli at save-net.com  Sun Aug  4 04:34:17 2002
From: hapibeli at save-net.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: 04 Aug 2002 07:34:17 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] SECURITY
Message-ID: <1028460859.2519.19.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I've been reading ,"Homeland Insecurity" by Charles C. Mann in the
September issue of the Atlantic magazine. He quotes much of of Bruce
Schneier's work from Schneier's books and his Crypto-Gram newsletter.
Enlightening, and darkly humorous as the antics of our government and
corporate security wardens are assessed. 
 An interesting sidebar speaks to insurance companies and their current
and future roles in forcing security on corporate if not government
activities, much the same way that I've read of the insurance industry
forcing environmental protection as its losses mount due to climate
change and cleanup bills mount.
To quote a young and bright co-worker of mine," Quality is insurance"
Mum's the word, Dirk

I just quit using Windows and that was that.  What are these problems
you have that require M$ stuff.  I also hate to mention it, there are
products that allow one to run M$ apps on Linux.  I think they are nice
parlor tricks, but I have no need for them.  

If the admin tools get any easier in linux any Click and Drool Fool
could admin it.  Do I really want a Click and Drool Fool adminning my
machines?   No. It is my experience that badly adminned M$ servers are
the biggest part of M$s problems.  They have a bunch of somewhat trained
monkeys adminning the servers of the world.  How many M$ Certified
admins have I heard say after 6 months of Linux fun say'  "Darn, I know
more about tcp/ip than I ever would have learned in M$."

I want admins that know the underlying system, not which button turns on
dhcp.

From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Aug  4 15:59:17 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun, 04 Aug 2002 15:59:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How to explain benefits of Linux for corporate
  droids?
In-Reply-To: <20020803100259.72800504.mike@linuxlink.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020803135045.029f4b88@pop.net-yan.com>
 <200208021505.g72F5Jm25002@gate.daniloff.com>
 <5.1.1.6.0.20020803135045.029f4b88@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020804154658.00b54f08@mail.localnet.dimstar.net>

The "golden app" that I'm looking for, is a replacement for Quicken/MS 
Money. I've tried GNU Cash, and a couple of others. GNU Cash comes closest, 
but no cigar... yet.

The features I *NEED* in a personal financial application that aren't 
available yet in anything that runs under Linux are:

1> Prints wallet checks. These are the standard, three to a page checks 
that work with both Quicken and MS Money. I looked at the check printing in 
the latest GNU Cash. There wasn't any way to save my settings from session 
to session, and no pre-made template for my most common of check format.

2> Connects to my bank and downloads the current balance and what has 
cleared since the last connection. Sorry folks, viewing the information in 
a web browser and manually comparing that with what I have in GNU Cash just 
doesn't cut it.

It'd also be nice if I could place SimCity and/or The Sims in Linux, but 
those aren't required. I only play them once in a great while.

Anyway, I am just not willing to give up the extra time I have to give up 
when I'm not using MS Money. In this case, Linux would cost me more in lost 
productivity. Yes, Windows is better in this instance, at least for my 
purposes.

Linux is great for my servers, where I literally run them and they just work.
