>I just quit using Windows and that was that.  What are these problems
>you have that require M$ stuff.  I also hate to mention it, there are
>products that allow one to run M$ apps on Linux.  I think they are nice

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sun Aug  4 16:16:40 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (karlheg at pdxlinux.org)
Date: 04 Aug 2002 16:16:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Those Woody CD's: Some help getting it installed.
Message-ID: <87ofcigqp3.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Don't judge a book by it's cover, folks.

The quickest way to get started is to not install any device drivers
at all during the installation.  You pretty much just keep pressing
the Enter key.  Don't worry about getting your network up, etc. until
after the initial reboot.  Everything it needs to get the base system
off the CD onto the hard drive is present.  You don't have to do any
device detection at all at this stage.

Be sure and put the CD backin the drive as soon as it is done
rebooting... and after the initial reboot, during "base-config" (which
you can run again later if you like), tell it not to use the "security
patches" site, but jot down the URL so you can add it to
"sources.list" later on... by running "apt-setup" then.  (hint: try
typing "apt" and pushing TAB to see the completion list.)

First thing you do after logging in as "root":

  # apt-get install discover aptitude

That will pull in "discover", the hardware detection program, along
with "aptitude", the wonderful new package manager TUI.  "discover"
should run after it's installed, via "/etc/init.d/discover start".

If you've got a modem and need a PPP connection, and you did not
choose the "dialup system" task, then try running:

  # apt-get install ppp pppconfig

OR

  # apt-get install pppoe pppoeconf

... if you've got cable or DSL using PPPOE rather than bridged mode.
(will someone please jump in if I'm wrong here?  My DSL box is in
bridged mode.)  "diald" is also available, and should be easy to
configure, since it has been debconfiscated quite nicely.

Once you've got a network connection of some kind and have run
"apt-setup" to add the security site and some other extra sources, you
can run "aptitude" and choose what you would like installed.

The apt URI for Openoffice.org is:

# Openoffice.org (mirror at University of Mississippi)
#
deb     http://www.phy.olemiss.edu/openoffice/ testing main contrib
deb-src http://www.phy.olemiss.edu/openoffice/ testing main contrib
deb     http://www.phy.olemiss.edu/openoffice/ unstable main contrib
deb-src http://www.phy.olemiss.edu/openoffice/ unstable main contrib

... and for LTSP it is:

# LTSP -- Linux Terminal Server Project
#
deb http://termserv.berlios.de/debian stable main non-free

You can find Blackdown (Sun) Java at:

# Java from blackdown.org  (Sun Java 2)
#
deb ftp://ftp.tux.org/pub/java/debian woody non-free


Don't forget to add the security site as well!

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sun Aug  4 17:18:59 2002

From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Aug  4 17:28:45 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun, 04 Aug 2002 17:28:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RedHat 7.3 MD5 Sums
In-Reply-To: <773759948.1028506740714.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020804172630.0249fa90@mail.localnet.dimstar.net>

Redhat had to respin the ISOs due to copyright issues in one or more 
packages. The original ISOs have different MD5 checksums.

Personal opinion... Redhat should increment some version indication when 
they do this. It causes much confusion when two different sets of CDs are 
both "Redhat Linux 7.3".

At 05:18 PM 8/4/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>Does anyone know why there would be two sets of ISOs for RedHat 7.3?

From revans at e-z.net  Sun Aug  4 17:44:42 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sun,  4 Aug 2002 17:44:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How to explain benefits of Linux for corporate droids?
Message-ID: <20020805003655.QUEZ221.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@dhcp-279-190>

<opinion>
I don't have an answer for this, but it got me to thinking about why I would
choose Linux over Microsoft products if I was building a company. 

The thing I think about when thinking about companies is that they are mostly
able only to travel in one direction. You don't see many companies that have
changed direction survive. It seems that once a company has committed to a
path, there isn't a way to turn back. The only way to change directions is to
stop. If the company doesn't have the resources to get the business moving
again, or has other paths (the company is really multiple companies) in motion
to cover for the stop, then the company dies.

The other thing I think I know about business, is that profitability is about
doing the same thing time and time again in an efficient manner. Thing being
deliver the product or service. Companies that are successful manage to do this
with more than one thing. Companies that can only do this with one thing
survive until the climate changes. I don't think they can really be considered
successful because it is probably only a matter of time before they fail.  

In order to survive the company as to be able to deliver multiple products or
services no matter what the environment is like. As I can't know what tomorrow
will be like, I have to assume that tomorrow will be worse than today and plan
for it. From the two things, I think I know about business, (I make no claim
that these are true), I would want to know that in five maybe ten years, I will
be able to use the same tools then as now, as this may be my only choice. I
base some of opinion this on Y2K. All that money was spent because the
companies with old tools still needed them to work on 1-1-00 and didn't know if
they would. Why they didn't have any other choice is irrelevant

Looking at Microsoft for the last five years, is there any tool that that MS
was making then, that has support now? How about being able to buy a five year
old product?

What is the past five - ten years like? Are those enterprise systems built with
SQL 2.0 still able to do their job or has everything have to have been updated
to SQL2000? Did that call for change the client  / database code? What would
have happened if those times were bad and the company couldn't have upgraded?
What if you couldn't afford to rebuild your enterprise code but you need more
capacity? Say you needed to put up another SQL 3.0 server, how would you if you
can't by it anymore. (I have no clue if you going from one version of MS SQL to
another requires code changes, but I would know if I was in charge of making
those types of decisions). Is MS a dead end if you can't keep paying? Is there
a company that hasn't had to entrench? It seems, from my ignorance, that the
choosing MS products could cost the company dollars, when pennies are precious,
and that would seem unwise choice.

If I gave Linux tools the same test, I think the answer would put me more at
ease than MS. Most of the tools I have seen are posted with all the old
releases. Even now we have gcc 3, GTK 2 and KDE 3 coexisting with their older
siblings. Not to mention being able to boot a generation change in kernels,
Let's see, possibility of a MS 3.1 app working in WIN2000, possibility of a 10
year old app running on my Linux box, I think the answer is in the past.

Way up at the top of this I said a company has to have multiple products or
services to succeed and that profitability is in the efficiency of delivering
those services. So if were talking backend technology the more products you can
support with less backend the more profitable you will be. So I start a
business and I have my first product. the company builds tools to support that
new product and reach the point were it can provide that product the same way,
every time. Now it need it's second product to survive a change that undermines
the first. The chances are that there is some time between the first and second
product, and there are probably new tools available. With MS it seems new and
old can't coexist. Can I run SQL6 and SQL2000 on the same box? The company is
building a new product infrastructure, it  learned from it's last deployment,
and it needs the new features in order maximize the efficiency of the second
product. The MS solution seems like it would need a new physical infrastructure
as part of the new infrastructure. It seems that a Linux solution would
leverage the existing physical infrastructure. This could help keep the cash
flow in balance as the companies expenses are going to go up during this
expansion.

So company now has the base needed to survive. The company has two product
deployments under it's belt, It wants to implement all it's has learned and a
new infrastructure to handle the increasing business. With the MS solution the
company has already spent the second budget allotment for infrastructure so it
doesn't have that option or is required to spend again. With the Linux solution
the company saved, drew interest, and can now spend even more on growth. The
company improves the efficiency of the first product using the new tools and
the acquired knowledge. The new infrastructure provides for the growth of the
current products and  the company now has a platform for a third product. This
seems more efficient as you only spend what is needed, and are in control of
the pace of your technology. The dependency of more boxes for more products
seems to be replaced in Linux by more with less.

More with less is something I haven't heard said in a while but with the new
economy, I'm sure it will come back in fashion.

</opinion>

Thank you
Russell


On Fri, 02 Aug 2002 08:05:19 -0700, Alex Daniloff said:

>  convince
>  executives to give Linux a try.

A library for creating graphical user interfaces.

that only has three alternatives. If life were so simple.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sun Aug  4 23:58:42 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sun, 4 Aug 2002 23:58:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] WYSWYG Programming environments for Linux?
In-Reply-To: <20020805041137.RLTQ23732.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@dhcp-279-190>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208042352490.27693-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

FYI, someone stated earlier on this thread that Kylix was Delphi only,
however the new 3.0 version will target C++ as well:

"Borland Software Corp is set to build on an early lead among Linux
developers, with today's expected launch of a C++ rapid application
development (RAD) environment.

Scotts Valley, California-based Borland will announce version 3.0 of its
Kylix RAD environment for C++. Previous versions of Kylix targeted Delphi
programmers on Windows and Linux.

Kylix 3.0 brings RAD to an estimated three million C++ developers on
Linux. Borland is playing in a highly fragmented Linux market, which
provides programmers with an array of open source command-line tools that
largely lack integrated features.

The company hopes Kylix 3.0's integrated, RAD-development environment will
attract those building graphical users interfaces (GUIs), databases and
web services.

"Command-line tools get the job done at a low-level, but these tools have
not been easy to use. You have several console windows open to build and
debug [an application]," said product manager for RAD solutions John Ray
Thomas.""

http://www.theregister.co.uk/content/4/26321.html

From satimis at writeme.com  Mon Aug  5 00:48:55 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Mon, 05 Aug 2002 15:48:55 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] Broadband speed monitoring software
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20020805152214.00a6a110@pop.net-yan.com>

Hi All Guys,

Is there open source software to monitor the broadband speed?  The story is :

I am subscribing a broadband of 10MB sharing dynamic IP.  From time to time 
the download or browsing speed is quite slow.  My ISP claims that it is 
caused by the traffic of the site I am browsing/downloading.  I expect to 
find a software which can clear my doubt whether the responsibility falls 
on my ISP's shoulder or otherwise because of too many users sharing one 
line at the same time.

I browsed "goolge".  There are many suggestions, spectrum, web monitoring, 
etc.  I am not sure which one shall be appropriate to my application.

Could any guy throw me some light.  Thanks in advance.

Stephen Liu





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Aug  5 01:09:03 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 01:09:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Broadband speed monitoring software
Message-ID: <1314229760.1028534945453.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Mon, 5 Aug 2002, Stephen Liu satimis at writeme.com wrote:

> Is there open source software to monitor the broadband speed?  The
> story is :
> 
> I am subscribing a broadband of 10MB sharing dynamic IP.  From time to time 
> the download or browsing speed is quite slow.  My ISP claims that it is 
> caused by the traffic of the site I am browsing/downloading.  I expect to 
> find a software which can clear my doubt whether the responsibility falls 
> on my ISP's shoulder or otherwise because of too many users sharing one 
> line at the same time.
> 
> I browsed "goolge".  There are many suggestions, spectrum, web monitoring, 
> etc.  I am not sure which one shall be appropriate to my application.
> 
> Could any guy throw me some light.  Thanks in advance.

I usually take a packet cpature using "tcpdump" (http://www.tcpdump.org)
and run it through "tcptrace"
(http://irg.cs.ohiou.edu/software/tcptrace/tcptrace.html) to get TCP
statistics on retries, throughput, round-trip time, etc.  Unfortunately,
if you don't have a firm grasp on the internals of TCP this low-level
information won't help much.

My favorite book on TCP internals is "Troubleshooting TCP/IP" by Mark
Miller.  I've heard good things about the O'Reilly "Network
Troubleshooting Tools" by Joseph Sloan, but I have not read it.

If you want to take a more "active" role and have a remote server you can
use, check out Netperf (http://www.netperf.org/netperf/NetperfPage.html)/

The quick version from my experience:

Often remote systems get congested.  When this happens you will see TCP
retries start to creep up, as packets get discarded on the back
end.  Sometimes the round trip time is very high as well, but the retries
are what really kills performance.

When your local system gets congested you will notice degraded interactive
performance to remote sites (i.e. telnet/ssh) regardless of which site you
go to.  If this is happening, you probably have a local problem.  If your
interactive response is good, but that stubborn FTP session won't go over
5k/s, odds are it's a remote problem.

Slowness on the initial connection is almost always due to lousy DNS
servers.  Try running your own caching DNS to solve that little problem.  
;-)

Many remote sites won't do more than 10-20k/s.  I see this all the time.  
All that 10Mbit connection does for them is let you wait faster. :-(

  -- Steve





From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sun Aug  4 18:48:00 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 01:48:00 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] WYSWYG Programming environments for Linux?
In-Reply-To: <20020805041137.RLTQ23732.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@dhcp-279-190>
References: <200208021518.g72FIOf25039@gate.daniloff.com> <200208021634.g72GYq412674@smtp.easystreet.com> <20020805041137.RLTQ23732.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@dhcp-279-190>
Message-ID: <200208050832.g758Wdi12548@smtp.easystreet.com>

On Monday 05 August 2002 04:19 am, Russell Evans wrote:

> GTK+ isn't an IDE. The entry on Freshmeat says it all

Nobody said it was an IDE. It has a command-line interface. Glade is 
available for users who want a graphical environment. Glade is not an IDE, 
but a graphical frontend to GTK. A brief visit to the home pages of any of 
the three mentioned shows a large number of options for each product.

> Kylix is an IDE, but one of only three? In Linux? Is there anything in
> Linux that only has three alternatives. If life were so simple.

Alex's original question was " ...graphical Linux environments to program 
desktop interfaces or web interfaces in WYSWYG mode. " Which doesn't sound 
like IDE to me. (Some people consider Emacs to be the ultimate IDE.) I could 
be wrong about Alex's intention- I mentioned the three products with 
graphical interfaces that I consider to be the best: the most useful, the 
most mature, the best feature sets, with active development teams behind 
them. 

>The following are the free ones that mention IDE in the release entry at
>Freshmeat. http://freshmeat.net/browse/65/?topic_id=65

You can find zillions of anything on Freshmeat, if you don't care about 
quality. 

Carla





From satimis at writeme.com  Mon Aug  5 03:35:52 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Mon, 05 Aug 2002 18:35:52 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] Broadband speed monitoring software
In-Reply-To: <1314229760.1028534945453.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20020805182153.02ac1ea8@pop.net-yan.com>

Hi Steve,

Thanks for your detail information.

My time does not allow me to penetrate deeply into this subject.  And my 
intention is only to clarify whether the slowness is due to my ISP having 
too many subscribes sharing one line.

I use this ISP's broadband service for more than 1 year.  At the beginning 
the browsing/download speed was quite fast but now the speed is 
questionable.  My ISP pushes the burden to the remote sites.  However I 
have certain reserve whether it is on account of the increase of subscribers.

I only need a simple and easy install software to monitor the speed of the 
broadband connection, if possible, identifying the cause of responsibility.

Anyway lot of thanks for your prompt advice.

Stephen


At 01:09 AM 8/5/2002 -0700, Steve Bonds wrote:
>On Mon, 5 Aug 2002, Stephen Liu satimis at writeme.com wrote:
>
> > Is there open source software to monitor the broadband speed?  The
> > story is :
> >
> > I am subscribing a broadband of 10MB sharing dynamic IP.  From time to 
> time
> > the download or browsing speed is quite slow.  My ISP claims that it is
> > caused by the traffic of the site I am browsing/downloading.  I expect to
> > find a software which can clear my doubt whether the responsibility falls
> > on my ISP's shoulder or otherwise because of too many users sharing one
> > line at the same time.
> >
> > I browsed "goolge".  There are many suggestions, spectrum, web monitoring,
> > etc.  I am not sure which one shall be appropriate to my application.
> >
> > Could any guy throw me some light.  Thanks in advance.
>
>I usually take a packet cpature using "tcpdump" (http://www.tcpdump.org)
>and run it through "tcptrace"
>(http://irg.cs.ohiou.edu/software/tcptrace/tcptrace.html) to get TCP
>statistics on retries, throughput, round-trip time, etc.  Unfortunately,
>if you don't have a firm grasp on the internals of TCP this low-level
>information won't help much.
>
>My favorite book on TCP internals is "Troubleshooting TCP/IP" by Mark
>Miller.  I've heard good things about the O'Reilly "Network
>Troubleshooting Tools" by Joseph Sloan, but I have not read it.
>
>If you want to take a more "active" role and have a remote server you can
>use, check out Netperf (http://www.netperf.org/netperf/NetperfPage.html)/
>
>The quick version from my experience:
>
>Often remote systems get congested.  When this happens you will see TCP
>retries start to creep up, as packets get discarded on the back
>end.  Sometimes the round trip time is very high as well, but the retries
>are what really kills performance.
>
>When your local system gets congested you will notice degraded interactive
>performance to remote sites (i.e. telnet/ssh) regardless of which site you
>go to.  If this is happening, you probably have a local problem.  If your
>interactive response is good, but that stubborn FTP session won't go over
>5k/s, odds are it's a remote problem.
>
>Slowness on the initial connection is almost always due to lousy DNS
>servers.  Try running your own caching DNS to solve that little problem.
>;-)
>
>Many remote sites won't do more than 10-20k/s.  I see this all the time.
>All that 10Mbit connection does for them is let you wait faster. :-(
>
>   -- Steve





From rplummer at wvi.com  Mon Aug  5 07:14:04 2002
From: rplummer at wvi.com (rplummer at wvi.com)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 07:14:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Broadband speed monitoring software
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020805152214.00a6a110@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <3D4E25BC.5779.4FB17DC@localhost>

Stephen,

Are you connecting through a Linksys Router? I have found that my 
broadband cable connection gets real doggy every couple of months. 
When that happens, I reset the router using the reset button on the 
front of the router. Speed goes back to normal automagically. I don't 
know the whys or wherefores unless it has something to do with the 
DHCP lease needing refreshing. 

I suppose that would be the same with any other router setup also. 

Ray

From plug at magnetinternet.com  Mon Aug  5 07:51:46 2002

Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 07:51:46 -0700 (PDT)

Message-ID: <3006.66.93.41.102.1028559106.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

One idea, since it seems you're running windows (at least from your
X-Mailer header), make sure you're clean of viruses.  My parents system
was acting the same, and I downloaded and installed Grisoft's AVG
software, and it found 300+ infected files.  It was infected so bad that
explorer.exe was infected, as well as a few other important files.

Hey we all know Windows just slows down after a while, performance
degradation is just a part of the life cycle of a windows box. ;-)  Have
you tried speed tests from another system besides that one?

-- 
Matt King

http://www.magnetinternet.com

configured to either leave messages on the server or delete them _and_ to
download only new messages. Perhaps ATTBI can tell you how to configure
their software,

From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon Aug  5 09:04:54 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Mon, 05 Aug 2002 09:04:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Novell (nis) running on Linux
References: <DFB1F60E-A675-11D6-B455-0030657E1890@pnca.edu>
Message-ID: <3D4EA226.5010203@sun.com>

No, I don't have an answer, but rather another question...

Why would one voluntarily use Novell anymore?

I spent some time in the early 90's administering a Novell network, and 
albeit my experience is quite dated, there's nothing that Novell does 
that Linux couldn't beat hands down.  I'm sure there are a lot of shops 
that have used Novell since the early years, and have too much money 
tied up in them to abandon them to a [near-]free solution...

Just curious.

-R

cian wrote:

> Hi all,
> 
> I read a post a while ago about someone running Novell Directory 
> Services on Linux, and now I'm considering doing the same. Does anyone 
> here know of any good sources for information, gotchas, and resources 
> for doing this? The person responsible for managing the users and shares 
> on the current box will have to make the transition as well. Is there 
> and administrative interface that is similar to the one that comes with 
> Novell?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Cian





From RSchlosser at newedgenetworks.com  Mon Aug  5 09:28:36 2002
From: RSchlosser at newedgenetworks.com (Schlosser, Ryan)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 09:28:36 -0700 
Subject: [PLUG] Novell (nis) running on Linux
Message-ID: <A3FA06C6C183D61188330008C7E6BF431E1CDE@vader.newedgenetworks.com>

First of all, Novell is a company, Netware is the product you're questioning
I think.


Novell NDS.  Regardless of your feelings of Big Red Novell Software Boxes,
they do have one of the better directory structures, feating full LDAP
support, and it's "near free" at $1 to $2 a seat.

Novell Zenworks.  Nothing compares to it from the Linux world.

Novell Netware.  Larger enterprise environments, that need a file sharing
system for an "enterprise", not a small LAN.  Samba is great for smaller
environments (I use it at home and at work for non critical tasks), but
there is still much question about how well it scales in larger corporate
environments.

From sean at seansdomain.org  Mon Aug  5 06:56:47 2002
From: sean at seansdomain.org (,,,)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 06:56:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Broadband speed monitoring software
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020805182153.02ac1ea8@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020805182153.02ac1ea8@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <20020805135647.C66812EE39@einstein.seansdomain.org>

Try dslreports.com.  They have servers connected to the Internet backbone 
that will download files to you and allow you to measure you connection speed 
through your ISP to the Internet backbone.


Sean

> >
> >Often remote systems get congested.  When this happens you will see TCP
> >retries start to creep up, as packets get discarded on the back
> >end.  Sometimes the round trip time is very high as well, but the retries
> >are what really kills performance.
> >
> >When your local system gets congested you will notice degraded interactive
> >performance to remote sites (i.e. telnet/ssh) regardless of which site you
> >go to.  If this is happening, you probably have a local problem.  If your
> >interactive response is good, but that stubborn FTP session won't go over
> >5k/s, odds are it's a remote problem.
> >
> >Slowness on the initial connection is almost always due to lousy DNS
> >servers.  Try running your own caching DNS to solve that little problem.
> >;-)
> >
> >Many remote sites won't do more than 10-20k/s.  I see this all the time.
> >All that 10Mbit connection does for them is let you wait faster. :-(
> >
> >   -- Steve
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug



From eli.stair at attbi.com  Mon Aug  5 03:51:16 2002
From: eli.stair at attbi.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 06:51:16 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Broadband speed monitoring software
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020805152214.00a6a110@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020805152214.00a6a110@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <20020805065116.76dbd136.eli.stair@attbi.com>

Try ntop, it's a utility that shows ethernet interface information in a format 
similar to top.  It has some dependencies, libmysqlclient, libdb, possibly 
something else.  Try that, it's easy and shows simply what you're probably
looking for.

/eli

> Hi All Guys,
> 
> Is there open source software to monitor the broadband speed?  The story is :

In-Reply-To: <116601c23bfc$9621cc70$0400a8c0@oem2k>

I disagree - even if you know what you're doing.  Installing and

files into the system directory, etc...  All of those muss up your 
system.  And most uninstall programs leave stuff laying around.

Even if you scandisk, defrag and prune your registry regularly, I found 
that after about 3 months of use my 98 gaming system would have to be 
reloaded.  What a PITA

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Mon Aug  5 11:06:08 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 05 Aug 2002 11:06:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Novell (nis) running on Linux
In-Reply-To: <3D4EA226.5010203@sun.com>
References: <DFB1F60E-A675-11D6-B455-0030657E1890@pnca.edu> 
	<3D4EA226.5010203@sun.com>
Message-ID: <1028570770.5815.2.camel@duron>

On Mon, 2002-08-05 at 09:04, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:
> No, I don't have an answer, but rather another question...
> 
> Why would one voluntarily use Novell anymore?
> 
> I spent some time in the early 90's administering a Novell network, and 
> albeit my experience is quite dated, there's nothing that Novell does 
> that Linux couldn't beat hands down.  I'm sure there are a lot of shops 
> that have used Novell since the early years, and have too much money 
> tied up in them to abandon them to a [near-]free solution...
> 
> Just curious.

I think ease-of-use comes in to play here.  With netware, it is very
simple to set up a fileserver with authenticated logins... the server
install is very quick and easy.  The client install is even better. 
Just add the usernames and you're done... and the client integrates
itself into Windows giving the user a single logon name.

Best of all... it isn't Microsoft.  Sure, it still costs lots of money,
but... IMHO... it is a good product.

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"




From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Mon Aug  5 11:18:10 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 05 Aug 2002 11:18:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Broadband speed monitoring software
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020805152214.00a6a110@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020805152214.00a6a110@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <1028571493.5815.7.camel@duron>

On Mon, 2002-08-05 at 00:48, Stephen Liu wrote:
> Hi All Guys,
> 
> Is there open source software to monitor the broadband speed?  The story is :
<story snipped>

Assuming you're in Linux (I know of no always-on type monitors for
Windoze), gkrellm might be a nice thing to get.  It's a very easy
compile and has all sorts of pretty graphics.  It is pretty easy on the
CPU, as well.  After running for 5 days, 17 hours, and 52 minutes, it
has consumed six seconds of CPU time.

It's one of those monitor-everything applications, including a bandwidth
monitor.  Really any other bandwidth monitor would work for you, though.

Just get a monitor of some sort (Freshmeat.net is a good place to look
if you don't want gkrellm) and start as many downloads from as many
places as you possibly can in a short period of time.  If your bandwidth
stays down around 10K/sec... then your ISP has a problem or all the
servers you are downloading from do.

I see you've already gotten a lot more advice... I like DSLReports, as
well.

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"

From derek at infotects.com  Mon Aug  5 11:45:56 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 05 Aug 2002 11:45:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Dying DVD drive / irksome fan
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031620250.24810-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031620250.24810-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1028573157.14011.36.camel@dereklinux>

On Sat, 2002-08-03 at 16:31, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> Two questions for the list's hardware hackers:
> 
> When I boot up, my dvd/cdrom drive yields this error:
> 
> hdd: no response (status = 0x80), resetting drive
> hdd: no response (status = 0x80)
> 
> Also pressing the "eject" button on the drive doesn't do anything, yet the
> light on the drive is on, indicating power. When I boot into Windows,
> the drive isn't recognized either. Any ideas whats wrong with
> this DVD drive? I just bought it at Fry's a few months ago...

A friend of mine bought one of those "Fry's" DVD drives,  it did the
same thing.  I told him to try putting on a different port (he has an
extra Hotpoint controller), or to change from master to slave (even if
it is the only drive on the cable).  DVD's drives can be _very_ picky,
the best rule of thumb: always have the DVD drive on its own IDE port
(meaning it is the only drive connected to the cable).  Most drives
would rather be slave, but some will only work as master.
> 
> Also one of my fans sometimes starts making a buzzing racket. When you
> strike it forcefully it stops buzzing, but this gets old after a while.
> Are there any permanent measures that can be taken to hush up this fan?

A good cleaning may extend it's life, but not by much.  Hold out for a
fan with ball bearings (it will say right on the fan "ball bearing"), if
it is your heatsink fan, it is usually much cheaper to get a new
heatsink and fan than to track down just a fan.  Be very careful if you
open up the power supply, it has hi-voltage capacitors that can pack a
good punch.


Good Luck

Derek Loree




From jon at manymoons.net  Mon Aug  5 12:20:42 2002

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Mon Aug  5 05:43:55 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 12:43:55 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Addendum: Something funny is going on
In-Reply-To: <20020805112823.B9653@dalsemi.com>
References: <20020805112823.B9653@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <200208051928.g75JSUk21909@smtp.easystreet.com>

Compaq has its own diagnostic utilities, check your docs, or see Compaq's Web 
site. Create the test floppy on a known good machine. I would use vendor 
utilities first. The most dependable results come from testing the hardware 
directly, which means shutting down and booting to the test suite. As goofy 
as your box is behaving, it seems that shutting down is not such a bad thing. 
Probably save time and hassle.

http://www.compaq.com/support/files/server/us/download/14740.html

Carla

From dealy at deatech.com  Mon Aug  5 12:31:16 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 12:31:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Dying DVD drive / irksome fan
In-Reply-To: <1028573157.14011.36.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051223570.20931-100000@critter.deatech.com>

> > Also one of my fans sometimes starts making a buzzing racket. When you
> > strike it forcefully it stops buzzing, but this gets old after a while.
> > Are there any permanent measures that can be taken to hush up this fan?

Sometimes buzzing noises are not actually the fan itself, but rather
something that isn't completely locked down inside the system which will
vibrate in synchronization with a harmonic of the fan's vibration.  If you
aren't completely sure it's the fan, you might just go through the system
and make sure all the screws holding everything in place (power supply
motherboard, drives, etc) are all tight.  Even if this is the problem,
tightening things won't always cure it since there may not actually be a
screw where the vibration is occuring

FWIW

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon Aug  5 12:44:48 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Mon, 05 Aug 2002 12:44:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Dying DVD drive / irksome fan
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051223570.20931-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <3D4ED5B0.4050304@sun.com>

I concur...my cpu fan was making a horrible noise, after I cleaned all 
of the accumulated dirt and crud from it, it was once again silent.  If 
you don't have access to compressed air, try a vacuum cleaner hose 
attachment and some q-tips.  Use the q-tips to loosen the dirt from the 
fans, and the hose to do the obvious.



Shannon C. Dealy wrote:

>>>Also one of my fans sometimes starts making a buzzing racket. When you
>>>strike it forcefully it stops buzzing, but this gets old after a while.
>>>Are there any permanent measures that can be taken to hush up this fan?
>>>
> 
> Sometimes buzzing noises are not actually the fan itself, but rather
> something that isn't completely locked down inside the system which will
> vibrate in synchronization with a harmonic of the fan's vibration.  If you
> aren't completely sure it's the fan, you might just go through the system
> and make sure all the screws holding everything in place (power supply
> motherboard, drives, etc) are all tight.  Even if this is the problem,
> tightening things won't always cure it since there may not actually be a
> screw where the vibration is occuring

From alex at daniloff.com  Mon Aug  5 11:57:43 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Mon, 05 Aug 2002 11:57:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Dying DVD drive / irksome fan
In-Reply-To: <3D4ED5B0.4050304@sun.com>
Message-ID: <200208051857.g75Ivhd10152@gate.daniloff.com>

Hello,
You can re-lubricate your buzzy sleeve or ball bearing CPU or Chassis
fan.
I do it about every two years on my servers.
Just peel off a sticker from the rear side of it and apply a couple of
drops 
of light oil on the spindle.
It'll make it quiet.

Alex

----- Forwarded message from Jill Schroeder <jill at richardsonfarrell.com> -----

Reply-To: <jill at richardsonfarrell.com>
From: "Jill Schroeder" <jill at richardsonfarrell.com>
To: <pasa-jobs at pasa.portland.or.us>
Message-ID: <GLELININOGFLHLOBCDGHOEODCEAA.jill at richardsonfarrell.com>
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook IMO, Build 9.0.2416 (9.0.2911.0)
Subject: [pasa-jobs] help wanted
Sender: pasa-jobs-admin at pasa.portland.or.us
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 12:24:16 -0700



Greetings,
I am currently searching for Cisco/Linux/Solaris systems engineer to join a
small but growing ISP.  This person must be self motivated, resourceful,
flexible!

Position: Systems Engineer
Location: Portland

SUMMARY:
Responsible for advanced level of systems & network support, and performance
monitoring 

Successful candidate will have a minimum of five years' related experience;
functional knowledge of broadband systems and networking components as well
as a working knowledge of the following ISP related systems including but
not limited to DNS, DHCP, LDAP, Email. 

	*	Strong knowledge of Cisco Routers a must  - CCNA required,
CCIE desired.

	*	Lucent (Cajun) experience desired.

	*	Expert knowledge of Linux/Solaris a must. 

	*	Knowledge of LAN/WAN/Broadband networking technology a must,
including but not limited to Ethernet, Gigabit Ethernet, RF, SONET, TCP/IP,
Internet routing protocols, and firewall security. 

	*	Additional networking experience required includes NIC's
spanning tree, bridging, routing, CMTS routing and switching; experience in
network maintenance including installing, upgrading, and maintaining WAN,
LAN and IP routed Networks. 

	*	Experience in design, configuration, implementation, support
and operation of high-end router networks and IP address structuring.
	 
	Background should include expertise in Internet service related
applications, backup, security and monitoring software. Working knowledge of
Data over Cable systems is a plus. 
	
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
Designs, configures, implements and maintains systems. 
 
Installs, configures, manages and maintains network components including but
not limited to routers, switches, firewalls, hubs, and bridges. 

 
Troubleshoots and resolves complex network and systems (server/client)
related problems to ensure minimal disruption of critical applications.
Reports and resolves basic/complex software, hardware, and operations
problems.
 

Establishes and maintains network users, user environment, directories, and
security. This includes but is not limited to network segmentation, TCP
wrappers, installation and maintenance of firewall and closing of all
potential ports that pose security risks. 

 Develops and implements disaster recovery procedures including backup
administration configuration. 
Analyzes and selects tools necessary for troubleshooting systems and network
components.
Maintains network configuration zones, local/wide area network hardware,
software, and telecommunications services such as personal computers, system
software, software applications, servers, routers, bridges, switches,
modems, cabling, and Internet service providers. 


EDUCATION and/or EXPERIENCE 
Bachelor's degree in a computer related field from four-year college or
university; minimum five years' related experience and/or training; or
equivalent combination of education and experience. 

To apply for this position please email resume and salary requirements to:
<jill at richardsonfarrell.com>




----- End forwarded message -----



From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Aug  5 13:14:45 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 13:14:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sun Java & RH 7.2
In-Reply-To: <3D4EC663.8060003@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051313200.12234-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 5 Aug 2002, Keith wrote:

> I just installed Java on my machine and none of my web browsers can
> seem to find it. I was able to point Open Office to the directory
> but how do I make Java available for web browsers and other
> programs?

1. Exit Mozilla/Netscape.

2. Symlink the Java plugin into the Netscape plugins directory, e.g.

   cd /usr/lib/netscape/plugins
   ln -s /usr/java/j2re1.4.0/plugin/i386/ns610/libjavaplugin_oji140.so .

3. Restart your browser.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From kevinc at dOink.COM  Mon Aug  5 13:32:15 2002
From: kevinc at dOink.COM (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Mon, 05 Aug 2002 13:32:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LyX won't start
Message-ID: <20020805203217.5DD0B2FE87@joseph.doink.com>

I'm trying to run LyX on my Mandrake 8.0 system, displaying
remotely on a Redhat 7.2 system, taking a SSH hop through a
Solaris 2.8 system along the way.  All my other X applications
can run in either direction just fine, so I think my SSH and X
setups are OK.

When I start lyx I get "Segmentation fault" with no core file.
I tried starting lyx with debugging turned on for "info", "init"
and "gui", and I got:

    Setting debug level to 1,2,8
    Debugging `info' (General information)
    Debugging `init' (Program initialisation)
    Debugging `gui' (GUI handling)
    Initializing LyXGUI...
    Segmentation fault

Since I'm running 8 bit color on the display server, I set
"-depth 8" but I get just the same response.  I also tried
"-visual PseudoColor" and "-shared" with the same results.

Any ideas on how to debug this more?

Thanks....

Oh yeah, I'm trying this with lyx version 1.1.6 that came with
Mandrake 8.0 which runs just fine when executed locally on this 
machine.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Mon Aug  5 16:09:56 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Mon, 05 Aug 2002 16:09:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
Message-ID: <3D4F05C4.18D603C6@attbi.com>

I've downloaded ethereal-0.9.5-2.i386.rpm to my RH 7.1 system. I ran:

  rpm -i ethereal-0.9.5-2.i386.rpm

and get the following error messages:

  error: failed dependencies:
	  libpcap >= 0.6 is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
	  net-snmp is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
	  libcrypto.so.2   is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
	  libpcap.so.o.6.2   is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
	  libsnmp.so.5   is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2

I understand that I need to install or upgrade something related to each
of the above, but I don't know where to start. Is the process the same
for each dependency? I.e., do I find the appropriate rpm for libpcap,
net-snmp, libcrypto.so.2, libpcap.so.o.6.2, and libsnmp.so.5, download
them, and run rpm -i on each of them? If they give me similar messages,
to I keep working through the dependencies until they go away?

If I upgrade the ones that are already installed (how do I tell that?)
will I break something else?

Thanks.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Mon Aug  5 16:13:12 2002
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (ptkwt at aracnet.com)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 23:13:12 GMT
Subject: [PLUG] tools for converting txt to jpg or gif ?
Message-ID: <200208052312.g75NBx4u019137@franka.aracnet.com>

Yeah, it's a strange request...  It's for a magazine article and they want a jpg
of some of my code ("In order to preserve the indentation").  

So, anyone know of any tools that will take a text file and spit out a jpg or gif?

Phil




From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Mon Aug  5 16:18:02 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 16:18:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
In-Reply-To: <3D4F05C4.18D603C6@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0208051612570.16903-100000@il.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

My solution to this problem was debian...seriously though, RedHat is
great, and debian (to me) is greater...You're milage may vary, but if you
like to keep things reasonably up todate, with little headache debian is
good.

On Mon, 5 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> I've downloaded ethereal-0.9.5-2.i386.rpm to my RH 7.1 system. I ran:
>
>   rpm -i ethereal-0.9.5-2.i386.rpm
>
> and get the following error messages:
>
>   error: failed dependencies:
> 	  libpcap >= 0.6 is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
> 	  net-snmp is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
> 	  libcrypto.so.2   is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
> 	  libpcap.so.o.6.2   is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
> 	  libsnmp.so.5   is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
>
> I understand that I need to install or upgrade something related to each
> of the above, but I don't know where to start. Is the process the same
> for each dependency? I.e., do I find the appropriate rpm for libpcap,
> net-snmp, libcrypto.so.2, libpcap.so.o.6.2, and libsnmp.so.5, download
> them, and run rpm -i on each of them? If they give me similar messages,
> to I keep working through the dependencies until they go away?

That's how I always solved it.  Try sites like rpmfind.net (is that the
right URL?).  You can download all the packages you need to upgrade and
then do them all on one command line, that can help rpm to understand
you're intentions and complain less.

HTH,
Jason




From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Mon Aug  5 16:21:36 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 16:21:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] tools for converting txt to jpg or gif ?
In-Reply-To: <200208052312.g75NBx4u019137@franka.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0208051619090.16903-100000@il.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Here is a seven step process.

Find a tool that takes code and generates pdf or postscript.  I can't
remember the names of such programs off the top of my head but google and
freshmeat should know.  a2ps might be your man.

Then load it (as postscript) in the gimp, now save as.

You might even be able to cut out the jpg step and give them the
postscript or pdf file.

Good luck,
Jason

On Mon, 5 Aug 2002 ptkwt at aracnet.com wrote:

>
> Yeah, it's a strange request...  It's for a magazine article and they want a jpg
> of some of my code ("In order to preserve the indentation").
>
> So, anyone know of any tools that will take a text file and spit out a jpg or gif?
>
> Phil
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

give less than optimal results.

From sandy at herring.org  Mon Aug  5 16:54:12 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 16:54:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0208051612570.16903-100000@il.ENGR.ORST.EDU>; from dagit@engr.orst.edu on Mon, Aug 05, 2002 at 04:18:02PM -0700
References: <3D4F05C4.18D603C6@attbi.com> <Pine.GHP.4.44.0208051612570.16903-100000@il.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20020805165412.A19559@kippered.herring.org>

On Mon, 05 Aug 2002, Jason Dagit wrote: 
> My solution to this problem was debian...seriously though, RedHat is
> great, and debian (to me) is greater...You're milage may vary, but if you
> like to keep things reasonably up todate, with little headache debian is
> good.

> On Mon, 5 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:
> 
> > I've downloaded ethereal-0.9.5-2.i386.rpm to my RH 7.1 system. I ran:
> >
> >   rpm -i ethereal-0.9.5-2.i386.rpm
> >
> > and get the following error messages:
> >
> >   error: failed dependencies:
> > 	  libpcap >= 0.6 is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
> > 	  net-snmp is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
> > 	  libcrypto.so.2   is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
> > 	  libpcap.so.o.6.2   is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
> > 	  libsnmp.so.5   is needed by ethereal-0.9.5-2
> >
> > I understand that I need to install or upgrade something related to each
> > of the above, but I don't know where to start. Is the process the same
> > for each dependency? I.e., do I find the appropriate rpm for libpcap,
> > net-snmp, libcrypto.so.2, libpcap.so.o.6.2, and libsnmp.so.5, download
> > them, and run rpm -i on each of them? If they give me similar messages,
> > to I keep working through the dependencies until they go away?
> 
> That's how I always solved it.  Try sites like rpmfind.net (is that the
> right URL?).  You can download all the packages you need to upgrade and
> then do them all on one command line, that can help rpm to understand
> you're intentions and complain less.
> 
> HTH,
> Jason

Note that some of the failed dependencies (like libpcap) are packaged in
their own rpm...

[bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ rpm -q libpcap
libpcap-0.6.2-12

...while others (like libcrypto) are part of another package...

[bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ rpm -qf `locate libcrypto.so`
openssl095a-0.9.5a-14
file /usr/lib/libcrypto.so.0 is not owned by any package
openssl096-0.9.6-9
file /usr/lib/libcrypto.so.1 is not owned by any package
openssl-devel-0.9.6b-24
openssl-0.9.6b-24
file /lib/libcrypto.so.2 is not owned by any package

...in this case, the openssl rpms. As Jason noted, www.rpmfind.net is the
best bet on finding them - but pay attention to the "Distribution" listed
(you'll want RedHat or RawHide - and note the for <processor>). If you can't
find what you need as an rpm, you'll need to unpack and install the tgz
file. rpmfind.net generally has a link to it as well (shown before the sites
having the rpms).

You should use the -Uv (update, verbose) options rather than the -i option
for upgrading packages (the exception being the kernel itself). You can find
the maxrpm book online at http://www.rpm.org/max-rpm/ .

cheers,
Sandy

rpm -i ethereal-0.9.5-2.i386.rpm

again, and the libpcap error message is gone. One down, four to go.

rpm -Uv openssl-0.9.6-9.i386.rpm

Preparing packages for installation...
openssl-0.9.6-9

	libelf.so.0  is needed by net-snmp-5.0.1-5

of openssl?

After upgrading openssl, when I run rpm -q libcrypto.so I still get:

package libcrypto.so is not installed.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Aug  5 17:30:54 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 17:30:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
In-Reply-To: <3D4F05C4.18D603C6@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051724000.5614-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 5 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> I understand that I need to install or upgrade something related to each
> of the above, but I don't know where to start. Is the process the same
> for each dependency? I.e., do I find the appropriate rpm for libpcap,
> net-snmp, libcrypto.so.2, libpcap.so.o.6.2, and libsnmp.so.5, download
> them, and run rpm -i on each of them? If they give me similar messages,
> to I keep working through the dependencies until they go away?

  Yup.
 
> If I upgrade the ones that are already installed (how do I tell that?)
> will I break something else?

  You have three options here, Richard. If you run 'rpm -Fvh ...', you'll
freshen an existing installation, but not install if an earlier version is
not on the system.

  If you run 'rpm -Uvh ...' you'll upgrade an existing installation and
install the new one if there is no earlier one there. Either the 'F' or 'U'
version will replace the existing version on your system.

  OTOH, you can keep multiple versions of a library on your system. If you
want to do this, use 'rpm -ivh ...' and you'll install the new package in
addition to the previous one.

  If you think it's a PITA with 7.1, try upgrading a 6.2 system. :-)

Rich




From plug at magnetinternet.com  Mon Aug  5 18:13:43 2002

From sandy at herring.org  Mon Aug  5 18:24:34 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 18:24:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
In-Reply-To: <3D4F1A4A.3AA6D374@attbi.com>; from rsteff@attbi.com on Mon, Aug 05, 2002 at 05:37:30PM -0700
References: <3D4F05C4.18D603C6@attbi.com> <200208052330.g75NU6411840@smtp.easystreet.com> <3D4F1A4A.3AA6D374@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020805182434.B19559@kippered.herring.org>

Unfortunately, the search engine at rpmfind.net does not accept regexp and
is not greedy. I'm realizing (since there are several openssl rpms) you'd
actually probably be better off going to RedHat's site...

http://www.redhat.com/apps/download/

...and doing a "By Keyword" search for openssl to get all related rpms.

You won't discover which rpm contains libcrypto.so.2 by just using the -q
switch. A simple query needs the package name as an argument. e.g.,

[bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ rpm -q openssl-perl
openssl-perl-0.9.6b-24

You need to add the -f switch to find out which rpm carries a given file.
e.g.,

[bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ rpm -qf /bin/cat
textutils-2.0.21-1

Note that you have to fully qualify the file location.  In the case of
libcrypto.so.2, it's a symlink...

[bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ ls -l `locate libcrypto.so.2`
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root           19 Jan 22  2002 /lib/libcrypto.so.2
-> libcrypto.so.0.9.6b

...so you'd need to...

[bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ rpm -qf `locate libcrypto.so.0.9.6b`
openssl-0.9.6b-24

It turns out that libelf is packaged in its own rpm...

[bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ rpm -q libelf
libelf-0.7.0-2

I'm beginning to understand why the Debian fans brag about their distro. :)

Good luck,
Sandy

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Mon Aug  5 12:05:48 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 19:05:48 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
In-Reply-To: <20020805182434.B19559@kippered.herring.org>
References: <3D4F05C4.18D603C6@attbi.com> <3D4F1A4A.3AA6D374@attbi.com> <20020805182434.B19559@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <200208060150.g761oJC26014@smtp.easystreet.com>

Sandy n Rich, a valiant effort. I hate when someone's idea of help is 
"apt-get- oh you can't? too bad!"  Those Deb packages are built by human 
hands, it doesn't take much of a search to find sad forum posts of Deb users 
having similar problems.

Ethereal is a sterling example of how not to build an RPM. I've been fussing 
with it all afternoon- it's been an interesting education. To heck with the 
damned RPMs. The machines I use it on, it was installed during the original 
Linux installation. I'm going to try building from source and see what 
happens. The libs are on my test system, but not in the RPM database- seems 
like there was a thread on this not too long ago.

Carla

On Tuesday 06 August 2002 01:24 am, you wrote:
> Unfortunately, the search engine at rpmfind.net does not accept regexp and
> is not greedy. I'm realizing (since there are several openssl rpms) you'd
> actually probably be better off going to RedHat's site...
>
> http://www.redhat.com/apps/download/
>
> ...and doing a "By Keyword" search for openssl to get all related rpms.
>
> You won't discover which rpm contains libcrypto.so.2 by just using the -q
> switch. A simple query needs the package name as an argument. e.g.,
>
> [bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ rpm -q openssl-perl
> openssl-perl-0.9.6b-24
>
> You need to add the -f switch to find out which rpm carries a given file.
> e.g.,
>
> [bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ rpm -qf /bin/cat
> textutils-2.0.21-1
>
> Note that you have to fully qualify the file location.  In the case of
> libcrypto.so.2, it's a symlink...
>
> [bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ ls -l `locate libcrypto.so.2`
> lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root           19 Jan 22  2002 /lib/libcrypto.so.2
> -> libcrypto.so.0.9.6b
>
> ...so you'd need to...
>
> [bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ rpm -qf `locate libcrypto.so.0.9.6b`
> openssl-0.9.6b-24
>
> It turns out that libelf is packaged in its own rpm...
>
> [bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ rpm -q libelf
> libelf-0.7.0-2
>
> I'm beginning to understand why the Debian fans brag about their distro. :)
>
> Good luck,
> Sandy
>
> On Mon, 05 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:
> > Carla Schroder wrote:
> > > See this page, http://www.ethereal.com/download.html
> > > Down near the bottom are detailed instructions and links for satisfying
> > > dependencies. it is a pain.
> >
> > I see what you mean.
> >
> > Sandy Herring wrote:
> > > Note that some of the failed dependencies (like libpcap) are packaged
> > > in their own rpm while others (like libcrypto) are part of another
> > > package...
> >
> > I found libpcap-0.7.1-2.i386.rpm and successfully installed it. I tried:
> >
> > rpm -i ethereal-0.9.5-2.i386.rpm
> >
> > again, and the libpcap error message is gone. One down, four to go.
> >
> > I found openssl-0.9.6-9.i386.rpm and ran
> >
> > rpm -Uv openssl-0.9.6-9.i386.rpm
> >
> > The system responded with:
> >
> > Preparing packages for installation...
> > openssl-0.9.6-9
> >
> > After that, I tried rpm -i net-snmp-5.0.1-5.i386.rpm and got:
> >
> > error: failed dependencies:
> > 	libcrypto.so.2  is needed by net-snmp-5.0.1-5
> > 	libelf.so.0  is needed by net-snmp-5.0.1-5
> >
> > If libcrypto.so.2 is in openssl, did I miss something with the upgrade
> > of openssl?
> >
> > After upgrading openssl, when I run rpm -q libcrypto.so I still get:
> >
> > package libcrypto.so is not installed.
> >
> > --
> > Regards,

> > "Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Aug  5 19:09:54 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 19:09:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
In-Reply-To: <200208060150.g761oJC26014@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051905580.5614-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 5 Aug 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Ethereal is a sterling example of how not to build an RPM. I've been fussing 
> with it all afternoon- it's been an interesting education. To heck with the 
> damned RPMs. The machines I use it on, it was installed during the original 
> Linux installation. I'm going to try building from source and see what 
> happens. The libs are on my test system, but not in the RPM database- seems 
> like there was a thread on this not too long ago.
 
Carla,

  I built ethereal from source then was sent a working rpm that's known to
work on a RH 6.2 system. It works just fine.

  When a library is built from source it's not registered in the package
database. If the rpm installation reports that dependency is missing, but
'locate' confirms it's installed, just use the '--nodeps' switch and the
rpm will install and run without complaints or problems.

  If anyone wants a copy of:

/usr1/rpm-packages/ethereal-base-0.9.1-1.i386.rpm
/usr1/rpm-packages/ethereal-gtk+-0.9.1-1.i386.rpm
/usr1/rpm-packages/ethereal-usermode-0.9.1-1.i386.rpm

  I'll be happy to push them your way as attachments; about 2.7M worth of
tools.

Rich

I would really like to see this happen as well. My suggestion would be to
put up a webpage where we can request classes to be taught, and list
classes we would be willing to teach. For example here's my list:

1. Stuff I want to learn:

OO Perl, computational geometry, anything on variant free operating
systems; AtheOS, mach, minix, plan9. Also, I haven't written anything in
html since 1996, it would be nice to take a class on creating a modern
website using php or perl.

2. Stuff I could teach:

Bash Programming
Unified Modelling Language stuff; software models.
Analysis of Algorithms, algorithmics
Cryptography; block ciphers, public key encryption.
Intermediate Lisp, Java, C, Fortran, Python, Perl.

Regarding the classes, location isn't that important provided
there's a chalkboard or display device of some kind. Being next to a
bus/MAX line is nice, too.


Tyler

From dealy at deatech.com  Mon Aug  5 20:54:39 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 20:54:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] An X Window System Question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051925460.5938-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208052047320.22004-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Mon, 5 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I sometimes -- too often, in fact -- lose track of the little arrow cursor
> on my monitor bacause it tends to have too little contrast with the
> background of the desktop or apps running in it. Is there a way to change
> the color of the cursor, say to red with a yellow border?

I solved the problem by going to a larger cursor, using the "X-Big-Cursor"
mini howto (it's included in Debian, probably some other distributions as
well).  If you prefer to go with the color scheme approach rather than the
big cursor approach, reading this howto may be of some help in creating
your own (though I'm not sure about the color handling).

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com




From plug at magnetinternet.com  Mon Aug  5 21:02:05 2002
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Mon, 5 Aug 2002 21:02:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] An X Window System Question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208052047320.22004-100000@critter.deatech.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051925460.5938-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
        <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208052047320.22004-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <35342.63.105.24.103.1028606525.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

See the xsetroot manual.  I changed my cursor to red with white outline
with this command:

xsetroot -cursor_name top_left_arrow -fg red -bg white

BUT, it only changes it for the root window, and not ALL applications.  I
know on a few terminal progs you can change the pointer color, etc.  Do
some more research and I'm sure you'll find something.

-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Mon Aug  5 21:05:52 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Mon, 05 Aug 2002 21:05:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051905580.5614-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3D4F4B20.2080500@pacifier.com>

Everyone (sans apt-get'ers) is right--ethereal is one of the most 
frustrating packages to install/update.  Not sure that building from scratch 
would help much either.  `make` will (or should) fail if you haven't met all 
the dependencies.  There are so many security lib deps and they are being 
updated very often.

If I could find my notes from the last time I did this (using rpms), they'd 
be out of date anyway.  But when you finally do it, your grunt gets a little 
deeper.

--
Kyle Accardi

up quite easily.  I taught a Ruby class out at FreeGeek in May/June.

computational geometry?  I could teach the Scanline algorithm as I'm quite
familiar with it at this point, but the application we're using it for is
probably a lot different than what you have in mind... still the algorithm
itself is the same.

Ha. Nailed it. Building from source was a breeze. Get a single big tarball at 
ftp://ftp.ethereal.com/pub/ethereal/  Do what INSTALL says. Don't forget to 
'make install' as root. Everything else can be done as an underprivileged 
user.

sheesh!

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Tue Aug  6 00:51:28 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 06 Aug 2002 00:51:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] tools for converting txt to jpg or gif ?
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208051625120.7271-100000@lukem.com> <mailman.1028592614.13960.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86k7n4whkv.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Anthony" == Anthony Schlemmer <aschlemm at attbi.com> writes:

Anthony> This works as long as "convert" knows you have a text file. It doesn't 
Anthony> work on a file with a .c extenstion but if you put a .text extension 
Anthony> "convert" works quite well in this respect.

convert txt:file-with-any-extension.c foo.png

convert txt:- <file-with-any-extension png:- >foo.png

ImageMagick (when it works) rocks!

From rkurth at starband.net  Tue Aug  6 01:17:55 2002
From: rkurth at starband.net (Richard Kurth)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 01:17:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Help with bash script
Message-ID: <35211042142.20020806011755@starband.net>

I need some help with a bash script. I need to read a file and find a
certain line in that file and then add two lines directly after that
line.
example
I need to search the file and find this line. The file is a httpd.conf file
RewriteRule ^/cgi-bin/test/(.+)  proto://servername:81/cgi-bin/test/$1 [L,R]

and then add two lines right below it.


  

-- 
Best regards,
 Richard                          mailto:rkurth at starband.net




From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Aug  6 06:48:24 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 06:48:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Help with bash script
In-Reply-To: <35211042142.20020806011755@starband.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208060641560.13429-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 6 Aug 2002, Richard Kurth wrote:

> I need some help with a bash script. I need to read a file and find a
> certain line in that file and then add two lines directly after that
> line.

How about something like this:

#!/bin/bash
while read line
do
  if expr "$line" '.*/cgi-bin/test/' > /dev/null
  then
    echo $line
    echo "new content line 1"
    echo "new content line 2"
  else
    echo $line
  fi
done < httpd.conf


--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Aug  6 06:53:13 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 06:53:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
In-Reply-To: <3D4F1A4A.3AA6D374@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208060648580.13429-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 5 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> If libcrypto.so.2 is in openssl, did I miss something with the
> upgrade of openssl?

In both Red Hat 7.2 and 7.3, /lib/libcrypto.so.2 is a symlink to 
/lib/libcrypto.so.0.9.6b, provided by the openssl-0.9.6b-24 rpm.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From drake_stuff at yahoo.com  Tue Aug  6 06:53:44 2002
From: drake_stuff at yahoo.com (Ken Nowack)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 06:53:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Help with bash script
In-Reply-To: <35211042142.20020806011755@starband.net>
Message-ID: <20020806135344.23811.qmail@web21207.mail.yahoo.com>

--- Richard Kurth <rkurth at starband.net> wrote:
> I need some help with a bash script. I need to read
> a file and find a
> certain line in that file and then add two lines
> directly after that
> line.
> example
> I need to search the file and find this line. The
> file is a httpd.conf file
> RewriteRule ^/cgi-bin/test/(.+) 
> proto://servername:81/cgi-bin/test/$1 [L,R]
> 
> and then add two lines right below it.

i'm not terribly sophisticated with this operation,
but, that said:

cat httpd.conf | sed -e 's:[oldline]:[newlines]:'

HTH,

ken

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Aug  6 06:58:16 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 06:58:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Help with bash script
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208060641560.13429-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208060653310.13429-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 6 Aug 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> #!/bin/bash
> while read line
> do
>   if expr "$line" '.*/cgi-bin/test/' > /dev/null
>   then
>     echo $line
>     echo "new content line 1"
>     echo "new content line 2"
>   else
>     echo $line
>   fi
> done < httpd.conf

Oops. There's a minor but fatal syntax error in my 'expr' invocation.  
The loop should read

  while read line
  do
    if expr "$line" : '.*/cgi-bin/test/' > /dev/null
    then 
      echo $line
      echo "new content line 1" 
      echo "new content line 2"
    else
      echo $line 
    fi
  done < httpd.conf

Note that expr's regex engine implicitly anchors all matches to the 
beginning of the line, hence the leading '.*'.

Of course, there are probably two dozen ways to accomplish this same 
thing (awk and perl would be nice tools of choice), but you asked for 
a bash script... :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Aug  6 06:58:42 2002

Subject: [PLUG] HP and linux
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208060651390.7611-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Some of you may recall that I've been trying to upgrade the firmware on my
HP DeskJet 2500C for several years now, but cannot do it because the only
available executable is for Microsoft.

  I've contacted HP in Boise and Carly Fiorini in California and everyone
agrees there should be a way to do this on a linux system -- and their own
HP-UX OS which now cannot be used to upgrade their printer from their
hardware.

  Recently I've read that Bruce Perens of debian fame is now the Chief Linux
Advocate at HP/Compaq/DEC. I would like to send him an e-mail on this issue
so if anyone has his e-mail address, please send it on to me.

Thanks,

Rich




From dcf at aracnet.com  Tue Aug  6 06:24:36 2002
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 06:24:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Help with bash script
In-Reply-To: <35211042142.20020806011755@starband.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208060621360.1091-100000@linux.sourballs.org>

On Tue, 6 Aug 2002, Richard Kurth wrote:

> I need some help with a bash script. I need to read a file and find a
> certain line in that file and then add two lines directly after that
> line.
> example
> I need to search the file and find this line. The file is a httpd.conf file
> RewriteRule ^/cgi-bin/test/(.+)  proto://servername:81/cgi-bin/test/$1 [L,R]
>
> and then add two lines right below it.

If you are sure the line you're looking for can be uniquely matched by
grep,  you can do something like this:

 x=`grep -n unique_string httpd.conf | cut -f 1 -d ':'`
 head -${x} httpd.conf
 echo "line of stuff"
 echo "second line of stuff"

 x=$((x = x + 1))
 tail +${x} httpd.conf


--
 David Fleck
 dcf at aracnet.com

From satimis at writeme.com  Tue Aug  6 09:10:01 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 00:10:01 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server can't see WinME
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20020807000531.02bded28@pop.net-yan.com>

Hi All Guys,

I have a WinME box connected to a Samba Server (RH7.3) via a crossover 
cable as experiment.  Both boxes can be connected.  WinME can transfer 
files from the share folder of Samba Server and to the folder of the same 
but not the other way round.  Samba Server can't see the WinME box.

Test No.1

-------- snip -----------
/etc/samba/smb.conf

[test]
comment = test share
path = /test
writable = yes
browsable = yes
follow symlinks = yes
wide links = yes
public = yes
read only = No
guest ok = Yes
guest only = Yes


(Remark :  Computer_name of WinME = IWILL
                  shared = share_folder of WinME)
IP address of RH7.3 = 192..168.0.2  Subnet : 255.255.255.-0
IP address of WinME = 192.168.0.2  Subnet : 255.255.255.-0

# smbclient -L IWILL
added interface ip=192.168.0.1 bcast=192.168.0.255 nmask=255.255.255.0
Got a positive name query response from 192.168.0.2 ( 218.188.76.202 
192.168.0.2 )
error connecting to 218.188.76.202:139 (Network is unreachable)
Error connecting to 218.188.76.202 (Network is unreachable)
Connection to IWILL failed

# mount -t smbfs //IWILL/shared/ /mnt/WinME/
Error connecting to 218.188.76.202 (Network is unreachable)
1668: Connection to IWILL failed
SMB connection failed


Test No.2

/etc/samba/smb.conf

------ snip -------
[test]
comment = test share
path = /test
writable = yes
browsable = yes
public = yes
read only = No
guest ok = Yes
guest only = Yes

# mount -t smbfs //IWILL/shared/ /mnt/WinME/
Error connecting to 218.188.76.202 (Network is unreachable)
1628: Connection to IWILL failed
SMB connection failed

# smbclient -L IWILL
added interface ip=192.168.0.1 bcast=192.168.0.255 nmask=255.255.255.0
Got a positive name query response from 192.168.0.2 ( 218.188.76.202 
192.168.0.2 )
error connecting to 218.188.76.202:139 (Network is unreachable)
Error connecting to 218.188.76.202 (Network is unreachable)
Connection to IWILL failed

Please advise.   Thanks in advance.

Stephen Liu





From plug at magnetinternet.com  Tue Aug  6 09:16:44 2002
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 09:16:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server can't see WinME
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020807000531.02bded28@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020807000531.02bded28@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <5534.66.93.41.98.1028650604.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

Your Samba box thinks IWILL is at 218.188.76.202, and your internal
address can't reach it, that seems like your problem.  Add IWILL to your
/etc/hosts file if it's not already there, and make sure your samba box
checks the hosts file before DNS.  I don't think, from what it looks like,
that it's a Samba issue.

-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com

From don at truedisk.com  Tue Aug  6 09:30:29 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 09:30:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Help with bash script
References: <35211042142.20020806011755@starband.net>
Message-ID: <3D4FF9A5.2AFEE56C@truedisk.com>

Richard Kurth wrote:
> 
> I need some help with a bash script. I need to read a file and find a
> certain line in that file and then add two lines directly after that
> line.
> example
> I need to search the file and find this line. The file is a httpd.conf file
> RewriteRule ^/cgi-bin/test/(.+)  proto://servername:81/cgi-bin/test/$1 [L,R]
> 
> and then add two lines right below it.
> 
> 

Use the sed "a" command.  

sed -e '/reg-exp_pattern/a\          # Address/pattern to match, and "a" command
line(s) of\                          # (the backslash after the "a" is req'd.)
new text to\                         # Backslashes are required after all but 
add                                  # the last line of new text.
'                                    # (Don't forget the last single quote mark!)


sed -e '/RewriteRule .*cgi-bin\/test.* proto:\/\/servername:81.*/a\
new_line#1\
new_line#2
'  < httpd.conf


I got a bit lazy on the reg-exp expression for matching -- you can
tighten it if necessary.

- Don



From mikedela at ipns.com  Tue Aug  6 09:29:13 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 09:29:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server can't see WinME
In-Reply-To: <200208061618.g76GI2q25078@smtp.easystreet.com>

From jon at manymoons.net  Tue Aug  6 09:56:30 2002
From: jon at manymoons.net (Jon Jacob)
Date: 06 Aug 2002 09:56:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft school opens in Gresham
In-Reply-To: <200208061515.g76FFNA11701@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200208061515.g76FFNA11701@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1028652990.7991.921.camel@lana.manymoons.net>

Okay, warning..... this email is flame bait :)

My first point is this: I am really tired of how this list diverges into
MicroSoft bashing.  Yes, I do not like MicroSoft, but you know what? 
They are successful.  They became successful.  They just didn't pop out
of thin air.  They had a plan and didn't whine about their opponents,
they went out and the attacked and won.

Linux could learn a thing or two from MicroSoft.  Yes, this point has
been made here before but I make it again with respect to this school
program posting.

You people want to protest, you want to whine.  Did you call up the
school and say: "Glad you have decided to enhance your high tech program
and it is very generous of MicroSoft to help you.  If you would like, I
am sure that we in the Linux community would be happy to help by
providing our services.  We will gladly mentor the kids, come in show
them how to use Linux, show them where we work and what is used in the
real work, etc....."  A great example of this statedgy is what some
folks are doing with the Portland Public Schools.  More power to them.



On Tue, 2002-08-06 at 08:15, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Why don't they name it M$ zombi training program
> or M$ button pusher and mouse clicker training program?
> 
> No way I'll put my kids in this "program".
