From prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com  Tue Aug  6 10:30:05 2002
From: prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com (Preston Crawford)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 10:30:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft school opens in Gresham
In-Reply-To: <1028652990.7991.921.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208061023490.4340-100000@serpentor.local>

On 6 Aug 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:

> Okay, warning..... this email is flame bait :)
>
> My first point is this: I am really tired of how this list diverges into
> MicroSoft bashing.  Yes, I do not like MicroSoft, but you know what?
> They are successful.  They became successful.  They just didn't pop out
> of thin air.  They had a plan and didn't whine about their opponents,
> they went out and the attacked and won.

They did this, in large part, by breaking the law. Maybe that's why they
get bashed.... perhaps??

> Linux could learn a thing or two from MicroSoft.  Yes, this point has

I don't think Linux can strongarm customers, purchase politicians to make
laws that work for them, or buy off diplomats to shill for Linux products
overseas.

> You people want to protest, you want to whine.  Did you call up the
> school and say: "Glad you have decided to enhance your high tech program
> and it is very generous of MicroSoft to help you.  If you would like, I
> am sure that we in the Linux community would be happy to help by
> providing our services.  We will gladly mentor the kids, come in show
> them how to use Linux, show them where we work and what is used in the
> real work, etc....."  A great example of this statedgy is what some
> folks are doing with the Portland Public Schools.  More power to them.

Many are already doing that. Some, such as myself, held back for fear of
seeming to "come on to strong" and worry the schools that we didn't have
their best interests at heart. I still want to help, but I think it's
important to help in such a way that it doesn't seeem like you're "using"
the schools as a battleground to fight a skirmish in a larger "war"
against Microsoft. It has to be professional and it has to be conducted
with the interests of the schools put first. I'd still like to help, but I
don't think it's THAT simple when you step back for a moment.

Either way, I'll whine about Microsoft if I want. They broke the law, they
buy legislation and favor and they abuse their monopoly power. I am
supposed to like that? Do I still have to like it when I'm unable to buy
hardware that doesn't work without a DCMA-approved piece of software (i.e.
not free software)? Do I still have to appreciate their business acumen
when they control my access to the Internet, to being able to conduct
business in my day to day life? Part of the responsibility of an
intelligent, informed citizen is to ACT when it is necessary to act and to
dissent when it is necessary to dissent.

Preston




From derek at infotects.com  Tue Aug  6 10:38:32 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 06 Aug 2002 10:38:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server can't see WinME
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020807000531.02bded28@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020807000531.02bded28@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <1028655512.14021.91.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Stephen,

On Tue, 2002-08-06 at 09:10, Stephen Liu wrote:
> Hi All Guys,
> 
> I have a WinME box connected to a Samba Server (RH7.3) via a crossover 
> cable as experiment.  Both boxes can be connected.  WinME can transfer 
> files from the share folder of Samba Server and to the folder of the same 
> but not the other way round.  Samba Server can't see the WinME box.

Samba Server isn't the program that is going to connect to the Winblowz
box, smbclient will be doing that.
[snip]
> 
> (Remark :  Computer_name of WinME = IWILL
>                   shared = share_folder of WinME)
> IP address of RH7.3 = 192..168.0.2  Subnet : 255.255.255.-0
> IP address of WinME = 192.168.0.2  Subnet : 255.255.255.-0
> 
Both machines have the same address?  This must be a typo, otherwise
they couldn't see each other.

> # smbclient -L IWILL
> added interface ip=192.168.0.1 bcast=192.168.0.255 nmask=255.255.255.0
> Got a positive name query response from 192.168.0.2 ( 218.188.76.202 
> 192.168.0.2 )
> error connecting to 218.188.76.202:139 (Network is unreachable)
> Error connecting to 218.188.76.202 (Network is unreachable)
> Connection to IWILL failed

There is the problem, your winblowz box thinks it still has the real ip
address, and is telling your RedHat box to connect to it using the real
ip address (SMB doesn't route very well,if at all).  Do you have 2 NIC's
in this box?  Is NetBIOS over TCP turned on for both NIC's?  

You could try using the ip address instead of the computer name:

# smbmount //192.168.0.2/shared /mnt/WinME -o username=stephen

If this works, then adding IWILL 192.168.0.2 to your /etc/hosts file
should straighten out your RedHat box.

Derek

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Aug  6 10:43:52 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 10:43:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft school opens in Gresham
In-Reply-To: <200208061716.g76HGrq22864@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208061021410.13429-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tuesday 06 August 2002 04:56 pm, Jon Jacob wrote:

> My first point is this: I am really tired of how this list diverges
> into MicroSoft bashing.  Yes, I do not like MicroSoft, but you know
> what? They are successful.  They became successful.  They just
> didn't pop out of thin air.  They had a plan and didn't whine about
> their opponents, they went out and the attacked and won.

A more accurate rendering might say something like

  ...whine about its opponents, Microsoft went out and, using business
  tactics that would

  * eventually lead Federal courts to find it guilty of abusing its 
    operating-system monopoly,

  * so anger its leading OEM resellers that they would testify against 
    Microsoft in court and in the industry press,

  * lead venture capitalists to reject out of hand requests for 
    funding from companies developing application software that might 
    compete on Microsoft's turf, knowing that Microsoft, if 
    interested, would eventually steamroll the market by "bundling"
    those features with Windows, and

  * actively undermine OS-independent standards and protocols 
    codified to *help* computer users rather than a specific computer 
    company,

  attacked and won.

There's no doubt that PLUG is often home to unfair Microsoft bashing, 
but to suggest that Microsoft's success has come largely as the result 
of by-the-rules competition is naive in the extreme.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From rkurth at starband.net  Tue Aug  6 11:05:29 2002
From: rkurth at starband.net (Richard Kurth)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 11:05:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Help with bash script
In-Reply-To: <3D4FF9A5.2AFEE56C@truedisk.com>
References: <35211042142.20020806011755@starband.net>
 <3D4FF9A5.2AFEE56C@truedisk.com>
Message-ID: <156246295874.20020806110529@starband.net>

Hello Don,

Tuesday, August 06, 2002, 9:30:29 AM, you wrote:


DB> Richard Kurth wrote:
>> 
>> I need some help with a bash script. I need to read a file and find a
>> certain line in that file and then add two lines directly after that
>> line.
>> example
>> I need to search the file and find this line. The file is a httpd.conf file
>> RewriteRule ^/cgi-bin/test/(.+)  proto://servername:81/cgi-bin/test/$1 [L,R]
>> 
>> and then add two lines right below it.
>> 
>> 

DB> Use the sed "a" command.  

DB> sed -e '/reg-exp_pattern/a\          # Address/pattern to match, and "a" command
DB> line(s) of\                          # (the backslash after the "a" is req'd.)
DB> new text to\                         # Backslashes are required after all but 
DB> add                                  # the last line of new text.
DB> '                                    # (Don't forget the last single quote mark!)


DB> sed -e '/RewriteRule .*cgi-bin\/test.* proto:\/\/servername:81.*/a\
DB> new_line#1\
DB> new_line#2
DB> '  < httpd.conf


DB> I got a bit lazy on the reg-exp expression for matching -- you can
DB> tighten it if necessary.

DB> - Don

This is what I am trying to write to the httpd.conf file a little more
elaborate than what I first sead in my e-mail

I keep getting this when I run the script
 sed: -e expression #1, char 233: Unknown command: ``R''
 so I figure that it is reading the first R in the first line I am
 trying to write and interpreting it as a command. Is there a way to
 make it understand that those 6 lines are to be written and not read


sed -e '/RewriteRule .*cgi-bin\/.cobalt.* proto:\/\/servername:81.*/a\

RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)
RewriteRule ^/acp/?$   proto://servername:800/autocontrol/index.php
RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)
RewriteRule ^/ucp/?$      proto://servername:800/user/index.php
RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)
RewriteRule ^/rcp/?$      proto://servername:800/resellerpanel/index.php
'  < httpd.conf







-- 
Best regards,
 Richard                            mailto:rkurth at starband.net




From shahms at shahms.com  Tue Aug  6 11:01:17 2002
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms E. King)
Date: 06 Aug 2002 11:01:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How to: screen shot?
In-Reply-To: <4626.66.93.41.98.1028655970.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
References: <B379IQY2AJ3A*/R=A1/R=TABOR/U=RUSSELLAL/@MHS>
	 <4626.66.93.41.98.1028655970.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
Message-ID: <1028656877.22617.2.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

It appears as though you're looking for some way to take a screenshot of
one window.  If you're running GNOME2, then Alt-PrtScreen will work
(under any WM), otherwise the most desktop environment agnostic way of
doing it is with xwd:
$ xwd -out <filename.xwd>

And then convert it to something useful.

--Shahms


On Tue, 2002-08-06 at 10:46, Matt King wrote:
> KDE - ksnapshot
> Gnome - GIMP
> 
> -- 
> Matt King
> magnet | internet
> http://www.magnetinternet.com

>   tactics that would
> 
>   * eventually lead Federal courts to find it guilty of abusing its 
>     operating-system monopoly,
> 
>   * so anger its leading OEM resellers that they would testify against 
>     Microsoft in court and in the industry press,
> 
>   * lead venture capitalists to reject out of hand requests for 
>     funding from companies developing application software that might 
>     compete on Microsoft's turf, knowing that Microsoft, if 
>     interested, would eventually steamroll the market by "bundling"
>     those features with Windows, and
> 
>   * actively undermine OS-independent standards and protocols 
>     codified to *help* computer users rather than a specific computer 
>     company,
> 
>   attacked and won.

All true, but what gets me is that Micro$oft is taking money from the
schools to train IT minions that will be selling their O$'s to the
masses.  How can we convince the schools to pay us to train Linux
minions?  (Not that I want to take money from the schools, but I would
rather see it go to a Linux instructor than to a corporation that won't
even be providing an instructor.  Sure you get a weeks worth of
training, but after that you are on your own, Micro$oft charges for
support too.)

whew, just a little venting.

Derek

From rkurth at starband.net  Tue Aug  6 11:22:07 2002
From: rkurth at starband.net (Richard Kurth)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 11:22:07 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Help with bash script
In-Reply-To: <156246295874.20020806110529@starband.net>
References: <35211042142.20020806011755@starband.net>
 <3D4FF9A5.2AFEE56C@truedisk.com> <156246295874.20020806110529@starband.net>
Message-ID: <41247294640.20020806112207@starband.net>

Hello Richard,

I figured it out thanks to every body

Tuesday, August 06, 2002, 11:05:29 AM, you wrote:


RK> Hello Don,

RK> Tuesday, August 06, 2002, 9:30:29 AM, you wrote:


DB>> Richard Kurth wrote:
>>> 
>>> I need some help with a bash script. I need to read a file and find a
>>> certain line in that file and then add two lines directly after that
>>> line.
>>> example
>>> I need to search the file and find this line. The file is a httpd.conf file
>>> RewriteRule ^/cgi-bin/test/(.+)  proto://servername:81/cgi-bin/test/$1 [L,R]
>>> 
>>> and then add two lines right below it.
>>> 
>>> 

DB>> Use the sed "a" command.  

DB>> sed -e '/reg-exp_pattern/a\          # Address/pattern to match, and "a" command
DB>> line(s) of\                          # (the backslash after the "a" is req'd.)
DB>> new text to\                         # Backslashes are required after all but 
DB>> add                                  # the last line of new text.
DB>> '                                    # (Don't forget the last single quote mark!)


DB>> sed -e '/RewriteRule .*cgi-bin\/test.* proto:\/\/servername:81.*/a\
DB>> new_line#1\
DB>> new_line#2
DB>> '  < httpd.conf


DB>> I got a bit lazy on the reg-exp expression for matching -- you can
DB>> tighten it if necessary.

DB>> - Don

RK> This is what I am trying to write to the httpd.conf file a little more
RK> elaborate than what I first sead in my e-mail

RK> I keep getting this when I run the script
RK>  sed: -e expression #1, char 233: Unknown command: ``R''
RK>  so I figure that it is reading the first R in the first line I am
RK>  trying to write and interpreting it as a command. Is there a way to
RK>  make it understand that those 6 lines are to be written and not read


RK> sed -e '/RewriteRule .*cgi-bin\/.cobalt.* proto:\/\/servername:81.*/a\

RK> RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)
RK> RewriteRule ^/acp/?$   proto://servername:800/autocontrol/index.php
RK> RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)
RK> RewriteRule ^/ucp/?$      proto://servername:800/user/index.php
RK> RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)
RK> RewriteRule ^/rcp/?$      proto://servername:800/resellerpanel/index.php
RK> '  < httpd.conf










-- 
Best regards,
 Richard                            mailto:rkurth at starband.net




From raanders at acm.org  Tue Aug  6 11:16:00 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 11:16:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] tools for converting txt to jpg or gif ?
In-Reply-To: <86k7n4whkv.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208061107300.9489-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

While looking for a method to convert large text-ish files to tiff I came 
up with this trick.

enscript <file.whatever> -p - | \
    gs -sDEVICE=tiffpack -sOutputFile=file%d.tiff

Or something very much like it.  :-)

With my copy of ghostscript (RHL 7.2) there is pngmono, pnggray, png16, 
png256, png16m, jpeg, jpeggray, and a bunch of others.

Enscript will also do some nifty formating if you want it to depending on 
the input source type: C, SQL, etc.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

page 2 reporting that the Gresham charter school (used by Gresham, Reynolds
and two other districts here) are paying Microsoft to establish a technology
center in the school. Students attend their regular school half-time and the
charter school half-time where they are trained as Microserfs to "better
prepare them for the Real World".

  Looks like an opportunity for the linux-in-education Emergency Response
Team to swing into action!

From rkurth at starband.net  Tue Aug  6 12:36:13 2002
From: rkurth at starband.net (Richard Kurth)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 12:36:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] another bash question
Message-ID: <133251740213.20020806123613@starband.net>

Will this work in bash

A='uname -n'   #or this A=$(uname -n)
sed -e '/ServerName localhost/c\
ServerName $A\
' < httpd.conf

So far all it does is just fill in the ServerName with an $A
it seams like the problem is that the variable is not read inside the
sed command how can I make this work

-- 
Best regards,
 Richard                          mailto:rkurth at starband.net




From don at truedisk.com  Tue Aug  6 12:36:04 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 12:36:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] another bash question
References: <133251740213.20020806123613@starband.net>
Message-ID: <3D502524.B6858312@truedisk.com>

Richard Kurth wrote:
> 
> Will this work in bash
> 
> A='uname -n'   #or this A=$(uname -n)
> sed -e '/ServerName localhost/c\
> ServerName $A\
> ' < httpd.conf
> 
> So far all it does is just fill in the ServerName with an $A
> it seams like the problem is that the variable is not read inside the
> sed command how can I make this work
> 

Change from single quote (') to double quote (").  It will
allow for the shell to expand "$A". 

A simple test of the different behavior:
   $ echo '$A'
   $ echo "$A"

Things can get messier though when other shell meta-characters
(e.g. '!', '`', or '\') appear in the double-quoted string.
(You'll become close friends with your back-slash key :-) )


- Don



From dealy at deatech.com  Tue Aug  6 12:42:41 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 12:42:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] another bash question
In-Reply-To: <133251740213.20020806123613@starband.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208061240280.24327-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Tue, 6 Aug 2002, Richard Kurth wrote:

>
> Will this work in bash
>
> A='uname -n'   #or this A=$(uname -n)
> sed -e '/ServerName localhost/c\
> ServerName $A\
> ' < httpd.conf
>
> So far all it does is just fill in the ServerName with an $A
> it seams like the problem is that the variable is not read inside the
> sed command how can I make this work

Use double quotes around the string on your sed command line, single
quotes suppress interpretation of the $A and pass it as part of the
string literal.

I changed it to look like this
A=$(uname -n)
sed -e '/ServerName localhost/c\
ServerName "$A"\   #<-I added the double quotes
' < httpd.conf

And this is what it looks like when it writes to the httpd.conf file
ServerName "$A"
It is not filling in the variable with what is in the variable.

A=`uname -n`
sed -e "/ServerName localhost/c\
ServerName $A
" < httpd.conf



From dealy at deatech.com  Tue Aug  6 13:18:56 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 13:18:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] another bash question
In-Reply-To: <128253825241.20020806131058@starband.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208061315500.24531-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Tue, 6 Aug 2002, Richard Kurth wrote:

[snip]
> I changed it to look like this
> A=$(uname -n)
> sed -e '/ServerName localhost/c\
> ServerName "$A"\   #<-I added the double quotes
> ' < httpd.conf
>
> And this is what it looks like when it writes to the httpd.conf file
> ServerName "$A"
> It is not filling in the variable with what is in the variable.

You need it around the whole string, replace your single quotes with
double quotes, the problem is the single quotes which supress
interpretation of the contents of the string between them.  In other
words, this:

 sed -e "/ServerName localhost/c\
 ServerName $A\
 " < httpd.conf

From don at truedisk.com  Tue Aug  6 14:15:44 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 14:15:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] another bash question
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208061315500.24531-100000@critter.deatech.com>
	 <72256025445.20020806134738@starband.net> <3D503602.DD06D8F7@truedisk.com> <96257355717.20020806140949@starband.net>
Message-ID: <3D503C80.3A2E9216@truedisk.com>

Richard Kurth wrote:
> 
> Ok I removed the backslash after $A so it looks like this
> A=$(uname -n)
>  sed -e "/ServerName localhost/c\
>  ServerName $A
>  " < httpd.conf
> 
>  and I still get the
>  sed: -e expression #1, char 24: Extra characters after command
> 

doh!, I forgot about my shell-meta-character warning earlier.
The backslash is one of them ...

  A=$(uname -n)
  sed -e "/ServerName localhost/c\\
  ServerName $A
  " < httpd.conf


Futhurmore, compare these two (identical results):

  sed -e "/ServerName localhost/c\\
  ServerName $A
  " < httpd.conf

  sed -e "/ServerName localhost/c\\
  ServerName $A" < httpd.conf
  
... to this one:

  sed -e "/ServerName localhost/c\\
  ServerName $A\\
  " < httpd.conf


The latter gives you an extra blank line.



From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Aug  6 14:19:16 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 14:19:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] another bash question
In-Reply-To: <96257355717.20020806140949@starband.net>
References: <3D503602.DD06D8F7@truedisk.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208061315500.24531-100000@critter.deatech.com>
 <72256025445.20020806134738@starband.net>
 <3D503602.DD06D8F7@truedisk.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020806141120.01a4e3f8@localhost>

Why not:

A=$(uname -n)
sed -e "s/ServerName localhost/ServerName $A/" < httpd.conf

Notice that you also need an 's' command for sed (before the first slash). 
As given, this will only replace the first instance of "ServerName 
localhost" with "ServerName $A". If you want all instances replaced:

A=$(uname -n)
sed -e "s/ServerName localhost/ServerName $A/g" < httpd.conf

I'm not sure why your redirecting here... You don't need to.

A=$(uname -n)
sed -e "s/ServerName localhost/ServerName $A/" httpd.conf >httpd.conf.new
mv httpd.conf.new httpd.conf

Will do that I think you are wanting.

At 02:09 PM 8/6/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>Ok I removed the backslash after $A so it looks like this
>A=$(uname -n)
>  sed -e "/ServerName localhost/c\
>  ServerName $A
>  " < httpd.conf
>
>  and I still get the
>  sed: -e expression #1, char 24: Extra characters after command

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net


Why aren't there any left-handed screwdrivers?

[snip]
>
>   sed -e "/ServerName localhost/c\\
>   ServerName $A
>   " < httpd.conf
[snip]

While Don was sorting this out, it occurred to me to ask what it was you
were trying to do (I had just been looking at it from a Bash perspective)
Wouldn't it be both simpler and cleaner to do this instead:

   sed -e "s/ServerName localhost/ServerName $A/" < httpd.conf

or am I missing something?

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Aug  6 12:25:38 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 12:25:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: An X Window System Question (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208061223500.8690-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  For those of you running xfce and desiring a larger cursor (no this is not
another Viagra spam), try this suggestion I obtained from another mail list:

Put this line:

xset +fp "/usr/share/xfce/cursors"

in your ~/.xinitrc

  You'll need to shut down X and restart it (not just reload it from the
root window menu).

Rich

Hello Russ,

I tried this
A=$(uname -n)
sed -e "s/ServerName localhost/ServerName $A/"httpd.conf > httpd.new
mv httpd.new httpd.conf

But it gave me an error message
sed: -e expression #1, char 57: Unknown option to 's'

this works
A=$(uname -n)
sed -e "/ServerName localhost/c\\
ServerName $A" httpd.conf > httpd.new
mv httpd.new httpd.conf

beyond the end of the sed command. It looks like you didn't put a space 
between the closing quote and the filename.

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Tue Aug  6 18:30:53 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 06 Aug 2002 18:30:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CD-ROM Driver (was [PLUG] (no subject))
In-Reply-To: <fc.004c4d190e37c9b2004c4d190e37c9b2.e37ca41@umit.maine.edu>
References: <fc.004c4d190e37c9b2004c4d190e37c9b2.e37ca41@umit.maine.edu>
Message-ID: <1028683859.8819.3.camel@duron>

On Mon, 2002-08-05 at 19:11, Lech Muszynski wrote:
> Hi there, 
> 
> I was wondering if I could find an old Toshiba cdrom driver for Linux.I am trying to turn one of our old PC's into a Linux terminal for another machine.The PC used to go bi-booth Linux/windows 3.11.The CD rom is Toshiba XM-3701TM.I can hardly find
> anything specific for this drive, not even mention Linux stuff. Could you offer some advice on that?

On an old system like that, the CD-ROM itself isn't nearly as important
as the controller it is plugged in to.  You need support for *that*.

What model is the Toshiba?  If it is a laptop (they did make desktops
back then, I know) then you can likely find a ton of information about
it and how to get things working at www.linux-laptop.net.  If it's a
desktop, things get a little more complicated.

I don't know how to get info about ISA things on there, and doubt the
controller will be on the PCI bus, if the system even *has* a PCI bus
(Win311 is *old*).  Hopefully somebody else on-list can help.

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"




From galens at seitzassoc.com  Tue Aug  6 18:08:04 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 18:08:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] (no subject) 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Mon, 05 Aug 2002 22:11:08 EDT."
             <fc.004c4d190e37c9b2004c4d190e37c9b2.e37ca41@umit.maine.edu> 
Message-ID: <200208070108.g77184427236@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> Hi there, 
> 
> I was wondering if I could find an old Toshiba cdrom driver for Linux.I am trying to turn one of our old PC's into a Linux terminal for another machine.The PC used to go bi-booth Linux/windows 3.11.The CD rom is Toshiba XM-3701TM.I can hardly find
> anything specific for this drive, not even mention Linux stuff. Could you offer some advice on that?
> 

It looks like the XM-3701 is a SCSI drive.  Is there a SCSI controller 
installed in the machine?  If so, you will just need the appropriate
driver for the SCSI controller.

galen

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Tue Aug  6 21:09:36 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 21:09:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft school opens in Gresham
In-Reply-To: <200208061607.g76G7Hq09875@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208062012420.4260-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Many people believe the computer has been given too much significance in
K-12 education generally. When your mind is young it's easier to learn
languages, musical intruments, art, and mathematics, whereas proficiency
in word-processing or using powerpoint can be acquired through experience
at a later age. The latter are highly applied skills that do not
transfer as readily to other domains.

For more thoughts on this, see this interview with Clifford Stoll, author
of "High Tech Heretic":

...

Q: You do say that you are not advocating zero computing for children. How
should computers be used in classrooms, if at all?

CS: It's okay to plunk a kid in front of a computer. Just like it's okay
for kids to watch TV. The problem is that we can see, after a generation
or two, that lots of television tends to be bad for kids, and adults too.
We haven't yet learned the pernicious way in which computers work against
an education. How much computing do we need? My feeling is that up to 12
years old, the answer is close to zero. In high school, teenagers, yeah,
the graduate of a high school ought to know word processing, ought to know
what a spreadsheet does, ought to have a sense of what a data base does,
ought to know how to send and receive e-mail. On the other hand, this
isn't really tough stuff. This is a few weeks worth of instruction. Not
many semesters.

CS: One of the weird things for me is to visit schools in California and
the principal, time and time again, walks up and says: "Let me show you my
wonderful computer lab." There are rows and rows of Apple Macintoshes, and
PCs. My first question is not: How fast are they, or how many are there?
My first question is: What did this computer lab used to be? The answer is
telling: "Oh, this room? It used to be the music studio, but we don't
teach music here anymore." "This computer lab? Oh, this was the art room.
We don't teach art." "This multi-media system? This used to be the
library, but we got rid of the books and installed computers."

http://www.familyhaven.com/parenting/hightechheretic.html


Tyler

On Tue, 6 Aug 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

$ rpm -qi mozilla
Name        : mozilla                      Relocations: /usr 
Version     : 1.0.0                             Vendor: Red Hat, Inc.
Release     : 9                             Build Date: Fri 07 Jun 2002 03:31:59 PM PDT
Install date: Sat 03 Aug 2002 10:41:46 AM PDT      Build Host: daffy.perf.redhat.com
Group       : Applications/Internet         Source RPM: mozilla-1.0.0-9.src.rpm
Size        : 26694171                         License: MPL
Packager    : Red Hat, Inc. <http://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla>
Summary     : Web browser and mail reader
Description :
Mozilla is an open-source web browser, designed for standards
compliance, performance and portability.

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Tue Aug  6 15:45:11 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Tue, 6 Aug 2002 22:45:11 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Shatter Attacks - How to break Windows
Message-ID: <200208070529.g775TWV07374@smtp.easystreet.com>

anyone following Slashdot today?

http://security.tombom.co.uk/shatter.html

 "This paper presents a new generation of attacks against Microsoft Windows, 
and possibly other message-based windowing systems. The flaws presented in 
this paper are, at the time of writing, unfixable. The only reliable solution 
to these attacks requires functionality that is not present in Windows, as 
well as efforts on the part of every single Windows software vendor. 
Microsoft has known about these flaws for some time; when I alerted them to 
this attack, their response was that they do not class it as a flaw - the 
email can be found here . This research was sparked by comments made by 
Microsoft VP Jim Allchin who stated, under oath, that there were flaws in 
Windows so great that they would threaten national security if the Windows 
source code were to be disclosed. He mentioned Message Queueing, and 
immediately regretted it. However, given the quantity of research currently 
taking place around the world after Mr Allchin's comments, it is about time 
the white hat community saw what is actually possible.

"This paper is a step-by-step walkthrough of how to exploit one example of 
this class of flaw. Several other attack methods are discussed, although 
examples are not given. There are many ways to exploit these flaws, and many 
variations on each of the stages presented. This is just one example."

>this paper are, at the time of writing, unfixable. The only reliable solution 
>to these attacks requires functionality that is not present in Windows, as 
>well as efforts on the part of every single Windows software vendor. 
>Microsoft has known about these flaws for some time; when I alerted them to 
>this attack, their response was that they do not class it as a flaw - the 
>email can be found here . This research was sparked by comments made by 
>Microsoft VP Jim Allchin who stated, under oath, that there were flaws in 
>Windows so great that they would threaten national security if the Windows 
>source code were to be disclosed. He mentioned Message Queueing, and 
>immediately regretted it. However, given the quantity of research currently 
>taking place around the world after Mr Allchin's comments, it is about time 
>the white hat community saw what is actually possible.
>
>"This paper is a step-by-step walkthrough of how to exploit one example of 
>this class of flaw. Several other attack methods are discussed, although 
>examples are not given. There are many ways to exploit these flaws, and many 
>variations on each of the stages presented. This is just one example."
>
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>
_____________________
Mike De La Mater
Computer Consulting
Twenty five years experience
Networks, PCs and office technologies
503-702-6749
mikedela at ipns.com 





From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Aug  6 23:10:19 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 06 Aug 2002 23:10:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Using "apt-proxy" to minimize Apt's Internet bandwidth useage.
Message-ID: <87y9bjxkqc.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

                    <URL:http://apt-proxy.sf.net/>

I've recently discovered the excellent "apt-proxy" program.  (It is
available via "aptitude install apt-proxy".)  It acts as a caching
proxy between the actual software archive out on the Internet and your
internal Debian (or Mac OS-X) systems.  Since "apt-proxy" has been
especially designed for Apt, it's to be preferred over a Squid proxy.
It will duplicate the remote archive's directory structure and create
a local mirror containing the union of the sets of packages installed
on each of your Debian machines.

Once a package is in it's cache, you don't have to wait for it to
download from the Internet again -- your machines can grab it at the
much higher LAN speeds.  You can use the local mirror for CD image
generation also, if you wish.

Here's the relevant parts (abridged) of my
"/etc/apt-proxy/apt-proxy.conf", just for example.

8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
add_backend /main/					\
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/debian/			\
	http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/

add_backend /non-US/					\
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/non-US/			\
	http://non-us.debian.org/

add_backend /security/					\
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/security/			\
	security.debian.org::debian-security/		\
	non-us.debian.org::debian-security/		

#Emdebian project
# add_backend /emdebian/ 				\
#	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/emdebian/ 			\
#	http://emdebian.sourceforge.net/emdebian/

# Blackdown java
#
add_backend /blackdown/ 				\
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/blackdown/ 			\
	ftp://ftp.tux.org/pub/java/debian/

#apt-proxy repository 
# see: http://apt-proxy.sourceforge.net/apt-proxy/README
# add_backend /apt-proxy/				\
#	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/apt-proxy/			\
#	http://apt-proxy.sourceforge.net/apt-proxy/

add_backend /xstrikeforce/ \
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/xstrikeforce/ \
	http://people.debian.org/~branden/

add_backend /ltsp/ \
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/ltsp/ \
	http://termserv.berlios.de/debian/

add_backend /openoffice/ \
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/openoffice/ \
	http://www.phy.olemiss.edu/openoffice/

# Local Variables:
# mode: shell-script
# End:
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

... and here is what it looks like on a machine on my LAN
(unabridged)...  If you use this, please move your old sources.list
aside rather than deleting it, so you don't lose any hard work and so
it remains for an example to yourself later on.  "apt" is quite happy
with a symlink for sources.list by the way.

   /etc/apt/sources.list:
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ potato main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ potato main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ woody main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ woody main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ stable main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ stable main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ sarge main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ sarge main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ testing main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ testing main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ sid main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ sid main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ unstable main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ unstable main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ potato/non-US main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ potato/non-US main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ woody/non-US main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ woody/non-US main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ stable/non-US main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ stable/non-US main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ sarge/non-US main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ sarge/non-US main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ testing/non-US main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ testing/non-US main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ sid/non-US main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ sid/non-US main contrib non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ unstable/non-US main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ unstable/non-US main contrib non-free
# deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/security/
# deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/security/
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/xstrikeforce/ sid/i386/
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/xstrikeforce/ sid/source/
# deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/blackdown/ woody non-free
# deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/blackdown/ woody non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/ltsp/ stable main non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/ltsp/ stable main non-free
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/openoffice/ testing main contrib
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/openoffice/ testing main contrib
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/openoffice/ unstable main contrib
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/openoffice/ unstable main contrib
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

  /etc/apt/preferences
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
Package: *
Pin: Release a=stable

Package: *
Pin: Release a=woody

Package: *
Pin: release a=bse,o=apt.hegbloom.net
Pin-Priority: 600
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

Don't forget to ensure that you do NOT have "Acquire::http::Proxy" set
anywhere in your apt.conf.d, and that you have not only put that
"preferences" file in place, but understand what it does.  The above
configuration will give you a Debian 3.0 (Woody, stable) system by
default, unless you explicitly select packages from "unstable" or
"testing", either interactivly using aptitude or on the command line,
using the "--target-release" option.

The last segment in there is a demonstration of how a local
"shadowing" archive can be set up as preferred over the remote Debian
archive mirror (actually, preferred over your apt-proxy cache, taking
the above configurations verbatim).  Given a locally created archive,
perhaps managed by "debarchiver", and the appropriate line in the
"sources.list" file, you can shadow mainstream packages with custom
builds, or add new ones that are locally prepared.  This is quite the
trouble fix ticket for the busy LAN administrator, isn't it?

Perhaps next time I'll (or one of the other Debian folks will?) talk
more about "apt-build", "apt-source", "debmirror", or "debarchiver".


Karl M. Hegbloom <karlheg at pdxlinux.org>

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'



From cbrown at woods.net  Tue Aug  6 23:18:52 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 00:18:52 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] two ethn in one box error
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020805125056.01d77a40@pop3.norton.antivirus>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208070015340.25398-100000@spruce.woods.net>

On Mon, 5 Aug 2002, Mike Russell wrote:

> i tried to setup an alias IP on the same nic "eth0". that seamed to fail.
> ok
> I put in a 2nd NIC and un-set the IP stuff i did on the first then out it
> on the second.
>
> now I get an error when I re-init the network.
> "error, some other host already uses address x.x.x.x"
>
> i tried changing the IP address same error.
>
> what other info may someone need to further help me.



Some actual info would help.

Initial interface configuration
The commands you used, etc...

The tools you ar using... (ifconfig or ip)


BTW:  alias interfaces were gotten rid of after 2.0.  2.2 and later
feature secondary IPs, for backwards compat each secondary IP supports
the concept of a "label".  When you configure what would have been an
alias interface this is translated into a secondary IP with a label of
what the alias interface would be.


 --
I route, therefore you are.

Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
>                     <URL:http://apt-proxy.sf.net/>
> 
> I've recently discovered the excellent "apt-proxy" program.  (It is
> available via "aptitude install apt-proxy".)  It acts as a caching
> proxy between the actual software archive out on the Internet and your
> internal Debian (or Mac OS-X) systems.  Since "apt-proxy" has been
> especially designed for Apt, it's to be preferred over a Squid proxy.
> It will duplicate the remote archive's directory structure and create
> a local mirror containing the union of the sets of packages installed
> on each of your Debian machines.
> 
> Once a package is in it's cache, you don't have to wait for it to
> download from the Internet again -- your machines can grab it at the
> much higher LAN speeds.  You can use the local mirror for CD image
> generation also, if you wish.

<snip>

Help me understand how this is different from rsync'ing a mirror.  I admit I 
don't have a grasp on squid either.  But isn't this just another way to 
maintain a local mirror?

Curious,
Kyle Accardi

Kernel IP routing table

Old file
# Do not remove the following line, or various programs
# that require network functionality will fail.
127.0.0.1       localhost.M2    localhost.localdomain

New file
# Do not remove the following line, or various programs
# that require network functionality will fail.
192.198.0.2     localhost.IWILL
127.0.0.1       localhost.M2    localhost.localdomain

1925: session request to 192.168.0.2 failed (Called name not present)
1925: session request to 192 failed (Called name not present)
1925: session request to *SMBSERVER failed (Called name not present)
SMB connection failed

session request to 192.168.0.2 failed (Called name not present)

session request to *SMBSERVER failed (Called name not present)

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Wed Aug  7 00:26:05 2002

list members.  Specifically Jurgen.  :-)

I got a roughly 50% speed incrase, in launch and general things.  I
don't know how much rendering of HTML sped up, if at all.  This is over
the stock Mozilla binaries distributed with Slackware.

So here's what I did.  For starters, I set up my uuber-optimized CFLAGS,
CXXFLAGS, LIBCFLAGS, and BOOT_CFLAGS...

CXXFLAGS="-O9 -s -mcpu=i686 -march=i686"
LIBCFLAGS=$CXXFLAGS
BOOT_CFLAGS=$CXXFLAGS
CFLAGS="-O9 -s -funroll-loops -ffast-math -mcpu=i686 -march=i686 \
    -fomit-frame-pointer -fno-exceptions -fschedule-insns2 \ 
    -fexpensive-optimizations"

-maligndouble caused it to seg fault during compile, so I disabled that
(which I usually use when I make my super-duper optimized programs).

For the actual config and building, I used the following (stolen
shamelessly from Chris Kassopulo from alt.os.linux.slackware):

./configure --disable-debug --disable-tests --enable-optimize \
    --enable-crypto && make
su
make install

Just make sure you set your compile variables before running
./configure.

Hope this helps somebody, I know the optimizations really sped things up
for me over the plain-jane stuff you get by default.  The launch-time
difference in itself helped a ton.  Be aware, Mozilla is a pretty big
compile.  It requires 2GB of free hard drive space and, depending on
your system, could take a *long* time.  It wasn't as bad as my optimized
KDE compiles, though!

Note; all compiles were done with GCC 2.95.  I don't know if 3.x will be
able to do the same, although I would hope they will.

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"




From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Wed Aug  7 00:37:45 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 07 Aug 2002 00:37:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Using "apt-proxy" to minimize Apt's Internet bandwidth
	useage.
In-Reply-To: <3D50C569.4030905@pacifier.com>
References: <87y9bjxkqc.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net> 
	<3D50C569.4030905@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <1028705866.9642.21.camel@duron>

On Tue, 2002-08-06 at 23:59, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> Help me understand how this is different from rsync'ing a mirror.  I admit I 
> don't have a grasp on squid either.  But isn't this just another way to 
> maintain a local mirror?

An rsync would grab all the packages.  If it didn't, you would have to
specify in advance which ones to store on the local server.

If I read the original email correctly, this essentially intercepts
apt-get requests (or debian is told to use your local server for apt-get
stuff, or both maybe like transparent squid proxying [iptables/chains
port redirects]) then checks to see if the packages is stored locally. 
If it is not stored locally, it goes to the Internet and downloads the
package on behalf of the client inside the LAN which can then use the
package.

Once the package has been downloaded once, it is cached locally so if
another client wants the same package, it is downlaoded directly from
the local server instead of going to the Internet again, which is what
you'd do without some sort of proxy/cache.

Squid does the same thing, essentially, but with webpages.  It lets you
cache them locally and with the use of squidguard you can easily filter
things out (like porn and ads).

Which reminds me of something I wanted to ask before... does the K12
LTSP(?) project provide a proxy of some sort?  If so, does it filter? 
Because the Squid/SquidGuard combo with a cron job to automatically
update blacklists ... with squid/squidgard set up for transparent
proxying ... it makes a very effective replacement for expensive
products like NetNanny or CyberPatrol.

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Wed Aug  7 01:21:50 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 07 Aug 2002 01:21:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Using "apt-proxy" to minimize Apt's Internet bandwidth useage.
In-Reply-To: <1028705866.9642.21.camel@duron>
References: <87y9bjxkqc.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	<3D50C569.4030905@pacifier.com> <1028705866.9642.21.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <87k7n3xen5.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

AthlonRob <AthlonRobNF at cs.com> writes:

> On Tue, 2002-08-06 at 23:59, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> 
> > Help me understand how this is different from rsync'ing a mirror.

Sure.

> > I admit I don't have a grasp on squid either.  But isn't this just
> > another way to maintain a local mirror?

Yes, it's obviously a way of automaticly maintaining a local mirror.
Squid is a more general purpose caching HTTP proxy.  It is not
specificly designed for the task of proxying and caching for Apt; it's
designed for caching web pages.  Squid has it's own directory layout
for the data that it caches, where "apt-proxy" uses the Debian
ftp-master archive's "package pool" layout, so that the locally cached
.deb's are locate-able by the same path sequence as on the official
Debian archive mirrors.  Squid does have a modular architecture, and
new storage backends can be written for it, but that must be done in
C.

> An rsync would grab all the packages.  If it didn't, you would have
> to specify in advance which ones to store on the local server.

Correct. The advantage of "apt-proxy" over "rsync" or "debmirror" is
that you don't have to decide in advance what packages you want to
cache locally.  You don't have to write an rsync exclude list, or
generate a package set list for debmirror.

> If I read the original email correctly, this essentially intercepts
> apt-get requests (or debian is told to use your local server for
> apt-get stuff, or both maybe like transparent squid proxying
> [iptables/chains port redirects]) then checks to see if the packages
> is stored locally. If it is not stored locally, it goes to the
> Internet and downloads the package on behalf of the client inside
> the LAN which can then use the package.

"apt-proxy" does not "intercept" the requests, and it does not really
work in the same way as a web page proxy cache like Squid does.  You
don't configure an "Acquire::http::Proxy" for Apt with "apt-proxy".
Instead, you explicitly list it in the "sources.list" file.  It
presently is not designed to work as a transparent proxy.

There are pros and cons with this approach, I suppose... I've not
thought about it enough to go there though.

There are several other Apt proxy cache projects out there.  I am not
certain which one will eventually prevail.  Probably one not even
begun yet that borrows from and refines the best feature set of
several of the others.  The big thing is apt-get install ability.  It
should be easy to make it Just Work with very little setup.  And I do
think it ought to work more like a regular web proxy...

It just occured to me that one advantage of the present "apt-proxy"
approach is that you control where the packages are actually coming
from in one place, at the proxy host, rather than in a zillion
"sources.list" files.  The "sources.list" and "preferences" can be
identical on all of your internal boxes.  You could distributed them
and maintain them using "cfengine", perhaps.

> Once the package has been downloaded once, it is cached locally so
> if another client wants the same package, it is downlaoded directly
> from the local server instead of going to the Internet again, which
> is what you'd do without some sort of proxy/cache.

Right!  If you install quite a number of machines, this represents a
quite large bandwidth and time savings!  I've been using "debootstrap"
a lot lately, to build little "user mode linux" environments to toy
with.  Without the "apt-proxy", it would take a lot longer to run
that, pulling inefficiently over and over again across my DSL line. At
Free Geek, it will be even more important to have and "apt-proxy"
configuration up and running!  Once you've primed the cache, access is
almost instant.

> Squid does the same thing, essentially, but with webpages.  It lets
> you cache them locally and with the use of squidguard you can easily
> filter things out (like porn and ads).
> 
> Which reminds me of something I wanted to ask before... does the K12
> LTSP(?) project provide a proxy of some sort?  If so, does it
> filter?  Because the Squid/SquidGuard combo with a cron job to
> automatically update blacklists ... with squid/squidgard set up for
> transparent proxying ... it makes a very effective replacement for
> expensive products like NetNanny or CyberPatrol.

karlheg at bittersweet:~
% apt-cache search squid
admwebuser - Manage Squid or Web users using a Web browser
chastity-list - blacklists for SquidGuard
jesred - A redirector for Squid
libsnmp-session-perl - Perl support for accessing SNMP-aware devices
modlogan - A modular logfile analyzer
netselect - Choose the fastest server automatically.
squidguard - filter, redirector and access controller plug for Squid
squidtaild - Squid log monitoring program
urlredir - utility for squid to perform url redirection.
calamaris - Log analyzer for Squid or Oops proxy log files
dansguardian - True web content filtering
frox - Transparent caching ftp proxy
libapache-mod-proxy-add-forward - Module for Apache which includes 'X-Forwarded-For' header
sarg - Squid Analysis Report Generator
squid - Internet Object Cache (WWW proxy cache)
squid-cgi - Squid cache manager CGI program
squidclient - Command line URL extractor that talks to (a) squid.
tinyproxy - A lightweight, non-caching, optionally anonymizing http proxy
webmin-squid - squid control module for webmin

As a goatherd learns his trade by goat, so a writer learns his trade by wrote.

karlheg at bittersweet:~
% apt-cache show squidguard
Package: squidguard
Priority: optional
Section: web
Installed-Size: 416
Maintainer: Debian QA Group <packages at qa.debian.org>
Architecture: i386
Version: 1.2.0-1
Depends: libc6 (>= 2.2.4-4), libdb3 (>= 3.2.9-15), perl, squid, liburi-perl, libwww-perl
Suggests: chastity-list
Filename: pool/main/s/squidguard/squidguard_1.2.0-1_i386.deb
Size: 129070
MD5sum: fb17396488db7a0fa97031dcc0294715
Description: filter, redirector and access controller plug for Squid
 squidGuard is a free (GPL), flexible and ultra fast filter, redirector
 and access controller plugin for squid.  It lets you define multiple
 access rules with different restrictions for different user groups on
 a squid cache.  squidGuard uses squid's standard redirector interface.

Package: chastity-list

Description: blacklists for SquidGuard
 squidGuard is a free (GPL), flexible and ultra fast filter, redirector
 and access controller plugin for squid.  It lets you define multiple
 access rules with different restrictions for different user groups on
 a squid cache.  squidGuard uses squid's standard redirector interface.
 .
 This package contains blacklists provided by the Chastity project.
 Chastity intends to make a maintained ACL-list for squid for use in
 public schools and other organizations. The projects is divided into a
 web-based adminstration tool, datastorage and client-tools.

Russ,

You're not suggesting that using and programming computers makes up for 
the loss of music and other forms of art from a child's education are 
you? As someone that did 10 years of music (mostly clarinet and 
saxophone) from 5th grade till my sophomore year in college I strongly 
disagree with your statement if you are. I don't think programming a 
computer compares to performing with other musicians in a band or 
orchestra on stage or a marching band performing a precision show on a 
football field during halftime. I know since I did all of these things 
when I was involved in various music programs in school.

I do feel that there is a certain sort of "art" and "craft" to computer 
programming but it's a different sort of art IMHO. Anyone else out 
there that was involved in band, orchestra, choir, drama, etc. in 
school? What do you think?

Tony

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Aug  7 06:17:30 2002

On 7 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> If I read the original email correctly, this essentially intercepts
> apt-get requests (or debian is told to use your local server for
> apt-get stuff, or both maybe like transparent squid proxying
> [iptables/chains port redirects]) then checks to see if the packages
> is stored locally.  If it is not stored locally, it goes to the
> Internet and downloads the package on behalf of the client inside
> the LAN which can then use the package.

Red Hat users, check out rpm-update, a Python script with similar 
functionality:

  http://www.kleemann.org/rpm-update/

It's quite configurable and can be used to maintain update trees for 
any valid combination of architectures and Red Hat release numbers.

On Wednesday 07 August 2002 08:47 am, you wrote:
> Carla Schroder <pluglist at bratgrrl.com> writes:
> > There's a rather large difference between running an honest
> > business, and doing what Microsoft does.
>
> How much of the revenue that Red Hat rakes in gets put in the pockets
> of the people who actually write and maintain the software that Red
> Hat merely PACKAGES for distribution (and sale)?

Speaking of non-sequiturs...that's a gold-medal winner. What illegal, 
strong-arm tactics has Red Hat committed? How many laws have they broken? How 
many customers have they bullied and extorted? What is your point?

Red Hat is one of the largest funders of Linux development. That's right, 
actual cash money to programmers. Can you show me where they demand royalties 
from projects they have funded? You can't- because they don't.

 When they rolled out their IPO they distributed stock grants to as many 
developers as they could find. I'm not sure what your point is- doubtless 
they have their flaws, but comparing them to Microsoft is absurd. 

Yes, they package and sell free software. They also give it away- download 
for free, dirt cheap from Cheapbytes, legally copied and distributed by 
friends. As do all of the commercial Linux distributors. If you can show me a 
gun pointed to anyone's head anywhere, I'll be quite surprised.

Carla

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Aug  7 07:42:13 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 07:42:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Unknown user?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208070631540.11880-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208070736340.1483-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 7 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> pcap:x:77:77::/var/arpwatch:/sbin/nologin
> 
> I did not add this "user" myself so I'm curious why it's there and
> what program installed it.

The pcap pseudo-user is added by the tcpdump or arpwatch rpms. Try

  rpm -q --scripts tcpdump
  rpm -q --scripts arpwatch

btw: 'rpm -q --scripts' is a tremendously useful query. I use it on 
uninstalled packages ('rpm -q --scripts -p blah.rpm') to figure out to 
what extent they're going to mess with my system :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed Aug  7 08:35:53 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 08:35:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Using "apt-proxy" to minimize Apt's Internet bandwidth useage.
References: <87y9bjxkqc.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>	<3D50C569.4030905@pacifier.com> <1028705866.9642.21.camel@duron> <87k7n3xen5.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <3D513E59.3030007@sun.com>

I have also successfully simply shared via NFS my 
/var/cache/apt/archives directory on my fileserver and mounted it on the 
other satellite systems.

However, now that Karl has given me some good examples of how to setup 
apt-proxy, I'll probably migrate.  It's much easier to modify my 
sources.list file than manually grab packages because the 2.2r5 version 
of package x doesn't play nice.  ;)

-R

Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> 
> Correct. The advantage of "apt-proxy" over "rsync" or "debmirror" is
> that you don't have to decide in advance what packages you want to
> cache locally.  You don't have to write an rsync exclude list, or
> generate a package set list for debmirror.

From miker at netsailer.com  Wed Aug  7 07:42:31 2002
From: miker at netsailer.com (Mike Russell)
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 07:42:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Unknown user?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208070631540.11880-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20020807071507.01d357a8@pop3.norton.antivirus>

It is the arpwatch demean, if you install arpwatch, it will use this user 
to send you arp info. my earlier post about "two ethn in one box error" was 
concerning this. I later found that my problem was on how I had my network 
wired up to the new router, I received email's every two minuets from 
pcap at mydomain.com until I fixed the issue.
example;
arpwatch: flip 
flop     the.ip.add.ress         the:mac:add:ress:xx 
(the:mac:add:ress:switch:from)

the issue was, I received an error that some other host had my IP address 
when I init'ed my eth0. then i would receive an arpwatch email from my 
other server telling me that the MAC address has changed for the IP 
address. I don't have enough TCP/IP knowledge to explain, but it happened 
when i had both sides of the router plugged into the same HUB with 
different IP blocks ( 10.10..1.x/24 and 209.162.208.x/24). I believe it had 
something to do with having the same subnet-mask. I thought they would 
ignore each other, my bad.

I hope I answered your question, and would appreciate any explanation of my 
TCP/IP issue.

mike

>>>>> "Tyler" == Tyler F Creelan <creelan at engr.orst.edu> writes:

Russell> I did some thinking about an ultimately unfunded problem of
Russell> rapidly computing distance to nearest surface of a set of
Russell> arbitrary scaled/translated geometric primitives (at
Russell> successive steps of a random walk).  If anyone has any
Russell> particular insight into efficient solutions, I am all ears.

Tyler> I understand this can already be solved in O(n) or O(log n)
Tyler> time. What level of improvement would your solution represent?

Sorry that I wasn't more clear.  I didn't _have_ a solution per se, I
was looking for a solution for a particular application.  If you've
got pointers, I'd love to hear about them.  I am also interested in
solutions to the related but more complex problem of computing nearest
distance to the surface of shapes defined in a constructive solid
geometry (e.g. ellipsoid with an off-center cylinder removed).  There
seems to be a lot of literature on drawing such shapes, ray tracing
and the like, but a lot less on the nearest-distance computation.  At
least, I had trouble finding much that I understood enough to tell if
it was applicable.

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Aug  7 09:32:35 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 09:32:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft school opens in Gresham
In-Reply-To: <87ofcfvywi.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
References: <200208062226.g76MQF309336@smtp.easystreet.com>

Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020807092726.01afa0d8@localhost>

So are you saying that Redhat (or any other entity) shouldn't be 
compensated for what they do?

The developers choose to give it away.

Redhat also gives away a significant amount of their work. Those that pay 
for it are CHOOSING to pay for it. The GPL specifically give them that 
right, and it's working.

I don't see any problem with this.

Redhat also creates some of the software used in their distribution. A case 
in point is the installer. They give that away too. Several other 
distributions use the same installer, or a branch thereof.

At 01:47 AM 8/7/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>How much of the revenue that Red Hat rakes in gets put in the pockets
>of the people who actually write and maintain the software that Red
>Hat merely PACKAGES for distribution (and sale)?

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208070850590.12170-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 7 Aug 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> btw: 'rpm -q --scripts' is a tremendously useful query. I use it on 
> uninstalled packages ('rpm -q --scripts -p blah.rpm') to figure out to 
> what extent they're going to mess with my system :-)

  Thanks, Paul. I've always used 'rpm -qip <packagename>' to query an
installed package; wasn't aware of the --scripts option. Good to know.

Rich

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Aug  7 11:13:21 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 11:13:21 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Optimal distro for dual-boot?
In-Reply-To: <3d50ba0e.298f.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208071101350.2559-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

On Tue, 6 Aug 2002, stuart mathews wrote:

> I've been told that Caldera is probably the best distro for setting up a dual-boot
> system.  Is there any merit to this?
>

I second Karl's response to this.

Any of the major distros should do fine.  I don't normally dual boot,
but I'm sure I've used Slackware and SuSE in dual boot systems; and
I think I've used SLS, RedHat, and Debian at times as well.

The major considerations are:

    -  Having a boot manager like lilo or grub that supports both OSs.
       (You can get around this by booting from floppies or CDs.)

    -  Having support for the non-Linux OS's filesystems in your Linux
       kernel.  You may also want support for your Linux filesystems
       in the other OS - if you trust the other OS's security - and
       you can find and afford software in the other OS to do this.
       (This isn't a hard and fast requirement, but it makes file
       transfers between the OSs easier.)


                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel

   ======================================================================
   David Mandel, Product Manager       http://www.MicroSharp.com
                          Other Affiliations
   David Mandel                        http://www.DavidMandel.com
   Portland Linux/Unix Group           http://pdxLinux.org
   LinuxFund                           http://LinuxFund.org
   ======================================================================

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Aug  7 10:12:48 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 07 Aug 2002 10:12:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Old cdrom drivers?
In-Reply-To: <20020807160725.28089.qmail@web14403.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20020807160725.28089.qmail@web14403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1028740368.20643.3.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>

On Wed, 2002-08-07 at 09:07, Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour wrote:
> If it's really old, it might be plugged into a Creative Labs or
> MediaVision
> soundcard with a stripped down Trantor SCSI controller on it. Check
> the howtos on Sound/SCSI, I've never had to make that combo work.

You have to determine what kind of interface it uses.  There is a
section in the kernel config for "non-ide cd-rom interfaces".  You have
to enable that section and pick which interface you need.

You will have to recompile the kernel to get this to work.  Those drives
are pretty rare anymore. They have not been made for many years.  (I
used to have a panasonic drive that worked off a sound blaster card.)

If you need specific help on this, contact me off list. I can help you
figure out how to make it work.

> 
> Sean Harbour
> 
> --- Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> wrote:
> > > Hi there, 
> > > 
> > > I was wondering if I could find an old Toshiba cdrom driver for
> > Linux.I am trying to turn one of our old PC's into a Linux terminal
> > for another machine.The PC used to go bi-booth Linux/windows
> > 3.11.The CD rom is Toshiba XM-3701TM.I can hardly find
> > > anything specific for this drive, not even mention Linux stuff.
> > Could you offer some advice on that?
> > > 
> > 
> > It looks like the XM-3701 is a SCSI drive.  Is there a SCSI
> > controller 
> > installed in the machine?  If so, you will just need the
> > appropriate
> > driver for the SCSI controller.
> > 
> > galen
> >

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Aug  7 10:15:51 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 07 Aug 2002 10:15:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Unknown user?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208070631540.11880-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208070631540.11880-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1028740551.20643.6.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>

On Wed, 2002-08-07 at 06:34, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I get warnings in my postfix daily report of a difference between
> /etc/passwd and /var/spool/postfix/etc/passwe. Turns out that the former has
> this user entry:
> 
> pcap:x:77:77::/var/arpwatch:/sbin/nologin
> 
> and the latter doesn't.
> 
>   I did not add this "user" myself so I'm curious why it's there and what
> program installed it.

Looks like you installed arpwatch after you installed postfix.

If you are not using arpwatch, you should uninstall it.  It forces your
network card into promiscuous mode.
 




From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Wed Aug  7 11:46:51 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 11:46:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Compiling Mozilla
In-Reply-To: <1028705166.9642.12.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208071132180.3937-100000@joan.burling.com>

On 7 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> I searched high and low looking for info when I wanted to recompile
> Mozilla... I finally got it working with the help of the Slackware-OT
> list members.  Specifically Jurgen.  :-)
>
> I got a roughly 50% speed incrase, in launch and general things.  I
> don't know how much rendering of HTML sped up, if at all.  This is over
> the stock Mozilla binaries distributed with Slackware.
>
> So here's what I did.  For starters, I set up my uuber-optimized CFLAGS,
> CXXFLAGS, LIBCFLAGS, and BOOT_CFLAGS...
>
> CXXFLAGS="-O9 -s -mcpu=i686 -march=i686"
> LIBCFLAGS=$CXXFLAGS
> BOOT_CFLAGS=$CXXFLAGS
> CFLAGS="-O9 -s -funroll-loops -ffast-math -mcpu=i686 -march=i686 \
>     -fomit-frame-pointer -fno-exceptions -fschedule-insns2 \
>     -fexpensive-optimizations"
>
> -maligndouble caused it to seg fault during compile, so I disabled that
> (which I usually use when I make my super-duper optimized programs).

Tres cool. I've been fighting the same fight on my own, but haven't thought
of fiddling with the *FLAGS options. Guess I'll have to try this tonight
(set up the compile, type ``make all" & go to bed).
>
> For the actual config and building, I used the following (stolen
> shamelessly from Chris Kassopulo from alt.os.linux.slackware):
>
> ./configure --disable-debug --disable-tests --enable-optimize \
>     --enable-crypto && make

My last configure command was as follows:

./configure  --enable-toolkit-xlib --disable-mailnews --disable-ldap --disable-debug --enable-crypto

(I disabled mailnews & ldap because I don't see the point of them.)

One bit of trouble I had was to get Moz to access pages protected with some
level of security -- the infamous ``you need to install the Personal
Security Module" error message. This was especially annoying since I had
downloaded the 1.0 source code direct from their web site, & I was
expecting this section of code to be included. What I found I had to do
was unpack that bit of code inside the Mozilla source tree, then run
./configure with all of the switches.

Maybe that was obvious to some folk, but I spent a few weeks trying to
find the solution. And compiling Mozilla at each attempt slowed things
further.

> su
> make install
>
I don't know if I'd go this far. I did a ``make all" & have been running
the binary from where the compile built it. Not entirely out of laziness:
Mozill acores for me when I try to launch it from where it gets installed.

(And if you have a solution, don't post it here: add it to the entry
under Mozilla Bug #153758).

Geoff

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Aug  7 12:18:01 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 12:18:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Shatter Attacks - How to break Windows
In-Reply-To: <005201c23e0b$4d888470$0400a8c0@oem2k>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208071150270.27926-100000@silver.CS.ORST.EDU> <005201c23e0b$4d888470$0400a8c0@oem2k>
Message-ID: <200208071218.01580.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Hasn't Microsoft provided some security patches for this behavior in 
OutLook? I recall my wife having a difficult time when one of her 
classmates emailed her a program and OutLook seemed to put the 
attachment in the bit bucket. We ended up using my email address and I 
saved the executable attachment from KMail instead. I don't know what 
OutLook is doing but there are times when you might need the ability to 
receive an executable attachment and don't want your email client to 
bit bucket the the thing.

I haven't really looked at OutLook to see if I can turn this behavior 
off or not. At least with Linux I can save off the file on our 
fileserver and then I can then virus scan the file with Norton 
Anti-Virus before allowing anyone else to access the file.

Tony

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Wed Aug  7 12:59:59 2002

Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 19:59:59 GMT
Subject: [PLUG] KDE Woes
Message-ID: <200208071958.g77Jwl3X017697@franka.aracnet.com>

 
I have my wife's system set up to use KDE 2.x and lately she's having a lot of
problems with it.  Applications (like Konqueror and Kmail) don't want to start,
but they start in her login, but they start fine for me when I'm logged into
that system.  I suspect that she crashed something that left some files
around,so I deleted the .MCOP* and .DCOP* files that were in her home directory,
but no luck.  I even went into .kde and some of it's subdirectories and deleted
a few things that looked safe to delete (I'm real careful in there 'cuz she
won't be happy if I lose her mail/browser configurations ;-).... but still no
luck, I can't figure out what is different about her login that's keeping these
applications from starting.

Any ideas? 

(BTW: What's all this mcop dcop stuff anyway?)

Phil




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Aug  7 13:22:18 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 13:22:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] KDE Woes
In-Reply-To: <200208071958.g77Jwl3X017697@franka.aracnet.com>
References: <200208071958.g77Jwl3X017697@franka.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <200208071322.18636.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Is her PATH or LD_LIBRARY_PATH environment variables modified in some 
way that hose KDE? Compare them with the ones that work for your 
userid.

Tony

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Wed Aug  7 13:36:20 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 07 Aug 2002 13:36:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla was:Linux at Intel
In-Reply-To: <1028748657.2300.31.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208062124360.28000-100000@lukem.com> 
	<3D50A51D.6000801@pacifier.com>  <1028705166.9642.12.camel@duron> 
	<1028748657.2300.31.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <1028752582.11159.8.camel@duron>

On Wed, 2002-08-07 at 12:30, Brent Rieck wrote:
> On Wed, 2002-08-07 at 00:26, AthlonRob wrote:
> > I got a roughly 50% speed incrase, in launch and general things.  I
> > don't know how much rendering of HTML sped up, if at all.  This is over
> > the stock Mozilla binaries distributed with Slackware.
> 
> Out of curiosity, do you know how your sped up Mozilla compares with
> Galeon for speed?

On startup time they're about on par with each other.

In everything else, Galeon is faster.  Things like java applets start up
about twice as fast in Galeon.  It also seems less 'heavy'.  But, there
are still a few things Galeon doesn't do.  It doesn't seem to work with
all javascript I've run in to, so for some sites I fire up Moz.  As far
as just speed is concerned, though, Galeon seems to beat out Mozilla
hands-down.

I don't know if my speeding up Moz would have sped up Galeon, because I
didn't ever even use Galeon until after I had Mozilla optimized.  I
really don't like gnome, and as such have only learned of gnome-type
applications through chance encounters.  I prefer them over the KDE sets
only because they're sooooo much faster loading up.  KDE apps all seem
to start up half of KDE with them.  Might as well just load up Win4Lin! 

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Wed Aug  7 13:50:17 2002

try your .kde directory as her (back hers up, copy yours over), if that
works you at least know where to look. Then you can manually rebuild her
settings from an empty .kde dir. (try with defaults, then copy over the
Kmail settings, if that breaks it then delv into kmail details...)

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Wed Aug  7 13:51:37 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 13:51:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] KDE Woes
In-Reply-To: <200208071958.g77Jwl3X017697@franka.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208071346560.8170-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Make a backup of the folders in her home dir that start with . and the
files too.  Then delete them all.  If it works then you know that the
problem is in one of those directories and you can start adding them back
until there is a problem.  Like a binary search...Somewhat slow, but it
can save time if you're initial hypothesis is wrong.

Just becareful when you backup those files.  You don't accidentally want
to add ./ and ../ to your backup.

HTH,
Jason

From jon at manymoons.net  Wed Aug  7 13:58:50 2002
From: jon at manymoons.net (Jon Jacob)
Date: 07 Aug 2002 13:58:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Usermod: adding a user to a group
Message-ID: <1028753930.7991.1008.camel@lana.manymoons.net>

I guess it has been awhile since I have done this, but when I do:

usermod -G league jon

to add me (jon) to the league group, nothing happens.  I do not get an
error message, but I also am not added to the group.  League does exist
as a group, and I do exist as a user.  So, why does this not work, and
how do I get it to work.

From don at truedisk.com  Wed Aug  7 14:15:39 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 14:15:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Usermod: adding a user to a group
References: <1028753930.7991.1008.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <3D518DFB.E9635639@truedisk.com>

Jon Jacob wrote:
> 
> I guess it has been awhile since I have done this, but when I do:
> 
> usermod -G league jon
> 
> to add me (jon) to the league group, nothing happens.  I do not get an
> error message, but I also am not added to the group.  League does exist
> as a group, and I do exist as a user.  So, why does this not work, and
> how do I get it to work.
> 

What does 'grep league /etc/group' show?
You just about have to logout/login again to inherit
newly-added group privileges.

Caveat:  The usermod(8) manpage cautions that, as shown above,
this command will remove you from all other groups!

   -G group,[...]
       A list of supplementary groups which the user is also
       a member of.  Each group is separated from the next by
       a comma, with no intervening whitespace.  The groups
       are subject to the same restrictions as the group given
       with the -g option.  If the user is currently a member
       of a group which is not listed, the user will be removed
       from the group

(I can't say I like that aspect of this command.)

- Don



From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Wed Aug  7 14:16:45 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (E. Rogan Creswick)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 14:16:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Usermod: adding a user to a group
In-Reply-To: <1028753930.7991.1008.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208071413590.29003-100000@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

if league dosen't appear when you run "groups" as jon, you may need to
logout and log backin. If that still dosen't help, check the group file.

cat /etc/group | grep league
or
ypcat ....

If you aren't in the group file then you may have a problem with the
command line you use.. (I can never remember the commands, so I edit
/etc/group manually <duck>).

-Rogan

Don't delete them as root either...
rm -rf .*
is a _bad_ command when it comes to the ../ directory.
(try ls .* in your home dir as any user, and notice that it lists ../)
