From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Aug  7 14:09:21 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 14:09:21 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OO question
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208071405410.12897-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I know we have some OpenOffice-1.0 users here and I'm sure you're more
experienced than I am, so I'll ask.

  Is there a way to convert the font (typeface and point size) in one, easy
step? This on a document imported from winWord, generally. That is, must I
block all 93 pages of an appendix to change from Times to Bitstream Amerigo
and from 12 point to 10 point?

  Also, is there a way to change the document's line justification from
ragged-right to fully justified again without blocking the whole thing?

TIA,

Rich




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Aug  7 14:39:47 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 14:39:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] KDE Woes
In-Reply-To: <200208071958.g77Jwl3X017697@franka.aracnet.com>
References: <200208071958.g77Jwl3X017697@franka.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <200208071439.47434.aschlemm@attbi.com>

The other thing to do is to rename the .kde2 subdirectory in your wife's 
home directory to something like .kde2.save. KDE should then create a 
new .kde2 directory when it is first started up. You could then just 
find the KMail and Konqueror configuration files and copy them from the 
old .kde2 directory.

I notice too that KDE spits out a lot of messages in the 
.xsession-errors file in a user's home directory. You could try looking 
at the file and see if there are any useful error messages in it. Most 
of the messages don't make any sense but you never know.

Tony

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Wed Aug  7 15:03:24 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (E. Rogan Creswick)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 15:03:24 -0700 (PDT)

From raanders at acm.org  Wed Aug  7 15:53:52 2002

Two things.
   Are you using 1.0?  I understand 1.0.1 fixes several problems but not
sure if this was one of them.
   Have you tried Edit -> Find & Replace -> [Attributes]

I don't have a document to test on but this 'kind-of' looks like where you 
need to go.
   There was also a message on the OOo [discuss] list about using a text
editor on the XML file to do a search and replace.

From don at truedisk.com  Wed Aug  7 15:57:36 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 15:57:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Usermod: adding a user to a group
References: <mailman.1028755030.21096.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <3D5194E9.81DAA349@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <3D51A5E0.48202CEB@truedisk.com>

Mike Witt wrote:
> 
> "E. Rogan Creswick" wrote:
> > (I can never remember the commands, so I edit
> > /etc/group manually <duck>).
> 
> I have always just edited /etc/group manually. Is there
> any reason not to do this?
> 

The theory is that a utility program can:
   (a) lock the database files (e.g. /etc/group + /etc/gshadow,
       or /etc/passwd + /etc/shadow) to keep two simultaneous
       hand-edit sessions stepping on each other.
   (b) from accidentally corrupting the file (which, in some
       cases can keep a system from running).

In the real world, with your own desktop Linux system, "No,
there is no reason an experienced Unix admin can't hand-edit
his passwd/group files."  Production environments should
probably work with the tool sets.

My $0.02.

- Don

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Aug  7 16:30:06 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 16:30:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Lost Partition
In-Reply-To: <3D51AA22.7010703@sun.com>
References: <20020807225518.GA21950@blain.org> <200208071609.53882.aschlemm@attbi.com> <3D51AA22.7010703@sun.com>
Message-ID: <200208071630.06198.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Formatting a partition in Linux usually entails creating a new file 
system on the specified partition. That operation overwrites all of the 
existing information that previously existed in that partition as far 
as I know. I'm not sure what information would be left to allow 
recovery of the data after such an operation occurred on a partition. 
I'm very happy if I am indeed wrong here.

On Wednesday 07 August 2002 16:15 pm, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:
> Are you sure?  I thought it simply overwrote the table that tells the
> disk where everything is/was (in MSDOS-terms, the FAT).
>
> If recovery or rebuilding is possible, you *should* be able to access
> the data once again.
>
> -R

Greetings all,

 I have recently completed downloading all the Debian
3.0 ISO's and will be burning what I call 'newbie
coasters'. These are just CD's with the ISO images as
files (eg /mnt/cdrom/debian-1.iso). I would be willing
to loan out these discs for anyone who wants to burn a
copy of the Debian CD's. There are 16 discs. 8 are
i386 and 8 are source. There are the usual NONUS and
normal disc 1 for each binary and source. So, that
makes a 7 disc set for i386 and a 7 disc set for
source.

[begin quasi-commercialized section of message]

(to cover the cost of the CD's and Sleeves, plus a $1
donation to the debian project). This is for a
complete source and i386 set, with the choice of a
NONUS or normal disc 1.

[end quasi-commercialized section of message]

open.

I'm also thinking about those specialized data recovery places that 
charge exorbitant rates to recover data from physically damaged or 
otherwise screwed up platters.  It's one thing if your 'format' command 
actually writes null data to the disk, quite another if it simply erases 
the pointers to files and simply claims the disk is 'empty'.

-R

From dealy at deatech.com  Wed Aug  7 17:24:15 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 17:24:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OO question
In-Reply-To: <1028757572.22618.66.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208071718120.28605-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On 7 Aug 2002, Shahms E. King wrote:

> Hmm.  Well, since the OpenOffice(.org) file format is gzip'd XML, I'm
> betting you can zcat it through a script that'll do it for you, or you
[snip]

This won't work, it's not gziped XML, it's XML whose field contents have
been compressed (I don't specifically remember if it's gzip, though I
assume so).  There is supposedly a method that can be used to get
XML/text out of the file, but it's not a simple export/save-as (which it
should be) and I haven't had time to try it.

> > subdirectories and deleted a few things that looked safe to delete (I'm
> > real careful in there 'cuz she won't be happy if I lose her mail/browser
> > configurations ;-).... but still no luck, I can't figure out what is
> > different about her login that's keeping these applications from starting.
> >
> > Any ideas?
> >
> > (BTW: What's all this mcop dcop stuff anyway?)
> >
> > Phil
> 
> I use same version of KDE. Recently, I tried to start Galeon and it just gave 
> up.  When I tried it from a console window, it said: "Segmentation Fault".  
> Being an old Windows user, I rebooted and it worked! Who knows?
 
No, rebooting has no effect.  Like I said, they'll start up fine when I'm logged
in.  When started from her login, though, if I do it from a command line I get
something like "can't connect to DCOP server" or some such (I'm not at home to
try it at the moment).  In the past all I had to do was remove some files in her
home directory that were named .DCOP* .MCOP* and all was well, but now it's not
working...

Phil

/etc/samba/smb.conf
# Samba config file created using SWAT

# Date: 2002/08/05 16:52:24

# Global parameters
[global]
         workgroup = SEC
         security = SHARE
         guest account = IWILL

[test]
         comment = test share
         path = /test
      writable = yes
      browseable = yes
         follow symlinks = yes
         wide links = yes
         public = yes
         read only = No
         guest ok = Yes
         guest only = Yes

nameserver 210.0.144.66
nameserver 210.0.144.26
search localdomain

(This is the original file when I first started Samba_Server without any 
alternation.  I have no idea what are those nameservers ????????)


At 12:10 PM 8/7/2002 -0700, Derek Loree wrote:
> > New file (/etc/hosts)
> > # Do not remove the following line, or various programs
> > # that require network functionality will fail.
> > 192.198.0.2     localhost.IWILL
> > 127.0.0.1       localhost.M2    localhost.localdomain
>
>This entry won't work, it says you have a machine called localhost in a
>domain called IWILL.  Do this instead:
>
>192.168.0.2     IWILL

Re-edit  /etc/hosts  according to your advice
# Do not remove the following line, or various programs
# that require network functionality will fail.
192.168.0.2     IWILL
127.0.0.1       localhost.M2    localhost.localdomain

(Again, I have no idea of  "127.0.0.1 localhost.M2 localhost.localdomain" 
???????   It was there when I first started Samba_Server)

From dealy at deatech.com  Wed Aug  7 18:36:17 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 18:36:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Lost Partition
In-Reply-To: <200208071630.06198.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208071730000.28605-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Wed, 7 Aug 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> Formatting a partition in Linux usually entails creating a new file
> system on the specified partition. That operation overwrites all of the
> existing information that previously existed in that partition as far
[snip]

No it does not, formating only creates the tables used to describe the
file system layout.  If you run a bad block scan as part of your reformat,
it - may - destroy all data on the partition, I don't know the specifics of
how the Linux block scan operates, though it is not specifically necessary
for it to destroy data.  Now of course, the new format tables and their
backup copies may destroy a small portion of your data when the partition
is reformatted, but the remainder of your data is there, the only question is
how difficult it will be to piece it together.  Unfortunately, while I
have gone through file recovery of this sort on other computers, I have
never done it on Linux (previous bad experiences ensured that I always
have very good backup systems and proceedures these days), though I have
heard of utilities to do it.  You could look around for Linux data and
partition recovery utilities, file system editors, and undelete programs.
One possible approach is if you can reformat the partition to the same
EXACT format it had before (be aware that there is an old and a new
version of ext2 format, if that was your old format, you probably need to
use the same one), then try running some kind of undelete program.
Probably most recovery methods are going to need the file system format to
be restored to what it was before by reformatting, though I suppose it's
possible that your old format may have stored it's backup tables in
different locations from your new format, in which case it might be better
to try to find/use those rather than reformatting again.

If you have the excess disk capacity available (and are running newer
kernel and tools that support files larger than 2 Gigabytes if your
partition is 2+ gig in size), you could copy the entire raw partition
to a file as a backup copy in case you mess it up, or as your primary copy
to work on while you go ahead and use the partition if you need it
immediately.  For backup copies, you will probably want to pipe them
through gzip to save space.

FWIW

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

On Wed, 7 Aug 2002, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:

> I'm also thinking about those specialized data recovery places that 
> charge exorbitant rates to recover data from physically damaged or 
> otherwise screwed up platters.  It's one thing if your 'format' command 
> actually writes null data to the disk, quite another if it simply erases 
> the pointers to files and simply claims the disk is 'empty'.

  Interesting point, Richard. I wonder if any of 'em can handle anything but
a Microsoft partition. They all use Microsoft tools, after all.

From satimis at writeme.com  Wed Aug  7 20:31:01 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Thu, 08 Aug 2002 11:31:01 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] Samba server can't see WinME (PROBLEM SOLVED)
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20020808112826.02aecb78@pop.net-yan.com>

Hi Derek,

Further to my posting of today.

******* Problem Solved Now ********

It is CASE SENSITIVE !!!!!

#smbclient -t smbfs //IWILL/SHARED /mnt/WinME/
[password]		[ENTER]

ignoring the password then it works.

Lot of thanks for your advice, particularly, /etc/hosts file  I almost 
surrendered.

Now my next step is to test "PRINTER" on Samba_Server

Have you had any comment on following entry to be made to 
/etc/samba/smb.conf ???

[printers]
comment = All Printers
path = /var/spool/samba
browseable = yes
guest ok = yes
writable = yes
printable = yes

Thanks in advance

Stephen

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Aug  7 21:15:23 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 7 Aug 2002 21:15:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Usermod: adding a user to a group
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208072019030.9360-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208072019030.9360-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <200208072115.23416.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Another way out of this problem would be booting from some sort of 
"rescue" floppy or CD. For my SuSE systems I usually boot from CD 1 to 
get into a "rescue" mode. This feature saved me big time after I 
installed a new kernel on one system and I forgot to create a ramdisk 
image with all of the kernel modules. 

My system was DOA when it couldn't load the module for the SCSI 
controller. :O

Tony

From gh at us.ibm.com  Wed Aug  7 22:50:47 2002

Subject: [PLUG] How to explain benefits of Linux for corporate

             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208021013060.12525-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <E17cgC7-0006CZ-00@w-gerrit2>

In message <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208021013060.12525-100000 at appl-ecosys.com>, > : Rich Shepard writes:
> On Fri, 2 Aug 2002, Terry Griffin wrote:
> 
> > Bottom Line: It's about *control*, controlling your own future rather
> > than having it be controlled by some proprietary software vendor.
> > You get to decide when to upgrade and when not to. You get to decide
> > what software to include with your product and what to exclude.
> > You can decide to fix bugs on your own rather than waiting for the vendor 
> > to get around to it (if they get around to it). You get the option
> > of enhancing the software any way you see fit without having to go
> > through the vendor.
> 
> Terry,
> 
>   I agree completely. One way to frame this for executives is in terms of
> risk management. Using open source software they can manage and reduce their
> fiscal risk, liability risk and any other risk with which they are
> concerned.
> 
> Rich

And about avoiding hardware vendor lock in, application lock in, etc.
Look at IBM's strategy, for instance.  Run Linux on everything.  Look
at Sun's recent change in strategy:  also offer Linux alternatives.
HP does the same.  Dell.  Compaq.  Want one OS that runs on pretty much
every box you can buy?  Simplify costs of system administration?  Your
card not supported?  A high school kid can probably write the driver.
You need a custom OS hook?  Sure, only the development/labor cost, no
OS contract required (other than maybe ensuring your support vendor
will still provide support if you muck the kernel ;-).

Have your corporate guys call IBM or HP and ask them about the benefits.
If it is good enough for (all!) the big boys to sell, it is probably good
enough for most other corporate uses...

gerrit



From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Aug  8 00:35:58 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 00:35:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] DVD player
In-Reply-To: <20020808053749.12624.qmail@web9608.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208080031400.12891-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 7 Aug 2002, Robert Kopp wrote:
> What is the best player to use for playing DVD movies
> on Linux? I have Caldera OpenLinux, so it should not
> be distribution-specific unless for Caldera.
> (Compiling from source is, of course, not distribution-specific.)

I use MPlayer (the cvs snapshot is usually quite good -- nothing pre-0.95
is worthwhile for DVDs in my opinion).  It's pretty freakin' stable.

The dvdnav library appears to be sought by the configure script, but I
haven't determined whether or not MPlayer can actualy use it.

I also use Ogle, which fully supports DVD menu navigation.  However, my
experience with Ogle is that it is slightly unstable, a little bit slow
sometimes, and can just halt in the middle of a scene and not recover, all
the while displaying a single frame of the video without error.

I've never had any luck with VLC (Video::LAN client), but your mileage may
vary.

You can also just rip the DVD's contents with transcode and play it back
with any opendivx player.  There is some loss in this approach, however.

J.

From guy1656 at ados.com  Thu Aug  8 07:00:05 2002
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 07:00:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Neat Bit from 'Linux on Intel'
Message-ID: <20020808134649.D1A3535F91@ados.com>

http://www-1.ibm.com/linux/news/michos.shtml

Linux on Intel: A Battle IBM will Win

June 2002

Most people now know that the success of Linux is important to IBM, and have 
heard about IBM's $1 billion Linux investment. But inside IBM's Linux push, a 
key battle is being fought on the Intel Architecture. Rich Michos, IBM Vice 
President of Linux Servers, was recently asked why the battle for Linux on 
Intel is so important to IBM, and how IBM plans to win on this strategically 
important architecture. Here's what he had to say.

Question: Rich, thanks for talking to us about IBM? and Intel. Let me begin 
by asking you why the Intel architecture so important to IBM?

Michos: The Intel platform is the fastest-growing hardware platform in the 
server business, and with IA-64 we're beginning to see greater penetration of 
Intel servers into enterprise computing. This comes at a time when Linux has 
moved out of the universities, away from just doing file, print and other 
basic infrastructure work, and into the enterprise. Linux is showing growth 
that's about four times that of Windows?, and its adoption rate far surpasses 
that of any other operating environment.

Over the past few years, we've adopted open standards for many of the things 
that we do inside of IBM. We have done this at the behest of our customers, 
who have an increasing need for integration. Open standards allow people to 
do other things as well. Our ability to use the Internet is largely based on 
the standardization of protocols like TCP/IP and HTML. We see XML allowing 
applications and processes to share data. We see people utilizing Java? as 
the standard platform for application development. Now, we see in Linux and 
Intel the standardization of operating system services and microprocessors.

We also believe that as the proliferation of Intel architecture and Linux 
continues, Intel/Linux will draw more applications, and increasing the number 
of applications will further propel volumes. All the while, the relative 
performance of Intel/Linux will continue to improve vs. the other 
alternatives. So in the end, Linux on Intel is a big winner.

But it's not enough just to have an Intel/Linux play. We believe shipping 
Intel/Linux high-volume is critical to IBM. As you know, Sun is a major 
competitor of ours and they've challenged us a bit over the past years.

Now, Sun has organized themselves around a low-volume strategy that's built 
on the Solaris operating system and SPARC microprocessor technology. We think 
that eventually, as the number of deployed Intel/Linux systems runs away, Sun 
may begin to struggle to keep a competitive application stack and competitive 
pricing, even in the enterprise. This will not happen to us.

Question: What does the increasing growth of Intel architecture mean to IBM 
and to its platform strategy?

Michos: It means we intend to dominate this Intel space, and use high-volume 
strategies to get them out the door.

We were in this game early, and we've benefited by working very closely with 
Intel. In fact, we've substantially contributed to optimizing Linux on the 
64-bit Intel architecture. And we're leveraging IBM research and the many 
technologies that we've developed over the years, and applying them in the 
Intel server space to give customers compelling reasons to prefer IBM's Intel 
solutions. We don't change the microprocessor. We get the microprocessor from 
Intel, but we make the processor do more.

At the center of this effort is X-Architecture? on Intel, and Project eLiza?. 
Mainframe-like partitioning and virtualization on Intel to allow one system 
to run different operating systems, or several instances of the same one. 
This eases integration in homogeneous environments, and enables server 
consolidation on larger Intel-based systems. We've also built features into 
our implementations to greatly enhance I/O. And the adaptive, self-healing 
technologies of Project eLiza predict, isolate and manage failures to 
minimize downtime.

On systems like the x440, customers can easily plan for growth. The x440 will 
let a customer scale from a 4-way to 16-way by simply adding and connecting 
4-processor nodes. We recently announced our easy-to-use Linux Web hosting 
appliances that can be deployed in minutes, and host multiple Web sites on a 
single server at a low cost. And with our upcoming Intel-based Blades 
solution, you'll be able to put literally hundreds of processors in a very 
small footprint, all centrally managed by IBM Director. That becomes very 
compelling for hosting Web applications, and for people that are supplying 
e-utility services. It means that they can manage hundreds of the blade 
servers from a single point of control, and at a fraction of the cost of a 
server farm.

We will continue to distinguish ourselves by not only having 
price-competitive blade offerings, but we'll be able to offer world-class 
systems design and microprocessor packaging. As the volumes will go up, we'll 
continue to ride those curves.

Question: These benefits are mostly hardware and architectural 
differentiators, and that's great. But where does Linux come in? How does it 
help IBM, and why should customers prefer our Intel/Linux solutions to those 
of our competitors?

Michos: One of the challenges we've had over the years is that the world of 
application development has not centered around IBM. ISVs have been writing 
their applications on either Windows, or on UNIX?, where Solaris was 
prevalent. So it's become incumbent upon IBM to find a way to motivate 
application developers to port their applications to IBM operating 
environments. Because Linux runs on everybody's technology, including all of 
IBM's eServers, adopting Linux neutralizes the significance of the operating 
system, and helps position IBM as the platform and vendor of choice due to 
IBM's advantages in technology and support.

By developing for Linux, ISVs can spend more money on function and less money 
on porting. It mitigates any advantage that some of our competitors might 
have had in the past. As we mentioned before, high volume will inevitably 
draw more applications, which in turn will drive even higher volume. It's a 
cycle that feeds back on itself.

Another challenge we've faced has been that he who controls the application 
development environment can also do things like control partnerships for tool 
vendors, and influence the target platform. So just as we have supported 
Apache for web servers, Linux as the open standard for operating systems, and 
Java as the standard development language we have brought vendor-independence 
to the Linux and Windows application development space by open-sourcing $40 
million of code to the Eclipse project. This permits any and all ISVs to 
integrate their developer tools into a vendor-neutral platform.

Linux technical enablements like this are important and necessary, but 
enablement by itself hasn't been enough to motivate enterprise Linux 
adoption. CTOs and IT-directors are a very risk-adverse group. So to complete 
the picture, it's been necessary to back up technical enablement with 
dependable, reliable Linux service and support to let our customers know it 
will be safe to take advantages of the value Linux offers.

Our customers mustn't be confused by all the shouting going on in the 
marketplace about service and support. IBM Global Services Organization (IGS) 
has done several things that make IBM stand out. They have Linux principals 
and practices in every geography. They have a complete portfolio of Linux 
offerings. And the ATS (Advanced Technical Support) organization, the 
technical services arm of IGS and their deep Linux competency, is a real 
asset.

IGS has also recently announced an agreement with SuSE that to a great extent 
allows IGS and SuSE to interoperate as one team. We can act as each other's 
contractors, for example. And we have a two-year technology agreement with 
SuSE to tightly fit the SuSE Linux Enterprise Server product to all of IBM 
eServers.

So in many ways, though technology has helped enable our Linux move into the 
enterprise, it's the IBM brand and the solid reputation of IGS that have been 
pushing it out the door and into enterprise deployments.

Question: You mentioned Web appliances. How do you see IBM's new Web 
appliance play stacking up against the Sun Cobalt appliance servers? After 
all, Sun was first to market.

Michos: Sun's acquisition of Cobalt bought them first into the Linux server 
appliance space, but Linux is still marginalized inside Sun because they 
don't really view Linux as core to their business. They know it's a threat, 
but they haven't quite figured out what to do about it and they're sorting it 
all out now, sometimes in public. Consider that every day, for ten years, 
when a Sun rep or reseller woke up in the morning, the story has been Solaris 
on the low end, Solaris in the middle and Solaris on the high end.

Sun will more than likely leverage Linux in competitive situations when they 
have to. In numerous cases we have removed dozens of Sun servers and replaced 
them with one or two IBM machines, running Linux. That has to be very 
frightening for them.

Question: How do we plan to move our Intel solutions into the marketplace?

Michos: There are several ways that we are delivering Linux/Intel. We are 
working to move more IBM Intel-based offerings into existing accounts, 
stepping up direct sales on the Web, leveraging the partner channel to extend 
our reach into the SMB space; and working with Software Group and their 
partners to accelerate xSeries Intel sales.

There is a misconception that we can't compete on price with our Intel 
servers. Not true. Any customers who believe this should contact their IBM 
sales rep and we'll clarify that quickly.

We will be using IBM.com to move Intel as well. Last month, we launched the 
Linux Store at www.ibm.com/linux/store that will eventually host all of IBM's 
Linux offerings. It will offer the entire xSeries server line, and feature 
the top selling xSeries server on the Linux store front page. Some people 
cede low-cost Intel to Dell, but we have now become cost competitive with 
Dell in the Intel space, and have made great strides in our ability to 
deliver through IBM.com to marginalize Dell's perceived advantage in 
fulfillment.

Beyond selling more Intel into the enterprise, and selling Intel/ Linux 
directly on the Web, we're building a value net around Linux on Intel with 
our broad community of channel partners to move Linux servers through the 
channel. Let me explain how this works in practice, by using a current 
example.

One of the partners that we've negotiated a relationship with is SteelEye, a 
provider of enterprise-grade, low cost, high availability clustering, data 
replication and disaster recovery software. We did some joint marketing with 
them, and now we've begun to leverage their network of partners to help sell 
IBM xSeries? Linux servers.

They're reaching customers we never would have seen. One of our most exciting 
references so far this year is BBDO, the largest advertising agency in the 
world. It turns out we got that account through a SteelEye business partner 
in Germany that we didn't even have a relationship with.

Then SteelEye came to IBM and asked if we would help sign Champion as a 
SteelEye business partner, and so we helped them do that. Of course, that 
helped us too. So the value net continues to expand. That's how this is 
supposed to work. And we're building a team inside of IBM to help Software 
Group and the IBM xSeries business partners to collaborate even better. We're 
introducing them to each other, training them, and educating them on 
cross-incentives available through the channel.

This is adding even more value to IBM partnership. For example, consider what 
we did with ACCPAC. ACCPAC is a leader in accounting software that 
specializes in delivering country-specific accounting solutions. They have 
grafted to IBM because one of their leading competitors, Great Plains, was 
purchased by Microsoft. They've now completely enabled their application on 
Linux, and Software Group has begun driving integrated offerings with ACCPAC, 
IBM middleware, and xSeries.

So the ISV partners are starting to say, "Linux and Intel is everywhere, but 
IBM can help us drive revenue." That's music to our ears. IBM can help these 
partners deliver a truly integrated offering that customers will be confident 
in, because they know their businesses will be backed up by IBM service and 
support.

Question: Thanks again for taking the time to discuss this with us, Rich. Do 
you have any closing thoughts you'd like to share with our readers?

Michos: Yes, I'd like to leave our readers with a vision of what's just 
around the corner, a vision that we believe will drive our Intel demand 
forward even further: Grid computing.

Our support of Grid computing and the goals of the Globus project are 
starting to remove the importance of "place" from computing. If the server 
you use is on the Grid and the work just happens, you don't care so much 
where or what the processor is. But, if you are paying for computing 
services, you'll really care about price, performance, and reliability. And, 
if you are providing computing services for web hosting, as part of some 
integrated collaboration, or as an e-utility; standards, price/performance, 
and reliability are everything.

Linux plays a key role in Grid initiatives. It is standards-based, delivers 
excellent cost of ownership benefits, and provides the flexibility needed for 
application integration. Many of the notable Grid deployments to date feature 
IBM eServers, and you will see and hear more on this as the year unfolds.

As our mainframe-inspired Intel-based implementations continue to deliver 
greater value than that of our competitors, as Intel microprocessor 
X-Architecture continues to improve performance, and as software initiatives 
such as Project eLiza deliver enhanced management capabilities, IBM will 
remain well-positioned as a leader in Grid technologies. We think the value 
that Linux and IBM server technology adds to Intel will give us an edge here, 
especially when compared with competing Intel commodity solutions. So when 
Grid computing begins to drive customer demand forward, we'll be ready to 
help them.

So, as you can see, we are very excited about our strategy going forward, and 
Linux on Intel is a key element as we charge into the future.

Note: All trademarks are the property of their respective holders.



From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Thu Aug  8 07:57:16 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 07:57:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Lost Partition
In-Reply-To: <200208071630.06198.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208080754290.11015-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> as I know. I'm not sure what information would be left to allow
> recovery of the data after such an operation occurred on a partition.
> I'm very happy if I am indeed wrong here.

The info page on "shred" might shed some light:

   On a busy system with a nearly-full drive, space can get reused in a
few seconds.  But there is no way to know for sure.  If you have
sensitive data, you may want to be sure that recovery is not possible
by actually overwriting the file with non-sensitive data.

   However, even after doing that, it is possible to take the disk back
to a laboratory and use a lot of sensitive (and expensive) equipment to
look for the faint "echoes" of the original data underneath the
overwritten data.  If the data has only been overwritten once, it's not
even that hard.

   The best way to remove something irretrievably is to destroy the
media it's on with acid, melt it down, or the like.  For cheap
removable media like floppy disks, this is the preferred method.
However, hard drives are expensive and hard to melt, so the `shred'
utility tries to achieve a similar effect non-destructively.

   This uses many overwrite passes, with the data patterns chosen to
maximize the damage they do to the old data.  While this will work on
floppies, the patterns are designed for best effect on hard drives.
For more details, see the source code and Peter Gutmann's paper `Secure
Deletion of Data from Magnetic and Solid-State Memory', from the
proceedings of the Sixth USENIX Security Symposium (San Jose,
California, 22-25 July, 1996).  The paper is also available online
<http://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/~pgut001/pubs/secure_del.html>.

   *Please note* that `shred' relies on a very important assumption:
that the filesystem overwrites data in place.  This is the traditional
way to do things, but many modern filesystem designs do not satisfy this
assumption.  Exceptions include:

   * Log-structured or journaled filesystems, such as those supplied
     with AIX and Solaris.

   * Filesystems that write redundant data and carry on even if some
     writes fail, such as RAID-based filesystems.

   * Filesystems that make snapshots, such as Network Appliance's NFS
     server.

   * Filesystems that cache in temporary locations, such as NFS version
     3 clients.

   * Compressed filesystems.

....

"info shred"

Tyler

corruption.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Thu Aug  8 08:27:08 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 08:27:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Lost Partition
In-Reply-To: <3D51AA22.7010703@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208080812180.11015-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> Are you sure?  I thought it simply overwrote the table that tells the
> disk where everything is/was (in MSDOS-terms, the FAT).

The extended filesystems (extfs/ext2fs) (theoretically extensions of the
minix fs) do not use a file allocation table, rather like BSD
systems they employ a combination of indexing and linking. Note that of
course in Linux the kernel uses the VFS which can call whatever filesystem
you want. Cf. the link below for some details, or Avi Silberschatz's OS
book (with the dinosaurs on the cover), in the appendix on Linux for VFS
and inode info.

......

Physical Structure

The physical structure of Ext2 filesystems has been strongly influenced by
the layout of the BSD filesystem [McKusick et al. 1984]. A filesystem is
made up of block groups. Block groups are analogous to BSD FFS's cylinder
groups. However, block groups are not tied to the physical layout of the
blocks on the disk, since modern drives tend to be optimized for
sequential access and hide their physical geometry to the operating
system.

The physical structure of a filesystem is represented in this table:
Boot
Sector Block
Group 1 Block
Group 2 ...
... Block
Group N

Each block group contains a redundant copy of crucial filesystem control
informations (superblock and the filesystem descriptors) and also contains
a part of the filesystem (a block bitmap, an inode bitmap, a piece of the
inode table, and data blocks). The structure of a block group is
represented in this table:
Super
Block FS
descriptors Block
Bitmap Inode
Bitmap Inode
Table Data
Blocks

Using block groups is a big win in terms of reliability: since the control
structures are replicated in each block group, it is easy to recover from
a filesystem where the superblock has been corrupted. This structure also
helps to get good performances: by reducing the distance between the inode
table and the data blocks, it is possible to reduce the disk head seeks
during I/O on files.

In Ext2fs, directories are managed as linked lists of variable length
entries. Each entry contains the inode number, the entry length, the file
name and its length. By using variable length entries, it is possible to
implement long file names without wasting disk space in directories. The
structure of a directory entry is shown in this table:
inode number entry length name length filename

As an example, The next table represents the structure of a directory
containing three files: file1, long_file_name, and f2:
i1 16 05 file1
i2 40 14 long_file_name
i3 12 02 f2

..............

http://web.mit.edu/tytso/www/linux/ext2intro.html

> disk where everything is/was (in MSDOS-terms, the FAT).

> If recovery or rebuilding is possible, you *should* be able to access
> the data once again.
>
> -R

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug  8 09:33:44 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 09:33:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208080925380.19072-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  OpenOffice appears to have copied everything bad from Word and Microsoft.
It tries to be the only application one needs for anything rather than just
a word processor (or, perhaps, a spreadsheet, too). I waste too much time
trying to write a letter and have the darned software get in my way.

  Today's case in point: my letterhead has the e-mail address,
info at appl-ecosys.com under the telephone and fax numbers. I suppose it is
because of this, I cannot block any text within the body of the letter.
When I move the pointer over text, the I-beam changes to a pointing finger
and I cannot block text or insert the cursor at that point. All I can do is
read a little window that points to a URI on my filesystem.

  I've gone into Tools -> Options -> html documents and turned off
everything I can find. I've saved the doc, exited OO and restarted. But, all
to no avail.

  I need to get this letter written and sent out this morning. It's quite
frustrating to have software that trys to be smarter than I am and won't let
me block text, insert the cursor where I want to type or be productive in
any way.

  Does anyone know how to overcome this behavior? I want OO to look at any
document as a string of text characters, not some URL, URI or anything but a
written document to be printed on a piece of paper. FWIW, the only time I
have this problem is when I use the letterhead template. If I write a report
or anything using the 'default' page layout there's no problem. So, I assume
it has something to do with the fact that I had the audacity to put an
e-mail address on a doument.

Thanks,

Rich




From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Thu Aug  8 10:53:11 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 10:53:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208080925380.19072-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0208081041470.8974-100000@hi.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Rich, I don't think I know any way to help you on this problem other than
suggesting you use AbiWord, it may have a way to get around this.

I think you might want to re-evauate what you are using for the future.
Do you actually NEED OO?  Is there some reason why you have to use it?
Are you sending documents to Word users?

My suggestion is LaTeX or html.  You can find editors for both, and both
allow you to export to a format that can be used by most people.  LaTeX
lets you convert to pdf, this is nice for published things, but the person
on the other end will have read-only access unless they own a pdf editor,
which is rare.  Many html editors will export to rtf, and I think there
are command line tools for doing that also.  Or they could just view the
html as-is.

Are you looking to have a graphical interface?  LyX and Texmacs both let
you create pdf and have a pretty good UI.

The bottom line, for today, try to use a different editor.  For the
future, lets try to find a better tool.  I am very curious about this too,
I recently had a group project where we were creating documentation.  I
was sending pdf files to my group memebers because LaTeX is so easy to
use, but they were silently getting pissed because they could not edit
anything I was sending them.

HTH,
Jason

From jason at vancleve.com  Thu Aug  8 11:04:35 2002
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 11:04:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DVD player
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208080031400.12891-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <20020808053749.12624.qmail@web9608.mail.yahoo.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.21.0208080031400.12891-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20020808110435.5fb4e3fd.jason@vancleve.com>

I struggled at great length with the DVD problem and concluded that Xine
was the best player for Linux.  Ogle is as Jeme describes it, pretty
flakey.  Mplayer is a cool app', and I use that for AVIs and MPGs, but
on my system (1.4 GHz Athlon), DVD playback on Mplayer is just a little
choppy--enough to be really annoying.  This may be hardward-related, as
most users don't seem to have this problem; but Xine plays smoothly
(using the same DVD lib's, I might add), so that's what I use.  If
Mplayer worked as well, though, I would probably ditch Xine.

Also, the Mplayer developers are rather cranky, especially Arpi, the
lead.  So if you ever post to their list, be prepared to get RTFM'ed.

--Jason


On Thu, 8 Aug 2002 00:35:58 -0700 (PDT)
Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> wrote:

> 
> On Wed, 7 Aug 2002, Robert Kopp wrote:
> > What is the best player to use for playing DVD movies
> > on Linux? I have Caldera OpenLinux, so it should not
> > be distribution-specific unless for Caldera.
> > (Compiling from source is, of course, not distribution-specific.)
> 
> I use MPlayer (the cvs snapshot is usually quite good -- nothing
> pre-0.95 is worthwhile for DVDs in my opinion).  It's pretty freakin'
> stable.
> 
> The dvdnav library appears to be sought by the configure script, but I
> haven't determined whether or not MPlayer can actualy use it.
> 
> I also use Ogle, which fully supports DVD menu navigation.  However,
> my experience with Ogle is that it is slightly unstable, a little bit
> slow sometimes, and can just halt in the middle of a scene and not
> recover, all the while displaying a single frame of the video without
> error.
> 
> I've never had any luck with VLC (Video::LAN client), but your mileage
> may vary.
> 
> You can also just rip the DVD's contents with transcode and play it
> back with any opendivx player.  There is some loss in this approach,
> however.
> 
> J.

Open Office will do many many things, if you know how, the online help is 
pretty thorough.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Thu Aug  8 11:16:34 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Thu, 08 Aug 2002 11:16:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208080925380.19072-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3D52B582.4020007@sun.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>   OpenOffice appears to have copied everything bad from Word and Microsoft.
> It tries to be the only application one needs for anything rather than just
> a word processor (or, perhaps, a spreadsheet, too). I waste too much time
> trying to write a letter and have the darned software get in my way.


The problem is, everyone *expects* this of a Office Suite nowadays.  If 
M$ Office has it, OUR Office Suite has to have the _exact same_ 
functionality.

In fact, there were a few emails on the sun-internal StarOffice 6 
mailing lists on just this fact.  Someone complained about a 
feature/bug/unexpected behaviour, and someone else said that it was 
there *specifically* because M$ Office does the same thing.

Sad, but true.

>   Does anyone know how to overcome this behavior? I want OO to look at any
> document as a string of text characters, not some URL, URI or anything but a
> written document to be printed on a piece of paper. FWIW, the only time I
> have this problem is when I use the letterhead template. If I write a report
> or anything using the 'default' page layout there's no problem. So, I assume
> it has something to do with the fact that I had the audacity to put an
> e-mail address on a doument.


There is a pretty extensive list of bugs, non-bugs, issues and whatnot 
on the OO Bugzilla pages (http://www.openoffice.org/issues/query.cgi). 
If you happen to find something that you think could be a bug, just go 
here and see if you find it.  Chances are, it's been reported OR it's 
something that M$ does too.

-R

s u n  m i c r o s y s t e m s

   richard.langis at sun.com




From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Aug  8 11:16:46 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 11:16:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208080925380.19072-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208081059330.693-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

[snip]
>   Today's case in point: my letterhead has the e-mail address,
> info at appl-ecosys.com under the telephone and fax numbers. I suppose it is
> because of this, I cannot block any text within the body of the letter.
> When I move the pointer over text, the I-beam changes to a pointing finger
> and I cannot block text or insert the cursor at that point. All I can do is
> read a little window that points to a URI on my filesystem.
[snip]
>   Does anyone know how to overcome this behavior? I want OO to look at any
> document as a string of text characters, not some URL, URI or anything but a
> written document to be printed on a piece of paper. FWIW, the only time I
> have this problem is when I use the letterhead template. If I write a report
> or anything using the 'default' page layout there's no problem. So, I assume
> it has something to do with the fact that I had the audacity to put an
> e-mail address on a doument.

I don't know about your problem with block selecting, it never gave me any
trouble, maybe there is something wrong with the template other than the
email address issue (which I did have problems with).  If I remember
correctly, the email address/URL problem that I had is caused by the
software automatically converting it to a hyperlink, even in non-HTML
documents.  I think the way that I fixed it was to go to their "Tools"
menu and select "AutoCorrect/AutoFormat", and on the "options" tab,
uncheck the two boxes next to "URL recognition".  At this point, the
problem still isn't cured, it only prevents future problems.  You must now
go back and delete/re-enter anything that it has converted to a hyperlink
such as your email address in the template.

As far as your block select problem, is it possible that you are trying to
select data in both a document header area and the main document itself at
the same time?  If your letter head template is setup the way mine is, the
company name, address, email, etc. is all in a document header, which is
entirely separate from the body of the document, and I don't recall that
any of the word processors I have used would allow selecting both the
headers and the document contents at the same time, and I believe it would
generally be a very bad idea if it did.

Hope this helps.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com




From hilsy at hilsy.com  Thu Aug  8 11:23:27 2002
From: hilsy at hilsy.com (hilsy at hilsy.com)
Date: Thu, 08 Aug 2002 11:23:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
Message-ID: <20020808112330.12574.h018.c001.wm@mail.hilsy.com.criticalpath.net>

Rich,

Here is a work-around that I have to do when using M$.
I would go to whatever document stores your letterhead
and select the email address, cut, then Paste Special
as unformatted text.

I found this trick to work with email addresses and
URL's.

Jim Hilsenteger

documents and

> everything I can find. I've saved the doc, exited OO
> and restarted. But, all
> to no avail.
> 
>   I need to get this letter written and sent out this
> morning. It's quite
> frustrating to have software that trys to be smarter
> than I am and won't let
> me block text, insert the cursor where I want to type
> or be productive in
> any way.
> 
>   Does anyone know how to overcome this behavior? I
> want OO to look at any
> document as a string of text characters, not some URL,
> URI or anything but a
> written document to be printed on a piece of paper.
> FWIW, the only time I
> have this problem is when I use the letterhead
> template. If I write a report
> or anything using the 'default' page layout there's no
> problem. So, I assume
> it has something to do with the fact that I had the
> audacity to put an
> e-mail address on a doument.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug  8 11:23:09 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 11:23:09 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0208081041470.8974-100000@hi.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208081109220.19478-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:

> I think you might want to re-evauate what you are using for the future.
> Do you actually NEED OO?  Is there some reason why you have to use it?
> Are you sending documents to Word users?

Jason,

  Bingo! I get Word docs and I need to provide copies that they can read in
that so-called OS. :-) (I'm cranky today because of this nonsense.) I also
get a lot of permit application templates in Word.

  I looked at AbiWord, too, but there was something it didn't support as
well as OO that is important to me. It might be the printer; I don't recall.
I did download both and try them. I now recall there was an issue with
printing envelopes. I spent a frustrating half-hour with AbiWord and
couldn't do it but did so in less than 5 minutes with OO. This was my first
exposure to both.
 
> My suggestion is LaTeX or html.  You can find editors for both, and both
> allow you to export to a format that can be used by most people.  LaTeX
> lets you convert to pdf, this is nice for published things, but the person
> on the other end will have read-only access unless they own a pdf editor,
> which is rare.  Many html editors will export to rtf, and I think there
> are command line tools for doing that also.  Or they could just view the
> html as-is.

  I would love to use LaTeX/LyX, but have been stymied for a couple of years
on two issues: installing the half-dozen typefaces/fonts I use and
developing style sheets for letters, invoices, and the like. I would
_really_ like guidance through the very complex, involved process of making
additional fonts visible to TeX (and its child, LaTeX, and grandchild, LyX);
I'm about 80% there (but have been away from it since the very early part of
this year). Style sheets and mail merge are also of high value here. That's
how I produce invoices, marketing letters and other "bulk" mailings.

  LaTeX is designed more for academid use than business use. It can, of
course, be used for the latter, but I've not had the time, expertise or
insight to be able to turn it quickly into a productive system here.
 
> Are you looking to have a graphical interface?  LyX and Texmacs both let
> you create pdf and have a pretty good UI.

  I've written several articles in LyX. It's the only GUI document processor
that doesn't raise my blood pressure.

  Although it's not particulary productive overall, I find myself using joe
in a virtual terminal to write. No formatting concerns, no removing my hands
from the keyboard, just look at the screen and write while focusing on the
content. _Very_ highly productive for me. The shitty part comes when I have
to import it to OO, then go line-by-line taking off the terminating LF so
it's formatted nice and pretty for printing. Of course, LyX does this very
quickly and easily; if I was really good with LaTeX I'd have emacs
keystrokes set up for inserting the markup as I wrote. But, overall, I
prefer to just write without regard for format or markup. 

> The bottom line, for today, try to use a different editor.  For the
> future, lets try to find a better tool.  I am very curious about this too,
> I recently had a group project where we were creating documentation.  I
> was sending pdf files to my group memebers because LaTeX is so easy to
> use, but they were silently getting pissed because they could not edit
> anything I was sending them.

  In your situation I'd produce .dvi output so that everyone could work with
it in LaTeX or LyX. 

  Maybe what we need is a group session where we all install LaTeX fonts and
learn how to build customized style sheets.

Thanks,

Rich




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug  8 11:29:48 2002

> Try turning off "URL Recognition" in Auto-Correct- Tools - 
> Autocorrect/autoformat - Options
> 
> Open Office will do many many things, if you know how, the online help is 
> pretty thorough. 
 
  I did this a while ago, Carla. It's still off.

  Yes, it will do a lot, but the model is completely foreign to me; probably
because I've never, ever used winWord for anything. The concept of markups
is both easy for me to grok and to support (even if I cannot see the codes).
But, figuring out what's a paragraph style issue and what's a page issue is
quite different. Don't forget that working for 18 years with WordPerfect
forged a strong sense of how processing words should be done. OO is totally
different; not necessarily worse, just different.

  There was something I sought in the on line help earlier this week and
could not find. Turned out in was hidden in a style formatting dialog box
but there was absolutely no reference to it in the help index.

Thanks,

Rich

On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:

> The problem is, everyone *expects* this of a Office Suite nowadays.  If 
> M$ Office has it, OUR Office Suite has to have the _exact same_ 
> functionality.
> 
> In fact, there were a few emails on the sun-internal StarOffice 6 
> mailing lists on just this fact.  Someone complained about a 
> feature/bug/unexpected behaviour, and someone else said that it was 
> there *specifically* because M$ Office does the same thing.
> 
> Sad, but true.

Richard,

  I've heard that argument too many times before. My response is that of my
parents when I was a teenager (back in the early Pleistocene) and wanted to
do something "because everyone else was doing it": "If everyone else jumped
off a cliff, would you do it, too?"

  We're letting Microsoft define the rules of the game, but trying to tell
them that our way is better. Discrepancy here! Why not do it a much better
way and sell that to the intelligent (i.e., non-sheep) out there?

  I guess it's difficult being an independent thinker in a herd of sheep.
That's been my problem all my life. Perhaps I should stop asking "why?".
 
> There is a pretty extensive list of bugs, non-bugs, issues and whatnot 
> on the OO Bugzilla pages (http://www.openoffice.org/issues/query.cgi). 
> If you happen to find something that you think could be a bug, just go 
> here and see if you find it.  Chances are, it's been reported OR it's 
> something that M$ does too.

  Heh! They've got a big bug there, too. I reported an issue and was asked
to post the winWord template that caused the problem. When I try to log in
to bugzilla it won't let me. I was told they were working on that problem,
too. Sigh.

Many thanks,

Rich

On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:

> If I remember correctly, the email address/URL problem that I had is
> caused by the software automatically converting it to a hyperlink, even in
> non-HTML documents.  I think the way that I fixed it was to go to their
> "Tools" menu and select "AutoCorrect/AutoFormat", and on the "options"
> tab, uncheck the two boxes next to "URL recognition".  At this point, the
> problem still isn't cured, it only prevents future problems.  You must now
> go back and delete/re-enter anything that it has converted to a hyperlink
> such as your email address in the template.

Shannon,

  As I responded to Carla, that's been unchecked since I first installed OO
a couple of months ago. What I think is happening is that the software
ignores the instructions and makes it a hyperlink anyway. Whenever I open
a new doc with that template, the e-mail address is light blue and
underlined: a hyperlink. But, that's been turned off from before I created
that template.

> As far as your block select problem, is it possible that you are trying to
> select data in both a document header area and the main document itself at
> the same time?

  No. I type a paragraph below the letterhead and recipient's address.
That's where I cannot block text.

  If your letter head template is setup the way mine is, the
> company name, address, email, etc. is all in a document header, which is
> entirely separate from the body of the document, and I don't recall that
> any of the word processors I have used would allow selecting both the
> headers and the document contents at the same time, and I believe it would
> generally be a very bad idea if it did.

  Actually, I made the letterhead the way I did in WordPerfect: part of the
document body itself. Didn't do it as a header or in a frame (as someone
else suggested). Perhaps this is what I should do once I get this letter out
the door today.

Thanks,

Rich

From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Aug  8 12:42:11 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 12:42:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] authentication
In-Reply-To: <20020807200329.GA18611@boora.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208081230480.846-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Wed, 7 Aug 2002, Michael Montagne wrote:

> I'm trying to use gnomecal and cron to send myself emails with my
> schedule.  All I keep getting are blank emails. I can run the command
> logged in as me but when I log in as root I get this:
>
> GnomeUI-WARNING **: While connecting to session manager:
> Authentication Rejected, reason : None of the authentication protocols
> specified are supported and host-based authentication failed.
>
> So that seems to be a clue.  I thought crontab -e setup programs to run
> as me.  Right?  What do I need to do to allow this command to run.  It
> is basically "gnomecal -e".

I don't think you are going to be able to do this (unless you want to do a
little code work, or submit a feature request and wait) because gnomecal
wants to access the X window display environment which you aren't going to
have when running from within a cron job.  To verify this, try running
your command line when logged into a virtual console rather than from
within X.  There is one way around this, if you have an X server running
when the cron job executes, and the user the cron job executes as has
permission to connect to the X server, and you set the "DISPLAY"
environment variable for the cron job to point to the active X server,
then it should work.


Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com




From richard.langis at sun.com  Thu Aug  8 12:46:20 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Thu, 08 Aug 2002 12:46:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208081130260.19478-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3D52CA8C.7020708@sun.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>
>   I've heard that argument too many times before. My response is that of my
> parents when I was a teenager (back in the early Pleistocene) and wanted to
> do something "because everyone else was doing it": "If everyone else jumped
> off a cliff, would you do it, too?"
> 
>   We're letting Microsoft define the rules of the game, but trying to tell
> them that our way is better. Discrepancy here! Why not do it a much better
> way and sell that to the intelligent (i.e., non-sheep) out there?


Oh, I agree with you 100%.  Why should we duplicate how M$ does things 
100% of the time?  We shouldn't...  But the problem is, when people are 
migrating to OO from M$, they *want and need* that same functionality in 
order to get the job done.

AFTER we've converted those who are willing to convert, THEN we can 
start changing functionality, or they can start using something that 
makes more sense.

This goes along with the whole 'linux on the desktop' debate as well. 
Advocates want to see linux prevail, Critics say they have to have 
Windows functionality TO prevail.  People are like sheep, the'll follow 
the crowd.  If M$ does something, then Linux has to do the SAME thing in 
order for people to accept it.  The only reason Linux *hasn't* prevailed 
on the desktop is because it's not Windows.

So, OO and SO are doing what people want.  People as a GROUP, mind you, 
not the geeks who know WTF they want.  Like K in MIB said, "A Person is 
smart.  PEOPLE are dumb, ignorant and scared."  Or something to that 
effect.  You get my point.

-R

<snip>

There's also KWord, part of the KOffice suite.  Although it is a KDE app
(less stable, starts up slower) it does do a pretty good job for what I
was doing (Engineering class papers... yeah, I know I should learn TeX
stuff)...

Just be sure and save your work in its native format often and always
before saving it as another format.  I had its filters barf out on me a
couple times, taking the whole thing down with it (most of the time that
was with KSpread, but it happened with KWord, too).

So it isn't super-stable, but it is pretty feature-rich and was
customizable enough.  It might do the trick for you....

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug  8 12:31:52 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 12:31:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <200208081906.g78J6TA24309@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208081224010.19478-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Ah, my apologies, I just tried what you were doing and it is obscure. Darn 
> thang. sorry!

  No apologies necessary, Carla.

  Although I'm an end user and not a professional geek, I'm _really_
discouraged by the herd mentality of those trying to move businesses from
Microsoft to Open Source Software.

  Why do we have to dumb-down and build in inefficiencies and bugs just
because that's what Microsoft does? I cannot think of any other product or
brand that markets itself as being just as bad as "the other guy". Ford
tried to ride the coattails of the reputation of Mercedes Benz some years
ago by advertising that their car (whatever model it was) "looks just like a
Mercedes!". Of course, it didn't have the same quality or reputation and
that ad campaign fizzled out.

  There are so many options in linux to automate offices that it's almost
criminal that we have to make something as bad as Word/Office to convince
folks to move. Why should they? What, other than money in their pocket, do
they gain by moving from Word to OO? We talk about stability, productivity
and control as selling points for OSS over Microsoft, then we take the most
important office application and make it just as crappy. OO is not stable,
productive or willing to share control over documents with the writer.
Rather takes the wind out of our sails, doesn't it?

Rich

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Thu Aug  8 06:17:23 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <3D52CA8C.7020708@sun.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208081130260.19478-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <3D52CA8C.7020708@sun.com>
Message-ID: <200208082001.g78K1Yt06242@smtp.easystreet.com>

On Thursday 08 August 2002 07:46 pm, you wrote:
> Rich Shepard wrote:
> >   I've heard that argument too many times before. My response is that of
> > my parents when I was a teenager (back in the early Pleistocene) and
> > wanted to do something "because everyone else was doing it": "If everyone
> > else jumped off a cliff, would you do it, too?"
> >
> >   We're letting Microsoft define the rules of the game, but trying to
> > tell them that our way is better. Discrepancy here! Why not do it a much
> > better way and sell that to the intelligent (i.e., non-sheep) out there?
>
> Oh, I agree with you 100%.  Why should we duplicate how M$ does things
> 100% of the time?  We shouldn't...  But the problem is, when people are
> migrating to OO from M$, they *want and need* that same functionality in
> order to get the job done.
>
> AFTER we've converted those who are willing to convert, THEN we can
> start changing functionality, or they can start using something that
> makes more sense.
>
> This goes along with the whole 'linux on the desktop' debate as well.
> Advocates want to see linux prevail, Critics say they have to have
> Windows functionality TO prevail.  People are like sheep, the'll follow
> the crowd.  If M$ does something, then Linux has to do the SAME thing in
> order for people to accept it.  The only reason Linux *hasn't* prevailed
> on the desktop is because it's not Windows.
>
> So, OO and SO are doing what people want.  People as a GROUP, mind you,
> not the geeks who know WTF they want.  Like K in MIB said, "A Person is
> smart.  PEOPLE are dumb, ignorant and scared."  Or something to that
> effect.  You get my point.
>
> -R

have you see Bruce Sterling's speech? 

http://www.viridiandesign.org/notes/301-350/00325_open_source_speech.html

"There's a noticeable lack of basic creativity in the free software world, 
that is alarming and not very flattering. People in free software still have 
a basically piratical state of mind. They want goods without working for 
them. They still have a cracker state of mind. "How can I look through that 
closed bedroom window?"

"GNU's Not Unix." Okay, you're "not Unix" ? but what are you really? Why do 
you have to live in that shadow? The shadow of this other enterprise. There's 
something basically juvenile about that. Something that is unworthy, 
creatively feeble, childish."

"
What's the real price you pay for free software? The real price you pay is 
having to bow the knee to the weird organizational model and the freaky, 
geeky social values that prop that up. If you're the user, you have to hang 
out with Linux freaks."

Carla

From m at netpro.to  Thu Aug  8 13:09:30 2002

On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I've heard that argument too many times before. My response is that of my
> parents when I was a teenager (back in the early Pleistocene) and wanted to
> do something "because everyone else was doing it": "If everyone else jumped
> off a cliff, would you do it, too?"

I've been slowly migrating the business I work for over to OO.  The more
closely it resembles MS Office, the better.  It's still an excellent free
and open office suite, and that's what matters most to me.  It's already
very difficult to get users to switch to something new.  If they have to
learn Yet Another Way To Do The Same Thing, then many of them will
flat-out refuse.  Now if the envelope printing in OO was the same as in MS
Office, I could eliminate about 70% of the complaints I get...
~M

forced to learn OO and it works differently. I know I don't mind 
learning new things and different ways of doing things but there are 
many people out there that are.

Oh and in answer to your other question, I think the sheep out number 
the non-sheep by a very wide margin.

From m at netpro.to  Thu Aug  8 13:20:48 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 13:20:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208081224010.19478-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208081316070.22375-100000@lukem.com>

On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Why do we have to dumb-down and build in inefficiencies and bugs just
> because that's what Microsoft does? I cannot think of any other product or
> brand that markets itself as being just as bad as "the other guy". Ford
> tried to ride the coattails of the reputation of Mercedes Benz some years
> ago by advertising that their car (whatever model it was) "looks just like a
> Mercedes!". Of course, it didn't have the same quality or reputation and
> that ad campaign fizzled out.

Oh come on, Rich.  MS Office isn't as bad as you make it out to be.  It's
a very nice office suite.  Yes, there are problems and annoyances, but on
the whole it works well and most people are familiar with it.

>   There are so many options in linux to automate offices that it's almost
> criminal that we have to make something as bad as Word/Office to convince
> folks to move. Why should they? What, other than money in their pocket, do
> they gain by moving from Word to OO?

Money in their pocket is the only real reason.  99% of users and managers
don't care about "freedom" or "stability."  We may, but we're in the vast
minority.  But if I can save my company thousands of dollars by using an
office suite that is nearly identical to what everyone is already familiar
with, then that's an attractive selling point to users and managers.  For
yourself, as an individual user, use whatever makes you happiest.  For a
business trying to save money by using free software, the more closely it
resembles Microsoft products, the easier it is (and in some cases the only
way) to break the Microsoft habit.
~M




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug  8 13:02:28 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 13:02:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Any TeX-perts out there? (was: Re: [PLUG] Struggling with
 OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <1028836295.13760.20.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208081255200.19478-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 8 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> From what I've heard, TeX is *the* way to write any kind of technical
> papers.  I haven't used it at all thus far, though.  Slackware has a
> whole seperate diskset for it, for some reason... I've never installed
> it. 
> 
> As an engineering student, I think a TeX class of some sort would be a
> good thing to have under my belt!  I'll bet you could get a lot of folks
> to participate in something like that if they were aware of it.

  LyX is your friend! Dean and I had a very good exchange on this last year.

  I use LyX for my articles and reports (that don't need a letterhead or
someone's specific formats). I can report that from my experience it has a
10-minute learning curve. That's the time it takes to read the tutorial.

  After that, there are issues that come up, but the online users guide,
reference manual and mail list are absolutely superb. LyX is, hands down,
the only GUI document processor I can more than tolerate. I actually like
the silly thing!

  I've put in equations, tables and figures with no problem. Sometimes it
was a problem to get them looking as I wanted, but then I was taught how to
do it. Herb Voss in Germany has a huge web site of LaTeX code ready to drop
into LyX that does almost everything but the shopping and laundry.

  Because you don't have to do anything about formatting output, you sit and
create quickly. Mark headings and lists from the pull-down menus and that's
all the effort it takes. And the output is stunning! It is, after all,
professionally typeset and that makes a tremendous positive impression on
those that read it.

  There are also styles for various and sundry scientific journals and many
different theses/dissertations from different universities.

  <http://www.lyx.org>

Rich




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Aug  8 13:28:27 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 13:28:27 -0700
Subject: Any TeX-perts out there? (was: Re: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208081232190.19478-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208081232190.19478-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200208081328.27756.aschlemm@attbi.com>

This isn't something I use much anymore but at one time there were 
numerous books on this subject. TeX, and LaTEX are great for saving 
paper. The nice thing is what I saw on the screen using "xdvi" I would 
get on paper when I was finally ready to print a hardcopy. 

I can't tell you how many times Word and other WYSIWYG word processors 
have hosed me where things looked great on the screen only to appear 
not-so-great when output to paper. I really think WYSIWYG should really 
be renamed to WYSMBWYG instead (What You See Might Be What You Get) 
where a lot of word processors are concerned.

Here are some reference books if anyone is interested. I don't know if 
these books are still in print or not as I've had most of them for 4-5 
years now:

"The LaTEX Companion" ISBN 0-201-54199-8
"The LaTEX" Graphics Companion" ISBN 0-201-85469-4
"A Guide to LaTEX 2E" ISBN 0-201-42777-X

I used TeX and LaTEX though "emacs" putting tags in by hand, etc. I know 
there is a wordprocessor called "LyX" that uses LaTEX for output. They 
call it WYSIWYM which is "What You See Is What You Mean)...

http://www.lyx.org/

Tony

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Thu Aug  8 13:35:50 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 13:35:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <3D52CA8C.7020708@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208081327390.11960-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:

> Rich Shepard wrote:
>
> Oh, I agree with you 100%.  Why should we duplicate how M$ does things
> 100% of the time?  We shouldn't...  But the problem is, when people are
> migrating to OO from M$, they *want and need* that same functionality in
> order to get the job done.

This is where I pop in with my $0.02 about software design.  Layered
component based development is good.  True object oriented design (like
that found in Unix, not like that found in programming languages like Java
and C++), is wonderful here.  Make expert programs and utilities at one
layer.  Make them form a fundamental system for the processing of office
data (whatever you want to call it), make them work with the command line.
Then on top of them create a layer for using them, probably graphical.
This way advanced users can have their advanced interface, either via the
command line or special graphical tools that are known to be for the
experts.  Then have programs with an interface like OO that is known to be
for the novice, or winWord expert.  The bottom line, strong integration is
bad, independent layers that are capable of working together are good.
The next time you think of designing software, say that to yourself for a
while first.  MS doesn't get this, perhaps its marketing, perhaps it's a
lack of consideration, who knows...

Jason




From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Thu Aug  8 13:52:43 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)

On Thu, 2002-08-08 at 13:03, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> If you're running from KDE, KWord starts up in a few seconds. OpenOffice 
> on the other hand takes nearly 10 seconds before I see anything other 
> than its splash screen. I guess my system isn't very fast anymore as I 
> only have 10K RPM Ultra-160 hard drives and a lowly 900MHZ Athlon. I 
> guess I need to upgrade my system again at some point.

I stopped running KDE a while ago simply because it is so terribly
bloated.  Sure, my system can handle it... but why should it have to? 
It seems to me a lot of KDE could be streamlined better.  On older
systems, it just takes forever to start.

So I switched to fluxbox.  About the only thing I miss is the ability to
start KDE apps as quickly as I was able to when running the full KDE
suite.  I can access things so much faster, though, and have weaned
myself off KDE apps for the most part.

Ok, I'm diverging...

Yeah, KOffice does start a lot faster when KDE already running. 
Definitely better than OO (which is just really slow no matter what, it
seems.  I can't run it over a forwarded X11 display worth beans... this
is over 100Mbps LAN).  But I always am sure to mention the loadup time
when they haven't mentioned they're using KDE.  :-)

Rob

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Thu Aug  8 13:55:26 2002
