As Rogan mentions I am willing to teach how to use LaTeX, I am not an
expert, just a user.  I use LaTeX via emacs on a daily basis, and have had
to learn little more than the basics even to do mathematical papers, and
reports with tables of content.  Gets me a grade that is at least 10%
higher than I would have gotten using word.  I must say I've never like
LyX because it has always been confusing to me.  I can't offer any help
with it...But I can with emacs.

I have a tutorial that I send to people that are curious about LaTeX, it
is 600KB so I don't like to email it, but you can find the latest version
on my web page:
http://www.engr.orst.edu/~dagit/latextutorial.tar.gz

There is a makefile in there to help with creating your documents, it has
a known bug with table of contents.  I know a work around, but I don't
know enough about make to put in an elegant solution.  If you're a make
expert let me know so we can fix this bug.

If you pluggers test it out, please send me your feed back so I can
improve it.

Also Rich, there is an archive of TeX/LaTeX templates and such at CTAN.
I have only used their site once, but it might have the business resources
you want/need.

http://www.ctan.org/

HTH,
Jason




From deanm at sharplabs.com  Thu Aug  8 14:04:52 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Thu,  8 Aug 2002 14:04:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Any TeX-perts out there? (was: Re: [PLUG] Struggling with
	OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <1028836295.13760.20.camel@duron> (message from AthlonRob on 08
	Aug 2002 12:51:32 -0700)
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208081204180.42-100000@silver.CS.ORST.EDU> <1028836295.13760.20.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <20020808210452.2B94410E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>

 :: On Thu, 2002-08-08 at 12:08, E. Rogan Creswick wrote:
 :: > >   Maybe what we need is a group session where we all install LaTeX fonts and
 :: > > learn how to build customized style sheets.
 :: > 
 :: > 
 :: > ...sounds like a good topic for a learning co-op. If there is no-one
 :: > better suited, Jason and I could probably put together a session if there
 :: > is interest.
 :: > 
 :: > 
 :: > -Rogan
 :: 
 :: >From what I've heard, TeX is *the* way to write any kind of technical
 :: papers.

It depends on the society.  AMS (American Mathematical Society) is (or
was, last time I looked) exclusively TeX/LaTeX-based.  They even have
a version of LaTeX named AMS-LaTeX.  The manifold theorist, Michael
Spivak, has published a nice book (in the style of Knuth and Lamport)
for those who want to do Pure Maths Typesetting with "straight"
TeX. It is called

    _The Joy of TeX - A Gourmet Guide to Typesetting with
                  the AMS-TeX Macro Package_.

He even formed his own publishing company (based on TeX) to publish
his five volume work on Differentiable Manifolds.

IEEE (my society) allows both .ps files (usually derived from LaTeX)
and .doc files (written with you-know-who's typesetting software)
and provides style files and templates for each system.

MPEG does everything with .doc files.

I don't know about Physics, Chemistry, or Biology, but I know that
LaTeX has sophisticated macro packages for the first two that allow
just about any graphic, e.g. Feynman diagrams, Organic Molecule
diagrams, to be designed.  There is also a nice Music Typesetting
package, as well as packages for Chess, Maps, &c.

Long before Linux and the "free software revolution" there was TeX and
the army of people writing all kinds of modules for it.  For serious
users it's a way of life and makes the "cult of emacs" pale in
comparison. (Well, that may be slight exaggeration).

Be aware that TeX/LaTeX is _not_ a WYSIWYG system, though there are
Linux packages out that have a WYSIWYG front end.  My (nearly nil)
knowledge of these is that they are great if you are not trying to do
anything very sophisticated.  But to get the full power of LaTeX you
must go to old-fashioned editing.  But it is not bad at all.  I can
code up a complex mathematical expression in TeX by typing in the
commands to a file, compiling it, and displaying it just as fast as my
colleagues can use "Equation Editor" in M$ Word.
And mine will look like professionally typeset mathematics rather than
the stuff that my eight grade algebra teacher would print off on the
school mimeograph machine thirty years ago.  (That's probably another
slight exaggeration.)

 :: I haven't used it at all thus far, though.  Slackware has a
 :: whole seperate diskset for it, for some reason... I've never installed
 :: it. 

There are two (or three?) major distributions of TeX/LaTeX.  I can't
remember the 2nd one but the one I use is called `tetex' and I have
version 1.0.7 installed.  Of course I simply do: "rpm -Uvh tetex*.rpm"
and it's installed and ready to use.
But since you use Slack you may have to compile.  It's not a single binary
but a whole raft of things.

In "the old days" compilation was a bear.  It probably isn't any more.
There are many, many components to a full TeX system including the
viewers, the translator(s) from .dvi format to .ps, the plethora of
fonts, and much more.  You need to worry about very little of this if
you use a tetex sub-system.

You may wish to look at http://www.ctan.org/ where the CTAN (comprehensive
TeX Archive Network) is housed. Everything (and a lot more) is there.


 :: As an engineering student, I think a TeX class of some sort would be a
 :: good thing to have under my belt!  I'll bet you could get a lot of folks
 :: to participate in something like that if they were aware of it.
 :: 
 :: -- 
 :: Rob
 :: "Google is your friend"

Dean



From deanm at sharplabs.com  Thu Aug  8 14:21:19 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Thu,  8 Aug 2002 14:21:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Any TeX-perts out there? (was: Re: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <200208081328.27756.aschlemm@attbi.com> (message from Anthony
	Schlemmer on Thu, 8 Aug 2002 13:28:27 -0700)

Message-ID: <20020808212119.63E9810E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>

Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
 :: Here are some reference books if anyone is interested. I don't know if 
 :: these books are still in print or not as I've had most of them for 4-5 
 :: years now:
 :: 
 :: "The LaTEX Companion" ISBN 0-201-54199-8
 :: "The LaTEX" Graphics Companion" ISBN 0-201-85469-4
 :: "A Guide to LaTEX 2E" ISBN 0-201-42777-X

All good books.  And of course there's the definitive

    _LaTeX User's Guide and Reference Manual_, 2nd ed.,  ISBN 0-201-52983-1

by Leslie Lamport, who invented LaTeX (and who, I hear, now works for M$).

Finally all the above refer, many times, to the Final Authority:

   _The TeX Book_ (sorry, it's home so no ISBN number handy)

by Donald Knuth.

It's a difficult book, but if you want to become a TeXpert, it is a
must.  Everything derives from it.  Many times the above books contain
footnotes like "to learn more about such-and-such refer to pg. xxx of
_The TeX Book_.

Dean

install-packages  tetex-1.0.7-i386-1.tgz      tetex-doc-1.0.7-i386-1.txt

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Thu Aug  8 16:27:42 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Thu,  8 Aug 2002 16:27:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Any TeX-perts out there? (was: Re: [PLUG] Struggling with
	OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <1028844724.14327.8.camel@duron> (message from AthlonRob on 08
	Aug 2002 15:12:02 -0700)
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208081204180.42-100000@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
	<1028836295.13760.20.camel@duron> 
	<20020808210452.2B94410E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com> <1028844724.14327.8.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <20020808232742.318CF10E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>

AthlonRob writes:
 :: > I don't know about Physics, Chemistry, or Biology, but I know that
 :: > LaTeX has sophisticated macro packages for the first two that allow
 :: > just about any graphic, e.g. Feynman diagrams, Organic Molecule
 :: > diagrams, to be designed.  There is also a nice Music Typesetting
 :: > package, as well as packages for Chess, Maps, &c.
 :: 
 :: That's good to know.... now if I do something in TeX, can I later
 :: convert it to pdf, postscript, or (ghasp!) Word?

Yes.  The TeX/LaTeX "compiler" generates a .dvi (DeVice Independent)
file.  This is a binary file which (as I understand it) contains the
placeholders and co-ordinates for each symbol in the document but no
actual symbols (e.g. letters and numbers) themselves.  One takes
a .dvi file and then runs something like dvips which renders the .dvi
file as a postscript document.  Finally you can use, e.g.,  ps2pdf to
convert to pdf format.  I don't know if you can do .dvi --> pdf directly
as I usually deal in .ps.

My usual commandline (yes, I said commandline :-) is:

latex foo.tex; dvips -o -N0 foo.dvi;

For things with lit. references, indices, tables of contents, &c.,
there are a few more steps, all of which can be done like the above
so you just hit "up-arrow" <RET> in a dedicated xterm, or, in Emacs,
a single key chord.


I don't know about Word, but I would guess there is no converter for
this else the entire TeX community would be buzzing about it.  A good
Word converter would, in fact, allow one to do Word directly from
Linux (Lyx --> TeX --> .dvi --> Word) without having to use StarOffice
or some other albatross, or without having to go with something like
win4lin (as I do) or vmWare that lets one run Windows (and hence Word
in its native environment) on top of Linux.

 :: I never got in to Emacs much.  There is quite a cult following, though,
 :: I've noticed.  "Linux is just the device driver"  "Emacs is a great OS,
 :: but it sucks as an editor"  Although if I include those, I *must*
 :: include "You can't spell eVIl without vi"  :-)

As a bone fide emacs cult member I must say that LaTeX + Emacs is a
_great_ combination.  I confess that I don't use all the features of
Emacs that make Emacs+LaTeX so great, but from what I hear, it is
better than WYSIWYG in that single key chords allow all kinds of
powerful functionality "at the press of a button" (pardon the pun).
I feel an Emacs Sermon coming on so I'll stop here.

 :: If it helps me get out those darned equations faster than the quite
 :: cumbersome equation editor, I'm sure I'll fall in love with it!  I like
 :: keystrokes when I'm typing a paper, not mouse movements and clicks.

This is the great thing about both TeX and Emacs.  My hands rarely
leave the keyboard. The mouse become superfluous except when (outside
Emacs) I have to go bink some idiotic button in some brain-dead GUI like
Netscape.

To write the Euler Equation (evaluated at \pi) in LaTeX or TeX I
simply type $$e^{-i\pi}+ 1 = 0$$ and I'm done.  The Word User is still
trying to find the \pi symbol in the pull-down menus when I've got the
eq. sitting, pretty as can be, in `ghostview' which I've got set up to
autosense that the .ps file has been updated.  From typing (in Emacs)
to display is (for a short document) under two seconds.

Best of all, the symbols are typeset (99% of the time) in exactly
the right positions to look "professional".  My parents were commercial
printers who did a bit of mathematics typesetting.  It is a
_very difficult_ business to get it to look right.  Knuth got it right.

Finally, like Linux (and Emacs), TeX is, as a system, an amazing, complex,
elegant piece of computing machinery.

But I feel another sermon coming on so I'll stop here.

 :: I'm sure I'll compile it... but Slackware has a whole diskset of TeX
 :: binaries.

Why?  Unless there is something in Slack or tetex, itself, that will
comprehensively `make' the entire tetex package (like rpm -bb), you'd
be foolish to hand-build everything.  I just looked in my tetex rpm
(rpm -ql tetex | wc -l) and it counts 6188 separate items. Some
are directories but the vast majority are files.


 :: rob:/mnt/cdrom/slackware/t > ls
 :: install-packages  tetex-1.0.7-i386-1.tgz      tetex-doc-1.0.7-i386-1.txt
 :: install.end   tetex-1.0.7-i386-1.txt      transfig-3.2.3d-i386-1.tgz
 :: maketag       tetex-bin-1.0.7-i386-1.tgz  transfig-3.2.3d-i386-1.txt
 :: maketag.ez    tetex-bin-1.0.7-i386-1.txt  xfig-3.2.3d-i386-1.tgz
 :: tagfile       tetex-doc-1.0.7-i386-1.tgz  xfig-3.2.3d-i386-1.txt

I'm guessing that stuff like tetex-bin-1.0.7-i386-1.tgz contains _many_
binaries, including the "web2c" compiler, xdvi, dvips, and much more.

 :: Linuxpackages.net likely has additional binaries to go along with
 :: these... they do a pretty good job getting the more professional (ie;
 :: not stuff like xmms) things out there up for download and easy installs.
 :: 
 :: But that doesn't matter, I'll have to compile it from source,
 :: super-optimizing it as much as it can stand!  I love gcc optimizations. 
 :: Just love 'em!

Sounds like a good way to turn yourself off to LaTeX real fast.

But that's just my opinion.  As I said in a previous post, things may
be much easier now than in the mid-eighties when we did have to
compile the whole she-bang "by hand".  It was an all-day job.  Sort of
like compiling all of X "by hand" (which I all did in the old days).


Dean

From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Aug  8 16:51:59 2002

On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Michael Montagne wrote:

> This is disturbing.  I was sent a .dwg file (autocad drawing) as an
> attachment.  I use mutt on Linux to do my mail.  I saved the attachment
> and tried to open the file with autocad.  The file was corrupt and I
> could not open it.  The same thing happened when it had been zipped.
> The only way it worked is forwarding it (before even opening it) to
> myself on my windows box and using Outlook to save it.
> Can this really be true?  Wonder why.

Maybe a bug in mutt?  You might try using a different mail program to save
the file.  I use pine and have never had a problem like this, though I
have on many occasions sent and received large (5 - 15 Meg) binary files
(executables, zip files, etc.) as attachments without problems.

Alternatively, the paranoid in me says maybe this is a new feature of
the (presumably Microsoft flavored) mail program used to send it to you,
intended to force people to use MS products to receive their email.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug  8 15:22:12 2002

Subject: Any TeX-perts out there? (was: Re: [PLUG] Struggling with

On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Dean S. Messing wrote:

>     _The Joy of TeX - A Gourmet Guide to Typesetting with
>                   the AMS-TeX Macro Package_.

  What a hoot! And it just goes to show that theoretical mathematicians can
have a well developed sense of humor, too.
 
> He even formed his own publishing company (based on TeX) to publish
> his five volume work on Differentiable Manifolds.

  If I install his differential manifolds on my diesel pickup will I get
better milage and more power from the engine?
 
> Long before Linux and the "free software revolution" there was TeX and
> the army of people writing all kinds of modules for it.  For serious
> users it's a way of life and makes the "cult of emacs" pale in
> comparison. (Well, that may be slight exaggeration).

  The TUG -- International TeX Users Group -- is headquartered here in
Portland. But, they apparently do nothing but collect annual dues and hold
annual meetings in furin' countries to which I cannot afford to travel. I
wish there was a local users group that met regularly (once a month?). I'd
sure be an active member!

  Perhaps Sharp would sponsor space and coffee?

  For me, getting the few fonts I need in is the major issue. Heck, I could
do well with Palatino as the body text (already available) and find
something as a header text, but I need Baker Signet as the company logotype.

  After this, I want to learn how to create stylesheets so I can have a
letterhead, invoices and so on.

  There is a TON of macro packages on CTAN. I need to get past the font and
style issues resolved first.

> Be aware that TeX/LaTeX is _not_ a WYSIWYG system, though there are Linux
> packages out that have a WYSIWYG front end.  My (nearly nil) knowledge of
> these is that they are great if you are not trying to do anything very
> sophisticated.  But to get the full power of LaTeX you must go to
> old-fashioned editing.

  The LyX web site describes it as WYSIWYM (What You See Is What You Mean).
I've put a lot of LaTeX in the preamble of docs and there's a way (called,
interestingly enough) Evil Red Text (or ERT) to write pure LaTeX in the
midst of your LyX document.

  The only real advantages of LyX over LaTeX are, IMO, 1) you don't need to
memorize and type macros, just select them from the pull down menu and 2)
it's just a mouse click to compile and view the dvi output or print a pdf
doc. The full power of LaTeX _is_ available.

  A couple of years ago I sold back to Powell's my LaTeX books, except for
one: "LaTeX for Linux" by Bernice Sacks Lipkin. That sits at my desk here.

Rich




From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Thu Aug  8 17:48:31 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 08 Aug 2002 17:48:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Usermod: adding a user to a group
In-Reply-To: <3D518DFB.E9635639@truedisk.com>
References: <1028753930.7991.1008.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
	<3D518DFB.E9635639@truedisk.com>
Message-ID: <877kj0oo0w.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Don Buchholz <don at truedisk.com> writes:

> Jon Jacob wrote:
> > 
> > I guess it has been awhile since I have done this, but when I do:
> > 
> > usermod -G league jon
> > 
> > to add me (jon) to the league group, nothing happens.  I do not
> > get an error message, but I also am not added to the group.
> > League does exist as a group, and I do exist as a user.  So, why
> > does this not work, and how do I get it to work.
> > 
> 
> What does 'grep league /etc/group' show?  You just about have to
> logout/login again to inherit newly-added group privileges.

You should not use "grep" for that purpose, because it is possible
that the "passwd" and "group" files are NOT where that information is
coming from.  If NIS or nss-LDAP are in use, for instance, the groups
a user is in may be getting filled in from sources other than the
"group" file.  The command to use is "id".

% id karlheg
uid=1000(karlheg) gid=1000(karlheg) groups=1000(karlheg),0(root),4(adm),20(dialout),24(cdrom),25(floppy),27(sudo),29(audio),40(src),44(video),50(staff),104(fwproj),105(pilot),110(cvs),111(cvsadmin),112(cvslock),113(debian),114(www),120(uml-net),127(plex86),800(Debian),1024(ksrc),128(freegeek)

In general, it's best to use a "documented api" -- an accessor program
or function -- rather than parsing or editting a file like "passwd" by
hand (or especially from a script), since there's often no guarantee
that the file format will not change in the future.  Encapsulation was
not invented for hiding proprietary secrets, but for insulating
software from changes internal to libraries or external subsystems
they rely on.

There's no way around logging out and logging in again, since the only
way that all of the processes in your environment (window manager,
terminals, shells, xemacs, dired, etc.) will have that new group in
their list is if they inherit them from "login" or "gdm".  See
"setgroups" and "initgroups" int the GNU LibC manual and the source to
"login" for more details.

> Caveat: The usermod(8) manpage cautions that, as shown above, this
> command will remove you from all other groups!

That's one of the reasons that Debian's "adduser" utility is the
command line tool of choice, at least on that platform, for adding new
users, groups, and adding users to groups.  It wraps the "shadow
suite" tools with a Perl script that makes this sort of operation a
lot easier to do.  It also ensures that new users and groups are
allocated from the UID and GID blocks mandated by the Debian Policy
Manual.

It is a little confusing, at first -- You have to rememeber that
there's both and "adduser" command and a "useradd" command.  For the
first few whiles, you should always start by typing the command and
it's "--help" switch, to make sure you have the right one.  A good
mnemonic is that "adduser" is first in the alphabet, and is the one
you should be using.

8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
adduser [--home DIR] [--shell SHELL] [--no-create-home] [--uid ID]
[--firstuid ID] [--lastuid ID] [--gecos GECOS] [--ingroup GROUP | --gid ID]
[--disabled-password] [--disabled-login] user
   Add a normal user

adduser --system [--home DIR] [--shell SHELL] [--no-create-home] [--uid ID]
[--gecos GECOS] [--group | --ingroup GROUP | --gid ID] [--disabled-password]
[--disabled-login] user
   Add a system user

adduser --group [--gid ID] group
addgroup [--gid ID] group
   Add a system group

adduser user group
   Add an existing user to an existing group

Global configuration is in the file /etc/adduser.conf.
Other options are [--quiet] [--force-badname] [--help] [--version] [--conf
FILE].
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

So, to perform the operation that was the subject of the original
question, a Debian administrator would simply type "adduser USER
GROUP".

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug  8 15:35:26 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 15:35:26 -0700 (PDT)

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Thu Aug  8 18:10:54 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 08 Aug 2002 18:10:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Need help with making a RPM
In-Reply-To: <94341688642.20020807133521@starband.net>
References: <200208071958.g77Jwl3X017697@franka.aracnet.com>
	<94341688642.20020807133521@starband.net>
Message-ID: <87wur0n8f5.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Richard Kurth <rkurth at starband.net> writes:

>  I need some help with the building of an RPM. What would case a
>  Segmentation fault I get one when it is reading the files list. It
>  does not tell me where the problem is and I can not find anything
>  on the RPM mail-list or any of the how-to's that are out there. If
>  I don't have a file list it does not give me a Segmentation fault
>  and creates the RPM but with out a file list there are no files
>  loaded in the RPM

A segmentation fault is when a program attempts to access memory
outside of the region allocated to it by the operating system.  There
are features of the CPU that are utilized by the operating system to
implement this.  (It's part of the virtual memory subsystem.)  You
will not find much about that in the HOWTO's, but you will find quite
a lot in textbooks about operating systems.  There are several good
choices of reading material on the subject available at Powell's
Technical Bookstore.  It's not 15 days for dummies type of reading.

So anyway, what's happening is that "rpm" has a bug that is triggering
a segmentation violation.

What you can do is turn on core dumps in your shell, with, assuming
you use "bash", "ulimit -c unlimited".  Then, run the command again,
and wait for it to dump core.  Then, you type "gdb rpm core", and open
the core dump in the debugger.  Now you can type "where" and attempt
to get a stack trace showing where the core dump occured.  Chances are
that you will not be able to get any useful information, however,
since the "rpm" binary has most likely been stripped (info binutils)
and there's no way for GDB to map raw addresses to function names or
variable names.  If this is the case, which it most likely is, you
will need to get an unstripped copy of "rpm" and try again...

By the way, if you have a core file and don't know what created it,
just type "gdb /bin/ls core" and GDB will tell you it's not a core
from "/bin/ls", then tell you what program created that core dump.

> Executing(%prep): /bin/sh -e /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.77827
> + umask 022
> + cd /usr/src/redhat/BUILD
> + rm -rf /usr/src/redhat/BUILD/autoserv
> + zcat /usr/src/redhat/SOURCES/autocontrolpro-3.0.tar.gz
> + tar -xf -
> + exit 0
> Executing(%install): /bin/sh -e /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.64205
> + umask 022
> + cd /usr/src/redhat/BUILD
> + cp -a /usr/src/redhat/BUILD/autoserv /usr/
> + cp /usr/src/redhat/BUILD/autoserv/autoserv /etc/rc.d/init.d/
> + /usr/lib/rpm/brp-compress
> + /usr/lib/rpm/brp-strip
> + /usr/lib/rpm/brp-strip-comment-note
> Processing files: autocontrolpro-3.0-0
> Segmentation fault

I find it amusing that RPM reimplements the Make utility like that.
It's like that old adage that "those who do not study Unix are doomed
to reimplement it, poorly".  Debian's package build system is Makefile
driven.  A debian/rules script is a Makefile named "rules", marked
executable, with a shebang line that looks like:

8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
#!/usr/bin/make -f
# ...
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

... so that it can be run like a script.

Also, packages are NEVER built as root, since once in a while, an
upstream "install" target will have a missing ${DESTDIR} or somesuch,
and wreak major havoc with the builder's computer.  So, the right way,
on Debian is to use "fakeroot", like this:

nonroot:~/src/pkg% fakeroot debian/rules binary

That will build the software, install it to a staging area, then
package it into a .deb package.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'

 :: On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Dean S. Messing wrote:
 :: 
 :: >     _The Joy of TeX - A Gourmet Guide to Typesetting with
 :: >                   the AMS-TeX Macro Package_.
 :: 
 ::   What a hoot! And it just goes to show that theoretical mathematicians can
 :: have a well developed sense of humor, too.

Here's some Chapter Headings (in order):

  Getting Acquainted
  Learning TeX's Lingo
  Printers Do It With All Types
  Your First TeX Experience
  TeX's Erroneous Zones
  Spaces That Separate, Ties That Bind
  Doing It With ?lan
  Lousy Breaks
  The 2nd Level of Complexity
  Our Problems Mount (on fractions of fractions, binomial coeffs, &c.)
  Fascinating Things That Expand By Themselves
  A Roman Orgy  (on including ordinary "roman" type w/in equations)
  Too Much of a Good Thing
  Sophisticated Positions  (on matricies, commutative diagrams)
  Practicing Self Control (on defining control sequenences)
  Ex-Rated Features  (advanced stuff)


 :: > He even formed his own publishing company (based on TeX) to publish
 :: > his five volume work on Differentiable Manifolds.
 :: 
 ::   If I install his differential manifolds on my diesel pickup will I get
 :: better milage and more power from the engine?

Since DM's are useful in "mechanics" (better milage) and essential to General
Relativity (more power), I suppose so.

 :: > Long before Linux and the "free software revolution" there was TeX and
 :: > the army of people writing all kinds of modules for it.  For serious
 :: > users it's a way of life and makes the "cult of emacs" pale in
 :: > comparison. (Well, that may be slight exaggeration).
 :: 
 ::   The TUG -- International TeX Users Group -- is headquartered here in
 :: Portland. But, they apparently do nothing but collect annual dues and hold
 :: annual meetings in furin' countries to which I cannot afford to travel. I
 :: wish there was a local users group that met regularly (once a month?). I'd
 :: sure be an active member!

Most of the work occurs, these days, in Europe, and in particular Germany.
Sebastian Rahtz and Frank Mittelbach are the big wizards.  The latter
is one of the designers of the advanced font scheme (NFSS) used in LaTeX.

Fonts have always been _the_ problem with LaTeX.  Knuth designed his own
(computer modern) and made TeX play nicely with them. If you're happy
with CM fonts, life's a breeze with TeX/LaTeX. If not, well ...

This was before commodity software typesetting so people were just
plain happy to have a beautiful typesetting alternative to troff
(yuck).  But being able to use generally available fonts is nearly
impossible in Plain TeX and, until Mittlebach, LaTeX.  Now its
relatively (key word) simple (as I understand) but I've never deviated
from the fonts that come in Tetex (a reasonable selection) and so I
don't know how to import Your Favourate Font and make it work.

But then I don't even know how to get TTF working in KDE, so it's no
surprise.

 :: 
 ::   Perhaps Sharp would sponsor space and coffee?

Fat chance.  I can't get them to supply klenex :-)

 ::   For me, getting the few fonts I need in is the major issue. Heck, I could
 :: do well with Palatino as the body text (already available) and find
 :: something as a header text, but I need Baker Signet as the company logotype.

Get on the TeX mailing list or the newsgroup and ask questions.
They are peopled with gurus who may just deign to help you. 

<snip>
 :: 
 :: > Be aware that TeX/LaTeX is _not_ a WYSIWYG system, though there are Linux
 :: > packages out that have a WYSIWYG front end.  My (nearly nil) knowledge of
 :: > these is that they are great if you are not trying to do anything very
 :: > sophisticated.  But to get the full power of LaTeX you must go to
 :: > old-fashioned editing.
 :: 
 ::   The LyX web site describes it as WYSIWYM (What You See Is What You Mean).
 :: I've put a lot of LaTeX in the preamble of docs and there's a way (called,
 :: interestingly enough) Evil Red Text (or ERT) to write pure LaTeX in the
 :: midst of your LyX document.
 :: 
 ::   The only real advantages of LyX over LaTeX are, IMO, 1) you don't need to
 :: memorize and type macros, just select them from the pull down menu and 2)
 :: it's just a mouse click to compile and view the dvi output or print a pdf
 :: doc. The full power of LaTeX _is_ available.

I stand corrrected, though if you are reduced to writing straight LaTeX in
the midst of your LyX document, to get all the functionality, then
I might be tempted to argue with you.

As for memorising and typing macros, it "just happens" after a little
while and then you find yourself speeding along just as I'm doing now
in typing this post.  I don't need to think about the individual
letters I'm typing.  I just write.  Same things happens in emacs.  The
initial period of learning is awkward (just as learning to drive a
"standard" tranny truck is awkward, but after three days you don't
even think about it.  But the mouse-clicking menu-binker will be
enslaved to pulling down menus, then pulling down sub-menues, then pulling down
sub-sub-menues, finding entries, and binking on them for the rest of
his life.  All to get \pi into his equation :-)

 ::   A couple of years ago I sold back to Powell's my LaTeX books, except for
 :: one: "LaTeX for Linux" by Bernice Sacks Lipkin. That sits at my desk here.
 :: 
 :: Rich

Maybe that's why you're having so much trouble with fonts :-)
The index of _The LaTeX Companion_ by Goossens, Mittelbach, and Samarin
contains no less than 1.5 pages of entries under "Font, (see also Character)".

I also see in Chapter 7 (Font Selection) sub-headings like:

Introduction to NFSS (New Font Selection Scheme)
Understanding Font Characteristics
Font Families and their Attributes
Encoding Schemes
Using Fonts in Text
Changing the Default Text Fonts
Standard Packages
Providing New Text Fonts
The Low Level Interface
Setting Up New Fonts,

and so on.

But, to be candid, I've not studied this section so I don't know
if  it will help.  Fonts always seem harder (to me) than they should.

By the bye, I'd love to see a nice in-depth tutorial at one of the
PLUG meetings on Fonts (for X, KDE, and or LaTeX).

Dean

through emacs again and things are starting to come back to me.

2000 I think. When I tried to convert a Word document I get an empty

AthlonRob, why would you want to compile that stuff? The "tetex" package 
is rather large and I would just install the stuff that Slackware 
includes. When I first started using TeX 5+ years ago I used the TeX 
tarballs included with the Slackware CD set I got from Walnut Creek 
CDROM. It worked great with emacs and xdvi and ran pretty well 
considering I was using my old 486DX33 w/32MB of memory back then. I 
just don't see the need to compile anything that already exists as a 
ready to install package from a CDROM. Sure back 5+ years ago Slackware 
didn't include that many packages so there were some things I 
downloaded and compiled from the source.

> Why?  Unless there is something in Slack or tetex, itself, that will
> comprehensively `make' the entire tetex package (like rpm -bb), you'd
> be foolish to hand-build everything.  I just looked in my tetex rpm
> (rpm -ql tetex | wc -l) and it counts 6188 separate items. Some
> are directories but the vast majority are files.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Thu Aug  8 23:07:42 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 2002 23:07:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Consistency => Usability? (Was: Re: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208081327390.11960-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208082155270.13251-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> The  bottom line, strong integration is
> bad, independent layers that are capable of working together are good.

For a different perspective, try reading Miguel de Icaza's paper
"Let's Make Unix Not Suck". According to Miguel, the Unix no-policy
tradition leads to "a remarkably low-quality experience for users." I
posted an excerpt below.

> MS doesn't get this, perhaps its marketing, perhaps it's a
> lack of consideration, who knows...

If we accept Miguel's arguments, it is not surprising that Microsoft
trades off application modularity for usability and a (supposedly) coherent interface.

...............

 No policies. - from "Let's make Unix Not Suck"

In the UNIX kernel, the tradition is to not implement policy. This
approach and philosophy permeates the whole UNIX system.

For instance, even X-Windows[1] avoids establishing policies for anything.

What we have ended up with is the ultimate pluggable system: the ultimate
"write your own" operating system.

Developers trying to satisfy every possible user from every possible
background, for every possible task end up making everything an optional
feature. They end up not standardizing on anything and leaving policy to
applications.

The problem is that leaving the policy to individual applications means
that each application gets to decide its policy, its user interface, its
configuration files, and its own way of doing things.

This leads to a complete lack of consistency on graphical applications. It
is not just a matter of toolkit fragmentation: even if you compare Motif
applications you will see that they behave radically different when they
have to deal with the operating system and with the user preferences and
with the environment in general.

Sure, we have the ultimate plug-and-play system, at the expense of having
a barely integrated environment.

Unix today is more of a collection of outdated and loosely coupled tools.
The result is a remarkably low-quality experience for users.

http://primates.ximian.com/~miguel/bongo-bong.html

..............


--Tyler


On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:

>
>
> On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:
>
> > Rich Shepard wrote:
> >
> > Oh, I agree with you 100%.  Why should we duplicate how M$ does things
> > 100% of the time?  We shouldn't...  But the problem is, when people are
> > migrating to OO from M$, they *want and need* that same functionality in
> > order to get the job done.
>
> This is where I pop in with my $0.02 about software design.  Layered
> component based development is good.  True object oriented design (like
> that found in Unix, not like that found in programming languages like Java
> and C++), is wonderful here.  Make expert programs and utilities at one
> layer.  Make them form a fundamental system for the processing of office
> data (whatever you want to call it), make them work with the command line.
> Then on top of them create a layer for using them, probably graphical.
> This way advanced users can have their advanced interface, either via the
> command line or special graphical tools that are known to be for the
> experts.  Then have programs with an interface like OO that is known to be
> for the novice, or winWord expert.  The bottom line, strong integration is
> bad, independent layers that are capable of working together are good.
> The next time you think of designing software, say that to yourself for a
> while first.  MS doesn't get this, perhaps its marketing, perhaps it's a
> lack of consideration, who knows...

> Jason

From keith at ahapala.net  Fri Aug  9 08:17:06 2002

date host mgetty[pid]: init chat failed, exiting...: Invalid argument
date host mgetty[pid]: failed in mg_init_data, dev=ttySHCF0, pid=pid

date host mgetty[pid]: init chat failed, exiting>>>: Interrupted system 
call
date host mgetty[pid]: failed in mg_init_data, dev=ttySHCF0, pid=pid

Here are my configuration lines from mgetty.config:
port ttySHCF0
   speed 38400
   modem-type data
   data-only yes
   toggle-dtr no
   direct no
   init-chat send ATQ0V1E0 expect AT send AT&K3S0=0 expect ok


Any suggestions, insights?

From mike at linuxlink.com  Thu Aug  8 13:55:56 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Struggling with OpenOffice

IBM really doesn't get it either.  We were evaluating some cluster admin
software that they were so happy with.  Almost all of us are old unix
hands.  About 1/2 hour into the first day we all raised our hands at
about the sme time and asked where the command line equivs of the gui
were.  There were none.  They actually expected to run this java junk
over a slow dialup connection from Caracas Venusuela to Agnano Italy.

We all asked why they did not start from the command line and later put
a gui on.  They really did not understand what we were wanting and why.

At the end of the second Day, they knew though.. Big Time.


On Thu, 8 Aug 2002 13:35:50 -0700 (PDT)
Jason Dagit <dagit at engr.orst.edu> spewed into the bitstream:

~
~
~This is where I pop in with my $0.02 about software design.  Layered
~component based development is good.  True object oriented design (like
~that found in Unix, not like that found in programming languages like
~Java and C++), is wonderful here.  Make expert programs and utilities
~at one layer.  Make them form a fundamental system for the processing
~of office data (whatever you want to call it), make them work with the
~command line. Then on top of them create a layer for using them,
~probably graphical. This way advanced users can have their advanced
~interface, either via the command line or special graphical tools that
~are known to be for the experts.  Then have programs with an interface
~like OO that is known to be for the novice, or winWord expert.  The
~bottom line, strong integration is bad, independent layers that are
~capable of working together are good. The next time you think of
~designing software, say that to yourself for a while first.  MS doesn't
~get this, perhaps its marketing, perhaps it's a lack of consideration,
~who knows...
~Jason
~

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Aug  9 09:36:21 2002

I recently began running a postfix log analyzer, and this raises 
questions.... :)

Part of the analysis is this:

/etc/cron.daily/0postfix-log:
Postfix log summaries for Aug 8
Grand Totals
------------
messages
480 received
405 delivered
30 forwarded
60 deferred (1016 deferrals)
45 bounced
98 rejected

The deferred total keeps going up. Yesterday is was around 960. The day 
before, 850 or so. I look farther in the analysis, and I see a list of the 
deferrals, and almost all are spamhouses that don't accept inbound mail, so 
they get "Connection Refused".

Is this just the price I pay for rejecting spam?

Is there a way to see what's in the queue and flush it manually if there's 
nothing important there? I've looked through the postfix, qmgr and flush 
man pages, and I didn't see anything there that looked like a userspace 
command.

Thanks in advance.

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net


There are two types of enumerations: correct ones, that state what they are 
about to enumerate and then contain the correct number of items.





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Aug  9 09:39:39 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 09:39:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Need help with making a RPM
Message-ID: <1550400849.1028911181893.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On 8 Aug 2002, karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom) wrote:

> By the way, if you have a core file and don't know what created it,
> just type "gdb /bin/ls core" and GDB will tell you it's not a core
> from "/bin/ls", then tell you what program created that core dump.

I'm not 100% sure about the linux version (and I don't have a convenient
test box right now to be 100% sure), but many versions of the
"file" command will show you who left that steaming core lying around on
your system.

I.e. "file core"

Which is much faster than firing up gdb on the file.

  -- Steve





From m at netpro.to  Fri Aug  9 09:54:14 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 09:54:14 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] DNS problems
In-Reply-To: <20020808144513.52e7953c.mike@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208090950310.23897-100000@lukem.com>

The DNS servers registered for these domains are:
AUTH101.NS.UU.NET            198.6.1.210
AUTH51.NS.UU.NET             198.6.1.162

I'm guessing that they don't have "www" listed as a valid host in their
zone files.  Once the DNS issues are resolved, make sure that Apache is
configured for both versions:

ServerName votermanagement.com
ServerAlias www.votermanagement.com

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Aug  9 09:58:12 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 09:58:12 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] DNS problems
Message-ID: <371801426.1028912294485.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Fri, 9 Aug 2002, Michael H.Collins subgeni at sbcglobal.net wrote:

> I have two sites that are giving me a hard time.  Along with these two,
> I have many more in the same records in the same way at Worldcom/uu that
> work fine.
> 
> votermanagement.com and activistmanagement work fine.  Put a www in
> front and neither get resolved.

It's your DNS entries.  The "www.votermanagement.com" name does not appear
to have any "A" record in the DNS.

Don't panic about the complexity of the data below.  It's intended for DNS
experts.  To become a DNS expert a good place to start is
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/dns4/.  Also set up a caching nameserver on
your local linux box to have some place to play.  (The transition from
caching to authoritative (local private network only) nameserver is not
too hard once you've read that book.)

Some analysis:

-----
$ dig votermanagement.com

; <<>> DiG 9.1.3 <<>> votermanagement.com
;; global options:  printcmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 35656
;; flags: qr aa rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 2, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;votermanagement.com.           IN      A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
votermanagement.com.    21600   IN      A       65.197.65.119

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
votermanagement.com.    21600   IN      NS      auth51.ns.uu.net.
votermanagement.com.    21600   IN      NS      auth101.ns.uu.net.

;; Query time: 70 msec
;; SERVER: 199.26.172.34#53(199.26.172.34)
;; WHEN: Fri Aug  9 09:43:25 2002
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 105
-----

The line:

votermanagement.com.    21600   IN      A       65.197.65.119

Is the key.  This address resolves to 65.197.65.119 because of that
"A" record present.

The "NS" section shows which nameservers are authoritative for your
domain.  This is where all the information in the "dig" output ultimately
comes from.

Now let's look at the www addresses:

-----
$ dig www.votermanagement.com

; <<>> DiG 9.1.3 <<>> www.votermanagement.com
;; global options:  printcmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 44988
;; flags: qr aa rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;www.votermanagement.com.       IN      A

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
www.votermanagement.com. 21600  IN      SOA
auth51.ns.uu.net. hostmaster.uu.net. 1 21600 3600 1728000 21600

;; Query time: 50 msec
;; SERVER: 199.26.172.34#53(199.26.172.34)
;; WHEN: Fri Aug  9 09:43:34 2002
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 104

-----

Note the lack of any IP address, and dig returns the name "commented
out" with the semicolon.  That name didn't resolve.

The "SOA" (start of authority) record also lets you know which hosts were
responsible for the answer.  Again, our good friend "auth51.ns.uu.net".

The short answer:

Your ISP (uu.net) needs to add the appropriate "A" records to their
DNS.

  -- Steve





From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Aug  9 09:57:36 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 09 Aug 2002 09:57:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DNS problems
In-Reply-To: <20020808144513.52e7953c.mike@linuxlink.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208071132180.3937-100000@joan.burling.com>
 <1028705166.9642.12.camel@duron>
 <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208071132180.3937-100000@joan.burling.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020809095542.022c3d98@localhost>

At 02:45 PM 8/8/2002 -0400, you wrote:
>votermanagement.com and activistmanagement work fine.  Put a www in
>front and neither get resolved.


You have to have an A record or alias in the table for www to resolve also.

>If someone has some free time and is a DNS expert, I could use some
>help.  Worldcom is now saying it is our servers, but It doesn not appear
>to get that far to me.

Dig is reporting this:

;; ANSWER SECTION:
votermanagement.com.    21600   IN      A       65.197.65.119

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
votermanagement.com.    21600   IN      NS      auth101.ns.uu.net.
votermanagement.com.    21600   IN      NS      auth51.ns.uu.net.

;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:
auth51.ns.uu.net.       152744  IN      A       198.6.1.162
auth101.ns.uu.net.      152744  IN      A       198.6.1.210


Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net


There are two types of enumerations: correct ones, that state what they are 
about to enumerate and then contain the correct number of items.





From srau at rauhaus.org  Fri Aug  9 09:48:57 2002
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 09:48:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DNS problems
In-Reply-To: <20020808144513.52e7953c.mike@linuxlink.com>
References: <1028705166.9642.12.camel@duron> <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208071132180.3937-100000@joan.burling.com> <20020808144513.52e7953c.mike@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <20020809164856.GA2093@rauhaus.org>

* Michael H. Collins <mike at linuxlink.com> [020809 09:11]:
> votermanagement.com and activistmanagement work fine.  Put a www in
> front and neither get resolved.

Looks like the uu.net DNS server are authoritative for your domain (I'm
pruning some of the dig command output for clarity):

	srau at kort:~$ dig votermanagement.com NS
	
	;; QUESTION SECTION:
	;votermanagement.com.           IN      NS
	
	;; ANSWER SECTION:
	votermanagement.com.    21383   IN      NS      auth101.ns.uu.net.
	votermanagement.com.    21383   IN      NS      auth51.ns.uu.net.

They know the A record for votermanagement.com:

	srau at kort:~$ dig votermanagement.com @auth101.ns.uu.net A
	
	;; QUESTION SECTION:
	;votermanagement.com.           IN      A

	;; ANSWER SECTION:
	votermanagement.com.    21600   IN      A       65.197.65.119

They don't know the A record for www.votermanagement.com:

	srau at kort:~$ dig www.votermanagement.com @auth101.ns.uu.net A

	; <<>> DiG 9.2.1 <<>> www.votermanagement.com @auth101.ns.uu.net A
	;; global options:  printcmd
	;; Got answer:
	;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 11940
	;; flags: qr aa rd; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 0
                                              
				(ANSWER: 0 means they don't know)

	;; QUESTION SECTION:
	;www.votermanagement.com.       IN      A
	
	;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
	www.votermanagement.com. 21600  IN      SOA     auth51.ns.uu.net. hostmaster.uu.net. 1 21600 3600 1728000 21600

So if you have requested a DNS entry for www.votermanagement.com, they
definitely haven't entered it, and it has nothing to do with your
servers. They also don't have a PTR (reverse DNS) record for
65.197.65.119, and you really should have one.

I didn't check, but the same is probably true of your other domain.

You might consider hosting your own DNS, rather than relying on someone
else. It is not horribly difficult, and you get to be in charge of your
own destiny.

--Stafford



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Aug  9 10:15:20 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 10:15:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix "Deferred"
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020809092906.02289398@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208091010250.22902-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 9 Aug 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:

> I recently began running a postfix log analyzer, and this raises 
> questions.... :)

Russ,

  My postfix installation included a daily report mailed to postmaster by
root. It has all sorts of neat stuff.
 
> Part of the analysis is this:

> The deferred total keeps going up. Yesterday is was around 960. The day 
> before, 850 or so. I look farther in the analysis, and I see a list of the 
> deferrals, and almost all are spamhouses that don't accept inbound mail, so 
> they get "Connection Refused".

  I think that I have finally figured out that the deferrals are outgoing
messages, not incoming. I get a lot of 'em, too. If these spam factories
cannot be annoyed by receiving bounced/rejected messages they sent to us,
then I would change the action from REJECT to IGNORE. According to
/etc/postfix/main.cf, 

# IGNORE the header line is silently discarded.

which I interpret to mean that the message is slipped into /dev/null. If I'm
wrong, then I, too, would like to know how to just throw away the rejections
that are not received by the sender so I can save the bandwidth.

Rich




From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Aug  9 10:50:55 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Fri, 09 Aug 2002 10:50:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix "Deferred"
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208091010250.22902-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3D5400FF.9040108@sun.com>

I believe you can set Postfix up to check to see if the domain from 
which the sender says he's coming from exists, and if it doesn't, to 
auto-reject the message.  Because obviously, if the domain doesn't 
exist, mail isn't EVER going to get back there.

Other checks could be to see if the address matches the initial 
sent-from domain/IP (but some people use from: headers that differ from 
sending domain for their own spam-avoidance reasons), if the netblock 
matches the domain, etc etc.

I had to switch email adresses at one point because I was getting so 
much spam.  I informed my friends, watched the logs and then set any 
mail to that address to REJECT, regardless of sender.

-R

Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I think that I have finally figured out that the deferrals are outgoing
> messages, not incoming. I get a lot of 'em, too. If these spam factories
> cannot be annoyed by receiving bounced/rejected messages they sent to us,
> then I would change the action from REJECT to IGNORE. According to
> /etc/postfix/main.cf, 
> 
> # IGNORE the header line is silently discarded.
> 
> which I interpret to mean that the message is slipped into /dev/null. If I'm
> wrong, then I, too, would like to know how to just throw away the rejections
> that are not received by the sender so I can save the bandwidth.
> 
> Rich



-- 
s u n  m i c r o s y s t e m s

   ~ Richard Langis Jr. ~
   richard.langis at sun.com




From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Fri Aug  9 11:24:44 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 11:24:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Any TeX-perts out there? (was: Re: [PLUG] Struggling with
 OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <200208082254.37894.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208091116040.3937-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Thu, 8 Aug 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

[here I snipped]
> [there he snipped]
>
> >
> >  :: I'm sure I'll compile it... but Slackware has a whole diskset of
> >  :: TeX binaries.
> >
>
> AthlonRob, why would you want to compile that stuff? The "tetex" package
> is rather large and I would just install the stuff that Slackware
> includes. When I first started using TeX 5+ years ago I used the TeX
> tarballs included with the Slackware CD set I got from Walnut Creek
> CDROM. It worked great with emacs and xdvi and ran pretty well
> considering I was using my old 486DX33 w/32MB of memory back then. I
> just don't see the need to compile anything that already exists as a
> ready to install package from a CDROM. Sure back 5+ years ago Slackware
> didn't include that many packages so there were some things I
> downloaded and compiled from the source.
>
As a further caveat, compiling the TeX & associated packages involves more
than ``./configure [mumble sqwitches]; make; make install". Grep the
mailing list for an email I sent out about compiling xdvi from source
for an introduction to some of the surprises that lie ahead. (I still
have the kpathsea documentation to understand before I try to tackle
more in that area.)

> > Why?  Unless there is something in Slack or tetex, itself, that will
> > comprehensively `make' the entire tetex package (like rpm -bb), you'd
> > be foolish to hand-build everything.  I just looked in my tetex rpm
> > (rpm -ql tetex | wc -l) and it counts 6188 separate items. Some
> > are directories but the vast majority are files.
> >
FWIW, kpathsea is a library designed to help programs manage their way
thru these files. Yes, it's configurable. But unless you have a burning
desire to be a LaTeX font geek, I'd stay with the defaults supplied.

(Hoping I added to the signal & not any noise to this thread)
Geoff

From guy1656 at ados.com  Fri Aug  9 13:46:52 2002
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 13:46:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CAD in Linux
In-Reply-To: <3D5319F6.3BCFEF63@k-com.net>
References: <20020808232900.GC7239@boora.com> <3D5319F6.3BCFEF63@k-com.net>
Message-ID: <20020809203329.2CC6D367BD@ados.com>

Q-CAD is free and does most of the drafting stuff that AutoCAD does - 
geometry creation, editing, (like fillets) copy multiple, radial arrays,  
(like for a bolt pattern) etc. 

However, it suffers from what I call 'AbiWord Syndrome' which that means it 
touts itself ad being able to create DXF files (its own output file 
extensions are '.dxf') which makes you think AutoCAD can read them in, while 
in truth these files do not cooperate with AutoCAD at all.

But Q-CAD certainly is a viable candidate if you're looking to design some 
simple mechanical parts and need to get them to a machine shop.

Also, it's certainly -awesome- given that it started out as a student design 
project.

On the other hand, a product to AVOID is 'LinuxCAD,' which was also known as 
'EntCAD' for a short while. This is put out by a take-it-or-leave it company 
which borders on a scam operation. The license (which you only get to read 
when you actually receive the disk,) includes language that says stuff like 
'by using the software you agree not to share your experiences with it to 
others' or some MS-level BS like that. Also, that the software is sold 'as 
is' and if nothing really works (and just about nothing does) then according 
to the license you're SOL, and thanks for the $99 bucks. (or $89, if it's "on 
sale"

I bought it using a credit card, and although the guy refused to refund my 
money, (although guaranteeing it over the phone,) my credit card company 
backed out the charges when I returned the software and filed a complaint. (I 
included screen shots of the website and emphaszed what LinuxCAD advertises 
itself to be able to do, then showd that is fails to perform as advertised.) 
The guy didn't contest it. 

Meanwhile, do a web-search of 'LinuxCAD' and 'fraud' and you'll see what I 
mean ...

GLL



GLL

From karlheg at pdxLinux.org  Fri Aug  9 14:22:56 2002
From: karlheg at pdxLinux.org (karlheg at pdxLinux.org)
Date: 09 Aug 2002 14:22:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] [libc6, apache, db1, apache2] Aptitude screenshot - It can downgrade!
Message-ID: <87sn1nbubz.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Had a little problem on drizzle today...  There is a security update
for `mailman', the list manager we use for these mailing lists.  I
went to upgrade it, and...

A recent packaging of `apache2-mpm-prefork' (from unstable Sid) was
partially installed and broken, requiring a reinstall before it could
be used or purged.  (When I had originally installed it, the build I
tried to install had a bug in the postinst or something.)  The next
build fixes the problem, but the next build requires a newer build of
`libc6'.  The build of `libc6' that it requires is now built without
`libdb1' compatibility support, which is required by the `apache'
(1.3) that runs the pdxlinux.org websites.

I heard about the "libc6" problem on irc.us.openprojects.net #debian
from "/msg apt news" and the topic line.  Had I not seen that, I may
have wound up with an unrestartable apache!  I do have
"apt-listchanges" installed, but the `libc6' changelog indicates that
no packages should be broken by it whos maintainer's had not been
notified.  Apparently, Ben Collins missed Apache's dependancy on the
libdb1 compatibility.  Is there a tool that could have gotten that
list automaticly???

This set of dependancy problems was blocking me from upgrading
`mailman' or anything else on the machine.  Note that on
drizzle.pdxlinux.org, the "/etc/apt/sources.list" contains entries for
stable Woody, testing Sarge, and unstable Sid.  An
"/etc/apt/preferences" control file is used to have the "apt" tools
choose stable Woody packages unless explicitly asked to install newer
builds.  (I really love the "preferences" mechanism!  Great design!)

"Simply" removing the testing Sarge and unstable Sid entries from
"sources.list" was NOT the solution.  Doing so made it impossible to
perform the upgrade of `apache2-mpm-prefork', since it was no longer
found in the package lists.  It could not "simply" be "dpkg
--purge"'d, because it was in broken and inconsistent state.  "dpkg"
refused and said that it needed to be reinstalled before I could purge
it.

The solution was to go ahead and let the Apt system upgrade `libc6'
and `apache2-mpm-prefork', and then to immediatly downgrade the libc
and purge apach2, so that the `libc6' installed will work with
`apache' (1.3).  This is important since our LUG web sites are running
on Apache 1.3 still, and probably will be for a few more whiles.

 <URL:http://people.pdxlinux.org/~karlheg/aptitude-can-downgrade.png>

Aptitude is a true UPGRADE to the venerable `dselect'.  It is
everything that dselect was, with most if not all of dselect's faults
fixed.  The upgrade was straightforward, and the new build of
`apache2-mpm-prefork' installed cleanly and all is A-Ok.  I then went
back and used "/" to search for "libc6", pressed "Enter" over it,
cursored down, and marked the older build for install.  I pushed "q"
to go back out to the top level, and then used "l" to limit the
display to only broken ("~b") packages.

I then selected the older build of the other libc related packages,
marked apache2 for purge, and located all other packages that depended
on the new libc6, marking them for either purge, downgrade, or hold.
I initially did this by hand, but as I write this, it occurs to me
that `aptitude' probably provides a better way to do it...  I think
that I could have used "l" to limit the display to "~Bdepends" and
thus obtained the list of packages that had unmep "depends".

The operation completed successfully, with no problems at all.  "ldd
$(which apache)" shows me that everything it needs will be there the
next time it restarts, also.  Excellent.  Time for lunch.  Time
elapsed: ~ 20 Minutes.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'

Sorry for the delay in getting back to you.  It's going to be some time
(two-three weeks?) before I get this up.  Typical bullshit, gotta update
PostgreSQL on my server, migrate a million bird sighting records I keep
for birders in the region, etc etc before I put up my own little website
with stuff like this presentation on that server.

In the interim, though, if you or anyone else wants to play with dotLRN
as deployed at Sloan/MIT, you're welcome to log in as a test user:

http://sloan.mit.edu

user e-mail: testguest at mit.edu
password: test

Feel free to make this info visible or otherwise publicize it and I'd
especially encourage the K12-linux folks to play around with it.  As a
test guest user you only have very limited access but enough to get some
idea of what's up.

I know the LA Unified School district is already planning some
deployments (for school-parent communication I believe), and about a
half dozen universities are working to deploy as well.

From sharbours at yahoo.com  Fri Aug  9 15:52:09 2002
From: sharbours at yahoo.com (Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 15:52:09 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux bootup arp request?
In-Reply-To: <20020808144513.52e7953c.mike@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <20020809225209.30080.qmail@web14407.mail.yahoo.com>

Apparently, when you boot up a Linux Redhat 7.3 box, it sends out
an arp request to see if anyone is using the IP address it has
assigned
to eth0. If it receives a reply, it does not enable eth0.

Normal behaviour, right?

However, this particular box is plugged into a Cisco PIX dmz. When
the Redhat box sends out the arp request, the PIX actually replies
back
with the MAC address of the Redhat box. Apparently, the Redhat box
doesn't
do any checking to see if the reply has its own MAC in it or not, it
just
doesn't bring up the interface at all if it gets a reply.

This is a problem, because if the Redhat box is rebooted in the DMZ,
it
will never come up on the network until it is unplugged from DMZ, the
network services restarted, then plugged back into the DMZ.

Is anyone familiar with this issue? Does anyone know how to change
this
behaviour in Redhat?

Thanks!

Sean Harbour

http://www.hotjobs.com



From cbrown at woods.net  Fri Aug  9 15:47:52 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 16:47:52 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix "Deferred"
In-Reply-To: <3D5400FF.9040108@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208091634050.29118-100000@spruce.woods.net>

On Fri, 9 Aug 2002, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:

> I believe you can set Postfix up to check to see if the domain from
> which the sender says he's coming from exists, and if it doesn't, to
> auto-reject the message.  Because obviously, if the domain doesn't
> exist, mail isn't EVER going to get back there.
>
> Other checks could be to see if the address matches the initial
> sent-from domain/IP (but some people use from: headers that differ from
> sending domain for their own spam-avoidance reasons), if the netblock
> matches the domain, etc etc.
>
> I had to switch email adresses at one point because I was getting so
> much spam.  I informed my friends, watched the logs and then set any
> mail to that address to REJECT, regardless of sender.
>
> -R


	Yes, you can set the reject_unknown_sender_domain restriction
under the smtpd_sender_restrictions parameter.  Note:   This does not
hard reject mail, but rejects is for now (remote end deferes till
later).  This is to protect against bouncing mail during a DNS outage.



I am running with the restrictions shown below (and some others done
later).  However, be *very* careful with

reject_invalid_hostname
reject_non_fqdn_hostname
reject_unknown_sender_domain
reject_non_fqdn_sender
reject_non_fqdn_recipient


Alot of broken MS mail clients don't handle these things correctly, it
is a good idea to understand exactly what each restriction does, and
test it with postfix in softbounce mode first.



smtpd_helo_required = yes
strict_rfc821_envelopes = no
smtpd_recipient_limit = 256
disable_vrfy_command = yes
allow_untrusted_routing = no

smtpd_client_restrictions = permit_mynetworks, reject_maps_rbl, check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/they_spammed_us.hash, permit

smtpd_helo_restrictions = permit_mynetworks, reject_invalid_hostname, reject_non_fqdn_hostname, permit

smtpd_sender_restrictions = permit_mynetworks,reject_unknown_sender_domain, reject_non_fqdn_sender, permit

smtpd_recipient_restrictions = permit_mynetworks, reject_unknown_recipient_domain, reject_non_fqdn_recipient, check_relay_domains

smtpd_etrn_restrictions = permit_mynetworks, reject

 --
I route, therefore you are.

From cbrown at woods.net  Fri Aug  9 16:00:25 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 17:00:25 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix "Deferred"
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208091010250.22902-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208091649440.29118-100000@spruce.woods.net>

On Fri, 9 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Fri, 9 Aug 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
>
>   I think that I have finally figured out that the deferrals are outgoing
> messages, not incoming. I get a lot of 'em, too. If these spam factories
> cannot be annoyed by receiving bounced/rejected messages they sent to us,
> then I would change the action from REJECT to IGNORE. According to
> /etc/postfix/main.cf,
>
> # IGNORE the header line is silently discarded.
>
> which I interpret to mean that the message is slipped into /dev/null. If I'm
> wrong, then I, too, would like to know how to just throw away the rejections
> that are not received by the sender so I can save the bandwidth.



*NO*

The line you are quoting about IGNORE deals with regexp or pcre header
checks.  An expression tagged as IGNORE instead of OK or REJECT will
cause postfix to *IGNORE* that one line while parsing the rest of the
rules.  It allows you to do a more specific match against what would
be a false positive later, and ignore that one line without suspending
the rest of the filters.


If you change that rule to IGNORE, if that is the only rule that spam
is being rejected for, it will no longer be rejected.


BTW, look into the local_recipient_maps setting if you are receiving
alot of mail for non-existant users (and trying to send hundreds of
bounce messages to spammers bad return addresses).


-- 
I route, therefore you are.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Aug  9 17:42:46 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 17:42:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Vanishing .bash_history
In-Reply-To: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844019C72@gilligan.gijoes.com>
References: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844019C72@gilligan.gijoes.com>
Message-ID: <200208091742.46132.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Any chance the file had read-only permissions on it? I tried this before 
and when there is no owner write permission on .bash_history, the file 
isn't updated at all. If the file is empty, it stays empty until owner 
write permission is set on the file. 

Tony

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Fri Aug  9 15:14:12 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 2002 22:14:12 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Help - problem in installing printer
In-Reply-To: <200208100036.35852.satimis@writeme.com>
References: <200208100036.35852.satimis@writeme.com>
Message-ID: <200208100458.g7A4w9U15867@smtp.easystreet.com>

Hi Stephen,

I have RH 7.2 and 7.3- I installed this with no trouble at all on the first 
try. Have you perhaps done a customized installation that left things out? I 
would first remove the RPMs you installed, then install gcc from your Red Hat 
disks. Use a graphical installer, like Kpackage, it makes it a lot easier to 
find things. Be sure to also install gcc- c++, and libstdc++ devel, all under 
Development.

Also install Ghostscript, under Publishing, this driver needs it.

# rpm -e [rpm name]

removes the rpm, append --nodeps if it whines about dependencies.

# which gcc

tells if it is installed

# gcc --version

shows which version is installed.

You probably know this, 'make install' must be done as root.

hope this helps!

Carla

> > net-snmp, libcrypto.so.2, libpcap.so.o.6.2, and libsnmp.so.5, download

Hey, a Tough Guy!  Tough Guy's use Slackware.

They say that the smarter you are the less you have to carry on your
back...  Here's how we do it with Debian GNU.

% apt-cache show apt-build
Package: apt-build
Priority: optional
Section: devel
Installed-Size: 96
Maintainer: Julien Danjou <acid at debian.org>
Architecture: all
Version: 0.5-5
Depends: perl, apt (>= 0.5), gcc | gcc-3.0 | gcc-3.1 , dpkg-dev (>= 1.9), libappconfig-perl (>= 1.5), debconf, devscripts
Recommends: fakeroot, build-essential
Conflicts: pentium-builder
Filename: pool/main/a/apt-build/apt-build_0.5-5_all.deb
Size: 11106
MD5sum: 11b2e35069af01486b78bfc7d4f90b63
Description: Frontend to apt to build, optimize and install packages
 This is an apt-get front-end for compiling software optimized
 for your architecture.
 It can manage system upgrade or dist-upgrade too.

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Sat Aug 10 03:15:17 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 10 Aug 2002 03:15:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
In-Reply-To: <200208060150.g761oJC26014@smtp.easystreet.com>
References: <3D4F05C4.18D603C6@attbi.com> <3D4F1A4A.3AA6D374@attbi.com>
	<20020805182434.B19559@kippered.herring.org>

Message-ID: <87d6sr9g0a.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

[ Please trim portions of citations you are not specificly replying
to.  This practice not only saves space in the archives, but makes it
much easier for others to follow the discussion.  It also lends your
email communications a much more professional appearance. ]

Carla Schroder <pluglist at bratgrrl.com> writes:

> Sandy n Rich, a valiant effort. I hate when someone's idea of help is 
> "apt-get- oh you can't? too bad!"  Those Deb packages are built by human 
> hands, it doesn't take much of a search to find sad forum posts of Deb users 
> having similar problems.

Good point.  They ARE built by human hands... not by quick and dirty
autowraps around the upstream makefiles that neglect silly things like
FHS (Filesystem Heirarchy Standard), stripping binaries, and <gasp>
policy compliance.  (well documented and public policy that is open to
modification through a defined process)

One of the biggest complaints I've heard about non-Debian
distributions is that the packagers often don't take the time to
ensure that files get installed to the correct locations, and things
like that.

Another gripe I have about RPM packages is that the documentation gets
installed with a version number appended to the directory name, like
"/usr/doc/trojanhorse-0.0.1-2", rather than as
"/usr/share/doc/trojanhorse".  With the version number appended like
that, each time you upgrade the software, the URL to the documentation
changes.  You have to update your bookmarks!

 <URL:http://www.pdxlinux.org/dc/>

> Ethereal is a sterling example of how not to build an RPM. I've been fussing 
> with it all afternoon- it's been an interesting education. To heck with the 
> damned RPMs. The machines I use it on, it was installed during the original 
> Linux installation. I'm going to try building from source and see what 
> happens. The libs are on my test system, but not in the RPM database- seems 
> like there was a thread on this not too long ago.

Perhaps if you run into trouble you can download the source and diff
from Debian, and see what they did.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'



From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Sat Aug 10 03:21:50 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 10 Aug 2002 03:21:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051905580.5614-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051905580.5614-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <878z3f9fpd.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

>   When a library is built from source it's not registered in the package
> database. If the rpm installation reports that dependency is missing, but
> 'locate' confirms it's installed, just use the '--nodeps' switch and the
> rpm will install and run without complaints or problems.

I you do not put software and libraries under package manager control,
later on, when you update your machine, the package management system
does not find any dependancies on that library, and removes it.  It
does this to keep cruft from building up in your lib directories.

When you do need something, perhaps even a specific version of
something, you can use (oh, right, only on Debian) "equivs" (search
for it) to create a quick (5 minutes) pseudo package that declares the
dependancies for you, to keep the package manager from uninstalling
that library on you.

You can also use "aptitude hold" to put things on "hold" status, to
keep them from getting upgraded automaticly...  The man
apt_preferences mechanism also provides a way to pin a package at a
specific version.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'

Most Linux users test a number of distributions, and choose the one or ones 
that meet their needs. There are many features other than package management 
to consider. A whole flock of  'gee, too bad you don't have Debian!' posts 
are unhelpful. When a person has a problem to solve and can't get a job done, 
it's annoying to be told "oh you don't have the right Linux, if you did your 
troubles would be over." It's like the inevitable twit who rolls up when 
you're changing a flat tire- chock-full of advice on tire brands, but won't 
actually get out and lend a hand. 

A solution was posted that didn't require the original poster to switch to a 
different Linux and re-install their entire system, and there were several 
other posts with useful bits as well.

From griffint at pobox.com  Sat Aug 10 09:26:30 2002

launched from there when you log in.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sat Aug 10 11:31:03 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)

It's probably simpler to use a desktop/laptop WITH a hard drive, install
linux on there, and use it as a simple X server.  I'd suggest using plain
ol' cat-5 wiring unless you already have all the wireless equipment.

What is the problem you're trying to solve?  What OS is on your desktop
that can't move?

  -- Steve

From prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com  Sat Aug 10 12:16:54 2002
From: prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com (Preston Crawford)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 12:16:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Thin clients?
In-Reply-To: <1296498001.1029004265850.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208101211030.4065-100000@serpentor.local>

On Sat, 10 Aug 2002, Steve Bonds wrote:

> It's probably simpler to use a desktop/laptop WITH a hard drive, install
> linux on there, and use it as a simple X server.  I'd suggest using plain

It's looking that way. Looking cheaper too.

> ol' cat-5 wiring unless you already have all the wireless equipment.

Well, cat-5 would definitely be easier, except that I do already have the
wireless AP. So all we're talking about at that point is buying another
card.

> What is the problem you're trying to solve?  What OS is on your desktop
> that can't move?
>

The problem is this. My wife needs the office. Which means I need to
relocate. There's no where in the house to relocate, that isn't a LONG
ways a way in terms of running cable. So my thought process was this. If I
have to be wireless, I'd rather not be wireless with my desktop. Reason
being that it's secure, stable and used for LOTS of stuff including SSH
server, web development server, java development, etc. So I frankly don't
want to mess it up trying to get a wireless card running on it and I'm
frightened about the idea of it being exposed wirelessly.

So, if I bought a thin client or a cheap PC that connected via wireless, I
could take THAT PC and connect to my desktop, using SSH, etc. That way the
data all remains on the desktop and the connection of the workstation
where I'm processing said data, to the data repository, is relatively
secure. The only thing slightly insecure would then be web surfing, etc.
Email, Usenet, programming, all of that would still be taking place on the
desktop via SSH.

So that's my thought process. I was thinking thin client would be cheaper
than PC, but I can't find anyone who sells thin clients and everywhere
online they're upwards of $350. So I'm thinking at this point it might be
cheaper to do a build-my-own box as cheap as humanly possible, slap Linux
on it and do it that way. Just so long as I can get the wireless card
running fairly easily.

Preston
