I'm also looking at wireless (802.11a to be exact) but don't like the 
insecurity of it. Using IPSec over wireless would be the key, then
there'd be very little insecurity and no need for SSH. However, from
what I hear it may take some hours to get IPSec setup.

Mark



From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Aug 10 12:41:35 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 12:41:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Diagnosing Hard Lock-Up
Message-ID: <3D556C6F.9040209@pacifier.com>

Okay, it's been twice in two months or so that I've come to find a 
particulat screensaver halted.  System ignores keyboard altogether,
and has dropped off the LAN (Destination Host Unreachable).

Only thing I didn't try was serial port login, but this workstation isn't 
set up for that--I think.  Anyway, was forced to do a hard reset--thank you 
ext3.  First thing I did was rpm -e xscreensaver.

Q: Cannot find any damning evidence in /var/log/messages nor /v/l/secure. 
Any ideas where I might find a clue.  I thought X kept a log in the user's 
home, but it's not to be found.

I really suspect the screensaver, but on the otherhand, how could a 
screensaver go so wrong as to bring down networking (lock up the kernel?)

--
Kyle Accardi




From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sat Aug 10 12:49:31 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 12:49:31 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Shell Shortcuts
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208092235040.16997-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

I put together this list of handy shortcuts in the bash shell, a lot of
them apply in other shells as well.

Handy shell shortcuts

key		effect
---------------------------------------------------------
Control A	jump to start of line
Control E	jump to end of line
Control K	delete to end of line
Control U	delete whole line
Control L	clear screen
Control D	log out / delete character

Control Y	yank deletions
Control X ~	list user accounts
Control W	delete word to the left
Control T	transpose two characters

Control F	Move forward a character
Control B	Move backward a character
Meta F		move forward one word
Meta B		move backward one word

Control R	search history in reverse
Control S	search history
Control P	move up history
Control N	move down history
---------------------------------------------------------

More info:
http://www.gnu.org/manual/bash-2.05a/html_chapter/bashref_8.html#SEC100




-----------------------------
Tyler F. Creelan
College of Engineering
Oregon State University
503-618-3101
-----------------------------

we should be glad of an opportunity to serve others by any
Invention of ours, and this we should do freely and generously."

--Benjamin Franklin

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Aug 10 12:51:45 2002

Preston Crawford wrote:

<snip>

> So, if I bought a thin client or a cheap PC that connected via wireless, I
> could take THAT PC and connect to my desktop, using SSH, etc. That way the
> data all remains on the desktop and the connection of the workstation
> where I'm processing said data, to the data repository, is relatively
> secure. The only thing slightly insecure would then be web surfing, etc.
> Email, Usenet, programming, all of that would still be taking place on the
> desktop via SSH.
> 
> So that's my thought process. I was thinking thin client would be cheaper
> than PC, but I can't find anyone who sells thin clients and everywhere
> online they're upwards of $350. So I'm thinking at this point it might be
> cheaper to do a build-my-own box as cheap as humanly possible, slap Linux
> on it and do it that way. Just so long as I can get the wireless card
> running fairly easily.


I have a ThinkNIC, like so

http://www.thenicstore.com/nic/learnmore.html
$249, no HD.  Runs Linux off a CD.  Mainly a web kiosk, but there is (or 
was) ssh, xterm, citrix client, etc.  Of course you could burn your own CD 
and put what you want on it.  I just installed a 20G laptop drive.

There's a decent Yahoo group (if there is such a thing) here

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/thinknic-tech/

--
Kyle Accardi




From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Sat Aug 10 12:55:41 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 10 Aug 2002 12:55:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Diagnosing Hard Lock-Up
In-Reply-To: <3D556C6F.9040209@pacifier.com>
References: <3D556C6F.9040209@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <1029009343.7748.2.camel@duron>

On Sat, 2002-08-10 at 12:41, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> Q: Cannot find any damning evidence in /var/log/messages nor /v/l/secure. 
> Any ideas where I might find a clue.  I thought X kept a log in the user's 
> home, but it's not to be found.
> 
> I really suspect the screensaver, but on the otherhand, how could a 
> screensaver go so wrong as to bring down networking (lock up the kernel?)

grep xscreensaver /var/log/*

Might not be a bad idea.

Your X log should be in /var/log/XFree86.0.log ... although I would be
surprised if it had a lot of information.  If the system dropped off the
network, it was likely not caused by xscreensaver.  xscreensaver
shouldn't even be able to kill the system if it wanted to.  Since it
shoudln't ever be run as root, it is a fairly safe program.

The fact that you dropped off the network would imply the crash was
further down than just the screensaver layer.  Think like kernel
problems.  :-\

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat Aug 10 13:03:42 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 13:03:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Diagnosing Hard Lock-Up
In-Reply-To: <3D556C6F.9040209@pacifier.com>
References: <3D556C6F.9040209@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <200208101303.42149.aschlemm@attbi.com>

>From what I seen there is a file  called .xsession-errors in the users 
home directory that has error and other messages in it. KDE seems to 
spit out alot of stuff into this file on my system. I know too that X 
also creates a logfile in /var/log/Xfree86.0.log.

Since it sounds like your system is crashing outright, have you run 
Memtest-86 to see if you have any bad memory? I had some spectacular 
crashes because of a bad DIMM in my system. I have LILO setup so I can 
choose to run Memtest-86 rather then booting Linux so I can test my 
system's memory. Since the bad DIMM was replaced I haven't had anymore 
crashes.

I've also had X crash and/or hang outright but Linux keep running and 
the box was still reachable from the network so I could login and and 
kill X and then get back to running X from the consol again.

Tony

> particulat screensaver halted.  System ignores keyboard altogether,
> and has dropped off the LAN (Destination Host Unreachable).

Have experienced that here as well.

> Q: Cannot find any damning evidence in /var/log/messages nor /v/l/secure. 
> Any ideas where I might find a clue.  I thought X kept a log in the user's 
> home, but it's not to be found.

Likewise, no log entries of value.  My conclusion is that it is a hardware
failure.

> I really suspect the screensaver, but on the otherhand, how could a 
> screensaver go so wrong as to bring down networking (lock up the kernel?)

My failures usually involve some OpenGL application running (game or
screensaver.)  So I had been thinking that the combo of an Athlon CPU, an
NVidia card (2MX) and heavy graphics use was doing it to me.  I recently
detuned my BIOS from AGP 4X to 2X; that seems to have helped considerably.

What are your hardware specs?

Marc

From eli.stair.lists at attbi.com  Sat Aug 10 11:27:04 2002
From: eli.stair.lists at attbi.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 14:27:04 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Diagnosing Hard Lock-Up
In-Reply-To: <3D5579D0.6040109@pacifier.com>
References: <3D556C6F.9040209@pacifier.com>
	<20020810130340.A21937@mentorg.com>
	<3D5579D0.6040109@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20020810142704.50874fbd.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>

I've had the same problems "for the longest time" with  that same vid.
card (ATI Radeon 64DDR+VIVO).  The drivers seem to be quite buggy, and
considering that ATI isn't (or hasn't been) very helpful with supporting
the linux/DRI driver it's not surprising.  I haven't had any problems for
quite a while now, though I'm not sure if it's due to the updated drivers
(XF4.2,kernel 2.4.19) or the fact that I've stopped trying to play any OGL
apps.  Whatever it is, my system is rock-solid now even with the kernel
compiled with -O3 -march=pentium3 -mmmx -msse -mfpmath, although I shouldn't
have said that....

Have you tried using the snapshot drivers from dri.sourceforge.net?  Also,
if it does it with enough regularity to make testing this worthwhile, try
disabling agpgart in the kernel and just running X non-DRI.

/eli


> > What are your hardware specs?
> 
> 
> PIV 1.9GHz
> 512MB SDRAM
> ATI Radeon 7200
> Asus P4T-E MB

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sat Aug 10 15:17:04 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 15:17:04 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Gresham Charter School - A Plan
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208101340510.17673-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

I've investigated some into the Center for Advanced Learning, the charter
school being built in Gresham. As you recall, the Oregonian reports how
the new school will pay Microsoft to become a Microsoft IT Academy [3].

Listed below are members of the committee that will decide the new
school's Information Technology curriculum. Would Pluggers be
interested in drafting a letter to the committee offering assistance in
the teaching of free software? It seems we could contribute a lot to such
a program; lesson plans, introductory courses for teachers, technical
assistance, and teachers themselves. We could also offer for a
representative of PLUG (David, Karl, etc) to be present at one of the
committee meetings to answer questions or propose ideas.

Assistance from our community could encourage the steering commitee
to incorporate more free software material into the curriculum than they
might otherwise. The charter school is also hiring technical instructors
and PLUG could serve as a good staff resource.

Listed below are members of the IT curriculum planning committee, as well
as contact information for Jim Buck, the committee facilitator. If David
Mandel or anyone could contact Jim that would be great. I personally plan
on contacting Morgan Anderson, the representative from Intel, and reporting
back with more information.

--Tyler

Subject: [PLUG] LILO and installing multiple distributions
Message-ID: <20020810223357.40567.qmail@web13302.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,
After playing around with slackware for awhile, I have decided to give
redhat7.3 distribution a try. 
 
I was amazed when installing slackware7.0, the ease that LILO was setup and
installed for my dual boot system.  I have three drives (C: and D: Windoze98,
E: Linux).  My concern is how the installation of redhat 7.3 (no, I don't want
to use grub) will affect my multiboot startup.  I want to retain my windows and
slackware distributions as well.  I would create another partition on my
E-drive for redhat.    
1. Has anyone had any problems with LILO under such installations of multiple
distributions? Whose "lilo.conf" file would have precedence?
2. How would using the new ext3 file system affect the current ext2 filesystem
I have under slackware 7.0 - including the FAT32 partitions?  
3. Just to make sure, may I use the same partition (mount point) for swap space
I have allocatated under slackware for redhat?  

Many thanks
-dennis

From dealy at deatech.com  Sat Aug 10 16:31:54 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 16:31:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Diagnosing Hard Lock-Up
In-Reply-To: <1029009343.7748.2.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208101621570.10236-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On 10 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

[snip]
> The fact that you dropped off the network would imply the crash was
> further down than just the screensaver layer.  Think like kernel
> problems.  :-\
[snip]

You would think so, but X has just a little to much access to the kernel,
I have had a number of system crashes over the years that were due to
problems with X.  My most recent was just a couple days ago, I setup a
"new" system (old parts from around the office) to use as a test bed,
installed the latest stable Debian, as soon as gdm starts up, it takes
the system down (at least five times in a row).  Having had previous
problems with gdm and system stability, I switched the system to using xdm
(no packages were installed/uninstalled, all I did was make a one line
configuration change to use xdm as the default instead of gdm), and it
boots/runs just fine every time.

dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From jon at manymoons.net  Sat Aug 10 17:26:25 2002
From: jon at manymoons.net (Jon Jacob)
Date: 10 Aug 2002 17:26:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Shell Shortcuts
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208092235040.16997-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Message-ID: <1029025586.455.3053.camel@lana.manymoons.net>

Correct me if I am wrong, but a lot of the editing shortcuts are based
on what your default editor is.  In your case, the default editor
appears to be emacs but if it is vi then the commands would be
different.

On Sat, 2002-08-10 at 12:49, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> I put together this list of handy shortcuts in the bash shell, a lot of
> them apply in other shells as well.
> 
> Handy shell shortcuts
> 
> key		effect
> ---------------------------------------------------------
> Control A	jump to start of line
> Control E	jump to end of line
> Control K	delete to end of line
> Control U	delete whole line
> Control L	clear screen
> Control D	log out / delete character
> 
> Control Y	yank deletions
> Control X ~	list user accounts
> Control W	delete word to the left
> Control T	transpose two characters
> 
> Control F	Move forward a character
> Control B	Move backward a character
> Meta F		move forward one word
> Meta B		move backward one word
> 
> Control R	search history in reverse
> Control S	search history
> Control P	move up history
> Control N	move down history
> ---------------------------------------------------------
> 
> More info:
> http://www.gnu.org/manual/bash-2.05a/html_chapter/bashref_8.html#SEC100
> 
> 
> 
> 
> -----------------------------
> Tyler F. Creelan
> College of Engineering
> Oregon State University
> 503-618-3101
> -----------------------------

> we should be glad of an opportunity to serve others by any
> Invention of ours, and this we should do freely and generously."
> 
> --Benjamin Franklin

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Aug 10 10:53:58 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 17:53:58 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Shell Shortcuts
In-Reply-To: <1029025586.455.3053.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208092235040.16997-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <1029025586.455.3053.camel@lana.manymoons.net>

On Sunday 11 August 2002 12:26 am, you wrote:
> Correct me if I am wrong, but a lot of the editing shortcuts are based
> on what your default editor is. ?In your case, the default editor
> appears to be emacs but if it is vi then the commands would be
> different.

You are correct. Emacs is the Bash default, so a user savvy enough to change 
the default editor will know the keybindings will change too.

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Sat Aug 10 17:41:58 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 17:41:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] laptop config problem
Message-ID: <200208101741.58806.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

Hi folks,

Anyone with Linux laptop config experience out there?

Here's what I've got:

Panasonic CF-62 
Pentium 133
32MB RAM
1.2GB HD
SCSI CD-ROM (yes!)
Optical Drive (yes!)

This thing was top of the line about 6 years ago.  The optical drive makes 
it weigh more than the usual boat anchor.

The PCMCIA controller is by Ricoh, but is listed as revision 0.

I'm trying to make this thing into a nice little portable X-terminal.  
That's about all I think it's worth these days.  Even my firewall has more 
memory.

I've been beating my head against the wall trying to get the PCMCIA system 
to work.  I'm using SuSE 8.0 which offers the "new" in-kernel PCMCIA or 
the old (Dave Hinds') pcmcia-cs package.  I've tried both.  Everything 
else seems to be fine (I'm not happy with the X color depth, but I think 
it's a solvable problem).

I think I've got the memory ranges correct in the PCMCIA config.opts file.  
However, the interrupts are a serious problem.  When I insmod the 
pcmcia_core stuff and the i82365 modules, no PCI interrupt routing table 
shows at all.  Generally this means that Linux has no idea where and what 
the routing table looks like.  This table is needed to route the 
interrupts from the PCMCIA cards to the PCI interrupts.

I have a new Realtek 8139 (8139too.o driver) that is recognized by the 
driver.   However, it always aborts saying that there is no interrupt or 
that "Region #1 is not MMIO...".

The core modules, when inserted, will show interrupts only if I manually 
pass them on the command line.

I've gone through the PCMCIA HOWTO many times and it strongly appears that 
the PCI interrupt routing mechanism on this laptop is totally unknown to 
Linux.  The recommendation is to start trying PCI interrupts until one 
works :-(

An added difficulty is that I have no known way to get to the BIOS on this 
beastie.  I have to keep a small Windows partition on it to run a little 
program that lets me set interrupts for the PCMCIA slots etc.  I've tried 
that, but Linux still doesn't see them.

I've gotten close a few times where cardmgr actually will beep when I 
insert a card, but the driver never works.

Does anyone have any ideas.  I've been working on this over the weekends 
for several weeks now and I'm not closer than when I started.

Best,
Kyle





From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Aug 10 18:39:24 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 18:39:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Shell Shortcuts
In-Reply-To: <1029025586.455.3053.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208101833050.19118-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 10 Aug 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:
> Correct me if I am wrong, but a lot of the editing shortcuts are based
> on what your default editor is.  In your case, the default editor
> appears to be emacs but if it is vi then the commands would be
> different.

Not quite.  I mean that your editor is irrelevant.

The shell movement commands are set in the shell options (SHELLOPT), which
can be viewed with `set -o`.  Two of those options (which are mutually
excusive) are "emacs" and "vi".  "emacs" defaults to on (leaving
"vi" off) in an attempt to standardize editting and movement across the
GNU system.

One can switch their shell to the vi editting style by issuing the
following command:
set -o vi

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org




From dealy at deatech.com  Sat Aug 10 21:06:10 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 21:06:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] LILO and installing multiple distributions
In-Reply-To: <20020810223357.40567.qmail@web13302.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208102054190.10737-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sat, 10 Aug 2002, Dennis wrote:

[snip]
> 1. Has anyone had any problems with LILO under such installations of multiple
> distributions? Whose "lilo.conf" file would have precedence?

The lilo.conf which has precedence is the one on the distribution from
which you last ran the lilo command.  This does not necessarily mean that
it will override lilo on the other distribution, each one could (depending
on how they are configured) simply modify things relating to their own
boot/root partition and leave the other alone, though most likely in their
default configurations there will be some collisions between them.

> 2. How would using the new ext3 file system affect the current ext2 filesystem
> I have under slackware 7.0 - including the FAT32 partitions?

Don't know, I've been using reiser and don't know the effect of ext3 on
ext2 file systems.

> 3. Just to make sure, may I use the same partition (mount point) for swap space
> I have allocatated under slackware for redhat?

Swap partition formats are pretty generic and while there have been a few
minor format changes over the years, I believe the new kernels can handle
all the old format variations, so as long as both distributions are
running roughly comparable kernel revisions (both from the same major
revision number), or the distribution that was used to format the swap
partition uses an older kernel version than the other distribution, you
shouldn't have any problems sharing it between them.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

 I once had a similar problem w/ .bash_history, it turned out that my
chmod for the file was 000, in other words I had no read and write 
permissions for it.

 From KDE (ADD Printer in Graphic Mode)
================================

K_Start -> System -> Printer Configuration
to start "printconf-gui"

click "New" to start "Add a New Print Queue"
Click "Next" to start "Set the Print Queue Name and Type"
Add "H" under "Queue Name" and select "Local Printer"
Click "Next" to popup "Configure a Local Printer" window
Device   /dev/lp0
Model    HP DeskJet 694C
(Remark:  This is the default model.  According to its Note : The drivers 
should cover HP Deskjet 690C-694C)

>Hi Stephen,

>I have RH 7.2 and 7.3- I installed this with no trouble at all on the first
>try. Have you perhaps done a customized installation that left things out? I
>would first remove the RPMs you installed, then install gcc from your Red Hat
>disks. Use a graphical installer, like Kpackage, it makes it a lot easier to
>find things. Be sure to also install gcc- c++, and libstdc++ devel, all under
>Development.
>
>Also install Ghostscript, under Publishing, this driver needs it.
>
># rpm -e [rpm name]
>
>removes the rpm, append --nodeps if it whines about dependencies.
>
># which gcc
>
>tells if it is installed
>
># gcc --version
>
>shows which version is installed.
>
>You probably know this, 'make install' must be done as root.
>
>hope this helps!
>

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Sun Aug 11 17:18:33 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 11 Aug 2002 17:18:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Kernal Panic
In-Reply-To: <1029098714.17580.9.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
References: <1029098714.17580.9.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
Message-ID: <87adntq692.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

alex <alexlinux at qwest.net> writes:

> I'm trying to install Linux onto a 500 Celeron system and keep
> getting kernel panic errors.

Perhaps the kernel you are attempting to install was built with
compiler switches instructing the compiler to use op codes for a
specific model of CPU that is not compatible with the one your machine
uses?  Given that other Linux disks boot and work fine, I would say
that's what it might be.

Try a Debian install CD.  I have a copy if you want it.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'



From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Sun Aug 11 17:20:33 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 11 Aug 2002 17:20:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What does this mean?
In-Reply-To: <98E0NMJFLK971VXS4XBAC0OMJDYOK.3d5696df@miked>
References: <98E0NMJFLK971VXS4XBAC0OMJDYOK.3d5696df@miked>
Message-ID: <8765yhq65q.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Mike De La Mater <mikedela at ipns.com> writes:

> The following entry showed up this morning. I'm concerned that it's
> a message indicating that my server relayed mail, which I don't want
> it to do. I've hacked the addrresses slightly. I can send mail from
> that server, that's why sendmail is installed on it. I haven't sent
> an e-mail from it for quite some time.
> 
> Aug 11 04:01:04 www sendmail[19422]: g7BB13n19422: to=mikedela at isp.com, 
> ctladdr=root (0/0), delay=00:00:01,  xdelay=00:00:00, mailer=esmtp, pri=30586, 
> relay=mail.isp.com. [208.187.227.1], dsn=2.0.0, stat=Sent  (g7BAdvhS092176 
> Message accepted for delivery)

Looks normal to me... since "mail.isp.com" is likely the mail server
where "mikedela at isp.com" receives his mail.  RTFM Sendmail (Bat Book
or online) and you'll find information about what that log entry
means.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Sun Aug 11 17:42:14 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 17:42:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Kernal Panic
References: <1029099183.17580.16.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
Message-ID: <3D570466.4040106@sun.com>

Go grab a copy of memtest86, and see what it says.

I'd been having some panics of my own recently that I thought might have 
been my scsi controller, but I finally found my old memtest disc while 
cleaning up my desk and decided to plop it in.

Lo and behold I had tons of errors right after the 256M boundary.  Go 
figure.

Give that a go.

-R

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Sun Aug 11 17:55:12 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 11 Aug 2002 17:55:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Diagnosing Hard Lock-Up
In-Reply-To: <3D556C6F.9040209@pacifier.com>
References: <3D556C6F.9040209@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <87sn1kq4jz.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Is the kernel you are running patched in any way?

Recently I was having lockup problems.  I had patched my kernel with
EVMS, XFS, and the preemptible kernel patch.  The preempt patch is
what did it, since it did not contain any fixups for the EVMS or XFS
code that are not part of the standard kernel.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.

  Bus  1, device   0, function  0:
    VGA compatible controller: ATI Technologies Inc Radeon QD (rev 0).

lockup problems since switching to XFree86 4.1.

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Sun Aug 11 19:55:01 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 11 Aug 2002 19:55:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Error installing Linux on old PC
In-Reply-To: <3d57212c.4527.0@pcez.com>
References: <3d57212c.4527.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <1029120902.10300.5.camel@duron>

On Sun, 2002-08-11 at 20:45, stuart mathews wrote:
> I am trying to take on old Pentium 100 (NEC) running Win 95a and put Red Hat
> 7.1 on it in a dual boot configuration. The CD ROM isn't bootable, so I'm using
> a "disk driver" to get the ball rolling.
> 
> The CD start whirring and the intstalll appears to be going down, but after
> a couple of minutes I get the following:
> 
> "...waiting for X servre....
> 
> Gdk - error ** Fatal IO error 104 (connection reset by peer) on X servre :1

It sounds to me like RedHat's lovely X-based install won't work with
your system.  No matter what you do, it is going to run very slow on a
Pentium 100.  Very slow!

What you need to do is do the text-based install thing.  I think there's
a choice when RedHat boots (there was back when I tried it last).  If
not, I'm sure a RH expert here will have an idea on what to do.  :-)

Good luck!

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Aug 12 07:10:35 2002

From keith at ahapala.net  Mon Aug 12 07:18:02 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 07:18:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] mgetty help SOLVED
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208090759160.22802-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208120715170.11672-100000@skua.ahapala.net>

I figured it out. I believe the compiled in modem initialization doesn't 
work for this modem so you have to specify the init in the config or on 
the mgetty command line. My specification of the init chat was 
syntactically incorrect but when I passed the init via the command line 
the modem and mgetty would listen for the call.

Kdog

On Fri, 9 Aug 2002, Keith Nasman wrote:

> 
> I am setting up a dial-in service on one of my servers. I've got the modem 
> installed and setup with drivers. (It's one of those Connexant/Rockwell 
> winmodems. It works, I can dial out with minicom just fine). I've 
> installed the mgetty package and read the various docs/howtos that I've 
> come across but am still having difficulty.
> 
> I try to run mgetty with "mgetty ttySHCF0" or "mgetty modem" and it 
> fails. It looks like the mgetty.config file doesn't have the right 
> settings. Here is what I get when I comment out all but the debug line:
> 
> date host mgetty[pid]: init chat failed, exiting...: Invalid argument
> date host mgetty[pid]: failed in mg_init_data, dev=ttySHCF0, pid=pid
> 
> Here is what I get when I use what I think is the correct config:
> 
> date host mgetty[pid]: init chat failed, exiting>>>: Interrupted system 
> call
> date host mgetty[pid]: failed in mg_init_data, dev=ttySHCF0, pid=pid
> 
> Here are my configuration lines from mgetty.config:
> port ttySHCF0
>    speed 38400
>    modem-type data
>    data-only yes
>    toggle-dtr no
>    direct no
>    init-chat send ATQ0V1E0 expect AT send AT&K3S0=0 expect ok
> 
> 
> Any suggestions, insights?
> 
> TIA,
> Kdog
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From satimis at writeme.com  Sun Aug 11 21:36:58 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 12:36:58 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] Help - problem in installing printer
Message-ID: <200208121236.58714.satimis@writeme.com>

Hi Carla

!!! PROBLEM SOLVED !!!!

New Printer installed.  It is not necessary to update "ghostscript".  
Procedure as follows:

On KDE

K_Start -> System -> CUPS Printer Configuration

to start "Common UNIX Printing System - Konqueror window" and then click 
"Manage Printers"

- click "ADD Printer" -> "Add New Ptinter"
- Fill_in
Name   DJ690C (Name_of_your_printer you expect to display)
Location   /dev/lp0 (zero, not capital 'o')
Description   HP DeskJet 690C (Description_of_your_printer)

- Continue -> Continue
-Select   
Device   Paraport #1 for DJ690C

- Continue
- Select
Make   HP

- Continue
- Select
Model    HP DeskJet 690C Foomatic+hpijs(en)
                                                     ^^^^^
(It is important to find out the applicable printer driver from HP website)

- Continue
Printer DJ690C has been added successfully

- Click "Printers on ESP bar
- Click "Print Test Page"

That is all, printer installation finished.

Hoping that other folks on the list can read this message understanding the 
step-by-step procedure to install a new printer on KDE environment.

Thanks

Stephen




From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Mon Aug 12 07:51:16 2002
From: John.Hampton at gijoes.com (John Hampton)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 07:51:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Vanishing .bash_history
Message-ID: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014D20@gilligan.gijoes.com>

Keith said:
> I once had a similar problem w/ .bash_history, it turned out that my
>chmod for the file was 000, in other words I had no read and write 
>permissions for it. 

 I checked the permissions when it was messed up and a ls -al showed me that the permissions were 600.  So I did have read/write permissions to the file.  Anyway, it is back to normal now.

John Hampton
Programmer Analyst
G.I. Joe's, Inc.
john.hampton at gijoes.com




From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon Aug 12 09:13:46 2002

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Aug 12 09:00:14 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 09:00:14 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Printing speeds
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208120855130.3473-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Back in the happy days when WordPerfect/8 worked as it should (i.e., up
until earlier this year), printing a processed bunch of words was a quick
job on my HP LaserJet 5. The printer is capable of 12 pages per minute
throughput and that's the speed at which WP docs were printed. Now that I've
switched to OpenOffice, print speed is back down to the level of my LaserJet
4P, about 3-4 ppm.

  It seems to be a function of the application feeding postscript output to
the system and ghostscript then translating it before handing the output to
the printer. Which brings up the question of what -- if anything -- I can do
to increase printing speed.

  If a postscript card is still available for the LJ 5, would that make a
difference and increase throughput? Are there other options available to me?

TIA,

Rich

In-Reply-To: <1029025586.455.3053.camel@lana.manymoons.net>

On 10 Aug 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:

> Correct me if I am wrong, but a lot of the editing shortcuts are based
> on what your default editor is.  In your case, the default editor
> appears to be emacs but if it is vi then the commands would be
> different.
>
> On Sat, 2002-08-10 at 12:49, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> > I put together this list of handy shortcuts in the bash shell, a lot of
> > them apply in other shells as well.
> >
> > Handy shell shortcuts
> >
> > key		effect
> > ---------------------------------------------------------
> > Control A	jump to start of line
> > Control E	jump to end of line
> > Control K	delete to end of line
> > Control U	delete whole line
> > Control L	clear screen
> > Control D	log out / delete character
> >
> > Control Y	yank deletions
> > Control X ~	list user accounts
> > Control W	delete word to the left
> > Control T	transpose two characters
> >
> > Control F	Move forward a character
> > Control B	Move backward a character
> > Meta F		move forward one word
> > Meta B		move backward one word
> >
> > Control R	search history in reverse
> > Control S	search history
> > Control P	move up history
> > Control N	move down history
> > ---------------------------------------------------------
> >
> > More info:
> > http://www.gnu.org/manual/bash-2.05a/html_chapter/bashref_8.html#SEC100
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > -----------------------------
> > Tyler F. Creelan
> > College of Engineering
> > Oregon State University
> > 503-618-3101
> > -----------------------------
> > "As we enjoy great Advantages from the Inventions of others
> > we should be glad of an opportunity to serve others by any
> > Invention of ours, and this we should do freely and generously."

From jason at vancleve.com  Mon Aug 12 15:52:54 2002
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 15:52:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DNS Nonsense
Message-ID: <20020812155254.580fed67.jason@vancleve.com>

Do you folks see anything wrong with this zone record?:


@ IN SOA www.fone.net. root.www.fone.net. (
	0208120859 ; serial
	10800 ; refresh
	3600 ; retry
	604800 ; expire
	86400 ) ; min ttl
christianecology.org.	IN NS	www.fone.net.
christianecology.org.	IN NS	www1.fone.net.
christianecology.org.	IN MX 10	mail.fone.net.
www.christianecology.org.	IN A	207.202.183.82
christianecology.org.	IN A	207.202.183.82


Note the last two lines.  I don't know DNS too well, but when I ping
www.christianecology.org, I get IP 206.168.68.228, one of the servers at
fone.net; though christianecology.org gives the correct IP.  Even
wierder, on Friday, it was the exact opposite.  So I'm growing dubious
of the admin in charge of this domain, and I was hoping someone here
could check his work.

He says it's a caching issue, but in the first place, he also said the
last changes were made before the weekend; and second,
www.christianecology.org was working before and should not have been
changed.  I now get the wrong IP from at least two different DNS
servers.  Can someone confirm this?

Thanx.

--Jason V. C.



From plug at magnetinternet.com  Mon Aug 12 15:59:18 2002
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 15:59:18 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] DNS Nonsense
In-Reply-To: <20020812155254.580fed67.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20020812155254.580fed67.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <3183.66.93.41.102.1029193158.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

 Jason Van Cleve busted out the keyboard and typed:
> christianecology.org.	IN NS	www.fone.net.
> christianecology.org.	IN NS	www1.fone.net.

   FONE.NET                     206.168.68.2
   WWW1.FONE.NET                206.168.68.27

Your DNS servers for your domain are listed above.  Note the difference on
the primary DNS server.  No WWW.

I say change your first NS record to fone.net, not www.fone.net.

--
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com





From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Mon Aug 12 09:17:55 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 16:17:55 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] rpm installation help, please
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208121536300.25810-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208121536300.25810-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <200208122301.g7CN1OO21848@smtp.easystreet.com>

On Monday 12 August 2002 10:37 pm, you wrote:
> 
> Is it possible to install apt on other distros so you can have the best of
> both worlds?
>
> I'm probably missing the point...
> Jason
>
>

Kpackage supports apt-get. I've never tried it, so I have no idea how well it 
works.

Any package manager is constrained by the availability of someone to build 
the packages. For example, new KDE releases do not find their way into Red 
Hat RPMs very quickly, they put more energy into Gnome.

Any more I build from source, for me it is less hassle. I've actually had 
fewer dependency hassles with tarballs. I don't go looking for off-the-wall 
or obscure apps to play with, but stick with quality, well-known apps, so 
that may have something to do with it.

It seems to me distro-centric package managers are a good thing. In theory, 
you get packages tailored for your distribution. As Linux matures, this 
should evolve into a dependable, polished process.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder, Bratgrrl Computing
Plain English spoken here
www.bratgrrl.com
this message brought to you by KMail, on
Red Hat Linux 7.2
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~



From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Mon Aug 12 16:23:40 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 16:23:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] LILO and installing multiple distributions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208102054190.10737-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208121523430.25810-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Sat, 10 Aug 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:

> On Sat, 10 Aug 2002, Dennis wrote:
>
> > 2. How would using the new ext3 file system affect the current ext2
> > filesystem I have under slackware 7.0 - including the FAT32
> > partitions?
>
I has always been a snap for me to upgrade an ext2 to ext3.  I think that
you can even read an ext3 as an ext2 if you just ignore the journal.  The
directions to convert between ext 2 & 3 are on the web, just google it.
You can even do it while the partition is mounted.  I believe the command
is tune2fs, and you give the -j option, something like that.  I don't
think FAT32 can get in on the action.  Just leave it alone.  BTW, you may
need to recompile your kernel to make sure it supports ext3, and you may
want to update /etc/fstab, again, check with google.

>
> > 3. Just to make sure, may I use the same partition (mount point) for
> > swap space I have allocatated under slackware for redhat?
>
> Swap partition formats are pretty generic and while there have been a few
> minor format changes over the years, I believe the new kernels can handle
> all the old format variations, so as long as both distributions are
> running roughly comparable kernel revisions (both from the same major
> revision number), or the distribution that was used to format the swap
> partition uses an older kernel version than the other distribution, you
> shouldn't have any problems sharing it between them.

My understanding was that it is basically just a partion of the disk you
don't care about, and that the data is not kept between uses of the OS.
So even if they had different formats they could just reinitialize the
partion when they boot up (in the worst case).  But I may have missed
something.

HTH,
Jason

From dealy at deatech.com  Mon Aug 12 16:51:40 2002

[snip]
> > > 3. Just to make sure, may I use the same partition (mount point) for
> > > swap space I have allocatated under slackware for redhat?
> >
> > Swap partition formats are pretty generic and while there have been a few
> > minor format changes over the years, I believe the new kernels can handle
> > all the old format variations, so as long as both distributions are
> > running roughly comparable kernel revisions (both from the same major
> > revision number), or the distribution that was used to format the swap

> partion when they boot up (in the worst case).  But I may have missed

You are correct, the swap partition contents are irrelevant once you
reboot, though it hadn't occurred to me to just reformat it on reboot
if there are compatibility issues, not sure if this is a good or bad
idea, but it would certainly work.

From ross at principia.edu  Mon Aug 12 20:52:02 2002
From: ross at principia.edu (Ross Brattain)
Date: 12 Aug 2002 20:52:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] how to generate a byte stream containing 0xff ?
In-Reply-To: <200208121613.g7CGDk431948@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> writes:

> There's /dev/zero and /dev/random, but no /dev/one.  Does anyone know
> of an easy way from the command line to generate a stream of 0xff bytes?
> Clearly it would be easy to write a program to do this, but I wonder
> if there is an existing tool that will do what I want.
> 
> galen

Does perl count as an existing tool?

perl -n0e 'print ~$_' < /dev/zero  might work.

-Ross



From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon Aug 12 20:58:58 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 20:58:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] how to generate a byte stream containing 0xff ?
In-Reply-To: <200208121613.g7CGDk431948@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208121958060.27085-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Beable is a linux kernel module to provide a /dev/one. Requires tweaking
for a 2.4 kernel it seems.

http://www.bitclean.com/download.shtml

Wouldn't it be easier though to write a script to write out binary 1's? Or
read in your zeroes via dd and perform bitwise negation?

$foo=readpipe("dd if=/dev/zero bs=1 count=4"); print ~$foo;


Tyler

Tyler F. Creelan
College of Engineering
Oregon State University
503-618-3101

Here's info on decompiling Microsoft Help Documents into html. This may
be useful if you prefer to read Microsoft SDK stuff on a non-Windows
machine.

Tyler


---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 20:10:33 +0300
From: Serge <serge at wildwestsoftware.com>
To: mono-list at ximian.com
Subject: Re: [Mono-list] Need help: writing a COM control.

> Only works if you have Visual Studio (Framework is not enough, so I couldn't
> try it)

The following page contains some info how to install MSHelp2 SDK without VS.NET:
http://www.helpware.net/mshelp2/h2faq.htm
You can decompile help files (extract HTML etc) using compiler included in
the SDK (hxcomp) with -u option.
If you have VS.NET there is a special help project type for decompilation.


Sergey

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon Aug 12 22:39:22 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 22:39:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] GETTING THE MS .NET DOC TO WORK ON LINUX (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208122234500.27588-101000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Oops, here is an even more detailed explanation.


---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 22:02:45 +0200
From: Guenther Roith <groith at tcrz.net>
To: mono-list <mono-list at ximian.com>
Subject: [Mono-list] GETTING THE MS .NET DOC TO WORK ON LINUX


GETTING THE MS .NET DOC TO WORK ON LINUX
========================================


1. Get the Help SDK and extract it to a temp directory.
http://download.microsoft.com/download/VisualStudioNET/Install/2.1/NT45XP/EN
-US/VSHIK.exe

2. If you don't have VS.NET get this, too and unzip it to the same
directory. http://www.sojdr.com/vshik/patch_vshik_setup.msi.zip

3. Change to that directory and run "patch_vshik_setup.msi.vbs", a
VB-Script. Then run Setup.exe

4. Create a new directory with at least 250 MB on your HD.

5. Change to it and type

"C:\program files\Microsoft Help 2.0 SDK\hxcomp.exe" -u C:\program
files\Microsoft.N
ET\FrameworkSDK\Docs\1031\cpref.HxS

at the command line. Your path may be a bit different.

This can take some time.

6. You will have some files in it and a sub-directory called "html" as well
as "Scripts".
Copy the file dtue.css in "Scripts" one dir level higher, that it is one dir
above "html".

7. Rename it to style.css

8. Copy the php-script convert.php (I've attached it again) in the same
directory and run it (not with Browser, of course!).
This can take 25 minutes.

9. Your done. Move the html directory and the style.css to another location
(or to linux) and point your Browser (Mozilla works well) to
"html/cpref_start.htm"

NOTICE: Most links will work, some not, because they don't point to html
files, but MS HELP 2.0 commands.
However, they are not the important ones.

ALSO NOTICE: While you perhaps might extract the html, MS will not like to
see the result copied somewhere and modified .They have coprights on it.
So don't do it (or don't tell them ;-)

Johannes
-------------- next part --------------

Type: application/octet-stream
Size: 466 bytes
Desc: 
Url : http://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/attachments/20020812/2c377d72/attachment.obj 

From revans at e-z.net  Mon Aug 12 23:26:30 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 23:26:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] login....
In-Reply-To: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGIEHKCCAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGIEHKCCAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20020813061737.EBZQ221.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@dhcp-279-190>

Starting with w
$ w
 11:03pm  up 20:56,  2 users,  load average: 0.03, 0.01, 0.00
USER	 TTY	  FROM		    LOGIN@   IDLE   JCPU   PCPU  WHAT
revans	 tty1	  -		    2:07am 20:55m 11.52s  0.01s  /bin/sh
/usr/X1
revans	 pts/0	  -		   11:03pm  0.00s  0.03s  0.01s  w

I open another xterm and use the w command agian

$ w
 11:03pm  up 20:57,  3 users,  load average: 0.02, 0.01, 0.00
USER	 TTY	  FROM		    LOGIN@   IDLE   JCPU   PCPU  WHAT
revans	 tty1	  -		    2:07am 20:55m 11.57s  0.01s  /bin/sh
/usr/X1
revans	 pts/0	  -		   11:03pm  0.00s  0.02s  0.00s  w 
revans	 pts/1	  -		   11:03pm  2.00s  0.01s  0.01s  bash

So now I know who is where and can use the write command on pts/0

$ write
usage: write user [tty]

OK so to write to myself 
$ write revans pts/1
hello

And at the other end 

$ 
Message from revans at localhost on pts/0 at 23:03 ...
hello

Now to answer back

$ write revans  pts/0
what


On pts/0 I get 

Message from revans at localhost on pts/1 at 23:04 ...
what

control c to end the conversation at one end. Another control c at the other
end to stop that sesion.

I don't think this can work in a three way conversation. You could have two one
on one conversations but the two others involved would not know what the other
was writing. If you want a three way conversation you will have to run some
type of server. There are many servers that can do this and the merits of which
type of server to use for this senario is beyond my experience.


Thank you
Russell

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Tue Aug 13 00:16:46 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 00:16:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] login....
In-Reply-To: <20020813061737.EBZQ221.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@dhcp-279-190>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208122346040.27843-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

On Mon, 12 Aug 2002, Russell Evans wrote:
> I don't think this can work in a three way conversation. ...

ytalk, an updated multi-user version of talk, can handle 3-way
conversations. Plus it's backwards compatible with talk. write is nice,
but not as intuitive as *talk, plus you don't get to watch people type in
realtime. Of course there's always "wall", and if you're already logged
in as root, why resist the urge? :)

echo "LAST WARNING-User accounts being reformatted in 1 minute, move your data NOW." | wall


Billy M Dimaculangan said:
> >  were three of us who knows the root passwd.
> > If  I log in as root and one of
> >  them or both of them log in also as root would
> > I be able to determine if how
> >  many has login as root.

Someone's going to admonish you for this, so I might as well take the
first stab. There are two problems here.

1) You don't need to share root's account to give users root privileges
2) You or the users may be logged in as root for no legitimate reason.

Instead of sharing an account, you can use programs like "sudo".


Hope this helps.

Tyler

From miker at netsailer.com  Tue Aug 13 05:50:01 2002
From: miker at netsailer.com (Mike Russell)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 05:50:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DNS Nonsense
In-Reply-To: <20020812155254.580fed67.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20020813053254.01dc3538@pop3.norton.antivirus>

At 03:52 PM 8/12/2002, you wrote:
>Do you folks see anything wrong with this zone record?:
>
>
>@ IN SOA www.fone.net. root.www.fone.net. (
>         0208120859 ; serial
>         10800 ; refresh
>         3600 ; retry
>         604800 ; expire
>         86400 ) ; min ttl
>christianecology.org.   IN NS   www.fone.net.
>christianecology.org.   IN NS   www1.fone.net.
>christianecology.org.   IN MX 10        mail.fone.net.
>www.christianecology.org.       IN A    207.202.183.82
>christianecology.org.   IN A    207.202.183.82

? what I see is
no "A" or "CNAME" record for "www" or "mail".
are these actual host name (www and mail)?
and what are there IP's.
I would expect something like this, but i am not an expert either;

$TTL 86400
christianecology.org.   IN      SOA     www.fone.net    root.fone.net   (
                 0208120859 ; serial
                 10800 ; refresh
                 3600 ; retry
                 604800 ; expire
                 86400 ) ; min ttl
christianecology.org.   IN      NS      www.fone.net
christianecology.org.   IN      NS      www1.fone.net
christianecology.org.   IN      MX      10      mail.fone.net
www.christianecology.org.       IN      CNAME   christianecology.org.
christianecology.org.   IN      A       207.202.183.82


******* here is mine, but i am not running a virtual domain , @ stands for 
"netsailer.net" ******
$TTL 86400
@       IN      SOA     ns2.netsailer.net.      root.netsailer.net. (
                         2 ; serial
                         28800 ; refresh
                         7200 ; retry
                         604800 ; expire
                         86400 ; ttl
                         )


@       IN      NS      ns2.netsailer.net.

         IN      MX      1       mail.netsailer.net.

@       IN      A       209.162.208.242
ns2     IN      A       209.162.208.242

mail    IN      CNAME   ns2.netsailer.net.
www     IN      CNAME   ns2.netsailer.net.

From keith at ahapala.net  Tue Aug 13 08:39:06 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 08:39:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sun
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208130803100.17049-100000@skua.ahapala.net>

I'd like to understand Sun's position better. My (weak) understanding is 
that they make most(all?) of their profit on the service agreements on 
their large, powerful systems. With the x86 architecture pushing the 
speeds that it is, Sun is seeing quite the competition from this front 
with clusters of these processors. Now I hear that Sun is coming out with 
some x86 based workstations. Are they really going to compete with the 
likes of Dell, HP/Compaq, Gateway, and everyone else? Are they going to 
get sales for these from their current customers that have big Sun iron 
and service agreements? In addition, Sun is introducing a linux 
distribution (http://news.zdnet.co.uk/story/0,,t272-s2120751,00.html), 
which is an "enhanced" RedHat 7.2. This will be included with their Linux 
server offering and be available for free download. They say in the story 
that support is the issue they are solving.

So, I see Sun's high end market shrinking. I see Sun trying to get into 
the low end x86 market. And, I see them jumping into the Linux distro 
fray.

What are your thoughts?

Keith

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Aug 13 09:08:24 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 09:08:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Sun
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208130803100.17049-100000@skua.ahapala.net>

Well, I work at Sun, and so - I do have a bit of insider information.  I 
can't share it, unfortunately...  This is, after all, a public list.

However, what I can say is that Sun is doing quite well in the high-end 
server market, and that any offshoots are simply positioning to get the 
maximum amount of market penetration.  If you have Sun on the high-end, 
you can also have Sun on the low-end, and everywhere in between.

-R

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Aug 13 09:11:39 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 09:11:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What about BSD?
In-Reply-To: <3d592b3c.3cd7.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208130904360.29568-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 13 Aug 2002, stuart mathews wrote:

> I am curious about this Free BSD OS and would like to experiment
> with it if it runs on Intel. Would it run on a Pentium 400 mmhz pc
> w/320 mb ram?  Where can I get the CDs of a recent release?

a. Yes, and speedily at that :-)

b. http://www.freebsd.org/

If you've got a decent DSL or cable-modem connection to the Internet, 
you won't need a CD. Just grab the images for the installation disks 
and do the installation over the Net. On any FreeBSD ftp mirror, take 
a look at the installation README:

  .../releases/i386/4.6-RELEASE/floppies/README.TXT

Grab the floppies; do a dd; reboot; install!

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From satimis at writeme.com  Tue Aug 13 09:22:14 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 00:22:14 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] =?iso-8859-1?Q?WinXP_can=92t_connect_Samba=5FServer_which_?=
 can connect WinXP for files sharing
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20020814002012.00b85e98@pop.net-yan.com>

Hi All Folks.

I encountered following problem

WinXP can't connect Samba_Server but Samba_Server can connect WinXP for 
files sharing

WinXP box and Samba_Server are connected directly via a crossover cable as 
experiment.  Firewall of WinXP is off and ipchains on Samba_Server also off.

(Remark: The WinXP box has been tested via direct connection with a 
crossover cable to a WinME box/Win98 box for files transfer.  No problem found)

Static IP address
Samba_Server (RH7.3)    192.168.0.1
                   Subnet Mask 255.255.255.0
WinXP                   192.168.0.2
                   Subnet Mask 255.255.255.0

Workgroup                       SEC
Name of Samba_Server            IWILL
Share folder                    test
Name of WinXP           M40G
Share folder                    Shared

On Window Exploror. SEC and M40G shown up under MSWindows Network.  But 
IWILL disappears

WinXP box
=========
 >ping 192.168.0.1

Pinging 192.168.0.1 with 32 bytes of data:

Reply from 192.168.0.1: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=128
Reply from 192.168.0.1: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=128
Reply from 192.168.0.1: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=128
Reply from 192.168.0.1: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=128

Ping statistics for 192.168.0.1:
     Packets: Sent = 4, Received = 4, Lost = 0 (0% loss),
Approximate round trip times in milli-seconds:
     Minimum = 0ms, Maximum = 0ms, Average = 0ms

Start  Run  \\WILL\test --> OK
"The net path was not found"

Start  Run  \\192.168.0.1 --> OK
WinXP shows up, not Samba_Server.  This looks strange to me.

Start  Run  \\192.168.0.2 --> OK
Popup for password.  But I have no password for both boxes.  Click "OK" 
does not work.


Samba_Server
===========
#/etc/samba/smb.conf
# Samba config file created using SWAT
# from localhost.localdomain (127.0.0.1)
# Date: 2002/08/05 16:52:24

# Global parameters
[global]
         workgroup = SEC
         security = SHARE
         guest account = M40G

[test]
         comment = test share
         path = /test
       writable = yes
       browseable = yes
         follow symlinks = yes
         wide links = yes
         public = yes
         read only = No
         guest ok = Yes
       guest only = Yes


# /etc/hosts
# Do not remove the following line, or various programs
# that require network functionality will fail.
127.0.0.1       localhost.M2    localhost.localdomain
192.168.0.1     IWILL

# /bin/hostname   [ENTER]
localhost.localdomain

The hostname "IWILL' does not show up ???

In "Network Configuration" window
under "HOSTS"

From keith at ahapala.net  Tue Aug 13 09:51:32 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 09:51:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] =?iso-8859-1?Q?WinXP_can=92t_connect_Samba=5FServer_which_?=
 can connect WinXP for files sharing
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020814002012.00b85e98@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208130931480.17049-100000@skua.ahapala.net>

On Wed, 14 Aug 2002, Stephen Liu wrote:

> Hi All Folks.
> 
> I encountered following problem
> 
> WinXP can't connect Samba_Server but Samba_Server can connect WinXP for 
> files sharing
> 
>          security = SHARE
> 
I have not tried SHARE. You might try setting that to USER and then make 
sure you are logging in to the XP box with the same username and password.

> 
> # /etc/hosts
> # Do not remove the following line, or various programs
> # that require network functionality will fail.
> 127.0.0.1       localhost.M2    localhost.localdomain
> 192.168.0.1     IWILL
>
> # /bin/hostname   [ENTER]
> localhost.localdomain
> 
> The hostname "IWILL' does not show up ???

The hostname command returns the machine's own host name, In this case the 
line with 127.0.0.1. The second field should be a Fully Qualified Domain 
Name (FQDN) and the third the host part like this:

127.0.0.1	server.abcxyz.com	server



HTH,
Kdog

I need to round a floating point number up to the next
integer, regardless of what the fractional part is.
Here's my first attempt:

if (int($score) != $score) {
    $score = int($score) + 1;
}

Is there a more clever way?

Ed - A Perl novice

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Aug 13 10:27:56 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 10:27:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Perl round-up
In-Reply-To: <1029258846.18351.3.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131025540.9451-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 13 Aug 2002, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> I need to round a floating point number up to the next integer, regardless
> of what the fractional part is. Here's my first attempt:
> 
> if (int($score) != $score) {
>     $score = int($score) + 1;
> }

Ed,

  Back in the Old Days, before BCD and large-integer math, we just added 0.5
to the float value, then rounded. I believe that the standard C library
rounds up; truncate would "round" down.

Rich




From bhoran at hexdev.com  Tue Aug 13 14:46:43 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 14:46:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What about BSD?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131014120.7733-100000@serpentor.local>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131014120.7733-100000@serpentor.local>
Message-ID: <200208131446.43963.bhoran@hexdev.com>

Having used FreeBSD as a primary Desktop/Server OS for years....I would 
thoroughly recommend it. The ports collection makes it fun for use on your 
desktop....they even have a Linux emulation system.....as well as a full(?) 
Linux development system....you can compile linux executables on you FreeBSD 
box.....

From rsteff at attbi.com  Tue Aug 13 11:20:50 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 11:20:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Resolved: rpm installation help, please
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051905580.5614-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <200208060439.g764dBC29446@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <3D594E02.23DAC8AF@attbi.com>

Carla Schroder wrote:

> Ha. Nailed it. Building from source was a breeze. Get a single big tarball at
> ftp://ftp.ethereal.com/pub/ethereal/  Do what INSTALL says. Don't forget to
> 'make install' as root. Everything else can be done as an underprivileged
> user.

Well, I'm finally getting back to working on this. (Had to take
advantage of the weather to refinish the decks.)

The machine in question is running RH 7.1 from the K12LTSP disks of
about a year ago.

Ok. I'm giving Carla's suggestion a try. I've got the tarball and I'm
reading INSTALL. Step 1 says to be sure that I have GTK+ and GLIB
installed. When I run gtk-config --version and glib-config --version I
get the following:

1.2.10

INSTALL tells me that I need versions 1.2.0 or above, so these should be
all right. But, INSTALL goes on to say that Red Hat users will need to
install a "gtk-devel" .rpm. rpm -q gtk-devel says "package gtk-devel is
not installed." I went to rpmfind.net and got gtk-devel.rpm. When I try
to install it with:

rpm -i gtk-devel.rpm

I get 13 conflict notices. They all say that some file "conflicts with
file from package gtk+-devel-1.2.10-ximian.10." I'm guessing that when
they said I needed a "gtk-devel" .rpm, they were being generic and that
the 1.2.10 version of gtk+-devel is OK.

I moved on and ran ./configure. I get the error message "UCD SNMP header
files found, but sprint_realloc_objid not found in SNMP library." One of
INSTALL's options is to run ./configure with "--without-ucdsnmp." The
description says, "If 'configure' finds a supported version of the UCD
SNMP library on your system, the SNMP dissector will be enhanced to use
routines from that SNMP library. Use this switch to avoid using the UCD
SNMP library even if you have it installed." So, I re-ran ./configure
using --without-ucdsnmp and it completed. 

Do I care about this? Should I try to find and install whatever is
missing so that my "SNMP dissector will be enhanced?"

Since ./configure --without-ucdsnmp completed, I'm assuming that the
gtk+-devel package was suitable for this project.

I went ahead and ran make. INSTALL helpfully says, "Hopefully, you won't
run into any problems." Apparently, there weren't any problems. There
were a couple of warnings, but I ran ./ethereal and was able to capture
some traffic between my various machines. I ran make install, and make
install-man. I logged back in as an ordinary user. As expected, ethereal
runs, but won't capture packets unless I su to root before running it.

Thanks to all for all your suggestions, and especially to Carla for
encouraging me to try installing something from source.

Carla Schroder wrote:

> sheesh!

Agreed!

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Aug 13 11:30:36 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 11:30:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What about BSD?
In-Reply-To: <3d5948e2.4456.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131103420.29568-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 13 Aug 2002, stuart mathews wrote:

> Also, is BSD going to be substantially different than Linux,
> justifying the purchase of a BSD book? If so, can you recommend a
> good BSD book?

In some ways, a BSD system will look and feel exactly like Linux. Most 
of your normal activity as a user won't be visibly affected.

When it comes to system administration, however, there are some fairly 
huge differences. Probably the best place to start is the FreeBSD 
Documentation Project:

  http://www.freebsd.org/docproj/

Among its offerings, the best complete introduction is the FreeBSD
Handbook, available in a dead-tree edition from amazon.com and for no 
cost online:

  http://www.freebsd.org/doc/en_US.ISO8859-1/books/handbook/index.html

Also, let me take an opportunity to plug "The FreeBSD Corporate
Networker's Guide" by local author Ted Mittelstaedt:

  http://www.freebsd-corp-net-guide.com/

It's not really intended as a general introduction to FreeBSD, but it 
includes some nice stuff for admins looking to replace any existing 
Windows infrastructure with FreeBSD.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue Aug 13 11:34:55 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 11:34:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Resolved: rpm installation help, please
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208051905580.5614-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <200208060439.g764dBC29446@smtp.easystreet.com> <3D594E02.23DAC8AF@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D59514F.3060904@pacifier.com>

Richard Steffens wrote:

<snip>

> INSTALL tells me that I need versions 1.2.0 or above, so these should be
> all right. But, INSTALL goes on to say that Red Hat users will need to
> install a "gtk-devel" .rpm. rpm -q gtk-devel says "package gtk-devel is
> not installed." I went to rpmfind.net and got gtk-devel.rpm. When I try
> to install it with:
> 
> rpm -i gtk-devel.rpm
> 
> I get 13 conflict notices. They all say that some file "conflicts with
> file from package gtk+-devel-1.2.10-ximian.10." I'm guessing that when
> they said I needed a "gtk-devel" .rpm, they were being generic and that
> the 1.2.10 version of gtk+-devel is OK.


To avoid this headache next time, I'd suggest grabbing the matching 
-devel.rpm from your distro instead of the wild world of rpmfind.  And 
definately install the same version of both--they weren't being generic.  As 
you saw, bad things can happen.

--
Kyle Accardi

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Aug 13 13:23:47 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 13:23:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] emacs or xemacs?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131225510.23692-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208131321230.23104-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 13 Aug 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
> After many years, I've decided to give emacs another shot, but now I
> see there are two versions available, does anyone know if there are
> any advantages/disadvantages to choosing xemacs over the emacs?

The essential difference between GNU emacs and Xemacs is that the Xemacs
team refuses to get proper copyright clearance for their submissions and
simply trust that their GPL status will hold out while various developers
go their separate ways while submissions to the GNU emacs project are
signed over to the Free Software Foundation and assured to remain Free for
all time.

The interesting side-effect here is that while XEmacs is free to lift code
from the GNU Emacs tree, GNU Emacs cannot do the same in reverse.

Personally, I'd go with GNU.  They won't do you wrong.
J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Aug 13 13:27:32 2002

In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208121436260.25810-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208131326350.23104-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 12 Aug 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:
> How do you set the default editor?  I thought these worked directly
> from bash.

See my message from Saturday.  It's unrelated to your default editor.

However, many utilities and tools do gather some information from the
EDITOR and VISUAL environment variables.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Aug 13 13:30:50 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 13:30:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sun
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208130803100.17049-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208131328410.23104-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 13 Aug 2002, Keith Nasman wrote:
> I'd like to understand Sun's position better. My (weak) understanding
> is that they make most(all?) of their profit on the service agreements
> on their large, powerful systems. With the x86 architecture pushing
> the speeds that it is, Sun is seeing quite the competition from this
> front with clusters of these processors.

Just to make something fairly clear, there's not a single x86 server
manufacturer that can compete with Sun systems for plain old reliability
and durability.  Even the few NEBS compliant systems you CAN find that run
an x86 architecture will fail when dropped from a few feet.  You can
launch a Sun out of a goddamn cannon without dropping an instruction.

Hyperbole abounds,
J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Aug 13 13:00:32 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 13:00:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] cfengine install
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131227560.18033-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131257070.29568-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 13 Aug 2002, Keith Nasman wrote:

> I'm going to give cfengine a whirl and grabbed the latest release
> from http://cfengine.org . The source compile is giving me the
> following error:
> 
> checking Berkeley DB Version... configure: error: This release of
> cfengine requires BerkeleyDB 3.2 or later
> 
> This system is the RedHat Limbo beta and it has:
> db4-4.0.14-11
> db4-devel-4.0.14-11
> db4-utils-4.0.14-11

You can either try

a. installing the db3 and db3-devel rpms (from limbo or another Red 
   Hat release), or

b. hacking the cfengine configure script to look for the db headers 
   and libs in whatever location the db4-* packages install them.

Personally, I'd try a. before b.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Aug 13 13:03:26 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 13 Aug 2002 13:03:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] emacs or xemacs?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131225510.23692-100000@critter.deatech.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131225510.23692-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <86vg6ewmpd.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Shannon" == Shannon C Dealy <dealy at deatech.com> writes:

Shannon> After many years, I've decided to give emacs another shot,
Shannon> but now I see there are two versions available, does anyone
Shannon> know if there are any advantages/disadvantages to choosing
Shannon> xemacs over the emacs?

Not really, that I know of.  I use GNU Emacs myself.  I think XEmacs
had better font support for a long time, if that matters to you.  I am
not sure how much of a difference there still is today.  XEmacs has
had something of a reputation (deserved or not, I can't say) with
being less concerned about the quality of patches that got in.  That's
basically all I "know" about the distinction (besides some technical
legal issues).

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Tue Aug 13 13:08:06 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 13:08:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] emacs or xemacs?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131225510.23692-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208131301460.28823-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Mostly the issues are political.  Technical aspects have slowly emerged
from that.

http://www.xemacs.org/About/XEmacsVsGNUemacs.html

>From a user point of view they are very similar, and I think anything you
can do in one can be done in the other with tweaking.  I think the biggest
difference is that a package written for one may not be available for the
other.

I tend to use which ever one was released most recently.  In this case I
feel that emacs21 is "ahead" of xemacs21 or whatever number they are on.

HTH,
Jason

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Aug 13 13:15:03 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 13:15:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Sun
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131258410.18033-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <3D5968C7.5040801@sun.com>

Those clusters are based on cheap, expendable hardware.  Probably less 
than $500/box.  I spec'ed out a relatively modest Ultra 10 on the Sun 
Store, and it came to over $2500, even with my 45% discount.

In my experience, Sun hardware is used in cases where reliability is of 
crucial importance.  24/7 high-availability servers and the like.  Like 
Jeme said, 'Shot out of a cannon...'  They're definitely not 
consumer-level boxes.

-R

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Aug 13 13:19:39 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 13 Aug 2002 13:19:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] emacs or xemacs?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208131321230.23104-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208131321230.23104-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <86r8h2wlyc.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> The essential difference between GNU emacs and Xemacs is that
Jeme> the Xemacs team refuses to get proper copyright clearance for
Jeme> their submissions and simply trust that their GPL status will
Jeme> hold out while various developers go their separate ways while
Jeme> submissions to the GNU emacs project are signed over to the Free
Jeme> Software Foundation and assured to remain Free for all time.

Note that the "assignment" to FSF isn't really the important part of
this, it is the "getting your employer to sign off" part that is
important in the "Free for all time" category.  That's what gives you
the right to put it under the GPL to begin with.  The FSF is just
being conservative and using its refusal to take patches/contributions
without the assignment as a motivator for getting the important
document signed.  At least, that's how I've always understood the
issue.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``The two chiefs turned to each other.        
seniorr at aracnet.com      Bellison uncorked a flood of horrible       
                         profanity, which, translated meant, `This is
                         extremely unusual.' ''

And real world performance/response will still be higher on the Sun
equipment than in the cluster environment.

From rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com  Tue Aug 13 13:27:37 2002
From: rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 13:27:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] emacs or xemacs?
Message-ID: <0E402AD0FEACD411B7C100508BCDF611060497CD@cmc-exchange.columbiafunds.com>

XEmacs was formerly Lucid emacs and developed largely or in part by Jamie
Zawinski.  On his site he says:

"Before Netscape, I was primarily to blame for Lucid Emacs, the next
generation of the GNU Emacs text editor / development environment / lisp
system / religion. Lucid finally managed to go bankrupt, and lucid.com was
melted down for scrap metal shortly thereafter. You can find the latest
version of lemacs, now called XEmacs, at www.xemacs.org. (Click here for
further evidence of why cooperation with RMS is impossible.)"


The "click here" about RMS is a link to
http://www.jwz.org/why-cooperation-with-rms-is-impossible.mp3

--  
  Michael Rasmussen - Network Engineer, Columbia Management
  voice:  971-925-6723  cell:  503-807-1447  rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Tue Aug 13 13:28:31 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 13:28:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] emacs or xemacs?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131225510.23692-100000@critter.deatech.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131225510.23692-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <200208131328.31609.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I haven't used XEmacs in a number of years now but I did use it when I 
first starting using Emacs. It had all the pulldown menus and other 
stuff which made it easy to use and learn. Later on I switched to emacs 
as I didn't need all of the extra pulldowns and stuff even though emacs 
has its fair share of drop down menus now.

Since many of my jobs over the years have required me to use a Windows 
machine I tend to now favor GNU emacs since it runs under both Windows 
and Unix. It even handles Windows textfiles properly with the CR/LF 
line terminators. I've seen some mixed environments get screwed up when 
someone edits a Windows textfile on Unix and lines are terminate with 
LF characters only. 

With emacs it didn't seem to matter what platform was used to edit the 
file as it seemed to do the right thing on either platform from what I 
remember. I did most of my editing from a Sun box since all of our 
files were in Clearcase and the Sun box was also our view and VOB 
server.

I guess where there might be a problem is if the file was originally 
created on Unix but was used on Windows. 

Tony

From ed at alcpress.com  Tue Aug 13 13:39:32 2002
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: 13 Aug 2002 13:39:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Perl round-up
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131025540.9451-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131025540.9451-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1029271172.18349.31.camel@red>

On Tue, 2002-08-13 at 10:27, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On 13 Aug 2002, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> 
> > I need to round a floating point number up to the next integer, regardless
> > of what the fractional part is. Here's my first attempt:
> > 
> > if (int($score) != $score) {
> >     $score = int($score) + 1;
> > }
> 
> Ed,
> 
>   Back in the Old Days, before BCD and large-integer math, we just added 0.5
> to the float value, then rounded. I believe that the standard C library
> rounds up; truncate would "round" down.

I wanted something different. I wanted to round up if there
was a fractional part, regardless of the value of the fractional
part. My code (in Perl) did that but there's a POSIX function
called ceil() that did it without the additional test:

$score = ceil($score);

Ed

On 13 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> Sorry about the date there, I had to roll my system back to the 18th to
> fool a program into working for me.  ;-)
>
> Sure, I should just buy it, but they want $70 for it.  And that is with
> a student discount!

> :::grumbles about not being able to change the clock for only a single
> application:::

I smell a device driver/kernel patch....Maybe it could be completely
usermode....or just hack glibc.  Maybe you would have a config file, like
~rob/.clockrc and when executable x asks for the date, you return a
specific date, with current time.

Any ideas on the easiest way to hook into the system calls to accomplish
this?  Of course applications could probably just create a file and test
the date if they want to get around this, so it might take some careful
thought to fool a "smart" program....or perhaps you could change the
system call for checking the date of a file too.

The fun you could have confusing make...

Jason
