From deanm at sharplabs.com  Tue Aug 13 15:18:38 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 15:18:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] emacs or xemacs?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208131321230.23104-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
	(message from Jeme A Brelin on Tue, 13 Aug 2002 13:23:47 -0700 (PDT))
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208131321230.23104-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20020813221838.F1F3110E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>

 :: On Tue, 13 Aug 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
 :: > After many years, I've decided to give emacs another shot, but now I
 :: > see there are two versions available, does anyone know if there are
 :: > any advantages/disadvantages to choosing xemacs over the emacs?
 :: 
 :: The essential difference between GNU emacs and Xemacs is that the Xemacs
 :: team refuses to get proper copyright clearance for their submissions and
 :: simply trust that their GPL status will hold out while various developers
 :: go their separate ways while submissions to the GNU emacs project are
 :: signed over to the Free Software Foundation and assured to remain Free for
 :: all time.
 :: 
 :: The interesting side-effect here is that while XEmacs is free to lift code
 :: from the GNU Emacs tree, GNU Emacs cannot do the same in reverse.
 :: 
 :: Personally, I'd go with GNU.  They won't do you wrong.
 :: J.

Apart from the above politcal considerations (on which I will not
comment) there are several fundamental technical differences between
the two, including how each renders fonts.  From what I understand
(and this is entirely from evesdropping on the various newsgroups)
Emacs 21, which just came out a little while ago, has moved
significantly toward Xemacs in its functionality in various areas.

Take a look at 

http://www.xemacs.org/About/XEmacsVsGNUemacs.html

to see the technical differences from the xemacs developers point of view.
This link is with regards to Emacs 20 but they appear (from my 5 second scan)
to say things about Emacs 21 as well.

My general feeling is the xemacs is (a bit) more technically advanced
but that emacs is (a bit) more solidly built.

You can also google on `emacs xemacs' and get a boatload of links
to peruse.

Dean

P.S. For what it's worth I use Emacs.  I tried to switch to xemacs a
year ago but I carried too much Emacs baggage with me to be
successful.  For a newbie, or for someone coming back and not (yet)
having a zillion little emacs-isms built into his fingers, it
probably doesn't make much difference.




From rsteff at attbi.com  Tue Aug 13 15:28:31 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 15:28:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Printer Install Help Please
Message-ID: <3D59880F.1DEF5514@attbi.com>

Flush from my success installing ethereal, I decided that I would
finally try installing a printer on one of my Linux machines. I recently
purchased an HP 656c based partly on finding it on the linuxprinting.org
supported list and mostly on the price (really cheap). I'm running RH
7.1. 

I started by trying to use Webmin. Very nice, but it didn't allow for a
USB connected printer.

I went to the linuxprinting.org web site and found a lot of unreachable
pages. I found a mirror site in Portland and started reading. In the
quick start section they recommend following the distribution's
instructions, so I went to the Red Hat site and started reading:

http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/linux/RHL-7.1-Manual/getting-started-guide/printconf.html

Very straight forward, until I get to the part where I'm supposed to
select the printer driver. The 656c is probably too new to be on that
list. Taking things one step at a time, I applied the selection with
PostScript queue on local device /dev/usb/lp0, giving the queue the
alias, hp656, and watched lpd restart. I ran a test page, knowing that
it wouldn't be right. It did print some text starting with:

%!PS-Adobe-2.0
              %%Title: testpage.fig
                                   %%Creator: fig2dev Version 3.2.3
Patchlevel

So, at least I know that the computer is talking to the printer.

I changed the driver to "Text Only Printer" and tried printing a two
line text file. It sort of worked. I had to press a button next to a
flashing led on the printer for it to actually start printing, but I did
get what I expected.

I found a reference to the sourceforge site that has the hpijs driver:

http://hpinkjet.sourceforge.net/

I followed the instructions at:

http://hpinkjet.sourceforge.net/install.php#download

1. Download and install HPIJS

2. Verify HPIJS is present
   # hpijs -h
   
   Hewlett-Packard Co. Inkjet Server 1.2
   Copyright (c) 2001=2002, Hewlett-Packard Co.

3. Verify your version of Ghostscript to see if IJS support is present 
   # gs -h | grep ijs
   cdjcolor cdjmono cdj550 pj pjxl pjxl300 uniprint ijs stp bj10e bj200

In order to get #3 to work I had to upgrade ghostscript to 7.05 from
5.50. I used:

rpm -U ghostscript-7.05-2.i386.rpm

They tell me that's all I need to do to install hpijs:

  This completes the HPIJS installation. Please see the Usage Example
for more   information.

On the Usage Example page they say:

  The following command will print a postscript file to the lp0 spooler. 
  $ lpr -Plp0 tiger.ps

I created a .ps file by printing a simple web page (just one line of
text) to a file from mozilla. Then I tried:

  # lpr -Php656 mozilla.ps

I went back into printconf to see if the HP 656 might have shown up, now
that the hpijs driver was installed. Not there.  

So, where do I go, now? Is there some way to get printconf to see the
new driver? Or is there something else I'm missing? I looked at rpmfind
for printconf and found different ones for RH 7.1, 7.2, and 7.3. The one
for RH 7.1 is a newer version than the one I have (printconf-0.2.15-2
versus printconf-0.2.12-1). The package html file lists a number of
printers, but the HP 656c is not among them. The package html file for
the RH 7.3 version does not list the printers. Should I try to use the
version of printconf packaged for RH 7.2 or 7.3 on my 7.1 system?

I have the Sybex book, Mastering Red Hat 7.1. It has a section on
printconf, but nothing on what to do if your printer is not on the list.

Thanks in advance for all the good ideas I know I'll get.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From griffint at aracnet.com  Tue Aug 13 15:36:36 2002
From: griffint at aracnet.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 15:36:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] emacs or xemacs?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131225510.23692-100000@critter.deatech.com> from "Shannon C. Dealy" at Aug 13, 2002 12:30:59 PM
Message-ID: <200208132236.g7DMaaJ24518@shell1.aracnet.com>

> 
> 
> After many years, I've decided to give emacs another shot, but now I see
> there are two versions available, does anyone know if there are any
> advantages/disadvantages to choosing xemacs over the emacs?
> 
>

Now there's a good way to open a flame war.

I use emacs because in my line of work I find myself working on a large 
variety of operating systems, some of which don't do X11. By using emacs 
instead of xemacs it makes it easier for me to hop from one OS to another 
and take my editor with me.

If I worked exclusively in X11 environments I'd certainly give xemacs
a spin.

Terry
-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/

> So, where do I go, now? Is there some way to get printconf to see the
> new driver? Or is there something else I'm missing? I looked at rpmfind

I would first try the newer version listed for 7.1.  Failing that, grab the 
latest one (presumably for 7.3) and do a rpm -F

Looks like only printconf-gui requires printconf (don't remember that being 
a seperate package) so grab both of those for 7.3.

Don't know the changelog, but printconf has been updated often over the last 
few years.

Kyle Accardi





From jeff at jhenshaw.com  Tue Aug 13 09:06:02 2002
From: jeff at jhenshaw.com (J Henshaw)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 16:06:02 -0000
Subject: [PLUG] From the Symantec Newsletter
Message-ID: <022b01c242e3$52243830$0400a8c0@oem2k>

Software Flaw Puts Multiple Operating Systems at Risk
REPRINTED FROM: Computerworld
AUG 12, 2002    ARTICLE ID: 1531

by Jaikumar Vijayan

Hole in protocol leaves wide range of vendors exposed


A security hole in software that's used by numerous technology vendors to
transfer data between different systems could allow attackers to run
malicious programs or cause denial-of-service problems on unprotected
servers, according to warnings issued during the past two weeks.


The vulnerability affects the Unix operating systems sold by companies such
as Sun Microsystems Inc. and IBM, as well as Red Hat Inc.'s versions of
Linux and Apple Computer Inc.'s Mac OS X Server software (see box). In
addition, Microsoft Corp. and Hewlett-Packard Co. said they're investigating
whether their operating systems are at risk.


Developers at MIT said the flaw also affects the widely used Kerberos
authentication software, which was developed at MIT and is designed to let
end users securely log onto remote systems. A patch is available on the MIT
Web site.


"This vulnerability was one that pertained to such a large number of
software distributions that we felt it was pertinent to issue an advisory,"
said Jeff Havrilla, a member of the CERT Coordination Center at Carnegie
Mellon University in Pittsburgh. "The problem is large enough that pretty
much every single major operating system vendor has reported being affected
by it."


The vulnerability involves a communication protocol that was developed by
Sun and is based on its SunRPC remote procedure call technology. The flaw
exists in a program function distributed as part of an External Data
Representation (XDR) library that's used by Sun and other vendors to provide
platform-independent methods for sending data between disparate systems.

Publicized Last Month



The problem was first publicized by Internet Security Systems Inc. (ISS),
late last month. ISS said it had found Sun Solaris and the open-source
FreeBSD and OpenBSD versions of Unix to be vulnerable to the hole.


CERT issued an advisory last week and broadened the warning to include other
vendors, as well as popular applications that are compiled using the flawed
library. Those include MIT's Kerberos 5 software, the DMI Service Provider
daemon for remote desktop management and the Common Desktop Environment's
Calender Manager service.


According to the security research organization, the vulnerability is caused
by an integer overflow in the XDR code that can result in improper memory
allocations. Attackers could take advantage of the flaw to cause buffer
overflows that would let them execute code on systems, CERT said.


No exploits have been reported so far, Havrilla said. But it won't take long
for attackers to develop tools that could let them use the hole and scanning
software that looks for vulnerable systems, he added. Until patches become
available from vendors, Havrilla said, users can mitigate their exposure by
disabling the affected services where possible.






From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Tue Aug 13 16:19:13 2002

SunRPC and an integer overflow could lead to root exploit.  Sounds like
the same thing to me...

Jason

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Aug 13 16:32:23 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 16:32:23 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sun
Message-ID: <1248935249.1029281545770.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Tue, 13 Aug 2002, Anthony Schlemmer aschlemm at attbi.com wrote:

> When I was working a contract at Boeing, we had our, as of yet unused,
> production server die several times from hardware failures. Generally
> I've been pleased with Sun's reliability and this was the first time I
> had ever seen a hardware failure on a Sun machine.

Let me guess-- ECache parity error?  Me and several of my sysadmin buddies
all had a number of these failures with the Sun 400/450MHz SPARC
processors.  Sun kept coming out to replace them, and the engineers
definately knew that something was wrong, but the problems persisted
without any official comment from Sun.

This was across 6 different companies with systems purchased over about a
2 year timespan (1999-2001).  I personally witnessed the failure of about
10 CPUs with the same problem over those two years, and among my friends
this count goes into the hundreds.

My guess is a major engineering defect, but again, Sun never confessed.  I
do know that their external cache (the Ecache in the above error) is not
ECC protected, so it's quite possible that they just had a nasty run of
chips with higher-than-normal alpha decay in there.

  -- Steve





From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Tue Aug 13 16:34:27 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 16:34:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Buffer Overrun Question
In-Reply-To: <3D51AD92.9A528711@truedisk.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208131630440.28823-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Wed, 7 Aug 2002, Don Buchholz wrote:

> here's a copy of a classic ....
>
>   http://www.cs.ucsb.edu/~jzhou/security/overflow.html

Has anyone tried their example3.c?  I was following along to make sure I
understood everything, but I don't have an x86 w/linux to test it on.  I
tried on HP-UX and Solaris machines and they output 1, which should be
wrong.  When I get home tonight I will try it on my amd under linux, but
it seems like this example should work under most versions of unix with
modern hardware.  (Of course there will always be exceptions.)

Thanks,
Jason




From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Aug 13 16:45:48 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 16:45:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Sun
References: <1248935249.1029281545770.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <3D599A2C.10906@sun.com>

The Sparc chips/boards are not my *BY* Sun, but rather by a 3rd party 
vendor.  They go through a fairly rigorous burn-in process before being 
shipped to customers (thus the high cost as compared to a similar x86 
chip), but some failures are intermittant.

We had a pretty bad issue a while ago that was 100% the fault of the 
board vendor.  Bad solder paths and such.  More info than that I 
probably shouldn't go into.  :)

Of course, I could cite similar examples from when I worked at the Xeon 
testing lab at Intel.  ;)

-R

Steve Bonds wrote:
> On Tue, 13 Aug 2002, Anthony Schlemmer aschlemm at attbi.com wrote:
> 
> 
>>When I was working a contract at Boeing, we had our, as of yet unused,
>>production server die several times from hardware failures. Generally
>>I've been pleased with Sun's reliability and this was the first time I
>>had ever seen a hardware failure on a Sun machine.
> 
> 
> Let me guess-- ECache parity error?  Me and several of my sysadmin buddies
> all had a number of these failures with the Sun 400/450MHz SPARC
> processors.  Sun kept coming out to replace them, and the engineers
> definately knew that something was wrong, but the problems persisted
> without any official comment from Sun.
> 
> This was across 6 different companies with systems purchased over about a
> 2 year timespan (1999-2001).  I personally witnessed the failure of about
> 10 CPUs with the same problem over those two years, and among my friends
> this count goes into the hundreds.
> 
> My guess is a major engineering defect, but again, Sun never confessed.  I
> do know that their external cache (the Ecache in the above error) is not
> ECC protected, so it's quite possible that they just had a nasty run of
> chips with higher-than-normal alpha decay in there.
> 
>   -- Steve
> 
> 
>

From steve at wirex.net  Tue Aug 13 17:44:44 2002
From: steve at wirex.net (Steve Beattie)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 17:44:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake pcmcia question
In-Reply-To: <1029268430.929.7.camel@coyote>
References: <1029268430.929.7.camel@coyote>
Message-ID: <20020814004444.GA24882@wirex.net>

On Tue, Aug 13, 2002 at 12:53:50PM -0700, Brian Beattie wrote:
> I'm tring to set Mandrake up on a laptop.  My previous setup under
> Debian would automaticaly bring up the network on card insertion. 
> Mandrake is not doing that and I'd like to figure out how to make it
> happen

Hey Brian,

AFAIK, Mandrake should support laptops. Some things to check (that
really shouldn't be distro specific except for the location of the init
scripts):

  - Do you get any beeps when you insert the card? You should get two
    beeps of the same tone. If the second tone is lower than the first,
    that means there was some configuration problem when setting up the
    card. 'chkconfig --list pcmcia' should show whether or not the
    pcmcia init script is configure to run on boot.

  - If you get no tones, is cardmgr running? This is the application that
    actually does the module loading when a pcmcia card is inserted. It
    should be started out of /etc/init.d/pcmcia.

  - What shows up in /var/log/messages when you insert the card, if
    anything?

Good luck!

-- 
Steve Beattie                               Don't trust programmers? 
<steve at wirex.net>                         Complete StackGuard distro at
http://NxNW.org/~steve/                            immunix.org
http://www.personaltelco.net -- overthrowing QWest, one block at a time.

From steve at wirex.net  Tue Aug 13 17:47:38 2002
From: steve at wirex.net (Steve Beattie)
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 17:47:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] From the Symantec Newsletter
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131651450.12254-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <022b01c242e3$52243830$0400a8c0@oem2k> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208131651450.12254-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20020814004738.GB24882@wirex.net>

On Tue, Aug 13, 2002 at 04:53:31PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Tue, 13 Aug 2002, J Henshaw wrote:
> 
> > Software Flaw Puts Multiple Operating Systems at Risk
> > REPRINTED FROM: Computerworld
> > AUG 12, 2002    ARTICLE ID: 1531
> 
>   Interesting, Jeff. In today's "Oregonian" (Business Section) there's a
> little piece about a major security hole in Microsoft's Internet Exploder.
> (So, what else is new, right?). At first, I thought that's what this story
> reported.
> 
>   The Microsoft flaw was confirmed by Symantec so perhaps it is the same
> problem.

It's not, the Microsoft problem (which also affects Konquerer) is related
to its handling of SSL certificates. The above flaw that Jeff quoted is
the buffer overflow vulnerability in Sun's RPC xdr_array code, which
exists in both glibc and kerberos' kadmind, so you should be seeing
advisories from your vendor for both of those packages.

--

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Tue Aug 13 22:51:33 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 13 Aug 2002 22:51:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Key Authentication
Message-ID: <1029304295.15559.29.camel@duron>

Hey everybody-

I'm trying to use SSH Key authentication (RSA) to log on to my school's 
server without the use of a password.  The keys work well on my LAN, but
won't work on the school's system.

Warning:  This is a long email with a lot of (likely useless)
information in it.

I'm running Slackware 8.1 at home on everything except the three Windoze
machines.

The school is runnins Solaris, SunOS 5.8.

My system is running OpenSSH_3.2.3p1, SSH protocols 1.5/2.0, OpenSSL
0x0090604f... and theirs seems to be running 3.4p1.  My actual server is
running 3.4p1, not to worry.

On my system, I'm logged in as rob.  On their system, I'm logged on as
gro.

I generated the keypair (which works great on my LAN and between users
on this box) with the ssh-keygen -t rsa command.  I ftp'd (ascii mode, I
was sure) id_rsa.pub over to the school's box and moved it to
~/.ssh/authorized_keys2 (as I did on local boxen).

I enabled a ton of debug output (-vvv) when I connected to see if I
could figure out what was wrong.  I couldn't.  Here's the pertinent
info, I think:

debug1: service_accept: ssh-userauth
debug1: got SSH2_MSG_SERVICE_ACCEPT
debug1: authentications that can continue: publickey,password
debug3: start over, passed a different list publickey,password
debug3: preferred publickey,keyboard-interactive,password
debug3: authmethod_lookup publickey
debug3: remaining preferred: keyboard-interactive,password
debug3: authmethod_is_enabled publickey
debug1: next auth method to try is publickey
debug1: try privkey: /home/rob/.ssh/identity
debug3: no such identity: /home/rob/.ssh/identity
debug1: try privkey: /home/rob/.ssh/id_rsa
debug3: no such identity: /home/rob/.ssh/id_rsa
debug1: try privkey: /home/rob/.ssh/id_dsa
debug3: no such identity: /home/rob/.ssh/id_dsa
debug2: we did not send a packet, disable method
debug3: authmethod_lookup password
debug3: remaining preferred: ,password
debug3: authmethod_is_enabled password
debug1: next auth method to try is password
gro at odin.pdx.edu's password: 

Any ideas?  I can provide the full debug output if you want it.  It's a
little longer, though!

I did email consultants at pdx.edu in hopes they could help... but every
time I've emailed them in the summer in the past, my emails seem to have
gotten lost.  :-(

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"




From raanders at acm.org  Wed Aug 14 04:13:07 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 04:13:07 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Key Authentication
In-Reply-To: <1029304295.15559.29.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208140409210.12916-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On 13 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> Hey everybody-
> 
> I'm trying to use SSH Key authentication (RSA) to log on to my school's 
> server without the use of a password.  The keys work well on my LAN, but
> won't work on the school's system.
> 
> debug1: try privkey: /home/rob/.ssh/identity
> debug3: no such identity: /home/rob/.ssh/identity

On the remote system are the permissions set correctly for 
/home/rob/.ssh/* ?

/home/rob/.ssh should be u+rwx only.

/hone/rob/,ssh/authorized_keys and identity should be u+rw only.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."




From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Wed Aug 14 05:39:52 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 05:39:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Key Authentication
In-Reply-To: <1029304295.15559.29.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208140454140.468-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Hmm... ssh can be so tricky. So you tried:

ssh -2 gro at odin.pdx.edu

and it doesn't work? Perhaps your authorized_keys file is corrupted; check
that each line corresponds to one key. What's in the .ssh/config or
/etc/ssh/ssh_config files? How does it compare to those on odin?

What happens if you generate a dsa key and use that? An rsa1 key?

What happens if you generate a key on odin, authorize yourself, and try to
connect to odin from odin?

HTH,

Tyler

On 13 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> Hey everybody-

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Aug 14 06:16:44 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 06:16:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Key Authentication
In-Reply-To: <1029304295.15559.29.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208140609080.28975-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

> I generated the keypair (which works great on my LAN and between users
> on this box) with the ssh-keygen -t rsa command.  I ftp'd (ascii mode, I
> was sure) id_rsa.pub over to the school's box and moved it to
> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys2 (as I did on local boxen).
> 
> I enabled a ton of debug output (-vvv) when I connected to see if I
> could figure out what was wrong.

Just to make sure we're on the same page:

1. If you do 'ssh-add -l' on your machine, the key in question
   shows up as listed, right?

2. You invoked ssh with the '-2' option?

3. The perms for ~/ on the school's machine disallow write access to 
   anyone but you?

4. The perms for the ~/.ssh/ directory on the school's machine are 
   0700?

5. The perms for ~/.ssh/authorized_keys2 on the school's machine are
   0600?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Aug 14 09:23:48 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 09:23:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS Setup
Message-ID: <3D5A8413.5B618AB8@attbi.com>

I'm trying to get my HP656c printer working. I decided to look into
CUPS. Yesterday, I had communication between the computer and the
printer using printconf. Today, the printer just sits there with it's
green led on.

Where do I look, next?

Here's what I did this morning.

I found an article describing CUPS at LinuxPlanet: 

http://www.linuxplanet.com/linuxplanet/reports/2913/1/

Following the directions in the article, I installed CUPS and started it
successfully. Then, using Mozilla connected to the web admin tool at:

http://localhost:631/admin

where I tried to add my HP 656c. The first screen asks for a Name, a
Location, and a Description. Eventually, I found a reference to Location
in the CUPS Software Administrators Manual, and based on what I read,
put "/printers" into the Location field.

The next screen asks for a Device. To my surprise, it lists:
USB PRINTER #1 (HEWLETT-PACKARD DESKJET 656C) as one of the options, so
I selected that one.

The next screen wants a "Model/Driver for hp656c," which is what I typed
for the Name in the first step. There is a list box labeled "Make" that
includes HP. Selecting that leads to another screen with a list box
including 3 options:

HP DeskJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)
HP LaserJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)
HP New DeskJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)

I selected "HP New DeskJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)," and tried to print a
test page. I'm told, "Test page sent; job ID is hp656c-1, but nothing
prints. I tried modifying the configuration by selecting "HP DeskJet
Series CUPS v1.1 (en)," and tried again. Again, nothing printed. I tried
a couple of times on each. I went to the "Jobs" screen and saw, "No
Active Jobs." I clicked on "Show Completed Jobs," and found four of
them, with ID's hp656c-1, hp656c-2, -3, and -4. The "State" listed for
each is:

  cancelled at
  Wed Aug 14 08:46:25 2002

(That was for -1. The other 3 are similar, with successively later
times.)

If I click "Restart Job," I get:

  Error:
	client-error-not-possible

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From montagne at boora.com  Wed Aug 14 09:32:03 2002
From: montagne at boora.com (Michael Montagne)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 09:32:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mail Failure
Message-ID: <20020814163203.GA6932@boora.com>

My mail server seems to have stopped receiving mail since I
dist-upgraded last night.  I think the problem is that the second IP is
misconfigured.  I am trying to fix it.  Can someone review my interfaces
file and tell me if it looks right?  FTP is supposed to listen on 227 and mail on 228.  FTP works fine so I'm suspecting this.  But the ifconfig lines look different between eth0 and eth0:1.

### etherconf DEBCONF AREA. DO NOT EDIT THIS AREA OR INSERT TEXT BEFORE IT.
auto lo eth0 eth0:1

iface lo inet loopback

iface eth0 inet static
        address 192.168.10.227
        netmask 255.255.255.0
        gateway 192.168.10.254

iface eth0:1 inet static
        address 192.168.10.228
        netmask 255.255.255.0
        gateway 192.168.10.254


### END OF DEBCONF AREA.  PLACE YOUR EDITS BELOW; THEY WILL BE PRESERVED.



if config shows this:
eth0      Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 00:10:4B:94:F3:E2
          inet addr:192.168.10.227  Bcast:192.168.10.255  Mask:255.255.255.0
          UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  Metric:1
          RX packets:36122869 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:23759787 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:1100279 txqueuelen:100
          RX bytes:2698280874 (2.5 GiB)  TX bytes:3405414307 (3.1 GiB)
          Interrupt:11 Base address:0x1000

eth0:1    Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 00:10:4B:94:F3:E2
          inet addr:192.168.10.228  Bcast:192.168.10.255  Mask:255.255.255.0
          UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  Metric:1
          Interrupt:11 Base address:0x1000

lo        Link encap:Local Loopback
          inet addr:127.0.0.1  Mask:255.0.0.0
          UP LOOPBACK RUNNING  MTU:16436  Metric:1
          RX packets:9394516 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:9394516 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:0 txqueuelen:0
          RX bytes:1824592771 (1.6 GiB)  TX bytes:1824592771 (1.6 GiB)

-- 
  Michael Montagne  [montagne at boora.com]   503.226.1575

In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208140454140.468-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

On Wed, 2002-08-14 at 05:39, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> Hmm... ssh can be so tricky. So you tried:
> 
> ssh -2 gro at odin.pdx.edu

I hadn't... just did:

rob:~ > ssh -2 gro at odin.pdx.edu
gro at odin.pdx.edu's password: 

> and it doesn't work? Perhaps your authorized_keys file is corrupted; check
> that each line corresponds to one key. What's in the .ssh/config or
> /etc/ssh/ssh_config files? How does it compare to those on odin?

My local config file is all commented out, so I'm going with defaults. 
It is different, however, on the server.  I just enabled X11 forwarding.

The odin config file is:

Host *
        ForwardAgent yes
        ForwardX11 yes
        FallBackToRsh no
        StrictHostKeyChecking no

I wonder if StrictHostKeyChecking no is the culprit?

My authorized_keys2 file looks good.  For the rsa1 test, below, I
symlinked it to authorized_keys1 and authorized_keys, just in case.

> What happens if you generate a dsa key and use that? An rsa1 key?

Wow, I've never seen Odin take so long for anything except when I
compiled fluxbox (gotta have a nice wm when you vnc in, yanno).  It took
a good 10 seconds!

No luck with a DSA key... and no luck with the RSA1 key.

> What happens if you generate a key on odin, authorize yourself, and try to
> connect to odin from odin?

I tried it with all of 'em, RSA, DSA, and RSA1.  Same thing, I was
presented with the password request.

> HTH,

It does, odin must have key-based authentication disabled, but not
explicitely disabled.... or something.

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Aug 14 10:31:53 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 14 Aug 2002 10:31:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mail Failure
In-Reply-To: <20020814163203.GA6932@boora.com>
References: <20020814163203.GA6932@boora.com>
Message-ID: <1029346323.14011.374.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Michael,

On Wed, 2002-08-14 at 09:32, Michael Montagne wrote:
> My mail server seems to have stopped receiving mail since I
> dist-upgraded last night.  I think the problem is that the second IP is
> misconfigured.  I am trying to fix it.  Can someone review my interfaces
> file and tell me if it looks right?  FTP is supposed to listen on 227 and mail on 228.  FTP works fine so I'm suspecting this.  But the ifconfig lines look different between eth0 and eth0:1.
> 
Can you ping the 228 address?

> ### etherconf DEBCONF AREA. DO NOT EDIT THIS AREA OR INSERT TEXT BEFORE IT.
> auto lo eth0 eth0:1
> 
> iface lo inet loopback
> 
> iface eth0 inet static
>         address 192.168.10.227
>         netmask 255.255.255.0
>         gateway 192.168.10.254
> 
> iface eth0:1 inet static
>         address 192.168.10.228
>         netmask 255.255.255.0
>         gateway 192.168.10.254
> 
>
I usually put in the broadcast and network addresses as well, just to
force the issue.
 
> ### END OF DEBCONF AREA.  PLACE YOUR EDITS BELOW; THEY WILL BE PRESERVED.
> 
> 
> 
> if config shows this:
> eth0      Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 00:10:4B:94:F3:E2
>           inet addr:192.168.10.227  Bcast:192.168.10.255  Mask:255.255.255.0
>           UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  Metric:1
>           RX packets:36122869 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
>           TX packets:23759787 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
>           collisions:1100279 txqueuelen:100
>           RX bytes:2698280874 (2.5 GiB)  TX bytes:3405414307 (3.1 GiB)
>           Interrupt:11 Base address:0x1000
> 
> eth0:1    Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 00:10:4B:94:F3:E2
>           inet addr:192.168.10.228  Bcast:192.168.10.255  Mask:255.255.255.0
>           UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  Metric:1
>           Interrupt:11 Base address:0x1000

This looks normal, try to connect with an alternative protocol (like
using ping or use nmap to scan the ports).  The more likely scenario is
that your mail server failed to restart (for some reason, might of even
been a race condition; in which case just try restarting the server --
/etc/init.d/exim restart, or whatever your mail program is).

Good Luck

Derek Loree




From srau at rauhaus.org  Wed Aug 14 10:23:13 2002
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 10:23:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Key Authentication
In-Reply-To: <1029304295.15559.29.camel@duron>
References: <1029304295.15559.29.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <20020814172313.GB17834@rauhaus.org>

* AthlonRob <AthlonRobNF at cs.com> [020813 22:41]:

> debug1: next auth method to try is publickey
> debug1: try privkey: /home/rob/.ssh/identity
> debug3: no such identity: /home/rob/.ssh/identity
> debug1: try privkey: /home/rob/.ssh/id_rsa
> debug3: no such identity: /home/rob/.ssh/id_rsa
> debug1: try privkey: /home/rob/.ssh/id_dsa
> debug3: no such identity: /home/rob/.ssh/id_dsa

Based on the debugging output, the exchange is obviously looking in the
wrong place for your public key - in ~rob/.ssh rather than ~gro/.ssh.

I've never tried using keys with different user accounts, but that's
where you need to start looking for the problem.

Maybe try "ssh -l gro ..."?

--Stafford

> * AthlonRob <AthlonRobNF at cs.com> [020813 22:41]:
> 
> > debug1: next auth method to try is publickey
> > debug1: try privkey: /home/rob/.ssh/identity
> > debug3: no such identity: /home/rob/.ssh/identity
> > debug1: try privkey: /home/rob/.ssh/id_rsa
> > debug3: no such identity: /home/rob/.ssh/id_rsa
> > debug1: try privkey: /home/rob/.ssh/id_dsa

> wrong place for your public key - in ~rob/.ssh rather than ~gro/.ssh.
>

> where you need to start looking for the problem.
>

I did do the ssh -l gro, for sure.

The /home/rob/.ssh/idneity, id_rsa, and id_dsa are the private keys it
is looking for to match up with the public ones that are up on the
server, in the authorized_keys2 file.

From beattie at beattie-home.net  Wed Aug 14 12:09:26 2002
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: 14 Aug 2002 12:09:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake pcmcia question
In-Reply-To: <20020814004444.GA24882@wirex.net>
References: <1029268430.929.7.camel@coyote> 
	<20020814004444.GA24882@wirex.net>
Message-ID: <1029352166.11174.9.camel@coyote>

On Tue, 2002-08-13 at 17:44, Steve Beattie wrote:
> On Tue, Aug 13, 2002 at 12:53:50PM -0700, Brian Beattie wrote:
> > I'm tring to set Mandrake up on a laptop.  My previous setup under
> > Debian would automaticaly bring up the network on card insertion. 
> > Mandrake is not doing that and I'd like to figure out how to make it
> > happen
> 
> Hey Brian,
> 
> AFAIK, Mandrake should support laptops. Some things to check (that
> really shouldn't be distro specific except for the location of the init
> scripts):
> 
>   - Do you get any beeps when you insert the card? You should get two
>     beeps of the same tone. If the second tone is lower than the first,
>     that means there was some configuration problem when setting up the
>     card. 'chkconfig --list pcmcia' should show whether or not the
>     pcmcia init script is configure to run on boot.
> 
>   - If you get no tones, is cardmgr running? This is the application that
>     actually does the module loading when a pcmcia card is inserted. It
>     should be started out of /etc/init.d/pcmcia.
> 
>   - What shows up in /var/log/messages when you insert the card, if
>     anything?
> 

The card is configured, but the interface is not brought up.  I have run
ifup by hand
--

beattie at beattie-home.net | for a Resource Action by my former employer,
                         | it is my pleasure announce my immediate
www.beattie-home.net     | availability, contract or permanent.
Embedded Systems, Linux/Unix internals Software Engineer




From shahms at shahms.com  Wed Aug 14 09:44:18 2002
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms E. King)
Date: 14 Aug 2002 09:44:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS Setup
In-Reply-To: <3D5A8413.5B618AB8@attbi.com>
References: <3D5A8413.5B618AB8@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1029343457.7257.9.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

*snip*
> where I tried to add my HP 656c. The first screen asks for a Name, a
> Location, and a Description. Eventually, I found a reference to Location
> in the CUPS Software Administrators Manual, and based on what I read,
> put "/printers" into the Location field.

the name is the only field here that "matters" it is what the printer
will be known as to CUPS, the other two are simply text fields to help
the end-user with a "what" the printer is and "where" it is (in
situations like say, an office with many, many printers). What you put
in those two doesn't really matter as it is simply for your own
edification.

> The next screen asks for a Device. To my surprise, it lists:
> USB PRINTER #1 (HEWLETT-PACKARD DESKJET 656C) as one of the options, so
> I selected that one.

That's good ;-)

> The next screen wants a "Model/Driver for hp656c," which is what I typed
> for the Name in the first step. There is a list box labeled "Make" that
> includes HP. Selecting that leads to another screen with a list box
> including 3 options:
> 
> HP DeskJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)
> HP LaserJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)
> HP New DeskJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)

It looks like you're missing reasonable print drivers. I highly
recommend going to http://www.linuxprinting.org and reading around there
for a bit.  I'm not sure if they have RPMS (I'm also not sure if that's
what you need in the first place), but I promise you they have proper
CUPS drivers for your printer.  Look it up in the database and read
about which drivers work best.  That site should also have good
instructions on installing and configuring each of the availible drivers
under CUPS, LPRng and, I believe, xpdq.

> I selected "HP New DeskJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)," and tried to print a
> test page. I'm told, "Test page sent; job ID is hp656c-1, but nothing
> prints. I tried modifying the configuration by selecting "HP DeskJet
> Series CUPS v1.1 (en)," and tried again. Again, nothing printed. I tried
> a couple of times on each. I went to the "Jobs" screen and saw, "No
> Active Jobs." I clicked on "Show Completed Jobs," and found four of
> them, with ID's hp656c-1, hp656c-2, -3, and -4. The "State" listed for
> each is:
> 
>   cancelled at
>   Wed Aug 14 08:46:25 2002
> 
> (That was for -1. The other 3 are similar, with successively later
> times.)
> 
> If I click "Restart Job," I get:
> 
>   Error:
> 	client-error-not-possible

Yeah, at the moment I'm not sure where this is "configurable" (I think
it might either be a compile time option or a even an #ifdef), but the
reasons behind this are mostly diskspace: in order to restart a print
job that has completed, CUPS needs to keep a copy of that printjob
around, which is probably not very secure nor very sensible for most
installations.

I'd say look at the cups error logs (by default in /var/log/cups/) but,
um, they're possibly the least helpful logs of almost any program I've
seen (with the exception of debug = 10 Samba log files ;-( )

--Shahms

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Aug 14 14:01:59 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 14:01:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Sun
In-Reply-To: <1248935249.1029281545770.JavaMail.root@monkey>
References: <1248935249.1029281545770.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <200208141401.59360.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I do believe that was the problem. Wow I didn't know it hit so many 
other companies. This wasn't a company wide problem at Boeing since it 
was our internal customer that decided what sort of hardware and 
software our project used. I guess if any other groups bought Sun 
systems around that timeframe they may have been hit as well.

Tony

On Tuesday 13 August 2002 16:32 pm, Steve Bonds wrote:
> On Tue, 13 Aug 2002, Anthony Schlemmer aschlemm at attbi.com wrote:
> > When I was working a contract at Boeing, we had our, as of yet
> > unused, production server die several times from hardware failures.
> > Generally I've been pleased with Sun's reliability and this was the
> > first time I had ever seen a hardware failure on a Sun machine.
>
> Let me guess-- ECache parity error?  Me and several of my sysadmin
> buddies all had a number of these failures with the Sun 400/450MHz
> SPARC processors.  Sun kept coming out to replace them, and the
> engineers definately knew that something was wrong, but the problems
> persisted without any official comment from Sun.
>
> This was across 6 different companies with systems purchased over
> about a 2 year timespan (1999-2001).  I personally witnessed the
> failure of about 10 CPUs with the same problem over those two years,
> and among my friends this count goes into the hundreds.
>
> My guess is a major engineering defect, but again, Sun never
> confessed.  I do know that their external cache (the Ecache in the
> above error) is not ECC protected, so it's quite possible that they
> just had a nasty run of chips with higher-than-normal alpha decay in
> there.
>
>   -- Steve
>
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Aug 14 14:49:11 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 14 Aug 2002 14:49:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What about BSD?
In-Reply-To: <86bs8587j8.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Randal" == Randal L Schwartz <merlyn at stonehenge.com> writes:

Randal> I'm not saying that OpenBSD is that much more secure... I
Randal> think the fact that it's a smaller installed base makes it a
Randal> smaller target. :) But OpenBSD does have security as a strong
Randal> driving priority.

I've occasionally wondered if the OpenBSD reputation is mostly just
hype and self-promotion.  Most of the people you hear repeating the
better "security" claims have never actually audited any code
themselves, they are just repeating what they have heard.  So, I
wonder about the basis for the claims and how solid that basis
actually is.

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Aug 14 15:03:23 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 14 Aug 2002 15:03:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Install errors
In-Reply-To: <5D541A4C.7409.6F1CF93@localhost>
References: <5D541A4C.7409.6F1CF93@localhost>
Message-ID: <1029362609.14021.399.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Dirk

Wow, talk about living in the future! (You might want to check your
clock.)
On Wed, 2019-08-14 at 14:27, hapibeli at save-net.com wrote:
> Hello to all. When trying to install RedHat 7.3 over a Debian  hdd I receive the 
> following error message;
> Code: 0f 0b 83 c4 0c 89 d8 2b 05 6c 2a 27 c0 8d 04 40 8d 04 80 89
> Kernel panic: Attempted to kill the idle task!
> In idle task - not syncing
> 
What part of the install did this error occur?  As a first guess, I
would say delete all the partitions on the hard drive that you will be
using for the install.  What I mean by this, if you have a swap
partition, a root partition and a data partition, and you want to
install on the root partition, but keep the data partition, then you
should delete the swap and the root partitions (leave them as free
space) before doing the RH install, but don't delete the data partition.

HTH

Derek Loree

From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed Aug 14 16:18:32 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 16:18:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Install errors
References: <5D541A4C.7409.6F1CF93@localhost>
Message-ID: <3D5AE548.6080301@sun.com>

Redhat 7.3 over Debian!?  That's blasphemy, my son!  ;)

Does the Debian install work fine on the current hardware?  If you're 
reinstalling because it's segfaulting or having other issues, chances 
are you've got a hardware problem (as evidenced by the panic).

Here's my mantra:  Memtest86 (http://www.memtest86.com/)

If that's not it, find a dos-bootable disk and fdisk prior to 
installation, then let the RH setup do it all for you.

Hope that helps.

-R

hapibeli at save-net.com wrote:

That was /etc/ssh_config

/etc/sshd_config is a little bit different, as one might expect.

StrictModes yes
RSAAuthentication yes
PubkeyAuthentication yes
RhostsAuthentication no
IgnoreRhosts yes
RhostsRSAAuthentication no
HostbasedAuthentication no
PasswordAuthentication yes
PermitEmptyPasswords no
ChallengeResponseAuthentication no
X11Forwarding yes
X11DisplayOffset 10
PrintMotd no
KeepAlive yes
UseLogin no  
UsePrivilegeSeparation no
Subsystem       sftp    /usr/sbin/sftp-server

(I cut out all the commented-out lines)

Will anything there keep me from logging in with my keys?

From satimis at writeme.com  Wed Aug 14 09:59:05 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 00:59:05 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS Setup
In-Reply-To: <3D5A8413.5B618AB8@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20020815005703.029a33b0@pop.net-yan.com>

Hi Richard

Try follows :

On KDE

K_Start -> System -> CUPS Printer Configuration

to start "Common UNIX Printing System - Konqueror window" and then click
"Manage Printers"


- click "ADD Printer" -> "Add New Ptinter"
- Fill_in
Name DJ690C (Name_of_your_printer you expect to display)
Location /dev/lp0 (zero, not capital 'o')
Description HP DeskJet 690C (Description_of_your_printer)

- Continue -> Continue
-Select
Device Paraport #1 for DJ690C

- Continue
- Select
Make HP

- Continue
- Select
Model HP DeskJet 690C Foomatic+hpijs(en)
                                                     ^^^^^
(It is important to find out the applicable printer driver from HP website)

- Continue
Printer DJ690C has been added successfully

- Click "Printers on ESP bar
- Click "Print Test Page"

That is all, printer installation finished.


Good Luck
Stephen

>I'm trying to get my HP656c printer working. I decided to look into
>CUPS. Yesterday, I had communication between the computer and the
>printer using printconf. Today, the printer just sits there with it's
>green led on.
>
>Where do I look, next?
>
>Here's what I did this morning.
>
>I found an article describing CUPS at LinuxPlanet:
>
>http://www.linuxplanet.com/linuxplanet/reports/2913/1/
>
>Following the directions in the article, I installed CUPS and started it
>successfully. Then, using Mozilla connected to the web admin tool at:
>
>http://localhost:631/admin
>
>where I tried to add my HP 656c. The first screen asks for a Name, a
>Location, and a Description. Eventually, I found a reference to Location
>in the CUPS Software Administrators Manual, and based on what I read,
>put "/printers" into the Location field.
>
>The next screen asks for a Device. To my surprise, it lists:
>USB PRINTER #1 (HEWLETT-PACKARD DESKJET 656C) as one of the options, so
>I selected that one.
>
>The next screen wants a "Model/Driver for hp656c," which is what I typed
>for the Name in the first step. There is a list box labeled "Make" that
>includes HP. Selecting that leads to another screen with a list box
>including 3 options:
>
>HP DeskJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)
>HP LaserJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)
>HP New DeskJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)
>
>I selected "HP New DeskJet Series CUPS v1.1 (en)," and tried to print a
>test page. I'm told, "Test page sent; job ID is hp656c-1, but nothing
>prints. I tried modifying the configuration by selecting "HP DeskJet
>Series CUPS v1.1 (en)," and tried again. Again, nothing printed. I tried
>a couple of times on each. I went to the "Jobs" screen and saw, "No
>Active Jobs." I clicked on "Show Completed Jobs," and found four of
>them, with ID's hp656c-1, hp656c-2, -3, and -4. The "State" listed for
>each is:
>
>   cancelled at
>   Wed Aug 14 08:46:25 2002
>
>(That was for -1. The other 3 are similar, with successively later
>times.)
>
>If I click "Restart Job," I get:
>
>   Error:
>         client-error-not-possible
>

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Aug 14 17:26:48 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 17:26:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What about BSD?
In-Reply-To: <86bs8587j8.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
References: <mailman.1029258616.17380.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <86bs8587j8.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <200208141726.48488.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Well many of the exploits occur in the installed applications not the 
operating system itself. Keep in mind that OpenBSD runs these same 
applications as Linux does so they both could be vulnerable.

I have OpenBSD on one system and I think what makes it very secure for 
the most part is that the system, after being installed, has virtually 
no services running. SSH is about the only service running on the box 
by default. 

As soon as other services are enabled the box probably becomes less 
secure although with proper IP Filtering setup access to running 
services can be controlled. I was contemplating OpenBSD for my 
gateway/firewall system but the when I tried to upgrade from OpenBSD 
2.9 to 3.0 I got a system that wouldn't boot so I had to level the 
system and reinstall 3.0 cleanly.

I don't know if the install process changed or what but I would really 
like to be able to upgrade a system so I can be done it 20 minutes or 
so. Now that I have 3.0 running I guess should try upgrading to 3.1 and 
see if it upgrades my system properly. 

I don't mind having to reconfigure the system since, for my purposes, I 
only have to restore a few text configuration files. I keep my 
configuration files under revision control so I can slap them back on 
my newly installed system with very little effort.

Tony

> fact that it's a smaller installed base makes it a smaller target. :)
> But OpenBSD does have security as a strong driving priority.

I built mozilla 1.1b today from the .src.rpm and am trying to get
various plugings to work.  To check out the video plugin I go to:

http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/hframe.html

and click on video/demo index on the right of frame.  When I click on
a video I can see the .MOV data loading into /tmp/plugtmp but as soon
as the helper app (in this case several instances of xanim according
to `ps') starts up, the files in /tmp/plugtmp just disappears and the
thing just hangs.  I can back out of the page but I can't get the
videos to play.  `xanim' seems to work just fine from the command line.

Anyone know what I can do to find out if it's my problem or mozilla's
(or xanim's) and how to fix it?

Relevant rpms:

rpm -q xanim
xanim-28010-16mdk

rpm -q mozilla
mozilla-1.1-0.branch.2mdk

rpm -q plugger
plugger-4.0-2mdk


Like so many things in Linux, I'm a dim-wit when it comes to plugins.
I really don't know much about MIME types, plugins, &c.

Here's another problem:

I go to:

http://www.colorado.edu/physics/2000/index.pl

and the top central picture is just blank.
I click on it and I get a dialog box which says:

   This page contains info of type (application/x-java-vm) that
   can only be viewed with the appropriate Plug-in.

plug-in for java?  Shouldn't it be on my Mandrake 8.2 system?

Thanks for any help.

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Wed Aug 14 22:52:02 2002

Subject: [PLUG] SSH Key Authentication

Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208142250490.3162-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Here is some cool trivia about the two that I just found:
http://www.math.umd.edu/~helpdesk/Online/GettingStarted/SunOS-Solaris.html

And to find out what versions match up:
http://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/solaris/versions/

So I guess you are running solaris 8 as you say.

Jason

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Aug 14 22:55:52 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 22:55:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SunOS vs Solaris version numbers.
In-Reply-To: <1029389691.17529.54.camel@duron>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208142157441.3162-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
 <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208142157441.3162-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020814224306.023d3870@mail.localnet.dimstar.net>

SunOS vs Solaris tends to cause lots of confusion. Here's how I understand it.

SunOS was what Sun originally had.

Solaris was what Sun bought, and merged with SunOS.

They merged the version numbers too.

Solaris 2.6 reports "SunOS 5.6".

Solaris 7.0 reports "SunOS 5.7"

Solaris 8.0 reports "SunOS 5.8"

and...

Solaris 9.0 reports "SunOS 5.9" (Surprise!)

Originally, there was something with the 2 and the 6 in 2.6, but that 
caused more confusion, so Sun chose to drop the 2, and just go with version 
7.0 for the next release, i.e. Solaris 7.0. Originally, Solaris 7.0 was 
going to be Solaris 2.7.

Mostly, I think it's marketing mayhem.  Marketing folks (droids?) think a 
higher number tells folks that it's better. That's also why Mandrake jumped 
versions a while back. Had to be a higher number than the competition.

At 10:34 PM 8/14/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>On Wed, 2002-08-14 at 21:57, Jason Dagit wrote:
> > uname -a ?
>
>It doesn't say Solaris anywhere... just SunOS still:
>
>SunOS gere.odin.pdx.edu 5.8 Generic_108528-12 sun4u sparc SUNW,Ultra-4
>
>I'm pretty sure Solaris and SunOS are one in the same.
>
>--
>Rob
>"Google is your friend"
>
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Russ Johnson
Stargate Online

http://www.dimstar.net
telnet://telnet.dimstar.net
ICQ: 3739685


If everything seems to be going well, you have obviously overlooked something.





From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Aug 14 23:18:57 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 23:18:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SunOS vs Solaris version numbers.
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020814224306.023d3870@mail.localnet.dimstar.net>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208142157441.3162-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <5.1.0.14.0.20020814224306.023d3870@mail.localnet.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <200208142318.57851.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I really hate it when a company plays the "version game". It reminds me 
of the play on versions Microsoft played with NT. When NT first came 
out it was rightly a 1.0 version but Microsoft named it version 3.1. I 
guess they jumped versions as a 1.0 product might be perceived in a bad 
way by customers.

I believe they did something similar with Word for Windows as well where 
it jumped from like 2.0 to 6.0. I guess they had to do that to make 
their product appear as mature as WordPerfect. Heck I used WordPerfect 
5.0 back in the late 80s under PC-DOS so WordPerfect was rightly way 
ahead in versions since it had been around for a quite some time 
compared to Word.

I think I got the versions right I'm a bit fuzzy on this stuff after all 
these years.

Tony

the aptartment...

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug 15 08:48:06 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 08:48:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying character codes in an ASCII text file
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208150841370.31476-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I downloaded a bunch of data from an agency web site by printing the
information to a disk file. This gave me the .ps version that I converted to
a text file with pstotext.

  On of the data fields is the decimal longitude, a numeric field preceeded
with a dash (because every longitude west of the Prime Meridian is a
negative value). But, in my text file, rather than having just a
dash/negative sign, the character is encased in a white rectangle.
Obviously, it's not a vanilla dash.

  How can I identify the hex code for this character? And, how would I
specify that code in a search-and-replace operation (in joe or emacs, for
example)?

  In the meantime, I'm digging into my awk references to learn how to
specify the beginning and end of alpha strings so they can have double
quotes around them (to make a CSV file).

TIA,

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug 15 08:54:21 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 08:54:21 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Printing speeds
In-Reply-To: <200208150837.02977.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208150848510.31476-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> Have you looked at the Linux printer website? Here's the list of HP 
> printers. I don't know which Laserjet 5 printer you have but it talks 
> about some of the drivers being "slow".

  Thanks, Tony. I've not looked there for several years; not since I
researched a tabloid-size color inkjet that would work with linux.

  The CUPS drivers work OK. I think the delay is having ghostscript
translate from PostScript to HP's PCL. I see the display say "PROCESSING
JOB", and a page or two comes out, then it thinks again before the next
couple of pages print.

  Anyway, I ordered the PostScript SIMM and I'll put that in when it
arrives. That should eliminate the translation step and bring the speed back
up. While this is now an "orphaned" model because the company is pushing its
latest and greatest. But, at 12 ppm, it's quite adequate for me. A couple of
years ago I bought the last available duplexing unit I could find anywhere
in the country. Now I can print double sided and that saves a ton of paper.
I expect the PostScript module will bring back the speed and then I'll have
all the printer I'll need for quite some time.

Rich




From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Aug 15 09:20:47 2002

> Obviously, it's not a vanilla dash.
> 
>   How can I identify the hex code for this character? And, how would I
> specify that code in a search-and-replace operation (in joe or emacs, for
> example)?

Don't try to identify it, leave it out of the equation and focus on
the characters that you want to keep.  This perl filter should do the
job:

perl -pe 'tr/\x10-\xFF/-/;' input_file > output_file

This changes all characters above 128 (hex 10) to a dash.

I don't have any data to test it on, but if you'd send me a copy
I'd be glad to.

>   In the meantime, I'm digging into my awk references to learn how to
> specify the beginning and end of alpha strings so they can have double
> quotes around them (to make a CSV file).

perl -pe 's/(\w+)/"$1"/g' input_file > output_file

\w is perl's shortcut for A-Za-z0-9_

if that doesn't work, replace it with \S, which is perl's shortcut
for anything which isn't whitespace.

Colin



From richard.langis at sun.com  Thu Aug 15 09:31:49 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 09:31:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Key Authentication
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208142157441.3162-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <1029389691.17529.54.camel@duron> <200208142240.18904.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D5BD775.2060408@sun.com>

Here's what I get from the server I log into at work:

[rl123358 at ecola:~]
[09:29:11] $  uname -a
SunOS ecola 5.8 Generic_108528-15 sun4u sparc SUNW,Ultra-80

I recently took a Solaris Sysadmin class, and IIRC the point number is 
the Solaris Version number.  So x.8 = Solaris 8, X.7 = Solaris 7, etc.

Don't ask me what the 5 stands for.  ;)

-R

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Aug 15 09:34:10 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 09:34:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying character codes in an ASCII text file
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208150841370.31476-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208150919150.3142-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> How can I identify the hex code for this character? And, how would I
> specify that code in a search-and-replace operation (in joe or
> emacs, for example)?

od is the command-line utility I typically use for such things. Try

  od -ab filename.txt | less

Then you can use perl for the search and replace:

  # replace spaces with '%'
  perl -pe 's/\055/%/g' filename.old > filename.new

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From richard.langis at sun.com  Thu Aug 15 09:36:25 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 09:36:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Q: Can you upgrade a system from the /var/cache/apt
 of another?
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208150020330.3569-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <3D5BD889.9010505@sun.com>

What I've done is simply share via NFS /var/cache/apt/archives, and then 
mount it on the other machine.  You'll have to add an entry to 
/etc/apt/atp.conf however:

Debug
{
  NoLocking "true";
}

So that dpkg won't write a lock file and then complain when it can't 
have exclusive access to the shared directory.  Just make sure you don't 
upgrade from two different machines at once.  :)

-R

Jason Dagit wrote:
> This question is probably more for Karl than anyone else, but lets see...
> 
> On my computer I haven't cleaned apt's cache in a very long time, 1.4GB
> worth of .deb's in fact.  I have only a puny dial up connection and I
> recently borrowed a friend's broadband to update my installation.  Now I
> want to upgrade my roommates computer.  Essentially I want to use the
> /var/cache/apt from my computer to upgrade his computer.
> 
> Is there an easy way to do this?  Could I somehow set my computer to act

> the aptartment...

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Aug 15 09:43:15 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 09:43:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Key Authentication
In-Reply-To: <3D5BD775.2060408@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208150935340.3142-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Richard Langis wrote:

> SunOS ecola 5.8 Generic_108528-15 sun4u sparc SUNW,Ultra-80
> 
> I recently took a Solaris Sysadmin class, and IIRC the point number
> is the Solaris Version number.  So x.8 = Solaris 8, X.7 = Solaris 7,
> etc.
> 
> Don't ask me what the 5 stands for.  ;)

The original SunOS went up to version 4, so uname on a SunOS 4 machine 
reports 4.blah. E.g., on a SunOS 4.1.3 machine:

  [heinlein]$ uname -sr
  SunOS 4.1.3_U1

When Sun released Solaris, it bumped up its internal numbering scheme 
to 5.blah.

  # Solaris 2.5.1
  [heinlein]$ uname -sr
  SunOS 5.5.1

  # Solaris 2.6
  [heinlein]$ uname -sr
  SunOS 5.6

  # Solaris 8
  [heinlein]$ uname -sr
  SunOS 5.8

Regardless of the product name ("Solaris 2.6" or "Solaris 7"), the 
uname reporting has stayed fairly consistent.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Aug 15 09:44:25 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 09:44:25 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Printing speeds
Message-ID: <531987793.1029429869651.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Mon, 12 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard rshepard at appl-ecosys.com wrote:

>   It seems to be a function of the application feeding postscript
> output to the system and ghostscript then translating it before
> handing the output to the printer. Which brings up the question of
> what -- if anything -- I can do to increase printing speed.

Although this doesn't answer your question, I recently noticed a definate
slowdown in printing when I shifted from RedHat 7.2 to RedHat 7.3.  (On
the same hardware).  I came to the same conclusion as you-- that
Ghostscript was slowing things down.

I used to print at about 1 page per second ("enscript"-ed text pages), but
now it's down to about 1 page every 3 seconds.

>   If a postscript card is still available for the LJ 5, would that
> make a difference and increase throughput? Are there other options
> available to me?

I would think this would help a lot.  It'll probably look better too,
since sometimes the Ghostscript fonts are just slightly off from the Adobe
fonts.

The only other option I can think of (which I have not tried) is using a
different output format from Ghostscript (i.e. PCL2 vs. PCL4) and see if
that speeds the processing any.  The output driver you're using might just
be really slow.

The hackerly option is to build a profiling version of Ghostscript, track
down where it's spending its time printing, and optimize the code.

  -- Steve

From sean at fork.com  Thu Aug 15 09:59:41 2002
From: sean at fork.com (sean at fork.com)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 09:59:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Q: Can you upgrade a system from the /var/cache/apt of another?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0208150950010.3412-100000@ky.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <3D5BD889.9010505@sun.com> <Pine.GHP.4.44.0208150950010.3412-100000@ky.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20020815165941.GA24727@einstein.seansdomain.org>

On Thu, Aug 15, 2002 at 09:51:58AM -0700, Jason Dagit wrote:
> Do I need to do anything to make his machine have the package list or can
> it build that automagically.

When you run an apt-get update;apt-get upgrade it will a)  get a new
package list, b) look at files in it's archive (which you have
generously mounted using nfs, c) figure out which files it doesn't have
and only download newer files.


Sean

Yes, and SunOS was a BSD derivative.

I'm not aware that Sun bought Solaris (could be, I just wasn't aware of
it). I do know that Solaris was an attempt by Sun to move from BSD to a
SVR4 Unix. SVR4 was supposed to be the great re-unification of the Unix
world. Rumor is that you could hear the screams of the SunOS admins from
space. ;)

That works, except with versions prior to Solaris 7. Solaris 2.6 (the 
immediate predecessor to Solaris 7.0) reports as SunOS 5.6. There was never

> 
>   Looks like the dash is ASCII 255. No wonder my table didn't list it, that
> goes only to 127. Let's see, ... ASCII 255 is 0xFF, isn't it?

> problems rather than the intransigent ones. :-)

If you want to replace the 255's, I think you need something like
's/\0377/\045/g'

I'm usually working with hex numbers, so I have an alias that uses od.
alias hd='od -A x -t x1'

galen

 ::  Could someone who's running on an Athlon send me the output of
 ::  "uname -m" and "uname -a" (deleting any info you think is sensitive)? 
 ::  I'm including a hardware-specific case statement in a shell script and 
 ::  I realized I don't have access to an Athlon for testing :-(
 ::
 ::  --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>


uname -a
Linux medulla.enet.sharplabs.com 2.4.18-20mdksmp #1 SMP Mon Jun 24 19:25:19 PDT 2002 i686 unknown

uname -m
i686

Note that I have modified my rpm system config files to force athlon switches
to get used in compilation, as well as the name "athlon" to appear in
the .rpm's built from .src.rpm's.

Had `uname' given "athlon" instead of i686, none of the changes to rpm config
files would have been necessary.

I re-built the kernel, gcc, and glibc, with these changes, but
`uname' still gives the i686 moniker.

Mostly I've rebuilt things to get whatever benefit I might gain by
having the "athlon" switch turned on in gcc-3.2.  Still, I'd sure like to
know where `uname' gets the i686 from.



Here's the output of  /proc/cpuinfo:

processor	: 0
vendor_id	: AuthenticAMD
cpu family	: 6
model		: 6
model name	: AMD Athlon(tm) MP 1500+
stepping	: 2
cpu MHz		: 1333.410
cache size	: 256 KB
fdiv_bug	: no
hlt_bug		: no
f00f_bug	: no
coma_bug	: no
fpu		: yes
fpu_exception	: yes
cpuid level	: 1
wp		: yes

bogomips	: 2660.76

From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Aug 15 10:56:33 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 10:56:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying character codes in an ASCII text file
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208150841370.31476-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208150933550.3608-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

[snip]
>   How can I identify the hex code for this character? And, how would I

Maybe there is a better way these days, but I use the "hexdump" command
along with a format file which contains the following lines (to give me
my preferred dump format):

"%06.6_ad "  16/1 "%02x "
"\t" "%_p"
"\n"

then I just enter the command:

  hexdump -f <format_file_name>  <name of file to look at>

this will display the file as a series of lines, each starting with
a number giving the current byte offset into the file (in decimal),
followed by 16 hex integers representing 16 bytes from the file, followed
by the same 16 bytes displayed as ASCII text (with "." used for
unprintable characters which your funny dash might be considered).
Using this, you can read through the file using the right hand column of
ASCII until you find the area you are looking for, then you can look at
the corresponding byte values to see the hex codes for any unprintable
or unusual characters you are interested in.

> specify that code in a search-and-replace operation (in joe or emacs, for
> example)?
[snip]

For emacs, you use ^Q followed by the value of the character code in
your current radix setting (defaults to octal on my system)
Radix setting can be changed by modifying: read-quoted-char-radix which
can be set under "editing" -> "editing basics" configuration options.

So to specify an arbitrary character with a value like 0xF2 with your
current "read-quoted-char-radix" set to 16 (hex) you would use:

  ^QF2

in your current context (character insertion, search and replace, etc.)


Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

>From looking at some of the Ghostscript device information it may be

Ghostscript "ljet4" driver.

http://www.gnu.org/software/ghostscript/devices.html

I agree that having a Postscript printer is the way to go. I've had the 
HP 4P for nearly 8 years and I can't yet justify buying a new printer 
until my HP dies or it's too expensive to fix. I only seem to be 
averaging about 1000 pages a year on the thing and so far the only 
expense has been toner cartridges and paper.

I did get a Lexmark color printer that has a Postscript engine in 
hardware so I would be assured I had a color printer that worked with 
both Windows and Linux. I also have a Lexmark Z11 that is supposed to 
be partially supported under Linux but when I tried it all I got was a 
bunch of "gibberish" on the paper so I've given up on that printer.

Tony

> > 0000420   6   7  sp   -   1   2   0   .   1   5   0   0  sp   N   A   D

You guys aren't thinking in octal, that's 255 OCTAL, which is 0xAD hex,
which also corresponds to the "-" character (0x2D) with the high order bit
set.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Aug 15 11:04:54 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 11:04:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] "uname -m" for athlon
In-Reply-To: <20020815174528.DA12117901@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208151057520.3142-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

Thanks to Galen, Richard, Dean, et al. for providing uname info for 
their AMD processors. The case statement I ended up writing looks 
something like this:

case "$(uname -m)" in
  alpha)
    arch="alpha noarch"
    # i know this grep isn't complete, but all we've got right
    # now are ev67s, so that's the only cpuinfo against which
    # i can test.
    if grep -qE '^cpu model.*\<EV67\>' /proc/cpuinfo; then
      arch="alphaev6 $arch"
    fi
    ;;
  i686)
    arch="i686 i386 noarch"
    # athlons and durons report themselves as i686 machines, but
    # red hat has begun building some amd-specific rpms under
    # the *.athlon.rpm rubric. yet another grep test.
    if grep -qE '^model name.*\<AMD\>' /proc/cpuinfo; then
      arch="athlon $arch"
    fi 
    ;;
  *)
    echo "unsupported architecture: '$(uname -m)'. bailing now"
    exit 1
    ;;
esac

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Aug 15 11:07:55 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 11:07:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Key Authentication
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208150935340.3142-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208150935340.3142-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <200208151107.55308.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I've seen some information that shows that SunOS 4.1.4 = Solaris 1.1.2 
which really confuses things.

Tony

On Thursday 15 August 2002 09:43 am, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Richard Langis wrote:
> > SunOS ecola 5.8 Generic_108528-15 sun4u sparc SUNW,Ultra-80
> >
> > I recently took a Solaris Sysadmin class, and IIRC the point number
> > is the Solaris Version number.  So x.8 = Solaris 8, X.7 = Solaris
> > 7, etc.
> >
> > Don't ask me what the 5 stands for.  ;)
>
> The original SunOS went up to version 4, so uname on a SunOS 4
> machine reports 4.blah. E.g., on a SunOS 4.1.3 machine:
>
>   [heinlein]$ uname -sr
>   SunOS 4.1.3_U1
>
> When Sun released Solaris, it bumped up its internal numbering scheme
> to 5.blah.
>
>   # Solaris 2.5.1
>   [heinlein]$ uname -sr
>   SunOS 5.5.1
>
>   # Solaris 2.6
>   [heinlein]$ uname -sr
>   SunOS 5.6
>
>   # Solaris 8
>   [heinlein]$ uname -sr
>   SunOS 5.8
>
> Regardless of the product name ("Solaris 2.6" or "Solaris 7"), the
> uname reporting has stayed fairly consistent.
>
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
>

From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Aug 15 12:04:50 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 12:04:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying character codes in an ASCII text file 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208151105191.31788-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208151200350.3943-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
>
> > You guys aren't thinking in octal, that's 255 OCTAL, which is 0xAD hex,
> > which also corresponds to the "-" character (0x2D) with the high order bit
> > set.
>
>   My ASCII code table shows the hyphen as 0x2D (Decimal 45), so why's the
> high order bit set when translated from ps to txt? Well, that's rhetorical

My guess would be that it was already set in the ps file and that the text
conversion does little more than strip the postscript code and reformat
whatever text there is, even if it uses weird characters.

> as I'd have to examine the pstotext code from gs. Anyway, is there a way to
> turn off that one bit so the '-' looks like all the other characters?

simplest thing is a straight character substitution with the tr command:

   tr \255 \55 <current_file >fixed_file

From steve at wirex.net  Thu Aug 15 12:25:30 2002
From: steve at wirex.net (Steve Beattie)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 12:25:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SunOS vs Solaris version numbers.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208151119110.3142-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <200208151107.42196.aschlemm@attbi.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208151119110.3142-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <20020815192530.GA30924@wirex.net>

On Thu, Aug 15, 2002 at 11:21:48AM -0700, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> 
> > Screams could also be heard from the users that had enjoyed very
> > stable systems under the BSD derived SunOS as well. My wife was
> > working for Sprint at the time Solaris rolled out and they had a
> > number of system crashes under early versions of Solaris. It was a
> > painful transition to say the least.
> 
> Yeah, I've heard the same. I wasn't doing SunOS work back then, but 
> one fellow colleague told me that it took a loooonnngg time for him to 
> accept the BSD -> SysV transition. I'm sure that was as true within 
> the Solaris engineering group at Sun as it was for SunOS users.

The rumor that I've heard is that Sun wanted SunOS to scale more to
multiple processor systems, but when they looked at the re-architecting
that needed to be done to the BSD kernel to support multi-processors and
saw that most of that work had already been done in the SysV kernel, they
decided that it'd be quicker/less effort to adopt SysV. That FreeBSD is
the only BSD just now starting to support SMP (AFAIK, but I don't follow
the BSDs that closely), while Solaris scales well to 16 or more processors
(or so I've been led to believe) gives some credence to that rumor,
but it very well could be a complete and utter figment of my imagination.

-- 
Steve Beattie                               Don't trust programmers? 
<steve at wirex.net>                         Complete StackGuard distro at
http://NxNW.org/~steve/                            immunix.org
http://www.personaltelco.net -- overthrowing QWest, one block at a time.
