>>>>This machine was last rebooted:  17 days 23:22 hours ago<<




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Aug 15 12:20:02 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 12:20:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SunOS vs Solaris version numbers.
In-Reply-To: <20020815192530.GA30924@wirex.net>
References: <200208151107.42196.aschlemm@attbi.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208151119110.3142-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <20020815192530.GA30924@wirex.net>
Message-ID: <200208151220.02373.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Having been in the situation where I had to support code that ran under 
Solaris, HP/UX, AIX, and IRIX, I felt it easier to maintain the code 
since all platforms supported System V signals and IPC mechanisms. It 
made it a bit easier to maintain the code so it ran correctly under all 
four environments. I don't want to think about what it would have been 
like to support both System V and BSD in the same code. Maybe it could 
be done in less work than what my insticts are telling me.

There were a number of subtle differences among the various Unix systems 
where the Unix APIs were concerned. I recall differences where on one 
systems structs were created from the heap while on other systems a 
struct was static and would be reused if the function that created it 
is was called again. 

With good documentation and man pages I found it possible to have code 
that ran on all of the systems and the things that were diffent used 
#ifdefs and liberal use of comments explaining why something was being 
done differently for one OS compared to another, etc.

Tony

On Thursday 15 August 2002 12:25 pm, Steve Beattie wrote:
> On Thu, Aug 15, 2002 at 11:21:48AM -0700, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> > > Screams could also be heard from the users that had enjoyed very
> > > stable systems under the BSD derived SunOS as well. My wife was
> > > working for Sprint at the time Solaris rolled out and they had a
> > > number of system crashes under early versions of Solaris. It was
> > > a painful transition to say the least.
> >
> > Yeah, I've heard the same. I wasn't doing SunOS work back then, but
> > one fellow colleague told me that it took a loooonnngg time for him
> > to accept the BSD -> SysV transition. I'm sure that was as true
> > within the Solaris engineering group at Sun as it was for SunOS
> > users.
>
> The rumor that I've heard is that Sun wanted SunOS to scale more to
> multiple processor systems, but when they looked at the
> re-architecting that needed to be done to the BSD kernel to support
> multi-processors and saw that most of that work had already been done
> in the SysV kernel, they decided that it'd be quicker/less effort to
> adopt SysV. That FreeBSD is the only BSD just now starting to support
> SMP (AFAIK, but I don't follow the BSDs that closely), while Solaris
> scales well to 16 or more processors (or so I've been led to believe)
> gives some credence to that rumor, but it very well could be a
> complete and utter figment of my imagination.

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer

I hadn't heard this either, though I do know that at about this time, Sun
bought Interactive UNIX (a System V implementation) which at the time was
the #2 x86 UNIX distribution (behind SCO).  The reason I heard for the
purchase was this was the simplest way to get a complete set of UNIX
device drivers for the x86 platform in order to complete their Solaris
port to the PC.

what everyone thinks the future is for Linux vs. FreeBSD. I know skills
are tranferable, but the bottom line is that since I have limited time I
will inevitably get to know one better than the other. I know Linux has
the *buzz* right now, but I get the feeling, especially with the
popularity of Mac OSX, that as corporations get more comfortable with the
PC-based Unix-like OSes, FreeBSD may pick up steam. Thoughts on that?

couldn't compile Java as fast as you could on Linux. Has this changed or
will this change soon?

#3 - Does anyone run wireless with FreeBSD? I can't get the OS to create
an interface (wi0) for my wireless card and I'm not sure why.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Thu Aug 15 14:06:12 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 14:06:12 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Anyone care to field a FreeBSD question?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208151255340.14513-100000@serpentor.local>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208151341230.11567-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Preston Crawford wrote:

> My mistake. Then I'll ask away. Thank you.
>
> #1 - I've dabbled in Linux for year. I only made the switch full-time as a
> desktop OS about 10 months. My reasoning, in part, was that doing so would
> force me to learn it better.  After using it for a while I'm a little put
> off by the complexities in configuration files and directory structure
> introduced by the various distros. And after trying out FreeBSD this
> weekend on an extra machine, I REALLY like what I see. However, since part
> of my motivation for what I choose as my desktop OS is learning, I
> consider this like a bet. I don't want to bet on the "wrong" horse, become
> skilled at FreeBSD, but have the market shift increasingly to Linux.
>
> So question #1 (and hopefully this doesn't lead to an ugly long thread) is
> what everyone thinks the future is for Linux vs. FreeBSD. I know skills
> are tranferable, but the bottom line is that since I have limited time I
> will inevitably get to know one better than the other. I know Linux has
> the *buzz* right now, but I get the feeling, especially with the
> popularity of Mac OSX, that as corporations get more comfortable with the
> PC-based Unix-like OSes, FreeBSD may pick up steam. Thoughts on that?
>
So the man wants some opinions, eh?

First, my guess is that Linux will continue to increase its user base &
be more popular than BSD -- Free-, other, or all combined. My reasoning for
this is that all of the major advantages *BSD has over, say, MS -- that
it is less expensive, more reliable, comes with the source code -- are the
same that Linux has. Unfortunately, the *BSDs do not have a user base
close to the size Linux now has, which means finding people as skilled
in any BSD is more difficult than for Linux, & outweigh the advantages
any of the BSDs profess.

Second, BSD will not disappear from the computer world for the same
reason that Linux never will: as long as at least one copy of the source
code exists, & is hacked at by one motivated user, it has the potential
of being rediscovered & starting a new life after a long, cold winter.
No proprietary OS has this ultimate survival plan.

What I feel will happen is that BSD will become more hobbyist-oriented,
the OS for the self-described computer cognescenti, the same sort of
folks who originally embraced Linux & developed it in the pioneering
days. This will keep BSD in a fairly good state of maintenance.

On the other hand, BSD will be of value in terms of strategic deployment
thru a business. Because its internals are different enough from Linux,
it can be useful in building firewalls or an ecommerce web server, where
security is an important consideration. Also, since OpenBSD & NetBSD both
support non-Intel architectures, BSD will be valuable in giving new life
to old hardware that are considered obsolete (e.g., the hardware doesn't
run the latest release of Bloatus 1000 with its 100GB disk & 20GB RAM
requirements), & allow them to be used to meet needs too low on the list
to otherwise justify buying equipment.

(Here, I hope BSD doesn't go into a death spiral, & become marginalized:
because BSD developers are still supporting older hardware architectures --
Sparc, Alpha, MIPS, PPC, Motorola 68xxx -- this provides competition to
prod Linux volunteers into continuing to support the same architectures.
Loss of either camp in this area would end this rewarding competion &
accelerate the destruction of still useable, but slower, computers.)

Now does this mean you shouldn't learn FreeBSD (or one of the other flavors)?
Many of the jobs that advertise for Linux skills, also are looking for
skills in one or more operating systems, & FreeBSD does get mentioned.
I'd say that if you like FreeBSD better than Linux, then learn it, while
keeping a weather eye on how it varies from Linux. And all the while
laugh whenever RMS's peevish argument that ``it's properly GNU/Linux"
comes around again.

Geoff
Geoff

From derek at infotects.com  Thu Aug 15 18:07:49 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 15 Aug 2002 18:07:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Install errors
In-Reply-To: <5D55939F.28905.657619@localhost>
References: <5D55939F.28905.657619@localhost>
Message-ID: <1029460069.14011.495.camel@dereklinux>

On Thu, 2019-08-15 at 17:17, hapibeli at save-net.com wrote:
> Someone please confirm for me this;
> If fdisk shows that I have only 76G on an 81G hdd , then something is locked 
> up on the disk somewhere, somehow, and I won't be able to install anything 
> successfully.
> Dirk
I really don't think so, the size difference has to do with the way a
Gig is calculated.  The system, displayed with fdisk, uses 1024 Megs for
each Gig (which is correct for block devices), but the drive
manufacturers use 1000 Megs for each Gig (which is correct for the
metric system), because it makes the drive look that much bigger (they
may do the same for Megs as well).  If you can call up cfdisk, it will
display the actual number of bytes, and will show all partitions,
whether it can properly recognize them or not,and free space.

HTH

Derek





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Aug 15 18:36:08 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 18:36:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SCSI hardware recommendations, pointers
Message-ID: <609500497.1029461771066.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On 15 Aug 2002, Russell Senior seniorr at aracnet.com wrote:

> My old 18-gig narrow SCSI drive just filled up and I am ready to
> upgrade to current technology, something like the Ultra 160 stuff.  
> It is my analysis workstation, so good disk bandwidth is important.
> Because of our backup needs (need something we can haul off-site), I
> want to get something hot-swappable.  What do you recommend, and where
> can I find decent prices on it?

What level of hot-swap are you looking for?  If you want true hot-swap
Will your workstation have redundant drives (at least) so it doesn't get
stupid when the drive is removed?  Are you planning on redundant SCSI
cards so the inevitable bus reset that hits when the drive is removed
doesn't interrupt/cancel the I/Os outstanding to the other drive?

Are you only looking for "warm swap"?  This is where you quiesce the I/O
to that drive (i.e. unmount everything), remove the device from the kernel
("echo 'scsi remove-single-device 0 0 1 0' > /proc/scsi/scsi" for ID 1),
and then remove the device.  You might be able to avoid the SCSI bus reset
in this case and save yourself a card.

Unfortunately, my experience with hot-swap hardware vendors is limited, so
I can't actually give you the info you were looking for.  ;-)

  -- Steve

PS: Be sure to check the actual sustained media-to-interface transfer rate
on the drives if performance is a concern.  Ignore any "burst" or "cache
to interface" figures.  You'll never see those.  ;-)  The fastest drive I
know of is the Seagate Cheetah XP15, rated at 51-69MB/s
media-to-interface.

PPS: No, they're not cheap.  ;-)





From eli.stair.lists at attbi.com  Thu Aug 15 16:18:21 2002
From: eli.stair.lists at attbi.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 19:18:21 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] LDAP login/authentication problems, unable to log in.
Message-ID: <20020815191821.3fc60e68.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>

Hello all,

I'm having an issue getting a client to use an LDAP server for login 
authentication.  In a nutshell: LDAP server (RH 7.3) is running slapd
providing passwd,groups and shadow (using OpenLDAP 2.0.13).  One set of 
clients (actually LTSP diskless clients) work fine, authorize against 
the LDAP server OK.  The problem system is configured similarly 
(ldap.conf,nss_ldap,pam_ldap), and I can do an ldapsearch, run gq or 
Directory Administrator with the credentials it uses for auth (root OR
proxyuser).

What happens is this:
If the client is _NOT_ configured with "ldap" in any fields in nsswitch,
I can boot, log in, su etc just as if everything were configured normally
(i.e. without LDAP), EXCEPT that it makes a BIND to the ldap server
(shown in /var/log/ldap on the server).  The login/su whatever completes
fine as if it were merely checking the flatfiles.  

When I set "ldap" for passwd, groups and shadow in /etc/nsswitch, I get
logged in as my current user (estair) fine, and it (seems) to auth against 
the ldap server.  However, I cannot su to any other user.  If I try to su 
root:  with incorrect password says "incorrect password", and the client log
shows:  --(the LDAP log on the server is listed at the end of this email)--
~~~~~~~~
Padmasambhava su: pam_ldap: error trying to bind as user "uid=root,ou=People,dc=homeunix, dc=net" (Invalid credentials)
Padmasambhava su(pam_unix)[7031]: check pass; user unknown
Padmasambhava su(pam_unix)[7031]: authentication failure; logname=estair uid=501 euid=0 tty= ruser= rhost=
Padmasambhava gconfd (estair-6978): GConf server is not in use, shutting down.
Padmasambhava gconfd (estair-6978): Exiting
~~~~~~~~

A correct password segfaults the su attempt, and returns to a user shell.
(log output for that from the LDAP server shown below also)

I'll be more than happy to supply more details, log entries, config files, 
try anything out, etc. if it would help.  It seems to me to just be a 
permissions issue with doing an auth, although I don't see how given what 
I have for access. I really can't get a grasp on how nss_ldap and pam_ldap 
interact, even after reading the LDAP-HOWO, LDAP-Ipmlementation howto and 
the Admin. guide, there isn't enough "clear" documentation of how it all 
works together (at least for ME to understand the whole).
Once I work this out, I'm sure I'll get it though.... :)

Cheers, and thanks for any input guys (and gals)

/eli


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
portions of slapd.conf
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
# ACL's

database	ldbm
suffix		"dc=homeunix, dc=net"
rootdn		"cn=root, dc=homeunix, dc=net"
rootpw		secret
# pam_passwd type is "clear" (for testing)

access to dn=".*,dc=homeunix,dc=net" attr=userPassword
	by dn="cn=root,dc=homeunix,dc=net" write
	by dn="cn=proxyuser,dc=homeunix,dc=net" read
	by dn="cn=proxyuser,dc=homeunix,dc=net" auth
	by self write
	by * auth

access to dn=".*,ou=People,dc=homeunix,dc=net"
	by * read
	by * auth

access to dn=".*,dc=homeunix,dc=net"
	by self write
	by * read
	by * auth
	
defaultaccess auth

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Thu Aug 15 22:39:32 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 15 Aug 2002 22:39:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] apt-proxy (Re: Debian Q: Can you upgrade a system from the /var/cache/apt of another?)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208150020330.3569-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208150020330.3569-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <87ptwjtl9n.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Jason Dagit <dagit at engr.orst.edu> writes:

> This question is probably more for Karl than anyone else, but lets
> see...
> 
> On my computer I haven't cleaned apt's cache in a very long time,
> 1.4GB worth of .deb's in fact.  I have only a puny dial up
> connection and I recently borrowed a friend's broadband to update my
> installation.  Now I want to upgrade my roommates computer.
> Essentially I want to use the /var/cache/apt from my computer to
> upgrade his computer.

You probably should run "apt-get autoclean" now and then, to purge old
ones that are no longer listed in the Packages and Sources metadata
files.

> Is there an easy way to do this?  Could I somehow set my computer to
> act like a debian mirror to his computer?  We have a 100Mbps network
> here in the aptartment...

Mise en place:

# apt-get install apt-proxy

... on the first machine.  After you RTFM...

Edit the "/etc/apt-proxy/apt-proxy.conf", and add something like:

8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
add_backend /main/					\
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/debian/			\
	http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/

add_backend /non-US/					\
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/non-US/			\
	http://non-us.debian.org/

add_backend /security/					\
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/security/			\
	security.debian.org::debian-security/		\
	non-us.debian.org::debian-security/		

add_backend /openoffice/ \
	$APT_PROXY_CACHE/openoffice/ \
	http://www.phy.olemiss.edu/openoffice/
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

You might like to adjust other things in there, of course.

Then, run, as root, "apt-proxy-import /var/cache/apt/archives".

On the other machine, you use URL's like this in
"/etc/apt/sources.list":

8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ stable main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/main/ stable main contrib non-free

deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ stable/non-US main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/non-US/ stable/non-US main contrib non-free

deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/security/ stable/updates main contrib non-free
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/security/ stable/updates main contrib non-free

deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/openoffice/ testing main contrib
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/openoffice/ testing main contrib
deb     http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/openoffice/ unstable main contrib
deb-src http://apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999/openoffice/ unstable main contrib
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

And that will cause the other machine to pull through the apt-proxy.
It will only go to the Internet for packages not already in it's cache.

I've been using this for a couple of weeks now, and am finding that it
works very well.  You can perform installs using it also.  During the
install, after the reboot when you are setting up Apt, where it asks
for the hostname, give something like "apt.intra.hegbloom.net:9999" as
the hostname, then when it asks for the directory on the server, tell
it "/main/".  I've been selecting "edit sources.list by hand" and
typing them in, including the "security" one through the proxy, then
saying "no" when it asks about whether to use security.  Also say no
to useing non-us, and add that by hand too, as shown above.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'

that is what you wanted to do.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Aug 16 06:17:22 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 06:17:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] LDAP login/authentication problems, unable to log in.
In-Reply-To: <20020815191821.3fc60e68.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208160613300.1750-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Eli Stair wrote:

> If the client is _NOT_ configured with "ldap" in any fields in
> nsswitch, I can boot, log in, su etc just as if everything were
> configured normally (i.e. without LDAP), EXCEPT that it makes a BIND
> to the ldap server (shown in /var/log/ldap on the server).  The
> login/su whatever completes fine as if it were merely checking the
> flatfiles.
> 
> When I set "ldap" for passwd, groups and shadow in /etc/nsswitch, I
> get logged in as my current user (estair) fine, and it (seems) to
> auth against the ldap server.  However, I cannot su to any other
> user.  If I try to su root:  with incorrect password says "incorrect
> password", and the client log shows:

> Padmasambhava su: pam_ldap: error trying to bind as user
> "uid=root,ou=People,dc=homeunix, dc=net" (Invalid credentials)
> Padmasambhava su(pam_unix)[7031]: check pass; user unknown

In nsswitch.conf, what's the order of things for passwd, shadow, and 
group? You should have 'files' listed before 'ldap':

passwd: files ldap
shadow: files ldap
group:  files ldap

If 'ldap' is listed prior to files, then your system won't (I think) 
have access to system-level accounts in /etc/passwd, /etc/shadow, and 
/etc/group.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From griffint at aracnet.com  Fri Aug 16 08:55:55 2002
From: griffint at aracnet.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 08:55:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] auto reply
In-Reply-To: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGOENACCAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph> from "Billy M Dimaculangan" at Aug 16, 2002 03:20:14 PM
Message-ID: <200208161555.g7GFttD09185@shell1.aracnet.com>

> 
> To all :
> 
> I am having some problem regarding those user accounts that have been remove
> in our mail server.  What we want to do is to have an auto reply message to
> all the messages that would be coming for that deleted account.  How can I
> make an auto reply message.
> 
> I hope someone could help me with this one.
> 
> Thank You and Good Day.
> 

If you're using sendmail, you could put something like this in your
/etc/aliases file for a deleted user we'll call bob.

   bob: "|/path/to/program/no-such-user"

This will pipe the e-mail message to standard input of the 'no-such-user' 
program, which could be a Perl script or something that generates an auto
reply. You might be able to use the vacation program for this purpose.

Terry
-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/



From fixin at peak.org  Fri Aug 16 09:04:28 2002

PCMCIA cards that use the modules ray_cs.o.  Though the manufacturer
dropped the card years ago, it still works with the latest kernel

course.)

anything but XP.  For which there are no drivers available for the
wireless card.

on XP?  I'd have expected somebody to have done this already (maybe
somebody with some skill on the platform :-), but can't find anything
on the web.

Any other ideas?  Or should I just go blow $150 on a pair of "modern"

cards are 802.11 compatible.)

From sean at seansdomain.org  Thu Aug 15 07:28:34 2002
From: sean at seansdomain.org (,,,)
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 2002 07:28:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Q: Can you upgrade a system from the /var/cache/apt of another?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208150020330.3569-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208150020330.3569-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20020815142834.E0A8A2F230@einstein.seansdomain.org>

Quick and dirty hack:
Without too much work you should be able to scp the files from you machine to 
his.  Place them in the appropriate directory and have him update.  Then when 
he goes to download packages it should recognize that all the files are there 
already.

More elegant, but not reasonable for one update:
If that doesn't work go read Karl's email that was posted on 
Date: 06 Aug 2002 23:10:19 -0700
Subject:  [PLUG] Using "apt-proxy" to minimize Apt's Internet bandwidth 
useage.
<URL:http://apt-proxy.sf.net/>

It should show you how to set up apt-proxy.

Sean

>> I'm not aware that Sun bought Solaris (could be, I just wasn't aware of

>> SVR4 Unix. SVR4 was supposed to be the great re-unification of the Unix
>[snip]
>
>I hadn't heard this either, though I do know that at about this time, Sun
>bought Interactive UNIX (a System V implementation) which at the time was
>the #2 x86 UNIX distribution (behind SCO).  The reason I heard for the
>purchase was this was the simplest way to get a complete set of UNIX
>device drivers for the x86 platform in order to complete their Solaris
>port to the PC.

Seems that I heard that Sun bought technology from someone, DEC I think, which
was the basis for the UE10K. And DEC had bought that technology from Cray. I
wonder if that technology acquisition was at all related to their acquisition
of Solaris?

http://www.pcez.com



From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Aug 16 10:21:10 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 10:21:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SunOS vs Solaris version numbers.
References: <3d5d0985.26af.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <3D5D3486.9040409@sun.com>

The technology behind the E10k was purchased from Cray.  Cray had 
purchased SGI's server division about 2 weeks before Sun aquired Cray, 
and I believe Cray had also purchased Floating Point Systems prior to 
that.  Some of the people I work with used to work at FPS.

Looking at the Sun Timeline, Solaris was a joint venture between AT&T 
and Sun (1987).  I don't have an external URL, unfortunately. :(

-R

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Aug 16 10:18:13 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 10:18:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] auto reply 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 16 Aug 2002 08:55:55 PDT."
             <200208161555.g7GFttD09185@shell1.aracnet.com> 
Message-ID: <200208161718.g7GHID411513@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> > 
> > To all :
> > 
> > I am having some problem regarding those user accounts that have been remove
> > in our mail server.  What we want to do is to have an auto reply message to
> > all the messages that would be coming for that deleted account.  How can I
> > make an auto reply message.
> > 
> > I hope someone could help me with this one.
> > 
> > Thank You and Good Day.
> > 
> 
> If you're using sendmail, you could put something like this in your
> /etc/aliases file for a deleted user we'll call bob.
> 
>    bob: "|/path/to/program/no-such-user"
> 
> This will pipe the e-mail message to standard input of the 'no-such-user' 
> program, which could be a Perl script or something that generates an auto
> reply. You might be able to use the vacation program for this purpose.
> 

You could also use sendmail's redirect feature if you know the user's
new address.  Again in /etc/aliases

bob:	bob at somewhereelse.com.REDIRECT

This will cause mail addressed to bob to be bounced with

  551 User not local; please try <bob at somewhereelse.com>

To enable the redirect feature, you will need to have FEATURE(`redirect')
in your sendmail.mc file.  It's possible that this is already turned on.
If you need help changing sendmail.mc, post to the list again.

If you do decide to make changes to /etc/aliases, you will need to run
the newaliases command in order for your changes to take effect.

galen






From prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com  Fri Aug 16 10:34:39 2002
From: prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com (Preston Crawford)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 10:34:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Anyone care to field a FreeBSD question?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208151341230.11567-100000@joan.burling.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208161030570.17463-100000@serpentor.local>

On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Geoff Burling wrote:

> So the man wants some opinions, eh?
>
> Now does this mean you shouldn't learn FreeBSD (or one of the other flavors)?
> Many of the jobs that advertise for Linux skills, also are looking for
> skills in one or more operating systems, & FreeBSD does get mentioned.
> I'd say that if you like FreeBSD better than Linux, then learn it, while
> keeping a weather eye on how it varies from Linux. And all the while
> laugh whenever RMS's peevish argument that ``it's properly GNU/Linux"
> comes around again.

That's the way I'm leaning. It just feels good to muck around with config
feels and have them be a little more sensible, a little less complex. It's
a good feeling to have very little (relative to SuSE 8) software installed
and thus just pick and choose what I want from the start. I know, I can do
this with Linux as well, but even the best installer makes this a long
process and in the process of installing stuff you need stuff you don't
want often gets included.

I'm having a problem with X not refreshing correctly under FreeBSD, but
I'm sure I'll be able to work that out. Either way, I like how much closer
I feel to the OS and how much cleaner it is.

I'd also be interested in any technical pros/cons to FreeBSD.

Preston




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Aug 16 11:18:41 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 11:18:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Anyone care to field a FreeBSD question?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208161030570.17463-100000@serpentor.local>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208161030570.17463-100000@serpentor.local>
Message-ID: <200208161118.41161.aschlemm@attbi.com>

While I think BSD is fine along with Linux, keep in mind that you don't 
have to do a "kitchen sink" install with SuSE. There are options for 
more minimal installs that doesn't have X or KDE so it's pretty 
barebones. I prefer this setup for firewalls where I want only a 
limited amount of functionality.

I am working on an OpenBSD gateway/firewall system but I haven't gotten 
around to getting all of the IP filter stuff in place. On top of that 
the IP filtering package changed in the last version or so of OpenBSD 
so I need to go back and rework my firewall rules to work with the new 
firewalling rules. There are some cool new capabilities with the new 
rule system that I want to use.

In my first trials of OpenBSD, I installed X and everything and it 
didn't feel much different than Linux. Probably the biggest shock to me 
was starting out when a "csh" (C shell). I had to install "bash" from a 
package since I like its ability to edit commands which is something 
that the basic "csh" doesn't support. There is "tcsh" that supports 
editing commands like "bash" does but I still prefer to use "bash" for 
my shell. 

Tony

Hi Eric, 

A great resources for this question would be the Personal Telco Project.

There is a wealth of knowledge on the wiki web site at
http://www.personaltelco.net/

and a active Wireless mailing list that you can find information on
here:
http://lists.personaltelco.net/mailman/listinfo/


To give some answer to your question however I would have to say that
I'm sure there would be many issues with the GPL in trying to adapt the
ray_cs open source driver to a windows platform. And I don't know if
your card it to old to be supported here but I found this link to some
windows drivers for Aviator Cards.. http://www.raylink.com/software.htm

A-

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Fri Aug 16 11:41:45 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 16 Aug 2002 11:41:45 -0700
Subject: iff Debian (Re: [PLUG] regarding deleting user)
In-Reply-To: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGAEMOCCAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGAEMOCCAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <8765yatzme.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

"Billy M Dimaculangan" <bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph> writes:

> I am running a RH 7.2 in our mail server.  My problem is whenever I
> delete a user using "userdel" command, the folder of that user being
> deleted is still in the home directory.  How do I delete a user at
> the same time deleting all the files and folders associated to it.

On a Debian system, it's "deluser", the counterpart to "adduser".
deluser can also remove a user from a group.

Billy,

Since you are running Redhat, and Debian has NOTHING to do with what you
asked, here's an actual answer for you:

userdel -r

-r removes the users home directory

Karl has just been added to my killfile.

--

Subject: [PLUG] Unix/Linux driver testing job...
Message-ID: <3d5d4c06.3727.0@pcez.com>

I have a friend who is looking for a Unix/Linux Testing person, validating network
adapter drivers on Unix and/or Linux.

Position requires considerable interaction with software
developers and other test personnel. Strong communication and
interpersonal skills are essential. Minimum of 2 years applicable experience.
Minimum of 2 years of study in applicable computer studies.

Skills:
1.Working knowledge of Unix or Linux OS in network environment (system services,
administration). 2. Ability to perform and analyze results of comparative multi-platform
Performance Testing. 3.Understanding of Local Area Networking Concepts as applied
to Ethernet environment (cabling, protocols, layers, copper, fiber). 4.Familiarity
with switches, routers,
hubs, (configuration, capabilities, analyzers). 5.Good verbal and written communication
skills (easily understood, can document findings).
6.Ability to work effectively, both independently and in collaboration with
others. 

Additional Skills Desired:
1.Programming or shell scripting knowledge.
2.Familiarity with PVCS Tracker reporting application. 3.Knowledge of other
Operating Systems (Microsoft, Novell NetWare).

From eli.stair.lists at attbi.com  Fri Aug 16 09:22:55 2002
From: eli.stair.lists at attbi.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 12:22:55 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] LDAP login/authentication problems, unable to log in.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208160613300.1750-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <20020815191821.3fc60e68.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0208160613300.1750-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <20020816122255.4bd0398f.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>

That's the order I've got them in... I've tried ONLY ldap, and also
with ldap first... if I have only ldap, I cannot log in at all to my box.
The way it's set up (files ldap), the nis-test user on the LDAP server shows
up in KDM, but I can't use it to log in, just like I can't su to that user.
When I do, the correct password segfaults, and the incorrect one is incorrect.

I can't figure out why that would happen, it obviously is correctly 
authenticating, otherwise it wouldn't know the diff between right/wrong pass.
I can find nothing on google, openldap.org, or anywhere else on this. 

The thing that makes it so difficult (for me anyway) is that there are two
mechanisms installed for using LDAP (nss_ldap and pam_ldap), which is the 
recommended way of doing it.  

 
> In nsswitch.conf, what's the order of things for passwd, shadow, and 
> group? You should have 'files' listed before 'ldap':
> 
> passwd: files ldap
> shadow: files ldap
> group:  files ldap



From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Aug 16 12:35:10 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 12:35:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: iff Debian (Re: [PLUG] regarding deleting user)
In-Reply-To: <22504.206.190.138.42.1029523658.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208161220010.7222-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 16 Aug 2002, Matt King wrote:

> Billy,
>
> Since you are running Redhat, and Debian has NOTHING to do with what you
> asked, here's an actual answer for you:
>
> userdel -r
[snip]

This is not an entirely fair assessment, many answers are not distribution
specific and are of value to people running other flavors of Linux, but
it is always a good idea to specify the distribution you are using so
people will realize that the answer may not always apply to their
distribution.  Many of us on this list (myself included) have answered
questions with something along the lines of:

   You might try XXX, that's how I do it on my systems which are running
   <enter your favorite distribution>

and I think that many people have been helped by these responses.

As it happens, the "userdel" command you give above is also included in
the Debian distribution, so had he picked this command instead of the
other, the answer would have been a useful response.  It is very difficult
to be sure which commands and features are distribution specific, and even
those that are today, won't necessarily be tomorrow.

FWIW

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com




From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Fri Aug 16 12:10:50 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 12:10:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SunOS vs Solaris version numbers.
In-Reply-To: <3D5D3486.9040409@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208161204160.11567-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Fri, 16 Aug 2002, Richard Langis wrote:

> The technology behind the E10k was purchased from Cray.  Cray had
> purchased SGI's server division about 2 weeks before Sun aquired Cray,
> and I believe Cray had also purchased Floating Point Systems prior to
> that.  Some of the people I work with used to work at FPS.
>
When I inteviewed for a job at Sun back in 1998, it was with the
group who assembled the E10K. One of my interviewers (who had been
with the product from its FPS days) explained that the history of
the E10K was that it was first FPS, then bought by Cray, who then were
bought by SGI.

SGI had their own high-end servers similar to the proto-E10K, so in a
break with the rest of the computer industry (which is to discontinue
the product, & thereby force hundreds of people to scramble for new
jobs), they sold the division to Sun. And SGI proceeded to follow their
own drummer, thereby taking their stock price to the levels it enjoys
today.

A slightly different history from what Richard wrote.

Geoff




From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Aug 16 12:50:08 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 12:50:08 -0700

Geoff Burling wrote:
> 
> When I inteviewed for a job at Sun back in 1998, it was with the
> group who assembled the E10K. One of my interviewers (who had been
> with the product from its FPS days) explained that the history of
> the E10K was that it was first FPS, then bought by Cray, who then were
> bought by SGI.
> 
> SGI had their own high-end servers similar to the proto-E10K, so in a
> break with the rest of the computer industry (which is to discontinue
> the product, & thereby force hundreds of people to scramble for new
> jobs), they sold the division to Sun. And SGI proceeded to follow their
> own drummer, thereby taking their stock price to the levels it enjoys
> today.
> 
> A slightly different history from what Richard wrote.
> 
> Geoff
> 
>

> PLUG mailing list

From mark at mjbynum.org  Fri Aug 16 13:56:01 2002
From: mark at mjbynum.org (Mark Bynum)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 13:56:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SunOS vs Solaris version numbers.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208161204160.11567-100000@joan.burling.com>
References: <3D5D3486.9040409@sun.com> <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208161204160.11567-100000@joan.burling.com>
Message-ID: <20020816135601.A82126@agora.rdrop.com>

Being a former SGI employee, Geoff's recollection is correct.
SGI bought Cray and then sold the rights to the E10k to Sun.
I may disagree about that being SGI's downfall. It was most
likely about their lack of direction, i.e. getting rid of 
IRIX and becoming a total Linux vendor, and then changing that back.
Also Rick Belluzo being president and now being a Microsoft, uh, employee.
On second thought, he's not even a Microsoft employee any more. Their stock
might go up.

Mark

From lemming at attbi.com  Fri Aug 16 15:17:56 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (Mark Morgan)

Subject: [PLUG] SunOS vs Solaris version numbers.

stuart mathews wrote:
>>On Thu, 15 Aug 2002, Dan Haskell wrote
>>>I'm not aware that Sun bought Solaris (could be, I just wasn't aware of
>>>it). I do know that Solaris was an attempt by Sun to move from BSD to a
>>>SVR4 Unix. SVR4 was supposed to be the great re-unification of the Unix
>>
>>I hadn't heard this either, though I do know that at about this time, Sun
>>bought Interactive UNIX (a System V implementation) which at the time was
>>the #2 x86 UNIX distribution (behind SCO).  The reason I heard for the
>>purchase was this was the simplest way to get a complete set of UNIX
>>device drivers for the x86 platform in order to complete their Solaris
>>port to the PC.

Interactive was sold to Kodak for a brief time on their way to Sun.  The 
company I worked for at the time used a mix of Interactive and AT&T, but 
Interactive had been less than helpful so we started using SCO instead.
When Sun bought what had been Interactive they had SunOS and wound up 
mixing the two.   (Or they had Solaris and Interactive was called SunOS 
for a bit.)  I just remember the Kodak bit the best.

-Mark




From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Fri Aug 16 16:49:59 2002
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (ptkwt at aracnet.com)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 23:49:59 GMT
Subject: [PLUG] Any shell have directory-based history
Message-ID: <200208162348.g7GNmqiM018635@franka.aracnet.com>

 
This is a request for something that probably doesn't exist... but maybe it should.

Anyone know of a shell that offers directory-based history?  I still want
'history' to do what it already does, but I'm thinking it would be nice to have
a command like 'dhist' that gives me a history of what I was doing in the
current directory.  Why would that be useful, you ask?  Well, sometimes I visit
a directory I haven't been in for some time and wonder what I was doing in that
directory last time I visited and oh, what were the obscure arguments I used to
gcc when I was compiling some source files there (yeah, I know, I should have
made a Makefile - it's just an example).

..of course the downside is that you probably would need some kind of .history
file that lives in each directory.

Phil




From m at netpro.to  Fri Aug 16 17:24:22 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)

Subject: [PLUG] Any shell have directory-based history

Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208161723180.29952-100000@lukem.com>

Well...  you could do something like:

script -a .history

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Aug 16 18:07:20 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 18:07:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] QCad
Message-ID: <1649573201.1029546442351.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Fri, 16 Aug 2002, Ron Doughten rdought at pacifier.com wrote:

> Awhile back I saw some mention of QCad as a possible option for
> drafting software.
>  I downloaded and went through the installation of QCad and updated to
> the Qt 3.x libraries.  When I try to execute QCad, I get a
> "Segmentation fault (core dump)" error.  I did some unfulfilling web
> searches for a solution that wasn't met.  Can anyone shed some light
> on this error message?

Segmentation faults are the GPFs of the UNIX world.  They mean that an
application has tried to follow a pointer to memory outside its allocated
memory space.  This is almost always due to a program bug.

The best thing you can do is to get a stack trace of the core file ("gdb
qcad core", at the prompt enter "bt") and send the results to the
developers.  You might ask them if they want it first.  ;-)

For what it's worth, I've seen a lot of Qt bugs that cause segfaults.

   -- Steve





From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Fri Aug 16 18:25:15 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 18:25:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] source for used laptops?
Message-ID: <200208161825.15937.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

In my quest to get my Panasonic CF-62 to work with Linux, I've started to 
think that getting a laptop made a little more recently would be a good 
idea.  

I've heard that there are a few places in the greater Portland area that 
have used laptops.  FreeGeek isn't one of them.  

The goal is to turn this laptop into a portable X-terminal so that my wife 
and I can share our current computer.  Space and other reasons preclude 
another computer (power being one).  I definitely do not need anything 
new.  However, I want one that is lightweight and has a good, clear 
screen.  

Does someone have any experience with used computer places in the area?  
I've done some searching, but only found broken links to places that do 
not appear to exist anymore.

have often seen hard use.  Maybe Computer Renaissance does?  The store 
"Stuff", wanted $1300 for one with no return whatsoever, I wished them good 
luck.

A year and a half ago I bought the cheapest new Toshiba I could find at 
Circuit City ($800).  Only disappointment is the screen resolution and 
clarity.  I'm thinking a factory refurbished IBM Thinkpad would be a good 
way to go.

From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Fri Aug 16 19:57:45 2002
From: John.Hampton at gijoes.com (John Hampton)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 19:57:45 -0700
Subject: iff Debian (Re: [PLUG] regarding deleting user)
Message-ID: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844019C76@gilligan.gijoes.com>

Matt said:
>> Billy,
>>
>> Since you are running Redhat, and Debian has NOTHING to do with what you
>> asked, here's an actual answer for you:
>>
>> userdel -r

Shannon said:
>This is not an entirely fair assessment, many answers are not distribution
>specific and are of value to people running other flavors of Linux, but
>it is always a good idea to specify the distribution you are using so
>people will realize that the answer may not always apply to their
>distribution. 

<snip>

And you can also say: "Hey, that deluser thing sounds like a cool tool!  I wonder if it works on my distro?"  And then you ask Karl: "Hey Karl, is deluser an executable that I could recompile, or perhpas a script that you could give me?" And then you find out that deluser is just a PERL script, and you think: "Hey, I've got PERL on my distro, I bet deluser will work!" So you get the deluser script from Karl and he also provides you with the man pages so you can find out what other cool things it does.  You hack at it jut a little and Voila! it works!  Your distro of choice now has deluser.  And an answer that was not specific to your distro just made life easier for you.  And then you might think: "This is a really neat tool.  It would be great if this were in an RPM" so you do it, and share it with your friends.  And that is good, because that is the Linux way of doing things, and the beauty of the GPL.

And if you don't want to bother Karl with questions about getting the deluser script, you can go to http://people.pdxlinux.org/~pacopablo/deluser.html and read how to get deluser and adduser to work on your system.

-John

From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Fri Aug 16 20:10:43 2002
From: John.Hampton at gijoes.com (John Hampton)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 20:10:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: cable modems]
Message-ID: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844019C77@gilligan.gijoes.com>

Dirk said:
>We're starting ATT broadband on Monday. Should we buy their modem or one
>of our own? If our own, where and how much should we pay? Or can any
>DSL beat their price [$48/month] and service?

DSL can't beat their price for what you get.  As for buying a cable modem, depends on how long you are planning on having cable internet.  AT&T switced the pricing recently so that owning your own modem only shaves $3 off of your bill instead of $10.  However, I have been seeing in the ads, that you can get a cable modem for around $40 after rebates (but you have to sign up for service there)  Also, if you haven't already signed up for the service, if you call AT&T you can get service for $19.95 for the first 6 months.  The trick is to tell them that you saw the offer.  They can't tell you about any offers, but if you tell them about an offer, then they can usually give it to you. (That is what I did).  Good luck.  I've been fairly happy with AT&T.

-John

From n6jpa_spam at attbi.com  Fri Aug 16 20:42:47 2002
From: n6jpa_spam at attbi.com (Keith)
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 20:42:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: cable modems
In-Reply-To: <5D5758CA.60101@save-net.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208162038490.1188-100000@12-225-29-45.client.attbi.com>

On Fri, 16 Aug 2019, Karen Ouellette wrote:

> We're starting ATT broadband on Monday. Should we buy their modem or one 
> of our own? If our own, where and how much should we pay? Or can any 
>  DSL beat their price [$48/month] and service?
> Thanks, Dirk
> 
> 

 Well the lease cost is $3 a month, the only benefit is that if the modem
dies then AT&T will replace it. You can get cable modems for between
$75-150, but the warranty is usually 3 months so if it dies you 
are stuck with the repair or rplacement cost. 
A year long lease is $36 so if you buy a cheap cable modem for $75 
and it last for two years then you have broken even. 

http://www.solutions4sure.com/ has cable modems for sale.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Sat Aug 17 08:10:56 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Sat, 17 Aug 2002 08:10:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: cable modems]
References: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844019C77@gilligan.gijoes.com>
Message-ID: <3D5E6780.956AC51C@attbi.com>

> Dirk said:

> Should we buy their modem or one of our own?

John Hampton wrote:

> As for buying a cable modem, depends on how long you are planning on
> having cable internet.

I signed up for cable when it was first offered by TTI. I took the modem
they offered, a COM21, or some such. Some months ago I started having
trouble that AT&T solved by replacing the COM21 with an RCA modem. Last
night I talked with a friend who lives in the same general area and who
started with TTI when I did. Last week he had to have his COM21 modem
replaced. The tech who came out and did the job said that AT&T is
turning off all the COM21's.

At one point I was thinking about buying my own modem to save a few
bucks a month. After learning that all modems are not alike, and that
the service won't work on some of them, and that which one is supported
can change, I decided that I would probably never buy a modem, but
always use the one supplied by the cable service. Plus, the price break
went away, as John pointed out.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From rseymour at spamcop.net  Sat Aug 17 08:53:43 2002
From: rseymour at spamcop.net (Richard Seymour)
Date: Sat, 17 Aug 2002 08:53:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] cron on first tuesday or last friday of the month?
Message-ID: <3D5E7187.70707@spamcop.net>

Can cron jobs be configured to run on the Nth specific weekday of each 
month?

I'm trying to set up an email reminder system that tells people about 
regularly scheduled meetings. For instance, the third Thursday of each 
month.

The third Thursday of each month would always have a day of the month 
range between 15 and 21 and a day of the week of 4. But this would run 
every Thursday as well as on the 15th, 16th, 17th, 18th, 19th, 20th, and 
21st.

 From man 5 crontab:

 > Note: The day of a command's execution can be specified by
 > two fields -- day of month, and  day  of  week.   If  both
 > fields  are restricted (ie, aren't *), the command will be
 > run when either field matches the current time.  For exam
 > ple,
 > ``30  4 1,15 * 5'' would cause a command to be run at 4:30
 > am on the 1st and 15th of each month, plus every Friday.

Besides the Nth specific weekday problem, I also need to be able to run 
jobs on the last specific weekday, which will be either the fourth or 
the fifth, depending on the calendar.

If cron doesn't do it, what will?

--

From sean at fork.com  Sat Aug 17 09:28:13 2002
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Sat, 17 Aug 2002 09:28:13 -0700
Subject: Fwd: Re: [PLUG] [Fwd: cable modems]
Message-ID: <20020817162814.5BB962F159@einstein.seansdomain.org>



On Friday 16 August 2019 18:35, you wrote:

It should make any difference in the modem you choose as long as it's DOCSIS
1.0 compliant.  If it's DOCSIS 1.1, that's better but don't spend any more
money on it.

It used to be that you could save money in the long run by buying your own
modem, however, ATT has decided that if you have purchased a modem you have a
monetary commitment to them and won't be switching to DSL any time soon.  So
they charge you a little more than if you get it from them.

You will need to price it out to see what makes more sense.

Motorola 4100 - Some have problems with the USB, so I would recommend
ethernet over USB (the MSO's don't like that answer, because they usually
shell out 5 bucks for a NIC, when they figure your USB ports cost them
nothing)

COM21 - I know people who love their modems and some who hate them.  They are
not completely DOCSIS 1.0 compliant (they will work on a system that has a
SNR a little higher than it should)

SA - There have been some problems with some of the firmware, but SA has been
good about resolving it.

I just learned that Seimens will be selling a line of modems @ Fred Meyers.
I met with the manufacturer the other day (not Siemens) and I was impressed
with the specs and manufacturing.  We haven't got one online yet, we're
hoping to get 500 in soon to play with.


An employee of a MSO other than ATT.

Sean

From dealy at deatech.com  Sat Aug 17 10:25:07 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sat, 17 Aug 2002 10:25:07 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] cron on first tuesday or last friday of the month?
In-Reply-To: <3D5E7187.70707@spamcop.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208171002510.21308-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sat, 17 Aug 2002, Richard Seymour wrote:

> Can cron jobs be configured to run on the Nth specific weekday of each
> month?
[snip]

It's a little convoluted, but you could run a cronjob on the 14th of the
month which would launch an "at" command to run on the next occurance of
the day of the week you are interested in.

> Besides the Nth specific weekday problem, I also need to be able to run
> jobs on the last specific weekday, which will be either the fourth or
> the fifth, depending on the calendar.
[snip]

For this one, the easiest ways I can come up with are:

1-Use cron to run a shell script every week on the day of the week you are
  interested in, then have the script test for whether or not it is the
  day you want by checking if there are at least seven more days left in
  the month, and if there aren't, then run the job you are interested in.

2-Use an approach similar to the one for your first question, but
  using multiple crontab entries, one for months that have 31 days, one
  for months with 30 days, and one or two for February (not quite sure how
  to handle leap years), set the entries to launch an "at" command to run
  on the next occurance of the day of the week you want, one week before
  the end of the month for each of these.


Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Aug 17 10:47:54 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat, 17 Aug 2002 10:47:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] cron on first tuesday or last friday of the month?
In-Reply-To: <3D5E7187.70707@spamcop.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208171020140.1750-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 17 Aug 2002, Richard Seymour wrote:

> Can cron jobs be configured to run on the Nth specific weekday of
> each month?

No, not without help.

We've got a regular mailing at work that goes out every other week; 
the only way to accomplish that trick is to have the script 
use 'at' to schedule itself to run again in 2 weeks.

In your case, I'd probably have a cron job that runs every Thursday,
but have the script (or whatever) check to see if the current date is 
within the acceptable range, e.g.,

  today=$(date +%d)

  if [ $today -lt 15 -o $today -gt 21 ]; then
    # don't need to run today
    exit 0
  fi

  # rest of script  

Alternatively, you can use a more complex check with something like
the Perl Date::Manip module.

> Besides the Nth specific weekday problem, I also need to be able to
> run jobs on the last specific weekday, which will be either the
> fourth or the fifth, depending on the calendar.

This one is also fairly easy to solve using GNU date. Just do 
something like this every Friday (or whatever):

  monththisweek=$(date +%m)
  monthnextweek=$(date --date'+ 1 week' +%m)

  if [ $monththisweek -eq $monthnextweek ]; then
    # there are more of this day in the month; don't need to run
    exit 0
  fi

  # rest of script

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sat Aug 17 12:01:44 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sat, 17 Aug 2002 12:01:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft Wins New Orleans contract w/out bid
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208171152370.9780-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Might be interesting to consultants who do state or city work.

......
City may get free Microsoft makeover

 N.O. would be used as a model

08/16/02

By Tara Young
Staff writer/The Times-Picayune

In a move that the city's chief technology officer said will make New
Orleans a "city of the future," Mayor Ray Nagin has entered a preliminary
agreement with Microsoft to update computer systems for City Hall and the
Police Department free of charge.

The only requirement the computer giant has made of the city is that New
Orleans let Microsoft use it as a model for marketing the system to other
governmental bodies once it is up and running, said Greg Meffert, the
city's technology officer. Eventually, he added, the city will have to
purchase software from the company, but he said it would be a "minuscule"
expense.

Microsoft officials could not be reached late Thursday, but Meffert said
work on the system will begin within two weeks. Meffert estimated the city
will save $100 million by accepting "the gift" of Microsoft's help and
software. Because these services are considered a gift, the city won't
have to publicly bid the project, he said.

The news comes one week after the administration canceled a $1.5 million
contract awarded last year to modernize the Police Department's
record-keeping. Meffert, who has been working for weeks on the Microsoft
deal, recommended the contract cancellation after saying the job could be
done for less than $100,000.

Microsoft Chairman and CEO Bill Gates and his entourage began to take New
Orleans seriously after an impromptu meeting held at a Xavier University
ceremony in mid-July, said Patrick Evans, Nagin's spokesman.

Meffert met again several days later with Microsoft executives at the
company's sales and marketing conference in New Orleans to discuss the
prospect of jointly developing and marketing software for other cities and
municipalities.

"The carrot for them is that they can work with an actual city to develop
this system," Meffert said. "They were extremely excited."

New Orleans police will be using a system Microsoft developed for the
state of Oklahoma. Dubbed the Offender Data Information System, the system
can link dozens of law enforcement agencies, jails and court systems. A
virtual crime-fighting tool, the system also provides officers with online
mug shots of suspects, warrants and other data. In Oklahoma, the system is
expected to expand into accident reporting, video arraignment and
automated pawn-shop-ticket tracking.

"It gives them a lot more weapons in fighting crime," Meffert said.

The New Orleans Police Department uses a system that holds 1 million
records and is in imminent danger of meltdown, city officials said. Backup
copies of most records exist on paper, but a crash could erase key data.

Few details were available Thursday concerning the system being developed
for City Hall records, but Meffert said it will be more efficient than the
current system.

"The systems that we are using right now . . . Elvis was still alive and
singing when they were made," he said.

http://www.nola.com/news/t-p/neworleans/index.ssf?/newsstory/o_microsoft16.html

From satimis at writeme.com  Sun Aug 18 19:42:57 2002

Hi all people,

1)  What command will be issued to display the history of the hard drive,

a)  its total size
b)  available size
c)  partition
d)  its spec

2)  Is it possible to create destroy point

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sun Aug 18 21:03:27 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sun, 18 Aug 2002 21:03:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive history and restore point question
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020819104148.02af1a70@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <3D606E0F.6040009@pacifier.com>

Stephen Liu wrote:
> Hi all people,
> 
> 1)  What command will be issued to display the history of the hard 
> drive, such as
> 
> a)  its total size
> b)  available size
> c)  partition
> d)  its spec
> etc.
> 
> 2)  Is it possible to create destroy point

You can browse specs in /proc/ide/ideX (where X=0,1 for primary and 
secondary controllers).  There seems to be some debate as to whether this 
info will stay in /proc in the 2.6 kernels, but for now, it's there.

Looks like Gnome provides a tool called `hwbrowser` that decodes the /proc 
entries and makes it easier to read.

Not sure what you mean by "create destroy point".  Mount points?

--
Kyle Accardi





From heinlein at attbi.com  Sun Aug 18 21:20:56 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun, 18 Aug 2002 21:20:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive history and restore point question
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020819104148.02af1a70@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208182100240.1750-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Mon, 19 Aug 2002, Stephen Liu wrote:

> 1)  What command will be issued to display the history of the hard
>     drive, such as
> 
> a)  its total size

This can be a bit tricky. If you've got an ATA (IDE) drive, then the 
hdparm utility will list all sorts of cool info for you, e.g.,

  hdparm -I /dev/hda

If you've got a SCSI drive, there's no quick fix (as far as I know). 
You can use fdisk to display the geometry:

  [root]# fdisk -l

  Disk /dev/sda: 255 heads, 63 sectors, 4425 cylinders
  Units = cylinders of 16065 * 512 bytes

Then do the math yourself. On my drive, there are 4425 cylinders, each 
of which has "16065 * 512 bytes":

  # using binary
  [root]# perl -e 'print ((4425 * 16065 * 512) / ((2 ** 30))'
  33.8972210884094
  # using powers of 10
  [root]# perl -e 'print ((4425 * 16065 * 512) / ( 10 ** 9))'
  36.396864

In other words, its capacity is either 33 GB (using binary counting)  
or 36 GB (using the base-10 method of counting favored by marketing
departments the world over :-).

> b)  available size

This is pretty dependent on any given drive's partitioning scheme...

> c)  partition

On GNU systems, "df -h" will tell you what you want to know.

> d)  its spec

Do you mean what the factory says the drive should do, or how well it 
actually performs?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Mon Aug 19 00:43:45 2002

> Being a former SGI employee, Geoff's recollection is correct.
> SGI bought Cray and then sold the rights to the E10k to Sun.

I didn't mean to imply that this alone led to SGI's downfall. God
help us when a time comes that keeping good & useful technology alive
& in development will lead to the inevitable death of a high tech
company. (Although I suspect many are run as if this were irrefutable
fact.)

> It was most
> likely about their lack of direction, i.e. getting rid of
> IRIX and becoming a total Linux vendor, and then changing that back.

Well, I guess ``lack of direction" is another way of saying ``marching
to another drummer." After all, isn't that what Apple claimed to be
doing thru most of the '90s when everyone wondered what exactly they
were doing?

> Also Rick Belluzo being president and now being a Microsoft, uh, employee.
> On second thought, he's not even a Microsoft employee any more. Their stock
> might go up.
>
Hmm. This leads to a theory I had about Microsoft many years ago: that
since they had such a large chunk of the software market locked up, they
would inevitably get fat & lazy thus could not help but find that a
younger, more imaginative generation wouldl push them to the side &
perhance out of business.

Of course, this never quite worked out as I thought. On one hand, MS
is always finding new ways to shove more product into the pipeline &
thus make it appear that all is well -- whether or not they are engaged
in technically abusing their monopoly.[*] On the other hand, it appears
that many PHBs are being drawn to jobs at MS -- the kind of PHBs who
are at best ineffective, but usually cause all sorts of damage & loss
of income, yet have mastered the art of ``failing upwards" -- that is,
they emerge from each disaster they have created at still another job
with more pay & more power.

Geoff

[*] It always seems that whenever I am arguing with a MS apologist, &
have the apologist on the ropes, she/he responds with the excuse that
``technically" MS may have done something wrong -- a magical little word
that allows them to continue living in denial of the fact Microsoft is
not the perfect company with the perfect product they fervently believe
is the case.




From satimis at writeme.com  Mon Aug 19 01:25:20 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive history and restore point question

In-Reply-To: <3D606E0F.6040009@pacifier.com>

At 09:03 PM 8/18/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>Stephen Liu wrote:
>>2)  Is it possible to create destroy point
>
>You can browse specs in /proc/ide/ideX (where X=0,1 for primary and 
>secondary controllers).  There seems to be some debate as to whether this 
>info will stay in /proc in the 2.6 kernels, but for now, it's there.
>
>Looks like Gnome provides a tool called `hwbrowser` that decodes the /proc 
>entries and makes it easier to read.
>
>Not sure what you mean by "create destroy point".  Mount points?

===========

It should be "RESTORE POINT".   Sorry for the typing mistake.

From randal.t.pluimer at intel.com  Mon Aug 19 08:42:42 2002
From: randal.t.pluimer at intel.com (Pluimer, Randal T)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 08:42:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: cable modems
Message-ID: <D9223EB959A5D511A98F00508B68C20C06CAE841@orsmsx108.jf.intel.com>

I've seen competing services for 39 to 49 a month.
I chose Verison because of a very poor history of service from AT&T phone
service.
Verizon has been on the ball and prompt with all issues. Plus I got the
modem free.
768 down 128 up 49 a month after 3 months. first 3 were 29 a month.

-----Original Message-----
From: Keith [mailto:n6jpa_spam at attbi.com]
Sent: Friday, August 16, 2002 8:43 PM
To: Karen Ouellette
Cc: pdx linux users groups
Subject: [PLUG] Re: cable modems


On Fri, 16 Aug 2019, Karen Ouellette wrote:

> We're starting ATT broadband on Monday. Should we buy their modem or one 
> of our own? If our own, where and how much should we pay? Or can any 
>  DSL beat their price [$48/month] and service?
> Thanks, Dirk
> 
> 

 Well the lease cost is $3 a month, the only benefit is that if the modem
dies then AT&T will replace it. You can get cable modems for between
$75-150, but the warranty is usually 3 months so if it dies you 
are stuck with the repair or rplacement cost. 
A year long lease is $36 so if you buy a cheap cable modem for $75 
and it last for two years then you have broken even. 

http://www.solutions4sure.com/ has cable modems for sale. 

-- 
Best Regards,  Keith

This is a special invitation to anyone who would like to shape the
knowledge of Linux newbies.  We're not looking for commitments at
this point, just wisdom.  Of course if you want to brain dump at our
meetings, that would be welcome. :)

BLUE group will be meeting this Tuesday, 8/20/2002. (NOT Monday,
sorry about the site glitch...) The purpose of this meeting will be
to flesh out the direction of the group as a whole.

The primary goal will be to flesh out the "Canon." The Canon, is
supposed to be a long term list of repeating topics, about once every
year or so.

He're the working list:
* Installation
* Everything you *THOUGHT* you needed MS Windows for, accomplished w/

Linux.
* Security, including anti-virus.
* Utilites
* System Maintenance and Upgrade. RPM's etc.
* System automation. scripts, etc.
* Networking. Broadband and Samba and Routers.

We're meeting at the usual place this month, Round Table Pizza 10150
SW Beaverton Hillsdale Hwy. It's on the corner Beaverton-Hillsdale
Highway and Western Ave., behind the KFC.

From rseymour at spamcop.net  Mon Aug 19 10:46:56 2002
From: rseymour at spamcop.net (Richard Seymour)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 10:46:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] bash question
Message-ID: <3D612F10.3030909@spamcop.net>

I'm writing a script where I want to figure out what month it will be X 
weeks from today. If it were one week from today, I could use date like 
this:

date --date='+ 1 week' +%m

This stores it to a variable (X):

X=$(date --date='+ 1 week' +%m)

But what if the 1 in the above statement is itself a variable?

Y=1
X=$(date --date='+ $Y week' +%m)

I get this error:

date: invalid date `+ $Y week'

How do I proceed here?

-- 
Oh, what a world! What a world!
~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~
    Richard Seymour, the Man Behind the Curtain
CHEEP GEEKS      Anarchy Software       FREE GEEK




From deanm at sharplabs.com  Mon Aug 19 10:50:55 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 10:50:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs: Where Did My Email Go?
In-Reply-To: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0208170345520.2632-100000@12-225-29-45.client.attbi.com>
	(message from Keith on Sat, 17 Aug 2002 03:49:32 -0700 (PDT))
Message-ID: <20020819175055.390C417904@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>

 ::  I opened up my mail inbox with Emacs and now I can't find out where
 :: it went to. I searched for Rmail in my home directory and then my HD
 :: using mc with find and case-sensitive off and I can not find it. 
 ::  Anyone know where to look for moved mail in Emacs? I was running X
 :: if that makes a differemnce

If you have ~/<mail dir>/inbox defined as your mailbox (mine is:

  (setq rmail-file-name "~/.mail/inbox")

then that is where your moved mail resides.  If you simply edit this
file no mail is moved.

If you hit C-g while editing your inbox, mail is moved (typically from
/var/spool/mail/<your username>).  If you start rmail (w/, e.g., M-x rmail)
then mail is also moved and your inbox is "found" (emacs-ese for "edited").

If something goes wrong during the move (like your home dir fills up)
you can usually find the moved mail somewhere in your home dir because
`movemail' does an indirect copy from /var/spool/mail/<your username>
to ~/.mail/inbox via a backup file.

For the details do (w/in Emacs):

 C-h i m emacs <RET> 
 C-s movemail  <RET> <RET>

and start reading.

You also may get a hint about where the missing mail is by doing something
slightly more general than your search:

You also may get a hint about where the missing mail is by doing something
slightly more general than your search:

find ~ -type f | fgrep -i "mail"

and picking through the output for the backup file.

But I'd read the info page above before doing the latter.

Dean

From raanders at acm.org  Mon Aug 19 11:23:46 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 11:23:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] bash question
In-Reply-To: <200208191752.KAA15092@smtp.gssf.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208191119440.3014-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Mon, 19 Aug 2002, Marvin J. Kosmal wrote:

> On Monday 19 August 2002 10:46, you wrote:
> > I'm writing a script where I want to figure out what month it will
> > be X weeks from today. If it were one week from today, I could use
> > date like this:
> >
> > date --date='+ 1 week' +%m
> >
> > This stores it to a variable (X):
> >
> > X=$(date --date='+ 1 week' +%m)
> >
> > But what if the 1 in the above statement is itself a variable?
> >
> > Y=1
> > X=$(date --date='+ $Y week' +%m)
> >
> > I get this error:
> >
> > date: invalid date `+ $Y week'
> >
> > How do I proceed here?
> 
> 
>  Try  $(Y) week

Or double quotes.  Single quotes (apostrophes) hide/prevent variable 
expansion.

X=$(date --date="+ $Y week" +%m)


Btw, I had a similar need coming up and hadn't thought too much about how 
to s similar 'calculation'.  Thanks!


Rod

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Aug 19 11:24:28 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 11:24:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] bash question
In-Reply-To: <3D612F10.3030909@spamcop.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208191122410.18363-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 19 Aug 2002, Richard Seymour wrote:

> But what if the 1 in the above statement is itself a variable?
> 
> Y=1
> X=$(date --date='+ $Y week' +%m)

You need to use double quotes instead of single (noninterpolating) 
quotes around "+ $Y week".

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From deanm at sharplabs.com  Mon Aug 19 11:27:44 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 11:27:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] bash question
In-Reply-To: <3D612F10.3030909@spamcop.net> (message from Richard Seymour on
	Mon, 19 Aug 2002 10:46:56 -0700)
References: <3D612F10.3030909@spamcop.net>
Message-ID: <20020819182744.E7C5317904@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>


 :: I'm writing a script where I want to figure out what month it will be X 
 :: weeks from today. If it were one week from today, I could use date like 
 :: this:
 :: 
 :: date --date='+ 1 week' +%m
 :: 
 :: This stores it to a variable (X):
 :: 
 :: X=$(date --date='+ 1 week' +%m)
 :: 
 :: But what if the 1 in the above statement is itself a variable?
 :: 
 :: Y=1
 :: X=$(date --date='+ $Y week' +%m)
 :: 
 :: I get this error:
 :: 
 :: date: invalid date `+ $Y week'
 :: 
 :: How do I proceed here?

$Y doesn't expand because it is enclosed in single quotes.

This works (on my machine):

Y=1
X=$(date --date='+ '$Y' week' +%m)


Dean



From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Mon Aug 19 11:34:41 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 11:34:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] bash question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208191119440.3014-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208191132250.14605-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Have you ever seen the following calculations?  They may be useful to you
for finding a particular day of the week or year:
http://webexhibits.org/calendars/week.html

There a bit of history, then towards the bottom are some equations that
compute various calendar related things.

You can find other such goodies on google.  The search I used was:
number theory calculate day of week

HTH,
Jason

<Rant on> I'd sure like to see people take the extra 5 seconds to
          actually test their proposed solutions instead if misleading
          people down dead-ends.  Especially when the proposed solution
          is trivially easy to test.  It is extremely frustrating to get
          17 solutions (as I did on another list with my recent xinerama
          problems) 16 of which were utterly useless, misleading,
          "solutions" from people who didn't even bother to read the
          problem statement fully.  (Thanks to the one or two who
          took the time to write a thoughtful answer.)

          It is actually better to not answer a question than to get a
          a non-sense answer that a newbie will believe as correct.
          He then tries it, bombs out, and says to his friends, "This
          Linux OS is a piece of hard-to-understand junk!"
<Rant off>


Bad morning.

Dean



From lamsokvr at xprt.net  Mon Aug 19 12:02:06 2002
From: lamsokvr at xprt.net (Marvin J. Kosmal)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 12:02:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] bash question
In-Reply-To: <20020819183954.AA38117904@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>
References: <3D612F10.3030909@spamcop.net> <200208191752.KAA15092@smtp.gssf.org> <20020819183954.AA38117904@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <200208191903.MAA17562@smtp.gssf.org>

On Monday 19 August 2002 11:39, you wrote:
>  :: On Monday 19 August 2002 10:46, you wrote:
>  :: > I'm writing a script where I want to figure out what month it
>  :: > will be X weeks from today. If it were one week from today, I
>  :: > could use date like this:
>  :: >
>  :: > date --date='+ 1 week' +%m
>  :: >
>  :: > This stores it to a variable (X):
>  :: >
>  :: > X=$(date --date='+ 1 week' +%m)
>  :: >
>  :: > But what if the 1 in the above statement is itself a
>  :: > variable?
>  :: >
>  :: > Y=1
>  :: > X=$(date --date='+ $Y week' +%m)
>  :: >
>  :: > I get this error:
>  :: >
>  :: > date: invalid date `+ $Y week'
>  :: >
>  :: > How do I proceed here?
>  ::
>  ::  Try  $(Y) week
>  ::
>  :: Marvin
>
> Marvin, did you? (Try it, I mean)?
>
> If it works I'd be mighty surpised since $(Y) will be just as
> enclosed in quotes as $Y was.  Which means it won't expand.
>
>
> <Rant on> I'd sure like to see people take the extra 5 seconds to
>           actually test their proposed solutions instead if

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Aug 19 12:44:24 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 12:44:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PASA Meeting the Wed, August 21st
References: <mailman.1029266055.23267.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <867kit87f7.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <h13w61.99f@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Randal L. Schwartz wrote:

>>>>>> "Wil" == Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc> writes:
> 
> Wil> Next Wednesday, August 21st PASA will have a meeting sponsored by
> Wil> Advance Corporate Solutions, at their office in Salem.
> 
> You know, when I was learning Technical Writing, one of the first
> things I got my knuckles whacked on was using a possibly unfamiliar
> acronym without defining it in first use.
> 
> Consider yourself whacked.
> 
> Sure, you gave a URL reference, but that's a sign of laziness.

Unfamiliar?  You don't know what PASA means??? Yeah, I know.  I put this 
together while running out to an on-site call.  For those who haven't 
figured it out, PASA stands for Portland Area Sys Admins.

Of course, the superabundance of acronyms in the technical industries leads 
to things like this, from a Cisco whitepaper on DSL:

<blockquote>
CPE represents any combination of end-user PCs or workstations, remote ADSL 
terminating units (ATU-Rs), and routers. For instance, a residential user 
may have a single PC with an integrated ADSL modem on a peripheral 
component interface (PCI) card, or perhaps a PC with an Ethernet or 
Universal Serial Bus (USB) interface to a standalone ADSL modem (the 
ATU-R). In contrast, business users will more often connect many end-user 
PCs to a router with an integrated ADSL modem or a router plus ATU-R pair.  

At the ADSL POP, the NAP deploys one or more DSL access multiplexers 
(DSLAMs) servicing the copper loops between the POP and CPE. In a process 
called subtending, DSLAMs can be chained together to enhance ATMpipe 
utilization. DSLAMs connect locally or via an inter-central office (CO) 
link to a local access concentrator (LAC) that provides ATM grooming,  PPP 
tunneling, and Layer 3 termination to local or cached content. A service 
selection gateway (SSG) may be colocated with the LAC, so customers can 
dynamically select destinations. From the LAC/SSG, services extend over the 
ATM core to the NSP or IP network core.
</blockquote>

What amuses me about this is that they leave lots of more obscure acronyms 
undefined, while painfully spelling out the meanings of acronyms one finds 
in newspaper adverts, like 'PCI' and 'USB'.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *

From McCannJ at trimet.org  Mon Aug 19 14:28:00 2002
