-----Original Message-----
From: Eric House [mailto:fixin at peak.org]
Sent: Friday, August 16, 2002 9:04 AM
To: Portland Linux User's Group
Subject: [PLUG] Can I use linux driver code for 'doze?


We have a wireless network at home.  The router and all machines but
one run Linux (LEAF on the router), and the cards are old Aviator
PCMCIA cards that use the modules ray_cs.o.  Though the manufacturer
dropped the card years ago, it still works with the latest kernel
thanks to the magic of open source (and somebody's hard work, of
course.)

Now the problem.  My brother had to get a new computer for school, has
to run windoze (teacher training!), and the machine won't work with
anything but XP.  For which there are no drivers available for the
wireless card.

Does anybody know how hard it'd be to adapt the Linux driver to work
on XP?  I'd have expected somebody to have done this already (maybe
somebody with some skill on the platform :-), but can't find anything
on the web.

Any other ideas?  Or should I just go blow $150 on a pair of "modern"
cards?  (One card would be for the router.  I don't think our old
cards are 802.11 compatible.)

Thanks,

--Eric House

**
* From the desktop of: Eric House, fixin at peak.org

On Mon, 2002-08-19 at 14:28, McCann, Joe wrote:
> This sounds like a job for
> VMware. 
> VMware network card is just a standard driver. Nothing special. You must
> configure your Linux host correctly first. 
> I wonder if they still have the free demo? 

Not a bad idea!

VMWare is kinda slow, though.  Win4Lin running Win9x would be a lot
faster and cheaper... but Win4Lin has no NT support.

VMWare costs $99 if you get the student discount (IIRC).  Otherwise it
is a lot more.  Win4Lin also offers a 10% student discount if you email
them and ask 'em about it.

VMWare has a 14 day free trial, I think.  The Win4Lin folks will do the
same for you if you ask them about it.

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"

Due to a dumb mistake on my part, the PASA (Portland Area Sys Admins)
meeting scheduled for this Wednesday in Salem at Advanced Corporate
Solutions is canceled.  I was gravely mistaken about the time; they had
intended 8:30 AM--not PM.  So, I assumed everyone who RSVP'd probably
wouldn't be able to make it and canceled.  They are, however, very
interested in having a meeting in the future, possibly October.

However, I'd still like to have a meeting.  Instead of going directly
for beer, I could put together a short presentation about what I'm doing
with Naked Ape Consulting that would be of interest of local sys
admins.  I would, however, need someone to host it, since my office
space (my home) would not be appropriate.  Be warned--it will be
assembled in a rush and I'm not a practiced speaker.

Or, we could not and leave the space open for the PLUG-AT meeting, which
I assume will be happening this month.

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Mon Aug 19 14:58:43 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 14:58:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ANNOUNCEMENT: August Advanced Topics Meeting
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208191455390.3529-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>


                       ADVANCED TOPICS MEETING

                    The Portland Linux/Unix Group
                              will meet
                      7 PM Wednesday Aug 21, 2002
                                  at
                         David Mandel's House
                             1440 NE 59th
                        Portland, Oregon 97213

      This is a yellow house on the corner of 59th and NE Halsey
      From East Portland:  It is probably best to use the surface streets.
                However, if you prefer the freeways ...
                Drive west on I-84.
                Take the exit- exit number 2- towards 43RD AVE..
                Turn RIGHT onto NE HALSEY ST.            drive 0.76 miles
                Turn RIGHT onto NE 59TH AVE. and park as soon as possible
      From West Portland and Suburbs:
                Drive east on I-84.
                Take the 39TH AVE. exit- exit number 2.
                Turn LEFT onto NE 39TH AVE.              drive 0.06 miles
                Turn RIGHT onto NE HALSEY ST.            drive 0.94 miles
                Turn RIGHT onto NE 59TH AVE. and park as soon as possible
      From MAX:
                Get off of the train at 60th Ave exit.
                Walk north on 60th to HALSEY ST.           about 4 blocks
                Walk west on HALSEY to 59th                      1 block


      **********************************************************

                                TOPIC

                              Opening Up
                          The Netule Project
                          http://Netule.org

                                  by
                             David Mandel
                        <dmandel at pdxLinux.org>


      The Netule Project is a project to build a family of special
      purpose Linux distributions.  So far we have built:

          FW-I  -- A firewall distribution
          EM-I  -- An Email server distribution
          WM-I  -- A Web server distribution

      and we would like to build distributions that are even more
      task oriented in the future.

      The current distributions are a mix between Open Source and
      Closed Source software.  I'm going to talk about what we have
      learned in building these distributions and why we why we
      would like to open the Netule Project completely.

      But mostly, I would like feed back from the group about:

          -  How can we make this project more attractive to
             the Linux community?
          -  How tightly should the project be organized?
          -  How should the project be organized in general?

      I don't expect this talk to be highly technical, but who knows?
      Mostly, I expect it to be interactive.  Be prepared to
      contribute ideas.

      **********************************************************

      Food and Beer

      Micro Sharp Technology <http://www.MicroSharp.com> will provide
      Pizza and Pop for the meeting.  People are free and encouraged
      to bring their own beer as it will not be provided by the hosts.


                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213
                                          (360) 260-2066
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell
                                          dmandel at pdxLinux.org


   ======================================================================
   David Mandel, Project Manager       http://www.Netule.org
                          Other Affliations
   David Mandel                        http://www.DavidMandel.com
   Portland Linux/Unix Group           http://pdxLinux.org
   LinuxFund                           http://LinuxFund.org
   Netule                              http://Netule.org
   ======================================================================

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Aug 19 15:41:22 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 15:41:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Web calendar?
Message-ID: <h144cy.ewb@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

So there are tons of web-based calendar things on Freshmeat.  I'm in a rush, 
so maybe someone knows one that has the features I require:

 o Publicly or anonymously modifiable
 o Ability to schedule recurring events
 o Has a good security record (yeah, I know, it's web-based and most have a   
really lousy history)
 o Perl, PHP, Python, or Zope; prefer no SQL db requirements (I can deal 
with the db if necessary, but I'd rather not)
 o Not too much of a PITA to set up

Nice to have:
 o Allow people to subscribe to get reminders via e-mail
 o Export to allow Evolution to import
 o Export to RDF for Evolution's summary/web sites/etc.  Actually, this 
would probably be the most preferred of the options.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *

application

# rpm -qa|grep samba
samba-2.2.5-1

# service smb start
Starting SMB services: [ OK ]

> > # /etc/hosts
> > # Do not remove the following line, or various programs
> > # that require network functionality will fail.
> > 127.0.0.1       localhost.M2    localhost.localdomain
> > 192.168.0.1     IWILL
> >
> > # /bin/hostname   [ENTER]
> > localhost.localdomain
> >
> > The hostname "IWILL' does not show up ???
>
>The hostname command returns the machine's own host name, In this case the
>line with 127.0.0.1. The second field should be a Fully Qualified Domain
>Name (FQDN) and the third the host part like this:
>
>127.0.0.1       server.abcxyz.com       server
>
>
>
>HTH,
>Kdog

From beattie at beattie-home.net  Mon Aug 19 23:03:22 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake pcmcia question
In-Reply-To: <20020814004444.GA24882@wirex.net>
References: <1029268430.929.7.camel@coyote> 
	<20020814004444.GA24882@wirex.net>
Message-ID: <1029823402.1058.75.camel@coyote>

On Tue, 2002-08-13 at 17:44, Steve Beattie wrote:
> On Tue, Aug 13, 2002 at 12:53:50PM -0700, Brian Beattie wrote:
> > I'm tring to set Mandrake up on a laptop.  My previous setup under
> > Debian would automaticaly bring up the network on card insertion. 
> > Mandrake is not doing that and I'd like to figure out how to make it
> > happen
> 
> Hey Brian,
> 
> AFAIK, Mandrake should support laptops. Some things to check (that
> really shouldn't be distro specific except for the location of the init
> scripts):

Well at least for Mandrake, the pcmica config scripts rely in the
hotplug package which is installed when usb hardware is detected.  This
is a problem, when as in the case of my laptop there is pcmcia hardware
without USB.

The solution is to manually install the hotplug package.

--

	Samba_Server which  can connect WinXP for files sharing
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020814130309.02b29c80@pop.net-yan.com>

On Mon, 2002-08-19 at 21:22, Stephen Liu wrote:
> Hi Keith,
> 
> Thanks for your response.
> 
> At 09:51 AM 8/13/2002 -0700, Keith Nasman wrote:
> >On Wed, 14 Aug 2002, Stephen Liu wrote:
> >
> > > Hi All Folks.
> > >
> > > I encountered following problem
> > >
> > > WinXP can't connect Samba_Server but Samba_Server can connect WinXP for
> > > files sharing
> > >
> > >          security = SHARE
> > >
> >I have not tried SHARE. You might try setting that to USER and then make
> >sure you are logging in to the XP box with the same username and password.
> 
> a)  I also tried 'user" but it did not help.
> 
> b) Yes in the same user's name but without password.  There is no 
> password.  This is an experiment.
> 
Try a password and once you've set it on the XP machine run smbpasswd on
the smb server to synchronize the passwords. I've also found the DOS
prompt to be very helpful where the wizard is not. You can use the "net
view" command to see if the share is visible to the XP machine and then
try mapping it to a local drive with "net use g: \\samba_server\share".
This will at least give you an error message to work with.

The DIAGNOSIS.TXT file included with the samba package gives about nine
steps that really help figure out where the problem is. Give that a try.

Sorry I can't be more specific.

> Now I download "Samba-2.2.5-1" from Samba.org website and upgrade samba 
> application
> 
> # rpm -qa|grep samba
> samba-2.2.5-1
> 
> # service smb start
> Starting SMB services: [ OK ]
> 
> Only "smb services" indicated. "nmb service" disappears. Is it correct for 
> version 2.2.5-1 ??? Kindly advise me whether I need to have it reinstall 
> !!!!!!!!
> 

"SMB services" includes the nmbd. You can check to see if nmbd is
running with the ps command (ps ax | grep nmbd).

Keith

had a patch or module that could warp the system time as seen by a
particular process.  I wish I could remember more details.  If you are
feeling lucky, you might try searching the lkml archives.

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Tue Aug 20 12:25:22 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Tue, 20 Aug 2002 12:25:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sun 
In-Reply-To: <200208201724.g7KHOD407146@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208201220470.19865-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Tue, 20 Aug 2002, Galen Seitz wrote:

>
> > On 13 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:
> >
> > > Sorry about the date there, I had to roll my system back to the 18th to
> > > fool a program into working for me.  ;-)
> > >
> > > Sure, I should just buy it, but they want $70 for it.  And that is with
> > > a student discount!
> > >
> > > :::grumbles about not being able to change the clock for only a single
> > > application:::
> >
> > I smell a device driver/kernel patch....Maybe it could be completely
> > usermode....or just hack glibc.  Maybe you would have a config file, like
> > ~rob/.clockrc and when executable x asks for the date, you return a
> > specific date, with current time.
> >
>
> Once upon a time, at least a couple of years ago, I saw an email on the
> kernel mailing list that mentioned this very thing.  I think the person
> had a patch or module that could warp the system time as seen by a
> particular process.  I wish I could remember more details.  If you are
> feeling lucky, you might try searching the lkml archives.
>
That's good to hear about.  I should check on sourceforge also to see if
there has already been an attempt.  So far the very little research I have
done about it was about exploits.  Changing the behavior of a few select
system calls is useful if you plan to root a box, so there are some people
who are experts on this sort of trick.  But I think it maybe a useful
thing to bring into the main stream of the kernel.  If done correctly it
may even allow for normal users to test operating system functions without
having to modify the kernel directly.

I don't plan to spend a lot of time on it, unless someone else is
interested, but it is a fun learning oppurtunity, and project for now...

Jason

response.  What is this, AOL?

It's best to edit out all but the particular part you are responding
to, then, leave one blank line below that, and enter what you have to
say.  There is no need to keep quoting and requoting what has gone
before; only the pertinent segments need be quoted (and correctly
attributed to the person who wrote it).  The record is the email list
archive.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'



From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Tue Aug 20 14:03:29 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 20 Aug 2002 14:03:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive history and restore point question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208182100240.1750-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208182100240.1750-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <87wuqljl9a.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> writes:

> If you've got a SCSI drive, there's no quick fix (as far as I know). 
> You can use fdisk to display the geometry:
> 
>   [root]# fdisk -l
> 
>   Disk /dev/sda: 255 heads, 63 sectors, 4425 cylinders
>   Units = cylinders of 16065 * 512 bytes
> 
> Then do the math yourself. On my drive, there are 4425 cylinders, each 
> of which has "16065 * 512 bytes":

You could also look at the kernel boot messages with "dmesg", wich are
probably also logged after boot in /var/log someplace.

In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020819104148.02af1a70@pop.net-yan.com>

Stephen Liu <satimis at writeme.com> writes:

> 2)  Is it possible to create destroy point

I wonder if you mean "snapshot volume"?  Check out the EVMS project at
IBM.  The patches and tools are available in Debian also.  If you use
snapshot volumes, be sure an also apply the VFS lock patch, and if you
use XFS, be sure an apply the patch you'll find on the EVMS
sourceforge site.

On Tue, 20 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   What are these 'vcards' that Microsoft users -- particularly at agencies

I think Netscape has this option also.  But ... vVard is defined in two
parts:

	RFC 2425, MIME Content-Type for Directory Information and
	RFC 2426, vCard MIME Directory Profile

I did a quick search using google and found this site at the top.

	http://www.imc.org/pdi/

>   When I open the pine mailbox containing one of these thingies it takes a
> while while the MUA goes through the "scroll text". Is there anyway to cut
> them off in postfix or procmail before the message is gently placed in the
> inbox?

I'm sure most anything is possible.  I don't seem to remember getting 
any of these (has to do with the company I keep - not many MSers ) so I 
can't say if I've seen the behavior you describe.  I too use pine.

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Tue Aug 20 15:41:00 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Tue, 20 Aug 2002 15:41:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: iff Debian (Re: [PLUG] regarding deleting user)
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020820153227.01ae4270@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208201536500.19865-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Russ, at first I thought the term was a bit harsh too, but I went to
www.dictionary.com and read the following:

bigot

A person who is religiously attached to a particular computer, language,
operating system, editor, or other tool (see religious issues). Usually
found with a specifier; thus, "Cray bigot", "ITS bigot", "APL bigot", "VMS
bigot", "Berkeley bigot". Real bigots can be distinguished from mere
partisans or zealots by the fact that they refuse to learn alternatives
even when the march of time and/or technology is threatening to obsolete
the favoured tool. It is truly said "You can tell a bigot, but you can't
tell him much." Compare weenie.

[Jargon File]


According to that definition, I think bigot is really the best descriptor.


On Tue, 20 Aug 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:

> At 02:14 PM 8/20/2002 -0700, you wrote:
> > > Karl has just been added to my killfile.
> >
> >PLUG your ears ?  Bigot.
>
> So now I'm a bigot if I choose not to listen to someone?

bigot

n : a prejudiced person who is intolerant of any opinions differing from
his own
Source: WordNet  1.6,  1997 Princeton University

Hey, they said it not me...(and I realize not listening is different from
intolerance, but they are similar).

>
> You have the right of free speech. I have the right to close my ears if I
> choose to.
>
> Honor diversity, even if it disagrees with your diversity.

Interesting thought.

Jason




From deathfox at moochercrew.org  Tue Aug 20 16:18:52 2002
From: deathfox at moochercrew.org (Chris Emery)
Date: 20 Aug 2002 16:18:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] attbi wierdness
In-Reply-To: <20020820133931.LGNY1746.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc57>
References: <20020820133931.LGNY1746.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc57>
Message-ID: <1029885532.6065.1.camel@moochercrew.org>

ATT made it so only one computer can get access out from their DHCP
server.  You need to go to sas.r1.attbi.com and select the machine that
you want access with.  Looks like it's time to start NATing your
Machines.

Hope this helps

On Tue, 2002-08-20 at 06:39, heinlein at attbi.com wrote:
> Has anyone else been getting 10.x.x.x addresses from
> attbi's dhcp server? If so, are you able to get out to
> the broader Internet at all? My home connection has been
> down for about 18 hours.

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Aug 20 16:47:00 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue, 20 Aug 2002 16:47:00 -0700
Subject: iff Debian (Re: [PLUG] regarding deleting user)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208201536500.19865-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU
 >
References: <5.1.0.14.0.20020820153227.01ae4270@localhost>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020820163417.019ffdd0@localhost>

At 03:41 PM 8/20/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>According to that definition, I think bigot is really the best descriptor.

I'd disagree, simply because it's not a matter of something being 
obsoleted. There's no advantage (IMNSHO) between Debian, Redhat, SuSE, 
Turbo, etc.

Also IMNSHO, giving an answer that does not apply to the distribution in 
question is the mark of a zealot.  It's as bad as a wrong answer, because 
you've just answered a question that wasn't asked. We've had discussions 
here on this list about giving distribution specific answers when the 
distribution is known and the answer doesn't apply to that distribution. If 
I ask a question about how something is installed with RPM, and Karl pipes 
up with "apt-get...", that doesn't help me, and is a waste of bandwidth. 
Almost as much as this message is a waste. Putting "iff debian" in the 
subject just makes it that much more of a zealot post. If your instructor 
at PSU asked a question on how to do something in Solaris, and you gave the 
correct answer for HP-UX, but it was wrong for Solaris, would this not be 
counted wrong on a test?

When I become a bigot because I refuse to listen to someone, something is 
wrong. I've a fairly open mind, but some of the things that are way out 
there just don't deserve my time. If I'm a bigot because I refuse to 
consider them (and I did consider them at one time...) then something is 
really really wrong with our political correctness... Moreso than I've 
thought in the past.

Again, Honor diversity, even if it disagrees with your diversity.


Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net


I have seen the future and it is just like the present, only longer.
                 -- Kehlog Albran

I think the part about it being obsoleted was a minor, minor part.  None
of the other definitions of bigot included it.  I picked the definition
because it applied to technology, and the quirks that us geeks have.
Perhaps I misunderstood it.

> It's as bad as a wrong answer, because you've just answered a question
> that wasn't asked. We've had discussions here on this list about giving
> distribution specific answers when the distribution is known and the
> answer doesn't apply to that distribution. If I ask a question about how
> something is installed with RPM, and Karl pipes up with "apt-get...",
> that doesn't help me, and is a waste of bandwidth.  Almost as much as

I got to OSU, but the point still holds, yes it would be wrong.  But this
isn't about exams and many times RH users have talked about this and that
and I thought, "gosh, but I use debian, how would I do that?" and before I
can ask, Karl told us.  The other thing, is that it was the simplicity of
solution (eg, apt) that made me want to try debian.  After I was using it
I found other reasons, such as moral (RH is a corporation, debian is more
GNU and FSF oriented).  But if people like Karl hadn't spoken up I would
have missed out on a lot in the past.

>
> When I become a bigot because I refuse to listen to someone, something is
> wrong. I've a fairly open mind, but some of the things that are way out
> there just don't deserve my time. If I'm a bigot because I refuse to

> really really wrong with our political correctness... Moreso than I've

I can't argue with that.  You're right.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Aug 20 19:37:11 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue, 20 Aug 2002 19:37:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Sun 
References: <mailman.1029871581.26738.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <h169xz.6fb@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Jason Dagit wrote:

>> Once upon a time, at least a couple of years ago, I saw an email on the
>> kernel mailing list that mentioned this very thing.  I think the person
>> had a patch or module that could warp the system time as seen by a
>> particular process.  I wish I could remember more details.  If you are
>> feeling lucky, you might try searching the lkml archives.
>>
> That's good to hear about.  I should check on sourceforge also to see if
> there has already been an attempt.  So far the very little research I have
> done about it was about exploits.  Changing the behavior of a few select
> system calls is useful if you plan to root a box, so there are some people
> who are experts on this sort of trick.  But I think it maybe a useful
> thing to bring into the main stream of the kernel.  If done correctly it
> may even allow for normal users to test operating system functions without
> having to modify the kernel directly.
> 
> I don't plan to spend a lot of time on it, unless someone else is
> interested, but it is a fun learning oppurtunity, and project for now...

You don't need kernel hacks to do this; just a loadable library.  In fact, I 
can't actually think of how to do this in the kernel, but doing it through 
a preloaded library should be fairly straightforward.

Wil

From dealy at deatech.com  Tue Aug 20 20:44:30 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 20 Aug 2002 20:44:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Faking system time (was: Sun)
In-Reply-To: <h169xz.6fb@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208201958100.2827-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Tue, 20 Aug 2002, Wil Cooley wrote:

[snip]
> You don't need kernel hacks to do this; just a loadable library.  In fact, I
> can't actually think of how to do this in the kernel, but doing it through
> a preloaded library should be fairly straightforward.
[snip]

This isn't entirely true.  You can create your own library with just the
functions you wish to replace, and use LD_PRELOAD to force your program to
use your custom version of these functions, but only if the program you
are running is not statically linked to the functions you are trying to
replace.  Most free software developers will use dynamically linked,
shared libraries because it makes their executables smaller, allows the
library functions to be updated without rebuilding their code, and there
is no major reason not to.  On the other hand, it has been my experience
that most commercial software developers/vendors will go with statically
linked programs because they often don't care that much about executable
program size on PC's, and static linking ensures that every customer is
running with the same, known version of the libraries, which makes
technical support and finding/fixing bugs much easier.

Of course, some vendors do use shared libraries, so it might work for this
particular case.  For a quick and dirty example of this:

====== libfaketime.c =========
/*  Override date/time related library function(s) */
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <time.h>

time_t time(time_t *tloc)
{
   time_t RetVal;
   struct tm FixedTime;

   FixedTime.tm_sec = 0;      /* Current time 00:00:00 */
   FixedTime.tm_min = 0;
   FixedTime.tm_hour = 0;
   FixedTime.tm_mday = 1;     /* 1st day of month */
   FixedTime.tm_mon = 0;      /* January */
   FixedTime.tm_year = 102;   /* 2002 */

   RetVal = mktime(&FixedTime);

   // Return the time value
   if (tloc) {
      *tloc = RetVal;
   }
   return RetVal;
}
======== End of File ==============
To create the library, put the above code in the file "libfaketime.c"
and run this command:

   gcc -shared -Wl,-soname,libfaketime.so -o libfaketime.so libfaketime.c

Now to test it execute this line:

  LD_PRELOAD=./libfaketime.so date

this will run the standard Linux "date" command, forcing it to use the
dummy library, and will print out the fixed time value hard coded in the
library instead of the system date/time.  This should work with any
program that uses the "time" function and is dynamically linked, however,
there at least a couple potentially serious limitations:

   1 - If the program expects the system time to change during execution
       this may cause problems (though of course a more sophisticated
       version could be created which provides some kind of time
       increment).
   2 - There are other platform specific date/time functions which the
       program could use instead, though a good programmer won't unless
       there is a real need for it, since "time" is the POSIX standard
       routine and ensures portability.  Unfortunately, in my experience
       there are alot of bad programmers out there :-(  Of course if they
       used other routines and didn't statically lin them, they could be
       added to the library and overridden as well.

FWIW

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com





From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Tue Aug 20 21:52:53 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 20 Aug 2002 21:52:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] pdxlinux.org login accounts
In-Reply-To: <1029890987.30618.12.camel@duron>
References: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844019C76@gilligan.gijoes.com>
	<87k7mljksz.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	<1029890987.30618.12.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <87n0rgiziy.fsf_-_@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

AthlonRob <AthlonRobNF at cs.com> writes:

> On Tue, 2002-08-20 at 14:13, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > "John Hampton" <John.Hampton at gijoes.com> writes:
> > 
> > > And you can also say: "Hey, that deluser thing sounds like a cool
> > > tool!  I wonder if it works on my distro?"  And then you ask Karl:
> > > "Hey Karl, is deluser an executable that I could recompile, or perhpas
> > > a script that you could give me?"
> > 
> > And if you like, I can give you a login account on
> > "drizzle.pdxlinux.org", where you can poke around on a Debian system
> > to find out for yourself.
> 
> What kind of restrictions are there on such an account?

Just that you mind your P's and Q's and don't expect it to be a
supercomputer with infinite bandwidth.  No cracking, DOS or warez type
activity, mind you don't leave heavy processes running un-niced, etc.
If you opt to create a website in your ~/public_html directory, please
limit it to a business card and download area type site... and if you
think it will get slashdotted, we'd better do some advanced planning!

Other than that, you will have a non-root account on a Celeron 433MHz
with 128MB RAM and a 20GB hard drive.  The disk is managed by the EVMS
volume manager (LVM compatible volumes) and has reiserfs filesystems.

You may run "aptitude" if you like, to browse the plethora of packages
available in the Debian trove, and you may look anywhere in the entire
filesystem that the standard Unix user/group/permissions will allow.
(If I accidently set bad permissions on "/etc/shadow" you can crack it
if you like, but no fair doing more than saying "tag you're it" with
that.  Don't sabatoge the box while you're root if you find a way in,
in other words.)  Aptitude runs fine as a non-root user, you just
won't be able to actually install anything.  All of the other features
should work though.  I will install software on request provided there
is adequate disk space.

X forwarding will work with SSH, and you may run XEmacs that way if
you like.  It would be interesting to see how many people can work on
the web site at once that way...  Screen is installed, and the default
shell is Zsh.  Your home directory will be fairly well populated by
the skel copy when it is initialized; I hope you like the setup.

 % xemacs /usr/sbin/{add,del}user

If there's a root exploit you want to try, go ahead, but please don't
break anything and tell us how you got in and let's get it fixed
pronto.  Do NOT EVER use pdxlinux.org as a base of operations for
"security scanning" anything but your own computers, please, etc. etc.
Common sense should tell you what's ok and what's not in this regard.

> I've been looking for some sort of permanent POP3/SMTP account.  It
> looks like I'll end up setting up my own server with a dyndns (even
> though it is a static IP) DNS setup.  I don't want to register a domain.

Well, the account does come with an email address, though I'd prefer
it be, like the people.pdxlinux.org/~loginid web page, for light use
PLUG / LUG / Linux related activity; it'll be your "@pdxlinux.org"
address.  You may read it there via Squirrelmail, IMAPS, or use a
.forward file.

> Ok, just ventured off-topic.  How does one go about setting up a
> drizzle account to play around in Debian?  :-)

Email "karlheg at pdxlinux.org", and send me your SSH Protocol 2
"id_dsa.pub" or "id_rsa.pub" along with your login name, full name,
and a daytime telephone number.  I will create the account then email
you.  After you log in, you must "echo PASSWORD >
~karlheg/Drop_Box/LOGIN && chmod o-rw ~karlheg/Drop_Box/LOGIN" then
let me know about it so I can set the password for email access.  The
password is optional if you are going to use a .forward.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'

organization's computing infrastructure?  (Independant consultants are
available; let your fingers do the walking; and they pay no ad fees.)

..." and been done with it in short order, because the package builder
and maintainer took over from where the software author left off, did
all the systems integration work for you, so you don't have to.  That
work is finished once and for all, so you can get on with YOUR
projects.

(The more free time you have the more you can contribute back to the

the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.

At 11:33 PM 8/20/2002 -0700, you wrote:

>Hmmm.  What's in your wallet?

I prefer RedHat, but I manage systems running Debian, SuSE, Turbo, Caldera, 
and Immunix. Along with FreeBSD, Solaris, HP-UX, AIX, and Tru64. I've got 
enough experience with each of them to know that each has it's pluses and 
minuses, and that one is not inherently *better* than the others. I don't 
have any problems with most corporations, so Redhat works for me.

> > Also IMNSHO, giving an answer that does not apply to the
> > distribution in question is the mark of a zealot.  It's as bad as a
> > wrong answer, because you've just answered a question that wasn't
> > asked.
>
>What's wrong with being a zealot?  (The Mark of the Zealot!)

Maybe I'm using the word wrong. I'd say a zealot is about the same as a 
bigot, as defined earlier in this thread. i.e., devoted to the cause beyond 
reason. In other words, even if debian was proved inferior, a zealot would 
still push it as the best thing since sliced bread.

>Ok, so what's the word for someone who trounces on and attempts to
>stiffle and repress anything regarding anything not deemed politically
>correct or in keeping with their corporate image or business plan?

Um, Human Resources Director? :)

>It's weird (weird and mounted for a trophy) how whenever Debian was

>GNU/Linux.

I don't think it was debian being attacked. I think it was the same old 
argument. A debian specific answer to a non-debian question is still not a 
correct answer. *IF* the generic or "other distro" answer accompanied the 
debian specific answer, that would be one thing.


>   The first thing that came to my mind, as you may recall me
>saying in an email to the list, was that perhaps they are selling Red
>Hat to their customers, and are angry that anyone would present an
>alternative.

I can't answer that, as I don't know. I'm a Engineering SysAdmin, not a 
Consultant. I work for an "Inc."

> > We've had discussions here on this list about giving distribution
> > specific answers when the distribution is known and the answer
> > doesn't apply to that distribution.

>cabal.

the already flustered newbie folks with answers that won't work in their 
environment was detrimental to the proliferation of Linux in general. As a 
former On-line Tech. Support Engineer, I am sensitive to how folks perceive 
the help they get on-line.

>What about the several times where someone was struggling to build
>some peice of software from scratch, and I offered that they might
>find it useful to grab the source from Debian and see what the package
>maintainer did?  Was that not a pertinent reply?

And I don't have any problem with that. I think you (as well as others on 
this list) have a wealth of information to offer. It's this one little 
sticking point that I have a problem with, and that's those distro specific 
answers to (not) solve the problem on another distro.

I'm only singling out debian because debian users seem to be the only ones 
that do this.

>The gist of the "apt-get install ..." responses is: Why are you
>spending your time building things from scratch (that are not part of
>the distro you chose first try at this newfangled Linux thing) and why

Hi Matt,

You might need to dig a little deeper about what aspect (or
functionality) of Project that you need to replace.  Like most Micro$oft
Suites, a large portion of the software is not needed (or used) by most
people.  In searching for free replacements, you should focus on the
jobs that need to get done instead of replacing the whole Suite.  I
think you will have a much better chance of succeeding that way.

Only about $0.02 worth.

Derek Loree

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Aug 21 10:42:13 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 10:42:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What'sa vcard?
References: <mailman.1029942510.29508.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <h17fuc.dag@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Pluimer, Randal T wrote:

> It is also a digital signature.
> It is something you get through Verisign.
> Theoretically if you have one of these it means it could only come from
> you. Unfortunately we all know how easy that is to fake.

You're confusing things.  A vCard is a special attachment that has contant 
information in a well-defined (by RFC) format.  It could be easy to "fake" 
such a thing.  A digital signature is a vague term, and could be something 
as simple as clicking on a button on a web page.  A CRYPTOGRAPIC signature, 
OTOH, can either be self-originated (as PGP signatures are) or they can be 
gotten from a Certificate Authority (as S/MIME signatures are) and they are 
almost impossible to fake, current CPU power being what it is.

BTW, I'm posting with Knode, is my PGP sig working as expected?

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Wed Aug 21 10:53:00 2002
From: John.Hampton at gijoes.com (John Hampton)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 10:53:00 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] It's free as in air and speech, not free as in beer.
Message-ID: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014D25@gilligan.gijoes.com>

Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net> writes:
>I don't think it was debian being attacked. I think it was the same old 
>argument. A debian specific answer to a non-debian question is still not a 
>correct answer. *IF* the generic or "other distro" answer accompanied the 
>debian specific answer, that would be one thing.

I agree that the debian answer might not have been correct for Red Hat, but I don't think that it was an entirely useless answer either.  It brought to light another way of accomplishing the task.  It also led me to research how to port the debian tool over to Red Hat (well, Mandrake, but now it will ok on Red Hat too.)  I think that the debian answer was good because it informed the new user.  It is up to the new user to decide how to use the information received.

>>Sure, but no formal ban on Open Response was ever ratified by the
>>cabal.
>
>I realize that. But I thought it was generally recognized that confusing 
>the already flustered newbie folks with answers that won't work in their 
>environment was detrimental to the proliferation of Linux in general. As a 
>former On-line Tech. Support Engineer, I am sensitive to how folks perceive 
>the help they get on-line.

I have not been an On-line Tech Support Engineer, but as one who has had to call tech support for various reasons.  I wish that they would treat me as someone who has a brain (not to say that you did, but this has been my experience with tech support). I welcome advice that they give me.   A, "Hey, you might want to try this in the future" would be great.  Once again, I don't think that posting an alternate way to solve the problem in a different distro is bad.  It gives the user options.  The user should be able to decide which option they want to choose.

>>What about the several times where someone was struggling to build
>>some piece of software from scratch, and I offered that they might
>>find it useful to grab the source from Debian and see what the package
>>maintainer did?  Was that not a pertinent reply?
>
>And I don't have any problem with that. I think you (as well as others on 
>this list) have a wealth of information to offer. It's this one little 
>sticking point that I have a problem with, and that's those distro specific 
>answers to (not) solve the problem on another distro.0

But his answer did help me solve the problem on a non-debian distro.  As I posted before, if you want to user adduser and deluser on Red Hat or Mandrake or any other distro, check out the page that I put up. 
http://people.pdxlinux.org/~pacopablo/deluser.html
Just because it is specific to another distro, doesn't mean it can't help me.  Especially in the Open Source community.

>You know, this isn't about debian vs. (distro of choice). It's about 
>answering a question correctly, so the poor guy can use his computer. If 
>he's already got RedHat on his system, and wants to keep it, an answer 
>specific to any other distro isn't going to help.

It CAN help.  This is Open Source.  People are encouraged to find new and different ways to do things.  If it's not available yet, go make it!  Isn't that the beauty of Open Source?  That we have the option of doing what we want?   I'm not saying that we should only give non-distro specific answers.  But I do think that non-distro specific answers are relevant and can be helpful.


John Hampton
Programmer Analyst
G.I. Joe's, Inc.
john.hampton at gijoes.com




From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Aug 21 11:07:40 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 11:07:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SECOND ANNOUNCEMENT: August Advanced Topics Meeting
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208211106071.2786-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>


                       ADVANCED TOPICS MEETING

                    The Portland Linux/Unix Group
                              will meet
                      7 PM Wednesday Aug 21, 2002
                                  at
                         David Mandel's House
                             1440 NE 59th
                        Portland, Oregon 97213

      This is a yellow house on the corner of 59th and NE Halsey
      From East Portland:  It is probably best to use the surface streets.
                However, if you prefer the freeways ...
                Drive west on I-84.
                Take the exit- exit number 2- towards 43RD AVE..
                Turn RIGHT onto NE HALSEY ST.            drive 0.76 miles
                Turn RIGHT onto NE 59TH AVE. and park as soon as possible
      From West Portland and Suburbs:
                Drive east on I-84.
                Take the 39TH AVE. exit- exit number 2.
                Turn LEFT onto NE 39TH AVE.              drive 0.06 miles
                Turn RIGHT onto NE HALSEY ST.            drive 0.94 miles
                Turn RIGHT onto NE 59TH AVE. and park as soon as possible
      From MAX:
                Get off of the train at 60th Ave exit.
                Walk north on 60th to HALSEY ST.           about 4 blocks
                Walk west on HALSEY to 59th                      1 block


      **********************************************************

                                TOPIC

                              Opening Up
                          The Netule Project
                          http://Netule.org

                                  by
                             David Mandel
                        <dmandel at pdxLinux.org>


      The Netule Project is a project to build a family of special
      purpose Linux distributions.  So far we have built:

          FW-I  -- A firewall distribution
          EM-I  -- An Email server distribution
          WM-I  -- A Web server distribution

      and we would like to build distributions that are even more
      task oriented in the future.

      The current distributions are a mix between Open Source and
      Closed Source software.  I'm going to talk about what we have
      learned in building these distributions and why we why we
      would like to open the Netule Project completely.

      But mostly, I would like feed back from the group about:

          -  How can we make this project more attractive to
             the Linux community?
          -  How tightly should the project be organized?
          -  How should the project be organized in general?

      I don't expect this talk to be highly technical, but who knows?
      Mostly, I expect it to be interactive.  Be prepared to
      contribute ideas.

      **********************************************************

      Food and Beer

      Micro Sharp Technology <http://www.MicroSharp.com> will provide
      Pizza and Pop for the meeting.  People are free and encouraged
      to bring their own beer as it will not be provided by the hosts.


                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213
                                          (360) 260-2066
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell
                                          dmandel at pdxLinux.org


   ======================================================================
   David Mandel, Project Manager       http://www.Netule.org
                          Other Affliations
   David Mandel                        http://www.DavidMandel.com
   Portland Linux/Unix Group           http://pdxLinux.org
   LinuxFund                           http://LinuxFund.org
   Netule                              http://Netule.org

Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208211106530.22861-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Wed, 21 Aug 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:

> I prefer RedHat, but I manage systems running Debian, SuSE, Turbo, Caldera,
> and Immunix. Along with FreeBSD, Solaris, HP-UX, AIX, and Tru64. I've got
> enough experience with each of them to know that each has it's pluses and
> minuses, and that one is not inherently *better* than the others. I don't
> have any problems with most corporations, so Redhat works for me.

Out of the non-linux do you have a preference?  As a user I prefer Solaris
over HP-UX, and Tru64 never gave me grief, but it did give our ONID
sysadmins here at OSU some grief.

> go to college, and have two years of schooling... for Auto Mechanics. Wow,
> that really helps in the Computer Industry, doesn't it.

I don't think it helps in a literal sense, but I bet the trouble shooting
skills and the ability to learn hands on helped you a lot.  The ability to
look at a multidimensional problem and mentally ignore the parts that
work, so that you can focus on a solution.  Fixing thing is a skill,
regardless of the domain.

Jason

I've never worked with HP-UX, but I greatly preferred AIX over Solaris, 
Digital UNIX (v4 back then), IRIX, SCO OpenServer, BSD/OS.  I really loved 
the LVM, JFS, and SMIT, and it ran on some really sweet hardware.  IRIX was 
kinda cool too, as a workstation, and the SGI hardware rocks.  NeXTSTEP was 
nice as a workstaion too...

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Wed Aug 21 12:57:52 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 12:57:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] need some font help (Mandrake)
Message-ID: <20020821195752.D1B07178FF@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>

I'm trying to get the whole complement of ttf fonts working
on my Mandrake 8.2 system.  So I did:

Mandrake Control Center --> System --> Fonts --> Advanced Options --> Add

and I added the windows 98 font directory on a remote machine that
I have NFS-mounted on the current machine.

Then I binked on Get Windows Fonts and the Font installer did it's thing.

It created two dirs in /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/drakfont

namely `ttf' and `Type1' and stuffed these full of fonts.

It also auto-modified /etc/X11/fs/config

adding the last two lines to the catalogue:

          catalogue = /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/misc:unscaled,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/drakfont,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/75dpi:unscaled,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/100dpi:unscaled,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/misc:unscaled,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/Type1,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/TTF,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/Speedo,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/pcf_drakfont:unscaled,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/mdk:unscaled,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/mozilla-fonts:unscaled,
          	/usr/share/fonts/default/Type1,
          	/usr/share/fonts/ttf/big5,
          	/usr/share/fonts/ttf/decoratives,
          	/usr/share/fonts/ttf/gb2312,
          	/usr/share/fonts/ttf/japanese,
          	/usr/share/fonts/ttf/western,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/drakfont/ttf,
          	/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/drakfont/Type1


I'm not sure what else it did.  I brought down X and restared the fontserver,
then restarted X.

Now when I do

Mandrake Control Center --> System --> Fonts --> Font list

I see a bunch of new fonts listed, some of which have a "(microsoft)"
after their name.

Problem is that when I bink on any of these  (microsoft) fonts it
says "The selected font is not available" and no font displays
in the window.

Interestingly, it appears that most (all?) the (microsoft) fonts in the list
have an identically named font followed by "(unknown)" just under it in
the list.

So, for example, I see in the list:

tahoma (microsoft)
tahoma (unknown)

Binking on the (unknown) version shows a font.

Is this normal?  Why do I see know (microsoft) fonts?
What's going on?


Dean

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Wed Aug 21 14:23:45 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 14:23:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Win2k network drive mapping issue
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208211417150.22861-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Sorry for the OT post, but I'm desperate...I googled but that didn't help
me.

The problem is that we install from an image.  Saves us a lot of time,
blah, blah, blah.  Well the image tries to map network drives, it is an
artifact from the setup process.  The normal users that will be logging on
do not need them.  The network drives require a password to map, since
they are shares that us administrators use.  It only asks to map the
drives the first time a user tries to login, so I *could* login as all the
users, but that would be lame.  What I want to do is make it *not* try to
map those drives anymore.

I have tried logging in as the configuration account, letting it map the
drives and then disconnecting them, but it didn't solve the problem.

Any clues?

Thanks,
Jason




From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Aug 21 15:17:04 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 15:17:04 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] It's free as in air and speech, not free as in beer.
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020821092549.0221ccf0@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208211503190.26485-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 21 Aug 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> But I thought it was generally recognized that confusing the already
> flustered newbie folks with answers that won't work in their
> environment was detrimental to the proliferation of Linux in general.

Well, I'm sure you've already figured out that A) you perception of what
is "generally recognized" might possibly be incorrect and B) something
that is generally recognized is not necessarily the belief of all people.

Personally, I don't think you've made any compelling case for the argument
that answers relevant to other operating systems and distributions is
detrimental to anything at all, so long as those answers are clearly
labelled.  I also think Karl made a strong counterpoint (to your
non-point) when he wrote that a solution in Debian serves to show a user
or administrator how the Debian system provides simple solutions to
problems that have complex (or merely convluted) solutions in other
environments.

Now, I don't run Debian on most of my boxes (just one).  I prefer to do
things manually pretty much all the time when it comes to my home
systems.  But I recognize that I need to regularly re-invent solutions
already embedded into other systems.

When I ask a question, I try to make clear which types of solutions are
important to me.  For example, I will often mention that I am not
interested in non-Free software.

I think people using this list as their personal helpdesk could benefit
much more if they asked WHY people choose one solution over another when
presented with multiple options.

Quite frankly, when I see these Debian v. Red Hat discussions on this
list, I am stunned by how few people actually support Red Hat on technical
merits.  Usually the argument is simply reduced to "Diff'rent strokes for
diff'rent folks" and the Red Hat users urge the discussion dropped.  I've
yet to hear anyone argue that Red Hat is actually superior to Debian in
any way.  Instead, Debian supporters are branded and their arguments
dismissed as zealotry.

By the way, "zealot" has a couple of meanings.  The first is merely a
person with enthusiasm in a particular pursuit.  I think Karl was owning
up to that sense of the word.  There is another sense in which the word is
used to describe FANATICAL devotion.  I don't think anyone here would
argue that Karl's devotion to Debian is uncritical.  That is to say, I
think he has made a critical choice and devoted himself enthusiastically
to the cause.  Honestly, I would say that Debian supporters are probably
some of the MOST critical of the Debian system and that's what pushes it
to such a high standard.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From lemming at attbi.com  Wed Aug 21 15:02:36 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (Mark Morgan)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 15:02:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] It's free as in air and speech, not free as in beer.
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208211503190.26485-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <3D640DFC.9080500@attbi.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> Quite frankly, when I see these Debian v. Red Hat discussions on this
> list, I am stunned by how few people actually support Red Hat on technical
> merits.  Usually the argument is simply reduced to "Diff'rent strokes for
> diff'rent folks" and the Red Hat users urge the discussion dropped.  I've
> yet to hear anyone argue that Red Hat is actually superior to Debian in
> any way.  Instead, Debian supporters are branded and their arguments
> dismissed as zealotry.

I haven't checked the latest Debian, but I would say Red Hat is easier 
to install and worked with all my hardware.  This may of changed with 
the woody release.

I've been playing around with different distributions on my Sony Vaio 
PCG-F580.

Ones I've gone through the entire install and used for at least a few 
days: SuSe 7.3, SuSe 8.0, Redhat 7.3, Mandrake 8.2, Gentoo 1.2

Of these, only Redhat installed correctly.  Mainly due to my pcmcia NIC. 
SuSe needed tweaking of a conf file before it would work, but probably 
needed the second least amount of work to get running the way I wanted 
it too. (For some reason, Mandrake gave me trouble, but I don't recall 
what now.)
On the other hand, having the Redhat site busy for updates all the time 
means I haven't done any patches. (Though, I'm betting I'm missing some 
mirror...)
With SuSe, that was easy.  Their update tool works flawlessly for me. I 
happen to like SuSe a lot and will be keeping my main server running it 
for some time.

I'm going to go back and load Gentoo again.  I found that distribution 
to be a fun delve into the nuts and bolts. Plus I do find running at the 
cutting edge to be a bit of a thrill.  The only reason I threw Redhat on 
was because I knew it would be a quick load and I was pressed for time 
when I reloaded. (I had a couple problems with X and sound. Just enough 
to be a pain.)

I might try Debian again just for to check it out again.

-Mark

Randal> gotten by ok.  I don't think anything was wrong with
Randal> routing... just with the DHCP service.

talked to him, around 1 or 2 pm, he had no WAN (cable) link light.
DHCP went out for him in the early morning hours (circa 1 or 2 am) and
everything was back to normal at about 4 pm.  On the East Side (NE
Portland), I never saw a burp the whole time.  Maybe my dhcp-client
was busted ;-).

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Aug 21 16:09:26 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 21 Aug 2002 16:09:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] pdxlinux.org login accounts
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208211625280.27263-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208211625280.27263-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <86wuqjx109.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> Watch your quoting, sir!

Jeme> The above statement was written by karlheg at hegbloom.net, NOT
Jeme> AthlonRobNF at cs.com.

[...]

Personally, I am pretty tolerant of this kind of thing.  If you look
carefully at the quoting, it is clear who said what.  The "mistake"
was leaving the who-said-it line in when all of their text had been
snipped.  There is always the previous posts in your own or a public
archive to check if you want to know for sure.  Personally, I'd rather
see people make this kind of mistake than not bother trimming down
quoted text at all.

Yes, the positioning of the lines does have the effect an "optical
illusion", but it was almost certainly unintentional and I think there
is at least as much burden on the reader to read carefully.

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Wed Aug 21 16:20:43 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 16:20:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] [mod_perl 1.2x] Intermittent code execution errors
Message-ID: <20020821162043.C25432@dalsemi.com>

PLUGgers,

This is a copy of my email to the mod_perl list. If any of you have
ideas as to how to go about debugging this, or suggestions for other
things to try, I'd really appreciate it.  I've been working on this for
about 4-5 weeks in my spare time in the evenings and I'm stumped.


[This is an update from my earlier posting which was entitled
"mod_perl has Alzheimers?".  Since then I've read through the
mod_perl guide, searched the mailing list archives, and done a
more thorough job of analyzing the debug output.]


I recently got a new server for our website, and installed RH7.2 on
it and shipped it off to the colo.  Since then, I've been getting
lots of 404 server errors, so I added debugging code to the stacked
content handler (a modified version of Apache::NavBar).

Here's the debug output from a "good" process.  There are snippets of
code down below so that you can understand the flow. The code itself is
attached to the email.

  NavGraphics(30165): conf_file = >/etc/httpd/etc/Sunset6.template<
  NavGraphics(30165) time=1025358762
  NavGraphics(30165): exists
  NavGraphics(30165): plate not cached
  NavGraphics(30165): plate
  NavGraphics(30165): before new
  NavPlate(30165): new </etc/httpd/etc/Sunset6.template>
  NavPlate(30165): after fh
  NavPlate(30165) ref: Text::Template
  NavGraphics(30165): after new Apache::NavGraphics::NavTemplate=HASH(0x8270b7c)
  NavGraphics plate(30165): Text::Template
  30165:/home/httpd/html/index.html:Text::Template:

The handler sees that it's cache is empty (it was just spawned), so it
calls new to create a new entry in the cache, which calls new for
Text::Template to get the templating object.  The template object is
returned to the handler and information from the page is used to
populate the object.

Here's the debug output from a newly spawned "bad" child.

  Graphics(30166): conf_file = >/etc/httpd/etc/Sunset6.template<
  NavGraphics(30166) time=1025358762
  NavGraphics(30166): exists
  NavGraphics(30166): plate not cached
  NavGraphics(30166): plate
  NavGraphics(30166): before new
  NavGraphics(30166): after new Apache::NavGraphics::NavTemplate=HASH(0x82689a4)
  NavGraphics plate(30166):
  30166:/home/httpd/html/Ministries/index.html::
  [Thu Aug  1 10:27:18 2002] [error] Can't call method "fill_in" without a package or object reference at /usr/lib/perl5/site_perl/5.6.1/Apache/NavGraphics.pm line 48.

This is similar to the "good" child, except notice that there's no
output from the templating object code (which was prefaced NavPlate).
However, "something" is placed into the cache and is returned to the
handler, but it isn't a Text::Template object.

Here's the debug output from a "bad" child on it's second request:

  NavGraphics(30166): conf_file = >/etc/httpd/etc/Sunset6.template<
  NavGraphics(30166) time=1025358762
  NavGraphics(30166): exists 1
  NavGraphics(30166): plate not cached
  NavGraphics(30166): plate Apache::NavGraphics::NavTemplate=HASH(0x8268adc)
  NavGraphics(30166): before new Apache::NavGraphics::NavTemplate=HASH(0x8268adc)
  NavGraphics(30166): after new Apache::NavGraphics::NavTemplate=HASH(0x82688a8)
  NavGraphics plate(30166): 
  30166:/home/httpd/html/Web/WebPolicy.html::
  [Thu Aug  1 11:03:41 2002] [error] Can't call method "fill_in" without a package or object reference at /usr/lib/perl5/site_perl/5.6.1/Apache/NavGraphics.pm line 48.

As above, except now the object is cached.  However, the caching code
correctly determines that the cache doesn't contain a Text::Template
object and tries to create a new object.  However, it fails.  There's
no debug output from the new method, and whatever is created by new
doesn't contain a Text::Template object.  Interestingly though,
something different from last time is returned, which indicates that
the call to new did something.  And if you print out what it did
return, you find the text of the template instead of the template
object.

As a stopgap, I tried making a second call to new if the first call to
new failed to return a Text::Template object, it also fails with no
debugging output so it appears that no calls to new will work in a
"bad" child process.

Here's the relevant sections of code from the module:

##The PRINT method for the Apache::OutputChain handler
sub PRINT {
  my $self = shift;
  my $r = $self->[0];
  my $bar   = load_nav($r);
  my $plate = load_plate($r);

  local $_ = join '', @_;
  my ($header, $content);
  ($header,$content) = m#<HEAD>(.+)</HEAD>.*<BODY.*?>(.+)</BODY>#si;
  my $thash = {
   'left_nav_java'    => $bar->java,
   'header'           => $header,
   'navigation_table' => $bar->table,
   'content'          => $content
  };
  warn join ':', $$, $r->filename, ref($plate), "\n";
  if (ref($plate) ne 'Text::Template') {
    warn join '', "NavGraphics($$) PRINT: >", $plate, "<\n";
  }
  my $result = $plate->fill_in(HASH => $thash);
  if (defined $result) {
    $self->Apache::OutputChain::PRINT($result);
  }
  else {
    warn "ERROR: $Text::Template::ERROR\n";
  }
  return OK;
}

##The template object caching subroutine
##Note the warn statements and their order
sub load_plate {
  my ($r) = @_;
  my $conf_file = $r->server_root_relative($r->dir_config('MyTemplate'));
  my $mod_time;
  if (-e $conf_file) {
    $mod_time = (stat _)[9];
  }
  else {
    $conf_file = '';
    $mod_time = 0;
  }
  
  warn "NavGraphics($$): conf_file = >$conf_file<\n";
  warn "NavGraphics($$) time=$mod_time\n";
  warn join '', "NavGraphics($$): exists ", exists $TB{$conf_file}, "\n";
  
  return $TB{$conf_file}->template()
    if exists($TB{$conf_file})
    && ($TB{$conf_file}->modified() >= $mod_time)
    && (ref($TB{$conf_file}->template()) eq 'Text::Template');
  warn "NavGraphics($$): plate not cached\n";
  warn "NavGraphics($$): plate $TB{$conf_file}\n";
  warn "NavGraphics($$): before new $TB{$conf_file}\n";
  $TB{$conf_file} = Apache::NavGraphics::NavTemplate->new($conf_file);
  warn "NavGraphics($$): after new $TB{$conf_file}\n";
  warn join '', "NavGraphics plate($$): ", ref($TB{$conf_file}->template()), "\n";
  return $TB{$conf_file}->template();
  
} 

##The new method for Apache::NavGraphics::NavTemplate
package Apache::NavGraphics::NavTemplate;

sub new {
  my ($class, $templateFile) = @_;
  warn "NavPlate($$): new <$templateFile>\n";
  unless ($templateFile) {
    warn "NavPlate($$) Empty templateFile sent\n";
    return bless { 'template' => '',
                   'modified' => 0 }, $class;
  }
  my $fh = Apache::File->new($templateFile) || return;
  warn "NavPlate($$): after fh\n";
  my $template = Text::Template->new(
                                   TYPE   => 'FILEHANDLE',
                                   SOURCE => $fh,
                                   DELIMITERS => ['{{', '}}']
                                 )
    or warn "($$)Problem with template: $Text::Template::ERROR\n";
  warn join '', "NavPlate($$) ref: ", ref($template), "\n";
  return bless({ 'template' => $template,
                 'modified' => (stat $templateFile)[9] }, $class);

}

The spawning of a bad child appears completely random and load
independent, which probably means that it isn't a memory problem.
However, I had the memory of the machine scanned and I've been able to
duplicate the problem on a completely different machine.

I've tested and seen the problem on:

RH6.2, with updated mod_perl and apache rpms (I forget the exact versions)
RH7.2 
  mod_perl-1.26-2 (from rpm)
  apache-1.3.22-6 (from rpm)
  mod_perl-1.27   (compiled from source)
  apache_1.3.26   (compiled from source)
RH7.3
  apache_1.3.26   (from rpm)
  mod_perl-1.27   (from rpm)

At this point, I don't understand why the output from warn in the "new"
method aren't going to the log file, or why Text::Template is returning
the template code instead of an object.  The debugging examples
from the website are pretty daunting, I could generate 100 Mb's of
log files with no errors, only to find that when I restart the server
that a "bad" child is started right away (which happened the night
before last.  I put about 240K hits on the server with no errors.
Then I made a few modifications to httpd.conf, restarted the server
and got an error right away.  Changing the config back to the original,
however, didn't make the problem go away).

Has anyone seen behavior like this, or have suggestions on how to
make the debugging a little easier?  Should I just wade in and see
what happens?  Is there some other combination of software that I
should try, like a different version of Perl itself?

Thanks for your help,
Colin Kuskie

httpd.conf snippet:

NameVirtualHost 199.108.225.3

PerlModule Apache::OutputChain
PerlModule Apache::NavGraphics
PerlModule Apache::SendFile

##Main site, www
<VirtualHost 199.108.225.3>
ServerName www.sunsetpres.org
DocumentRoot /home/httpd/html

<Directory "/">
  SetHandler perl-script
  PerlHandler Apache::OutputChain Apache::NavGraphics Apache::SendFile
  PerlSetVar MyTemplate etc/Sunset6.template
  PerlSetVar NavGraphicsDir /navgraphics
</Directory>

</VirtualHost>

perl -V:

Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net> writes:

> At 11:33 PM 8/20/2002 -0700, you wrote:
                               ^^^^^^^^^

Who wrote?  After it gets requoted, the original attribution is lost.
(how convenient)

> >Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net> writes:
> >Ok, so what's the word for someone who trounces on and attempts to
> >stiffle and repress anything regarding anything not deemed politically
> >correct or in keeping with their corporate image or business plan?
> 
> Um, Human Resources Director? :)

"Very funny" (charmed, I'm sure), and very in character.  I guess if
you don't want to hire someone you don't have to.  By the same token,
I don't have to work for someone I don't want to work for.  Or pay
tuition somewhere I don't want to be a student.

> > > (Attribution lost)
> > > We've had discussions here on this list about giving distribution
> > > specific answers when the distribution is known and the answer
> > > doesn't apply to that distribution.
> >
> >Sure, but no formal ban on Open Response was ever ratified by the
> >cabal.
> 
> I realize that. But I thought it was generally recognized that
> confusing the already flustered newbie folks with answers that won't
> work in their environment was detrimental to the proliferation of
> Linux in general. As a former On-line Tech. Support Engineer, I am
> sensitive to how folks perceive the help they get on-line.

So you subscribe to the "philosophy" that the user is a moron who must
be given only the bare minimum amount of information and given that in
simple words, and that they are easily confused due to poor reading
skills?  That all of the users are "non technical"?  Perhaps it takes
one to know one?  I think that this so called "philosophy" is one of
the most detrimental barriers to entry that exists in the computer
industry.  It is insulting.

It's better to expose them to new things and to teach them to write
their own homework assignments and how to follow through and find
answers for themselves.  Then the task for the experts is to document
everything sufficiently and make that documentation available.

The thing is, that in the real world, they will always encounter "non
standard" configurations and setups (like Red Hat's).  They must learn
to adapt, and to do so from the beginning.  The other thing is that
just because you use Red Hat and that you buy into the marketting BS
about how "Red Hat is synonomous with Linux" doesn't mean that
everyone else buys that advertising claim or that everyone else uses
your favorite brand of Linux.

You cannot PROVE that Red Hat is the most popular distro or that there
are more copies of it installed.  And for that matter, where and who
has installed what brand of Linux is probably more pertinent wrt "best
distro" than number of installs or especially number of copies sold.
Note that I am trying to be very careful not to make any false claims
regarding the relative popularity or fitness of the Debian
distribution.  It's a cavet emptor and see for yourself situtation.  I
am NOT the marketing department.

> >What about the several times where someone was struggling to build
> >some peice of software from scratch, and I offered that they might
> >find it useful to grab the source from Debian and see what the package
> >maintainer did?  Was that not a pertinent reply?
> 
> And I don't have any problem with that. I think you (as well as others
> on this list) have a wealth of information to offer. It's this one
> little sticking point that I have a problem with, and that's those
> distro specific answers to (not) solve the problem on another distro.

But they present an alternative solution, another angle, and the
similar howto information for users of the Debian (or slackware or
whatever) distribution.  You are free to ignore the non Redhatlike
centric responses if you like.  Just hit "next message" and get on
with your lives.

> I'm only singling out debian because debian users seem to be the
> only ones that do this.

Perhaps the others should speak up as well then.  IMO, they are more
than welcome to do so.

> >The gist of the "apt-get install ..." responses is: Why are you
> >spending your time building things from scratch (that are not part of
> >the distro you chose first try at this newfangled Linux thing) and why
> >are you wasting time hunting down stuff to meet software dependancies,
> >and why are you spending money that's probably not ever going to be
> >lining the pockets of the actual software developers?
> 
> OK, maybe I missed that point. Was it every stated that way previously?

Not until just now, apparently.  Anyone have any remarks regarding
this issue that they would like to put forth?

> > > Almost as much as this message is a waste. Putting "iff debian" in

> >for a silly certification test and you think you're a god damned Linux

> I don't have any "certifications", "licenses" or even a college

> doesn't it.

Perhaps it does help.  Cooking on the line in a restaurant actually
provides plenty of analogs to what can go on inside a multi processing
computer software system.

> >Do you contradict yourself by claiming to be "open minded" yet

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Wed Aug 21 16:56:01 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 21 Aug 2002 16:56:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] It's free as in air and speech, not free as in beer.
In-Reply-To: <3D640DFC.9080500@attbi.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208211503190.26485-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
	<3D640DFC.9080500@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <87lm6zg41a.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Mark Morgan <lemming at attbi.com> writes:

> Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > Quite frankly, when I see these Debian v. Red Hat discussions on this
> > list, I am stunned by how few people actually support Red Hat on technical
> > merits.  Usually the argument is simply reduced to "Diff'rent strokes for
> > diff'rent folks" and the Red Hat users urge the discussion dropped.  I've
> > yet to hear anyone argue that Red Hat is actually superior to Debian in
> > any way.  Instead, Debian supporters are branded and their arguments
> > dismissed as zealotry.
> 
> I haven't checked the latest Debian, but I would say Red Hat is easier
> to install and worked with all my hardware.  This may of changed with
> the woody release.

Do the cartoons and soft round cornered GUI provide the illusion that
it is easier to install?  Does the simple and elegant TUI of the
Debian "boot-floppies" install really make it seem that hard to
install?  Does the Red Hat installer speak 8 or 10 languages?

You don't NEED automatic device detection when you are installing
Debian from a CDROM.  You can install the base Debian system without
ever loading any driver modules.  After the base is installed and the
post install reboot, you simply type:

# apt-get install discover aptitude

... and at that point you will have hardware auto detection and a
wonderful TUI for software installation managment.

# apt-get install etherconf

... and you'll have network configuration, which you can change at any
time with a simple (once you learn of it):

# dpkg-reconfigure etherconf

>From that point on, you're on the net, and thus have all available
resources at your fingertips.  You'll find "task" packages for the X
Window System desktop in the "aptitude" user interface.  You may
choose Gnome or KDE, or build your own from a plethora of available
window managers.

> I've been playing around with different distributions on my Sony Vaio
> PCG-F580.

Is that an i386 arch CPU?  What is it?  Will it hibernate (suspend to
disk)?  If it's capable of it, I know how to make that work under
Linux.  All of the tools required are part of Debian, but not in the
default installer...  I have a static copy of "lphdisk", which is
required to format the hibernation partition.

> Ones I've gone through the entire install and used for at least a few
> days: SuSe 7.3, SuSe 8.0, Redhat 7.3, Mandrake 8.2, Gentoo 1.2

Would you like a Debian 3.0r0 (Woody) CDROM so you can try that also?
I can burn one for you if you like, no charge.

> Of these, only Redhat installed correctly.  Mainly due to my pcmcia
> NIC. SuSe needed tweaking of a conf file before it would work, but
> probably needed the second least amount of work to get running the way
> I wanted it too. (For some reason, Mandrake gave me trouble, but I
> don't recall what now.)

PCMCIA should work just fine in the Debian installer.  I've tested it
on my laptop, and had no trouble at all.  It Just Works.

> On the other hand, having the Redhat site busy for updates all the
> time means I haven't done any patches. (Though, I'm betting I'm
> missing some mirror...)

There are a lot of Debian mirrors, and I've never had any trouble
getting through on donated bandwidth.  They have a brand new security
build system set up, and security updates are out very soon after the
upstream patches become available.  You can subscribe to the
"debian-security-announce" mailing list to be promptly notified when
update packages become available on the mirror network.

> With SuSe, that was easy.  Their update tool works flawlessly for
> me. I happen to like SuSe a lot and will be keeping my main server
> running it for some time.

Does SuSe ship documentation or tools for creating your own update
server, for the case where you need to shadow their versions or to
provide packages of software they do not package?  How does their
update technology operate, I wonder...  and how does it compare to
"Apt", I wonder?  (the similar wondering about Red Hat's)

> I'm going to go back and load Gentoo again.  I found that
> distribution to be a fun delve into the nuts and bolts. Plus I do
> find running at the cutting edge to be a bit of a thrill.

Debian "unstable" is very near the cutting edge.  With "apt-build",
you can build from source, configured with optimizations for your
particular CPU.  If a Debian package fails to autobuild, it's
considered a bug!

> I might try Debian again just for to check it out again.

Email me (karlheg at hegbloom.net) and I'll burn you a CD.  Anyone else?

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Wed Aug 21 17:00:43 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 17:00:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Win2k network drive mapping issue
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208211455270.22861-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208211657510.22861-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

So the fix was to login as someone besides Administrator (root is so much
easier to spell) say user x, delete the registry keys.  Login as
Administrator and then copy user x's profile to the "Default user"
profile.

<sigh> if 2k natively had su, then I could do it without so much loging in
and out...but I'll stop ranting there.

Thanks Paul,
Jason

technical thing, in the most technical terms will confuse them.

familiar with, and changing just isn't that important to me. It does what I 
want, and works well.

Did I pay for it? Nope. I downloaded the isos, and burned 'em myself.

>You cannot PROVE that Red Hat is the most popular distro or that there

experience, and MY familiarity with what's out there. If I need to, I can 
use just about any distro out there. My choice of Redhat has nothing to do 
with anyones motives or anything like that.
