From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Aug 21 17:09:20 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 17:09:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Moving Files
Message-ID: <3D642BB0.A6B7F009@attbi.com>

I understand that using mv to move a file from one directory to another
doesn't actually move the contents of the file, but just changes the
information about where that file is stored. (At least I think I
understand that.)

I have a system with two hard drives, an 8 GB drive that was in the
system when I installed RH 7.0, and a 40 GB drive that I added later,
with the intention of storing all the mp3 files I will create from my LP
collection.

Until I get around to recording all those LPs, I'm using the space for
temporary backups of other systems. I have another machine with a 12 GB
drive running Win98 which talks to the RH machine via Samba. I started
backing up a large number of files, intending that they go on the 40 GB
drive. To my dismay, I discovered that I put them on the 8 GB drive, and
pretty well filled it up.

If mv doesn't actually move files from one place to another, what tool
do I use to put the files I accidentally stored on the 8 GB drive onto
the 40 GB drive? Would I use cp to move them to the 40 GB drive and then
delete them from the 8 GB drive? Or is there a better way?

Thanks in advance.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"

From RSchlosser at newedgenetworks.com  Wed Aug 21 17:13:26 2002
From: RSchlosser at newedgenetworks.com (Schlosser, Ryan)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 17:13:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT: FW: Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-044 : Unsafe Functions i
 n Office Web Components (Q328130)
Message-ID: <A3FA06C6C183D61188330008C7E6BF4354FC0B@vader.newedgenetworks.com>

Some of you deal with Windows workstations, so hey, is this on topic?

If nothing else, it gives good meat for the anti-microsoft chatter.
Microsoft rated this as a "CRITICAL" security risk for clients, and I think
that indicates some of the risk they associate with this particular problem.

-----Original Message-----
From: Microsoft
[mailto:0_35529_8DD5B9E3-E5C4-1849-A65C-98E1C24AB25A_US at Newsletters.Micr
osoft.com]
Sent: Wednesday, August 21, 2002 4:26 PM
To: rschlosser at newedgenetworks.com
Subject: Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-044 : Unsafe Functions in
Office Web Components (Q328130)


-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

- ----------------------------------------------------------------------
Title:      Unsafe Functions in Office Web Components (Q328130)
Date:       21 August 2002
Software:   Office Web Components, Office, BackOffice Server,
            BizTalk Server, Commerce Server, ISA Server, Money,
            Microsoft Project, Microsoft Project Server
            Small Business Server
Impact:     Three vulnerabilities, the most serious of which could
            allow an attacker to run commands on the user's system.
Max Risk:   Critical
Bulletin:   MS02-044

Microsoft encourages customers to review the Security Bulletin at: 
http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/MS02-044.asp.
- ----------------------------------------------------------------------

Issue:
======
The Office Web Components (OWC) contain several ActiveX controls
that give users limited functionality of Microsoft Office in a web
browser without requiring that the user install the full
Microsoft Office application. This allows users to utilize
Microsoft Office applications in situations where installation
of the full application is infeasible or undesirable. 

The control contains three security vulnerabilities, each of
which could be exploited either via a web site or an HTML mail.
The vulnerabilities result because of implementation errors
in the following methods and functions the controls expose: 

 - Host(). This function, by design, provides the caller with
   access to applications' object models on the user's system.
   By using the Host() function, an attacker could, for instance,
   open an Office application on the user's system and invoke
   commands there that would execute operating system commands
   as the user. 

 - LoadText(). This method allows a web page to load text into a
   browser window. The method does check that the source of the
   text is in the same domain as the window, and in theory should
   restrict the page to only loading text that it hosts itself.
   However, it is possible to circumvent this restriction by
   specifying a text source located within the web page's domain,
   and then setting up a server-side redirect of that text to a
   file on the user's system. This would provide an attacker with
   a way to read any desired file on the user's system. 

 - Copy()/Paste(). These methods allow text to be copied and pasted.
   A security vulnerability results because the method does not
   respect the "disallow paste via script" security setting in IE.
   Thus, even if this setting had been selected, a web page could
   continue to access the copy buffer, and read any text that the
   user had copied or cut from within other applications. 

The patch does not set "kill bit" on the control, for reasons
discussed in the FAQ.

Mitigating Factors:
====================
Overall: 

 - In the case of the web-based attack, an attacker would need
   to force a user to visit the attacker's Web site. Users who
   exercise caution in visiting web sites could minimize their
   risk. 

 - In the web based attack, If ActiveX controls have been
   disabled in the zone in which the page were viewed, the
   vulnerability could not be exploited. Users who place
   untrusted sites in the Restricted Sites zone, which disables
   ActiveX by default, or have disabled ActiveX controls in the
   Internet zone could minimize their risk. 

 - In the case of HTML email based attacks, customers who read
   email in the Restricted Sites zone would be protected against
   attempts to exploit this vulnerability. Customers using
   Outlook 2002 and Outlook Express 6.0, as well as
   Outlook 2000 and Outlook 98 customers who have applied the
   Outlook Email Security Update would thus be protected by
   default. Also, Outlook Express 5.0 customers who have chosen
   to read mail in the Restricted Sites zone would be protected
   by default. 

 - In the HTML email based attack, Outlook 2002 customers who
   have enabled the "Read as Plain Text" option available in
   SP1 or later would also be protected.
 
Host() Vulnerability: 

 - The attacker's code would be limited by restrictions on the
   user's account. Users of non-privileged accounts would limit
   the potential damage from a successful attack. 

LoadText(): 

 - The attacker would need to know the full path and name of the
   file. In addition the file would have to be viewable in a
   web browser. 

Copy()/Paste(): 

 - The vulnerability could enable an attacker to access only to
   information in the Windows clipboard. The information in the
   clipboard is unpredictable and this vulnerability gives no
   means for an attacker to target and retrieve specific
   information. Further, it is possible for the clipboard to
   be empty, which would yield an attacker nothing. 

 - The security setting in question is not enabled by default.
   Thus, the vulnerability does not present a threat to the 
   default installation.

Risk Rating:
============
 - Internet systems: Moderate
 - Intranet systems: Moderate
 - Client systems: Critical

Patch Availability:
===================
 - A patch is available to fix this vulnerability. Please read the 
   Security Bulletin at
   http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/ms02-044.asp
   for information on obtaining this patch.

- ---------------------------------------------------------------------

THE INFORMATION PROVIDED IN THE MICROSOFT KNOWLEDGE BASE IS 
PROVIDED "AS IS" WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY KIND. MICROSOFT DISCLAIMS
ALL 
WARRANTIES, EITHER EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING THE 
WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.
IN NO EVENT 
SHALL MICROSOFT CORPORATION OR ITS SUPPLIERS BE LIABLE FOR ANY
DAMAGES 
WHATSOEVER INCLUDING DIRECT, INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL, CONSEQUENTIAL,
LOSS OF 
BUSINESS PROFITS OR SPECIAL DAMAGES, EVEN IF MICROSOFT CORPORATION OR
ITS 
SUPPLIERS HAVE BEEN ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGES. SOME
STATES DO 
NOT ALLOW THE EXCLUSION OR LIMITATION OF LIABILITY FOR CONSEQUENTIAL
OR 
INCIDENTAL DAMAGES SO THE FOREGOING LIMITATION MAY NOT APPLY.

From don at truedisk.com  Wed Aug 21 17:21:17 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 17:21:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Moving Files
References: <3D642BB0.A6B7F009@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D642E7D.3CDFD601@truedisk.com>

Richard Steffens wrote:
> 
> I understand that using mv to move a file from one directory to another
> doesn't actually move the contents of the file, but just changes the
> information about where that file is stored. (At least I think I
> understand that.)

When mv(1) is instructed to move a file (or directory) from one filesystem
to another, the data will be copied to the destination, and then deleted
from the original location.

> ... what tool
> do I use to put the files I accidentally stored on the 8 GB drive onto
> the 40 GB drive? Would I use cp to move them to the 40 GB drive and then
> delete them from the 8 GB drive? Or is there a better way?
> 

Just use "mv".

- Don

From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Aug 21 17:45:04 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 17:45:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Moving Files - resolved
References: <3D642BB0.A6B7F009@attbi.com> <3D642E7D.3CDFD601@truedisk.com>
Message-ID: <3D643410.74F6A2A@attbi.com>

Don Buchholz wrote:

> When mv(1) is instructed to move a file (or directory) from one filesystem
> to another, the data will be copied to the destination, and then deleted
> from the original location.

> > ... what tool
> > do I use to put the files I accidentally stored on the 8 GB drive onto
> > the 40 GB drive?

> Just use "mv".

Aha! I just reread my notes from when I installed the 40 GB drive and I
see that I ran mkfs.ext2 -c/dev/hdd1. So that created a separate file
system. Now I understand that mv is moving files between file systems.
It is so transparent in day to day use that, since I haven't done this
too often, it seemed like I was dealing with one file system. I think I
get the distinction, now.

Since I can hear the disk drive clicking away, and the command prompt
hasn't returned, I can assume that a large block of files is actually
moving.

Thanks, Don.

Dick Steffens

From RSchlosser at newedgenetworks.com  Wed Aug 21 17:45:48 2002
From: RSchlosser at newedgenetworks.com (Schlosser, Ryan)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 17:45:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Win2k network drive mapping issue
Message-ID: <A3FA06C6C183D61188330008C7E6BF4354FC0D@vader.newedgenetworks.com>

Open Explorer, navigate to C:\winnt\system32

Hold shift key, Right click an application, such as regedt32.exe  - and
choose "Run As".

I don't use it much, but the theory is it helps prevent logging in and out
for admin tasks (or in this case the other way around?).

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Aug 21 18:55:28 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 18:55:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Moving Files
In-Reply-To: <3D642BB0.A6B7F009@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208211852500.30325-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 21 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> I understand that using mv to move a file from one directory to another
> doesn't actually move the contents of the file, but just changes the
> information about where that file is stored. (At least I think I
> understand that.)

  I believe, Dick, that this holds within a filesystem. However, if you move
a file across a filesystem boundary (i.e., from one partition to another),
it is moved physically as well as logically (in the inode).

  I've run out of space on one workstation and moved files to a different
partition on another workstation (or just to a different partition on the
same workstation) and df shows the change in percentage used.

Rich

On 21 Aug 2002, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> Mark Morgan <lemming at attbi.com> writes:
>
> > Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > > Quite frankly, when I see these Debian v. Red Hat discussions on this
> > > list, I am stunned by how few people actually support Red Hat on technical
> > > merits.  Usually the argument is simply reduced to "Diff'rent strokes for
> > > diff'rent folks" and the Red Hat users urge the discussion dropped.  I've
> > > yet to hear anyone argue that Red Hat is actually superior to Debian in
> > > any way.  Instead, Debian supporters are branded and their arguments
> > > dismissed as zealotry.
> >
> > I haven't checked the latest Debian, but I would say Red Hat is easier
> > to install and worked with all my hardware.  This may of changed with
> > the woody release.
>
> Do the cartoons and soft round cornered GUI provide the illusion that
> it is easier to install?  Does the simple and elegant TUI of the
> Debian "boot-floppies" install really make it seem that hard to
> install?  Does the Red Hat installer speak 8 or 10 languages?
>
> You don't NEED automatic device detection when you are installing
> Debian from a CDROM.  You can install the base Debian system without
> ever loading any driver modules.  After the base is installed and the
> post install reboot, you simply type:
>
> # apt-get install discover aptitude
>
> ... and at that point you will have hardware auto detection and a
> wonderful TUI for software installation managment.
>
> # apt-get install etherconf
>
> ... and you'll have network configuration, which you can change at any
> time with a simple (once you learn of it):
>
> # dpkg-reconfigure etherconf
>
> >From that point on, you're on the net, and thus have all available
> resources at your fingertips.  You'll find "task" packages for the X
> Window System desktop in the "aptitude" user interface.  You may
> choose Gnome or KDE, or build your own from a plethora of available
> window managers.
>
> > I've been playing around with different distributions on my Sony Vaio
> > PCG-F580.
>
> Is that an i386 arch CPU?  What is it?  Will it hibernate (suspend to
> disk)?  If it's capable of it, I know how to make that work under
> Linux.  All of the tools required are part of Debian, but not in the
> default installer...  I have a static copy of "lphdisk", which is
> required to format the hibernation partition.
>
> > Ones I've gone through the entire install and used for at least a few
> > days: SuSe 7.3, SuSe 8.0, Redhat 7.3, Mandrake 8.2, Gentoo 1.2
>
> Would you like a Debian 3.0r0 (Woody) CDROM so you can try that also?
> I can burn one for you if you like, no charge.
>
> > Of these, only Redhat installed correctly.  Mainly due to my pcmcia
> > NIC. SuSe needed tweaking of a conf file before it would work, but
> > probably needed the second least amount of work to get running the way
> > I wanted it too. (For some reason, Mandrake gave me trouble, but I
> > don't recall what now.)
>
> PCMCIA should work just fine in the Debian installer.  I've tested it
> on my laptop, and had no trouble at all.  It Just Works.
>
> > On the other hand, having the Redhat site busy for updates all the
> > time means I haven't done any patches. (Though, I'm betting I'm
> > missing some mirror...)
>
> There are a lot of Debian mirrors, and I've never had any trouble
> getting through on donated bandwidth.  They have a brand new security
> build system set up, and security updates are out very soon after the
> upstream patches become available.  You can subscribe to the
> "debian-security-announce" mailing list to be promptly notified when
> update packages become available on the mirror network.
>
> > With SuSe, that was easy.  Their update tool works flawlessly for
> > me. I happen to like SuSe a lot and will be keeping my main server

> > distribution to be a fun delve into the nuts and bolts. Plus I do
> > find running at the cutting edge to be a bit of a thrill.

> Debian "unstable" is very near the cutting edge.  With "apt-build",
> you can build from source, configured with optimizations for your
> particular CPU.  If a Debian package fails to autobuild, it's
> considered a bug!

From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Aug 21 19:52:47 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 19:52:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Moving Files
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208211852500.30325-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3D6451FF.86743723@attbi.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I believe, Dick, that this holds within a filesystem. However, if you move
> a file across a filesystem boundary (i.e., from one partition to another),
> it is moved physically as well as logically (in the inode).

That is indeed what occurred. 

Before mv:

Filesystem           1k-blocks      Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/hda1              8222624   7804608       328 100% /
/dev/hdd1             38464340   6960524  29549912  20% /home/mp3

After mv:

Filesystem           1k-blocks      Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/hda1              8222624   3817744   3987192  49% /
/dev/hdd1             38464340  10947392  25563044  30% /home/mp3

It's another one of those nuances that I'm slowly getting used to.
Thanks for the clarification.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Aug 21 21:06:29 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 21:06:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Moving Files
In-Reply-To: <3D6451FF.86743723@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208212104150.31769-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 21 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> It's another one of those nuances that I'm slowly getting used to.
> Thanks for the clarification.

  Several years ago Eric put it all in perspective for me. Linux is made up
of little pieces, and each little piece is very easy to understand. The
problems arise because there are thousands of little pieces. :-)

  This advice has served me well. There are time, however, when several
little pieces need to be well understood all at once, and there are other
issues requiring my attention, too.

Rich

> advantage (IMNSHO) between Debian, Redhat, SuSE, Turbo, etc."

The conversation as you see it.  (hint: I was leading it in that
direction. ;) And there ARE FOR CERTAIN specific advantages to one
distribution or the other.  They each have their strong and weak
points.  There is more than one packaging format, more than one
package creation and build methodology, more than one software
configuration toolset, etc.

There are likely aspects of each that have merit over any other's way
of doing the similar, and aspects of each that are just wrong or lame.
Debian's runlevel configuration is poorly done, as of the present.
(It will be much improved by the dependancy based setup mandated by
the LSB.)

> I did say that *I* prefer Redhat. That is purely MY preference, due to
> MY experience, and MY familiarity with what's out there. If I need to,
> I can use just about any distro out there. My choice of Redhat has
> nothing to do with anyones motives or anything like that.

Apparently this particular printer/fax machine needs to be configured using 
Windows tools.  Namely, telling it to route incoming calls based on 
distinctive ring.

Printing over the net works fine, haven't tried scanning/faxing yet.

letting a Windows client with the right software fully exploit the features 
of the device?

support pc faxing.  But should one expect pc faxing to work if using a 
windows client on the net?  How would samba know where to spool an incoming fax?

Currently using lpd, but would CUPS offer more functionality in this regard?

Kyle Accardi

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Thu Aug 22 01:00:19 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 22 Aug 2002 01:00:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Moving Files
In-Reply-To: <3D642BB0.A6B7F009@attbi.com>
References: <3D642BB0.A6B7F009@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <87ptwbcoh8.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Richard Steffens <rsteff at attbi.com> writes:

> I understand that using mv to move a file from one directory to
> another doesn't actually move the contents of the file, but just
> changes the information about where that file is stored.

Sure, it does not move the file's data or change it's inode (look that
up), it only changes or moves that directory entry for that inode.

> If mv doesn't actually move files from one place to another, what
> tool do I use to put the files I accidentally stored on the 8 GB
> drive onto the 40 GB drive? Would I use cp to move them to the 40 GB
> drive and then delete them from the 8 GB drive? Or is there a better
> way?

One way of answering this question for your self would be to RTFS
"mv", which is in the "fileutils" package.  (If you are running a
Debian GNU system you can use "apt-get source mv" to grab it really
quick.)  You might also check the man page to rename(2) (say "man 2
rename" to read it, provide you've got the devel man pages installed),
the system call that actually renames a file.

What you will discover is that "mv" will check and see if the two
files are on the same device or not.  If so, it will use "rename(2)",
and if not, it will copy the file then remove it from the old
location.  Most people use "cp" or "tar" for this sort of task though,
since it's a little safer.  You'll know it's copied for sure before
you remove the old copy of the file from the other disc.  Every now
and then cross device "mv" will lose a file for one reason or another.

Though "cp -a" will work fine, preserving hard links, ownership and
permissions, it is generally much faster to use "tar" to copy large
numbers of files from one spindle to another.  The general formula
is... ("#" means root prompt, "%" means user prompt)

# (cd /source && tar cpf - .) | (cd /dest && tar xpf -)

Please RTFM "tar" (say "info tar") to find out what those switches do.
The reason this is faster, especially when you are copying files from
one device to another, is that now there are two processes running, a
reader and a writer, each on a separate spindle.  With "cp -a",
there's only one process doing both the reading and the writing, so
there is less parallelism.

You can speed up the copy a little more, especially when the two
devices do not operate with the same sustained data throughput speed,
by using a program like "buffer" (apt-get install buffer) in the
pipeline, like:

# (cd /source && tar cpf - .) | buffer | (cd /dest && tar xpf -)

You can also copy files from one machine to another by piping the tar
(tape archive) through a secure shell pipe, like this:

% ssh -e none root at datahost 'cd /source && tar cpf - .' | (cd /dest && tar xpf -)

 Question!  Does anyone who has studied queueing theory (isn't that
            what I need to learn to know this answer?) know where the
            "buffer" belongs in that pipeline for optimal throughput?
            Please discuss.

To copy an entire host to a tarfile, I use this (and got PAID to
develop it):

"make-tarball"
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
#!/bin/bash
find / -print0 |
 grep --invert-match --extended-regexp --null-data --file=/root/make-tarball.exclude-patterns |
 tar --null --files-from=/dev/stdin --no-recursion -cpf -
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

"make-tarball.exclude-patterns"
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
^/proc/.*
^/dev/.*
^/tmp/.*
^/mnt/target/.*
^/target/.*
^/lost+found
^/boot/lost+found
^/var/cache/apache/.*
^/var/cache/apt/.*\.deb
^/var/log/.*\.log
^/var/log/\(amanda\|apache\|gdm\|ksymoops\|mailman\|news\|named\|bind\|sendfile\|wu-ftpd\)/.*
^/var/log/\(syslog\|smb\|nmb\|messages\|mail\|lpr\|debug\|dmesg\).*
^/var/lock/\.LCK.*
^/var/run/.*\.pid
^/var/run/\(ndc\|utmp\)
^/var/samba/.*
\.bash_history
\.gnome-errors
.*~
/\.saves-.*
/\.#.*
/\.netscape/cache/.*
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.

 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'

galen


 HPOJ 0.90 is out!  Sat Aug 10 11:41:50 2002

On August 7th, exactly one year after the last release, David Paschal from HP 
has released a new version of his low-level driver package for HP's 
multi-function devices (HP OfficeJet, PSC, PhotoSmart, LaserJet with scanner, 
Sony IJP-V100).

The new HPOJ 0.90 is vastly improved against the old one. The most important 
new features are:

    * All models with scanner scan via the SANE infrastructure now.
    * Access to the drives for photo memory cards is supported in all 
appropriately equipped models (most PhotoSmarts, PSC 950, OfficeJet D145/155).
    * Configuration program now also auto-detects devices connected on the 
parallel port. It sets up all device types: parallel, USB, JetDSirect.
    * Tons of bug fixes.

Everyone who had problems with HPOJ 0.8 is encouraged to update. Most problems 
will disappear this way.

Happy printing, scanning, and photo card reading!

different functions and pieces individually before you can understand how

want it to do that" then email "plug at lists.pdxlinux.org".  or am I way off
base here?

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Aug 22 10:32:09 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 22 Aug 2002 10:32:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Ok to post a mod_perl question?
References: <mailman.1029967999.28723.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86sn16kdeu.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Colin" == Colin Kuskie <ckuskie at dalsemi.com> writes:

Colin> Would it be okay to post a mod_perl question here?  It isn't
Colin> Linux specific, but I've been trying to fix this for a month
Colin> and haven't gotten anywhere with either my own debugging
Colin> efforts or with the mod_perl mailing list.

If you've not gotten anywhere with the world's experts in mod_perl on
the mod_perl mailing list, I'm not sure what you expect to gain by
posting here.

It's a bit like going to a car repair shop and saying to the mechanic
on duty: "you know, my doctor couldn't help me with this pain in my
back, but maybe *you've* got some advice".

OK, maybe I'm just being cynical.  But that's how it lands for me.

I'd say stay with the mod_perl list.  Either you don't have the
problem refined enough for *anyone* to help you, or *that* list will
be the solution, eventually.  Plus, if you solve it *there* you'll
help a much more apropos audience for future reference.

> on duty: "you know, my doctor couldn't help me with this pain in my
> back, but maybe *you've* got some advice".

I agree, but there are a few caveats:

1) I've been posting to user/developer forums for almost a decade, and
this is the first time I've received absolute silence about a problem.
Even when I was a newbie learning perl back in '93, Larry Wall,
yourself and Tom Christensen would at least say "Go read this man
page."

2) I know there are mod_perl users here on PLUG.  I'm hoping that my
problem will trigger something like "Hey, I ran your code and had no
problems.  I use mod_perl xxx, Apache xxx, perl xxx" and so on.

> OK, maybe I'm just being cynical.  But that's how it lands for me.
> 
> I'd say stay with the mod_perl list.  Either you don't have the
> problem refined enough for *anyone* to help you, or *that* list will
> be the solution, eventually.  Plus, if you solve it *there* you'll
> help a much more apropos audience for future reference.

I understand, and in general would agree with what you're saying.
However, have _you_ actually read my post?  The problem I'm having
doesn't exactly lend itself to minimization.  It's completely random
and load independent.

Colin



From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Thu Aug 22 10:48:18 2002

From mikedela at ipns.com  Thu Aug 22 11:01:29 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 11:01:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
In-Reply-To: <1541.208.151.243.124.1030038498.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <3X74WQJDIHJINH93SQXM74898URYV.3d6526f9@miked>

There's a "Consulting for Dummies" book. It covers a lot of the basics. Pricing 
is more about confidence and polish in my opinion than much else. One of my 
favorite answers is "I don't know, but I can find out/ know somebody who does" 
People are happy with the answer and I don't have to be a know-it-all in all of 
the areas I get asked about. (the best phone systems, how much data does their 
external payroll system  backup on their local PC...)

Mike

cross over.

modems may do the same job. I just figure that if the Cisco would work, 
Qwest would be willing to sell you one, if they're still distributing them.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug 22 11:56:59 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 11:56:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
In-Reply-To: <1541.208.151.243.124.1030038498.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221150450.1924-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 22 Aug 2002, Robby Russell wrote:

> Can any consultants here recommend some sites to some tips on getting
> started with becoming a consultant?
> 
> Such as...pricing... legal aspects... oregon business license (??
> necessary?, laws)
> 
> I've been asked to do some work...but was curious if I should try to just
> go all out and set myself up as a part-time consultant...
> 
> any advice would be great...

Robby,

  I've run a consulting company for the past nine years. Environmental, not
computer, but the principles are the same.

  First, go to the library (or Powell's) and check out the books on computer
consulting and consulting in general. Second, set up a business name and
register it with the Secretary of State. You don't need to incorporate or
get fancy now, but a registered business name helps prospective clients gain
confidence in you. Depending on where you live, a local business license is
a worth-while investment. Third, pricing is dependent on the value you
deliver to clients and what others -- with similar levels of knowledge and
experience -- are charging for similar services. Don't forget, the state is
in economic straits and money is tight for almost every business. Finally,
start small and work up as you gain a reputation among clients.

  The biggest difference between consulting and any other marketing/sales
position is that we're selling the invisible. Track record and reputation
are everything.

HTH,

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard at appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Thu Aug 22 13:03:21 2002
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: 22 Aug 2002 13:03:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221150450.1924-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221150450.1924-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1030046603.2527.105.camel@mikado>

On Thu, 2002-08-22 at 11:56, Rich Shepard wrote:
> Second, set up a business name and
> register it with the Secretary of State. You don't need to incorporate or
> get fancy now, but a registered business name helps prospective clients gain
> confidence in you.

Ditto to registering a name, but don't underestimate the importance (or
ease) of incorporation.  It's not a crucial first step, but don't let
yourself get more than a year or two into being a consultant without
doing it.  Sole proprietorship is a losing proposition, long term. (IMO,
YMMV, etc.) 

Also, get an accountant as soon as you make any money at all.  You'll
need one.

> we're selling the invisible

Oddly enough, the very title of a book I was going to recommend.  If you
get just *one* book on marketing a service business, it should be Harry
Beckwith's _Selling The Invisible_.

FWIW,

Dylan

From cschluti at pdx.edu  Thu Aug 22 13:05:24 2002
From: cschluti at pdx.edu (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 13:05:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] HP OfficeJet 600 & samba
In-Reply-To: <3D647A59.600@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <000801c24a17$43b5b400$4500000a@SERVANYA>

Well, I used to do OfficeJet support for HP.
So, basically what you want to do isn't possible. You cannot fax over
the network without the HP windows software. But, as far a settings go,
if you connect it to a windows box, set the distinctive ring or rings to
answer, and disconnect it from the computer, it will hold the settings. 
You can also access the parameters menu using *# (press together, then
release), then push 1,2,3. I don't remember which parameters to change,
but I could probably get a list. You won't have to mess with that if you
install the software on a windows box temporarily anyways.

In order to PC fax, you just have to hope the linux driver will some day
support that. However, by that time, the false paper jams will probably
have frustrated you so much that the machine will be in pieces :)

Oh, on a side note, PC faxing with the windows version cannot be done
over a network anyways. At least, not with the OJ600.

-Charlie



> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]
> On Behalf Of Kyle Accardi
> Sent: Wednesday, August 21, 2002 10:45 PM
> To: plug
> Subject: [PLUG] HP OfficeJet 600 & samba
> 
> Hopefully, some folks have more experience with all-in-one devices
than I.
> Apparently this particular printer/fax machine needs to be configured
> using
> Windows tools.  Namely, telling it to route incoming calls based on
> distinctive ring.
> 
> Printing over the net works fine, haven't tried scanning/faxing yet.
> Question is: How much functionality is part of the Linux driver vs.
just
> letting a Windows client with the right software fully exploit the
> features
> of the device?
> 
> Example: the Linux driver (being developed by HP, yea them) doesn't
yet
> support pc faxing.  But should one expect pc faxing to work if using a
> windows client on the net?  How would samba know where to spool an
> incoming fax?
>

> regard?

From cschluti at pdx.edu  Thu Aug 22 13:12:44 2002
From: cschluti at pdx.edu (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 13:12:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux DSL modems (Possibly OT)
In-Reply-To: <1030046897.8477.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <000901c24a18$498022c0$4500000a@SERVANYA>

The 678 should work. Just verify that the DSL circuit you will be
getting is DMT, and it will work. The 678 is cool. NAT and port
forwarding capabilities, just like any router. There's different ways to
configure it, depending on whether or not you have a static IP.

-Charlie

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Aug 22 13:25:12 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 22 Aug 2002 13:25:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Ok to post a mod_perl question?
References: <mailman.1029967999.28723.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <86sn16kdeu.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com> <mailman.1030038561.24498.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <868z2yk5ef.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Colin" == Colin Kuskie <ckuskie at dalsemi.com> writes:

>> I'd say stay with the mod_perl list.  Either you don't have the
>> problem refined enough for *anyone* to help you, or *that* list will
>> be the solution, eventually.  Plus, if you solve it *there* you'll
>> help a much more apropos audience for future reference.

Colin> I understand, and in general would agree with what you're saying.
Colin> However, have _you_ actually read my post?  The problem I'm having
Colin> doesn't exactly lend itself to minimization.  It's completely random
Colin> and load independent.

I just now read your post (it had expired from my mail box), and I
think I know why I didn't remember it.

You've got a difficult problem.  You are pulling in a lot of other
modules, and you have some interesting issues.  But it's not something
that stands out for me as "Oh duh, just do this".  And I bet that's
what most people said on the mod_perl list as well.  So we all glaze
over, and move along.

But I'll stand by my first statement.  If there *is* an expert who can
help you, it's there, not here.

And this may be a problem that requires the waving of cash to help.  I
know that it'd take me at least a half hour just to stare at all the
relevent code, to ensure there's no "oh duh" factor there.  And that's
generally a lot more than you can expect from a volunteer mailing
list.

I *understand* that it's important to you.  But the fact that you
didn't get an answer on the mod_perl list is the most relevant clue
here: your problem is HARD and will require an EXPERT that's not yet
willing to do it for FREE.

Good luck.  But use the right forum.

--

<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug 22 13:16:37 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 13:16:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
In-Reply-To: <1030046603.2527.105.camel@mikado>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221313410.1924-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 22 Aug 2002, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:

> Ditto to registering a name, but don't underestimate the importance (or
> ease) of incorporation.  It's not a crucial first step, but don't let
> yourself get more than a year or two into being a consultant without
> doing it.  Sole proprietorship is a losing proposition, long term. (IMO,
> YMMV, etc.) 

  Being incorporated 1) implies stability and longevity and 2) gives the
impression of a larger company. A sub-chapter 'S' corporation is ideal for a
single individual.
 
> Also, get an accountant as soon as you make any money at all.  You'll
> need one.

  And find one who knows self-employed, service businesses. I'll recommend
my accountant in Gresham if asked: she's worked for me for eight years and
is worth every penny of her very reasonable rates.
 
> Oddly enough, the very title of a book I was going to recommend.  If you
> get just *one* book on marketing a service business, it should be Harry
> Beckwith's _Selling The Invisible_.

  Yup. After reading too many product-oriented marketing books, this _is_
the one to buy, read, and re-read at least once a year.

Rich

From Ben.Mazhary-Clark at nike.com  Thu Aug 22 13:59:15 2002
From: Ben.Mazhary-Clark at nike.com (Mazhary-Clark, Ben)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 13:59:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] access_log
Message-ID: <DB4CCE75C758D211818F0008C7B140893374275D@beavertn-svr-78.nike.com>

Paul,
If you setup virtual domains in apache and say have the default domain be
something other than your primary all of this logging will go to that domain
log when they hit your IP.  This is how I have mine setup right now.  I
don't know of other solutions except firewall filtering.

Let me know if you want specific examples of the httpd.conf.
--ben

From m at netpro.to  Thu Aug 22 14:15:26 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 14:15:26 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] access_log
In-Reply-To: <20020822135543.62da41d9.paul@pflnet.ws>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208221413170.13202-100000@lukem.com>

grep -v cmd.exe mydomain.log | grep -v root.exe > nicecleanlog.log

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Aug 22 14:51:12 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 14:51:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] HP OfficeJet 600 & samba
References: <000801c24a17$43b5b400$4500000a@SERVANYA>
Message-ID: <3D655CD0.5000008@pacifier.com>

Charlie Schluting wrote:
> Well, I used to do OfficeJet support for HP.
> So, basically what you want to do isn't possible. You cannot fax over
> the network without the HP windows software. But, as far a settings go,
> if you connect it to a windows box, set the distinctive ring or rings to
> answer, and disconnect it from the computer, it will hold the settings. 
> You can also access the parameters menu using *# (press together, then
> release), then push 1,2,3. I don't remember which parameters to change,
> but I could probably get a list. You won't have to mess with that if you
> install the software on a windows box temporarily anyways.
> 
> In order to PC fax, you just have to hope the linux driver will some day
> support that. However, by that time, the false paper jams will probably
> have frustrated you so much that the machine will be in pieces :)
> 
> Oh, on a side note, PC faxing with the windows version cannot be done
> over a network anyways. At least, not with the OJ600.


I'm doing this for a friend and am not familiar with the machine.  He had 
set the distinctive ring once with windows software, but it has since 
"forgot", he didn't think you could do it through the panel--good to know 
that's possible.

So you can't fool windows into thinking it's a local device?

Any recommendations on all-in-one makers/models that work in a mixed linux 
and win environment?


--
Kyle Accardi




From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Aug 22 14:54:23 2002

Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 14:54:23 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] access_log

On Thu, 22 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

Or

  grep -v -E '/(cmd|root)\.exe' access_log > niceclean_log

:-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Aug 22 15:00:02 2002

References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208221413170.13202-100000@lukem.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221451040.25701-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, Aug 22, 2002 at 02:54:23PM -0700, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Thu, 22 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> 
> > grep -v cmd.exe mydomain.log | grep -v root.exe > nicecleanlog.log
> 
> Or
> 
>   grep -v -E '/(cmd|root)\.exe' access_log > niceclean_log

This is probably a linux box, so

grep -v '.exe$' access_log > niceclean_log

would probably work in general, no? :)  Takes care of all
current and future problems with Windows executable files.

Colin



From chordchemist at znet.com  Thu Aug 22 15:03:10 2002
From: chordchemist at znet.com (Lauren Elliott)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 15:03:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SquirrelMail parsing problem
In-Reply-To: <4912.208.151.243.124.1030032488.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
References: <4912.208.151.243.124.1030032488.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <20020822220306.GA13212@znet.com>

> I got squirrel mail working great... :-)
> 
> however... some emails... mainly threaded emails...like the ones here in
> PLUG don't parse within the 30secs before it errors out.
> 
> Any thoughts on what might cause this?
> is there a setting somewhere that might prevent it from erroring out?

Dunno, but increase the max_execution_time variable in your system's
php.ini file.  Works for me (running squirrel for several thousand users
at work, on, er, less than bleeding-edge hardware, I am intimately
familiar with this annoynance =/ ).

-- 
Regards,
Lauren Elliott
chordchemist at znet.com

From cschluti at pdx.edu  Thu Aug 22 16:06:41 2002
From: cschluti at pdx.edu (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 16:06:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] HP OfficeJet 600 & samba
In-Reply-To: <3D655CD0.5000008@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <000b01c24a30$96faa710$4500000a@SERVANYA>

> I'm doing this for a friend and am not familiar with the machine.  He
had
> set the distinctive ring once with windows software, but it has since
> "forgot", he didn't think you could do it through the panel--good to
know
> that's possible.
> 
> So you can't fool windows into thinking it's a local device?
> 

Well, you can install a "generic" driver, like the DJ550c and tell it to
print to the network path of the OJ600, but not faxing. The reason
printing works is because print sharing is enabled on the "server"
computer. Hmmm.....
I'm curious now. If you install a fax driver for the OJ600, then change
the print path to the server i.e. \\server\OJ600  ...and share the fax
driver on the server....it might work. But that doesn't help with the
linux issue.


> Any recommendations on all-in-one makers/models that work in a mixed
linux
> and win environment?

Your best bet is to get a jet-direct print server, and a model that
works with it. You can then scan from any computer on the network using
a web browser. You are still left with no easy way to fax though (from a
linux box). The jetdirect just plugs into the network, and then the
printer. I don't know if you have linux workstations, or if you just
wanted to run this through samba... But, if its all windows
workstations, a jet direct will allow you to print, scan, and PC fax
(send only) from all (windows) computers. From linux boxes, you can
print, scan ...I doubt faxing is possible unless you are really l33t.
You would have to make/modify a fax driver for linux I believe.
The best model is the G85. The scanner rocks. There is the new D series,
but I don't know much about them. 
I'd recommend the jet direct 170x if you only need one parallel port.
They are $150-$170. The G85 can be purchased used for $250.
Disclaimer: I don't work for HP anymore. :)

Hope that helps.
-Charlie




From derek at infotects.com  Thu Aug 22 16:43:04 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 22 Aug 2002 16:43:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Bizarre audio CD player problem
In-Reply-To: <20020822220306.GA13212@znet.com>
References: 
	<4912.208.151.243.124.1030032488.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com> 
	<20020822220306.GA13212@znet.com>
Message-ID: <1030059785.14021.7225.camel@dereklinux>

Hi All,

I'm having some strange behavior when trying to play audio CD's.  The
behavior seems to be dependent on the software (all pre-compiled
debian-sid packages), but it is acting like a hardware problem (PIII
550, 256 Megs, SoundBlaster AWE 64, and a Delta 48x CDROM). On the other
hand, it almost seems like a permissions problem, but not quite.  I'm
just looking for ideas on how to go about troubleshooting this.

As a normal user that is in the disk, audio and video groups

If I use Workman (usually a pretty stable player) it will play the first
5 to 30 seconds of a selected track, then stop and won't start again,
though it still thinks there is an audio CD in the drive.  If I eject
the CD using the software button, then stuff the CD back in, I can play
the first 5 to 30 seconds of a selected track.

If I use FreeAmp, it won't even eject the CD, and it doesn't recognize
that there is a CD in the drive.

If I use XfreeCD, it won't even eject the CD, and it doesn't recognize
that there is a CD in the drive.


As root,

If I use Workman it will play the first 5 to 30 seconds of a selected
track, then stop and won't start again, though it still thinks there is
an audio CD in the drive.  If I eject the CD using the software button,
then stuff the CD back in, I can play the first 5 to 30 seconds of a
selected track.

If I use FreeAmp, (first, I have to eject the CD a couple of times with
the software; until it stops pulling itself back in -- however, this is
behavior for FreeAmp that I've seen on other systems) it will play most
of the tracks most of the way through, some will actually play all the
way through.  There doesn't seem to be a specific cutoff time, but some
of the tracks will just stop playing and the player will move on to the
next track.

XFreeCD plays nicely until about track 9, then it just stopped, claimed
no disk is present, then after sitting for a little, started playing
track 9 again.  It played the entire track 9 and went on to the next and
played to the end, then claimed that no CD was in the drive.

Any ideas?

Derek Loree




From bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph  Thu Aug 22 16:50:58 2002
From: bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph (Billy M Dimaculangan)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 07:50:58 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] POP3
Message-ID: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGGEGBCDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>

Hello to everyone,

	We are running RH7.2 as our mail server.  I would like to ask everyone on
how would I setup a POP3 mail service to be available for public.  In order
for other users to access their mailbox using their own email client
software through other dial-up connection.

	Hope someone could help me with this.

	Thank you and good day!


---
BMD





From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Aug 22 17:00:26 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 17:00:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] POP3
References: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGGEGBCDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <3D657B1A.9050509@dimstar.net>

Billy M Dimaculangan wrote:

>	We are running RH7.2 as our mail server.  I would like to ask everyone on
>how would I setup a POP3 mail service to be available for public.  In order
>for other users to access their mailbox using their own email client
>software through other dial-up connection.
>
There may be a pop3 server already installed. Run ntsysv and if it's 
installed, you'll be able to see it in the list. If it is, you can 
enable it by putting an 'X' in the box, save your changes and exit. Then 
to start it, run '/etc/init.d/xinetd restart'.

Russ




From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Aug 22 17:23:28 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 17:23:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Bizarre audio CD player problem
In-Reply-To: <1030059785.14021.7225.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221720130.8951-100000@critter.deatech.com>

Your description sounds like maybe some other program is accessing
the drive at the same time you are trying to play the CD.  Is it possible
that there is some automatic program configured to run when you insert a
CD (detect disk type, mount the disk, play the music, etc.)?

From derek at infotects.com  Thu Aug 22 17:47:09 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 22 Aug 2002 17:47:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Bizarre audio CD player problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221720130.8951-100000@critter.deatech.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221720130.8951-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <1030063629.14011.7299.camel@dereklinux>

On Thu, 2002-08-22 at 17:23, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
> 
> Your description sounds like maybe some other program is accessing
> the drive at the same time you are trying to play the CD.  Is it possible
> that there is some automatic program configured to run when you insert a
> CD (detect disk type, mount the disk, play the music, etc.)?

Good question.  As far as I know, there is no such critter.  I don't use
Gnome or KDE (blackbox is so much faster) and I haven't installed
anything that would do that.  The relevant line from fstab reads:

/dev/cdrom      /cdrom          iso9660 defaults,ro,user,noauto        
0       0

The noauto part should disable any attempts at auto mounting, if I read
the manual correctly.  Is there somewhere else such a beast may be
lurking?

Derek

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Aug 22 19:32:02 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 19:32:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] access_log
In-Reply-To: <20020822150001.E26468@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221929000.5718-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Thu, 22 Aug 2002, Colin Kuskie wrote:

> This is probably a linux box, so
> 
> grep -v '.exe$' access_log > niceclean_log
> 
> would probably work in general, no? :)

Since the '.exe' wouldn't end the line, no. This would probably work:

  grep -v -E '\.exe\>' access_log

where the \> token functions like \b in Perl.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Subject: [PLUG] Hard drives -- danger?
In-Reply-To: <20020803172325.3b6dad54.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031957210.25325-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

On Sat, 3 Aug 2002, Eli Stair wrote:
> Check to see if you possibly have both your IDE hard disk and your IDE DVD drive
> on the same cable, and both set to master.

Thanks for the help on these issues; I decided to retire the cd drive and
buy a new fan.

Another hardware question for sysadmins; is it okay to stack harddrives
right next to each other? Since I only have two bays there's not much
choice, but there's virtually no space between my two hard drives and it
gets awfully hot there. What happens if hard drives get too hot? Is it
possible in a desktop environment?

Tyler


On Sat, 3 Aug 2002, Eli Stair wrote:

> Come to think of it, after having re-read your problem, and my own response...
> Check to see if you possibly have both your IDE hard disk and your IDE DVD drive
> on the same cable, and both set to master.
>
> Generally if that happens, nothing will work, but depending on the hard drive
> it will sometimes take over and bump off the other device.  Just something
> to check while you're in there.
>
> /eli
>
> On Sat, 3 Aug 2002 17:17:28 -0400
> Eli Stair <eli.stair.lists at attbi.com> wrote:
>
> > > When I boot up, my dvd/cdrom drive yields this error:
> > >
> > > hdd: no response (status = 0x80), resetting drive
> > > hdd: no response (status = 0x80)
> > >
> > > Also pressing the "eject" button on the drive doesn't do anything, yet the
> > > light on the drive is on, indicating power. When I boot into Windows,
> > > the drive isn't recognized either. Any ideas whats wrong with
> > > this DVD drive? I just bought it at Fry's a few months ago...
> >
> > If the drive is seen by the bios, but it won't eject even before an OS takes
> > over, it's toast.  That error message is for your primary IDE HD though, 0x80.
> >
> > > Also one of my fans sometimes starts making a buzzing racket. When you
> > > strike it forcefully it stops buzzing, but this gets old after a while.
> > > Are there any permanent measures that can be taken to hush up this fan?
> >
> > If it stops when you whack it, it's probably your case fan.  If you're handy
> > with a soldering iron you could buy a new one for ~$3 and replace it yourself.
> > Or, buy a new PS for ~$15-30 depending on type and wattage.  Do yourself a
> > favor and fix it somehow before it stops altogether and you flame out :)
> >
> > /eli
> >
> > ________________________________
>

> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From alan at clueserver.org  Thu Aug 22 16:54:46 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 16:54:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drives -- danger?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031957210.25325-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221650500.9122-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Thu, 22 Aug 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

> On Sat, 3 Aug 2002, Eli Stair wrote:
> > Check to see if you possibly have both your IDE hard disk and your IDE DVD drive
> > on the same cable, and both set to master.
> 
> Thanks for the help on these issues; I decided to retire the cd drive and
> buy a new fan.
> 
> Another hardware question for sysadmins; is it okay to stack harddrives
> right next to each other? Since I only have two bays there's not much
> choice, but there's virtually no space between my two hard drives and it
> gets awfully hot there. What happens if hard drives get too hot? Is it
> possible in a desktop environment?

It is possible for them to get too hot.  (Especially if they are a type 
that run hot normally, like the old Seagate Baracudas.)

I had one drive start to hallucinate because of overheating.  It caused 
some "interesting" problems.  (I got a file with a null (0x00) in it. Ted 
Tso was quite amazed over that one...  Took a bit to fix.)

There are fans that you can get that will help cool the drives.  You can 
also get heat sinks and other things to help cool them down.  Many 
computer stores have them. Pacific Solutions on SE Powell is where I get 
them.  Other places may be closer to you.





From mikedela at ipns.com  Fri Aug 23 01:21:03 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 01:21:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drives -- danger?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221650500.9122-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <MI75MKPKJNKSR1T72XS11U1VOMRQJH.3d65f06f@miked>

I wouldn't stack two right next to each other if I could avoid it at all. You 
might try a 5.25" to 3.5" adapter to mount a drive in a CD-Rom drive space. I do 
that a lot. Most PC stores have these gizmos if you ask.

Mike

From bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph  Fri Aug 23 01:28:01 2002
From: bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph (Billy M Dimaculangan)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 16:28:01 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] POP3
In-Reply-To: <3D657B1A.9050509@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGMEGMCDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>

The pop3 service only have private subnet address.  Can I make it available
for public use, in order for other users to access their mail using MS
Outlook when they're out of the country.

Hope you can help me

Thank and good day.

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On
Behalf Of Russ Johnson
Sent: Friday, August 23, 2002 8:00 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] POP3

Billy M Dimaculangan wrote:

>       We are running RH7.2 as our mail server.  I would like to ask
everyone on
>how would I setup a POP3 mail service to be available for public.  In order
>for other users to access their mailbox using their own email client
>software through other dial-up connection.
>
There may be a pop3 server already installed. Run ntsysv and if it's
installed, you'll be able to see it in the list. If it is, you can
enable it by putting an 'X' in the box, save your changes and exit. Then
to start it, run '/etc/init.d/xinetd restart'.

Russ


_______________________________________________
PLUG mailing list
PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug




From aj at haightmail.org  Fri Aug 23 04:48:03 2002
From: aj at haightmail.org (Aj Lavin)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 04:48:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A training cooperative?
In-Reply-To: <1030084068.29806.470.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208030756190.23746-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <1030084068.29806.470.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <20020823114803.GE624@zappa>

On Thu, Aug 22, 2002 at 11:27:48PM -0700, Jon Jacob wrote:
> 
> I am not sure that putting up a web page would help much, but if you
> want to start something that would be cool.  My hope was that it would
> grow organically.  No plan, but just people taking the initiative.
> 
> However, if someone wants to make things more formal, I would support
> that.

Hello Linux fans,

The co-op sounds like a very cool idea. 

You should consider using the (free) Xenternet community service to
organize it. I made Xenternet precisely for this sort of thing.

At www.xenternet.com, you can create an online community that has its
own threaded discussion board, events calendar, and news
articles. There is a 3 level moderation system. Group access can be
made public or private. Pictures with captions can be attached to all
content.

For example, check out the Portland Tech events calendar:

http://www.xenternet.com/calendar_show.php?groupid=44

Also check out the screen shots at:

http://www.ajlavin.com/products.php

If you require additional functionality I might be interested to
implement it.

Xenternet was made using PHP, PostgreSQL, XML, and XSLT, and runs
under Apache on Linux 2.4.

- Aj



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Aug 23 06:16:02 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 06:16:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drives -- danger?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031957210.25325-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208230615060.6571-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 22 Aug 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

> Another hardware question for sysadmins; is it okay to stack harddrives
> right next to each other? Since I only have two bays there's not much
> choice, but there's virtually no space between my two hard drives and it
> gets awfully hot there. What happens if hard drives get too hot? Is it
> possible in a desktop environment?
 
Tyler,

  That's the way many cases are designed. If the case has places for extra
fans (in addition to the power supply and CPU), put them in there.

Rich





From raanders at acm.org  Fri Aug 23 06:55:24 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 06:55:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drives -- danger?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208031957210.25325-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208230645390.28165-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Thu, 22 Aug 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

> Another hardware question for sysadmins; is it okay to stack harddrives
> right next to each other?

Tyler,

As mentioned in another message think about mounting them, or at least one
of them, in the 5 1/4" bays.  Also well worth the money are bay coolers
(CyberGuys.Com).  These are for 5 1/4" bays and have two or three fans and
a dust filter on the front.  Be sure to sufficient exhaust fans also.  
Getting more air in than is going out is just pressurized heat.  :-)


Rod

> Since I only have two bays there's not much choice, but there's
> virtually no space between my two hard drives and it gets awfully hot
> there. What happens if hard drives get too hot? Is it possible in a
> desktop environment?

Oh yeah!  I you're running a pretty hot system system, 1+ GHz, fast video
card, etc. you should also look at putting in round drive cables verses
the flat cables normally using in desktop systems.  (Again CyberGuys.Com  
:-)  They will let the air flow much better and help prevent hot spots in 
the case where the flat cables could force air to circulate in a small 
area.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."




From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Fri Aug 23 07:53:12 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (Robby Russell)

Subject: [PLUG] SquirrelMail parsing problem
In-Reply-To: <h19ols.55b@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <4912.208.151.243.124.1030032488.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
        <mailman.1030053981.5125.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
        <h19ols.55b@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <4536.208.151.243.124.1030114392.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>

I did some snooping...and testing all the plugins in squirrelmail.
apparently it was the address_add plugin.

Someone else on the squirrelmail list had that problem...no known fixes
yet. I just disabled the plugin... works fine now...
it would get stuck on url parsing...

-Robby

Wil Cooley said:
> Lauren Elliott wrote:
>
>>> I got squirrel mail working great... :-)
>>>
>>> however... some emails... mainly threaded emails...like the ones here
>>> in PLUG don't parse within the 30secs before it errors out.
>>>
>>> Any thoughts on what might cause this?
>>> is there a setting somewhere that might prevent it from erroring out?
>>
>> Dunno, but increase the max_execution_time variable in your system's
>> php.ini file.  Works for me (running squirrel for several thousand
>> users at work, on, er, less than bleeding-edge hardware, I am
>> intimately familiar with this annoynance =/ ).
>
> Might also try one of the PHP optimizers or byte-code caches...
>
> Wil

From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Fri Aug 23 08:25:46 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 08:25:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SquirrelMail parsing problem
In-Reply-To: <4536.208.151.243.124.1030114392.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
References: <4912.208.151.243.124.1030032488.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
        <mailman.1030053981.5125.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
        <h19ols.55b@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
        <4536.208.151.243.124.1030114392.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <4665.208.151.243.124.1030116346.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>

I found that I could use abook_take plugin instead of the address_add
plugin. It scans through every email address in the email and lets you add
any one of them to your address book.
....and it doesn't give me a parsing timeout error. :-)

Hope that helps for anyone who may be using squirrelmail...or are
considering it. I really like this application.

-me again

Robby Russell said:
> I did some snooping...and testing all the plugins in squirrelmail.
> apparently it was the address_add plugin.
>
> Someone else on the squirrelmail list had that problem...no known fixes
> yet. I just disabled the plugin... works fine now...
> it would get stuck on url parsing...
>
> -Robby
>
> Wil Cooley said:
>> Lauren Elliott wrote:
>>
>>>> I got squirrel mail working great... :-)
>>>>
>>>> however... some emails... mainly threaded emails...like the ones
>>>> here in PLUG don't parse within the 30secs before it errors out.
>>>>
>>>> Any thoughts on what might cause this?
>>>> is there a setting somewhere that might prevent it from erroring
>>>> out?
>>>
>>> Dunno, but increase the max_execution_time variable in your system's
>>> php.ini file.  Works for me (running squirrel for several thousand
>>> users at work, on, er, less than bleeding-edge hardware, I am
>>> intimately familiar with this annoynance =/ ).
>>
>> Might also try one of the PHP optimizers or byte-code caches...
>>

From bjh at avalongroup.net  Fri Aug 23 08:49:44 2002
From: bjh at avalongroup.net (Brian Hoag)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 08:49:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] POP3
In-Reply-To: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGMEGMCDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <NGBBLJPCILJHOGABMALBMEKICLAA.bjh@avalongroup.net>

If you have a firewall to a broadband connection, just redirect port 110
from the public IP to the private IP.  This should allow access from outside
the private network.  There may be some security issues to deal with but it
works.

Brian Hoag
Group Avalon Technology Services, Inc.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
> [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Billy M Dimaculangan
> Sent: Friday, August 23, 2002 1:28 AM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: RE: [PLUG] POP3
>
>
> The pop3 service only have private subnet address.  Can I make it
> available
> for public use, in order for other users to access their mail using MS
> Outlook when they're out of the country.
>
> Hope you can help me
>
> Thank and good day.
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
> [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On
> Behalf Of Russ Johnson
> Sent: Friday, August 23, 2002 8:00 AM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: Re: [PLUG] POP3
>
> Billy M Dimaculangan wrote:
>
> >       We are running RH7.2 as our mail server.  I would like to ask
> everyone on
> >how would I setup a POP3 mail service to be available for
> public.  In order
> >for other users to access their mailbox using their own email client
> >software through other dial-up connection.
> >
> There may be a pop3 server already installed. Run ntsysv and if it's
> installed, you'll be able to see it in the list. If it is, you can
> enable it by putting an 'X' in the box, save your changes and exit. Then
> to start it, run '/etc/init.d/xinetd restart'.
>
> Russ
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug




From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Aug 23 09:09:27 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 09:09:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drives -- danger?
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208230645390.28165-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <3D665E37.1010109@sun.com>

You might also take a look at a new case - in particular one of those 
Luan Lui (or whatever they're named) all-aluminum cases.  I believe they 
have two 60mm fans in the front of the case, and the HD's are mounted 
directly behind them, with a 1-2mm space between the drives for airflow. 
  I don't have one myself, but a friend of mine showed me his, and it 
looked pretty slick.

Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> 
> Oh yeah!  I you're running a pretty hot system system, 1+ GHz, fast video
> card, etc. you should also look at putting in round drive cables verses
> the flat cables normally using in desktop systems.  (Again CyberGuys.Com  
> :-)  They will let the air flow much better and help prevent hot spots in 
> the case where the flat cables could force air to circulate in a small 
> area.

Another option would be to take the extreme box builder route from last 
year and route the cables so that they run flat against the MB side of 
the case.  If you don't want to spend the $$ on the round cables, 
anyway.  ;)

I've got one fan in the front of my case bringing in cool air, and the 
PS + an 80mm at the back sucking out the hot.  Unfortunately the box is 
in a corner, so it gets pretty warm - took me a while to get it so that 
it wouldn't lock up due to overheating on moderately warm days.

-R




From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Fri Aug 23 09:28:50 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (E. Rogan Creswick)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 09:28:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: case heat / tyan mpx sensors (was: Re: [PLUG] Hard drives -- danger?
In-Reply-To: <3D665E37.1010109@sun.com>

Lian Li cases are pretty nice :) it's a bit eerie having a metal case that
is warm to the touch, but they are very well made and look spectacular.

On a related note, has anyone been able to get the onboard heat sensors to
work on a tyan tiger MPX mobo? I'm dying to see what temp. my cpu's are
pushing, but lmsensors dosen't appear to support this chipset. (or I've
overlooked something).

Thanks :)
Rogan

Okay, here goes:
 o Recurring events
 o Able to schedule not only first/second/third day, but also first & last 
(webcal doesn't have 'last', which makes scheduling PTP and PACUG 
difficult).
 o Click on date to add event, instead of selecting 'New Event' and trying 
to remember the date.
 o Export in RDF, so Evolution, websites, etc can get a feed from the 
calendar.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Aug 23 10:17:53 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 10:17:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drives -- danger?
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208230645390.28165-100000@main.cyber-office.net> <mailman.1030119051.3255.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <h1b41u.edg@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Richard Langis wrote:

> You might also take a look at a new case - in particular one of those
> Luan Lui (or whatever they're named) all-aluminum cases.  I believe they
> have two 60mm fans in the front of the case, and the HD's are mounted
> directly behind them, with a 1-2mm space between the drives for airflow.
>   I don't have one myself, but a friend of mine showed me his, and it
> looked pretty slick.

You might also take a look at the cases from Enermax or Antec.  They have 
some cases that I'm told are just rebranded by them but with their very 
good power supplies.  They come stock with several fans, with slots for 
several more and they're thermal-controlled, so they slow down when the 
temp is low enough.  I just built a mail server for a customer with an 
Antec PLUS880 (http://www.antec-inc.com/en_plus860.html) and it's very 
nice.  The drive bays have a latch and click out and have a space for a fan 
mount.  I added a fan and the 2 10,000 RPM Ultra160 Seagate Cheetahs stay 
very cool.

PC Club on 82nd (I believe there is one in the west somewhere too) carries 
the Enermax cases which are very high-quality like the Antec and some of 
the aluminum ones.

BTW, PC Heidens has gone out of business.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *



From smathews at pcez.com  Fri Aug 23 11:29:52 2002
From: smathews at pcez.com (stuart mathews)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 10:29:52 -800
Subject: [PLUG] Network snag
Message-ID: <3d667110.7be6.0@pcez.com>

I apparantly forgot how to get a Linux box to connect to the Internet, am seeking
counsel to get my box back online.

I reinstalled Red Hat 7.2, and now can't reach the Internet (not a HUGE shock!).


I can successfully ping 127.0.0.0.1 but attempts to ping my default gw or even
"localhost" generates a "Network is unreachable" message.

I am pretty sure I have /etc/hosts and resolv.conf set correctly.

This file currently looks like  /etc/sysconfig/network:

NETWORKING=yes
HOSTNAME=(my hostname...)
GATEWAY=(my ISP's default gw here...)


And /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts

ONBOOT=yes
BOOTPROTO=static
IPADDR=(my IP address here...)
NETMASK=255.255.255.0
GATEWAY=(my ISP's default gw here...)
BROADCAST=(not 100% certain what this should look like)
NETWORK=(should this be my default gw with a .255 at the end?)
USERCTL=no

What am I overlooking?

-------------------
http://www.pcez.com

> I apparantly forgot how to get a Linux box to connect to the Internet, am
seeking
> counsel to get my box back online.
>
> I reinstalled Red Hat 7.2, and now can't reach the Internet (not a HUGE
shock!).
>
>
> I can successfully ping 127.0.0.0.1 but attempts to ping my default gw or
even
> "localhost" generates a "Network is unreachable" message.
>
> I am pretty sure I have /etc/hosts and resolv.conf set correctly.
>
> This file currently looks like  /etc/sysconfig/network:
>
> NETWORKING=yes
> HOSTNAME=(my hostname...)
> GATEWAY=(my ISP's default gw here...)
>
>
> And /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts
>
> ONBOOT=yes
> BOOTPROTO=static
> IPADDR=(my IP address here...)
> NETMASK=255.255.255.0
> GATEWAY=(my ISP's default gw here...)

This is fine,  as long as the machine is directly connected to your ISP ( no
firewall box in the middle )

> BROADCAST=(not 100% certain what this should look like)
> NETWORK=(should this be my default gw with a .255 at the end?)

This should be your IPADDR with .255 at the last octect

> USERCTL=no
>
> What am I overlooking?

In pine it appears (although I have yet to test it) that you can scroll
down to the bottom of the message body, and hit enter when it highlights:
[ Note: This message contains email list management information ]

Then you gives you unsubscribe as an option.

> >

> > BOOTPROTO=static
> > IPADDR=(my IP address here...)
> > NETMASK=255.255.255.0
> > GATEWAY=(my ISP's default gw here...)
>

 no
> firewall box in the middle )

> > NETWORK=(should this be my default gw with a .255 at the end?)
>
> This should be your IPADDR with .255 at the last octect
>

Oops,  I mean a 0 as the last octect,  and broadcast will have .255
typically

Like this:
NETWORK=192.168.0.0
BROADCAST=192.168.0.255

What are the results of ifconfig and/or route -n ?


On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 11:29, stuart mathews wrote:
> I apparantly forgot how to get a Linux box to connect to the Internet, am seeking
> counsel to get my box back online.
> 
> I reinstalled Red Hat 7.2, and now can't reach the Internet (not a HUGE shock!).
> 
> 
> I can successfully ping 127.0.0.0.1 but attempts to ping my default gw or even
> "localhost" generates a "Network is unreachable" message.
> 
> I am pretty sure I have /etc/hosts and resolv.conf set correctly.
> 
> This file currently looks like  /etc/sysconfig/network:
> 
> NETWORKING=yes
> HOSTNAME=(my hostname...)
> GATEWAY=(my ISP's default gw here...)
> 
> 
> And /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts
> 
> ONBOOT=yes
> BOOTPROTO=static
> IPADDR=(my IP address here...)
> NETMASK=255.255.255.0
> GATEWAY=(my ISP's default gw here...)
> BROADCAST=(not 100% certain what this should look like)
> NETWORK=(should this be my default gw with a .255 at the end?)
> USERCTL=no
> 
> What am I overlooking?






From derek at infotects.com  Fri Aug 23 10:54:53 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 23 Aug 2002 10:54:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Network snag
In-Reply-To: <3d667110.7be6.0@pcez.com>
References: <3d667110.7be6.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <1030125293.2524.8340.camel@dereklinux>

On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 11:29, stuart mathews wrote:
> I apparantly forgot how to get a Linux box to connect to the Internet, am seeking
> counsel to get my box back online.
> 
> I reinstalled Red Hat 7.2, and now can't reach the Internet (not a HUGE shock!).
> 
> 
> I can successfully ping 127.0.0.0.1 but attempts to ping my default gw or even
> "localhost" generates a "Network is unreachable" message.
> 
> I am pretty sure I have /etc/hosts and resolv.conf set correctly.
> 
> This file currently looks like  /etc/sysconfig/network:
> 
> NETWORKING=yes
> HOSTNAME=(my hostname...)
> GATEWAY=(my ISP's default gw here...)
> 
> 
> And /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts
> 
> ONBOOT=yes
> BOOTPROTO=static
> IPADDR=(my IP address here...)
> NETMASK=255.255.255.0
> GATEWAY=(my ISP's default gw here...)
> BROADCAST=(not 100% certain what this should look like)
> NETWORK=(should this be my default gw with a .255 at the end?)

No, the network is the very start of the address block, not the end. 
With a netmask of 255.255.255.0 the last part of your network should be
a .0 (But, where should I put the period to end the sentence?).  

The Broadcast is the very end of the address block, in this case, it
will be your ip address with .255 on the end.  (Your gateway address
must have the first three parts the same as your ip address.)

HTH

Derek




From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Fri Aug 23 10:54:29 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 23 Aug 2002 10:54:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Network snag
In-Reply-To: <3d667110.7be6.0@pcez.com>
References: <3d667110.7be6.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <1030125270.7102.0.camel@duron>

On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 11:29, stuart mathews wrote:
> I apparantly forgot how to get a Linux box to connect to the Internet, am seeking
> counsel to get my box back online.
> 
> I reinstalled Red Hat 7.2, and now can't reach the Internet (not a HUGE shock!).
> 
> 
> I can successfully ping 127.0.0.0.1 but attempts to ping my default gw or even
> "localhost" generates a "Network is unreachable" message.
> 
> I am pretty sure I have /etc/hosts and resolv.conf set correctly.

Well, is your network card working?  Is its module loaded?  Do an
/sbin/lsmod and look for something that looks like your network card.

-- 
Rob
