From alan at clueserver.org  Fri Aug 23 12:33:13 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 23 Aug 2002 12:33:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] GCC 3.2 and the kernel warning
Message-ID: <1030131193.3355.4.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

Be very careful when you install GCC 3.2.  If you have any kernel
drivers that are provided by a third party, such as nVIDIA drivers, they
must be compiled by GCC 3.2 if the kernel is compiled by GCC 3.2.

This means that if you move to the Redhat 7.3.94 (Null) beta, your
nVIDIA drivers from nVIDIA will no longer load.  They do not have a GCC
3.2 driver set out yet.  I found out about this the hard way.

GCC 3.2 is going to be a rough upgrade for all concerned.







From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Aug 23 12:34:51 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 12:34:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] IPv6 (was: Network snag)
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208231105390.9130-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <1030127661.14011.8398.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <3D668E5B.5090703@sun.com>

Okay, so I apt-get'ed the freenet6 client, got it working, went to the 
freenet6.net page, and got a login and everything is all peachy keen.

Now...why use a ipv6 tunnel?  I looked around the site, but there wasn't 
really any *why* listed for the project.

Granted, ipv6 will be a good thing, but only when *everyone* starts 
using it.  Is the freenet6 project trying to increase awareness and get 
people used to using ipv6 address space so that the transition (when it 
happens) will be seamless, or...?

That said, I either compile in or make a module for ipv6 in every 
install.  Now if only my switches and ISP used 'em.  ;)

-R

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Fri Aug 23 13:03:11 2002

itself.  The o key sometimes stopps working until I slam down on it
(just the o key) with such force that my finger hurts.  And it is very
clicky.  VERY clicky.  They hear me on the second floor when I type.

So, I'm going to Fry's today oor tomorrow to buy myself a new keyboard! 
Oh, look at that, the o key is repeating just like the i key does.  Are
there any suggestions for a decent keyboard that'll last me a while? 
Sure, keyboards are things most people spend $10 on and never worry
about, but I want a decent keyboard that'll last me another six years.

:::looks in wallet:::

$27 there, and somebody owes me $10 cash, so the budget for this
adventure is $37.  I require the oversized (2.5 keys length?) backspace
key and under the enter key need it set up like:

/ SHIFT (1.5 keys length?) \

Not any of those with the \ key hidden somewhere.  I also need my
Windows key between CTRL and ALT on the left side.  I don't care about
much else... I woudl think the winkey placement is standard now,
though.  I want a *real* keyboard, too, not one of those Microsoftian
'contour' ones.  Flat and straight, please.  :-)

Do y'all have Keyboard buying tips/suggestions/good brands?  I would
definitely appreciate some input!

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Fri Aug 23 13:06:52 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)

On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 12:33, Alan wrote:
> Be very careful when you install GCC 3.2.  If you have any kernel
> drivers that are provided by a third party, such as nVIDIA drivers, they
> must be compiled by GCC 3.2 if the kernel is compiled by GCC 3.2.
> 
> This means that if you move to the Redhat 7.3.94 (Null) beta, your
> nVIDIA drivers from nVIDIA will no longer load.  They do not have a GCC
> 3.2 driver set out yet.  I found out about this the hard way.

Ok... question....

Do the nVidia drivers not compile or something?  They are literally the
easiest compile out there.  Even if there were modules available
(precompiled) for my distro, I certainly wouldn't use them as they take
about three seconds to compile and install.

Was your only problem that the precompiled drivers won't work or that
you couldn't get the tarballs to compile?

That's interesting that GCC 3.2 does that to the kernel.  I wonder why
it is.  Off the top of my head, I can't think of a single reason why
that might be.... oh well.

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"




From shahms at shahms.com  Fri Aug 23 13:13:23 2002
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms E. King)
Date: 23 Aug 2002 13:13:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] GCC 3.2 and the kernel warning
In-Reply-To: <1030133212.7643.11.camel@duron>
References: <1030131193.3355.4.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>
	 <1030133212.7643.11.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <1030133603.20975.21.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

You're not actually compiling the driver.  The driver itself is shipped
precompiled and the "compiling" you're doing is only of the external
interface; the code that depends on kernel symbols.

--Shahms

On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 13:06, AthlonRob wrote:

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Fri Aug 23 13:21:20 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 13:21:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)
In-Reply-To: <1030132991.7643.7.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208231311150.10136-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Avoid any keyboards with quiet touch in the name.  Dell makes some like
that and they last about 6 months not years.

Logitech makes keyboards that I really like.  Nice feel and I assume that
with logitech they would last a long time, I know their mice do.  I don't
know how well X supports all the extra buttons, so you could save some
money by getting one of the more "basic" logitech models.

IBM keyboards are loud but they probably last the longest.  I bet that's
what you had :)

Generally, I have been pleased with generic low end cheap-o keyboards.
The one I've had for the last 3 years cost me $4 and it is pretty much a
generic keyboard.  Dell, compaq, packard bell, and microsoft keyboards are
crap almost always.  The other nice thing about cheap keyboards is that
they often allow you to remove the keycaps more easily than the expensive
ones.  This is a useful trait if you plan to learn to type in dvorak (I
HIGHLY recommend doing so if you type for 1 hour/day or more, check here
http://www.engr.orst.edu/~dagit for instructions).  Also, radio shack
currently has an "interesting" keyboard for sell.  It is indestructable
according to them.  You should try it out, definitely try before you buy.
It is one piece of clear rubber, and strange to type on, but should last a
long time.

It's refreshing to see someone else that cares as much about the keyboard
they use as I do...

Jason

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Aug 23 13:24:03 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 13:24:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)
In-Reply-To: <1030132991.7643.7.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208231315320.7224-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 23 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> I think, however, that it is time for a new keyboard.  The i key repeats
> itself.  The o key sometimes stopps working until I slam down on it
> (just the o key) with such force that my finger hurts.  And it is very
> clicky.  VERY clicky.  They hear me on the second floor when I type.

> Do y'all have Keyboard buying tips/suggestions/good brands?  I would
> definitely appreciate some input!

  About three weeks ago I replace my old Gateway omni-key board (the one
with the function keys on the left -- where they belong -- rather than on
the top) because it, too, had a malfunctioning key. I considered getting a
Happy Hacker keyboard, but decided the price was too high. So, I went to
Office Depot.

  For $11 (maybe it was $12) I have a Belkin keyboard that has the specs you
listed. It works just fine, but I doubt that it, or any other keyboard for
that matter, will last six years. I remapped the caps lock and control keys
so they'd be where they belong, and the control key is already a teeny bit
sticky.

  I realized that I don't use function keys too often in linux, but I sure
use the ctrl key a lot so having the former out of the way on the top is not
too bad (I'll eventually get used to it). My solution was to buy cheap and
plan on replacing more frequently.

Rich




From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Aug 23 13:55:53 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)

Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)

Rich Shepard wrote:
> For $11 (maybe it was $12) I have a Belkin keyboard that has the specs you
> listed. It works just fine, but I doubt that it, or any other keyboard for
> that matter, will last six years.

I hate to say it, but my MS Natural keyboard is going on 8 years now. I 
bought it in 1994 when they first came out because my hands were hurting 
after typing. My hands no longer hurt during or after typing, and the 
keyboard is still functioning perfectly. Some of the keycaps have lost 
parts of the letters due to wear, but they still work right.

-- 
Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net


1 + 1 = 3, for large values of 1





From mike at computer-arts.net  Fri Aug 23 13:56:07 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)

shift keys so they both moved like a typewriter and very deeply sculpted 
keys, miss that one.

From mike at computer-arts.net  Fri Aug 23 14:05:21 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 14:05:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
References: <mailman.1030048581.32560.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <3D66A391.4F37EF57@computer-arts.net>

Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
> On 22 Aug 2002, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:
> 
> > Ditto to registering a name, but don't underestimate the importance (or
> > ease) of incorporation.  It's not a crucial first step, but don't let
> > yourself get more than a year or two into being a consultant without
> > doing it.  Sole proprietorship is a losing proposition, long term. (IMO,
> > YMMV, etc.)
> 
>   Being incorporated 1) implies stability and longevity and 2) gives the
> impression of a larger company. A sub-chapter 'S' corporation is ideal for a
> single individual.

Just curious if you guys have had specific experiences where you
lost work (or whatever) because of not being incorporated. I almost
incorporated (as opposed to sole proprietorship) a couple of years
ago. My accountant advised against it at that time just because it
made it a little bit harder to move money back and forth between
me and the business (and he didn't see any advantage.)

I planned to incorporate the first time I actually *lost* a contract
because of being a sole proprietorship. Even though a number of people
have told me they wouldn't hire me if I wasn't incorporated, every
time (so far :-) this has turned out to be *wrong* and the contract
went through.  The issue generally turned out to be EAO and Liability
insurance, which I have (1M), and of course a separate Federal Tax
ID for the business.

Since business is pretty bad right now, I'm kind of curious whether
or not there is something to this, and just looking for more info.

-Mike

probably go with a Logitech... however much Logitech $37 can get me.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Aug 23 14:50:08 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 14:50:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
In-Reply-To: <3D66A391.4F37EF57@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208231440410.7329-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Mike Witt wrote:

> Just curious if you guys have had specific experiences where you lost work
> (or whatever) because of not being incorporated. I almost incorporated (as
> opposed to sole proprietorship) a couple of years ago. My accountant
> advised against it at that time just because it made it a little bit
> harder to move money back and forth between me and the business (and he
> didn't see any advantage.)

Mike,

  This cannot be measured. If you don't get a project it's almost impossible
to learn the real reason why.

  Regarding moving money around: that's no problem at all. Set up an account
for your S-corporation distributions and you can write yourself checks
whenever you like. It's very clean -- as far as the IRS and state are
concerned. Functionally, the money's yours, but by keeping it in two
different pockets you can legitimately charge business expenses without
anyone thinking they're personal. Unless, of course, you're from Enron,
Adelphia, WorldCom, ....
 
> I planned to incorporate the first time I actually *lost* a contract
> because of being a sole proprietorship. Even though a number of people
> have told me they wouldn't hire me if I wasn't incorporated, every
> time (so far :-) this has turned out to be *wrong* and the contract
> went through.  The issue generally turned out to be EAO and Liability
> insurance, which I have (1M), and of course a separate Federal Tax
> ID for the business.

  It cost less than $100 to incorporate and get official registration. You
lose the home office deduction on your personal taxes but you gain business
expense and other deductions on that side.

  When you go looking for a professional, can you list all the criteria --
honestly -- that you apply? There's a lot of subjective, emotional aspects
to our decisions and a little thing like an "Inc.", "LLC", "PC" after your
business name may make that difference.

  If you can quantify the number of people who did not call you because you
were not incorporated you'd have a solid basis for making a decision. :-)

> Since business is pretty bad right now, I'm kind of curious whether
> or not there is something to this, and just looking for more info.

  Every edge helps. Ask yourself this question: Why should someone hire me,
rather than a competitor? 

Rich

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Fri Aug 23 15:48:51 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 15:48:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)
In-Reply-To: <1030137080.7643.34.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208231523240.11029-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> Naw, I type with QWERTY and QWERTY alone.  I type on *way* too many
> computers to learn a different typing style.  I do PC repair type stuff
> in my free time.

s:/QWERTY/Microsoft
s:/typing style/operating system

This argument sounds familar... :)

The issue can be condensed to what is called "exploration vs.
exploitation" in AI research; does an intelligent agent devote time to
learning and performing optimally, or just try to do well with what he
already knows?

You see this conflict reflected in many ways; some people explore too
much, devoting excess time to learning instead of getting the job done,
whereas others exploit too much and try to do stuff without adequate
preparation. I guess a balance is best.

Most gnu/linux users, I think, are "exploratory", and devote a lot of time
to learning; conversely in my college CS classes the majority of students
suffer from being too "exploitative".

So anyway, if you argue against Dvorak for being non-standard and
difficult to learn, don't complain about Windows users making the same
argument... the underlying action is choosing exploitation (getting
the job done, poorly) over exploration (learning how to do it better).

PS: Like Linux/Windows, it is possible to learn both Qwerty and Dvorak! :)


Tyler


-----------------------------
Tyler F. Creelan
College of Engineering
Oregon State University
503-618-3101
-----------------------------

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Aug 23 15:57:58 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 15:57:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
In-Reply-To: <3D66A391.4F37EF57@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208231502100.15866-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Mike Witt wrote:

[snip]
> Just curious if you guys have had specific experiences where you
> lost work (or whatever) because of not being incorporated. I almost
> incorporated (as opposed to sole proprietorship) a couple of years
> ago. My accountant advised against it at that time just because it
> made it a little bit harder to move money back and forth between
> me and the business (and he didn't see any advantage.)

Some reasons to incorporate (based on my experience):

  1 - If you ever get work through an agency/job shop, some of them will
      only take you on as either an employee of the agency (W-2), or on a
      corp-to-corp basis (some require various types of insurance as
      well, but some don't).  I have personally encountered a number of
      agency based jobs where a sole proprietorship was out of the
      question, and I have had a couple of customers who might not have
      hired me if I hadn't been incorporated (I can't say for sure, they
      were seriously concerned about the contractor tax issue but since
      I was incorporated, after some discussion they went ahead with
      hiring me).  Some agencies won't even do corp-to-corp though
      these seem to be getting fewer.

  2 - Some companies will only hire through a corporation (yours or an
      agency) in order to try and head off any claims by the IRS that you
      are their employee, followed by a big tax bill and fines.

  3 - Some tax deductions are much easier/safer to take as a corporation
      than as a sole proprietorship.  Some deductions may only be
      available to you as a corporation.

  4 - If you are making a large income from your business, or wildly
      varying income from one year to the next, you can often save a
      large amount of money in taxes if you set things up correctly.

  5 - Liability!!  As a sole proprietor, if you are sued over your work,
      everything you own is up for grabs, so you can lose your house, car,
      bike, and latest Linux CD's :-)  As a corporation, so long as you
      are careful to follow all the rules and keep a strict separation
      between your business and personal life/finances/etc., it is
      very difficult for anyone to successfully go after your personal
      assets as a result of things you did for them through your
      corporation.  There are some exceptions (like theft), but done
      right, you should be pretty safe.

NOTE: If you do decide to incorporate, you will almost certainly want to
      look into Subchapter S tax classification.

Some reasons not to incorporate:

  1 - Alot more paperwork (a good accountant can relieve you of some, but
      not all of it).


My personal feeling is that unless you have liability concerns, if your
business net and salary/wages from the business are less that $10,000 a
year, it's probably not worth it, but once you start getting into the
$30,000 and beyond range, the tax differences can become really
significant.  If you are doing this as a sideline and have a full-time job
as well (or your wife does if you are married), incorporating may be
worthwhile at significantly lower business income levels, because you will
presumably already be in a higher tax bracket from your other income.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Fri Aug 23 16:44:38 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 23 Aug 2002 16:44:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221150450.1924-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <mailman.1030046422.29859.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86wuqhdtsp.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Dylan" == Dylan Reinhardt <plug at dylanreinhardt.com> writes:

Dylan> Ditto to registering a name, but don't underestimate the
Dylan> importance (or ease) of incorporation.  It's not a crucial
Dylan> first step, but don't let yourself get more than a year or two
Dylan> into being a consultant without doing it.

The advice I've gotten is basically:

1) If you're doing it for tax purposes, you'll usually wind up
as a S-corp anyway, so the tax benefit is nearly nil.

2) If you're doing it to limit liability, you can't protect things
*you* do personally behind a corporate shield.  If you have others
working with you, then yes, a corp prevents you from personally
biting for their stupidity, but nothing is going to prevent you
from being responsible for *your* actions.

Take that as you wish.  I wasn't inc'ed until I had others flying
under the Stonehenge banner.  I was a sole-prop for about 10 years.

--

On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 15:48, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> > Naw, I type with QWERTY and QWERTY alone.  I type on *way* too many
> > computers to learn a different typing style.  I do PC repair type stuff
> > in my free time.
> 
> s:/QWERTY/Microsoft
> s:/typing style/operating system
>

Not to me.

1)  DVORAK works in most any operating system, including PalmOS which
doesn't even use a keyboard by default.
2)  Learning Linux would essentially have no effect on Windows usage,
minus the occaisional cp instead of copy while learning DVORAK well
could have quite an effect on my use of systems set up for QWERTY.

<snip>

> So anyway, if you argue against Dvorak for being non-standard and
> difficult to learn, don't complain about Windows users making the same
> argument... the underlying action is choosing exploitation (getting
> the job done, poorly) over exploration (learning how to do it better).

I'm not arguing against DVORAK at all.  I'm simply saying I'm not going
to learn it right now as it would take keyboard fixing (I'm not going to
learn to type on a keyboard by hitting the WRONG letters), and basic
training.  Right now, with QWERTY, if I think I, I hit I.  If I learned
to do the same with DVORAK, I would have to think I, think DVORAK or
QWERTY? and then hit the proper I.  Because I *do* work on many systems
set up for QWERTY, I cannot justify hampering my QWERTY-skills by
learning a new keyboard/typing style because three people say it works
better.

> PS: Like Linux/Windows, it is possible to learn both Qwerty and Dvorak! :)

It is possible to run both Linux and Windows, looking like Linux or
Windows, on the same (single) computer, thoough.  It isn't possible to
have both a QWERTY and DVORAK keymap on the same keyboard, though, is
it?  If you switch from one to the other, your keys will look wrong,
unless you pry each of them off and put it in the proper place (except I
noticed A was in the same place).

No thank you.

And why am I defending my typing style here?  Sheesh.  :-)

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Fri Aug 23 16:47:50 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 23 Aug 2002 16:47:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
References: <mailman.1030143682.6695.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86sn15dtnd.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Shannon" == Shannon C Dealy <dealy at deatech.com> writes:

Shannon>   5 - Liability!!  As a sole proprietor, if you are sued over your work,
Shannon>       everything you own is up for grabs, so you can lose your house, car,
Shannon>       bike, and latest Linux CD's :-)  As a corporation, so long as you
Shannon>       are careful to follow all the rules and keep a strict separation
Shannon>       between your business and personal life/finances/etc., it is
Shannon>       very difficult for anyone to successfully go after your personal
Shannon>       assets as a result of things you did for them through your
Shannon>       corporation.  There are some exceptions (like theft), but done
Shannon>       right, you should be pretty safe.

Careful, this is a myth, according to my sources.  More and more,
even if you are very careful to follow all the rules, there's one
thing that case law has pointed time and time again:

    If *you* do the work, *you* are liable.

Piercing corps to get at the actual actors is routine now.  So,
beware.

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Aug 23 17:23:20 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 17:23:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
In-Reply-To: <86sn15dtnd.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208231713410.16030-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On 23 Aug 2002, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:

> >>>>> "Shannon" == Shannon C Dealy <dealy at deatech.com> writes:
>
> Shannon>   5 - Liability!!  As a sole proprietor, if you are sued over your work,
> Shannon>       everything you own is up for grabs, so you can lose your house, car,
> Shannon>       bike, and latest Linux CD's :-)  As a corporation, so long as you
> Shannon>       are careful to follow all the rules and keep a strict separation
> Shannon>       between your business and personal life/finances/etc., it is
> Shannon>       very difficult for anyone to successfully go after your personal
> Shannon>       assets as a result of things you did for them through your
> Shannon>       corporation.  There are some exceptions (like theft), but done
> Shannon>       right, you should be pretty safe.
>
> Careful, this is a myth, according to my sources.  More and more,
> even if you are very careful to follow all the rules, there's one
> thing that case law has pointed time and time again:
>
>     If *you* do the work, *you* are liable.
>
> Piercing corps to get at the actual actors is routine now.  So,
> beware.

It's not a myth, but it isn't bulletproof either.  In most cases that I
have looked at, the people who got nailed, got it because they did
something to pierce the corporate shield.  Usually this means they did
something illegal, or they mixed business with personal.  I am not
implying that this is the only way, sometimes all it takes is a bad judge
or a lousy attourney,  In either case, you are still MUCH safer as a
corporation than a sole proprietorship, since as a corporation the law
assumes that you are not personally liable until proven otherwise, where
as a sole proprietorship, the law assumes you are personally liable, no
proof required.

                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Aug 23 17:32:27 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 17:32:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
In-Reply-To: <86wuqhdtsp.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

On 23 Aug 2002, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:

[snip]
>
> 1) If you're doing it for tax purposes, you'll usually wind up
> as a S-corp anyway, so the tax benefit is nearly nil.

This depends on how much money the corporation makes, how much you pay
yourself as salary and a variety of other things that are mostly up to
the person running the corporation (within certain limits).  I have saved
an enormous amount of money in taxes since switching from sole
proprietorship to S corporation.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Aug 23 17:43:49 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 23 Aug 2002 17:43:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] GCC 3.2 and the kernel warning
In-Reply-To: <1030145625.4704.2.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208231321160.19378-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Aug 23 17:59:30 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 17:59:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208231713410.16030-100000@critter.deatech.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208231713410.16030-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <200208231759.30369.aschlemm@attbi.com>

My wife looked into what was involved with incorporation. It seemed like 
the most popular state is Delaware from what I recall. They have fairly 
lax rules governing corporations with regard to board meetings and a 
bunch of other stuff. I've worked for several small companies on the 
west coast over the years and they were all incorporated in Delaware. 
I think you pay some sort of registered agent in Delaware so you 
technically have a office within the state or something to that effect. 

I don't recall how much it cost to incorporate but seemed to be pretty 
cheap and there are a lot of websites put up by agents in Delaware that 
can be used to setup a corporation.

Tony

On Friday 23 August 2002 17:23 pm, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
> On 23 Aug 2002, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> > >>>>> "Shannon" == Shannon C Dealy <dealy at deatech.com> writes:
> >
> > Shannon>   5 - Liability!!  As a sole proprietor, if you are sued
> > over your work, Shannon>       everything you own is up for grabs,
> > so you can lose your house, car, Shannon>       bike, and latest
> > Linux CD's :-)  As a corporation, so long as you Shannon>       are
> > careful to follow all the rules and keep a strict separation
> > Shannon>       between your business and personal
> > life/finances/etc., it is Shannon>       very difficult for anyone
> > to successfully go after your personal Shannon>       assets as a
> > result of things you did for them through your Shannon>      
> > corporation.  There are some exceptions (like theft), but done
> > Shannon>       right, you should be pretty safe.
> >
> > Careful, this is a myth, according to my sources.  More and more,
> > even if you are very careful to follow all the rules, there's one
> > thing that case law has pointed time and time again:
> >
> >     If *you* do the work, *you* are liable.
> >
> > Piercing corps to get at the actual actors is routine now.  So,
> > beware.
>
> It's not a myth, but it isn't bulletproof either.  In most cases that
> I have looked at, the people who got nailed, got it because they did
> something to pierce the corporate shield.  Usually this means they
> did something illegal, or they mixed business with personal.  I am
> not implying that this is the only way, sometimes all it takes is a
> bad judge or a lousy attourney,  In either case, you are still MUCH
> safer as a corporation than a sole proprietorship, since as a
> corporation the law assumes that you are not personally liable until
> proven otherwise, where as a sole proprietorship, the law assumes you
> are personally liable, no proof required.
>

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> I don't recall how much it cost to incorporate but seemed to be pretty 
> cheap and there are a lot of websites put up by agents in Delaware that 
> can be used to setup a corporation.

  Most of us are not so large that the breaks related to Delaware
incorporation are worth while.

  In 1994 my accountant charged me $84 to fill out and file the papers. The
corporate stamp and the bank deposit stamp _were_ expensive. I pay $30 per
year to retain registration with the Corporate Division of the Oregon
Secretary of State's Office.

  Every so often I write up minutes for the annual meeting (which I usually
hold over a cup of coffee some morning when I think of it). I print the
minutes and put them in the corporate binder.

  No big deal.

Rich

From wallywharton at attbi.com  Fri Aug 23 21:41:17 2002
From: wallywharton at attbi.com (Wally Wharton)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 21:41:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)
In-Reply-To: <1030137080.7643.34.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208232110070.24121-100000@dhcp-73-190.attbi.com>

On 23 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

: On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 13:21, Jason Dagit wrote:
:
: > It's refreshing to see someone else that cares as much about the keyboard
: > they use as I do...
:
: Well, if you do a lot of typing, as I do, then you need a good
: keyboard.  If it weren't for my i and o keys, this one would probably
: last me another six years.  :-)
:

If you like the keyboard you have, why not pull it apart, clean it up,
and give it another few years of service?  It might take an hour or
so, but there are worse ways to spend an hour than caring for a
reliable tool.

A bowl of warm, mildly soapy water, a small screwdriver to pry the
keycaps off with, patience, and a sense of meticulousness have helped
when I've done this in the past.  Slosh the keycaps in the bowl of
water, rinse well, and give them plenty of time to dry.  Compressed
air is useful, too.

I wouldn't think twice about doing this for my own keyboard.  Aside
from the avoidable risk of moisture in the electonics, the thing I
should do, but don't, is apply some type of lubricant to the few
moving parts as I reassemble it.  Not knowing what type of grease they
use in the factory, I'd rather leave them dry than apply something to
them that will deteriorate the plastic.

Of course, your mileage may vary.  And a single lost part can render
most of the rest of your efforts moot.

Good luck -

Wally




From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Aug 23 22:26:45 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 22:26:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208232127240.4598-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208232215190.27330-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I agree.  RH is the most successful commercial distro so naturally
> there's a backlash against them, I suppose.  RH has quite a few
> developers on staff and contributes a lot of code to various open
> source projects. But ooooohh...  they're a commercial company so that
> automatically makes them the anti-christ, doesn't it.  Sheesh.

Please don't use the term "anti-christ".  We should not confuse real-world
evil with ancient mythological mumbo jumbo.

Red Hat has taken something truly progressive that could be a gateway into
a new world of abundance and sharing and compromised it down to something
palatable to the Capitalists.

We have already shown that our community yields superior tools available
to a greater number of people than any market could possibly produce, yet
there are those among us who still believe it is necessary to inject
greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation.

Now, Debian has produced far superior software and greater distribution
capacity (and I've yet to hear an argument to the contrary) while still
holding strong to essentially progressive ideals.

J.

References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208231644230.11711-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1030165030.5181.3.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 16:45, Jason Dagit wrote:
> 
> 
> On 23 Aug 2002, Alan wrote:
> 
> > On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 13:22, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > >
> > > On 23 Aug 2002, Alan wrote:
> > > > GCC 3.2 is going to be a rough upgrade for all concerned.
> > >
> > > It shouldn't be too rough for people that don't use non-Free software.
> > >
> > > Let GNU be your guide.
> >
> > The GNU nVIDIA drivers suck.
> 
> Where can I find these?  I would like to try them out, I don't like using
> these infernal closed source drivers...

Change the name of the driver in XF86Config or XF86Config-4 from
"nvidia" to "nv".  You may have to disable the GL extension or reinstall
X due to the NVIDIA_GLX package overwriting the GL code in X.

From kens at cad2cam.com  Fri Aug 23 22:20:45 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 22:20:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Commands to be used avoiding reboot PC
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208232126260.4598-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208232126260.4598-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <200208232220.45700.kens@cad2cam.com>

On Friday 23 August 2002 09:26 pm, Matt Alexander wrote:
> On Sat, 24 Aug 2002, Stephen Liu wrote:
> > At 05:52 PM 8/23/2002 -0700, you wrote:
> > > > 2) XF86Config-4
> > >
> > >   Shut down X, log out, log in, startx.
> >
> > To carry out those commands in Konsole window ???

after editing fstab you may issue the command:  mount -a
this command reads the /etc/fstab file and mounts what is not mounted and 
possible to mount.  If you don't have a floppy in the drive it won't mount 
it.

After editing the XF86Config, exit X.  If you are using xdm or init 5 or X 
login window you must do the init 3 then init 5 to stop X and restart it.
If you had started X from a console window after logging in, then just exit X 
by CTRL-ALT-<backspace>.  This kills the X server and brings you back to the 
text console.  Then just startx.

-- 
Ken Stephens
www.cad2cam.com
www.cadtocam.com



From auto22879 at yahoo.com  Fri Aug 23 22:34:22 2002
From: auto22879 at yahoo.com (Don Baldwin)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 22:34:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
Message-ID: <20020824053422.82132.qmail@web10507.mail.yahoo.com>

 

Gosh:

I have nothing against Red Hat.  I think they have
done a wonderful job since 1994 when I first got
interested in Linux.  Infomagic used to include RH on
their 5 CD sets of Linux.  Red Hat has just grown and
grown and grown.  They make a superior product.  I
haven't tried Slackware for around 6 years or so. 
They used to make a good product, but not to my taste.
 (Thanks, Rob for the offer of a CD of Slackware 8.0) 
The strangest one I tried was Yggdrisal (spelling?). 
I don't believe you can beat Red Hat for ease of
install and automatic detection of hardware.  Things
have come a long way.  

In a lot of ways I am still a fossil.  I like to
tinker and Linux is great for that.  Even if I do buy
the Red Hat distros via an inexpensive alternative
route, I still wind up buying support just like
everyone else when I need it.  I have bought RH 5.1,
6.1 and several earlier distros direct from RH.  I
suppose I could just download the distros via FTP in
an ISO format and burn them.  They are on a lot of
servers.  My CD burner though only supports 650 MB
formats and the ISO's are around 700 Mb (including
Index).  So I find it easier to buy them than I do to
burn them.  (I just don't feel like buying a new
burner.)    

I think it is a good idea to support your favorite
distro and I have done that in the past.  I will do it
again in the future.  We are talking a public product
and there is nothing wrong with getting the distros
anyway you can.  I did send Kevin money for a Kevin's
Red Hat Uber Distribution (KRUD) at www.tummy.com.  It
sounds intersting.

I discovered that you can download an ISO of a boot CD
for Debian and then download the rest of what you need
from the internet.  That is an exciting new way to get
the distribution (for me).  I am going to try it
tonight.  There are a few things I don't like about
Red Hat 7.2 so I am going to try something new.

Thanks for all the response.  I didn't mean to be
stirring up any kind of argument.  I think we all need
to work together for the good of computing in general
and Linux specifically rather than shouting
irresponsibly about one distro or company over other
companies.  Any person or entity who is furthering
Linux is furthering something we all love.  The more
boxes with penguins there are in the world will create
a broader customer base for better software.

Thank you for listening.

Don

that's the way things work in the world economy we currently have.

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Fri Aug 23 23:39:24 2002
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: 23 Aug 2002 23:39:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT, sorta..: consulting question
In-Reply-To: <86wuqhdtsp.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208221150450.1924-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
	<mailman.1030046422.29859.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> 
	<86wuqhdtsp.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <1030171164.3732.250.camel@mikado>

On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 16:44, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> 1) If you're doing it for tax purposes, you'll usually wind up
> as a S-corp anyway, so the tax benefit is nearly nil.

Well... the corp gets taxed at your rate if you're an S corp, but that
doesn't make it a non-benefit.  By splitting your income between two
entities (the corp and you) you can pay a lower rate overall.  Just as
importantly, it becomes a lot easier to avoid the dreaded AltMin tax
when you can split your income.

It's probably the case that there is little tax advantage for household
incomes less than $70-80K.

There are, however, other perks to incorporation, such as the ability to
set up your own 401K, to buy health insurance with pre-tax dollars,
etc.  Again, the benefits scale with income.  If you're not going to
save more than $3K a year, a SEP IRA is all you'll need and a sole prop
can get one of those easily.

> 2) If you're doing it to limit liability, you can't protect things
> *you* do personally behind a corporate shield.

An excellent point.  Making a distinction between the actions of the
principal owner and the actions of the corporation can be subtle and
subject to interpretation. All small biz would do well to be aware that
incorporation does not make one bulletproof nor make one's own assets
untouchable.  

Dylan





From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Fri Aug 23 23:39:03 2002

On 23 Aug 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> because you prefer QWERTY and don't want to learn Dvorak.  Most all of

I don't think any of us were implying that.  MS Luser and QWERTY have no
connection.  In fact the support in windows2000 for dvorak is really good.
You can toggle between them with a keyboard shortcut.

The reason I brought it up in the first place, was that I was just trying
to pass on a cool thing I learned.  Dvorak made my hand aches go away.  I
thought that was worth sharing with other typists.

I'm sorry if my advice has caused anyone to feel inferior or persecuted.
Jason




From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Fri Aug 23 23:42:35 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 23:42:35 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Commands to be used avoiding reboot PC
In-Reply-To: <200208232220.45700.kens@cad2cam.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208232340070.12144-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:

> On Friday 23 August 2002 09:26 pm, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > On Sat, 24 Aug 2002, Stephen Liu wrote:
> > > At 05:52 PM 8/23/2002 -0700, you wrote:
> > > > > 2) XF86Config-4
> > > >
> > > >   Shut down X, log out, log in, startx.
> > >
> > > To carry out those commands in Konsole window ???
>
> after editing fstab you may issue the command:  mount -a
> this command reads the /etc/fstab file and mounts what is not mounted and
> possible to mount.  If you don't have a floppy in the drive it won't mount
> it.

I use mount -a as a trouble shooting tool.  After editing /etc/fstab, run
mount -a and you can basically double check your work. About 99% of the
time you can detect a typo at that time.  Instead of 3 months later when
you upgrade your kernel.

>
> After editing the XF86Config, exit X.  If you are using xdm or init 5 or X
> login window you must do the init 3 then init 5 to stop X and restart it.
> If you had started X from a console window after logging in, then just exit X
> by CTRL-ALT-<backspace>.  This kills the X server and brings you back to the
> text console.  Then just startx.

I would like to add that a lot of setting for X can be expeiremented with
useing xset.  I like to try things out before they go into the config
file.  xset is great for that, most of the time.

HTH,
Jason

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Aug 24 06:46:37 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 06:46:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Commands to be used avoiding reboot PC
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020824120313.00b77148@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208240637530.11339-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 24 Aug 2002, Stephen Liu wrote:

> >   Shut down X, log out, log in, startx.
> 
> To carry out those commands in Konsole window ???

Stephen,

  I've no idea. I've never run KDE and I'm completely unfamiliar with all
its toys and gadgets.

  The only X desktop I've run -- since I discovered it after a couple of
weeks with xfwm, xfwm2 and afterstep -- is Xfce. For me, it's perfect. I
never log in directly to X because there are times when I just want to check
mail or do other tasks that would be done on the command line in any case.

  So, I have a command line when I log in and I use the 'startx' command to
load the gooey. Again, this suits my preferences and is not advocated as the
Right Way for anyone else.

  Back to your question: I presume that a 'konsole' window is KDE's version
of an (x|a|e|term/rxvt); that is, a virtual console with a command line in
which to type. I may be completely wrong, because I'm not a RHCE or SysAdmin
or any other kind of computer professional, but I don't think that you can
have the system pick up changes in your Xconfiguration without stopping X
and restarting it so it reads all the preference files.

  In Xfce, a left-pointer click on the root window (i.e., background) pops
up a menu. One of the choises is to Quit xfce, and the submenu from that
offers a choice to restart xfce. This I can do without shutting down X or
closing any open applications. Convenient. Perhaps KDE has the same ability.

HTH,

Rich




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Aug 24 07:04:20 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 07:04:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <1030162730.18713.12.camel@laptop>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208240651220.11339-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 23 Aug 2002, Aaron Baer wrote:

> This statement seems to be just for kewl RH bashing.. 

> But I guess now it's cool to hate Red Hat. That must be it.. 

  I have no intention of igniting a vitriolic tempest here, but I really
would like to understand the emotional basis for this recurring theme on the
PLUG mail list: my distribution is better than your distribution.

  For the past four or five years I've seen this over and over again;
sometimes it gets quite annoying, sometimes only takeing up space in the
mail file until deleted. But, the defenders of one distribution attack
others with equal intensity. Reminds me of the rear windows in pickup trucks
I see: Ford trucks have a decal of Calvin pee-ing on a Chevy or Dodge logo;
Chevy trucks have a decal of Calvin pee-ing on a Ford logo, and so on.

  Why?

  What possible difference does it make what distribution any of us use? As
a matter of fact, those who are most zealous in defending their
philosophical favorite are actually exhibiting behavior that is inimical to
the linux/*BSD/UNIX/etc. way. We see examples of this constantly on this
mail list.

  For example, someone -- including me -- will post a question on how to
achieve a certain task. Answers pour in from the audience showing how it can
be done via shell script, perl, python, grep, awk, sed, emacs, vi, scheme,
and so on. Why? Because there is more than one way to solve any computer
problem on a unix-type system. Even the linux kernel, as I understand it,
has selected the best parts of SysV (SVR4) and BSD (4.3?) to create another
Way to Computing Nirvana.

  So, the bigotry/zealotry/hatred for and against certain businesses
contradicts this base. Those who rail againt Corporations, "suits", the
un-pure and lower castes only exhibit naivety, ignorance or blindness to the
world in which we all live.

  I do not expect to change anyone's beliefs. But, I would very much like to
understand why we see so many messages on this same theme.

Off-list responses welcomed,

Rich




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Aug 24 07:17:47 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 07:17:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)
In-Reply-To: <3D6724D8.2020606@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208240716030.11339-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:

> Geez, that sounds like MS created the QWERTY keyboard. We've had QWERTY 
> keyboards for many decades longer than MS and been around.

  Can you say, "typewriter"? The QWERTY layout came about to slow typists
down because the arms on a mechanical typewriter would become jammed if you
typed too fast. I know this from experience, having used mechanical
typewriters in the '50s and '60s (that's 1900, not 1800).

Rich

From miker at netsailer.com  Sat Aug 24 08:56:35 2002
From: miker at netsailer.com (Mike Russell)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 08:56:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A training cooperative?
In-Reply-To: <1030084068.29806.470.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208030756190.23746-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20020824085102.01dd5d60@pop3.norton.antivirus>

I have a moderate ranch stile house, live by my self and want to be more 
efficient at being a linux geek. my one hurdle is i have two house's worth 
of furniture to contend with, but i think i could set up a TV computer 
display and room for about 10 > 15 people to sit comfortably, plus network 
connections. I live in aloha.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Aug 24 09:49:03 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 09:49:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Upgrading PHP - How do I uninstall the old versoin?
References: <3D67B479.E6E89D3D@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <3D67B8FF.4010906@pacifier.com>

Bill Thoen wrote:
> Last spring I installed PHP 4.1 with MySQL on my RH 7.2 server,
> and following the instructions from
> http://wdvl.internet.com/Authoring/DB/SQL/Build/, I did it
> without using the RPM. It's been working beautifully. But now I
> want to upgrade PHP to version 4.2.2 to take care of some
> security problems.
> 
> So my question is: How do I get rid of the old version of PHP
> before recompiling the new, or do I even need to worry about
> that? I guess I can't use rpm -e, and the doc mentioned above
> says to "Seek help from an experienced user if you don't know
> how..." So here I am asking for help. 
> 
> How do I do this without getting myself and server totally fubar?


If you still have the source laying around, try `make uninstall`.
It's always nice when that works, but not all programmers are nice that way.

--
Kyle Accardi





From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Aug 24 14:25:17 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 14:25:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208240651220.11339-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208241327140.3547-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 24 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On 23 Aug 2002, Aaron Baer wrote:
> 
> > This statement seems to be just for kewl RH bashing.. 
> 
> > But I guess now it's cool to hate Red Hat. That must be it.. 
> 
>   I have no intention of igniting a vitriolic tempest here, but I
> really would like to understand the emotional basis for this recurring
> theme on the PLUG mail list: my distribution is better than your
> distribution.

Why do you assume it's an emotional basis?

This is more example of what I've been trying to describe for the past
year (seemingly every time these arguments arise):  Red Hat users try to
dismiss the argument as emotional, merely preferential, and irrelevant.

It's not a theoretical, "My dad could beat up your dad" argument and it is
only Red Hat (and Red Hat-like) users who try to say so.

Personally, I think this is because Red Hat users do not have a strong
technical, ethical, and moral reason for choosing the software they use
and, therefore, have a very hard time understanding that some people DO
have such a foundation for their choices.

This whole approach to the discussion is just a defense mechanism to avoid
actually discussing the system on its merits, which are few.

>   What possible difference does it make what distribution any of us
> use?

I think that's exactly the question Karl has been trying to answer all
along and has been completely ignored.

There is a system out there that gives people freedom on an individual
level.  There is a distribution that is developed and maintained with
higher ideals than greed and selfishness.  Using such a system builds a
stronger, more empowered community.  Using such a system for development
brings unparalleled consistency to software packaging and
configuration.  Working within such a system gives a person a better
understanding of how people can interact without competition, greed,
exploitation or other destructive forces and that might carry over into
other aspects of that person's life.

The Red Hat user's response to all this has been something like, "I'm not
sure if that's true.  I don't care.  I don't care.  I don't care.  Yeah,
but maybe not."  There is no counter-argument proclaiming that using Red
Hat actually makes the world a better place.  Hell, there's not even the
counter-argument that Red Hat is technically superior, easier to use (in
fact, it's fairly apparent from the number of rpm questions that at least
the package management system is NOT as easy to use or technically
advanced as Debian system), or on higher ethical ground.  Instead, there
is merely the argument that we shouldn't have the argument.

> As a matter of fact, those who are most zealous in defending their
> philosophical favorite are actually exhibiting behavior that is
> inimical to the linux/*BSD/UNIX/etc. way. We see examples of this
> constantly on this mail list.

What "way" is that, again?

>   For example, someone -- including me -- will post a question on how
> to achieve a certain task. Answers pour in from the audience showing
> how it can be done via shell script, perl, python, grep, awk, sed,
> emacs, vi, scheme, and so on. Why? Because there is more than one way
> to solve any computer problem on a unix-type system.

And for small tasks such as this, there really isn't any difference in
which method you choose.  The speed, efficiency, and efficacy of each is
mitigated by the simple fact that it's still going to take less than two
seconds no matter which method you use.  However, in larger questions of
architecture, the relative differences become more relevant and a bigger
sticking point in the decision process.

How many hours have YOU spent tracking down rpm dependencies?

And, of course, your example also totally avoids any ethical consideration
of the issue at hand.  All of the utilities you described above are
available in GPL-compatible variants and available to all people
everywhere without conditional restriction or imposed control.

>   So, the bigotry/zealotry/hatred for and against certain businesses
> contradicts this base. Those who rail againt Corporations, "suits",
> the un-pure and lower castes only exhibit naivety, ignorance or
> blindness to the world in which we all live.

It might be naivete, but it's not ignorance or blindness.  Many of us
believe that the world in which we all live is on the fast track to
destruction; be that destruction environmental, social, or otherwise.  The
systems used in this world to which we willfully turn a blind eye have
evolved in such a way so as to incorporate criticism, protest, and even
outright dissidence without changing those aspects criticized, protests,
or dissented.

Working within the system is, unfortunately, the only choice in certain
arena (until, of course, the revolution comes and people get off their
asses all at once), but software is thankfully is not one of those.  We
can develop Free Software and the community outside the destructive
systems of power.  And because the Free Software community is based on
basic ideas of freedom and communication, any attempt by the power
structure to restrict our community is a shining and obvious example of
our that structure works against the people to protect itself and
therefore can be used as ammunition for evangelizing and bringing about
greater revolt against the powers that be.

>   I do not expect to change anyone's beliefs. But, I would very much
> like to understand why we see so many messages on this same theme.

Mostly because the discussion is quickly derailed from actual merits of
the software system (quality, philosophy, usability, etc.) and into this
meta-discussion of who useless the discussion is.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Aug 24 14:28:09 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 14:28:09 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <3D672423.1020801@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208241425360.3547-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> You do realize that one truth that MS has proven time and again is
> that the best product doesn't necessarily get the most use (read
> "market share"). It's the product that has the best marketting that
> generally gets the most eyeballs, and those eyeballs translate
> directly into sales.
> 
> I'm not saying it's right, wrong or indifferent.

Yes, but do you CARE if it's right, wrong or indifferent?

Do you want think there is a right way?  Do you want to make a little
effort to bring your world a little closer to your sense of right?

> What I'm saying is that's the way things work in the world economy we
> currently have.

Economy is the science of scarcity.  Free Software is abundant.  We don't
have to worry about the world economy.  (Now, bandwidth is a scarce
resource, but that's another issue.)

We can take our community outside that world and construct a new one that
is better.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

 http://www.openlaw.org

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Sat Aug 24 14:46:26 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 14:46:26 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208241327140.3547-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208241418150.12915-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Sat, 24 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>
> On Sat, 24 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
> >
> >   I have no intention of igniting a vitriolic tempest here, but I
> > really would like to understand the emotional basis for this recurring
> > theme on the PLUG mail list: my distribution is better than your
> > distribution.
>
> Why do you assume it's an emotional basis?
>
> This is more example of what I've been trying to describe for the past
> year (seemingly every time these arguments arise):  Red Hat users try to
> dismiss the argument as emotional, merely preferential, and irrelevant.

This behavior isn't just coming from the RH users.  Not IMHO.

> Personally, I think this is because Red Hat users do not have a strong
> technical, ethical, and moral reason for choosing the software they use
> and, therefore, have a very hard time understanding that some people DO
> have such a foundation for their choices.

RH ships with a modified kernel, with more device drivers..  And a lot of
rpm's are optimized for newer computers.  These are two technical reasons
to use RH over other distros.  There are more reasons, some consider it a
defacto standard.  I don't use RH, but if I did, I know I could lay those
on the line as technical reasons.  BUT, the counter argument would be that
you can download the RH kernel and use it on other distros, that you can
install RPM on other distros.  It's free software, we could create a plug
distro which is a RH/debian hybrid...how cool would that be! :)

> >   What possible difference does it make what distribution any of us
> > use?
>
> I think that's exactly the question Karl has been trying to answer all
> along and has been completely ignored.
>
> There is a system out there that gives people freedom on an individual
> level.  There is a distribution that is developed and maintained with
> higher ideals than greed and selfishness.  Using such a system builds a
> stronger, more empowered community.  Using such a system for development
> brings unparalleled consistency to software packaging and
> configuration.  Working within such a system gives a person a better
> understanding of how people can interact without competition, greed,
> exploitation or other destructive forces and that might carry over into
> other aspects of that person's life.

Is this about technical merit?  I feel it is closer to an emotional
argument.

> The Red Hat user's response to all this has been something like, "I'm not
> sure if that's true.  I don't care.  I don't care.  I don't care.  Yeah,
> but maybe not."  There is no counter-argument proclaiming that using Red
> Hat actually makes the world a better place.

Does using RH make the world a worse place?  You're either part of the
problem or solution, right?  Use RH supports open source, so I think it
does help make the world a better place, maybe not as quickly as other
approaches, but it's not evil.


> Hell, there's not even the counter-argument that Red Hat is technically
> superior, easier to use (in fact, it's fairly apparent from the number
> of rpm questions that at least the package management system is NOT as
> easy to use or technically advanced as Debian system), or on higher
> ethical ground.

I think you have to becareful about lumping the overall ease of use, with
the ease of use for specific utilities and programs.  I don't want to
argue about apt or rpm, but yes I would say apt is easier to use. BUT, RH
comes with many programs to help people do many command line tasks.  Well,
so what, so do other distrobutions?  In RH they are usually graphical,
making the transition from a more "user friendly" OS easier.  I remember
back when I was new to all this that RH won me over compared to slackware
because of that.

> Instead, there is merely the argument that we shouldn't have the
> argument.

Shouldn't the argument be "how can we (users of distro x) make our
distribution better?".  I mean really, since it is all free software, then
we can merge features to satisfy user groups.

> Working within the system is, unfortunately, the only choice in certain
> arena (until, of course, the revolution comes and people get off their
> asses all at once), but software is thankfully is not one of those.  We
> can develop Free Software and the community outside the destructive
> systems of power.  And because the Free Software community is based on
> basic ideas of freedom and communication, any attempt by the power
> structure to restrict our community is a shining and obvious example of
> our that structure works against the people to protect itself and
> therefore can be used as ammunition for evangelizing and bringing about
> greater revolt against the powers that be.

Is this a technical argument...

>
> >   I do not expect to change anyone's beliefs. But, I would very much
> > like to understand why we see so many messages on this same theme.
>
> Mostly because the discussion is quickly derailed from actual merits of
> the software system (quality, philosophy, usability, etc.) and into this
> meta-discussion of who useless the discussion is.

I think the man has a point.  We pluggers should be devoting our energies
not toward converting everyone to our distro, but to helping linux users.

And yes, I realize that I should never have replied because now I'm
encouraging this thread to go on even longer...And no I don't use RH and
that shouldn't matter.

Jason





From beattie at beattie-home.net  Sat Aug 24 15:35:46 2002
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: 24 Aug 2002 15:35:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208241327140.3547-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208241327140.3547-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1030228546.26584.14.camel@coyote>

On Sat, 2002-08-24 at 14:25, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> On Sat, 24 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > On 23 Aug 2002, Aaron Baer wrote:
> > 
> > > This statement seems to be just for kewl RH bashing.. 
> > 
> > > But I guess now it's cool to hate Red Hat. That must be it.. 
> > 
> >   I have no intention of igniting a vitriolic tempest here, but I
> > really would like to understand the emotional basis for this recurring
> > theme on the PLUG mail list: my distribution is better than your
> > distribution.
> 
> Why do you assume it's an emotional basis?
> 
> This is more example of what I've been trying to describe for the past
> year (seemingly every time these arguments arise):  Red Hat users try to
> dismiss the argument as emotional, merely preferential, and irrelevant.
> 
> It's not a theoretical, "My dad could beat up your dad" argument and it is
> only Red Hat (and Red Hat-like) users who try to say so.
> 
> Personally, I think this is because Red Hat users do not have a strong
> technical, ethical, and moral reason for choosing the software they use
> and, therefore, have a very hard time understanding that some people DO
> have such a foundation for their choices.
> 

I'm not a RedHat user and I'd be a FreeBSD user if Linux had not won the
"hype war".  I use debian and have been playing with Mandrake.  Bu I can
find no "strong technical, ethical, [or] moral reason for choosing" one
Linux distro over another, at least the major distro's, for general
workstation use.

If one want's a strictly moral or ethical choice and one finds making
money selling free software objectional, I think you'd have to go with
debian or one of the minor distro's. Frankly, what RedHat, Mandrake,
SUSE and others are doing would appear to be within the original intent
of the GPL, it is certainly within the letter. If somebody did not want
RedHat to include their software in it's package they should have chosen
a different License or not released it at all.

Having done software development in UNIX since 1978, I am of the opinion
that, the technical differences between the various free UNIX
distributions are trival.

--

beattie at beattie-home.net | for a Resource Action by my former employer,
                         | it is my pleasure announce my immediate
www.beattie-home.net     | availability, contract or permanent.
Embedded Systems, Linux/Unix internals Software Engineer

On Fri, 2002-08-23 at 13:03, AthlonRob wrote:
> Yeah, this one has lasted me about siix years now and only cost me $2
> (on sale).
> 
> I think, however, that it is time for a new keyboard.

I just got back from Fry's.  I was really hoping they would have a
better selection than they did.  The only Logitech keyboard they had on
display was a $50 one... way more than what I needed.  The only
Microsoft ones they had on display were the wavy ones... while I did
find myself able to type quickly on it just right there without any
practice, I'd rather stick with a traditional one and save a little desk
space.

They had but one with the exact layout I wanted.  I guess when I do my
DOS stuff (DOSSLACK is still needing lots of work...) I'll probably be
hitting shift instead of \ a lot.  Oh well.  At least I'm not hitting \
instead of enter!  :-)

It's an Inland Pro Keyboard 4000.  It cost $20, so if it only lasts a
year, I'll be able to justify getting a nicer one (maybe one of those
Microsoft Office keyboards, they've gotten rave reviews).

It's got a fairly soft sound to it and the keys almost feel like they're
padded... they don't stop so abruptly at the bottom of the stroke.  They
take a little more force to push down, though, I think... so that might
cause problems ... or might not.

Well, there's all you ever wanted to know about Rob's keyboard!  :-)

Rob

Someone once told me--I've never researched this--that the reason that there 
was almost no carpal tunnel injuries with typewriters is because some force 
was required to press the keys and that the advent of "soft-touch" keyboards 
don't give your fingers enough excercise: muscular resistance.

download from kernel.org and then there is a SuSE modified kernel. The 
SuSE installation sets up a /etc/lilo.conf file so that the user has 
the choice of selecting either the "Linux" or "SuSE" kernel when 
booting the system. By default I believe I get the "standard" kernel if 
I don't pick one.

On Sat, 2002-08-24 at 16:36, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> On Saturday 24 August 2002 14:46 pm, Jason Dagit wrote:
> 
> I'll add my $0.02 and just say that RH isn't alone here. SuSE is my 
> distro of choice and they include the "standard" kernel that you can 
> download from kernel.org and then there is a SuSE modified kernel. The 
> SuSE installation sets up a /etc/lilo.conf file so that the user has

> booting the system. By default I believe I get the "standard" kernel if 
> I don't pick one.

I have a few friends who love SuSE... they hadn't mentioned this... do
you happen to know what the differences are between the two kernels?

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"




From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sat Aug 24 16:54:06 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 16:54:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208232215190.27330-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208241304200.3323-100000@joan.burling.com>

[Apologies to the rest of the list, but Jeme has pressed a couple of
my hot butoons here his his response.]

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>
> On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > I agree.  RH is the most successful commercial distro so naturally
> > there's a backlash against them, I suppose.  RH has quite a few
> > developers on staff and contributes a lot of code to various open
> > source projects. But ooooohh...  they're a commercial company so that
> > automatically makes them the anti-christ, doesn't it.  Sheesh.
>
> Please don't use the term "anti-christ".  We should not confuse real-world
> evil with ancient mythological mumbo jumbo.

This is interesting. The ``ancient mythological mumbo jumbo" you mention --
the symbols, allusions & trope of the Judeo-Christian religion -- are part
& parcel of Western Civilization. Just as Buddhism is integral to Japanese
culture, Taoism to Chinese, & Hinduism to Indian. In other words, one
doesn't have to believe in the ideas this complex of symbols embraces, but
avoiding its contribution to our language impoverishes your ability to
communicate. According to the literary critic Northrop Frye, no major
literary work of Western Civilization since about AD 300 fails to use
this background either explicitly or implicitly. (And the exceptions draw
upon an alternative set of -- in your terms -- ``ancient mythological
mumbo jumbo".

And would you also object as vehmently to some using the term ``karma"?
Say in the phrase, ``So-&-so's karma finally caught up with him?"
>
> Red Hat has taken something truly progressive that could be a gateway into
> a new world of abundance and sharing and compromised it down to something
> palatable to the Capitalists.
>
> We have already shown that our community yields superior tools available
> to a greater number of people than any market could possibly produce, yet
> there are those among us who still believe it is necessary to inject
> greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation.
>
> Now, Debian has produced far superior software and greater distribution
> capacity (and I've yet to hear an argument to the contrary) while still
> holding strong to essentially progressive ideals.
>
I find nothing here but sloppy assertions & emotion. How has RH
corrupted ``something truly progressive"? Is it for reasons other than
they are a business & have been paid money for developing Linux?

How has RH injected ``greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation"?
You can still download their isos -- including source code -- from their
servers, they pay numerous developers to work on Linux code, and they
have donated money & labor to support computers in the North Carolina
school district. Am I missing something in how RH operates?

Has RH not abided to the terms of the GPL? And is following the GPL that
important? Linus doesn't appear to think so, otherwise he wouldn't be
using BitKeeper to manage his code.

>From what you wrote, Jeme, I see little more than a bit of disingenious
distro-bashing. And if this is all you have to offer in defense of your
attack on Red Hat, I am not persuaded by your arguments.

Geoff

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Aug 24 18:03:40 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 18:03:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <1030228546.26584.14.camel@coyote>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208241749200.6654-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 24 Aug 2002, Brian Beattie wrote:
> I'm not a RedHat user and I'd be a FreeBSD user if Linux had not won
> the "hype war".

What does this mean?  You choose a GNU/Linux system over FreeBSD because
there are more magazines bout GNU/Linux?  I don't get it.

> I use debian and have been playing with Mandrake.  Bu I can find no
> "strong technical, ethical, [or] moral reason for choosing" one Linux
> distro over another, at least the major distro's, for general
> workstation use.

Technical:  While the underlying technologies of operation are similar in
every important respect, the package management and configuration systems
in Debian are far more advanced than those in Red Hat.  Building and
maintaining packages and managing dependencies is cleaner and easier with
the Debian system.

Ethical:  Debian is a community-based project.  The purpose of Debian is
to both create a strong and versatile Free Software operating system (or
set of operating systems) and a strong and versatile Free Software
community.  Debian draws hard lines between packages which are Free and
non-Free.

Moral:  Decisions regarding the Debian project are not made by those who
personally benefit more than the community at large by those
decisions.  There is no power structure within the Debian project that
allows the few to exploit the many.  The Debian project does not accrue
capital based on its monopoly of existing capital.  The Debian project has
no secrets.

> If one want's a strictly moral or ethical choice and one finds making
> money selling free software objectional, I think you'd have to go with
> debian or one of the minor distro's.

Selling software isn't a problem so long as the people who buy it have the
right to redistribute.  The problems with corporations are more closely
related to the manipulation of "public" stock, the wage slavery of
hundreds or thousands of workers, and the consequential accrual of
inordinate wealth by the few.

> Frankly, what RedHat, Mandrake, SUSE and others are doing would appear
> to be within the original intent of the GPL, it is certainly within
> the letter. If somebody did not want RedHat to include their software
> in it's package they should have chosen a different License or not
> released it at all.

I absolutely respect the right of Red Hat to exist.  I just think it's sad
that people use their system when there are alternatives with greater
benefit.

> Having done software development in UNIX since 1978, I am of the
> opinion that, the technical differences between the various free UNIX
> distributions are trival.

I would argue that the only non-trivial technical difference between the
various common distributions is the package management system.  Certainly
the tiny differences in filesystem layout and configuration file location
or format is trivial (unless we're talking about a system that uses binary
configuration files, which would be a non-trivial difference in my book).

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

 http://www.openlaw.org

From russj at dimstar.net  Sat Aug 24 17:40:11 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 17:40:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)
References: <1030132991.7643.7.camel@duron> <1030230113.14570.6.camel@duron> <3D6817DC.4020309@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <3D68276B.90503@dimstar.net>

Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Someone once told me--I've never researched this--that the reason that 
> there was almost no carpal tunnel injuries with typewriters is because 
> some force was required to press the keys and that the advent of 
> "soft-touch" keyboards don't give your fingers enough excercise: 
> muscular resistance.

That "sounds" counter intuitive to me. Carpal Tunnel Syndrom (CTS) is a 
Repetitive Stress Injury (RSI) and a Cummulative Trama Disorder (CTD). 
According to one article 
(http://continuous-speech.com/carpal_tunnel.html) CTS has been described 
and studied since at least 1863. The carpal tunnel release surgery has 
been common since the 1950s.

According to other papers I've read (sorry, no online reference), the 
drastic increases we've seen in the last 30 years is due to the vast 
proliferation of computers. Prior to this time, CTS was seen mostly 
among professions where repetitive hand motions were used. Typing is 
only one of these. Factory workers on an assembly line were also 
aflicted. Mail handlers at Postal facilities have been aflicted 
practically since the inception of mail service. I've also seen reports 
that playing a traditionally shaped guitar can cause CTS.

According to this (http://www.lunnflutes.com/ho6.htm), many musicians 
suffer from CTS. Pianists and guitarists among them. I suspect that CTS 
has been with us since the invention of the piano, and probably much longer.

The thing is, more people are using keyboards, both musical and digital. 
  Because of this, more people are getting CTS, so we hear about it 
more. It's more mainstream than it was previously.

Of course, I'm not a doctor, and I'm just going by what reports I've 
read. YMMV, so take everything I've written here with a $1.55 and you 
can buy a cup of coffee at Shari's.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online

http://www.dimstar.net
telnet://telnet.dimstar.net
ICQ: 3739685


Why did the chicken cross the road?

Because it was too long to walk around.

could find a similar free program for Windows.
