From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Aug 24 18:47:56 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 18:47:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208241728160.1496-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208241832350.7468-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 24 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I've never built an RPM, but I've heard that Debian is not "far more
> advanced", it's just that the people making .debs put a little more
> effort into making them work well, whereas RPM builders, on the whole
> are slightly more careless.

And you should ask yourself, "Why is that?"

I think the reason is at least two-fold:  First, the Debian project
maintains an official repository of packages that have been checked and
rechecked by committed members of the community to ensure that the
packages adhere to the strict guidelines in the Debian documentation.  
Second, the Debian project uses specific package maintainers who are
committed personally to the success of the project while Red Hat packages
are either produced by wage slaves or hobbyists whose primary motivation
is just to bust out something that works "good enough" for a majority of
installations.

This concept can be generalized into the idea that people working for
wages do just enough to get by while people who work for either love or
necessity do as much as they possibly can.

Also, the superiority of the system is not merely in the packages and
their structure, but the package management tools that allow, within the
Debian system, a user or administrator to download, install, and configure
a package and all of its dependent packages with a single command.

> But then again, since you've mentioned many times that you don't use
> any packaging system, but instead build from source, I'm wondering if
> you are able to provide any details as to why .debs are "far more
> advanced."

How'd I do?

> > Ethical:  Debian is a community-based project.  The purpose of Debian is
> > to both create a strong and versatile Free Software operating system (or
> > set of operating systems) and a strong and versatile Free Software
> > community.  Debian draws hard lines between packages which are Free and
> > non-Free.
> 
> I don't think any of the other distros are really any different in
> this regard.  They all want a strong community.  And Red Hat
> complained recently about licensing restrictions on StarOffice.

Yes, they all WANT a strong community.  Surely the strong community is
good for Red Hat's profits.  That's where morality comes in.  To me,
ethics is a determination of right and wrong and morals are a
determination of motivation to do right or wrong.

The question then is, "What are they doing about it?"

Debian is structuring itself AS that community of involved human beings
who are committed to building a great system for the sake of having a
great system and making it available to all people for all time.

Red Hat is complaining about licenses because a good office package would
boost their saleability and, hence, their profits.

Which stands on higher ground?

> Just out of curiosity, do you have a job?

Nope.

> Or would that compromise your beliefs?

As I've written a thousand times, the entire reason we should be looking
toward alternatives to the structure of our current economy and society is
the inherent, required exploitation of a system based on greed,
selfishness, and fear.  Note the word "required".

I wrote just today that it's unfortunate that we must work within this
abusive, destructive system in some (perhaps many, certainly too many)
capacity in order to simply maintain the struggle against it.  Therefore,
it is necessary, from time to time, to allow a capitalist to exploit my
labor for his personal profit so that I can simply sustain myself.

To put it bluntly, it is necessary for the vast majority to find some way
to please the wealthy minority in order to continue to survive.  The most
reliable way to please the wealthy is to help them accrue more wealth.

Sick, isn't it?

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

 http://www.openlaw.org

hard most people would be pressing the keys because they just lost some 
important work. One has to wonder about the amount of high blood 
pressure and other stress related diseases caused by the instabilities 
of Microsoft's product offerings occurring at the wrong time.

I've certainly been there when Word decides to puke and a document that 
I had spent many days working on was mostly lost. I was very stressed 
out having to work alot of extra hours to put the document back 
together again to meet a scheduling deadline. I've tried to work around 
this problem by saving often and also having Word do autosaves at very 
short intervals.

Tony

> > I wish I could find a similar free program for Windows.

>
>   Isn't that the purpose of having to reboot several times per day?

> especially if you're working on a tight deadline.
>
> Rich

From kens at cad2cam.com  Sat Aug 24 19:14:47 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 19:14:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Commands to be used avoiding reboot PC
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020824142041.00b77868@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208232126260.4598-100000@lukem.com> <5.1.1.6.0.20020824142041.00b77868@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <200208241914.48007.kens@cad2cam.com>

On Friday 23 August 2002 11:32 pm, Stephen Liu wrote:
> Hi Ken,
>
> Thanks for your advice.
>
> At 10:20 PM 8/23/2002 -0700, you wrote:
> >after editing fstab you may issue the command:  mount -a
> >this command reads the /etc/fstab file and mounts what is not mounted and
> >possible to mount.  If you don't have a floppy in the drive it won't mount
> >it.
>
> If I use text editor to edit fstab on KDE can I use the desktop icon to
> mount the floppy???  Or I have execute those commands on Konsole window ???
>

Yep.  If you wish a users to be able to mount the floppy add "user" to the 
options portion of fstab.   A man fstab will give you the options.

>After editing the XF86Config, exit X.
>
> If I use text editor to editor XF86Config-4, whether exit X to text-mode
> (Ctrl+Alt+F2) and then change back to X (graphic mode) with (Ctrl+Alt+F7)
> ???.  The new settings would be executed.
>

Ctrl-Alt-F2 just switches you to a text console.  The X server is still 
running on the seventh console.  You are switching to different sessions and 
not stopping and restarting the X server.  You must do one of the following 
to get the X server to stop and reread the configuration file.

> Thanks in advance.
>
> Stephen
>
> >If you are using xdm or init 5 or X
> >login window you must do the init 3 then init 5 to stop X and restart it.
> >If you had started X from a console window after logging in, then just
> > exit X by CTRL-ALT-<backspace>.  This kills the X server and brings you
> > back to the text console.  Then just startx.
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

-- 
Ken Stephens
www.cad2cam.com
www.cadtocam.com



From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Aug 24 19:24:22 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 19:24:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)
References: <1030132991.7643.7.camel@duron> <1030230113.14570.6.camel@duron> <3D6817DC.4020309@pacifier.com> <3D68276B.90503@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <3D683FD6.1080506@pacifier.com>

Russ Johnson wrote:
> Kyle Accardi wrote:
> 
>> Someone once told me--I've never researched this--that the reason that 
>> there was almost no carpal tunnel injuries with typewriters is because 
>> some force was required to press the keys and that the advent of 
>> "soft-touch" keyboards don't give your fingers enough excercise: 
>> muscular resistance.
> 
> 
> That "sounds" counter intuitive to me. Carpal Tunnel Syndrom (CTS) is a 
> Repetitive Stress Injury (RSI) and a Cummulative Trama Disorder (CTD). 
> According to one article 
> (http://continuous-speech.com/carpal_tunnel.html) CTS has been described 
> and studied since at least 1863. The carpal tunnel release surgery has 
> been common since the 1950s.

<sniping some links & history for further study>

This all seems likely.  Sorry, it was heresay on my part.  The only thing I 
could think of is the extra muscular effort required to "pull" your fingers 
from the key as opposed to letting it "bounce" off.

Seems strange that in 2002, with all the so-called science availble, that we 
are still suffering with such primitive input devices.  As much as I like my 
scroll mouse, it is terribly uncomfortable in my big hand (both hands are 
the same size).  Haven't tried a trackball yet only because I don't want to 
shell out $50+ for something that I might hate.


--
Kyle Accardi

What kind of mouse do you have?  You might see if you can locate an old
IntelliMouse Explorer 1.0.  If they say it doesn't work, say you'll give
'em $5 for it, because there's a design flaw which is fairly easily
fixed in 'em.

really wrap your hands around it.  While uncomfertable for most folks,
you might find it meets your needs exactly.

did scratch out the M$ logo on the back  <G>) since about three months
after they were released... maybe two years ago?  It's a good mouse,
built to last!

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Sat Aug 24 21:49:19 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 24 Aug 2002 21:49:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)
In-Reply-To: <3D684D79.9060206@pacifier.com>
References: <9NLJEMHZ4ZLA7VPKZYUT0931QK97.3d68469e@miked> 
	<3D684D79.9060206@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <1030250959.16110.1.camel@duron>

On Sat, 2002-08-24 at 20:22, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> > AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro> wrote:
> > What kind of mouse do you have?  You might see if you can locate an old
> > IntelliMouse Explorer 1.0.  If they say it doesn't work, say you'll give
> > 'em $5 for it, because there's a design flaw which is fairly easily
> > fixed in 'em.
> 
> This here's a IntelliMouse 1.2A (shiped with a Gateway computer).  It's the 
> largest wheel mouse I've seen.  Always keeping my eyes open, though.  What 
> is the design flaw?

The soldering connecting the cable and/or it's connector to the board
inside the mouse has come loose on a lot of these things.  It causes the
mouse to apparetnly just die, when in fact it's just a bad cable.  If
you pop the sucker open and do a little soldering (very little) it'll be
in tip-top shape again.  :-)

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"

From m at netpro.to  Sat Aug 24 21:57:17 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 21:57:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Upgrading PHP - How do I uninstall the old versoin?
In-Reply-To: <3D67B479.E6E89D3D@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0208242147580.8773-100000@lukem.com>

You should be able to just 'make install' over the old PHP install (add
any specific configure options for your environment, of course).  If
you've made changes to your php.ini, then you'll want to backup those
changes somewhere.  Everything else, including your httpd.conf should stay
the same.  As per the instructions you followed below, I recommend setting
'register_globals = Off' for security reasons (it's the default now
anyway).  You'll then use the $_POST, $_GET, and $_COOKIE arrays instead.
~M


On Sat, 24 Aug 2002, Bill Thoen wrote:

> Last spring I installed PHP 4.1 with MySQL on my RH 7.2 server,
> and following the instructions from
> http://wdvl.internet.com/Authoring/DB/SQL/Build/, I did it
> without using the RPM. It's been working beautifully. But now I

> security problems.
>

> before recompiling the new, or do I even need to worry about
> that? I guess I can't use rpm -e, and the doc mentioned above
> says to "Seek help from an experienced user if you don't know
> how..." So here I am asking for help.
>
> How do I do this without getting myself and server totally fubar?
>
> - Bill Thoen

From russj at dimstar.net  Sat Aug 24 22:34:23 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)

Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)

Mike De La Mater wrote:
> As far as I'm concerned, there's only one decent trackball, the Logitech Trackman 
> Marble, it has eveloved into the Trackman Marble Plus model, which has a scroll 
> button. I've even purchased spares. Don't bother with the later one that has a 1 
> 1/2" diameter ball, I can't even start to use it as well. I have a big hand, too, 
> but it's bigger than my left hand. The trackman marble only comes in a RH (right 
> hand) model. 

I too use this trackball and love it. The thing with trackball is that 
they come with right, left or center balls. These can also be classified 
as either 'thumb' or 'finger' balls. I prefer to use my thumb for the 
trackball, and therefor, I use a left ball, for my right hand. My 
so-to-be-ex-wife preferred to use her fingers, so she had a center ball 
trackball, from MS.

From smathews at pcez.com  Sat Aug 24 23:41:55 2002
From: smathews at pcez.com (stuart mathews)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 22:41:55 -800
Subject: [PLUG] Network Snag update & cracker question
Message-ID: <3d686e23.6fb3.0@pcez.com>

It took me a while, but I realized that among the changes I made to my Linux
system, installing an Iomega Zip drive fouled up the IRQ settings for my NIC.


But I wonder; if a box has a misconfigured eth0, or if eth0 is not up, would
it be totally impossible for a cracker to gain access to that system while is
was in that state?

-------------------
http://www.pcez.com



From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Aug 24 22:52:38 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 22:52:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Network Snag update & cracker question
References: <3d686e23.6fb3.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <3D6870A6.5030007@pacifier.com>

stuart mathews wrote:
> It took me a while, but I realized that among the changes I made to my Linux
> system, installing an Iomega Zip drive fouled up the IRQ settings for my NIC.
> 
> 
> But I wonder; if a box has a misconfigured eth0, or if eth0 is not up, would
> it be totally impossible for a cracker to gain access to that system while is
> was in that state?

Not at all.

Misconfigured NIC: you could be hacked, depends...

Down NIC: you could be hacked from serial port or local user (which includes 
physical access).

You can root any Linux box if you can type ctrl-atl-del and reboot to single 
user mode.  Of course, there's trojans as well.  Basically, being 
un-networked makes you more secure, but not totally.

--
Kyle Accardi




From robbert at vafam.com  Sat Aug 24 23:19:33 2002
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 23:19:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Uninstall KDE
In-Reply-To: <3d686e23.6fb3.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <003401c24bff$614d1320$6401a8c0@robbert>

How do I uninstall KDE and its programs?  I never use it and I want to
clear up some space on the hard drive.  

Thanks for the help,
Robbert van Andel




From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Sat Aug 24 23:27:29 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 24 Aug 2002 23:27:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Uninstall KDE
In-Reply-To: <003401c24bff$614d1320$6401a8c0@robbert>
References: <003401c24bff$614d1320$6401a8c0@robbert>
Message-ID: <1030256850.16585.9.camel@duron>

On Sat, 2002-08-24 at 23:19, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> How do I uninstall KDE and its programs?  I never use it and I want to
> clear up some space on the hard drive.  

That depends greatly upon your linux distro.  If you're in Slackware
you'd likely use pkgtool > remove packages > check all the KDE packages
> hit ok.

If you're in RedHat, you'll have to use RPM and might run into some
dependency problems requiring you uninstall other programs that rely
upon KDE in order to remove KDE without it being forced.  I think these
dependency things Debian's apt package system is so good at means in
debian the packages would be automagically removed, likely with
warnings... although I only installed debian once to try it out.

I'm sure others will chime in with specific instructions for RH,
Mandrake, Debian, SuSE, or whatever.  But in Slackware, pkgtool would be
your best bet.

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"

rpm -q --whatrequires kdebase

should be a place to start.

From cynical at penguinness.org  Sun Aug 25 04:01:19 2002
From: cynical at penguinness.org (Justin The Cynical)
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 04:01:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drives -- danger?
In-Reply-To: <3D665E37.1010109@sun.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208230645390.28165-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
	<3D665E37.1010109@sun.com>
Message-ID: <20020825040119.1689ed0c.cynical@penguinness.org>

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002 09:09:27 -0700
Richard Langis <richard.langis at sun.com> wrote:

RL> You might also take a look at a new case - in particular one of those 
RL> Luan Lui (or whatever they're named) all-aluminum cases.  I believe they 
RL> have two 60mm fans in the front of the case, and the HD's are mounted 
RL> directly behind them, with a 1-2mm space between the drives for airflow. 
RL> I don't have one myself, but a friend of mine showed me his, and it 
RL> looked pretty slick.

</lurk>

On the subject of new cases, air flow and hard drives getting too warm...

If a case is in order, I would suggest getting a ChiefTech case.  Mid-sized tower, space for two 80mm fans up front and two 80mm in back (three if one counts the P/S fan).  This is the case one sees Antec and Endermax buying, modifying very slightly (such as adding USB ports to the front and tossing in their own P/S unit), slapping their name on it and selling it for even more that before.

I've got one of said cases, and it is a Very Good Thing(tm).  I installed Panaflow fans I got from Wacky Willys, moved the case a few feet down from the desk to the floor and watched my system temps drop over 5 degrees C.

One of the front intake fans sits in front of one of the two removable 3.5" bays, perfect for helping keep hard drives cool.  The bays appear to be able to hold three 1/4 height drives.  Myself, I'd not put anymore than two for heat reasons.

I did see a nice mid-tower at Fry's.  It has space for a single 120mm fan in the front and back.  CFM potential there.  It was also one of those all aluminum cases, which of course made it more expensive than it should have been.  Give me a nice steel case anyday.  Sturdy, not nearly as expensive, and one isn't afraid to use it as the occasional foot rest.

<lurk>

JM, just subcribed

-- 
"Remember, no matter how cynical you think you are,
  reality is going to find a way to make you look naive."
	-- Shmuel Metz in the SDM
              * Justin The Cynical - cynical at penguinness.org*

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Aug 25 09:52:19 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 09:52:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Time for a new keyboard....  (OT?)
In-Reply-To: <3D684D79.9060206@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208250946260.21791-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 24 Aug 2002, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> > As far as I'm concerned, there's only one decent trackball, the Logitech Trackman 
> > Marble, it has eveloved into the Trackman Marble Plus model, which has a scroll 

> Yes, this was the one I've been hearing good things about for years.  Seems 
> the marble is always missing on the display units which I'm sure is great 
> for sales.  Are the models bearing larger marbles (!) still avail, or are 
> you glad you bought spares?

  OK, I'll throw in my opinion on this weekend, off-topic thread. We've been
using the Kensington Orbit trackballs here for the past four or so years.
Ever since using a mouse gave me a bad case of tendinitis in my right elbow
(cured, by the way, by acupuncture).

  One unit failed about three years ago; the replacemnt and the other
original one work flawlessly, with a periodic cleaning of dog fur and dust
from the bearings and rotating rods.

  This is a two-button model with a large ball at the top, center. It's
extremely comfortable to use and permits very fine control. Trackballs that
require the use of the thumb are depending on the finger with the least
fine-motor control of the five (for most of us) fingers. That's the reason
you'll learn to never pipette anything in a microbiology course with your
thumb over the top of the pipette: can't control the outflow. We work these
trackballs with the second and third fingers on the ball and the thumb and
fourth finger on the buttons. Quite natural.

Rich




From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Sun Aug 25 10:44:42 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (E. Rogan Creswick)
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 10:44:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drives -- danger?
In-Reply-To: <20020825040119.1689ed0c.cynical@penguinness.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208251039440.15732-100000@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

> I did see a nice mid-tower at Fry's.  It has space for a single 120mm
> fan in the front and back.  CFM potential there.  It was also one of
> those all aluminum cases, which of course made it more expensive than it
> should have been.  Give me a nice steel case anyday.  Sturdy, not nearly
> as expensive, and one isn't afraid to use it as the occasional foot
> rest.


Aluminum cases have the advantage of acting as a heatsink (more so than
a steel case), since aluminum conducts heat very well. They are quite
expensive, but they also tend to be very well engineered (I have never
seen a case as preciesly made as my lian li). While you may be loosing
some "sturdyness" it is negligible, and they serve quite well as footrests
:) perhaps better, since they radiate heat in all directions ;).


-Rogan

From jon at manymoons.net  Sun Aug 25 14:18:13 2002
From: jon at manymoons.net (Jon Jacob)
Date: 25 Aug 2002 14:18:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How to handle relay attempt
Message-ID: <1030310294.29806.507.camel@lana.manymoons.net>

I noticed that following in my mail log:

Aug 24 04:55:57 lana sendmail[2618]: g7OBtub02618:
from=<net2845mike at filnet.es>, size=0, class=0, nrcpts=0, proto=SMTP,
daemon=MTA, relay=1Cust176.tnt1.san-fernando.ca.da.uu.net
[67.227.10.176]

It is obvious that someone is attempting, but failing, to relay mail
through my machine.  

What is the best protocol for handling this?  If I read this correctly,
someone witha  filnet.es address is trying to attempt to send mail
through my machine from 1Cust176.tnt1.san-fernando.ca.da.uu.net.  I have
also noticed attempted to scan my machine from this IP (67.227.10.176). 
I wonder if the person administrating the machine is aware of this, or
is responsible for it.

Any advice would be greatly apprecated.

Since that is a UUNet address, your best bet is to send an email, with
the log entries, to abuse at uu.net.

--Stafford

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Aug 25 15:55:54 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 15:55:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] How to handle relay attempt
In-Reply-To: <1030310294.29806.507.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208251551100.22501-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 25 Aug 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:

> It is obvious that someone is attempting, but failing, to relay mail
> through my machine.  
> 
> What is the best protocol for handling this?  If I read this correctly,
> someone witha  filnet.es address is trying to attempt to send mail
> through my machine from 1Cust176.tnt1.san-fernando.ca.da.uu.net.  I have
> also noticed attempted to scan my machine from this IP (67.227.10.176). 
> I wonder if the person administrating the machine is aware of this, or
> is responsible for it.

  I find some attempts like this, but all -- so far -- are rejected by
postfix. However, I also see, in /var/log/messages, where someone has
attempted to crack in via ssh. For those attempts, I send a message to both
abuse at ... and postmaster at ... telling them someone from their IP address has
attempted to crack into our network and I provide a copy of the log record.
Quite often I get a reply telling me they've found and fixed the hole in
their system.

  Same thing with spam that gets through postfix. I have a two-sentence form
letter that I use when forwarding a copy of the offending mail -- with full
headers turned on -- to both abuse at ... and postmaster at .... Except for
originators in Asia. They don't pay attention in any case so I just add the
IP address (or address block) to the badip file that postfix checks. Much
peace of mind -- mine -- ensues.

Rich




From jon at manymoons.net  Sun Aug 25 18:00:29 2002
From: jon at manymoons.net (Jon Jacob)
Date: 25 Aug 2002 18:00:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How to handle relay attempt
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208251551100.22501-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208251551100.22501-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1030323630.1412.539.camel@lana.manymoons.net>

Well, I did send a note to abuse@ and got a form letter response.

I'm going to hold my breath until they tell me they fixed it ;)

>   I find some attempts like this, but all -- so far -- are rejected by
> postfix. However, I also see, in /var/log/messages, where someone has
> attempted to crack in via ssh. For those attempts, I send a message to both
> abuse at ... and postmaster at ... telling them someone from their IP address has
> attempted to crack into our network and I provide a copy of the log record.
> Quite often I get a reply telling me they've found and fixed the hole in
> their system.
> 
>   Same thing with spam that gets through postfix. I have a two-sentence form
> letter that I use when forwarding a copy of the offending mail -- with full
> headers turned on -- to both abuse at ... and postmaster at .... Except for
> originators in Asia. They don't pay attention in any case so I just add the
> IP address (or address block) to the badip file that postfix checks. Much
> peace of mind -- mine -- ensues.
> 





From smathews at pcez.com  Sun Aug 25 20:35:28 2002
From: smathews at pcez.com (stuart mathews)
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 19:35:28 -800
Subject: [PLUG] What about BSD?
Message-ID: <3d6993f0.577e.0@pcez.com>

>In some ways, a BSD system will look and feel exactly like Linux. Most 
>of your normal activity as a user won't be visibly affected.
>
>When it comes to system administration, however, there are some fairly 
>huge differences. Probably the best place to start is the FreeBSD 
>Documentation Project:
>
>  http://www.freebsd.org/docproj/
>
>Among its offerings, the best complete introduction is the FreeBSD
>Handbook, available in a dead-tree edition from amazon.com and for no 
>cost online:
>
>  http://www.freebsd.org/doc/en_US.ISO8859-1/books/handbook/index.html
>
>Also, let me take an opportunity to plug "The FreeBSD Corporate
>Networker's Guide" by local author Ted Mittelstaedt:
>
>  http://www.freebsd-corp-net-guide.com/
>
>It's not really intended as a general introduction to FreeBSD, but it 
>includes some nice stuff for admins looking to replace any existing 
>Windows infrastructure with FreeBSD.

This is good info on getting one's feet wet with BSD. Thanks!

-------------------
http://www.pcez.com



From revans at e-z.net  Sun Aug 25 21:14:58 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 21:14:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208250733070.6801-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208250733070.6801-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
Message-ID: <20020826040421.GCUI1186.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@dhcp-320-212>

I read this a little differently. I thought Mike was pointing out that with
little thought, Jeme insulted some people. Just as you were insulted that you
would not be allowed your beliefs, others were insulted that their beliefs were
ridiculed. I assumed Mike's point was "let's not insult or build walls as a
group".  I read your post to say the same thing.

The only way to respect your religious opinion and Mike's, is to not have the
issue broached in the first place. We are usually a good group because we all
agree to respect each other and only talk about the charter of the group. The
charter isn't official, its what we all agree is acceptable to each other. That
is why we see these periodic flare ups. We are re-learning the boundaries that
a acceptable to the group as new and old, join and leave, the group. 

The only issue with this informal demonstration of community, is when we have a
rouge that won't accept the lack of formal boundaries.The only course is to use
inaction to become action. When we have a rouge, and the person posts out of
bound, ignoring the post is the only action that will force the rouge to
either, stop posting or post within the boundaries. 


With all respect to everyone
Russell

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Aug 25 22:48:40 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 22:48:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Port probes...
In-Reply-To: <3d69bcfb.60c4.0@pcez.com>
References: <3d69bcfb.60c4.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <200208252248.40919.aschlemm@attbi.com>

If you're referring to port 1433 it is quite common anymore. It might 
that SQLsnake worm that is looking for open SQL Server systems where it 
can attempt to crack the DB adminstrator password via brute force 
means. Once DB administrator access is obtained, queries can be run 
against the database and files can be modified on the system.

http://online.securityfocus.com/news/429

My cable modem has been lit up like a xmas tree for weeks and reminds me 
of the same sort of network activity I saw when when the Nimba virus 
was making the rounds.

Tony

On Sun, 25 Aug 2002, Russell Evans wrote:
> I read this a little differently. I thought Mike was pointing out that
> with little thought, Jeme insulted some people.

Well, I received both of Preston's posts in this thread, but oddly never
received either of the posts to which he was responding.  I've been
waiting to receive the original posts to respond, but it's been a couple
of days and they're not forthcoming.  Can anyone tell me why?

> The only issue with this informal demonstration of community, is when
> we have a rouge that won't accept the lack of formal boundaries.  The
> only course is to use inaction to become action. When we have a rouge,
> and the person posts out of bound, ignoring the post is the only
> action that will force the rouge to either, stop posting or post
> within the boundaries.

This is so close to how an anarchist system SHOULD work, it hurts.  The
one tiny detail that you don't seem to grasp is that ignoring the rogue
poster doesn't AND SHOULDN'T make him stop or change his behavior.  The
behavior simply becomes irrelevant.

Of course, that only holds for non-destructive behavior.

And in response to Mike, whose message never reached me (replies should 
probably go to plug-talk)...

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> Suckered in again, sorry.

By Christianity?

(Sorry, cheap shot but I couldn't pass it up.  Heh.)

> Mumbo-Jumbo?

Any object or personage of superstitious homage or fear.

Yup.  I'd call the anti-christ Mumbo Jumbo.

> Do you realize that the Bible and the Koran are major books in over
> 75% of the world's population?

First, what the hell does the Koran have to do with the anti-christ?  
Seeing as how the Koran doesn't include Christ as a divine figure, the
anti-christ has no meaning in that context.  So that's totally
meaningless.

Second, what does it mean to say that something is a "major book" and how
would that make the concept of the anti-christ NOT mumbo jumbo?

Third, did you just pull those numbers out of thin air?  (He chokes back
the more natural metaphor.)  The only real numbers I could find on the
subject was the breakdown here:
<URL: http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0904108.html >
This page gives estimates of about 53% for Christianity and Islam
combined.  And given the earlier statement that Islamic people have no
anti-christ and my anecdotal experience which informs me that many
Christians think the anti-christ is just so much ancient superstition, I'd
say we're talking about a fairly small minority indeed.

> Had you considered that most people would find your comment offensive?

No, I figured most people would agree that the anti-christ is an object of
superstitious fear and see the difference between that and the real danger
of greed and economic warfare in our civilization.

Those who would be offended are certainly in the minority.

Now, you want offensive?
<URL: http://www.brelin.net/~jeme/image/I_TT_NY.jpg >

Man, I can't wait to finish my screen press.

Although I don't agree with some things you've said in this thread
(speaking personally as an evil SuSE user), I agree with this. I look at
the use of "anti-christ" as being a rhetorical cousin to those things
which invoke Godwin's law. If you say someone else thinks X is the
"anti-christ" then you've essentially said you won't take the time to find
a better way to explain concerns people have with X company, that might
actually be legitimate in nature.

Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 16:54:06 -0700 (PDT)
From: Geoff Burling <geoff at agora.rdrop.com>
Reply-To: Geoff Burling <llywrch at agora.rdrop.com>
To: Portland Linux Users Group <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Linux Distros

[Apologies to the rest of the list, but Jeme has pressed a couple of
my hot butoons here his his response.]

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>
> On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > I agree.  RH is the most successful commercial distro so naturally
> > there's a backlash against them, I suppose.  RH has quite a few
> > developers on staff and contributes a lot of code to various open
> > source projects. But ooooohh...  they're a commercial company so that
> > automatically makes them the anti-christ, doesn't it.  Sheesh.
>
> Please don't use the term "anti-christ".  We should not confuse real-world
> evil with ancient mythological mumbo jumbo.

This is interesting. The ``ancient mythological mumbo jumbo" you mention --
the symbols, allusions & trope of the Judeo-Christian religion -- are part
& parcel of Western Civilization. Just as Buddhism is integral to Japanese
culture, Taoism to Chinese, & Hinduism to Indian. In other words, one
doesn't have to believe in the ideas this complex of symbols embraces, but
avoiding its contribution to our language impoverishes your ability to
communicate. According to the literary critic Northrop Frye, no major
literary work of Western Civilization since about AD 300 fails to use
this background either explicitly or implicitly. (And the exceptions draw
upon an alternative set of -- in your terms -- ``ancient mythological
mumbo jumbo".

And would you also object as vehmently to some using the term ``karma"?
Say in the phrase, ``So-&-so's karma finally caught up with him?"
>
> Red Hat has taken something truly progressive that could be a gateway into
> a new world of abundance and sharing and compromised it down to something
> palatable to the Capitalists.
>
> We have already shown that our community yields superior tools available
> to a greater number of people than any market could possibly produce, yet
> there are those among us who still believe it is necessary to inject
> greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation.
>
> Now, Debian has produced far superior software and greater distribution
> capacity (and I've yet to hear an argument to the contrary) while still
> holding strong to essentially progressive ideals.
>
I find nothing here but sloppy assertions & emotion. How has RH
corrupted ``something truly progressive"? Is it for reasons other than
they are a business & have been paid money for developing Linux?

How has RH injected ``greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation"?
You can still download their isos -- including source code -- from their
servers, they pay numerous developers to work on Linux code, and they
have donated money & labor to support computers in the North Carolina
school district. Am I missing something in how RH operates?

Has RH not abided to the terms of the GPL? And is following the GPL that
important? Linus doesn't appear to think so, otherwise he wouldn't be
using BitKeeper to manage his code.

>From what you wrote, Jeme, I see little more than a bit of disingenious
distro-bashing. And if this is all you have to offer in defense of your
attack on Red Hat, I am not persuaded by your arguments.

Geoff





From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Aug 26 06:02:40 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 06:02:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros

On Sun, 25 Aug 2002, Geoff Burling wrote:
> Obviously, you never received my response. Find it below.

I hadn't received your response.  What the heck is up with this?  My mail
logs don't show any bounces.  Can someone give me a pointer on next steps
to troubleshooting this?

> From: Geoff Burling <geoff at agora.rdrop.com>
> 
> On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > > But ooooohh...  they're a commercial company so that automatically
> > > makes them the anti-christ, doesn't it.  Sheesh.
> >
> > Please don't use the term "anti-christ".  We should not confuse real-world
> > evil with ancient mythological mumbo jumbo.
> 
> This is interesting. The ``ancient mythological mumbo jumbo" you
> mention -- the symbols, allusions & trope of the Judeo-Christian
> religion -- are part & parcel of Western Civilization.

I agree that the symbols, allusions and tropes can be used throughout
western civilization with reasonable expectation of understanding,
acceptance, and even resonance.  I don't disagree with your sentiment here
at all.

My qualm here was with his choice of metaphors.  The anti-christ,
according to the superstitions of the Christians, works toward evil ends,
rejoices in evil, and simply IS evil.  In the real world, very few bad
things are so straightforward.  The idea that any thing in the real world
could be as purely evil as the anti-christ is, of course, absurd and
therefore causes readers to dismiss the concept that corporations could be
evil at all since they're obviously not the anti-christ.

It's late and I hope that makes sense.

I'm sure there's a proper rhetorical term for that kind of association,
but it escapes me at the moment.

> (And the exceptions draw upon an alternative set of -- in your terms
> -- ``ancient mythological mumbo jumbo".

I don't disagree with anything you wrote, Geoff.  I feel you misunderstood
my intent.  I can't tell you right now who is at fault in that
misunderstanding, if anyone.

> And would you also object as vehmently to some using the term
> ``karma"? Say in the phrase, ``So-&-so's karma finally caught up with
> him?"

First and foremost, I would hardly call a one line objection "vehement".  
I was objecting to his rhetorical method, not his choice of terms.

A mumbo jumbo is a great evil to be feared because of superstition or
religion whereas a corporation is a great evil to be fought because of its
degradation of human interaction and debasement and devaluation of life.

> > Red Hat has taken something truly progressive that could be a gateway into
> > a new world of abundance and sharing and compromised it down to something
> > palatable to the Capitalists.
> >
> > We have already shown that our community yields superior tools available
> > to a greater number of people than any market could possibly produce, yet
> > there are those among us who still believe it is necessary to inject
> > greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation.
> >
> > Now, Debian has produced far superior software and greater distribution
> > capacity (and I've yet to hear an argument to the contrary) while still
> > holding strong to essentially progressive ideals.
>
> I find nothing here but sloppy assertions & emotion.

I would say that's because you don't understand economic and class
warfare.

> How has RH corrupted ``something truly progressive"? Is it for reasons
> other than they are a business & have been paid money for developing
> Linux?

Red Hat, Inc. has corrupted the truly progressive Free Software community
by developing, encouraging, and marketting an alternative community that
compromises the ethics of the purely anarchic social structure of Free
Software in favor of the greed and exploitation based hierarchical
structure of corporate America.

I would say that the inception of Red Hat, Inc. was an unavoidable part of
this struggle between the old and new worlds.  Red Hat is no more or less
evil than any other commercial operation.  The truly disappointing (and
destructive to any hope of a progressive revolution) thing is that some
would choose this compromised alternative over one of the many that carry
higher ideals.

> How has RH injected ``greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation"?

By working for profit.  By restricting access to paying customers.  By
keeping wage slaves.  By selling shares on the stock market.

> You can still download their isos -- including source code -- from
> their servers, they pay numerous developers to work on Linux code, and
> they have donated money & labor to support computers in the North
> Carolina school district. Am I missing something in how RH operates?

You're missing all the ways in which Red Hat, Inc. is like every other
profit driven corporation beholden to investors.

> Has RH not abided to the terms of the GPL?

I think a fair argument can be made that Red Hat's relationship with
certain hardware vendors is responsible for the potentially GPL violating
code included in the Linux kernel source.

> And is following the GPL that important?

Absolutely.  The GPL is that unique thing in our community that prevents
us from being exploited.

> Linus doesn't appear to think so, otherwise he wouldn't be using
> BitKeeper to manage his code.

Linus is an amoral twit.  He has practically no ethics whatsoever beyond
his own personal happiness.

I've written a hundred times that this whole world would be a better place
if Linus had just handed his copyrights to the FSF in 1994.

> From what you wrote, Jeme, I see little more than a bit of
> disingenious distro-bashing.

It's not distro-bashing, it's ideology-bashing.

> And if this is all you have to offer in defense of your attack on Red
> Hat, I am not persuaded by your arguments.

You didn't understand a word I wrote, sir.

J.

From prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com  Tue Aug 27 06:39:20 2002
From: prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com (Preston Crawford)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 06:39:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208252321220.3323-100000@joan.burling.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208270633470.4409-100000@serpentor.cobrala>


On Sun, 25 Aug 2002, Geoff Burling wrote:

> > Please don't use the term "anti-christ".  We should not confuse real-world
> > evil with ancient mythological mumbo jumbo.
>
> This is interesting. The ``ancient mythological mumbo jumbo" you mention --
> the symbols, allusions & trope of the Judeo-Christian religion -- are part
> & parcel of Western Civilization. Just as Buddhism is integral to Japanese
> culture, Taoism to Chinese, & Hinduism to Indian. In other words, one
> doesn't have to believe in the ideas this complex of symbols embraces, but
> avoiding its contribution to our language impoverishes your ability to
> communicate. According to the literary critic Northrop Frye, no major
> literary work of Western Civilization since about AD 300 fails to use
> this background either explicitly or implicitly. (And the exceptions draw
> upon an alternative set of -- in your terms -- ``ancient mythological
> mumbo jumbo".

As I said earlier, I think using the term "anti-christ" shows a lack of
ability to communicate. It's the rhetorical cousin to comparing someone to
Nazis or Hitler, in mhy opinion. It shows that the person using the term
doesn't have the ability at the time to come up with a meaningful way to
explain his opponents position. It's very easy to say "All you people
think Red Hat's the anti-christ." Rather than to say something more
meaningful.

Secondly, I'm not sure how ancient the tradition of the anti-christ is. My
understanding is that Revelations was included into the New Testament
somewhere during the middle ages, by the Catholic Church. It didn't used
to be part of the Bible originally.

Anyway, other than that, I agree with the rest of what you said. I just
think using "anti-christ" is kind of weak. Getting offended or bothered by
it is silly, but it's still a weak term to use.

Preston




From prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com  Tue Aug 27 06:48:21 2002

> > How has RH corrupted ``something truly progressive"? Is it for reasons
> > other than they are a business & have been paid money for developing
> > Linux?
>
> Red Hat, Inc. has corrupted the truly progressive Free Software community
> by developing, encouraging, and marketting an alternative community that
> compromises the ethics of the purely anarchic social structure of Free
> Software in favor of the greed and exploitation based hierarchical
> structure of corporate America.

???

That's a huge assertion to make without more explaination. Not that I want
you to explain that "mumbo-jumbo", but it just doesn't make sense as
explained there.

> I would say that the inception of Red Hat, Inc. was an unavoidable part of
> this struggle between the old and new worlds.  Red Hat is no more or less
> evil than any other commercial operation.  The truly disappointing (and
> destructive to any hope of a progressive revolution) thing is that some
> would choose this compromised alternative over one of the many that carry
> higher ideals.

It's called pragmatism. It's not evil. In fact it's sometimes necessary to
make true progress.

> > How has RH injected ``greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation"?
>
> By working for profit.  By restricting access to paying customers.  By
> keeping wage slaves.  By selling shares on the stock market.

I'll agree regarding the stock market, because I think the stock market is
a ponzi scheme designed to shake down the average investor (or at least,
that's how it's operated now). The rest of this, is "mumbo-jumbo". :-)

> Linus is an amoral twit.  He has practically no ethics whatsoever beyond
> his own personal happiness.
>
> I've written a hundred times that this whole world would be a better place
> if Linus had just handed his copyrights to the FSF in 1994.

?????

Care to back that up, or just let the stand as is?

> > And if this is all you have to offer in defense of your attack on Red
> > Hat, I am not persuaded by your arguments.
>
> You didn't understand a word I wrote, sir.

And your argument sounds like a foreign language to me. I consider myself
extremely liberal, but a lot of what I just read doesn't make any sense to
me in the current context. Maybe that's just because you sling rhetoric
without explaining why "Linus is an amoral twit".

Preston




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Aug 26 07:17:02 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 07:17:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208260707150.24839-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I apologize to the list subscribers for inadvertently sparking the
off-topic thread I had hoped to avoid.

  My intention was to understand why people feel so strongly pro or con
various distributions, not to generate traffic on a slow weekend. Naively, I
hoped to read a few thoughtful, reasoned replies. I did receive one for
which I will extend my thanks. In my opinion, objective consideration of why
people make the choices they do in the open source community would help us
to better communicate the advantages to the non-user: individual or
business.

  Anyway, I will no longer ask philosophical questions on this list and will
have to satisfy my intellectual curiosity in other fora. I am continually
disappointed in how quickly a thread can veer off into emotional language
that invariably pushes someone's hot button.

Mea culpa!

Rich

Yes, it's pretty pitiful. I made a filter that deletes Jeme's posts on 
arrival, and manually delete every post that replies to any of his insulting 
nonsense. It is fast and easy, and an amazingly large number of interesting, 
relevant messages remain. 

It only takes one troll, and other people taking the bait, to derail and 
spoil a discussion.

From auto22879 at yahoo.com  Mon Aug 26 10:10:01 2002

I'm the guy who started this thread and my question
still isn't answered.  

Is there a place in the greater Portland area where I
can buy just the distribution of say Red Hat or Debian
for a really low price?  I like to buy them from Linux
Central but the shipping cost is too high so I am
looking for alternates.  Red Hat from Linux Centeral
costs $7 and Debian costs $14.

I am new to the list and I don't understand how a
simple yes/no question could have devolved into
something that has dominated this list for the last 4
days.  

Let's keep our discussion on Linux technical issues
and leave the philosophy to others.  

Don




Send PLUG mailing list submissions to
	plug at lists.pdxlinux.org

To subscribe or unsubscribe via the World Wide Web,
visit
	http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
or, via email, send a message with subject or body
'help' to
	plug-request at lists.pdxlinux.org

You can reach the person managing the list at
	plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org

When replying, please edit your Subject line so it is
more specific
than "Re: Contents of PLUG digest..."

Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 16:54:06 -0700 (PDT)
From: Geoff Burling <geoff at agora.rdrop.com>
Reply-To: Geoff Burling <llywrch at agora.rdrop.com>
To: Portland Linux Users Group
<plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Linux Distros

[Apologies to the rest of the list, but Jeme has
pressed a couple of
my hot butoons here his his response.]

On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>
> On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > I agree.  RH is the most successful commercial
distro so naturally
> > there's a backlash against them, I suppose.  RH
has quite a few
> > developers on staff and contributes a lot of code
to various open
> > source projects. But ooooohh...  they're a
commercial company so 
that
> > automatically makes them the anti-christ, doesn't
it.  Sheesh.
>
> Please don't use the term "anti-christ".  We should
not confuse 
real-world
> evil with ancient mythological mumbo jumbo.

This is interesting. The ``ancient mythological mumbo
jumbo" you 
mention --
the symbols, allusions & trope of the Judeo-Christian
religion -- are 
part
& parcel of Western Civilization. Just as Buddhism is
integral to 
Japanese
culture, Taoism to Chinese, & Hinduism to Indian. In
other words, one
doesn't have to believe in the ideas this complex of
symbols embraces, 
but
avoiding its contribution to our language impoverishes
your ability to
communicate. According to the literary critic Northrop
Frye, no major
literary work of Western Civilization since about AD
300 fails to use
this background either explicitly or implicitly. (And
the exceptions 
draw
upon an alternative set of -- in your terms --
``ancient mythological
mumbo jumbo".

And would you also object as vehmently to some using
the term ``karma"?
Say in the phrase, ``So-&-so's karma finally caught up
with him?"
>
> Red Hat has taken something truly progressive that
could be a gateway 
into
> a new world of abundance and sharing and compromised
it down to 
something
> palatable to the Capitalists.
>
> We have already shown that our community yields
superior tools 
available
> to a greater number of people than any market could
possibly produce, 
yet
> there are those among us who still believe it is
necessary to inject
> greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation.
>
> Now, Debian has produced far superior software and
greater 
distribution
> capacity (and I've yet to hear an argument to the
contrary) while 
still
> holding strong to essentially progressive ideals.
>
I find nothing here but sloppy assertions & emotion.
How has RH
corrupted ``something truly progressive"? Is it for
reasons other than
they are a business & have been paid money for
developing Linux?

How has RH injected ``greed, selfishness, scarcity,
and exploitation"?
You can still download their isos -- including source
code -- from 
their
servers, they pay numerous developers to work on Linux
code, and they
have donated money & labor to support computers in the
North Carolina
school district. Am I missing something in how RH
operates?

Has RH not abided to the terms of the GPL? And is
following the GPL 
that
important? Linus doesn't appear to think so, otherwise
he wouldn't be
using BitKeeper to manage his code.

>From what you wrote, Jeme, I see little more than a
bit of disingenious
distro-bashing. And if this is all you have to offer
in defense of your
attack on Red Hat, I am not persuaded by your
arguments.

Geoff

Message: 3
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 06:02:40 -0700 (PDT)

On Sun, 25 Aug 2002, Geoff Burling wrote:
> Obviously, you never received my response. Find it
below.

I hadn't received your response.  What the heck is up
with this?  My 
mail
logs don't show any bounces.  Can someone give me a
pointer on next 
steps
to troubleshooting this?

> From: Geoff Burling <geoff at agora.rdrop.com>
> 
> On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > On Fri, 23 Aug 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > > But ooooohh...  they're a commercial company so
that 
automatically
> > > makes them the anti-christ, doesn't it.  Sheesh.
> >
> > Please don't use the term "anti-christ".  We
should not confuse 
real-world
> > evil with ancient mythological mumbo jumbo.
> 
> This is interesting. The ``ancient mythological
mumbo jumbo" you
> mention -- the symbols, allusions & trope of the
Judeo-Christian
> religion -- are part & parcel of Western
Civilization.

I agree that the symbols, allusions and tropes can be
used throughout
western civilization with reasonable expectation of
understanding,
acceptance, and even resonance.  I don't disagree with
your sentiment 
here
at all.

My qualm here was with his choice of metaphors.  The
anti-christ,
according to the superstitions of the Christians,
works toward evil 
ends,
rejoices in evil, and simply IS evil.  In the real
world, very few bad
things are so straightforward.  The idea that any
thing in the real 
world
could be as purely evil as the anti-christ is, of
course, absurd and
therefore causes readers to dismiss the concept that
corporations could 
be
evil at all since they're obviously not the
anti-christ.

It's late and I hope that makes sense.

I'm sure there's a proper rhetorical term for that
kind of association,
but it escapes me at the moment.

> (And the exceptions draw upon an alternative set of
-- in your terms
> -- ``ancient mythological mumbo jumbo".

I don't disagree with anything you wrote, Geoff.  I
feel you 
misunderstood
my intent.  I can't tell you right now who is at fault
in that
misunderstanding, if anyone.

> And would you also object as vehmently to some using
the term
> ``karma"? Say in the phrase, ``So-&-so's karma
finally caught up with
> him?"

First and foremost, I would hardly call a one line
objection 
"vehement".  
I was objecting to his rhetorical method, not his
choice of terms.

A mumbo jumbo is a great evil to be feared because of
superstition or
religion whereas a corporation is a great evil to be
fought because of 
its
degradation of human interaction and debasement and
devaluation of 
life.

> > Red Hat has taken something truly progressive that
could be a 
gateway into
> > a new world of abundance and sharing and
compromised it down to 
something
> > palatable to the Capitalists.
> >
> > We have already shown that our community yields
superior tools 
available
> > to a greater number of people than any market
could possibly 
produce, yet
> > there are those among us who still believe it is
necessary to 
inject
> > greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation.
> >
> > Now, Debian has produced far superior software and
greater 
distribution
> > capacity (and I've yet to hear an argument to the
contrary) while 
still
> > holding strong to essentially progressive ideals.
>
> I find nothing here but sloppy assertions & emotion.

I would say that's because you don't understand
economic and class
warfare.

> How has RH corrupted ``something truly progressive"?
Is it for 
reasons
> other than they are a business & have been paid
money for developing
> Linux?

Red Hat, Inc. has corrupted the truly progressive Free
Software 
community
by developing, encouraging, and marketting an
alternative community 
that
compromises the ethics of the purely anarchic social
structure of Free
Software in favor of the greed and exploitation based
hierarchical
structure of corporate America.

I would say that the inception of Red Hat, Inc. was an
unavoidable part 
of
this struggle between the old and new worlds.  Red Hat
is no more or 
less
evil than any other commercial operation.  The truly
disappointing (and
destructive to any hope of a progressive revolution)
thing is that some
would choose this compromised alternative over one of
the many that 
carry
higher ideals.

> How has RH injected ``greed, selfishness, scarcity,
and 
exploitation"?

By working for profit.  By restricting access to
paying customers.  By
keeping wage slaves.  By selling shares on the stock
market.

> You can still download their isos -- including
source code -- from
> their servers, they pay numerous developers to work
on Linux code, 
and
> they have donated money & labor to support computers
in the North
> Carolina school district. Am I missing something in
how RH operates?

You're missing all the ways in which Red Hat, Inc. is
like every other
profit driven corporation beholden to investors.

> Has RH not abided to the terms of the GPL?

I think a fair argument can be made that Red Hat's
relationship with
certain hardware vendors is responsible for the
potentially GPL 
violating
code included in the Linux kernel source.

> And is following the GPL that important?

Absolutely.  The GPL is that unique thing in our
community that 
prevents
us from being exploited.

> Linus doesn't appear to think so, otherwise he
wouldn't be using
> BitKeeper to manage his code.

Linus is an amoral twit.  He has practically no ethics
whatsoever 
beyond
his own personal happiness.

I've written a hundred times that this whole world
would be a better 
place
if Linus had just handed his copyrights to the FSF in
1994.

> From what you wrote, Jeme, I see little more than a
bit of
> disingenious distro-bashing.

It's not distro-bashing, it's ideology-bashing.

> And if this is all you have to offer in defense of
your attack on Red
> Hat, I am not persuaded by your arguments.

You didn't understand a word I wrote, sir.

J.

Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 06:39:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: Preston Crawford

Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org



On Sun, 25 Aug 2002, Geoff Burling wrote:

> > Please don't use the term "anti-christ".  We
should not confuse 
real-world
> > evil with ancient mythological mumbo jumbo.
>
> This is interesting. The ``ancient mythological
mumbo jumbo" you 
mention --
> the symbols, allusions & trope of the
Judeo-Christian religion -- are 
part
> & parcel of Western Civilization. Just as Buddhism
is integral to 
Japanese
> culture, Taoism to Chinese, & Hinduism to Indian. In
other words, one
> doesn't have to believe in the ideas this complex of
symbols 
embraces, but
> avoiding its contribution to our language
impoverishes your ability 
to
> communicate. According to the literary critic
Northrop Frye, no major
> literary work of Western Civilization since about AD
300 fails to use
> this background either explicitly or implicitly.
(And the exceptions 
draw
> upon an alternative set of -- in your terms --
``ancient mythological
> mumbo jumbo".

As I said earlier, I think using the term
"anti-christ" shows a lack of
ability to communicate. It's the rhetorical cousin to
comparing someone 
to
Nazis or Hitler, in mhy opinion. It shows that the
person using the 
term
doesn't have the ability at the time to come up with a
meaningful way 
to
explain his opponents position. It's very easy to say
"All you people
think Red Hat's the anti-christ." Rather than to say
something more
meaningful.

Secondly, I'm not sure how ancient the tradition of
the anti-christ is. 
My
understanding is that Revelations was included into
the New Testament
somewhere during the middle ages, by the Catholic
Church. It didn't 
used
to be part of the Bible originally.

Anyway, other than that, I agree with the rest of what
you said. I just
think using "anti-christ" is kind of weak. Getting
offended or bothered 
by
it is silly, but it's still a weak term to use.

Preston

to

paying customers.

> keeping wage slaves.  By selling shares on the stock

is

you sling rhetoric
without explaining why "Linus is an amoral twit".

  I apologize to the list subscribers for
inadvertently sparking the
off-topic thread I had hoped to avoid.

  My intention was to understand why people feel so
strongly pro or con
various distributions, not to generate traffic on a
slow weekend. 
Naively, I
hoped to read a few thoughtful, reasoned replies. I
did receive one for
which I will extend my thanks. In my opinion,
objective consideration 
of why
people make the choices they do in the open source
community would help 
us
to better communicate the advantages to the non-user:
individual or
business.

  Anyway, I will no longer ask philosophical questions
on this list and 
will
have to satisfy my intellectual curiosity in other
fora. I am 
continually
disappointed in how quickly a thread can veer off into
emotional 
language
that invariably pushes someone's hot button.

Mea culpa!

Rich



--__--__--

If you can't find a suitable local option, you might want to try 
www.cheapbytes.com.  For example:

Unofficial redhat 5 cd set $9 + $6.50 UPS Ground (or $5 US Mail)

Debian 3.0 x86 binary 8 cd set $18 + $6.50 UPS Ground (or $5 US Mail)

Be aware that these are strictly the CD's.  No manuals, support, etc.
They do sell the official versions of Redhat, Suse, etc., but of course
it will cost more.

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Aug 26 11:03:28 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 26 Aug 2002 11:03:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] GCC 3.2 and the kernel warning
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208261001010.16407-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Message-ID: <1030385008.21998.4.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Mon, 2002-08-26 at 10:03, Jason Dagit wrote:
> The new matrox parahilea(sp??) is pretty good and even more expensive.
> The new nvidia geforce 4 ti4600 has about the same MSRP, but the matrox
> card will cost you a lot more in practice.  I don't know how good the
> matrox drivers are, or if they are open source. But I think they are...
> Anyone have that card?

The Matrox cards tend to have faster 2D. The nVIDIA has faster 3D.  Both
have proprietary libraries needed for full use.  (The Matrox libraries
are less obnoxious.)  The main reason for the Matrox Hardware
Abstraction Library being closed source is that there is one bit in the
library that controls Macrovision(tm).  They don't want that information
getting out.  (Even though I have the exact location somewhere in this
mess...)

One bit to rule them all and in the darkness bind them...

> 
> Jason
>

From montagne at boora.com  Mon Aug 26 12:41:11 2002
From: montagne at boora.com (Michael Montagne)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 12:41:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] .gz file extraction
Message-ID: <20020826194111.GA7642@boora.com>

I downloaded a bunch of source code the other day that came as a .gz
file.  When I extract it with "gunzip filename", it creates a huge file.  But, it
is supposed to be a directory with files in it.  If I use "ark", the KDE
archiver, I can extract them correctly.  
But I don't want to rely on KDE.  I should be able to tell (or at least
extract to the correct format)using standard tools.  What am I doing
wrong?  
This is the URL of the site where I downloaded the .gz file.

http://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=30996&release_id=104823


-- 
  Michael Montagne  [montagne at boora.com]   503.226.1575

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Mon Aug 26 12:48:08 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 12:48:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] .gz file extraction
References: <20020826194111.GA7642@boora.com>
Message-ID: <3D6A85F8.1020505@parkrose.k12.or.us>

Michael Montagne wrote:
> I downloaded a bunch of source code the other day that came as a .gz
> file.  When I extract it with "gunzip filename", it creates a huge file.  But, it
> is supposed to be a directory with files in it.  If I use "ark", the KDE
> archiver, I can extract them correctly.  
> But I don't want to rely on KDE.  I should be able to tell (or at least
> extract to the correct format)using standard tools.  What am I doing
> wrong?

gunzip will unzip the file into a "tarball". tar is the utility to break 
the tarball into the folder and individual files you seek.

tar -xvf filename.tar

Multiple, small tools all doing their part is the Unix Way.

tar -xvzf filename.tar.gz

will unzip and untar in one step, FWIW.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District





From sean at fork.com  Mon Aug 26 12:54:12 2002
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 12:54:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] .gz file extraction
In-Reply-To: <20020826194111.GA7642@boora.com>
References: <20020826194111.GA7642@boora.com>
Message-ID: <20020826195413.49DFB2EFB9@einstein.seansdomain.org>

I am assuming here but if the file you downloaded is a .tar.gz file, try this

tar xvfz file.tar.gz

This should gunzip and untar it into the appropriate directory structure that 
you are expecting.

If it's already gunzipped.  Try tar xvf file.tar and it should create the 
filestructure and files you are expecting.

Sean

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon Aug 26 13:20:47 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (E. Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 13:20:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] .gz file extraction
In-Reply-To: <20020826195840.GA7767@boora.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208261316450.16618-100000@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

"file" is a very good tool for this sort of thing, it will tell you what a
file is, regardless of the extension (within the capabilities of it's
database).

$ file testFile.tar.gz
testFile.tar.gz: gzip compressed data, deflated, last modified: Sat Nov 10
15:23:37 2001, max compression, os: Unix

$ gunzip testFile.tar.gz

$ file testFile.tar
testFile.tar: GNU tar archive

$ mv testFile.tar tstfile
`testFile.tar' -> `tstfile'

$ file tstfile
tstfile: GNU tar archive


-Rogan

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Aug 26 14:15:55 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 14:15:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208270640170.4409-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208261326110.31612-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 27 Aug 2002, Preston Crawford wrote:
> 
> On Mon, 26 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > Red Hat, Inc. has corrupted the truly progressive Free Software community
> > by developing, encouraging, and marketting an alternative community that
> > compromises the ethics of the purely anarchic social structure of Free
> > Software in favor of the greed and exploitation based hierarchical
> > structure of corporate America.
> 
> ???
> 
> That's a huge assertion to make without more explaination.

...from where you're sitting.  I don't mean that as an insult, I just mean
that, given a certain critical framework, it's a fairly straightforward
recognition of the obvious.

However, I did say that I wasn't choosing my best words.  It was quite
late.

> Not that I want you to explain that "mumbo-jumbo", but it just doesn't
> make sense as explained there.

It's fairly simple.  Red Hat's purpose for being is to "increase
shareholder value" while doing all the same stuff that the community could
(and does) do for itself without the extraneous fatcat fattening.  Red Hat
then pushes this on people through marketting and an agressive PR
campaign.  All this adds up to folks who could be part of a progressive
system [as] outside the destructive Capitalist economy [as possible]
being, instead, little more than "software consumers".

And for an idea of how they corrupt the Free Software ethic, see their
page on software patents.  I don't fault them for their paltry
justification of their hyprocritical stance.  We all know how hard it is
to explain everything about a complex situation in a document read
casually and in short time.  However, they do go on to invent a new,
misleading term "Open Source/Free Software" (great idea, since people
think it means two different things already) and define it to mean
software licensed under ANY LICENSE RED HAT ISSUES.

So Red Hat is an undemocratic organization unaccountable to the community
that simply assumes the power to define and redefine important terms at
will (whatever will can be attributed to a beast made up of hundreds of
self-interested parties acting under selfish, greedy motivation) and use
those terms in the popular media as if they have commonly accepted
definitions.

> > I would say that the inception of Red Hat, Inc. was an unavoidable part of
> > this struggle between the old and new worlds.  Red Hat is no more or less
> > evil than any other commercial operation.  The truly disappointing (and
> > destructive to any hope of a progressive revolution) thing is that some
> > would choose this compromised alternative over one of the many that carry
> > higher ideals.
> 
> It's called pragmatism. It's not evil. In fact it's sometimes
> necessary to make true progress.

Pragmatism is an agent of evil.  Pragmatism is a type of situational
ethics that allows one to justify their evil as somehow less evil than it
would be in other circumstances.  I personally believe that a situation
can make an evil perhaps necessary, but no less evil.

But anyway, this isn't a matter of pragmatism AT ALL.  There are
organizations who provide the same or better services to the Free Software
community who do not make the same compromises to the existing power
structure.

> > > How has RH injected ``greed, selfishness, scarcity, and exploitation"?
> >
> > By working for profit.  By restricting access to paying customers.  By
> > keeping wage slaves.  By selling shares on the stock market.
> 
> I'll agree regarding the stock market, because I think the stock
> market is a ponzi scheme designed to shake down the average investor
> (or at least, that's how it's operated now).

The single effect of the stockmarket that makes it both the most
destructive to life and freedom and a most desirable to the powers that be
is the removal of accountability and motivation from the hands of those
who manage or maintain a "public" company and replacing all ethics and
morality with greed and profit motive.

Nearly every company that lends its name to stock traded on the market
modifies its mission statement so that the primary verb is "to increase
shareholder value" (in one form of the words or another).  The primary
motivators go out the window at that point.  If the board of such an
organization decides to make a major decision based on something other
than a consideration for shareholder value, they can be sued into
submission to the will of the profiteers.

That aside, you don't see how the up2date system increases scarcity (to
pick one of my other above statements at random)?

> The rest of this, is "mumbo-jumbo". :-)

I guess you're using the second sense of the word meaning "unnecessarily
overcomplicated"?  I guess this because I don't see any superstitious fear
here.  I have real-world rationale for each of those statements.

> > Linus is an amoral twit.  He has practically no ethics whatsoever beyond
> > his own personal happiness.
> >
> > I've written a hundred times that this whole world would be a better place
> > if Linus had just handed his copyrights to the FSF in 1994.
> 
> ?????
> 
> Care to back that up, or just let the stand as is?

Did you read his book?  Do you listen to him in interviews?  Do you read
his arguments on the kernel dev list?

He repeatedly states that he has no particular moral drive and his ethics
depend almost entirely on what is fun or easy.  He is a situational
ethicist at best and amoral at worst.

So I'll grant you that "amoral" was assuming the worst, but it is a
reasonable assumption given his comments.  And I'll also admit that "twit"
was just vitriole.

> > > And if this is all you have to offer in defense of your attack on Red
> > > Hat, I am not persuaded by your arguments.
> >
> > You didn't understand a word I wrote, sir.
> 
> And your argument sounds like a foreign language to me.

And that's totally OK!  I mean, it's disappointing and all, but it's great
that you didn't assume I wasn't making sense (all the time... you did
assume that a couple of times, I think) just because you don't have the
framework in which to couch my arguments.

Anyway, you're exactly right.  The language of class and economic warfare
is foreign to most Americans.  Every institution in our civilization is
driven by the overriding economic and political system.  All evolved
systems are somewhat resistant to change and self-protecting.  The concept
of class or economic warfare within that system is destructive to the
system and therefore not acceptable subject matter.

And so we are told to believe that our society is classless and since
there is no ruling class, there is no systematic method by which the
ruling class maintains its power and subjugates the other classes.

> I consider myself extremely liberal, but a lot of what I just read
> doesn't make any sense to me in the current context.

Would you like some suggested reading to expand your context?

> Maybe that's just because you sling rhetoric without explaining why
> "Linus is an amoral twit".

I do apologize for the insulting "twit" comment, but I really did think
that people understood that Linus was not involved in Free Software for
any ethical or moral reason whatsoever.  Even the title of his book show
that his hedonism overrides any consideration of the greater societal
effects of his actions.

J.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Aug 26 13:30:38 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 26 Aug 2002 13:30:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] GCC 3.2 and the kernel warning
In-Reply-To: <3D6A58B2.6010106@sun.com>

	<1030145625.4704.2.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

>>>>> "Richard" == Richard Langis <richard.langis at sun.com> writes:

Richard> Okay then...here's a question: What's a nice, fast, 3D aware,
Richard> OpenGL and/or DX (for you dual-boot fans), Linux and X
Richard> supported Video card?  With *good* open-source/GNU drivers?

If I was in the market for such a thing, I think I'd start at the
xfree86.org web site.  Also, either check their mailing list archives
or subscribe and ask myself.  

Remember, the more you are willing to accept proprietary drivers, the
less likely are manufacturers to respect your freedom by releasing the
necessary information to write free ones.  I prefer to boycott
proprietary hardware, which is certainly my right even in this
country, at least so far.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon Aug 26 13:35:26 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 13:35:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] .gz file extraction
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208261316450.16618-100000@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <3D6A910E.1040200@sun.com>

I've seen this myself - sometimes people rename them to .gz even though 
they're a tar archive ONLY, or vice-versa.

Instead of running them through file or whatnot, I just try to either 
gunzip or untar them individually.  So far, it's worked 100% of the 
time.  YMMV.

-R

E. Rogan Creswick wrote:
> "file" is a very good tool for this sort of thing, it will tell you what a
> file is, regardless of the extension (within the capabilities of it's
> database).
> 
> $ file testFile.tar.gz
> testFile.tar.gz: gzip compressed data, deflated, last modified: Sat Nov 10
> 15:23:37 2001, max compression, os: Unix
> 
> $ gunzip testFile.tar.gz
> 
> $ file testFile.tar
> testFile.tar: GNU tar archive
> 
> $ mv testFile.tar tstfile
> `testFile.tar' -> `tstfile'
> 
> $ file tstfile
> tstfile: GNU tar archive
> 
> 
> -Rogan
> 
> On Mon, 26 Aug 2002, Michael Montagne wrote:
> 
> 
>>Yeah, that's what I needed...tar.  But the extension of the file I
>>downloaded was not .tat.gz.  It was just .gz.  The only clue is the file
>>name I guess.
>>
>>
>>
>>>On 26/08/02, from the brain of Sean Whitney tumbled:
>>
>>>I am assuming here but if the file you downloaded is a .tar.gz file, try this
>>>
>>>tar xvfz file.tar.gz
>>>
>>>This should gunzip and untar it into the appropriate directory structure that
>>>you are expecting.
>>>
>>>If it's already gunzipped.  Try tar xvf file.tar and it should create the
>>>filestructure and files you are expecting.
>>>
>>>Sean
>>>
>>>On Monday 26 August 2002 12:41, you wrote:
>>>
>>>>I downloaded a bunch of source code the other day that came as a .gz
>>>>file.  When I extract it with "gunzip filename", it creates a huge file.
>>>>But, it is supposed to be a directory with files in it.  If I use "ark",
>>>>the KDE archiver, I can extract them correctly.
>>>>But I don't want to rely on KDE.  I should be able to tell (or at least
>>>>extract to the correct format)using standard tools.  What am I doing
>>>>wrong?
