From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Aug 26 14:23:44 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 14:23:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <200208261525.g7QFPlc15342@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208261416100.31612-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 26 Aug 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Yes, it's pretty pitiful. I made a filter that deletes Jeme's posts on
> arrival, and manually delete every post that replies to any of his
> insulting nonsense. It is fast and easy, and an amazingly large number
> of interesting, relevant messages remain.

Isn't it great how we can automate ignorance?

At least when you're manually deleting a post, you know you're missing
something and you're making a choice not to know every time.  With an
automated action, you can completely forget that you've got your head in
the sand.

I've often said that mass communication has one truly socially destructive
aspect:  It allows a person to communicate with like-minded people to the
near exclusion of all others.  It started with the telephone and has only
been exacerbated by the internet.  Why talk to your next door neighbor
when you can call someone that's already a friend?  Why discuss things
with the entire community when you can build a Yahoo Group that can be
moderated down to the people who all have the compatible opinions?

> It only takes one troll, and other people taking the bait, to derail and 
> spoil a discussion.

Until folks started bashing MY ideology, the discussion was completely
on-topic.

Richard asked WHY we get into repeated and essentially identical arguments
about distributions every few months and I made an attempt to show that
the reason for the repetition is a total failure to come to any rational
conclusion because Red Hat users work very hard to dismiss the argument as
irrelevant and simply a matter of preference and so the real discussion of
technical or ethical consideration is buried and no resolution can be
made.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Aug 26 13:35:38 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 13:35:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] .gz file extraction
In-Reply-To: <20020826195840.GA7767@boora.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208261330270.26130-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 26 Aug 2002, Michael Montagne wrote:

> Yeah, that's what I needed...tar.  But the extension of the file I
> downloaded was not .tat.gz.  It was just .gz.  The only clue is the file
> name I guess.

  Unlike another operating system that shall go un-named here, there is no
hard and fast rule for extensions in linux compressed files. By
_convention_, files compressed by the 'compress' utility end in .Z, those
squished by gzip end in .gz, and Tape ARchived (tar) files end in .tar.

  When a bunch of files are both tarred and gzipped, the creater usually
names the resulting file as either .tar.gz or .tgz. But, the file could be
named *.herman and it would work as well.

HTH,

Rich

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Mon Aug 26 14:33:50 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 14:33:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] .gz file extraction
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208261330270.26130-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208261407040.16407-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Mon, 26 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   When a bunch of files are both tarred and gzipped, the creater usually
> names the resulting file as either .tar.gz or .tgz. But, the file could be
> named *.herman and it would work as well.

You could, if you are sadistic about it, embed terminal control codes into
the file name.  (I did this once on accident).  It can be a lot of fun,
maybe the file name is *.herman^H^H^Htoo.  Under normal conditions with ls
it would display as *.hertoo.  But if you try to open the file you will
find that it doesn't exist, neither would *.herman.  Finally one day I was
in dired mode in emacs and saw the real filename.

Ah the joy of file names.... :)

Jason




From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Mon Aug 26 14:38:10 2002
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: 26 Aug 2002 14:38:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CRIME meeting 09/102002 @ 10AM @ Verizon Airtouch
Message-ID: <1030397890.11859.29.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

CRIME meeting 05/12/2002 @ 10AM @ Verizon Airtouch

Speaker(s): Gene Kim, CTO Tripwire

Subject:  "An IT Safety Metric: Why Is It So Difficult To Maintain
Control?"

Directions: C.R.I.M.E. meets in the Verizon (Airtouch) Cellular building (Take I-5
South to Carmen Drive. The building is on the West side [Tigard side] of
the Freeway). The meeting room is in the back of the building. The talk
begins at 10:00 a.m.The street address is 15575 Sequoia Pkwy, Tigard

Web Page: http://crime.whiteknighthackers.com/meetings.php3.

 
Topic:  The job of security practitioners is bad enough trying to detect bad
guys, but what happens when forces conspire to make the task of
remediation and recovering almost impossible?  Rapid capacity expansion
and "break/fix" cycles often lead to loss of repeatable builds.  This
talk describes how the loss of production controls, configuration
management, and change control leads to configuration drift and the loss
of what is a "known, good state." We also describe how to measure it,
and recover it before you need to.

To measure an IT organization's ability to avert "unbounded security
remediation" efforts, Kim and Dr. Spafford developed the IT Safety
Index. We present case studies to display the various attributes of
Level 0 to Level 5 organizations to show how basic capabilities map to
an IT organizations ability to provide business continuity and security.

Gene's Bio:
As co-creator of the original Tripwire software and co-founder of
Tripwire, Inc., Gene Kim now serves as Vice President and Chief
Technical Officer. While his major responsibility is Tripwire products
and development of future technology, his stamp on Tripwire can be seen
everywhere, from new products and business development, to sales and
marketing. Kim also frequently serves as the company evangelist,
speaking at industry events and contributing articles on
security-related topics. 
Kim co-created the first version Tripwire software in 1992 when he was a
student at Purdue University working under security luminary, Dr. Eugene
Spafford. Tripwire worked so well it was quickly embraced by the
security community and eventually became a part of best practices for
computer security professionals around the world. After earning his B.S.
in Computer Sciences from Purdue, he earned an M.S. in Computer Sciences
from the University of Arizona. Kim also spent summers at the
Supercomputing Research Center (now known as the Center for Computing
Sciences) in Maryland working with many of the country's best computer
scientists, engineers, and mathematicians on high-performance computing
techniques for the National Security Agency. Following that, Kim worked
at Intel and then at Infinite Pictures where he met Wyatt Starnes. He
and Starnes formed Tripwire, Inc. in 1997 to create a dramatically
enhanced version of Tripwire that would protect data and network
integrity for Internet-driven businesses. 



-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com




From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Mon Aug 26 14:38:36 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 14:38:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] postfix relay?
Message-ID: <1203.208.151.243.124.1030397916.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>

should a relay attempt from an outside source get this far? Where does the
server typically stop an attempt to send emails from my server

Aug 26 14:31:16 dns postfix/qmgr[9650]: 4E6578D0F: from=<>, size=3086,
nrcpt=1 (queue active)

Aug 26 14:31:57 dns postfix/smtp[21415]: 4E6578D0F:
to=<Bobasdf at mails.com>, relay=none, delay=162153, status=deferred (Name
service error for mails.com: Host not found, try again)

From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon Aug 26 14:54:43 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 14:54:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] postfix relay?
References: <1203.208.151.243.124.1030397916.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <3D6AA3A3.3040308@sun.com>

I see these all the time - when I actually see something come into my 
server and it disallows the relay, what usually happens is it rejects it 
and then sends a 'message not sent' mail back to the original sender.

What you're seeing here is postfix trying to send that message - and it 
can't find the tld for the domain that was in the original sender's FROM 
address.

-R

Robby Russell wrote:
> should a relay attempt from an outside source get this far? Where does the
> server typically stop an attempt to send emails from my server
> 
> Aug 26 14:31:16 dns postfix/qmgr[9650]: 4E6578D0F: from=<>, size=3086,
> nrcpt=1 (queue active)
> 
> Aug 26 14:31:57 dns postfix/smtp[21415]: 4E6578D0F:
> to=<Bobasdf at mails.com>, relay=none, delay=162153, status=deferred (Name
> service error for mails.com: Host not found, try again)
> 
> 
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Mon Aug 26 15:20:24 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 15:20:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208270633470.4409-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208261450190.7283-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Tue, 27 Aug 2002, Preston Crawford wrote:
>
> On Sun, 25 Aug 2002, Geoff Burling wrote:
>
> > > Please don't use the term "anti-christ".  We should not confuse real-world
> > > evil with ancient mythological mumbo jumbo.
> >
> > This is interesting. The ``ancient mythological mumbo jumbo" you mention --
> > the symbols, allusions & trope of the Judeo-Christian religion -- are part
> > & parcel of Western Civilization. Just as Buddhism is integral to Japanese
> > culture, Taoism to Chinese, & Hinduism to Indian. In other words, one
> > doesn't have to believe in the ideas this complex of symbols embraces, but
> > avoiding its contribution to our language impoverishes your ability to
> > communicate. According to the literary critic Northrop Frye, no major
> > literary work of Western Civilization since about AD 300 fails to use
> > this background either explicitly or implicitly. (And the exceptions draw
> > upon an alternative set of -- in your terms -- ``ancient mythological
> > mumbo jumbo".
>
> As I said earlier, I think using the term "anti-christ" shows a lack of
> ability to communicate. It's the rhetorical cousin to comparing someone to
> Nazis or Hitler, in mhy opinion. It shows that the person using the term
> doesn't have the ability at the time to come up with a meaningful way to
> explain his opponents position. It's very easy to say "All you people
> think Red Hat's the anti-christ." Rather than to say something more
> meaningful.

I disagree.

The misuse of the terms ``fascist" & ``Nazi" have so blurred the meaning
of these words that they have become empty & pejorative words. Anyone
from an offical in a police state to a person enforcing common etiquette
can be called ``fascist." (As a point of Fascist trivia, not all Fascists
were anti-Semitic: there were Jewish Fascists in England before Hitler
came to power in Germany, & Italian Fascists -- the folks who coined
the term -- didn't explicitly persecute Jewish Italians until Hitler
forced Mussolini to do so. At the same time, not all Fascists seem to
embrace the ideal of civil obedience & law & order: look at the
proclamations of contemporary neo-Nazis.)

Anytime someone starts clearly throwing cliched insults around is a
clear sign that this person has stopped thinking & is lashing out with
emotion.

The image of ``Antichrist", on the other hand, is still a fresh & precise
one. He is a human so evil & opposed to humanity that Tolkien's Sauron or
Melkor pale in comparison, who is supposed to emerge in the Last Days
before something like Jeme's long-awaited revolution occurs.

Granted, caling someone the Antichrist, or Sauron or Melkor without any
explanation why possibly betrays a likewise lack of reasoned thinking,
but the original statement merely was describing how a certain organization
was perceived in a short, easily-understood sentence. Much like one of
my favorite lines from the late magazine _Spy_, where the negotiating
methods of a pair of Hollywood agents were described as not
``good cop--bad cop, but bad cop--Antichrist".
>
> Secondly, I'm not sure how ancient the tradition of the anti-christ is. My
> understanding is that Revelations was included into the New Testament
> somewhere during the middle ages, by the Catholic Church. It didn't used
> to be part of the Bible originally.

It dates to AD 75-100, when the Book of Revelations was written. Maybe a
generation earlier. Higher textual criticism theorizes that this work is
based on a lost Jewish prototype.
>
> Anyway, other than that, I agree with the rest of what you said. I just
> think using "anti-christ" is kind of weak. Getting offended or bothered by
> it is silly, but it's still a weak term to use.
>
I'm taking the rest of this discussion between Jeme & me offline for
everyone else's benefit.

Geoff

Did anyone mention that you can get a copy of any Distro CD for the
price of the media at FreeGeek? (In other words, bring the needed blank
CDs, & it's free; otherwise it's a dollar a CD IIRC).

BTW, be careful with buying CDs on the Web. I tried to get a copy of
the Debian Distro for Sparc from one company, never received the disks,
sending email only got me an autoresponse, & their clearing house billed
my credit card even though they told me the charges would be reversed.
Yes, I am contesting it with my credit card company.

Geoff

understand the seriousness of this evil that's sure to come anytime now,
but when I hear that term I take the person who spoke it less seriously,
precisely because I don't take the source very seriously either. You could

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Aug 26 17:11:08 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 17:11:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Distros
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208271528040.15344-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208261704420.794-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>


DAMNIT!  Why did I receive Preston's reply, but not Geoff's original
message AGAIN?

If anyone has any idea why this is happening or any evidence that it's
happening to anyone else, please let me know.  My mail logs are totally
clean.  Near as I can tell, there is no attempt to deliver some of these
messages to my server.

I apologize to Geoff, but I can only reply to the portion Preston quoted.

On Mon, 26 Aug 2002, Geoff Burling wrote:
> The image of ``Antichrist", on the other hand, is still a fresh &
> precise one. He is a human so evil & opposed to humanity that
> Tolkien's Sauron or Melkor pale in comparison, who is supposed to
> emerge in the Last Days before something like Jeme's long-awaited
> revolution occurs.

Geoff, I hate to say this, but you still seem to be missing the point.

Even if everything you write is absolutely true (and I don't think it is,
but that's no matter at all in this discussion), that only makes my point
stronger.

Corporations and profit-driven actions are not evil in that same sense.  
They are not directly and obviously anti-human and so a comparison to the
anti-christ is inappropriate and misleading and just shows the ignorance
and laziness of the person making the analogy.

Preston was right when he said that such a reference is the action of a
person who either does not understand or cannot be bothered to properly
consider the opposing view rationally.

This whole thing is a comment on rhetorical style, not superstition or
mythology.

J.

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Mon Aug 26 17:55:25 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 17:55:25 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] GCC 3.2 and the kernel warning
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208261001010.16407-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0208261742170.17692-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

Matrox drivers are open-source, although not for Parthelia ("coming
soon", according to Matrox web site). So it remains to be seen whether
Matrox will provide open-source 3D-accelerated drivers (I don't know if 3D
acceleration is enabled in Matrox drivers for G450 and below, but I don't
think it matters, the 3D performance of these cards is pathetic).
Parthelia, despite very impressive and expensive hardware, still
underperforms GeForce 4, although not by much. The difference is small,
so, if they provide a 3D driver, I'd consider switching to Matrox, for the
convenience of having an open-source driver.

Your next choice is ATI. Radeon 8500 is decent, and Radeon 9700
outperforms GeForce 4 Ti 4600... with their Windows driver. Open-source
drivers don't do a good job of 3D acceleration.

So, for now, you have a choice: if you want to have a good 3D-accelerated
card, and have the freedom to accomplish what you need, go with NVidia.
If your believes do not allow you to pollute your system with close-source
drivers, then a small inconvenience of not being able to have decent 3D
performance is a small price to pay for ideological purity (besides, what
are you going to run on that fast 3D card, most 3D card are for games, and
most 3D games are not open-sourced either).

Fedor

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Mon Aug 26 15:56:25 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 15:56:25 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ppp
In-Reply-To: <200208262032.NAA12298@smtp.gssf.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208261552460.7283-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Mon, 26 Aug 2002, Marvin J. Kosmal wrote:
>
> Hello

Hello back.
>
> Having a problem with kppp all of  sudden.
>
>
> Stopped working..
>
> I am using a 56k modem
>
> I can dial up and connect...

Which probably rules out permission problems on your serial port, but
you might as well check them; I find them easy to break.
>
> I can ping both IP numbers on the ppp link.

What does ifconfig & route show? Is the netmask correct?
>
> I cannot ping the nameserver IP numbers in /etc/resolv.
>
> I cannot ping anyone outside.

Any luck with traceroute?
>
> It had worked .....and just stopped???
>
> Kmail with neither send or receive mail.
>
> I get an error message indicating it can't locate the
> pop or smtp server.
>
>
>
> Any Ideas???
>
Out of curiousity, which version of the Linux kernel are you using?
And -- assuming kppp is a GUI frontend for pppd -- which version
of pppd are you using?

Geoff

Subject: [PLUG] squid rotation
Message-ID: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGEELJCDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>

rotation, where would I change it.

From cbrown at woods.net  Mon Aug 26 22:41:55 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 23:41:55 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] squid rotation
In-Reply-To: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGEELJCDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208262337230.27244-100000@spruce.woods.net>

On Tue, 27 Aug 2002, Billy M Dimaculangan wrote:

> Anyone who could help me?  I want to change the time frame of squid
> rotation, where would I change it.
>
> Thank you and good day!



???  You need to be a bit more clear here.

Are you talking about squid log rotation?

general cache object high-water/low-water flush params?

per object class  high-water/low-water flush params?

general cache object keep times?

per object class keep times?

memory pool flush params???

They are all in squid.conf, most are within the default config with
fairly detailed descriptions.

Also, squid version matter, from 2.2 to 2.4 there was a fair amount of
change, versions before 2.2 handle cache control *alot* differently
(more closely tied to the original Harvest Cache project code).


-- 
I route, therefore you are.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Tue Aug 27 08:46:45 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 08:46:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Levity
Message-ID: <3D6B9EE5.6BB61449@attbi.com>

I promise not to do this very often, but since things seem to have
gotten a bit intense of late on this list I decided that a little levity
was in order. Thus I forward on to you the decipherings of ancient
scrolls, recently discovered, that tell:

How the Internet Began

In ancient Israel, it came to pass that a trader by the name of Abraham
Com did take unto himself a young wife by the name of Dot.  And Dot Com
was a comely woman, broad of shoulder and long of leg. Indeed, she had
been called Amazon Dot Com.  

She said unto Abraham, her husband, "Why doth thou travel far from town
to town with thy goods when thou can trade without ever leaving thy
tent?"

And Abraham did look at her as though she were several saddle bags short
of a camel load, but simply said, "How, Dear?"

And Dot replied, "I will place drums in all the towns and drums in
between to send messages saying what you have for sale and they will
reply telling you which hath the best price. And the sale can be made on
the drums and delivery made by Uriah's Pony Stable (UPS)."

Abraham thought long and decided he would let Dot have her way with the
drums. The drums rang out and were an immediate success.   Abraham sold
all the goods he had at the top price, without ever moving from his
tent.

But this success did arouse envy. A man named Maccabia did secret
himself inside Abraham's drum and was accused of insider trading.   And
the young men did take to Dot Com's trading as doth the greedy horsefly
take to camel dung. They were called Nomadic Ecclesiastical Rich
Dominican Siderites, or 
NERDS for short.

And lo, the land was so feverish with joy at the new riches and the
deafening sound of drums that no one noticed that the real riches were
going to the drum maker, one Brother William of Gates, who bought up
every drum company in the land. And indeed did insist on making drums
that would work only with Brother Gates' drumheads and drumsticks.

Dot did say, "Oh, Abraham, what we have started is being taken over by
others."

And as Abraham looked out over the Bay of Ezekiel, or as it came to be
known "eBay" he said, "We need a name that reflects what we are."

And Dot replied, "Young Ambitious Hebrew Owner Operators."

"YAHOO", said Abraham.

And that is how it all began. It wasn't Al Gore after all.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Aug 27 10:43:35 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 10:43:35 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] An unauthorized biography of RMS (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208271042410.11067-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------

AN UNAUTHORIZED BIOGRAPHY OF RMS
     (Source: LinuxWorld.com) Sam Williams filled in a few
missing tiles on the mosaic of the history of Richard Stallman
and the free software movement with his unauthorized biography of
Richard Stallman.
http://www.idg.net/go.cgi?id=733273

IE USERS (STILL) WAITING FOR SSL BUG FIX
     (Source: InfoWorld.com) A fix for Konqueror was available
within two days. As I write this, there's still no patch for
Internet Explorer, almost a week after the vulnerability became
common knowledge.
http://www.idg.net/go.cgi?id=733275

WHY YOU DON'T NEED TO FEAR THE GPL
     (Source: InfoWorld.com) A few software companies have tried
to convince folks the GNU General Public License is evil. It's
not. In fact, the GPL is perhaps the most empowering license a
software user could ever receive.
http://www.idg.net/go.cgi?id=733276

for anything on the scsi, I can't find it. There is no /dev/scsi
and "scsi_info /dev/scd0" says there is "no such device"

build of (Mandrake) linux. I switched to the 53c815 because I can't
figure out how to get my current kernel to recognize the Tekram

From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Tue Aug 27 15:42:56 2002

Rich said:
>  Another thing: I searched google for the dynamic_cast symbol and saw a
>whole bunch of broken programs reporting the same thing. According to one
>message, this my indicate that the runtime needs libc-2.2 rather than
>libc-2.1. But, I thought that rebuilding on the local system avoided
>dependencies like this.


ok, I'm no expert, but I believe that you'll have to upgrade to libc-2.2

The reason being (and someone correct me on this) is that the API changed slightly.  somethings were deprecated, something were added, etc.  The reason that it didn't complain at compile time, is probably because the symbol doesn't get resolved until run time (ie dynamically linked).

I hope that my explanation is fairly close to accurate.  Is there a major reason for not upgrading your libc?

John Hampton
Programmer Analyst

john.hampton at gijoes.com



From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Aug 27 15:41:53 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 15:41:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Help with SCSI CD-RW drive
In-Reply-To: <3D6BD286.56B33E15@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0208271528090.24002-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

First thing to check is this:
cat /proc/scsi/scsi
This should show something like this:
Host: scsi0 Channel: 00 Id: 00 Lun: 00
  Vendor: Yamaha  Model: ...
Host: scsi1 .....

You should see one "Host" for the actual SCSI controller, one for iscsi,
and if you use ide-scsi for your ide CD, one more for that.
And you should see all devices on all SCSI hosts, including the CDRW.

If you don't see that, your controller or your CD were not recognized.

If you see that, the next step is to do
cdrecord --scanbus

Now you should see something like this:
scsibus0:
   0,0,0     0) 'Yamaha ' ...
where the numbers are channel, ID, and LUN.

If you don't see this, there is a problem with the generic device driver,
sg. Check lsmod, you should see "sg" module loaded unless you compiled all
this stuff into the kernel. If you see the autput like above, cdrecord
should work for burning the CDs, using the 3 numbers it gave you for the
CDRW.

You should also have the sr_mod module loaded, although usually its
autoload is triggered by trying to access the device. So now you actually
need to know the device. It will be /dev/scd0 or scd1, depending on which
CD is first. When you did cat /proc/scsi/scsi, you can just count them
from the top, the first CD is scd0, and so on. But you need those modules
loaded to access the device. Try to load everything manually first:
modprobe sr_mod sg
then if it works, add this to your modules.conf:
alias scsi_hostadapter <scsi>
alias scd0 sr_mod                    # load sr_mod upon access of scd0
pre-install sg     modprobe <scsi>   # load <scsi> before sg
pre-install sr_mod modprobe <scsi>   # load aic7xxx before sr_mod

where <scsi> it the module for your SCSI card.
If you have more than one SCSI CD (in your case it means if your ide CD is
on ide-scsi), you need to give some thought to the order. It'll be scd0 or
scd1 above, and you need to decide what you want to load first, ide-scsi
or scsi (and if you use initrd to load scsi modules, or some of it is
compiled into the kernel, you may not have a choice, go with whatever
order you end up with).

On Tue, 27 Aug 2002, Mike Witt wrote:
> Anyway, assuming the Yamaha CDRW is being detected, I can't figure
> out how to access it after I boot. If there is an entry in /dev
> for anything on the scsi, I can't find it. There is no /dev/scsi
> and "scsi_info /dev/scd0" says there is "no such device"
>

-- 
                                  Fedor G. Pikus
Mentor Graphics Corporation         | Phone: (503) 685-4857
8405 SW Boeckman Road               | FAX:   (503) 685-1239
Wilsonville, Oregon 97070           | http://www.pikus.net/~pikus/

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Tue Aug 27 16:41:22 2002

at peak could probably help you find linux places in town.  He runs RH ISP
here in town.  The url for the lug is: http://lug.peak.org/usergroups.html

maybe color blind...)

This seemed to do the trick. The Yamaha drive is now recognized
properly, and (as Fedor mentioned) "cdrecord -scanbus" now reports
it properly. CDPlayer comes up as soon as I put something in the
drive and tries to read it (which is NOT what I expected or wanted,
since I'm trying to use it for data :-) But I assume I can figure
out how to turn that off. 

Do you know where the documenation is for "iscsi".  My system
doesn't have a man page for it, and I'm curious what it is.

-Mike

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Aug 27 17:50:17 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 17:50:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Help with SCSI CD-RW drive
In-Reply-To: <3D6C13D6.3C560CD0@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0208271738001.7350-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

iscsi is scsi over IP.
Normally it should not affect you, other than it might change the number
of scsi host, what was scsi0 can become scsi1 for example.
If you need iscsi but must have real scsi loaded first, you can ensure
it.
The reason CDPlayer comes up is probably because you use Gnome or KDE or
something similar which thinks it knows better what's good for you, so it
runs the autostarter in background. The autostarter is typically broken,
so it brings up CDPlayer on data CDs, or keeps polling audio CDs after you
start playing them, killing play every 5 seconds, or does something else
like that.
Under Gnome it's called "magicdev". Under KDE, I thinks it's "autorun".
Every now and then I have to troubleshoot someone's PC where CD does not
work. I begin by uninstalling magicdev and the other one. Usually this
concludes the troubleshooting process.

On Tue, 27 Aug 2002, Mike Witt wrote:
> "Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour" wrote:
> >
> > Try removing iscsi from /etc/init.d and see what happens.
> >
> > Sean Harbour
>
> This seemed to do the trick. The Yamaha drive is now recognized
> properly, and (as Fedor mentioned) "cdrecord -scanbus" now reports
> it properly. CDPlayer comes up as soon as I put something in the
> drive and tries to read it (which is NOT what I expected or wanted,
> since I'm trying to use it for data :-) But I assume I can figure
> out how to turn that off.
>
> Do you know where the documenation is for "iscsi".  My system
> doesn't have a man page for it, and I'm curious what it is.
>
> -Mike
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Aug 27 19:50:44 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 19:50:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] pflogusmm.pl
References: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGAEMOCDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <3D6C3A84.5010600@dimstar.net>

Billy M Dimaculangan wrote:
> I encountered the following error upon installing the pflogusmm.pl,  what
> shoul I do?
> Internal Server Error

The first thing to do is look at the apache logfile, and see what it 
says when that script is run. Could be permissions, or the apache on 
your system may not be configured to run files with the .pl extension. 
-OR- you may have the file in the wrong place. I'm sure there are other 
possibilities too.

The apache log will reveal more information about what's going on.

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Tue Aug 27 20:43:37 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 20:43:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Having problems loading shared libraries. (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208271640240.7409-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208271640240.7409-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200208272043.37984.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

On Tuesday 27 August 2002 16:41, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Tue, 27 Aug 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:
> > I'm clueless.  I would like to know for future reference how to debug
> > this.  It would be a very useful skill I imagine.
>
> Jason,
>
>   I searched on google for this symbol name and found a bunch of
> programs that broke with the same load error. Apparently the API changed
> between libc-2.1 and -2.2; the latter is what's needed.
>
>   The OS upgrade is scheduled for tomorrow morning.

It sounds like you've got two things going against you.  The first is that 
the GNU C++ libraries are in a little more flux than the C libraries and 
there were incompatibilites between several of the versions in the last 
couple of years.  Second, 2.96.X was a compiler that the GNU GCC team said 
should not be used, but RH did anyway.  Not sure why.  It generates 
binaries that are not compatible with binaries from other versions.  So If 
you've got a mixed system with old C++ libraries that were made with GCC 
2.95.X and code you've compiled with GCC (g++) 2.96.Y, you are probably 
going to have problems.

Dynamic cast is a newish C++ feature.  I am somewhat shocked that it would 
be implemented as a named function rather than being inlined directly in 
place.  Weird.  My guess is that GCC/G++ 2.96 supports dynamic cast and 
the old library doesn't.  

I believe there are compiler flags that will turn off support for this 
stuff, but you'd probably have to change code then.  It is harder to keep 
binary compatibility with C++ libraries than C libraries in general.

Best,
Kyle

From jon at manymoons.net  Tue Aug 27 21:34:32 2002
From: jon at manymoons.net (Jon Jacob)
Date: 27 Aug 2002 21:34:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] pflogusmm.pl
In-Reply-To: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGAENACDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGAENACDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <1030509273.1413.595.camel@lana.manymoons.net>

Sounds like the #! line of the script is pointing to a place that is
different than where your perl interpreter is actually located.  If this
is the case, you can change the line or put a sym link in its place
pointing to the place you do actually keep it.

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Tue Aug 27 22:09:44 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 22:09:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] pflogusmm.pl
In-Reply-To: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGIENACDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <1030509273.1413.595.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
        <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGIENACDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <64581.12.231.181.15.1030511384.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

Billy M Dimaculangan said:
> Can you help me and  tell where would I put this pearl file to run
>
> Tnx!

Billy,

The pflogsumm.pl is the Postfix log summarizer. My understanding is that
isn't a CGI script to be run via mod_perl on your web server. Just log in
as root and:

% perl /path/to/pflogsumm.pl /var/log/maillog

It has a few other options, but I'd consult the docs; conveniently, they
are embedded in the code as comments.

% perl /path/to/pflogsumm.pl --help

may elucidate as well. I run this out of cron to get a handle on the
previous day's mail usage. Enjoy,

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District





From sean at fork.com  Tue Aug 27 22:15:37 2002
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 22:15:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] pflogusmm.pl
In-Reply-To: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGIENACDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGIENACDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20020828051538.DB8AB2EF03@einstein.seansdomain.org>

Step 1:

type 
	file /var/www/cgi-bin/pflogusmm.pl

It should tell you something like 
pflogusmm.pl: perl script text executable

If this is true then type 

which perl
You might get something like

/usr/bin/perl

Now edit the file pflogusmm.pl with your handy editor like vim, pico, emacs, 
joe, gedit (whatever)

On the first line might be something like

#!/usr/local/bin/perl

If so change the /usr/local/bin/perl part so that it matches the output of 
which perl command you ran above

like

#!/usr/bin/perl

Save the file, and see if this works.

Sean

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Tue Aug 27 22:57:49 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 22:57:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla hangs machine

If you have a way to remotely login in your machine you could probably 
just kill X and then you could go back and login again. I have managed 
to lockup X once in a while and have telnet'ed in and then killed the X 
process. The rest of the system was still running fine but in my case 
my X process seems to get stuck in some loop and starts consuming 80% 
or more of the CPU time and my entire desktop is frozen.

Tony

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Aug 27 23:14:12 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 23:14:12 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla hangs machine
In-Reply-To: <200208272235.11111.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0208272304590.12539-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

It's not hung, it's just busy loading up all the cool shit they bloated
mozilla with. Give it a few hours, it'll come back :)

No, it probably won't.
Check system logs, they may have some messages from just before the
freeze. But if you just reset the machine, they may not.
Try this: before calling mozilla, go to a text
console (Ctrl-F1), log in as root, start tail -f /var/log/messages there.

Then, go back to X, start mozilla, and immediately go back to text. If you
can do it before mozilla freeses X, you'll be watching the system log as
it scrolls by. May be mozilla does not freeze everything, only X, then you
won't notice anything wrong. Until you switch to X, that is :)

In any event, I'd suspect video drivers, especially if everything locks
up not just X. You did not mention what video
card you use, and what drivers? Some AGP video cards like to do this kind
of stuff on some motherboards, you can try disabling AGP (set AGP page
size to below 32M and it's disabled in your BIOS). With closed-source
NVidia drivers, you can disable AGP from software too, other drivers may
have this option.

Fedor

to that

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Wed Aug 28 01:56:57 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 01:56:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] C++ is too complex (was: Having problems loading shared
 libraries. (fwd))
In-Reply-To: <200208272043.37984.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208280148310.13675-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Tue, 27 Aug 2002, Kyle Hayes wrote:

> Dynamic cast is a newish C++ feature.  I am somewhat shocked that it would
> be implemented as a named function rather than being inlined directly in
> place.  Weird.  My guess is that GCC/G++ 2.96 supports dynamic cast and
> the old library doesn't.
>
> I believe there are compiler flags that will turn off support for this
> stuff, but you'd probably have to change code then.  It is harder to keep
> binary compatibility with C++ libraries than C libraries in general.

It has been my feeling for a while now that because C++ is OOP, it causes
people to think about the design longer, causing people to write a better
design, but because the langauge is more complex than most programmers are
used to, it can lead to very complicated, hard to maintain code.  If you
screw up in the implementation (ie. in c you have a buffer over flow) then
you have shot your foot.  But if you screw up the design (ie. in c++ you
misuse a language feature to express some OO concept) then it can have far
reaching consequences down the line.  I know C++ has many improvements
over C, and it really does help conceptualize some problems, but it is a
VERY complex langauge that allows you to do many things you shouldn't be
doing...And you can create bugs which "don't make sense"...

Many times, simple is better and less is more.  Not saying c++ is a waste
of time, I just wish it wasn't so complex.

Jason

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Aug 28 06:17:28 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 06:17:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Final test release of rpm-4.1
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208280616230.23740-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

I thought some of you might be interested in this. I'll be interested 
to see how the new dependency tracking/suggestion stuff works out.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>


---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 19:00:34 -0400
From: Jeff Johnson <jbj at redhat.com>
Reply-To: rpm-list at redhat.com
To: rpm-list at redhat.com
Subject: Final test release of rpm-4.1 ...


There's a complete version of rpm-4.1-1.01 available for testing at

	ftp://ftp.rpm.org/pub/rpm/test-4.1

I've included source and binary packages compiled for all Red Hat platforms.
All the packages are signed with the BETA-GPG-KEY, also present at the
above URL.

AFAIK, this *is* rpm-4.1, but there's always something that needs fixing
at the last minute.

If you have the time to install and try out rpm-4.1, I'd appreciate any
bug reports at

	http://bugzilla.redhat.com

Here's a short summary (again) of features that have been added. See the
CHANGES file in the src rpm for more details.

1) Header signatures and digests can (if configured) be verified when
   retrieved from the rpm database. See /usr/lib/rpm/macros for comments
   about how to configure %_vsflags_install et al macros.

   Note: this is only mechanism, a better/configurable security policy
   is gonna be needed in rpm somewhen soon. Suggestions/patches/audits are
   very much appreciated.

2) The rpm database permits concurrent access. That means that it is now
   possible to run rpm in %post scriptlets.

   Note: What still remains is to find out whether there are deadlocks
   (there are), and whether the deadlocks can be avoided or otherwise
   handled gracefully. I'd really like to support (at least read)
   concurrent access to the rpm database, but it's gonna take a lot
   of careful (i.e. reproducible) testing to achieve that goal. Any
   and all help is appreciated. What's very promising is that the
   problems are deadlocks, not segfaults, but reproducing deadlocks
   is gonna be quite challenging.

3) The rpmdb-redhat package (which contains an "everything" rpm database),
   if installed, will be used to provide suggested solutions for unresolved
   dependencies. Try installing the rpmdb-redhat package from Raw Hide if
   interested.

4) /usr/lib/rpm/rpmcache has been added to the rpm-devel package. rpmcache
   can be used to create a custom rpm database to provide suggested solutions
   for unresolved dependencies. See rpmcache(8) for some hints about how to
   use.

5) /usr/bin/rpmgraph has been added to the rpm-devel package. rpmgrapgh
   will generate dependsnecy graphs of packages for display by graphwiz.
   See rpmgraph(8) for details. If nowhere else, there's a graphvix source
   rpm that can be compiled to display the output at
	ftp://people.redhat.com/jbj/graphviz-1.7.14-1.src.rpm

There are several goals in rpm-4.1:

1) new, header-only, digital signatures and digests for packages.

2) verifying header signatures/digests when the header is read.

3) replacing the internal representation of headers with smaller data
   structures to reduce memory footprint.

4) enriching and stabilizing the rpmlib API.

Both 3) and 4) are gonna be quite painful for developers, as the
entire rpmlib API has changed. What's good is that I can now expose
more of the internals of rpmlib more or less opaquely.

What's bad is that everything has changed. I'll be happy to answer questions
or help with porting (assuming time available) as needed.

Below is a short description of the signature changes.
==========================================================================
DSA/RSA signature verification using RFC-2440 OpenPGP V3
packets is now implemented directly in rpm. The signature,
if available, is always verified when reading a package, and failures
are always reported.

Signing is done with gpg/pgp helpers as always, and both a new,
header-only, as well as the Good Old header+payload signature
are generated. In fact, all of Red Hat 7.3 was signed with rpm-4.1,
so both signatures should be present in 7.3 packages.

What's also new is pubkey management using --import. Basically
	rpm --import RPM-GPG-KEY
(or any ascii armored OpenPGP pubkey) will wrap the binary OpenPGP
packet in a header, and install much like any other package.

Here's what you see if you have not yet imported the correct pubkey(s):

bash$ sudo rpm -Uvh /B/7.3/rpm/4.0.4-7x.18/i386/*
warning: /B/7.3/rpm/4.0.4-7x.18/i386/popt-1.6.4-7x.18.i386.rpm: Header V3 DSA signature: NOKEY, key ID db42a60e
...

Here's what the Red Hat pubkeys look like when imported:
==========================================================================
bash$ rpm -qa | grep pubkey
gpg-pubkey-0352860f-3c3cb5e4
gpg-pubkey-db42a60e-37ea5438

bash$ rpm -qi gpg-pubkey-db42a60e
Name        : gpg-pubkey                   Relocations: (not relocateable)
Version     : db42a60e                          Vendor: (none)
Release     : 37ea5438                      Build Date: Sat 16 Mar 2002 10:47:53 AM EST
Install date: Sat 16 Mar 2002 10:47:53 AM EST      Build Host: localhost
Group       : Public Keys                   Source RPM: (none)
Size        : 0                                License: pubkey
Summary     : gpg(Red Hat, Inc <security at redhat.com>)
Description :
-----BEGIN PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----
Version: rpm-4.1 (beecrypt-2.2.0)

For the extremely security conscious and the overly curious, I note the
following limitations:

	1) there's no attempt (yet) to verify the signature on the
	pubkey before verifying the package signature.

	2) there's no attempt (yet) to implement any trust model using
	OpenPGP packets. All imported keys are considered trusted.

	3) only V3 signatures are implemented ATM.

If that's not to your taste, then you can export the signature from a
package and verify using gpg outside of rpm. For example, here's a
short script that verifies good old header+payload signatures of
a package using gpg:

==========================================================================
#!/bin/sh

for pkg in $*
do
    if [ "$pkg" = "" -o ! -e "$pkg" ]; then
	echo "no package supplied" 1>&2
	exit 1
    fi

    plaintext=`mktemp $0-$$.XXXXXX`
    detached=`mktemp $0-$$.XXXXXX`

# --- Extract detached signature
    rpm -qp -vv --qf '%{siggpg:armor}' $pkg > $detached

# --- Figger the offset of header+payload in the package
    leadsize=96
    o=`expr $leadsize + 8`

    set `od -j $o -N 8 -t u1 $pkg`
    il=`expr 256 \* \( 256 \* \( 256 \* $2 + $3 \) + $4 \) + $5`
    dl=`expr 256 \* \( 256 \* \( 256 \* $6 + $7 \) + $8 \) + $9`

    sigsize=`expr 8 + 16 \* $il + $dl`
    o=`expr $o + $sigsize + \( 8 - \( $sigsize \% 8 \) \) \% 8`

# --- Extract header+payload
    dd if=$pkg ibs=$o skip=1 2>/dev/null > $plaintext

# --- Verify DSA signature using gpg
    gpg --batch -vv --debug 0xfc02 --verify $detached $plaintext

# --- Clean up
    rm -f $detached $plaintext
done
==========================================================================
-- 
Jeff Johnson	ARS N3NPQ
jbj at redhat.com (jbj at jbj.org)
Chapel Hill, NC

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Aug 28 06:31:00 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 06:31:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla hangs machine
In-Reply-To: <200208272235.11111.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208280626310.23740-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Tue, 27 Aug 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> Why would the Mozilla browser hang my machine? I'm using Galeon
> 1.2.0 and Konqueror 3.0.0.10 on RedHat 7.3 [after current
> updates]and they work fine , but when I call up Mozilla, it trys to
> more than fill the screen and then completely hangs the machine. I
> can't even ctl alt delete or backspace and must reboot manually.

My first troubleshooting suggestion would be to tar up ~/.netscape/ 
and ~/.mozilla/ and save them out of the way, delete the original 
directories, and then restart mozilla.

If it works properly, then it's a configuration error (though it 
leaves unanswered the question about how mozilla could lock up a 
machine in the first place).

Otherwise, I'm fairly stumped. I'd probably start with mozilla.org's 
bugzilla database, looking to see if there are known problems with 
your video card/driver.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

As I said before, pflogsumm.pl is not a cgi script to be run out of a 
browser. Run it from a terminal as root, and I'll bet you'll be in business.

Carla was on the right track. Start w/ the basics. Think about getting a 
book (O'reilly's Running Linux?) or finding some things on the web to 
get you started, particularly w/ file ownership/permissions issues. Use 
Google frequently. Do a little more experimenting. Lather, rinse, repeat.

http://www.tldp.org/ has some good docs on a variety of topics.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Aug 28 08:27:38 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 28 Aug 2002 08:27:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] C++ is too complex (was: Having problems loading shared libraries. (fwd))
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208280148310.13675-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208280148310.13675-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <86bs7nt34l.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jason" == Jason Dagit <dagit at engr.orst.edu> writes:

Jason> It has been my feeling for a while now that because C++ is OOP,
Jason> it causes people to think about the design longer, causing
Jason> people to write a better design, but because the langauge is
Jason> more complex than most programmers are used to, it can lead to
Jason> very complicated, hard to maintain code.  If you screw up in
Jason> the implementation (ie. in c you have a buffer over flow) then
Jason> you have shot your foot.  But if you screw up the design
Jason> (ie. in c++ you misuse a language feature to express some OO
Jason> concept) then it can have far reaching consequences down the
Jason> line.  I know C++ has many improvements over C, and it really
Jason> does help conceptualize some problems, but it is a VERY complex
Jason> langauge that allows you to do many things you shouldn't be
Jason> doing...And you can create bugs which "don't make sense"...

Jason> Many times, simple is better and less is more.  Not saying c++
Jason> is a waste of time, I just wish it wasn't so complex.

Here is a brief section from the introductory chapter of _On Lisp:
Advanced Techniques for Common Lisp_ by Paul Graham, now out-of-print
but the copyright has been recovered by the author and it is now
available online at <http://www.paulgraham.com/onlisp.html>, from
Section 1.1 Design by Evolution:

  [...] And if you're not sure yet what kind of program you're
  writing, it's a safe bet to write it in Lisp. Whatever kind of
  program yours turns out to be, Lisp will, during the writing of it,
  have evolved into a language for writing _that_ kind of program.

  If you're not sure yet what kind of program you're writing? To some
  ears that sentence has an odd ring to it. It is in jarring contrast
  with a certain model of doing things wherein you (1) carefully plan
  what you're going to do, and then (2) do it. According to this
  model, if Lisp encourages you to start writing your program before
  you ve decided how it should work, it merely encourages sloppy
  thinking.

  Well, it just ain't so. The plan-and-implement method may have been
  a good way of building dams or launching invasions, but experience
  has not shown it to be as good a way of writing programs. Why?
  Perhaps it's because computers are so exacting. Perhaps there is
  more variation between programs than there is between dams or
  invasions. Or perhaps the old methods don't work because old
  concepts of redundancy have no analogue in software development: if
  a dam contains 30% too much concrete, that's a margin for error, but
  if a program does 30% too much work, that _is_ an error.

  It may be difficult to say why the old method fails, but that it
  does fail, anyone can see. When is software delivered on time?
  Experienced programmers know that no matter how carefully you plan a
  program, when you write it the plans will turn out to be imperfect
  in some way. Sometimes the plans will be hopelessly wrong. Yet few
  of the victims of the plan-and-implement method question its basic
  soundness. Instead they blame human failings: if only the plans had
  been made with more foresight, all this trouble could have been
  avoided. Since even the very best programmers run into problems when
  they turn to implementation, perhaps it's too much to hope that
  people will ever have that much foresight. Perhaps the
  plan-and-implement method could be replaced with another approach
  which better suits our limitations.

For another introductory look at Lisp, see the recent document:

  <http://www.pascalcostanza.de/lisp/guide.html>

-- 
Russell Senior         ``The two chiefs turned to each other.        
seniorr at aracnet.com      Bellison uncorked a flood of horrible       
                         profanity, which, translated meant, `This is
                         extremely unusual.' ''

From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed Aug 28 08:49:09 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 08:49:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix Linux-on-cd
Message-ID: <3D6CF0F5.8060508@sun.com>

I just wanted to share my first experience with the Knoppix CD.

I downloaded the .iso last night, and got my ide cd-burner working in 
the same timeframe.  My first test cd happened to be the Knoppix ISO, 
and it worked perfectly.  Yay for that!

Since my machine already had linux on it, I decided to traipse 
downstairs and see how it would work on the wife's laptop.  After 
futzing with the bios to make sure it would boot from the CDROM first, 
Knoppix came right up, detected *everything* on the machine (even the 
wireless network card!) and sat there looking pretty spiffy right from 
the get-go.

Let me just say that I am mightily impressed.  That is _the_ slickest CD 
I have ever had the pleasure of booting.

Now, if it only had a 'clone this cd to the first available hard disk' 
option.  ;)

I sent the disc with my wife to try out on her work machine today.  I 
want to see if she can do her Word/Excel/etc stuff via Knoppix instead 
of using M$ stuff.  If I can wean her from it even a little bit, I'll 
consider my life complete.  ;)

-Richard

> Jason> people to write a better design, but because the langauge is
> Jason> more complex than most programmers are used to, it can lead to

> Jason> (ie. in c++ you misuse a language feature to express some OO

> Jason> does help conceptualize some problems, but it is a VERY complex
> Jason> langauge that allows you to do many things you shouldn't be
> Jason> doing...And you can create bugs which "don't make sense"...

>
> Here is a brief section from the introductory chapter of _On Lisp:
> Advanced Techniques for Common Lisp_ by Paul Graham, now out-of-print
> but the copyright has been recovered by the author and it is now
> available online at <http://www.paulgraham.com/onlisp.html>, from
> Section 1.1 Design by Evolution:
>
>   [...] And if you're not sure yet what kind of program you're
>   writing, it's a safe bet to write it in Lisp. Whatever kind of
>   program yours turns out to be, Lisp will, during the writing of it,
>   have evolved into a language for writing _that_ kind of program.
>
<snipped stuff about Lisp's flexibility>

Lisp isn't the only language that gives you this kind of flexibility, in
general you can say the same about dynamic languages as a class of
languages - you could say similar things about SmallTalk or Ruby for
example.

The previous poster is right, you have to be a lot more careful about the
up front design in C++ because it'll be a lot harder to change the
architecure later.  As an analogy you can think of working with C++ like
sculpting in marble and working with the dynamic langauages like sculpting
in modeling clay.  Some might argue that having to pay more attention to
your design up front is a good thing that C++ forces you to do.  Others
(in the agile design camp) will argue that you can never forsee all of the
requirements upfront and it's best to just consider change a part of
reality and get used to it.


Phil




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Aug 28 09:13:31 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 09:13:31 -0700 (PDT)

On Wed, 28 Aug 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:

> The reason I use c and c++ is because they are so widely used and so well
> known.  I figure if I ever work as a programmer, I will need to be
> experienced at c/c++ above all else.

  Hehehe! My son received his degree in CS and thought the same thing. Ended
up working for the banking and insurance industries writing an maintaining
COBOL -- which he hates.

  You'll probably end up supporting VB. :-)

Rich




From montagne at boora.com  Wed Aug 28 09:27:30 2002

only linux box in the office it isn't backed up at the moment and she
wondered if it's possible to undelete.  A quick search revealed that mc
has an undelete command and debian offers a "recover" package.  The mc
option seems easiest.  But I don't know for sure.

But I'm having trouble following directions for mc.  The man page says I
need to ch to /#undel/hda2.  But it doesn't exist. I also read that I
need to unmount the filesystem first.  Right now mc is still "loading
deleted inode information" so perhaps that directory will exist when it
is done.  But about unmounting.  This machine serves as our ftp site and
all our incoming mail goes through here to be cleansed by spamassassin
before going on to exchange.  If I need to unmount /dev/hda2:  Will these
services be disabled till I mount again?  How do I browse the directory
for deleted files?  How exactly do I perform the whole unmount/mount on
the main filessytem?  It is the only one besides the swap partition.
I'm a little nervous cause it could wreak havoc.

Any other advice?

From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Aug 28 09:46:30 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 09:46:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla hangs machine
References: <200208272235.11111.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D6CFE66.D4AC756B@attbi.com>

Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> Why would the Mozilla browser hang my machine?

I'm in the process of loading Debian on one of my machines. I'm in the
Configuring Mozilla-browser phase. I don't know if this will shed any
light on your problem, but here's what they say on this screen:

Sometimes mozilla hangs since plugins (e.g. flashplugin) lock /dev/dsp.
You can use dsp wrapper to resolve it. 'auto' will decide which dsp
wrappers should b used according to the sound daemon running. When no
sound daemon is detected, mozilla won't use any wrapper. This setting
will be saved into /etc/mozilla/mozillarc and can be overridden with
your ~/.mozillarc.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From srau at rauhaus.org  Wed Aug 28 09:55:44 2002
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 09:55:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] NFS mounting cdrom from Linux to Solaris
Message-ID: <20020828165543.GA32718@rauhaus.org>

I have an odd problem with cdrom volumes nfs mounted from a Linux box on
to a Solaris box. Occaisionally files, directories, and even the entire
volume will dissappear temporarily from the nfs mounted partition.

I thought it might have to do with the way Linux does either caching or
handles spinning up and spinning down the cdrom drive, so while I needed
to access the nfs mount on the Solaris machine, I've tried keeping the
drive in use on the Linux side:

cd /cdrom
while true; do
	ls -lR .
	sleep 30
done

But even that hasn't completely made this problem go away. Any magic
switches, either for mounting the cdrom volume on the Linux box, or nfs
mounting it elsewhere, that might help?

Thanks,
--Stafford

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Aug 28 12:31:49 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 12:31:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] C++ is too complex (was: Having problems loading shared libraries. (fwd))
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208280148310.13675-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208280148310.13675-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <200208281231.49891.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Having worked on large C++ projects and had a hand maintaining C++ code 
over the years I would have to agree. I've seen horrible things done in 
C++ that made it very difficult to maintain and even debug a system. 
I've been doing more Java work recently and I'm sort of wondering where 
things are going to go. I see J2EE being very big using Java and Java 
being much less complicated that C++ avoids many of the pitfalls I've 
seen in C++ projects. I see Microsoft's .NET initiative where they're 
toting C# and so wonder where C++ is going these days since much of the 
trend is towards these sort of interpretive virtual machine 
environments.

The one thing that I've found with Java is that on even large projects 
we've had fewer problems and better stability much more rapidly than 
what I've seen on C++ projects. I was involved with a "alpha/demo" 
release of a Java product that was installed at a customer's site and 
it ran for many months without any major problems. I don't think 
something like that would have been so easy with C++ even through the 
team doing the work had considerable experience with large C++ 
development projects.

Certainly Java performed rather sluggishly on older systems that were 
slower but I've worked on some rather complicated Swing/AWT based GUIs 
and when running Java applications on a 1+ GHz clocked machine the 
performance appeared as smooth as a natively written application. I got 
the same comment from the analysts and users that were involved with 
the project as well so it wasn't something I was smokin or anything. :)

Tony

On Wednesday 28 August 2002 01:56 am, Jason Dagit wrote:
> On Tue, 27 Aug 2002, Kyle Hayes wrote:
> > Dynamic cast is a newish C++ feature.  I am somewhat shocked that
> > it would be implemented as a named function rather than being
> > inlined directly in place.  Weird.  My guess is that GCC/G++ 2.96
> > supports dynamic cast and the old library doesn't.
> >
> > I believe there are compiler flags that will turn off support for
> > this stuff, but you'd probably have to change code then.  It is
> > harder to keep binary compatibility with C++ libraries than C
> > libraries in general.
>
> It has been my feeling for a while now that because C++ is OOP, it
> causes people to think about the design longer, causing people to
> write a better design, but because the langauge is more complex than
> most programmers are used to, it can lead to very complicated, hard
> to maintain code.  If you screw up in the implementation (ie. in c
> you have a buffer over flow) then you have shot your foot.  But if
> you screw up the design (ie. in c++ you misuse a language feature to
> express some OO concept) then it can have far reaching consequences
> down the line.  I know C++ has many improvements over C, and it
> really does help conceptualize some problems, but it is a VERY
> complex langauge that allows you to do many things you shouldn't be
> doing...And you can create bugs which "don't make sense"...
>
> Many times, simple is better and less is more.  Not saying c++ is a
> waste of time, I just wish it wasn't so complex.
>
> Jason
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com

From pate at eylerfamily.org  Wed Aug 28 13:55:19 2002
From: pate at eylerfamily.org (Pat Eyler)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 16:55:19 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RFP for Perl work on existing project
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208281653020.925-100000@petrol.whirlycott.com>

(I hope this is to the right list, if not I apologize.)

The Nelsonville, Ohio, Public Library has recently announced that they
will be migrating to Koha, a GPL'd library software system
(<http://www.koha.org>) which is written in Perl.  They have decided to
contribute to the ongoing development of Koha and have released an
RFP to solicit bids to work on full MARC support for the 1.4 release,
the RFP is available at
<http://pate.eylerfamily.org/geek/MARCRFP.txt> (a copy is also
included below).

I'd encourage interested parties to read carefully through the RFP and
to join the koha-devel mailing list
(<http://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/koha-devel>).  It may
also be worthwhile to join the #koha channel at irc.katipo.co.nz to
discuss the project in general or MARC support specifically.  If you
know anyone else that might be interested in responding to the RFP,
please feel free to forward it as appropriate.

Further background on Nelsonville's announcement is at
<http://www.linuxpr.com/releases/5053.html>.  For more information,
please feel free to contact me by email at info at koha.org.

thanks,
-pate

Pat Eyler
Kaitiaki/manager
the Koha project
http://www.koha.org


REQUEST For PROPOSAL -- MARC 21 record support for Koha (www.koha.org)

The Nelsonville Public Library invites all interested parties to
submit proposals in response to the following request.  Proposals may
be submitted in any format, but should carefully answer all questions
in the request.  Proposals should be sent to Stephen Hedges, Director,
Nelsonville Public Library, e-mail nelpl at athenscounty.lib.oh.us, fax
740-753-3543, mail 95 W. Washington Street, Nelsonville, Ohio 45764.
Proposals are due no later than 8:00 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time,
September 30, 2002.  Any responses made in proposals from interested
parties may be incorporated as part of a final agreement.

BACKGROUND
The Nelsonville Public Library is a public library system consisting
of seven libraries serving the residents of Athens County, Ohio, USA,
with 36,000 active borrowers and over 250,000 items in the
collections.  The library has made plans to switch from its current
library automation system to Koha, but only if Koha has certain
required capabilities.  Among these is the ability to store and
retrieve item records in MARC 21 format at the (Full) National Record
Level.

Accordingly, the Library is seeking proposals from parties who are
capable of modifying the current Koha code to provide this capability.
Proposals will be evaluated by a committee of five Library staff
members, and a contract will be negotiated with the submitter of the
successful proposal.

Please note that the Nelsonville Public Library does not expect to
fund the entire development process, but is instead offering a
financial reward to encourage development of Koha to be able to handle
MARC 21 format.  Nelsonville Public Library may elect to share some of
this financial burden with other agencies as it sees fit.

SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONS
Nelsonville Public Library realizes that several people/groups may
wish to combine resources to fulfill the requirements of this RFP.
The Library is aware of the special nature of Open Source software
projects, which encourages wide participation in the development
process, and is thus amenable to proposals which divide the work
between parties.  In such a case, however, the Library prefers to
receive only one combined proposal, with payment going to only one
person or organization.  If no acceptable combined proposal is
received, then the library will entertain partial proposals from
several persons or organizations that can demonstrate a plan to
coordinate their efforts toward achieving the intended goal.

SELECTION CRITERA
Proposals will be evaluated on the basis of cost, qualifications of
the programmer(s), time to delivery, ease of integration of the
proposed code into the current Koha software, and ease of upgrading
the delivered software to incorporate future changes to the MARC
formats.

The Library also intends to share information from proposals with the
current Koha development team, in order to better judge the
compatibility of the proposals with the overall Koha development
plan.

REQUIRED INFORMATION
- How will you modify current Koha tables and/or scripts to accomodate
MARC 21 National (Full) Level Record Requirements?  (See
http://lcweb.loc.gov/marc/bibliographic/nlr/).  Please provide enough
detail so that the committee may judge the viability of your plan, but
do not submit sample tables and/or scripts.
- Who will undertake this work?
- What are the qualifications of the person(s) doing this work?
- How have you been involved in previous Koha development?
- How long will it take to complete this work?
- How much will you charge for this work? (in US Dollars, please)
- How will you coordinate your work with the existing work on MARC for
the 1.4 release of Koha?

From aarghj at yahoo.com  Wed Aug 28 16:17:15 2002
From: aarghj at yahoo.com (john morgali)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 16:17:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix Linux-on-cd
In-Reply-To: <1030573113.678.0.camel@coyote>
Message-ID: <20020828231715.89636.qmail@web10508.mail.yahoo.com>

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Wed Aug 28 17:36:44 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (E. Rogan Creswick)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 17:36:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] pcmcia storage device (solid-state?)
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208281731340.18548-100000@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

Can anyone reccomend a pcmcia storage device, preferrably solidstate? A
pcmcia compact-flash reader would do it, but I would like to hear some
success stories under linux before splurging on one.

It would be nice to have a large ammount of storage, 512mb would be a nice
number, but 128mb might do it, I suppose a few gigs would be prefferable
( I doubt compact flash will go that high, other options? USB is not a
good alternative in this situation.)

The purpose is for flight logging of an unmaned autonomous(sp?) craft.

Thanks!
Rogan




From pem at nellump.net  Wed Aug 28 18:06:24 2002
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 18:06:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] pcmcia storage device (solid-state?)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208281731340.18548-100000@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208281731340.18548-100000@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20020829010624.GD3673@nellump.net>

On Wed, Aug 28, 2002 at 05:36:44PM -0700, E. Rogan Creswick wrote:
> 
> Can anyone reccomend a pcmcia storage device, preferrably solidstate? A
> pcmcia compact-flash reader would do it, but I would like to hear some
> success stories under linux before splurging on one.

In my experience, it just works. I've had no difficulty getting the
kernel to recognize CF cards via a PCMCIA adapter under either RedHat or
Debian. On my ancient P166 laptop, they're seen as /dev/hdc.

The Portland State Aerospace Society (a rocketry group) uses a 128MB CF
card for the root filesystem of the Linux-driven flight computer. Check
out <http://twiki.psas.pdx.edu/twiki/bin/view/PSAS/LvTwoCompactFlash>
for more details. The lead FC developer is here on the PLUG list (say
hello, James!). Perhaps he'll chime in with real details.


Paul

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Aug 28 20:40:55 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 20:40:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A _Red Hat_ upgrade question
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208282030030.29256-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  It seems to me that previous Red Hat upgrades kept the configuration
options in a file so that all packages to be upgraded/installed need not be
re-selected if the upgrade was aborted and restarted. But, selecting
'upgrade' on the RH 7.3 cdrom #1 makes me select the packages each time.

  While my expert help today was absolutely invaluable, there was just one
problem after another. Imagine, 500M free in /usr was not sufficient for the
upgrade! I certainly got a thorough education in the use of parted to resize
and move partitions. A great tool, but it was too bad we needed to use it.

  Anyhow, I gave up for the evening when the cdrom had a corrupted file that
wouldn't install. Tomorrow is another day and the contest continues. Is it
only the kernel sources that permit 'make config' and let you use the same
options time and again? It would sure save a ton of time if I didn't need to
reselect the packages for a fourth time but could use a saved configuration
file.

Thanks,

Rich




From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Wed Aug 28 21:12:02 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 21:12:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A _Red Hat_ upgrade question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208282030030.29256-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0208282102110.3329-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Wed, 28 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   It seems to me that previous Red Hat upgrades kept the configuration
> options in a file so that all packages to be upgraded/installed need not be
> re-selected if the upgrade was aborted and restarted. But, selecting
> 'upgrade' on the RH 7.3 cdrom #1 makes me select the packages each time.

I don't think it did that, if the upgrade is restarted you do it from
scratch. But it does know what you currently have, and a typical upgrade
will just take the list of installed packages and upgrade them, so you
should not have to select anything as a part of the upgrade.
If you want to change your system configuration significantly, do it after
the upgrade. Aftermy upgrades, I used to go through the upgrade log, see
what packages I have, remove those I don't really want, check
configuration files it updated, and did other cruft removal (there is
nothing in the upgrade process itself which makes it necessary or any
easier than at any other time, but since I was already doing maintenance,
it looked like a sensible occasion).

However, I have to say that after RH7.1 I stopped using upgrades at all.
I now use apt-rpm to upgrade all myu RedHat boxes. Get it from
http://apt-rpm.tuxfamily.org/ or from freshrpm's, edit the sources file,
you can add your RH7.3 CDs to the "repository" (it has a command for
that), and upgrade away.

-- 
                                  Fedor G. Pikus
Mentor Graphics Corporation         | Phone: (503) 685-4857
8405 SW Boeckman Road               | FAX:   (503) 685-1239
Wilsonville, Oregon 97070           | http://www.pikus.net/~pikus/



From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Aug 28 21:14:51 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 21:14:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] First Time Debian Install
Message-ID: <3D6D9FBB.53FC9434@attbi.com>

I started installing Debian via the Internet (cable connection) on
Monday. As someone mentioned, I could have left a chicken in charge of
most of it since it primarily consisted of hitting the Enter key. The
process did take a long time, though. The installation continued through
all of yesterday and probably a good part of last night. This morning it
was waiting for me to tell it to continue. It finished before lunch
time.

When I logged in for the first time, it was from an 80 x 25 terminal
screen. I ran startx and found myself looking at KDE, even though that
wasn't what I checked during the installation. I had some things I
needed to do with Windows, so I tried to log out and halt Linux. I'm
used to the logout options provided by Red Hat 7.0 and 7.1, which
include halt. Halt was not an option. I wondered if I had to be logged
in as root in order to halt, so I tried to log in as root. I was
informed that logging in as root is not allowed from that screen! So, I
logged back in as an ordinary user, su'd and ran halt. That mostly
worked. Everything shut down, and I got "Power down." on the monitor,
but the machine never powered down.

Lilo happily allowed me to start up Windows. I did what I needed to do,
and rebooted into Linux. This time, I was given a Gnome login screen,
and it was Gnome into which I was put. Again though, no option to halt.
I guess I've got some more reading to do. (Actually, I know I've got a
lot of reading to do.)

There are a number of things that are not the same as what I've come to
expect when I start up either of my other two RH systems. I suppose some
of that is configuration related and some of it is convention related.
But, this is intended to be a learning experience, so time to start
reading.

Any recommendations for things to read that will help me understand what
I should expect (regarding the difference between the way things look on
Debian vs RH) other than everything on the debian site?

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/
