On Wed, 28 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> I started installing Debian via the Internet (cable connection) on
> Monday. As someone mentioned, I could have left a chicken in charge of
> most of it since it primarily consisted of hitting the Enter key. The

Lol, I love the way you phrased that.  I should get a stuffed chicken and
use that at work to signal to people that I am "working" on their computer
and that I will be back when the install is finished :)  Or maybe even a
rubber chicken, because when I'm trouble shooting I could swing it around
me head...

> When I logged in for the first time, it was from an 80 x 25 terminal
> screen. I ran startx and found myself looking at KDE, even though that
> wasn't what I checked during the installation. I had some things I

did you use tasksel, aptitude or dpkg?  Or did you pay attention? I didn't
the first couple times.  I guess I'm just suggesting that you may have
installed without realizing it, I haven't used the new installer, but the
2.2 installer was pretty good about only installing what you ask for.

> needed to do with Windows, so I tried to log out and halt Linux. I'm
> used to the logout options provided by Red Hat 7.0 and 7.1, which
> include halt. Halt was not an option. I wondered if I had to be logged
> in as root in order to halt, so I tried to log in as root. I was
> informed that logging in as root is not allowed from that screen! So, I
> logged back in as an ordinary user, su'd and ran halt. That mostly
> worked. Everything shut down, and I got "Power down." on the monitor,
> but the machine never powered down.

I bet you need to change the kernel options.  Becareful with the kernel
options for power management, I have found a reproduceble bug with the
config scripts, where you enable a lot of the power management features,
save the config, load it up again and turn some of them off.  If the build
fails back up your config, make mrproper and then reload your config.  I
can get more detailed if you want.  I would fix it if I knew how...

HTH,
Jason





From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Wed Aug 28 21:56:27 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Wed, 28 Aug 2002 21:56:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] postfix/sendmail errors on -t
Message-ID: <40625.12.231.224.10.1030596987.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>

I'm using a php app...and it gives my /var/log/mail/error log this when it
tries to send an email.
I'm pretty sure that this is where it attempts to send emails..

anything that i can do to fix postfix to let this work?

Aug 28 21:33:51 dns postfix/sendmail[1362]: fatal: cannot handle
command-line recipients with -t

...code snip....
  // This is the function used to send mail throughout OPT. It has
  // precisely the same syntax as mail() - the nice thing is that
  // it sends the correct character encoding provided in the globals.
  function OPT_mail($to, $subject, $message, $ah="", $ap="") {
    $tah=$ah;
    if (!(($tah) && (substr($tah,-1,1)=="\n"))) {
      $tah.="\n";
    }
    global $_OPT;
    $tah.="Content-Type: text/plain; charset=".$_OPT["local"]["encoding"];
    if (isphpver("4.0.5")) {
      return(mail($to, $subject, $message, $tah, $ap));
    } else {
      // additional parameters only in PHP>4.0.5
      return(mail($to, $subject, $message, $tah));
    }
  }
....end code snip...

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Thu Aug 29 00:40:28 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 00:40:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Advanced Topics Meeting on Netule - Follow up.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208290004450.11165-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

This note is primarily for people who attended the Advanced Topics Meeting
last week.  I'm trying to get some feed back on things.

Also, I want to thank everyone.  You gave Dale and I a lot to
think about.  From my point of view, the meeting was very worth while.

(1)  Was the meeting location acceptable?
     I'm trying to get a feel for how much I want to use it
     for things like this in the future.  I know parking is tight
     in the neighborhood.

(2)  A couple people ask me to post my slides.
     I will post my slides on the net sometime next week.

(3)  The big question people had was, "Why should I help?
     What is in it for me?"
     This is a good question.  The theory is that if successful,
     it should lead to name recognition and consulting gigs.
     I certainly willing to talk to anyone about how to make
     this happen.

(4)  Several people proposed virtualizing the individual Netules
     using something like User Mode Linux.  We have considered
     this.  In fact, Karl Hegbloom has looked at this in detail.
     I even had a slide on this, but I didn't show it.

     I think Netules probably could be virtualized using UML,
     and there could be many many advantages to this.  This would
     isolate the Netules from the hardware, make the systems
     scale better, and make them easier to backup and replicate,
     and this is only the beginning of the advantages of using UML.
     Right now, time and resources are a concern.  If they weren't,
     I would definitely take this approach.  Indeed, one could
     consider the whole Netule project as a way of building root
     file systems for UML.

                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213
                                          (360) 260-2066 at work
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell

   ======================================================================
   David Mandel, Product Manager       http://www.MicroSharp.com
                          Other Affiliations
   David Mandel                        http://www.DavidMandel.com
   Portland Linux/Unix Group           http://pdxLinux.org
   LinuxFund                           http://LinuxFund.org
   ======================================================================

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Thu Aug 29 01:08:22 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 29 Aug 2002 01:08:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Having problems loading shared libraries. (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208271057520.4093-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208271057520.4093-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <87lm6q84uh.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

> [rshepard at salmo ~]$ lyx
> lyx: error in loading shared libraries: lyx: undefined symbol: __dynamic_cast_2

IIRC, "dynamic cast" is part of a newer ISO C++ standard now supported
by GCC 3.2.  Am I right?

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Thu Aug 29 01:19:16 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 29 Aug 2002 01:19:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Uninstall KDE
In-Reply-To: <003401c24bff$614d1320$6401a8c0@robbert>
References: <003401c24bff$614d1320$6401a8c0@robbert>
Message-ID: <87bs7m84cb.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

"Robbert van Andel" <robbert at vafam.com> writes:

> How do I uninstall KDE and its programs?  I never use it and I want to
> clear up some space on the hard drive.

YMMV, but I would just log in as root and run "aptitude".  Then I
would search for the "kde" task package, open it, and select
everything under it for "purge".  Perhaps first I would run, from the
command line:

# aptitude markauto '~slibs'

... to ensure that it will auto uninstall most of the no-longer-used
libraries also.

To save a little more space, you might install the "apt-localepurge"
package, and configure it to purge all foreign language translations
that you are not ever going to use.

If you would like a Debian CD, just let me know, and I'll burn you
one.

the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Aug 29 03:05:50 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 03:05:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] First Time Debian Install
In-Reply-To: <3D6D9FBB.53FC9434@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208290300540.27896-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 28 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:
> This time, I was given a Gnome login screen, and it was Gnome into
> which I was put. Again though, no option to halt. I guess I've got
> some more reading to do. (Actually, I know I've got a lot of reading
> to do.)

First, when you finished the install and were given a console for login,
the init scripts installed by the recently configured packages had not
run, so certain first-time-run options hadn't yet taken effect.  When you
rebooted, the init script that fires up the display manager was run and
the display manager has a default session/window manager configured.

If you're using gdm, you will find that it's fairly easy to ensure that a
menu bar exists on the login screen that has a Shutdown and a Reboot
option.  I'm less familiar with xdm as a display manager.  You certainly
don't want Halt as a logout option from your X session as a regular user
and you probably don't want to run most session managers as root.  Best to
setup an .xinitrc in /root that runs a very simple window manager and
that's all for those very few times when you really must use X as root.

> Any recommendations for things to read that will help me understand
> what I should expect (regarding the difference between the way things
> look on Debian vs RH) other than everything on the debian site?

Good golly.  I think it's just time to start becoming familiar with each
package's configuration options instead of relying on some package
maintainer to select what they think you need.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From beattie at beattie-home.net  Thu Aug 29 05:27:13 2002
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: 29 Aug 2002 05:27:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] First Time Debian Install
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208290300540.27896-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208290300540.27896-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1030624033.731.4.camel@coyote>

On Thu, 2002-08-29 at 03:05, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> ...  You certainly
> don't want Halt as a logout option from your X session as a regular user

Why do you say that?  Certainly you would not want a remote console or
terminal for security reasons, but if I'm sitting at the connected
display, I'm probably within reach of the power and reset switches, or I
can just switch to the text console and give the three finger salute. 
The only thing one gains by not putting reboot and halt options on the
logout popup, is inconvinence.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug 29 06:06:24 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 06:06:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A _Red Hat_ upgrade question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0208282102110.3329-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208290602180.31346-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 28 Aug 2002, Fedor G. Pikus wrote:

> I don't think it did that, if the upgrade is restarted you do it from
> scratch. But it does know what you currently have, and a typical upgrade
> will just take the list of installed packages and upgrade them, so you
> should not have to select anything as a part of the upgrade.
> If you want to change your system configuration significantly, do it after
> the upgrade. Aftermy upgrades, I used to go through the upgrade log, see
> what packages I have, remove those I don't really want, check
> configuration files it updated, and did other cruft removal (there is
> nothing in the upgrade process itself which makes it necessary or any
> easier than at any other time, but since I was already doing maintenance,
> it looked like a sensible occasion).

  Thanks, Fedor. The reason I wouldn't be comfortable letting the installer
see what's there and doing its thing unmonitored is that certain critical --
or useful -- packages are not detected and marked for installation. And,
almost all KDE and Gnome packages _are_ marked for "upgrade" although
they're not on the system now. Makes no sense, but that's the way it is.
 
> However, I have to say that after RH7.1 I stopped using upgrades at all.
> I now use apt-rpm to upgrade all myu RedHat boxes. Get it from
> http://apt-rpm.tuxfamily.org/ or from freshrpm's, edit the sources file,
> you can add your RH7.3 CDs to the "repository" (it has a command for
> that), and upgrade away.

  I will certainly grab this and give it a shot. I'm now downloading another
copy of the disk 1 iso because the other one has an apparently corrupt
package that won't install. I _thought_ I had checked the md5 sum before
burning it onto a disk, but I must not have done so.

  Excellent advice that I will take.

Rich




From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Aug 29 06:21:25 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 06:21:25 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A _Red Hat_ upgrade question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208282030030.29256-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208290618350.10555-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 28 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> Anyhow, I gave up for the evening when the cdrom had a corrupted
> file that wouldn't install. Tomorrow is another day and the contest
> continues. Is it only the kernel sources that permit 'make config'
> and let you use the same options time and again? It would sure save
> a ton of time if I didn't need to reselect the packages for a fourth
> time but could use a saved configuration file.

After a successful Red Hat 7.3 installation, there'll be a file named 
/root/anaconda-ks.cfg that can be used to duplicate your installation. 
(Of course, then you'd have to learn about kickstarting a host, which 
takes a bit of time.)

Sadly, I don't know if there's any way to save a configuration 
mid-stream.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Aug 29 06:28:49 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 06:28:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A _Red Hat_ upgrade question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208290618350.10555-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208290622290.31440-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> After a successful Red Hat 7.3 installation, there'll be a file named 
> /root/anaconda-ks.cfg that can be used to duplicate your installation. 

Paul,

  The boxes are set up differently here. For example, I do development work
on only one box so the other workstation and the notebook have fewer
packages installed.
 
> Sadly, I don't know if there's any way to save a configuration mid-stream.

  Ah, well. What I did discover is that the TUI (the "text" install option)
is faster than the GUI (default) option. Much quicker package
selection/deselection and faster running overall.

  One of the most important lessons I learned from Cooper is the value of
'parted' to edit partitions from within linux. It may not be quite as slick
as PartitionMagic, but it's free and it works.

  For whatever reason, /usr didn't have sufficient room. So through magic,
smoke and mirrors and several hours of waiting for the machine to do its
thing, punctuated by moments of blind panic when we thought we had lost a
partition or two, we shrunk /usr2 by 5G and added that space to /usr. A very
useful tool that I hope I don't need to use again. :-)

Many thanks,

Rich

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Thu Aug 29 10:03:17 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 10:03:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Flag folders w/new mail under pine?
In-Reply-To: <3D6E506F.5030108@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208290953480.23238-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

How do I configure pine or mutt to flag folders when they contain new
mail? For example, I sort PLUG-related email into a plug mail folder under
pine, but I can't tell when that folder contains new mail without actually
opening it. This becomes tedious when dealing with many folders. Is there
a way to configure the client so it lists when new messages are there,
and (even better) how many new messages? ie:

plug(3)  spam(4)  foo-list(19)

Any ideas?

Tyler




From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Aug 29 10:12:02 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 10:12:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Flag folders w/new mail under pine?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208290953480.23238-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208291009200.10555-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

> How do I configure pine or mutt to flag folders when they contain
> new mail?

In pine, you add an incoming-folders directive to ~/.pinerc, e.g.,

incoming-folders="plug" mail/mailinglists/plug,
 	"spam" mail/spam,
	"foo-list" mail/mailinglists/foo-list

Then once you're done reading your inbox, just press the Tab key. pine 
will cycle through your incoming folders, giving you the option to 
visit them if they contain new messages.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Thu Aug 29 10:14:45 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 10:14:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A training cooperative?
In-Reply-To: <1030234291.32738.497.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208290904390.11165-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

    A training cooperative is an interesting idea, but I think it
would have to be a bit more involved than some of the postings
would lead one to believe.  Basically, I don't think one can do
an effective training cooperative without charging.  People need
to get paid for their facilities if they are used very much,
and the instructors should get something as well.  The truth is
it costs money to maintain space and equipment, and it generally
costs an instructor a bit of money just to teach a class.  On the
other hand, I don't think one needs to charge the sort of rates
most commercial training companies charge which seem to run from
$30 per student hour for low level classes and well over $50 per
student hour for higher level classes.  For example, PEAK in Corvallis
ran a pretty decent training program that charged $10 to $15 per
student hour for many years.  (They have since closed it.)

    As far as facilities,

    -  I would be willing and interested in using the area we
       used for the last Advanced Topics Meeting for a training
       cooperative if it made financial sense to me.

or

    -  I'm sure MicroSharp would be interested in some sort of
       an arrangement.  Potentially, they have space for multiple
       class rooms.  Unfortunately, they are in East Vancouver,
       but they are close to main roads.

    Likewise, I think we could make deals for furniture, white boards,
projectors, and so on.  Some of these would be pretty poor to start
with, but that is life.  (By the way, Allen Montgomery from Alliance
Internet Solutions is loaning PLUG a projector for four months.
It has some problems, but it is nice to have.)

    I guess, I think a good goal would be to charge $15/hr retail
with some sort of discount available so most "PLUG members" paid
about $10/hr.  This might be broken up as:

              $5/hr to any reseller who signed someone up.
                    (However, discount cards would be passed out at
                    PLUG meetings, so meeting attendees could sign
                    up without this fee.  Or something like this.
                    Also, the discounts would be available to other
                    Open Source Groups like the Eugene and Mid-Valley
                    Group.)
              $5/hr to the instructor.
              $5/hr for facilities and PLUG.
                    (most of this would go for things like paying for
                    broadband if it is at my house and equipment.
                    Maybe PLUG could eventually afford a projector.
                    Maybe PLUG could afford to get 501(c)3 status?)


    Ok, I'm a bit unsure about all the details, but this is the
general idea.  Is this something that would interest people?
Or is this a dumb idea?


                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213
                                          (360) 260-2066 at work
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell

I guess a lot of people were thinking that it should be free so that folks
who are out of work can afford it.  Most classes out there (like the two
or three day classes out at OGI) charge something like $2000 - there's
no way people who are not working can afford this.  They may have the
money, but since they don't know when they'll be working again they want
to save it. If it's cheap enough for people who have no current income,
then charging may make some sense.

Phil

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Thu Aug 29 11:04:38 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 11:04:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A training cooperative?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208291027210.14529-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208291042440.23436-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Charging people for the class would place pressure on the teacher to
make it high quality. Since we don't have a lot of
time to dedicate towards teaching, this pressure might not be welcome.
Charging by the hour might also pressure the teacher to keep the class
under an hour and could discourage questions. Personally, I would also
feel discouraged from teaching subjects that I enjoy but am less
knowledgeable in.

So generally I would prefer a free class, both as teacher and student.


Tyler


On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Phil Tomson wrote:

>
>
> On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, David Mandel wrote:
>
> >
> >     A training cooperative is an interesting idea, but I think it
> > would have to be a bit more involved than some of the postings
> > would lead one to believe.  Basically, I don't think one can do
> > an effective training cooperative without charging.  People need
> > to get paid for their facilities if they are used very much,
> > and the instructors should get something as well.  The truth is
> > it costs money to maintain space and equipment, and it generally
> > costs an instructor a bit of money just to teach a class.  On the
> > other hand, I don't think one needs to charge the sort of rates
> > most commercial training companies charge which seem to run from
> > $30 per student hour for low level classes and well over $50 per
> > student hour for higher level classes.  For example, PEAK in Corvallis
> > ran a pretty decent training program that charged $10 to $15 per
> > student hour for many years.  (They have since closed it.)
> >
> >     As far as facilities,
> >
> >     -  I would be willing and interested in using the area we
> >        used for the last Advanced Topics Meeting for a training
> >        cooperative if it made financial sense to me.
> >
> > or
> >
> >     -  I'm sure MicroSharp would be interested in some sort of
> >        an arrangement.  Potentially, they have space for multiple
> >        class rooms.  Unfortunately, they are in East Vancouver,
> >        but they are close to main roads.
> >
> >     Likewise, I think we could make deals for furniture, white boards,
> > projectors, and so on.  Some of these would be pretty poor to start
> > with, but that is life.  (By the way, Allen Montgomery from Alliance
> > Internet Solutions is loaning PLUG a projector for four months.
> > It has some problems, but it is nice to have.)
> >
> >     I guess, I think a good goal would be to charge $15/hr retail
> > with some sort of discount available so most "PLUG members" paid
> > about $10/hr.  This might be broken up as:
> >
> >               $5/hr to any reseller who signed someone up.
> >                     (However, discount cards would be passed out at
> >                     PLUG meetings, so meeting attendees could sign
> >                     up without this fee.  Or something like this.
> >                     Also, the discounts would be available to other
> >                     Open Source Groups like the Eugene and Mid-Valley
> >                     Group.)
> >               $5/hr to the instructor.
> >               $5/hr for facilities and PLUG.
> >                     (most of this would go for things like paying for
> >                     broadband if it is at my house and equipment.
> >                     Maybe PLUG could eventually afford a projector.
> >                     Maybe PLUG could afford to get 501(c)3 status?)
> >
> >
> >     Ok, I'm a bit unsure about all the details, but this is the
> > general idea.  Is this something that would interest people?
> > Or is this a dumb idea?
> >
>
>
> I guess a lot of people were thinking that it should be free so that folks
> who are out of work can afford it.  Most classes out there (like the two
> or three day classes out at OGI) charge something like $2000 - there's
> no way people who are not working can afford this.  They may have the
> money, but since they don't know when they'll be working again they want
> to save it. If it's cheap enough for people who have no current income,
> then charging may make some sense.
>
> Phil
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208291042440.23436-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

You're right, payment creates pressure, but at those rates I wouldn't feel much pressure as an instructor OR a 
student. Pay the instructor a couple of grand a day, and I'll expect a halftime show and an escalator. I'm for 
the form that David has proposed, it generates the needed capitol to make it run, without overly taxing those 
who have it to share (facilities, knowledge, hardware)

Count me in as a student.

Mike

8/29/02 11:04:38 AM, "Tyler F. Creelan" <creelan at engr.orst.edu> wrote:

>
>Charging people for the class would place pressure on the teacher to
>make it high quality. Since we don't have a lot of
>time to dedicate towards teaching, this pressure might not be welcome.
>Charging by the hour might also pressure the teacher to keep the class
>under an hour and could discourage questions. Personally, I would also
>feel discouraged from teaching subjects that I enjoy but am less
>knowledgeable in.
>
>So generally I would prefer a free class, both as teacher and student.

>Tyler

From alex at daniloff.com  Thu Aug 29 10:50:32 2002

Subject: [PLUG] GPIB cards for =?iso-8859-1?q?Linux=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208290953480.23238-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Hello Linux folkz,
Does somebody know about any PCI GPIB cards 
which will reliably work with Linux?
I need to solve some equipment control problems at work.
Therefore I have to pick up the proper GPIB card with 
known protocol and existing Linux driver for it.
May be somebody could share his/her experience of using
GPIB interface with Linux.
Thank you very much in advance for any thoughts or sources 
of information.

Alex

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Aug 29 13:25:37 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 13:25:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] GPIB cards for Linux?
In-Reply-To: <200208291750.g7THoWj06397@gate.daniloff.com>; from alex@daniloff.com on Thu, Aug 29, 2002 at 10:50:32AM -0700
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208290953480.23238-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <200208291750.g7THoWj06397@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <20020829132537.E5836@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, Aug 29, 2002 at 10:50:32AM -0700, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Linux folkz,
> Does somebody know about any PCI GPIB cards 
> which will reliably work with Linux?
> I need to solve some equipment control problems at work.
> Therefore I have to pick up the proper GPIB card with 
> known protocol and existing Linux driver for it.
> May be somebody could share his/her experience of using
> GPIB interface with Linux.
> Thank you very much in advance for any thoughts or sources 
> of information.

We use National Instruments.  They come with Linux drivers, and
if you use Perl, then there are some great drivers that you can
use for data acquisition.  At work, we dual-booted our lab machine
to see if they worked, and that machine hasn't run Windows since.
We can even run experiments remotely from our desktops by logging
in via ssh.

Colin

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Thu Aug 29 14:40:01 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 14:40:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Making web browsing fun again
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208291430470.23738-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

I wanted to share a tip I learned, and then ask others if they have
similar tips they would like to share.

My tip is to use Galeon to browse the web, it seems faster than mozilla,
but supports the same things (I think they use embeded gecko or
something).  I have mine set so that when I middle click on a link it
opens in a new tab in the same window, but doesn't get focus.  This is
nice, because I can continue to read the page I'm on (works well when
searching with google), and when the tab turns blue (meaning it is loaded,
but unread) I can go look at it.  Galeon has another nice feature called
smart bookmarks.  I have google, google linux, and debian searchable
from the top of any galeon window.

My only complaint about Galeon is that sometimes when I launch it, it asks
if I want to restore my last session.  But I think I can turn that off.

Does anyone know of a good filter proxy for blocking banner ads and
pop-ups?  I just found one called Yet Another Filter Proxy (YAFP), but I
haven't had a chance to test it.

I'm interested to hear the advice of others.

Has anyone gotten so sick of web browsers that you use a script where wget
downloads the page, and they you convert it to ps and use ghostview? (The
thought has crossed my mind several times...)

Jason




From keith at ahapala.net  Thu Aug 29 14:46:58 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 14:46:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Making web browsing fun again

Thanks, I'll give that a try. :-)

> pop-ups?  I just found one called Yet Another Filter Proxy (YAFP), but I
> haven't had a chance to test it.

In galeon you can go to the settings menu and uncheck "popups" and choose 
"load images from current server only". This should quiet it down quite a 
bit.

Keith




From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Thu Aug 29 14:57:08 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 14:57:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Making web browsing fun again
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208291444400.13992-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208291450320.23738-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Keith Nasman wrote:

> In galeon you can go to the settings menu and uncheck "popups" and choose
> "load images from current server only". This should quiet it down quite a
> bit.

I'll give that a try, I don't allow pop-ups, but I had never thought about
the second option as a way to block banners.  There is a program I use at
work called proxomitron (great for windows users) that blocks the image if
the image has certian characteristics, such as shape and size.  This
catchs most if not all banners.  Proxomitron uses perl I believe, but I
don't know how one would port it to linux.  That is why I was considering
YAFP.  Perhaps I should contac the Proxomitron author and see if I can
convince him to use the gpl and make a linux port.

Jason




From richard.langis at sun.com  Thu Aug 29 15:10:37 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 15:10:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Making web browsing fun again
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208291430470.23738-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <3D6E9BDD.7050903@sun.com>

I'm using a combination junkbuster -> squid proxy at home.  Junkbuster 
is an opt-in filter, meaning you have to manually add the things you 
want to block.  However, most ad banner cgis and urls are pretty 
similar, and/or come from the same place, so only a few entries will 
catch 90% of the ads.

My wife likes to use IE under XP, so she doesn't have the option of 
turning off popups or other Bad(tm) things.  I have to do all that on 
the packet-pushing side.  Lucky me.

She DOES like how junkbuster can block out an ad and put in a custom 'ad 
blocked' page/image/url.  Keeps the page layout workable - some ad 
blockers replace the ad with a 1x1 .gif.

-R

> I wanted to share a tip I learned, and then ask others if they have

> pop-ups?  I just found one called Yet Another Filter Proxy (YAFP), but I

From sandy at herring.org  Thu Aug 29 15:31:11 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 15:31:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Flag folders w/new mail under pine?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208291009200.10555-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>; from heinlein@attbi.com on Thu, Aug 29, 2002 at 10:12:02AM -0700
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208290953480.23238-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208291009200.10555-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <20020829153111.B11499@kippered.herring.org>

On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote: 
> On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> 
> > How do I configure pine or mutt to flag folders when they contain
> > new mail?
> 
> In pine, you add an incoming-folders directive to ~/.pinerc, e.g.,
> 
> incoming-folders="plug" mail/mailinglists/plug,
>  	"spam" mail/spam,
> 	"foo-list" mail/mailinglists/foo-list
> 
> Then once you're done reading your inbox, just press the Tab key. pine 
> will cycle through your incoming folders, giving you the option to 
> visit them if they contain new messages.

And since you also asked about mutt...

In your .muttrc, you designate which folders receive mail with the `mailboxes'
command...

   Linkname: The Mutt E-Mail Client: Configuration
        URL: http://www.mutt.org/doc/manual/manual-3.html#ss3.11

Also of interest in this regard is `status_format'...
   
   Linkname: The Mutt E-Mail Client: Reference
        URL: http://www.mutt.org/doc/manual/manual-6.html#status_format

...to control the information displayed on the status line of the index
menu.

Sandy

From alex at daniloff.com  Thu Aug 29 14:52:46 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 14:52:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] GPIB cards for =?iso-8859-1?q?Linux=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <743QNC8SM231WUPK31KHOK51YT08V.3d6e8994@miked>
Message-ID: <200208292152.g7TLqkw06574@gate.daniloff.com>

It is a General Purpose Interface Bus.
HP has developed it a long time ago to operate 
with test and measurement equipment.
It has a protocol which is some what similar to USB. 
Initially it was named HPIB. 
When it has became an industry open standard, 
its name changed to GPIB.
Currently about 85% of test and measurement tools are
using GPIB protocol.
Hope this helps.
Alex 

-------------------
> What's a GPIB card?
> 
> 
> _____________________
> Mike De La Mater
> 



From montagne at boora.com  Thu Aug 29 16:48:22 2002

differs from konsole in one big way.  When I edit a file in vim or use

Jason Dagit said:
> Does anyone know of a good filter proxy for blocking banner ads and
> pop-ups?  I just found one called Yet Another Filter Proxy (YAFP), but I
> haven't had a chance to test it.

Not a proxy-based solution, but Mozilla users can look to should check out
BannerBlind. It filters based on banner size, with many presets available.
It did a semi-decent job w/ default settings, and could probably do much
better w/ a few custom sizes added.

http://bannerblind.mozdev.org

I was shocked how clean the web looked afer using this for the first time.
More like the web of yore, before the dark times, before DoubleClick.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District





From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Thu Aug 29 18:20:02 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 29 Aug 2002 18:20:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] gnome-terminal
In-Reply-To: <20020829234821.GA31334@boora.com>
References: <20020829234821.GA31334@boora.com>
Message-ID: <1030670402.18166.10.camel@duron>

On Thu, 2002-08-29 at 16:48, Michael Montagne wrote:
> I'm trying out gnome after using KDE for a long time.  Gnome-terminal
> differs from konsole in one big way.  When I edit a file in vim or use
> mutt to view my mail, the text from the program stays on the screen
> after I've terminated it.  In konsole, it just went away and you were
> back to how you started.  Is this a feature?  How can I emulate konsole
> behavior in gnome-terminal? 

I never noticed the difference before... but you're right.

A regular console does the same thing (not resetting), this must be a
konsole feature.

You can run konsoles in gnome just fine by running konsole as if it were
any other application.  I like the gnome-terminals, though.  They're
what I use here in fluxbox and even when I'm in KDE or GNOME, which is
quite rare.

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"

I'm not certian what you mean, and I don't have a konsole arround (so
mabey I shouldn't be answering this email...).  But, you could create an
alias that runs "clear" after vim or mutt.

That being said, I reccomend rxvt for a console, it is _very_ fast, and
as far as I can tell it has all the features of gnome-terminal.

the boot process to hang when trying to load these daemons?

of a sudden. (I was rebooting because I built the 2.4.19 kernel and tried to
boot with it as a test. Something's wronng with the installation of that
kernel, and it was when trying to boot with the old, 2.2.19 kernel, that it
started to hang.)

  Here's another wierd thing. During the POST check before booting, the
system reports that the floppy drive test fails. I press the F1 key to go on
and the floppy drive is perfectly usable. So, I've not thought too mauch
about it, especially as I don't reboot too often.

  Today, I commented out the nfs-mounted filesystems in /etc/fstab, and now
the floppy disk failure error does not appear during a boot! I have the X
font server problems, however, just to keep me on my toes.

  FWIW, trying to upgrade the other workstation (caddis, to those of you who
know of my network) to RH 7.3 kept failing when the upgrade program tried to
install 'chkconfig'. This happened twice, on two different medium brands,
but with the ISO from the same mirror source. Using yet another disk 1, from
a different ISO source, I specified to NOT upgrade 'chkconfig' and the
process ran to completion.

  But, packages I specifically excluded from upgrade -- the KDE and Gnome
packages -- were installed anyway! This is the most troublesome upgrade in
five years. I have expert consultation here, but it's an ongoing challenge.

Sigh,

From jon at manymoons.net  Thu Aug 29 20:13:52 2002

Have you tried Opera?  It is very fast, and you can easily turn popups
on and off.  I have never used either of the proxies mentioned here, but
with Opera if you need a popup (because sites DO use them for legitimate
reasons) then they are easy to activate.

Of couse, it does not block banner ads, but then I have never had a
problem ignoring them.....

On Thu, 2002-08-29 at 14:40, Jason Dagit wrote:
> I wanted to share a tip I learned, and then ask others if they have
> similar tips they would like to share.
> 
> My tip is to use Galeon to browse the web, it seems faster than mozilla,
> but supports the same things (I think they use embeded gecko or
> something).  I have mine set so that when I middle click on a link it
> opens in a new tab in the same window, but doesn't get focus.  This is
> nice, because I can continue to read the page I'm on (works well when
> searching with google), and when the tab turns blue (meaning it is loaded,
> but unread) I can go look at it.  Galeon has another nice feature called
> smart bookmarks.  I have google, google linux, and debian searchable
> from the top of any galeon window.
> 
> My only complaint about Galeon is that sometimes when I launch it, it asks
> if I want to restore my last session.  But I think I can turn that off.
> 
> Does anyone know of a good filter proxy for blocking banner ads and
> pop-ups?  I just found one called Yet Another Filter Proxy (YAFP), but I
> haven't had a chance to test it.
> 
> I'm interested to hear the advice of others.
> 
> Has anyone gotten so sick of web browsers that you use a script where wget
> downloads the page, and they you convert it to ps and use ghostview? (The
> thought has crossed my mind several times...)
>

From kens at cad2cam.com  Thu Aug 29 21:41:01 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 21:41:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Advanced Topics Meeting on Netule - Follow up.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208290004450.11165-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208290004450.11165-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <200208292141.01114.kens@cad2cam.com>

On Thursday 29 August 2002 12:40 am, David Mandel wrote:
> This note is primarily for people who attended the Advanced Topics Meeting
> last week.  I'm trying to get some feed back on things.
>
> Also, I want to thank everyone.  You gave Dale and I a lot to
> think about.  From my point of view, the meeting was very worth while.
>
> (1)  Was the meeting location acceptable?
>      I'm trying to get a feel for how much I want to use it
>      for things like this in the future.  I know parking is tight
>      in the neighborhood.
>
> (2)  A couple people ask me to post my slides.
>      I will post my slides on the net sometime next week.
>
> (3)  The big question people had was, "Why should I help?
>      What is in it for me?"
>      This is a good question.  The theory is that if successful,
>      it should lead to name recognition and consulting gigs.
>      I certainly willing to talk to anyone about how to make
>      this happen.
>
> (4)  Several people proposed virtualizing the individual Netules
>      using something like User Mode Linux.  We have considered
>      this.  In fact, Karl Hegbloom has looked at this in detail.
>      I even had a slide on this, but I didn't show it.
>
>      I think Netules probably could be virtualized using UML,
>      and there could be many many advantages to this.  This would
>      isolate the Netules from the hardware, make the systems
>      scale better, and make them easier to backup and replicate,
>      and this is only the beginning of the advantages of using UML.
>      Right now, time and resources are a concern.  If they weren't,
>      I would definitely take this approach.  Indeed, one could
>      consider the whole Netule project as a way of building root
>      file systems for UML.
>
>                                           Sincerely,
>                                           David Mandel
David,

A distribution is more than the software.  A distribution needs to have also 
(in no particular order of importance and some points may be redundant):
1.  A viable mailing list for support, 
2.  Training for both the installers/supporters and users. 
3.  User community/target market.
4.  Documentation.
	Howtos
	Quick Step intallation instructions
	Detailed man pages
5.  Purpose or niche.
6.  Sponsor or support organization willing to organize the other points.
7.  Be fun to use. (Why not just work, to start with?)
8.  A unique mascot.(I can supply a picture of my dog with antlers)  87)

-- 
Ken Stephens
www.cad2cam.com
www.cadtocam.com

From robbert at vafam.com  Thu Aug 29 22:12:35 2002
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 22:12:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla Upgrade
In-Reply-To: <200208292141.01114.kens@cad2cam.com>
Message-ID: <000001c24fe3$dad5cb50$6401a8c0@robbert>

I'm having an issue upgrading Mozilla 1.1.  I downloaded the RPM from
Mozilla.org and tried doing an RPM -ivh mozilla-1.1-0.i386.rpm and get
the following

Error: failed dependencies:
	Mozilla-nspr = 1.1-0 is needed by mozilla-1.1-0

So I downloaded mozilla-nspr-1.1-0.i386.rpm and tried the same rpm
command on it.  I get the following error

Error: failed dependencies
	mozilla-nspr = 0.9.9-12.7.3 is needed by mozilla-0.9.9-12.7-3
	mozilla-nspr = 0.9.9-12.7.3 is needed by
mozilla-nspr-devel-0.9.9-12.7.3
	mozilla-nspr = 0.90.9.9-12.7.3 is needed by
mozilla-nss-0.9.9-12.7.3

I tried adding -U to do an upgrade, but got the same error.  Anyone out
there have an idea that I can use to upgrade Mozilla and deal with the
dependencies.  I'm guessing I'm missing a switch on the rpm command.

Robbert van Andel




From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Thu Aug 29 22:45:56 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 22:45:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla Upgrade
In-Reply-To: <000001c24fe3$dad5cb50$6401a8c0@robbert>
References: <200208292141.01114.kens@cad2cam.com>
        <000001c24fe3$dad5cb50$6401a8c0@robbert>
Message-ID: <64543.12.231.181.15.1030686356.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

Robbert van Andel said:
--snipped--
> Anyone out
> there have an idea that I can use to upgrade Mozilla and deal with the
> dependencies.  I'm guessing I'm missing a switch on the rpm command.

First, do a:

rpm -qa | grep mozilla

to see what mozilla packages you have installed.

Then d/l the updated ones to match. Followed by

rpm -Uvh mozilla*1.1-0.i386.rpm

That will match all of the mozilla rpms you d/l'ed that are v1.1-0 and
will update all of the mozilla rpms at once. If multiple packages are
dependant on each other, you have to upgrade them all at once, rather than
one at a time.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District





From guyh at aracnet.com  Thu Aug 29 22:51:09 2002
From: guyh at aracnet.com (Guy Hammer)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 22:51:09 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Flag folders w/new mail under pine?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208291009200.10555-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.10.10208292246380.29740-100000@noname.nodomain.nowhere>

On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> In pine, you add an incoming-folders directive to ~/.pinerc, e.g.,
> 
> incoming-folders="plug" mail/mailinglists/plug,
>  	"spam" mail/spam,
> 	"foo-list" mail/mailinglists/foo-list
> 
> Then once you're done reading your inbox, just press the Tab key. pine 
> will cycle through your incoming folders, giving you the option to 
> visit them if they contain new messages.

Sweet! That's one of the better tips I've gleaned off of this list.
Many thanks, Paul.

Now another question - I use vim in place of pico for my pine compose
editor. Can some one 'splain to me how to invoke ispell within vim?

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Aug 29 23:49:11 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 2002 23:49:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Flag folders w/new mail under pine?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.10.10208292246380.29740-100000@noname.nodomain.nowhere>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208292345170.12420-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Guy Hammer wrote:
> On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > In pine, you add an incoming-folders directive to ~/.pinerc, e.g.,
> > 
> > incoming-folders="plug" mail/mailinglists/plug,
> >  	"spam" mail/spam,
> > 	"foo-list" mail/mailinglists/foo-list
> > 
> > Then once you're done reading your inbox, just press the Tab key. pine 
> > will cycle through your incoming folders, giving you the option to 
> > visit them if they contain new messages.
> 
> Sweet! That's one of the better tips I've gleaned off of this list.
> Many thanks, Paul.

I would also share with you that I use the following in my .pinerc:
initial-keystroke-list=l,
    CR,
    ;,
    p,
    n

I'm not sure if there's a better way to do that, but essentially it hops
to the first entry in my folder group list (the ones that get incoming
mail), opens that group, then selects groups that contain new
messages.  That way, I get a little X next to the names of all the folders
that contain new mail.

> Now another question - I use vim in place of pico for my pine compose
> editor. Can some one 'splain to me how to invoke ispell within vim?

That I don't know, but I have a related question:

On this list a while back, folks were describing how they use vim as their
editor from pine and are capable of doing more robust quote formatting
than pico handles by default.  This interest me immensely.  Can someone
share that info?

Thanks.
J.

From karlheg at pdxLinux.org  Fri Aug 30 00:30:45 2002
From: karlheg at pdxLinux.org (karlheg at pdxLinux.org)
Date: 30 Aug 2002 00:30:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 3ddesk, sawfish, hotkeys, Microsoft Natural Pro USB
Message-ID: <87fzww7qhm.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Has anyone else discovered "3ddesk"?  <URL:http://desk3d.sourceforge.net/>

Here's what I've done with it...  It's really cool to switch desktops
with a hotkey and watch the OpenGL rendered "flip" from one screen to
the next.  It's almost as if the glass of the monitor spins around
pivots at the top and bottom center, flipping from one side to the
other to show a different virtual desktop.  I can push a different
hotkey and it stays in the 3ddesk mode, where the mouse wheel flips
from one to the next until I find the one I want, then I click the
wheel and there I am.  Works best on a fast computer, of course.

I've got one of those Microsoft Natural Pro USB keyboards that has the
extra buttons along the top of it (and two USB ports).  I installed
"hotkeys" so I can use those buttons, and wrote a keyboard definition
for it.  I've turned the "Back", "Forward", "Stop" and "Refresh"
buttons into controls for the "3ddesk".  I can also control XMMS and
the sound volume from the keyboard.

"/usr/share/hotkeys/mymsnatpro.def"
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<CONFIG model="Microsoft Natural Keyboard Pro">
  <userdef    keycode="234"
              command="3ddesk --gotoleft">Back</userdef>
  <userdef    keycode="233"
              command="3ddesk --gotoright">Forward</userdef>
  <userdef    keycode="232"
              command="3ddesk --mode=flip">Stop</userdef>
  <!-- Refresh button -->
  <userdef keycode="121" command="/usr/local/bin/hotkeys-refresh">Refresh</userdef>
  <Search     keycode="229"/>
  <Favorites  keycode="230"/>
  <WebBrowser keycode="130"/>
  <Email      keycode="236"/>

  <Mute       keycode="166"/>
  <VolUp      keycode="158" adj="2"/>
  <VolDown    keycode="165" adj="2"/>

  <Play       keycode="159"/>
  <Stop       keycode="151"/>
  <PrevTrack  keycode="164"/>
  <NextTrack  keycode="162"/>
  <!-- Media button -->
  <userdef keycode="129" command="/usr/bin/gnome-vlc">VLC</userdef>

  <MyComputer keycode="111"/>
  <Calculator keycode="161"/>

  <!-- <Sleep      keycode="227"/> -->
  <userdef keycode="227" command="/usr/bin/X11/xset dpms force off">DPMS off</userdef>

</CONFIG>
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

"/etc/hotkeys.conf"
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
############################################################
# Global configuration for hotkeys                         #
############################################################

# These are the default values.
# A line starting with # is a comment.

### Specify the default keyboard  (without the .def extension) so you
### don't need to specify -t every time
# Kbd=acerwl
# CDROM=/dev/cdrom

Kbd=mymsnatpro
CDROM=/dev/cdroms/cdrom0

PrevTrack=xmms --rew
Play=xmms --play-pause
Stop=xmms --stop
Pause=xmms --pause
NextTrack=xmms --fwd
# Rewind=

WebBrowser=galeon -n http://www.intra.hegbloom.net/
# Email=mozilla -mail
Email=evolution
# Calculator=xcalc
Calculator=gnumeric
# FileManager=nautilus
MyComputer=nautilus
# MyDocuments=nautilus
Favorites=galeon -n http://www.intra.hegbloom.net/dc/
# Transfer=gtp
# Record=grecord
# Shell=xterm -rv
# ScreenSaver=xscreensaver-command -activate
# NewsReader=mozilla -news
# Communities=mozilla -remote 'openURL(http://slashdot.org)'
Search=galeon -n http://www.google.com/
# Idea=mozilla -remote 'openURL(http://sourceforge.net)'
# Shopping=mozilla -remote 'openURL(http://thinkgeek.com)'
# Go=mozilla -remote 'openURL(http://linux.com)'
# Print=lpr
# Rotate=

Sleep=xset dpms force off

# osd_font=-arphic-ar pl kaitim big5-bold-i-normal--0-250-0-0-c-0-*-*
### For the color, you can either use the strings in /etc/X11/rgb.txt,
### or use the RGB syntax #RRGGBB, e.g. ##A086FF
# osd_color=LawnGreen
# osd_timeout=3
### osd_position is either 'top' or 'bottom'
# osd_position=bottom
# osd_offset=25
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

"/usr/local/bin/hotkeys-refresh"
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
#!/bin/sh
PATH=/usr/bin/X11:/usr/bin:/bin
xrefresh
3ddesk --acquirecurrent
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

I've also written some simple hooks for the Sawfish window manager
that make 3ddesk work a lot more smoothly.  I've got 4 workspaces
configured, that are one screen or viewport each, but I think it would
work fine with other configurations.  In my "~/.sawfishrc" is:

8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
(defun 3ddesk ()
  (interactive)
  (system "3ddesk --mode=flip &"))

(defun 3ddesk-acquire ()
  (system "3ddesk --acquire &"))

(defun 3ddesk-acquirecurrent ()
  (system "(sleep 1 && 3ddesk --acquirecurrent)&"))

(add-hook 'enter-workspace-hook 3ddesk-acquirecurrent)
(add-hook 'add-to-workspace-hook 3ddesk-acquirecurrent)
(add-hook 'remove-from-workspace-hook 3ddesk-acquirecurrent)

(bind-keys global-keymap "W-Button2-Click" 3ddesk)

;; NO!  You'll regret it.
;; (add-hook 'workspace-state-change-hook 3ddesk-acquire)
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

Placeing 3ddesk-acquirecurrent on those hooks makes it grab a snapshot
of the screen right after changing desktops, so that it always has a
reasonablely current picture of each virtual screen, even if I use the
Gnome pager to change screens.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Fri Aug 30 01:16:40 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 30 Aug 2002 01:16:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] gnome-terminal
In-Reply-To: <20020829234821.GA31334@boora.com>
References: <20020829234821.GA31334@boora.com>
Message-ID: <87bs7k7od3.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Michael Montagne <montagne at boora.com> writes:

> I'm trying out gnome after using KDE for a long time.
> Gnome-terminal differs from konsole in one big way.  When I edit a
> file in vim or use mutt to view my mail, the text from the program
> stays on the screen after I've terminated it.  In konsole, it just
> went away and you were back to how you started.  Is this a feature?
> How can I emulate konsole behavior in gnome-terminal?

Launch an "xterm" (a recent one, from XFree86 4), then hold down the
Ctrl key and hold down the middle mouse button.  You'll see a popup
menu, and down near the bottom of it, you'll see "Enable alternate
screen switching".  Try using "less" on something with and without
that menu item checked.

Now, look at the man page for "xterm" and the one for "terminfo",
searching the xterm page for the string "alternate screen" and the
terminfo one for "ca_mode"...  You'll see that there is a control
sequence that switches to an alternate screen, and another that
switches back.  There is a document that describes all of the xterm
control sequences in <URL:http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/xterm/>.

I do not know how to make "gnome-terminal" behave that way, but do
know that "multi-gnome-terminal" does support the alternate screen.
Apparently "screen" does not have that "alternate screen" feature, at
least not with the termcap mine is using.

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'



From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Fri Aug 30 01:51:21 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 30 Aug 2002 01:51:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] First Time Debian Install
In-Reply-To: <3D6D9FBB.53FC9434@attbi.com>
References: <3D6D9FBB.53FC9434@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <877ki87mra.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Richard Steffens <rsteff at attbi.com> writes:

> I started installing Debian via the Internet (cable connection) on
> Monday. As someone mentioned, I could have left a chicken in charge
> of most of it since it primarily consisted of hitting the Enter
> key. The process did take a long time, though. The installation
> continued through all of yesterday and probably a good part of last
> night. This morning it was waiting for me to tell it to continue. It
> finished before lunch time.

You installed a LOT of software if it took that long over a cable
connection!  It must be really loaded!

> When I logged in for the first time, it was from an 80 x 25 terminal
> screen. I ran startx and found myself looking at KDE, even though
> that wasn't what I checked during the installation.

Perhaps the X Desktop Environment task pulled in KDE for you?  If you
"apt-get install aptitude", you can use "aptitude" to unload the stuff
you don't want.  Once again, I highly recommend it in preference to
"dselect" for package management.

> I had some things I needed to do with Windows, so I tried to log out
> and halt Linux. I'm used to the logout options provided by Red Hat
> 7.0 and 7.1, which include halt. Halt was not an option. I wondered
> if I had to be logged in as root in order to halt, so I tried to log
> in as root. I was informed that logging in as root is not allowed
> from that screen! So, I logged back in as an ordinary user, su'd and
> ran halt. That mostly worked. Everything shut down, and I got "Power
> down." on the monitor, but the machine never powered down.

I'm not sure what you are saying happened here, in that I don't know
what screen you are on when you try to log in as root.  You had run
"startx", but I don't know if you did that as "root" or as yourself.
When you use "startx" rather than an X login manager, you do not need
the "halt" option on a logout menu.  The "logout" there is to log out
of X, back to your text mode shell.  Once there, you can use
"Ctrl-Alt-DEL" or "halt" to shut down the computer.

I can't imagine why it would not allow you to log in as root from the
text console...  the X login managers do have configuration options to
disallow root logins, and are shipped with somewhat parnoid security
settings.  For "gdm", you must edit "/etc/gdm/gdm.conf", find the
"[Security]" section, and change "AllowRoot" to "true", then restart
"gdm" with "/etc/init.d/gdm restart".  After that, log into X as root,
and look in the "System" menu (underfoot) for the "GDM Configurator".
(For KDE's X login manager, log into X as root (IIRC it will let you
do so by default), and use the control center to configure the KDM.)

If you have more than one X login manager installed, you can switch
which one is run at boot with "dpkg-reconfigure gdm" or
"dpkg-reconfigure kdm".  You may also reconfigure your X Server the
same way: "dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xfree86", for instance.  Do this
as root from a text console with no X login manager running.
("/etc/init.d/gdm stop"; and don't do that if you are logged into X or
it will blow away your session.)

The reason it did not power itself off is that you do not have the
"apm" module loaded.  Try "modprobe apm" and see if "halt" shuts the
computer off after that.  If it does not work, then try "apt-get
install apmd", and try the "halt" again after ensuring that the "apm"
module got loaded AND the "apmd" was running.  If it worked without
the apmd, you probably don't need to run it, and you can "echo apm >>
/etc/modules" (make certain you use TWO ">") to ensure that the apm
module will be loaded on boot.

(I've had some trouble on a few machines in the past where the APM
stuff pegged the CPU meter and I had to reboot to get control back, so
keep an eye on that in case it happens.  I think it was with a custom
built kernel and I selected the "make idle calls", AFAIK IIRC YMMV.)

> Lilo happily allowed me to start up Windows. I did what I needed to do,
> and rebooted into Linux. This time, I was given a Gnome login screen,
> and it was Gnome into which I was put. Again though, no option to halt.
> I guess I've got some more reading to do. (Actually, I know I've got a
> lot of reading to do.)

It smiled but was not really happy, no doubt... <grin>

Once you fix the "AllowRoot" option and restart "gdm", you can, as I
said before, use the GDM Configurator and turn on the system menu that
offers shutdown and reboot.  Note that with "gdm", there is nothing
preventing anyone with access to the console from halting that
computer...

> There are a number of things that are not the same as what I've come
> to expect when I start up either of my other two RH systems. I
> suppose some of that is configuration related and some of it is
> convention related.  But, this is intended to be a learning
> experience, so time to start reading.

Can you be more specific?  Is it the "green lights" thing, or
something less "cosmetic only" in nature?

> Any recommendations for things to read that will help me understand
> what I should expect (regarding the difference between the way
> things look on Debian vs RH) other than everything on the debian
> site?

The Debian Policy Manual is somewhat helpful.  You'll find it
available as a package if you like, or read it on the LUG web server
at <URL:http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/debian-policy/>.  Another good
source of information is the "linuxcookbook" which you may install
yourself or read at:

<URL:http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/linuxcookbook/cookbook.html#SEC_Top>

Also, you may like to install "discover", for hardware auto-detection,
"hotplug", for USB support, and of course "aptitude", for software
installation management.  You may also find "gkdebconf" helpful, along
with the "configlet-frontends".  Perhaps you will also like to install
a newer kernel-image as well; you'll find several to choose from when
you learn to use "aptitude".

As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Fri Aug 30 02:07:15 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 30 Aug 2002 02:07:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A _Red Hat_ upgrade question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208290618350.10555-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208290618350.10555-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <87y9ao67gc.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> writes:

> On Wed, 28 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
> > It would sure save a ton of time if I didn't need to reselect the
> > packages for a fourth time but could use a saved configuration
> > file.
> 
> After a successful Red Hat 7.3 installation, there'll be a file
> named /root/anaconda-ks.cfg that can be used to duplicate your
> installation. (Of course, then you'd have to learn about
> kickstarting a host, which takes a bit of time.)

How much information does that "kickstart" file contain?  Does it know
how you've configured those installed packages, your networking, etc,
or does it merely contain the list of packages to install?

With "dpkg", you can say "dpkg --get-selections", and get a list of
the packages that are installed as a specially formatted ascii text
file.  That file can then be used as standard input to "dpkg
--set-selections", after which you may run "apt-get dselect-upgrade"
to match that package list.  It looks like "aptitude" also might have
at least the rudiments of this sort of ability.

There is an "autoinstall" package that comes from Progeny.  It's not
really "right" yet... it's still somewhat prototypical in many ways,
and fails to work on some hardware since they used a nonstandard
floppy disk format for the boot floppy.  (It's initrd is too big to
fit with a kernel on a 1.44 MB diskette, so they used a larger
diskette format ala "superformat".)

The cool thing that "autoinstall" does is to get a dump of the
"debconf" database on the machine you want to clone, and then preload
that on the new box, and run the install with DEBIAN_FRONTEND set to
"noninteractive".  One problem is that not all packages have been
debconfsicated...  There is much work to be done in this area.

As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'



From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Fri Aug 30 02:10:05 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 30 Aug 2002 02:10:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A _Red Hat_ upgrade question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208291236520.10555-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208291236520.10555-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <87u1lc67bm.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> writes:

> On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Galen Seitz wrote:
> 
> > I'm looking forward to the day when LVM or EVMS comes into common
> > use. When that happens, juggling partitions in this manner will be a
> > thing of the past.
> 
> Has anybody used/tested EVMS? It's on my to-do list at work.

Yes; it works very well.  I'm useing EVMS and XFS together on two
machines.  All of the kernel patches and tools are available in Debian
for both, except for (this may have changed) a critical patch for XFS
that allows it to work correctly with EVMS.  That patch is available
at the EVMS sourceforge site.  You must use the "VFS-Lock" patch if
you plan to use snapshot volumes with journalling file systems.

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Aug 30 03:06:20 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 03:06:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Flag folders w/new mail under pine?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208300101340.25898-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208300301110.13910-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 30 Aug 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:
> On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > I would also share with you that I use the following in my .pinerc:
> > initial-keystroke-list=l,
> >     CR,
> >     ;,
> >     p,
> >     n
> 
> I tried that, then typed pine and it loaded up, opened my INBOX and
> prompted me:
> Enter comma-delimited list of numbers (dash between ranges):
> ^G Help
> ^C Cancel    Ret Accept
> 
> I'm not sure what is going on.  Any ideas?

Yes.

For one of several reasons, the CR openned the folder called INBOX instead
of a folder collection.  Inside a folder, the select operation (;) does
not have a properties option (p), but it does have a numeric selection
option (n).  So you're selecting messages in a folder instead of folders
in a collection.

So maybe you forgot the first command (l) or maybe you don't have folder
collections defined.

> if I type my usual pine -i then it just ignores the above commands, is
> that right?

The -i switch starts up in the folder index screen.  That's not the screen
from which those initial keystrokes were intended to begin running.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org





From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Fri Aug 30 02:37:44 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 30 Aug 2002 02:37:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs & word wrap
In-Reply-To: <86znv4en67.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208300108240.25922-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
	<86znv4en67.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <87u1lc4rh3.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

> >>>>> "Jason" == Jason Dagit <dagit at engr.orst.edu> writes:
> 
> Jason> Does anyone know if emacs has a feature for automatically doing
> Jason> word wrap?  I want the functionality of M-q.  I have word wrap
> Jason> turned off (for coding) and that may be the problem.  Is there
> Jason> a way I can pass emacs a command line switch to turn on word
> Jason> wrap? That would be great since I am expeirementing with emacs
> Jason> as my alternate editor in pine.

Experimenting with emacs as a mail editor will perhaps lead you to
useing "vm" or "gnus" as your mail reader.  I think you'll find "vm"
to be superiour to Pine.  ("apt-get install vm" if you use GNU Emacs;
it's part of XEmacs already.)

> Interactively, M-x auto-fill-mode.  I am sure the right thing in your
> .emacs would turn it on for the appropriate mode, but I don't know
> off-hand what that is.

(defun add-to-hooks (hook-fun hooklist)
  "Add HOOK-FUN to each hook variable in HOOKLIST"
  (mapc #'(lambda (mode-hook)
	    (add-hook mode-hook hook-fun))
	hooklist))

(add-to-hooks #'auto-fill-mode '(text-mode
                                 message-mode
                                 ;; ... add more mode names here ...
                                ))

You'll still need to use "M-q" now and then.

Ever notice that "M-q" is the keybinding that completely EXITS
Netscape Navigator?

the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.

From karlheg at pdxLinux.org  Fri Aug 30 04:27:47 2002
From: karlheg at pdxLinux.org (karlheg at pdxLinux.org)
Date: 30 Aug 2002 04:27:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] autofs executable map for automount of floppy
Message-ID: <87d6s04mdo.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

I was trying to use a static automounter map for removable media, and
ran into a snag.  I wanted it to, if the diskette is a Windows disk,
mount it with the "uid=0,gid=25,umask=002" options, so that the
diskette will be writable by GID 25 (floppy).  But if it's a Linux
native file system disk, I want to mount with options appropriate for
that file system.

I was trying to use a static map with "-fstype=auto" and a set of
options that was the union of the option sets for all file system
types that I'd want to mount.  That setup does not work!  It fails to
mount ext2fs diskettes, erroring on unsupported mount options.  I
reported the problem in:

<URL:http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=128616&repeatmerged=yes>

Today I came up with a solution.  Here it is, for all to use and
enjoy...  The "autofs" automounter supports an executable map.  It
runs your script, handing it the "key", and your script prints what
would be the right hand side of the static map.

Now I can put a diskette in the floppy drive, and access it at
"/mnt/rem/floppy".  One second after nothing is using the diskette, it
is umounted.  The "sync" mount option ensures that even if somebody
ejects the diskette before it's truely umounted, the data will still
make it to the diskette before the light winks out.

It sucks that we must use floppy drives that have a physical eject
button on them, rather than one that only _requests_ an eject, like on
a Zip drive or CDROM.  On those, the eject button should not open the
drawer until the disc is really umounted.  (and then we need an easy
(gui) way to discover what is keeping a disc active and thus un
umountable)

8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
#!/bin/sh
#
# autofs executable map for removable media
#
# Karl M. Hegbloom <karlheg at pdxlinux.org>
#
key="$1"

me=$(basename $0)

echo "$me: key is '$key'" >&2

PATH=/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin

tmpfile=$(tempfile)

case "$key" in
    floppy)
	dd if=/dev/fd0 of=$tmpfile bs=512 count=4 2>/dev/null
	file_says=$(file $tmpfile)
	rm -f $tmpfile
	if echo $file_says | grep -iq 'x86 boot sector'
	then
	    echo "$me: Diskette contains vfat or msdos filesystem" >&2
	    echo '-fstype=vfat,sync,uid=0,gid=25,umask=002 :/dev/fd0'
	else
	    echo '-fstype=auto,sync,nosuid,nodev :/dev/fd0'
	fi
	;;

    cdrom)
	echo "-fstype=iso9660,nodev,nosuid,ro :/dev/cdrom"
	;;

    *)
	echo "$me: Unknown removable device mountpoint: $key" >&2
	exit 1
	;;
esac
exit 0
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

-- 
As any limb well and duly exercised, grows stronger,
the nerves of the body are corroborated thereby. --I. Watts.  .''`.
 Debian -- The blue collar Linux distribution.               : :' :
 <URL:http://www.debian.org/social_contract>		     `. `'



From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Aug 30 06:40:55 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 06:40:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A _Red Hat_ upgrade question
In-Reply-To: <87y9ao67gc.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208300620530.30895-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On 30 Aug 2002, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> How much information does that "kickstart" file contain?  Does it
> know how you've configured those installed packages, your
> networking, etc, or does it merely contain the list of packages to
> install?

It includes

* supported languages and default language
* keyboard and mouse hardware info
* X configuration info (video hardware, default resolution/depth)
* network info (dhcp or static addr/dns/gateway/netmask)
* md5 version of your root password
* firewall/iptables info: disabled, low, medium, high
* authorization configuration (nis? ldap? shadow? md5?)
* timezone
* which bootloader (lilo? grub?) and where it's installed
* local disk partitioning
* package listing

The idea is that, given this kickstart file, you could re-install Red 
Hat to the exact same state if the need arose.

In general, the kickstart facility is one of the things I really like 
about Red Hat. At work I keep two unaltered trees for, say, Red Hat 
7.3 on an nfs fileserver:

* linux/7.3   -- the original 7.3 installation tree
* updates/7.3 -- all the patches, updates

Then I have a tree for locally built rpms

* local/7.3

I've written a Perl script that copies the original installation tree 
into a parallel <version>-current directory, i.e.,:

* linux/7.3-current

The script then scans that tree, making note of all the rpms 
(including those specific to athlon, i686, and i585 architectures). 
Then the script scans the updates directory and, when it finds an 
updated package in updates/7.3, it moves the new package into 
7.3-current and deletes the previous one.

I haven't yet written into the script similar functionality for
scanning my local rpms for updates, so I still have to do that by 
hand. :-(

In any event, the 7.3-current tree ends up with all the latest updates 
plus all my latest local packages (cfengine, xfce, aterm) plus a 
couple third-party packages (java, the ICA client).

Red Hat has a plain text file that allows you to create/edit named 
package groups that you see at installation time, so I have a couple 
groups, one containing non-standard packages that we install on 
desktop machines and one for infrastructure servers.

Once the updates are in place and the package-list file ("comps") is
edited, my perl script uses Red Hat's anaconda tools to regenerate the
installation images -- so any new installation from the 7.3-current
tree is fully patched and includes local and third-party packages.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Aug 30 07:12:45 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

Subject: [PLUG] Emacs & word wrap
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208300108240.25922-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208300711550.5449-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 30 Aug 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:

> Does anyone know if emacs has a feature for automatically doing word
> wrap?  I want the functionality of M-q.  I have word wrap turned off
> (for coding) and that may be the problem.  Is there a way I can pass
> emacs a command line switch to turn on word wrap? That would be great
> since I am expeirementing with emacs as my alternate editor in pine.
 
Jason,

(setq default-major-mode 'text-mode)
(add-hook 'text-mode-hook 'turn-on-auto-fill)

  If you want your default-major-mode to be something else, modify as
appropriate.

Rich

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Aug 30 08:29:59 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 08:29:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] X font server cause boot hang 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 30 Aug 2002 07:07:17 PDT."
             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208300705240.5449-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <200208301529.g7UFTx204974@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> 
> > Does the font server have nfs mounts in its configuration?  I bet xfs is
> > hanging due to broken/hanging nfs mounts.
>  
> galen,
> 
>   I don't know. Wouldn't have thought to look, either. But, I certainly will
> look today!
> 
>   I've scanned the man pages for xfs and xfstt but I still don't fully
> understand the role they play. I've both of them shut off in run level 3 and
> I can see no difference in the appearance of X. Where can I read more, just
> to satisfy my curiosity?

The font server was originally designed with large installations in mind.  It
allows admins to install fonts once, and make them available to many X
servers.  For your small setup, you may be better off just duplicating
fonts on each machine.  As you have noticed, XFree86 can be configured to
look for fonts from a font server, as well as directly.  Have a look at
the "Files" section of XF86Config.

For more info on font servers, check out
man xfs
http://www.x-docs.org/


galen

From ali at axian.com  Fri Aug 30 08:55:29 2002
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 08:55:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs & word wrap
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208300108240.25922-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>; from dagit@engr.orst.edu on Fri, Aug 30, 2002 at 01:15:45AM -0700
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208300108240.25922-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20020830085529.A25210@zaphod.axian.com>

I have this in my .emacs file:

(add-hook 'find-file-hooks 'turn-on-auto-fill)

This is pretty all-encompassing, and turns on word-wrapping for every
buffer without exception.  I occassionally have to do a
'M-x auto-fill-mode' to toggle it off.

Ali

From sandy at herring.org  Fri Aug 30 09:42:13 2002
