On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Rogan Creswick wrote: 
> 
> While we are on the topic of email clients, I started using mutt today (and enjoy it so far, I previously used pine).

Did you use Mutt to post this? I don't see it in your X-headers, and your
line length appears to be > 125 characters.

> One question though: I want to have mutt open my inbox with any new messages from the mail spool copied there automatically. 
> It currently is opening my mail spool, then prompts me to copy read messages from the spool to mbox (which is not my inbox..). 
> 
> Any pointers would be great, I'm really not sure where to start to get this to happen (any search terms?).

This would be better handled by a procmail recipe. Simply set the DEFAULT
environment variable to point at your mbox. You can then instruct mutt to
use your mbox as your mail spool by setting `spoolfile' in your .muttrc to
point to it... http://www.mutt.org/doc/manual/manual-6.html#spoolfile

Sandy

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Fri Aug 30 10:52:03 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 10:52:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla Upgrade
In-Reply-To: <000001c24fe3$dad5cb50$6401a8c0@robbert>
References: <000001c24fe3$dad5cb50$6401a8c0@robbert>
Message-ID: <20020830175203.81A8F178FF@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>

Dan Young wrote:
 :: Robbert van Andel said:
 :: --snipped--
 :: > Anyone out
 :: > there have an idea that I can use to upgrade Mozilla and deal with the
 :: > dependencies.  I'm guessing I'm missing a switch on the rpm command.
 :: 
 :: First, do a:
 :: 
 :: rpm -qa | grep mozilla
 :: 
 :: to see what mozilla packages you have installed.
 :: 
 :: Then d/l the updated ones to match. Followed by
 :: 
 :: rpm -Uvh mozilla*1.1-0.i386.rpm
 :: 
 :: That will match all of the mozilla rpms you d/l'ed that are v1.1-0 and
 :: will update all of the mozilla rpms at once. If multiple packages are
 :: dependant on each other, you have to upgrade them all at once, rather than
 :: one at a time.
 :: 
 :: -Dan Young
 :: -Parkrose School District

Dan's instructions are crystal clear. I'll add one more useful thing.

You can also do:

rpm -Uvh <package_list>

where <package_list> is a file that contains the paths to a collection
of packages you want to install.

This has the advantage that you can put disparate packages in the list
whose names don't necessarily reduce to a nice shell globbing
expression like "mozilla*1.1-0.i386.rpm".

I don't remember what the path names are relative to.  Full pathnames
will always work.  Also the package names, alone, will work if
<package_list> is in a common directory with the packages it names and
that directory is the current directory.

It may be that the package names simply need to be relative to the
current directory.  Or they may need to be relative to the directory
in which <package_list> sits.  The rpm man page is less than clear
on the use of <package_list> so I'm giving you what I've discovered
on my own.

Dean



From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Aug 30 11:11:18 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 11:11:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Kmail to call up Galeon
In-Reply-To: <200208301019.20861.hapibeli@attbi.com>
References: <200208301019.20861.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200208301111.19055.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Yes you can do this by going into Konqueror and changing the file 
association. Once in the file association setup, look for the "html" 
file type under "text". Use the "add" feature to add "galeon" and then 
move the "galeon" entry to the top of the application list so it is 
used over Konqueror. That should make any KDE app that opens an HTML 
filetype use galeon rather than Konqueror.

You may have to shutdown all instances of Kmail and Konqueror to get the 
new settings to work. I tried it for kicks and initially Kmail was 
still using Konqueror. I finally shutdown Kmail and all instances of 
Konqueror. I restarted Kmail and it was using "galeon" rather than 
Konqueror to open HTML links.

Tony

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Fri Aug 30 11:14:56 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)

Subject: [PLUG] Did I just do something very stupid?

I may have just done a very stupid thing.

On a mandrake 8.2 system I just did:

chmod -R o-w /usr/share

Don't ask why.

Lot's of disk crunching (expected).

Then all the icons on my desktop flashed, (unexpected)
like when you install a new mandrake package
that automatically updates your menus and icons.

Have I just irreparable broken my system?

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Aug 30 11:43:49 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 11:43:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Did I just do something very stupid?
In-Reply-To: <20020830181456.B14F3178FF@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>
References: <20020830181456.B14F3178FF@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <200208301143.49460.aschlemm@attbi.com>

All you did was make it so that "other" doesn't have write access to 
anything on /usr/share. Doesn't really sound bad to me. That's usually 
they way you want all files and directories to be in /usr/share 
otherwise anyone could create a file or another directory somewhere in 
the /usr/share filesystem hierarchy. 

Tony

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Aug 30 13:55:05 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 13:55:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Flag folders w/new mail under pine?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208301003100.26957-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208301350070.22143-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 30 Aug 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:
> On Fri, 30 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> > So maybe you forgot the first command (l) or maybe you don't have folder
> > collections defined.
> 
> It would be the second one I think.  I double checked and l is in
> there.  How would/should I create a folder collection?

You define them in the .pinerc.

> And will doing so screw up my procmail recipes?

Not at all.  A folder collection is merely a logical collection of mboxes
for pine's own purposes.  There is no change to the filesystem.

Here's a section from my .pinerc:

# List of directories where saved-message folders may be. First one is
# the default for Saves. Example: Main {host1}mail/[], Desktop mail\[]
# Syntax: optnl-label {optnl-imap-hostname}optnl-directory-path[]
folder-collections=IN mail/[IN.*],
    ROOT mail/[ROOT.*],
    OUT mail/[OUT.*],
    SAVE mail/[SAVE.*],
    ADMIN mail/[ADMIN*],
    WEB mail/[WEB*],
    ALL mail/[]


Dig?  I have mboxes called IN.whatever, OUT.whatever, SAVE.whatever,
WEB.domain, ROOT.host.domain, and so on.  You'll see there's also a
collection called ALL that contains every mbox.

My procmail filters put mail in IN.whatever based on different rules.  So
there's an IN.plug and an IN.plug-talk and an IN.jeme.brelin (for this
address, but not from a mailing list) and so on.  The OUT.whatever boxes
are set as the default FCC for different roles are addresses.  I also use
roles in pine pretty extensively and the ability to set a default role by
folder, but also select a role manually at compose time is the number one
reason I haven't been able to switch to mutt.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From sandy at herring.org  Fri Aug 30 13:22:44 2002

In-Reply-To: <20020830172519.GB19627@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>; from creswick@cs.orst.edu on Fri, Aug 30, 2002 at 10:25:19AM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.10.10208292246380.29740-100000@noname.nodomain.nowhere> <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208292345170.12420-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> <20020830060604.GA19574@silver.CS.ORST.EDU> <20020830094213.B19562@kippered.herring.org> <20020830172519.GB19627@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20020830132244.A21261@kippered.herring.org>

On Fri, 30 Aug 2002, Rogan Creswick wrote: 
> On Fri, Aug 30, 2002 at 09:42:13AM -0700, Sandy Herring wrote:
> > Did you use Mutt to post this? I don't see it in your X-headers, and your
> > line length appears to be > 125 characters.
> 
> I did use mutt, with vi as my editor and it did not linewrap, and I didn't pay
> enough attention to the line length (that's a task for today, get vi to wrap 
> lines for in email..)

Woops, so you did...

User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i

...I missed that, sorry. As for line wrapping, if you're truly using `vi'
and not `vim' (poor guy), then in your .exrc you'd need to `set wrapmargin='
to some value...

    wm=<*>                  | wrapmargin - In append mode vi automatically
                            |   puts a <lf> whenever there is a <sp> or <ht>
                            |   within <wm> columns from the right margin
                            |   (0 = don't put a <lf> in the file, yet put it
                            |   on the screen).

Hopefully `vi' is actually brining up `vim', in which case in your .vimrc
you could `set textwidth=' to the number of characters you always want for a
line length. `vim' offers a host of formatting controls. See...

   Linkname: Vim online doc: usr_25.txt
        URL: http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/cgi-bin/vim2html2.pl?page=usr_25.txt#usr_25.txt

One handy tip with `vim' that parlays with `mutt' is to include this
autocommand in your .vimrc ...

au FileType mail set textwidth=76 formatoptions=t

There are plenty of other ways to skin that cat. I'll leave the RTFM and
Googling as an exercise for you :)

cheers,
Sandy

From guyh at aracnet.com  Fri Aug 30 14:46:02 2002
From: guyh at aracnet.com (Guy Hammer)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 14:46:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Flag folders w/new mail under pine?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208292345170.12420-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.10.10208301435170.29740-100000@noname.nodomain.nowhere>

On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> On this list a while back, folks were describing how they use vim
> as their editor from pine and are capable of doing more robust quote
> formatting than pico handles by default.  This interest me immensely.
> Can someone share that info?

In your .vimrc file add:

map Q !}fmt --prefix="> "
map W !}fmt

The Q is for formatting quoted text, handy if the text has 'long line,
short line' syndrome. The W is for formatting your reply. Make sure the
block of text you want to format is surrounded by one or more blank lines
- more than once I've accidentaly formatted my entire reply including
the sig! =:-0

-- 
Guy Hammer, guyh at aracnet.com  KD7QXF
http://www.aracnet.com/~guyh
--
  2:35pm  up 102 days, 13:48,  7 users,  load average: 1.31, 1.22, 1.33





From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Aug 30 15:55:37 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 15:55:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Flag folders w/new mail under pine?
In-Reply-To: <20020830132954.B21261@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208301548480.23140-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 30 Aug 2002, Sandy Herring wrote:
> On Fri, 30 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote: 
> [...]
> > I also use
> > roles in pine pretty extensively and the ability to set a default role by
> > folder, but also select a role manually at compose time is the number one
> > reason I haven't been able to switch to mutt.
> 
> Is this what you're looking to do in `mutt'?
> 
> f           edit-fcc               enter a file to save a copy of this message in
> 
> ("f" entered from "compose" window)

Not quite.

I need to set both FCC and From: based on one of several criteria:

The currently active mbox (what am I doing right now)

The From: or Reply-To: address of the mail to which I'm replying (who do I
want them to think I am)

The To: address of the mail to which I'm replying (who do they think I am)

The subject line of the message (for certain mailing lists and other weird
situations where the From: address and mbox are not predicatable)

I would also like the ability to change roles at compose time.  Ideally, I
would be presented with a list of options, but that's not strictly
necessary.  I can simply memorize a list of role names.

This is all functionality of pine that I use all the time.  I'd love to
use a truly Free mail client, but I have had little success with mutt in
doing some of the more complex things with roles and the learning curve on
gnus caused me to roll downhill really fast.  I know that's no excuse, but
that's all I've got at the moment.

J.

From mcintoshrt at attbi.com  Fri Aug 30 15:15:35 2002
From: mcintoshrt at attbi.com (Robert McIntosh)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 15:15:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Erratic FTP Failure
Message-ID: <200208301515.35907.mcintoshrt@attbi.com>

Hi,

I'm running a small home network that is using FreeBSD 4.3 for some local 
services (http, ftp, mail, smbd, atalkd, name resolution).  Roughly 60% of 
the time the FreeBSD box has ridiculously slow upload rates (via ftp, atalkd, 
and smbd) and eventually stalls the transfer without getting past < 500KB of 
the job.  Downloading data from the server is nice and zippy, however.  
Pinging the server produces normal results - no errors or losses.  Checking 
/var/log/messages shows no errors.

 Here's the output from netstat -i;

Name  Mtu   Network       Address            Ipkts Ierrs    Opkts Oerrs  Coll
sis0  1500  <Link#1>    00:02:e3:0a:43:16     2846   153     2266     0     0
sis0  1500  192.168.1     orangeowl.lan       2816     -     2231     -     -

lo0   16384 127           localhost             52     -       52     -     -
lo0   16384 atalk:0            0.0               -     -        -     -     -
ppp0* 1500  <Link#7>                             0     0        0     0     0
sl0*  552   <Link#8>                             0     0        0     0     0
faith 1500  <Link#9>                             0     0        0     0     0

Due to the high input errors noted on sis0, I suspect a bad cable connection.  
Would anyone else agree with this?  Or am I running too many services on the

which regularly use the server)?

32 MB RAM

From sandy at herring.org  Fri Aug 30 15:16:03 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 15:16:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Flag folders w/new mail under pine?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.10.10208301435170.29740-100000@noname.nodomain.nowhere>; from guyh@aracnet.com on Fri, Aug 30, 2002 at 02:46:02PM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0208292345170.12420-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> <Pine.LNX.4.10.10208301435170.29740-100000@noname.nodomain.nowhere>
Message-ID: <20020830151603.A22598@kippered.herring.org>

On Fri, 30 Aug 2002, Guy Hammer wrote: 
> On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> > On this list a while back, folks were describing how they use vim
> > as their editor from pine and are capable of doing more robust quote
> > formatting than pico handles by default.  This interest me immensely.
> > Can someone share that info?
> 
> In your .vimrc file add:
> 
> map Q !}fmt --prefix="> "
> map W !}fmt
> 
> The Q is for formatting quoted text, handy if the text has 'long line,
> short line' syndrome. The W is for formatting your reply. Make sure the
> block of text you want to format is surrounded by one or more blank lines
> - more than once I've accidentaly formatted my entire reply including
> the sig! =:-0

Bah! That's the old way... a la `vi'. ViMmers do...

  nmap <C-J>      gq}
  vmap <C-J>      gq

Thus, Ctrl-J reformats (Justifies) the paragraph (starting at the current
cursor position) in "normal mode", and reformats the selected text in
"visual mode". And if you goof, just 'u'ndo it (`vim' supports multiple undo
levels, unlike `vi').

This mapping has the added advantages of (1) not spawning another process,
and (2) not overriding the default mappings for "Q" (Switch to "Ex" mode)
and "W" ([count] WORDS forward - motion command)l.

As for quoted text, you can specify what leading characters are to be
interpreted as a comment via "set comments". Here's what I use...

set comments=b:#,:%,fb:-,n:>,n:)

That automatically takes care of formatting quoted text, unless you've done
"set paste" (which is handy in and of itself). For more details, while in
`vim', do...

    :help format-comments

Sandy (JAVH)
-- 
Sandy Herring, RHCE                        o              sandy at herring.org
Peck of Pickled Pisces               __  o               http://herring.org/

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Fri Aug 30 15:25:54 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 15:25:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Did I just do something very stupid?
In-Reply-To: <200208301143.49460.aschlemm@attbi.com> (message from Anthony
	Schlemmer on Fri, 30 Aug 2002 11:43:49 -0700)
References: <20020830181456.B14F3178FF@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com> <200208301143.49460.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020830222554.4BC55178FF@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>

Thanks Tony for the reply.

Yeah, I know what it does. And I would have agreed with you before I
did it.  The operative word in your post is "usually".

But the fact that my desktop "refreshed" (icons blinked, panel
refreshed) as the permission changes were being performed made me
think (with that feeling of nausea in the pit of one's stomach):

"Uh-oh.  Does Mandrake or KDE keep their system menu/desktop stuff in
/usr/share and do they requre it to be open so that they can easily
update menu libraries when packages are installed or deleted by
ordinary users?

Are all my menus going to be hosed from now on?  Have I, at the push
of a <RET> key (I'm a commandline kinda guy) just cost myself hours
of pain, toil, and tears? ..."

So ran the train of my morbid thoughts.
I guess time will tell.

 :: All you did was make it so that "other" doesn't have write access to 
 :: anything on /usr/share. Doesn't really sound bad to me. That's usually 
 :: they way you want all files and directories to be in /usr/share 
 :: otherwise anyone could create a file or another directory somewhere in 
 :: the /usr/share filesystem hierarchy. 
 :: 
 :: Tony
 :: 
 ::
 :: On Friday 30 August 2002 11:14 am, Dean S. Messing wrote:
 :: > I may have just done a very stupid thing.
 :: >
 :: > On a mandrake 8.2 system I just did:
 :: >
 :: > chmod -R o-w /usr/share
 :: <snip>
 :: > Have I just irreparable broken my system?
 :: >
 :: >
 :: > Dean

From sandy at herring.org  Fri Aug 30 15:57:41 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 15:57:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla Upgrade
In-Reply-To: <64543.12.231.181.15.1030686356.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>; from dan_young@parkrose.k12.or.us on Thu, Aug 29, 2002 at 10:45:56PM -0700
References: <200208292141.01114.kens@cad2cam.com> <000001c24fe3$dad5cb50$6401a8c0@robbert> <64543.12.231.181.15.1030686356.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <20020830155741.C22598@kippered.herring.org>

On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Dan Young wrote: 
> Robbert van Andel said:
> --snipped--
> > Anyone out
> > there have an idea that I can use to upgrade Mozilla and deal with the
> > dependencies.  I'm guessing I'm missing a switch on the rpm command.
> 
> First, do a:
> 
> rpm -qa | grep mozilla
> 
> to see what mozilla packages you have installed.
> 
> Then d/l the updated ones to match. Followed by
> 
> rpm -Uvh mozilla*1.1-0.i386.rpm
> 
> That will match all of the mozilla rpms you d/l'ed that are v1.1-0 and
> will update all of the mozilla rpms at once. If multiple packages are
> dependant on each other, you have to upgrade them all at once, rather than
> one at a time.
> 
> -Dan Young
> -Parkrose School District

...and if you then get...

error: failed dependencies:
        mozilla = 0.9.9 is needed by galeon-1.2.0-7

...grab the Red Hat rawhide version of galeon from...

ftp://ftp.rpmfind.net/linux/rawhide/1.0/i386/RedHat/RPMS/galeon-1.2.5-6.i386.rpm

...and...

[root at kippered i386]# rpm -Uvh galeon-1.2.5-6.i386.rpm mozilla*1.1-0.i386.rpm
Preparing...                ########################################### [100%]
   1:mozilla-nspr           ########################################### [ 12%]
   2:mozilla                ########################################### [ 25%]
   3:galeon                 ########################################### [ 37%]
   4:mozilla-chat           ########################################### [ 50%]
   5:mozilla-devel          ########################################### [ 62%]
   6:mozilla-mail           ########################################### [ 75%]
   7:mozilla-nss            ########################################### [ 87%]
   8:mozilla-psm            ########################################### [100%]

Sandy

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Fri Aug 30 16:36:43 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 16:36:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Venezuela adopts GPL [selections]
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208301627430.29678-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

...
 Venezuela's Government Shifts to Open Source Software

According to government sources in Venezuela, the South American nation
has announced an official policy that exclusively calls for the use of
open source software in that government.

The announcement, made on Wednesday, stated that from now on, all software
developed for the government must be licenced under the GPL. The entire
policy was summed up in this statement by Dr. Felipe Prez-Mart, Planning
and Development Minister: "Open source whenever possible, propietary
software only when necesary."

[snippage]

Rey also outlined additional details of the plan. Besides the government's
GPL requirement, the policy requires that the official accounting
application for Venezeula must be a GPL'ed application. The policy also
states that the government will openly combat software piracy by purging
all unlicensed copies of software from its offices.

Additionally, the policy also outlines a new Internet access program where
all machines would be Linux-based and held under community franchise.

[snippage]

In an interview (in Spanish) with LaRed.com, Prez-Mart outlined one of the
big reasons why this policy was announced. According to Prez-Mart, the
government and the people of Venezeula were increasingly concerned that
over 75 percent of the funds for software licenses went to foreign
nations, 20 percent to foreign support agencies, and only 5 percent to
Venezuelan programmers.

[snippage]

http://linuxtoday.com/news_story.php3?ltsn=2002-08-30-011-26-NW-LL-PB




From lhomer at attbi.com  Fri Aug 30 17:15:20 2002
From: lhomer at attbi.com (lhomer)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 17:15:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Venezuela adopts GPL [selections]

The amazing thing is that open source is not automatically a preferred
choice for anyone anywhere.

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Fri Aug 30 17:21:58 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 17:21:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Did I just do something very stupid?
In-Reply-To: <200208301534.52238.aschlemm@attbi.com> (message from Anthony
	Schlemmer on Fri, 30 Aug 2002 15:34:52 -0700)
References: <20020830181456.B14F3178FF@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com> <200208301143.49460.aschlemm@attbi.com> <20020830222554.4BC55178FF@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com> <200208301534.52238.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020831002158.19AB1178FF@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>

 :: I did a quick scan of my SuSE 8.0 system and I couldn't find a single 
 :: case of where any file or directory was writable by "other". Maybe 
 :: Mandrake is different but all of my KDE stuff goes into /opt and I 
 :: didn't see that any KDE related in /usr/share.
 :: 
 :: Tony

Unfortunately Mandrake is sufficiently different from SuSE that
such a comparison is probably not useful (but thanks just the same).

And unfortunately KDE under Mandrake goes in /usr with a boat load of
it in /usr/share.  For example, heres a small snippet from the "A's":

  drwxr-xr-x    8 root     root         4096 Apr  1 10:11 applets/
  drwxr-xr-x    2 root     root         4096 Aug 26 19:27 application-registry/
  drwxr-xr-x   17 root     root         4096 Feb 22  2002 applnk/
  drwxr-xr-x   14 root     root         4096 Aug 26 19:28 applnk-mdk/
  drwxr-xr-x   11 root     root         4096 Aug 26 19:28 applnk-mdk-simplified/
  drwxr-xr-x  150 root     root         4096 Apr  1 13:21 apps/

Each of these have reams of KDE .desktop and other files in them.  And
that's just the A's.

Mandrake tries to be very sophisticated when it comes to KDE and
menu/desktop updates when you install/de-install their packages.  Lots
of little perl scripts get fired off behind the scenes that do lots of
little magical things. It actually all works remarkable well---until
some Dolt comes along and does a global permission change on a major
system subdirectory!

So far I have not seen any adverse effects, but I'm just using the system
right now.  I guess I'll find out next time I install an rpm or
restart KDE.  I'm almost afraid to try.

Dean

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Aug 30 17:42:59 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 17:42:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Did I just do something very stupid?
In-Reply-To: <20020831002158.19AB1178FF@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208301738210.6903-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 30 Aug 2002, Dean S. Messing wrote:

> Unfortunately Mandrake is sufficiently different from SuSE that
> such a comparison is probably not useful (but thanks just the same).

Hi, Dean!

  My RH 6.2 system has directories with 755 permissions (just like your
example below) and files with 644 permissions.
   
>   drwxr-xr-x    8 root     root         4096 Apr  1 10:11 applets/
>   drwxr-xr-x    2 root     root         4096 Aug 26 19:27 application-registry/
>   drwxr-xr-x   17 root     root         4096 Feb 22  2002 applnk/
>   drwxr-xr-x   14 root     root         4096 Aug 26 19:28 applnk-mdk/
>   drwxr-xr-x   11 root     root         4096 Aug 26 19:28 applnk-mdk-simplified/
>   drwxr-xr-x  150 root     root         4096 Apr  1 13:21 apps/
 
> So far I have not seen any adverse effects, but I'm just using the system
> right now.  I guess I'll find out next time I install an rpm or
> restart KDE.  I'm almost afraid to try.

  I'll bet that what you saw was the OS blinking when it said to itself,
"Huh? There ain't no other permissions besides read; what's the guy want me
to do?"

  By removing write permissions that did not exist before it is almost
certain that you did nothing to the system but momentarily confuse it.

  Enjoy the holiday! I'm barbecuing a brisket tomorrow: up at 3 am to fire
the pit. Then ~12 hours of slow cooking.

Rich





From flee at aracnet.com  Fri Aug 30 19:53:43 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 19:53:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs & word wrap
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208300108240.25922-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> on Fri, 30 Aug 2002 01:15:45 PDT.
Message-ID: <200208310253.g7V2rjG04982@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

I tried having auto-fill mode turned on automatically for
some file types for a while, but found it a little too
annoying.  Now, I just have a key that will toggle it.

(global-set-key [f12] 'auto-fill-mode)
--



From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Fri Aug 30 21:15:41 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 21:15:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs & word wrap
In-Reply-To: <87u1lc4rh3.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208302112430.388-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On 30 Aug 2002, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> (defun add-to-hooks (hook-fun hooklist)
>   "Add HOOK-FUN to each hook variable in HOOKLIST"
>   (mapc #'(lambda (mode-hook)
> 	    (add-hook mode-hook hook-fun))
> 	hooklist))
>
> (add-to-hooks #'auto-fill-mode '(text-mode
>                                  message-mode
>                                  ;; ... add more mode names here ...
>                                 ))

I added that stuff to my .emacs, but it never happens.  I noticed that
when I edit email the major mode is Fundamental, so I added
fundamental-mode to list, and it still doesn't work.  What am I doing
wrong...

And I already deleted the other posts to compare with.

Jason




From sean at fork.com  Fri Aug 30 21:36:13 2002

Ok how about the other way around.  I have the following in my galeon config 
to use kmail as the mail program, but I'm not very happy with the results so 
far.

kmail --composer  -s "%s" --body "%y" %u

Anyone have anything better?

Sean

On Friday 30 August 2002 11:11, you wrote:
> Yes you can do this by going into Konqueror and changing the file
> association. Once in the file association setup, look for the "html"
> file type under "text". Use the "add" feature to add "galeon" and then
> move the "galeon" entry to the top of the application list so it is
> used over Konqueror. That should make any KDE app that opens an HTML
> filetype use galeon rather than Konqueror.
>
> You may have to shutdown all instances of Kmail and Konqueror to get the
> new settings to work. I tried it for kicks and initially Kmail was
> still using Konqueror. I finally shutdown Kmail and all instances of
> Konqueror. I restarted Kmail and it was using "galeon" rather than
> Konqueror to open HTML links.
>
> Tony
>
> On Friday 30 August 2002 10:19 am, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> > Is it possible to have Kmail default to Galeon from a URL in an
> > email? Dirk
> >
> > _______________________________________________
> > PLUG mailing list
> > PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Sandy Herring
Sent: Friday, August 30, 2002 3:58 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Mozilla Upgrade

On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Dan Young wrote: 
> Robbert van Andel said:
> --snipped--
> > Anyone out
> > there have an idea that I can use to upgrade Mozilla and deal with
the
> > dependencies.  I'm guessing I'm missing a switch on the rpm command.
> 
> First, do a:
> 
> rpm -qa | grep mozilla
> 
> to see what mozilla packages you have installed.
> 
> Then d/l the updated ones to match. Followed by
> 
> rpm -Uvh mozilla*1.1-0.i386.rpm
> 
> That will match all of the mozilla rpms you d/l'ed that are v1.1-0 and
> will update all of the mozilla rpms at once. If multiple packages are
> dependant on each other, you have to upgrade them all at once, rather
than
> one at a time.
> 
> -Dan Young
> -Parkrose School District

...and if you then get...

error: failed dependencies:
        mozilla = 0.9.9 is needed by galeon-1.2.0-7

...grab the Red Hat rawhide version of galeon from...

ftp://ftp.rpmfind.net/linux/rawhide/1.0/i386/RedHat/RPMS/galeon-1.2.5-6.
i386.rpm

...and...

[root at kippered i386]# rpm -Uvh galeon-1.2.5-6.i386.rpm
mozilla*1.1-0.i386.rpm
Preparing...                ###########################################
[100%]
   1:mozilla-nspr           ###########################################
[ 12%]
   2:mozilla                ###########################################
[ 25%]
   3:galeon                 ###########################################
[ 37%]
   4:mozilla-chat           ###########################################
[ 50%]
   5:mozilla-devel          ###########################################
[ 62%]
   6:mozilla-mail           ###########################################
[ 75%]
   7:mozilla-nss            ###########################################
[ 87%]
   8:mozilla-psm            ###########################################
[100%]

P?rez-Mart? outlined one of the big reasons why this policy was announced.
According to P?rez-Mart?, the government and the people of Venezeula were
increasingly concerned that over 75 percent of the funds for software

only 5 percent to Venezuelan programmers.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Aug 30 23:17:44 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 30 Aug 2002 23:17:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs & word wrap
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208302112430.388-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <86wuq7d01j.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jason" == Jason Dagit <dagit at engr.orst.edu> writes:

Jason> I added that stuff to my .emacs, but it never happens.  I
Jason> noticed that when I edit email the major mode is Fundamental,
Jason> so I added fundamental-mode to list, and it still doesn't work.
Jason> What am I doing wrong...

My reading of the emacs info pages lead me to think that the
add-to-hooks call should look like this instead:

(add-to-hooks #'auto-fill-mode '(text-mode-hook
                                 message-mode-hook
                                 ;; ... add more mode names here ...
                                ))

Note the addition of -hook to Karl's example.  Also, I don't think
there is a 'fundamental-mode-hook, which partially torpedoes that for
you.

I think a reasonable solution is to indicate a default mode for new
buffers and then make sure auto-fill is on for text-mode with the two
following lines:

  (setq default-major-mode 'text-mode)
  (add-hook 'text-mode-hook 'turn-on-auto-fill)

-- 
Russell Senior         ``The two chiefs turned to each other.        
seniorr at aracnet.com      Bellison uncorked a flood of horrible       
                         profanity, which, translated meant, `This is
                         extremely unusual.' ''                      



From flee at aracnet.com  Fri Aug 30 23:35:09 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)

In-Reply-To: <86wuq7d01j.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> on 30 Aug 2002 23:17:44 PDT.

Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com>:
> Note the addition of -hook to Karl's example.  Also, I don't think
> there is a 'fundamental-mode-hook, which partially torpedoes that for
> you.

but you can set 'default-major-mode' to something other than
fundamental-mode.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Aug 31 00:18:23 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 31 Aug 2002 00:18:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs & word wrap
In-Reply-To: <86it1rcy83.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208302342200.514-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
	<86it1rcy83.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <86elcfcx8g.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

>>>>> "Jason" == Jason Dagit <dagit at engr.orst.edu> writes:
Jason> Is there a way I could pass a variable on the command line?
Jason> Then just enable auto-fill-mode if the var is set?  Since pine
Jason> starts a new instance of emacs for every edit, then that might
Jason> work really well.

Russell> It looks like this will work for you:

Russell>   emacs --eval "(setq default-major-mode 'text-mode)"

Hmm.  Actually, that didn't work when I just tested it.  What did, for
me, was making a file, say, special.el:

  (setq default-major-mode 'text-mode) 
  (add-hook 'text-mode-hook 'turn-on-auto-fill)

and then using:

  emacs -l special.el message-file

You can even byte-compile the special.el into special.elc, though it
isn't clear to me why you don't want to just put the two lines in your
.emacs file.

--

seniorr at aracnet.com      Bellison uncorked a flood of horrible       
                         profanity, which, translated meant, `This is
                         extremely unusual.' ''

  locate xfs

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Aug 31 07:03:22 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 07:03:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] System message/kernel error?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208310653110.9866-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Each morning when I come to log in on the workstation I see where the SCSI
bus has been queried for devices and the details of the tape drive revealed.
This information is posted to /var/log/messages and printedon the screen. It
happens only when there is a scheduled backup.

  In the daily run-parts report I see the same information presented as
"kernel errors".

  I would very much like to understand why this appears in 1)
/var/log/messages, 2) the cron.daily report and 3) on the monitor. I'd also
like to know if there's something I can do to eliminate this behavior. If,
as I suspect, this is normally written to /var/log/messages, I also suspect
that it's _not_ normal to have it appear on the monitor and in the run-parts
report.

  Here's an example from /var/log/messages:

Aug 30 23:30:01 appl-ecosys kernel: st: bufsize 32768, wrt 30720, max buffers 5, s/g segs 16. 
Aug 30 23:30:01 appl-ecosys kernel: sym53c8xx: at PCI bus 0, device 12, function 0 
Aug 30 23:30:01 appl-ecosys kernel: sym53c8xx: 53c895 detected with Tekram NVRAM 
Aug 30 23:30:01 appl-ecosys kernel: sym53c895-0: rev 0x1 on pci bus 0 device 12 function 0 irq 12 
Aug 30 23:30:01 appl-ecosys kernel: sym53c895-0: Tekram format NVRAM, ID 7, Fast-40, Parity Checking 
Aug 30 23:30:01 appl-ecosys kernel: scsi0 : sym53c8xx-1.7.1-20000726 
Aug 30 23:30:01 appl-ecosys kernel: scsi : 1 host. 
Aug 30 23:30:06 appl-ecosys kernel:   Vendor: TANDBERG  Model: SLR60             Rev: 0420 
Aug 30 23:30:06 appl-ecosys kernel:   Type:   Sequential-Access                  ANSI SCSI revision: 02 
Aug 30 23:30:06 appl-ecosys kernel:   Vendor: PLEXTOR   Model: CD-R   PX-W1210S  Rev: 1.01 
Aug 30 23:30:06 appl-ecosys kernel:   Type:   CD-ROM                             ANSI SCSI revision: 02 
Aug 30 23:30:06 appl-ecosys kernel: Detected scsi CD-ROM sr0 at scsi0, channel 0, id 6, lun 0 
Aug 30 23:30:11 appl-ecosys kernel: sym53c895-0-<6,*>: FAST-20 SCSI 20.0 MB/s (50 ns, offset 16) 
Aug 30 23:30:11 appl-ecosys kernel: sr0: scsi3-mmc drive: 32x/32x writer cd/rw xa/form2 cdda tray 
Aug 30 23:30:11 appl-ecosys kernel: Detected scsi tape st0 at scsi0, channel 0, id 4, lun 0 
Aug 30 23:30:11 appl-ecosys kernel: sym53c895-0-<4,*>: FAST-20 WIDE SCSI 40.0 MB/s (50 ns, offset 15) 
Aug 31 02:00:00 appl-ecosys kernel: sym53c895-0: detaching ... 
Aug 31 02:00:00 appl-ecosys kernel: sym53c895-0: resetting chip 
Aug 31 02:00:00 appl-ecosys kernel: scsi : 0 hosts. 
Aug 31 02:00:00 appl-ecosys kernel: st: Unloaded.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Aug 31 07:27:08 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 07:27:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] System message/kernel error?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208310653110.9866-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208310724020.1568-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 31 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> I would very much like to understand why this appears in 1)
> /var/log/messages, 2) the cron.daily report and 3) on the monitor.

The file governing what messages get logged and where those entries 
get posted is /etc/syslog.conf.

> I'd also like to know if there's something I can do to eliminate
> this behavior.

See the syslog.conf(5) man page and edit the syslog.conf file 
accordingly :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Aug 31 07:32:48 2002

From raanders at acm.org  Sat Aug 31 09:05:21 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 09:05:21 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] System message/kernel error?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208310653110.9866-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208310854250.1315-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Sat, 31 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

[snip]

>   I would very much like to understand why this appears in 1)
> /var/log/messages,

Rich,

I have a couple of systems that have the same 'problem' and some that
don't.  The ones that don't have BusLogic PCI/SCSI cards, the ones that do
have other cards.  (Mostly Adaptec 29xx cards.)  I believe it has to do
with a setting on the SCSI card about a sleep-mode/ bus-reset/ power-down/
some-such-thingy but the problem systems are 24/7 so I can't explore them
right now.  Only one of the BusLogic systems is under my direct control
and I've never had this problem with BusLogic SCSI cards.
   It would be interesting to know which chip set the SymBios is using.

Btw, I think you're using the same backup software I am, BRU, o we can't
blame it.  What about asking the BRU people (Tolis Group?) to see if
others have reported this issue and if they worked out a solution.  
   They've always been good to me.


Rod

  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sat Aug 31 09:45:22 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 09:45:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Collect input via bash?
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208310939350.7874-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

How do I collect user input using bash? For example, if you wanted to
collect three strings at the command line and store them as variables:

$./myscript.sh

your name: foo bar
number of oranges : 34
number of apples : 6

Any ideas?





From dcf at aracnet.com  Sat Aug 31 10:14:28 2002
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 10:14:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Collect input via bash?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208310939350.7874-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208311011090.16298-100000@linux.sourballs.org>

On Sat, 31 Aug 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> How do I collect user input using bash? For example, if you wanted to
> collect three strings at the command line and store them as variables:
>
> $./myscript.sh
>
> your name: foo bar
> number of oranges : 34
> number of apples : 6
>
> Any ideas?

#!/bin/sh

echo "your name: "
read name

echo "number of apples: "
read apples

echo "number of oranges: "
read oranges

echo "$name $apples $oranges"


--
 David Fleck
 dcf at aracnet.com

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Sat Aug 31 10:53:37 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)

Subject: [PLUG] gPhoto compiling: missing cc.
Message-ID: <200208311053.37041.hapibeli@attbi.com>

# cd gphoto2-2.0
[root at localhost gphoto2-2.0]# ./configure
creating cache ./config.cache
checking for a BSD compatible install... /usr/bin/install -c
checking whether build environment is sane... yes
checking whether make sets ${MAKE}... yes
checking for working aclocal... missing
checking for working autoconf... missing
checking for working automake... missing
checking for working autoheader... missing
checking for working makeinfo... missing
checking whether to enable maintainer-specific portions of Makefiles... no
checking for gcc... no
checking for cc... no
configure: error: no acceptable cc found in $PATH
 How do I correct this?
Dirk



From richard.langis at sun.com  Sat Aug 31 11:07:36 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 11:07:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] gPhoto compiling: missing cc.
References: <200208311053.37041.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D7105E8.70602@sun.com>

Finding the package of 'automake' might be a good bet.  Since you didn't 
list your distribution, here's what I did under debian:

$ apt-cache search automake

automake1.5 - A tool for generating GNU Standards-compliant Makefiles.
automake1.6 - A tool for generating GNU Standards-compliant Makefiles.
autoproject - create a skeleton source package for a new program
autotools-dev - Update infrastructure for config.{guess,sub} files
autobook - GNU Autoconf, Automake and Libtool Book
automake - A tool for generating GNU Standards-compliant Makefiles.

Finding whatever package under your distro that has those files would be 
a good place to start.  If you already have them (or think you do), try 
to 'locate' them and edit your $PATH.

-Richard


Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> # cd gphoto2-2.0
> [root at localhost gphoto2-2.0]# ./configure
> creating cache ./config.cache
> checking for a BSD compatible install... /usr/bin/install -c

> checking for working makeinfo... missing

From dcf at aracnet.com  Sat Aug 31 11:39:58 2002

Subject: [PLUG] System message/kernel error?

On Sat, 31 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Here's the relevant (and topmost) lines from /etc/syslog.conf:
>
> # Log all kernel messages to the console.
> # Logging much else clutters up the screen.
> #kern.*                                                 /dev/console
> kern.*                                                  /dev/tty12
>
>   Notice that I commented out the /dev/console destination. I've no idea
> what /dev/tty12 is; perhaps that needs to also be commented out.

It's the console you get by mashing Ctrl-Alt-F12, I believe.  At least it
is on my system.

>   I don't see any directions for kernel messages to go to /var/log/messages,
> but they sure end up there, too. Ergo, I must be misunderstanding the file
> or I'm missing something really simple.

something like:
kern.debug                      /var/log/messages

should send all kernel messages to /var/log/messages.  I think

kern.*                          /var/log/messages

would work too.


--
 David Fleck
 dcf at aracnet.com

From cschluti at pdx.edu  Sat Aug 31 12:26:21 2002
From: cschluti at pdx.edu (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 12:26:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] (Q & A) How do I know if I'm in Full-Duplex mode??
In-Reply-To: <001301c2511f$99b4e380$6401a8c0@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <000e01c25124$499e5160$4500000a@SERVANYA>

Recently in the #orlug chat room, we were wondering how to find out if
our NIC is in Full Duplex mode or not.

Well, I found this: http://more.sbc.co.jp/slj/doc/commands/mii_tool.asp
which is the man page for mii-tool.
And this VERY good info about it:
http://www.stonesoft.com/document/art/2185.html
I was very please to find out that I have mii-tool on my Mandrake 8.2
laptop.

Here's what I did:
su
mii-tool (it told me that I'm operating at 100baseTx-HD)

So, then I typed:
mii-tool -F 100baseTx-FD

Now, mii-tool said that I was running in Full-Duplex mode, but my switch
said otherwise. I got the other light on my switch to light up by
messing with what my NIC "advertises".
mii-tool -A 100baseTx-FD

Ta-da.
Hope this is helpful.
If you don't have mii-tool, you can get it here:
http://pcmcia-cs.sourceforge.net/ftp/extras/mii-tool.tar.gz

Now if I could just get my wireless card working, I'd be one happy
person :)

-CharlieS




From rsteff at attbi.com  Sat Aug 31 12:32:10 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 12:32:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] First Time Debian Install
Message-ID: <3D7119BA.A558B8FD@attbi.com>

Richard Steffens <rsteff at attbi.com> writes:
 
> > I'm used to the logout options provided by Red Hat
> > 7.0 and 7.1, which include halt. Halt was not an option.

"Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:

> I'm not sure what you are saying happened here, in that I don't know
> what screen you are on when you try to log in as root.   You had run
> "startx", but I don't know if you did that as "root" or as yourself.

I was on a text console when I logged in as rsteff, and when I ran
startx. 

> When you use "startx" rather than an X login manager, you do not need
> the "halt" option on a logout menu.  The "logout" there is to log out
> of X, back to your text mode shell.  Once there, you can use
> "Ctrl-Alt-DEL" or "halt" to shut down the computer.

Hmmm. When I logged out of KDE, I didn't get out of X, but was at the
KDE login screen.
 
> I can't imagine why it would not allow you to log in as root from the
> text console...

Didn't get back to a text console. Also, couldn't get to a text console.
I tried <ctrl><alt>F1, (and all the other function keys up through F8)
but all I get is a beep. Must be another configuration thing. What do
you call this one, and where do I change it so I can switch between
consoles?

> the X login managers do have configuration options to
> disallow root logins, and are shipped with somewhat parnoid security
> settings.  For "gdm", you must edit "/etc/gdm/gdm.conf", find the
> "[Security]" section, and change "AllowRoot" to "true", then restart
> "gdm" with "/etc/init.d/gdm restart".  After that, log into X as root,
> and look in the "System" menu (underfoot) for the "GDM Configurator".

> (For KDE's X login manager, log into X as root (IIRC it will let you
> do so by default), and use the control center to configure the KDM.)

There it is (GDM Configurator). One of the options is "Show the 'system'
menu, (for reboot, shutdown etc.) For now, I'm more familiar with Gnome,
so I'll just work with that. Later on I might try KDE.

Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> First, when you finished the install and were given a console for login,
> the init scripts installed by the recently configured packages had not
> run, so certain first-time-run options hadn't yet taken effect.  When you
> rebooted, the init script that fires up the display manager was run and
> the display manager has a default session/window manager configured.

That makes sense.

> You certainly
> don't want Halt as a logout option from your X session as a regular user
> and you probably don't want to run most session managers as root.  Best to
> setup an .xinitrc in /root that runs a very simple window manager and
> that's all for those very few times when you really must use X as root.

Brian Beattie wrote:

> Certainly you would not want a remote console or
> terminal for security reasons, but if I'm sitting at the connected
> display, I'm probably within reach of the power and reset switches, or I
> can just switch to the text console and give the three finger salute.
> The only thing one gains by not putting reboot and halt options on the
> logout popup, is inconvinence.

I have to agree with Brian on this one. I can see the advantages for
systems that are out where the "public" can access them, but not for the
one in my office at home.

Again, thanks for the help.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From revans at e-z.net  Sat Aug 31 13:16:31 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 13:16:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Collect input via bash?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208311011090.16298-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0208311011090.16298-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <20020831200515.HORI11061.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@dhcp-320-212>

I like to use read with the -p option instead of echo. 

while true ; do
	read -p "Please input your name: " NAME
	if [ ${#NAME} != 0 ] ; then 
		echo "Thank you, your name will be $NAME" 
		break  
	fi
done


Thank you
Russell


On Sat, 31 Aug 2002 10:14:28 -0700 (PDT), David Fleck said:


>  
>  #!/bin/sh
>  
>  echo "your name: "
>  read name
>  
>  echo "number of apples: "
>  read apples
>  
>  echo "number of oranges: "
>  read oranges
>  
>  echo "$name $apples $oranges"
>  





From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Aug 31 13:06:49 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 31 Aug 2002 13:06:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] gPhoto compiling: missing cc.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208311205030.10514-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208311205030.10514-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86wuq6bxnq.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

>> portions of Makefiles... no checking for gcc... no checking for
>> cc... no configure: error: no acceptable cc found in $PATH

>> How do I correct this?

Rich>   Install the development environmnent for whatever distribution
Rich> you're using. You have no compiler (gcc -- cc is the original
Rich> name) and no autoconf or automake tools. 

You don't need autoconf or automake.  Those are things used to create
the configure script.  You might need them if you were hacking on
gphoto, buy not just to build it.  You _will_ need gcc and possibly
some other development packages.

                         extremely unusual.' ''                      



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Aug 31 12:58:32 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 12:58:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: Re: gPhoto
In-Reply-To: <200208311240.52765.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208311255450.10514-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 31 Aug 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> You're right Rich. I forgot to install all of the Developement rpm's.

Dirk,

  This is an important lesson for all, and one worth having in the archive.
Even if you don't intend to write a single line of code in any compiled or
intepreted language, you need the development tools installed. Lots of
applications need them.

  Sometimes you need the development version of a tool set, in addition to
the tools themselves, in order to compile/install an application at a higher
level of abstraction.

  That's why we all have a dozen or two languages languishing on our hard
drives.

Good luck!

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Aug 31 15:16:35 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 15:16:35 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: RedHat RPMS
In-Reply-To: <200208311455.23055.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0208311514060.11140-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 31 Aug 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

>  I should have been more specific. How do I install all uninstalled rpms at 
> one time from the command line?

  Oh. In this case, I would probably put the cdrom #1 in the drive, run
'init 6' from the command line and get back to the install/upgrade program.
I'd select 'upgrade', let the software check for packages to upgrade, tell
it you want to select among those, then go to the "Development System"
section and pick the ones you want. The installer will then find the
dependencies those need and install the whole bunch. Usually.

Rich




From rsteff at attbi.com  Sat Aug 31 15:53:21 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 15:53:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Power Down doesn't
Message-ID: <3D7148E1.FDBA004E@attbi.com>

"Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:

> The reason it did not power itself off is that you do not have the
> "apm" module loaded.  Try "modprobe apm" and see if "halt" shuts the
> computer off after that.

Avatar:~# modprobe apm
modprobe: Can't locate module apm

> If it does not work, then try "apt-get
> install apmd", and try the "halt" again after ensuring that the "apm"
> module got loaded AND the "apmd" was running.=

After running apt-get install apmd:

Avatar:~# apmd start
No APM support in kernel

Does this mean I left something important out during the initial
installation, and that I need to recompile the kernel?

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Sat Aug 31 16:23:48 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 16:23:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Power Down doesn't
In-Reply-To: <3D7148E1.FDBA004E@attbi.com>
References: <3D7148E1.FDBA004E@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020831232348.GA20829@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

You will need to recompile your kernel, or at least compile the apm modules.
The easiest thing to do, is use "make menuconfig" to enable apm as a module
(APM is under the General Setup section in 2.4.17), then enabling the
aspects of APM you need.. I would start with just "Use real mode APM BIOS
call to power off", but others may have better advice.

Once you do that, exit menuconfig (saving your settings when prompted), then
do: 
	make dep && make modules && make modules_install

Assuming all that goes well, you will now be able to do the modprobe and
start apmd.

-Rogan

From rsteff at attbi.com  Sat Aug 31 16:34:33 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 16:34:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian console switching
Message-ID: <3D715289.A60E28AF@attbi.com>

Richard Steffens wrote:

> > There are a number of things that are not the same as what I've come
> > to expect when I start up either of my other two RH systems. I
> > suppose some of that is configuration related and some of it is
> > convention related.  But, this is intended to be a learning
> > experience, so time to start reading.

"Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:

> Can you be more specific?  Is it the "green lights" thing, or
> something less "cosmetic only" in nature?

Mostly cosmetic, I think.

One non-cosmetic thing is switching between virtual consoles. I can go
from X to one of the other consoles, but I can't go from that console to
anything else. Before I reconfigured gdm, I couldn't switch between
consoles at all -- I'd just get a beep. Now that the system menu is on
the Gnome login screen, I can switch to another console. I guess that's
a paranoia level security thing. <ctrl><alt><del> didn't work, either.
Makes sense. If the keyboard is in a public space, and you don't want
the public shutting things down, you wouldn't want them to be able to
switch to another console. (You can always lock the box itself in a
cabinet to prevent manual power interruption.)

Someplace, I read that I should use the left hand <ctrl> and <alt> keys
with the function keys for switching between consoles. On my keyboard,
the left hand <ctrl> and <alt> keys don't produce any effect.  Right
hand works for switching into another console in Linux, but doesn't want
to switch back? I tried all combinations of left and right hand
<ctrl><alt>F1-F8, including just F1-F8, and just <ctrl>F1, or <alt>F1
(through F12, actually). I get the X screen back when I reboot, though.

A similar thing happens in Windows -- left hand <ctrl><alt><del> doesn't
work, but right hand does. (It's an older keyboard, Precision
Instruments model KB101MC. It's really comfortable, so I stayed with it
through two machine upgrades.)

--

because the cord for the hub was short so I needed to move the mouse to a
lower port so that the hub could sit on top of my box. Mouse still works in
windows (after re-recognizing). When I fired up Linux, Harddrake informed me
that my USB mouse was gone. I can't see it in /dev/USB (I'm using devfs).
I've tried running mousedrake, but apparently that only configures the
software side (GPM + Xwindows). Any clues?

plugged in to the port the mouse is plugged in to?

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Sat Aug 31 18:35:08 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 18:35:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Power Down doesn't
In-Reply-To: <3D7157B6.A2367FCA@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208311829150.21850-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Sat, 31 Aug 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Rogan Creswick wrote:
>
> > You will need to recompile your kernel, or at least compile the apm modules.
> > The easiest thing to do, is use "make menuconfig"...
>
> Avatar:~# make menuconfig
> make: *** No rule to make target `menuconfig'. Stop.
>
> I must be missing something.

Apt has a way to get kernels and install them, but I have never tried
it.  I got to www.kernel.org, and grab the latest stable kernel.
Should be something like 2.4.19 or 2.4.20.  Once you have that, I
usually put it in /usr/src/linux-x.x.xx, and then type
ln -s /usr/src/linux-x.x.xx /usr/src/linux

Then you can go into /usr/src/linux and do make menuconfig, or make
xconfig.  You may want to get some help with the kernel options.  I
usually configure from scratch, but it took me a while to get to the
point where I could make a kernel with all the features I wanted on
the first try.  #orlug would be a good place to get help with the
config.

HTH,
Jason

From sean at fork.com  Sat Aug 31 19:08:03 2002
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 19:08:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Power Down doesn't
In-Reply-To: <3D7157B6.A2367FCA@attbi.com>
References: <3D7148E1.FDBA004E@attbi.com> <20020831232348.GA20829@silver.CS.ORST.EDU> <3D7157B6.A2367FCA@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020901020804.2FFF22F5F0@einstein.seansdomain.org>

Once you get the kernel-source downloaded, look at the debian.README.gz in 
the doc/kernel-source-X.XX/ folder it will give pretty good instructions on 
what to do.

Also copy /boot/config to your /usr/src/linux folder, that way you are 
starting from a known good configuration.


Sean

> Rogan Creswick wrote:
> > You will need to recompile your kernel, or at least compile the apm
> > modules. The easiest thing to do, is use "make menuconfig"...

> Avatar:~# make menuconfig
> make: *** No rule to make target `menuconfig'. Stop.
>
> I must be missing something.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Aug 31 19:15:45 2002

  The docs for a couple of Palm Pilot applications are distributed as html

code to, for example, PostScript or PDF?

From revans at e-z.net  Sat Aug 31 21:37:37 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 21:37:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Fw: Nmap 3.10ALPHA2 released
Message-ID: <20020901042615.BCLJ19514.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@dhcp-320-212>

You might want to be sure your firewall rules filter ipv6 as while as ipv4. I
had left the ipv6 module in the default  SuSE kernel loading after I toasted
the networking by disabling everything but net-pf-1 / unix. I have ATT cable
and need DHCP to work and it took a while for me to realize that the net-pf-17
/ af_packet module was needed for DHCP. I was playing with a lot of things when
I broke DHCP and wasn't testing the changes one at a time. Once I figured out
what I did, I disabled the net modules that I don't use.  

I haven't figured out how to keep SuSE from configuring IPv6 other than by
disabling the ability to load the module. There is probably a better way to do
this but this works. The following is what I did in /etc/modules.conf. YMMV  

alias net-pf-1 unix
#alias net-pf-3 ax25
alias net-pf-3 off
#alias net-pf-4 ipx
alias net-pf-4 off
#alias net-pf-5 appletalk
alias net-pf-5 off
#alias net-pf-6 netrom
alias net-pf-6 off
#alias net-pf-10 ipv6
alias net-pf-10 off
#alias net-pf-11 rose
alias net-pf-11 off
alias net-pf-17 af_packet

I will download the new nmap and load ipv6 tomorrow to see if SuSEfirewall2
blocks the scans. I'll post my findings if someone doesn't beat me to it. 


Thank you
Russell





--- Forwarded Message ---
 From: "Fyodor" <fyodor at insecure.org>
 To: nmap-hackers at insecure.org
 Sent: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 19:23:57 -0700
 Subject: Nmap 3.10ALPHA2 released

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

Hello everyone,

I am pleased to announce that Nmap version 3.10ALPHA2 is now
available!  This version has some cool stuff that I couldn't add
before due to stability issues.  In particular, IPv6 is now supported
and the codebase has been migrated to C++.  Due to all the changes,
there may be portability problems.  But I have lightly tested it on
Linux, FreeBSD, Solaris, and Windows.  If it does not compile/work for
you, please let me know (including details on the OS you are running).
A patch is even better :).

The IPv6 support is currently limited to the most important options
such as -sT.  I may add raw packet scans (ICMP6 pinging, UDP, SYN,
etc) if there is demand.  The protocol is actually pretty fun!	Not
only do I feel like a king with my own /64 allocation
(18446744073709551616 addresses!), but it can be useful for bypassing
certain firewalls.  Check out this host that has a bunch of filtered
IPv4 ports, but is wide open via IPv6.	Pay special attention to port
111 (SunRPC).

> nmap www.kame.net

Starting nmap V. 3.10ALPHA1 ( www.insecure.org/nmap/ )
Interesting ports on kame220.kame.net (203.178.141.220):
(The 1585 ports scanned but not shown below are in state: closed)
Port	   State       Service
19/tcp	   filtered    chargen
21/tcp	   open        ftp
22/tcp	   open        ssh
53/tcp	   open        domain
80/tcp	   open        http
111/tcp    filtered    sunrpc
137/tcp    filtered    netbios-ns
138/tcp    filtered    netbios-dgm
139/tcp    filtered    netbios-ssn
513/tcp    filtered    login
514/tcp    filtered    shell
2049/tcp   filtered    nfs
2401/tcp   open        cvspserver
5999/tcp   open        ncd-conf
7597/tcp   filtered    qaz
31337/tcp  filtered    Elite

Nmap run completed -- 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 34 seconds

> nmap -6 www.kame.net

Starting nmap V. 3.10ALPHA1 ( www.insecure.org/nmap/ )
Interesting ports on 3ffe:501:4819:2000:210:f3ff:fe03:4d0:
(The 1595 ports scanned but not shown below are in state: closed)
Port	   State       Service
21/tcp	   open        ftp
22/tcp	   open        ssh
53/tcp	   open        domain
80/tcp	   open        http
111/tcp    open        sunrpc
2401/tcp   open        cvspserver

Nmap run completed -- 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 19 seconds

Note that this may have changed, since I notified the Kame folks last
week.  But I'm sure this is a common mistake.

Here are the CHANGELOG entries since 3.00 (ALPHA1 was a dev-only
release):

Nmap 3.10ALPHA2

o Fixed compilation and IPv6 support on FreeBSD (tested on
  4.6-STABLE).	Thanks to Niels Heinen (niels.heinen at ubizen.com) for
  suggestions.

o Made some portability changes based on suggestions by Josef 'Jupp'
  Schugt (jupp at gmx.de)

o Fixed compilation and IPv6 support on Solaris 9 (haven't tested
  earlier versions).

Nmap 3.10ALPHA1

o IPv6 is now supported for TCP scan (-sT), connect()-style ping scan
  (-sP), and list scan (-sL)!  Just specify the -6 option and the IPv6
  numbers or DNS names.  Netmask notation is not currently supported
  -- I'm not sure how useful it is for IPv6, where even petty end
  users may be allocated trillions of addresses (/80).	If you need
  one of the scan types that hasn't been ported yet, give Sebastien
  Peterson's patch a try at http://nmap6.sourceforge.net/ .  If there
  is demand, I may integrate more of that into Nmap.

o Major code restructing, which included conversion to C++ -- so
  you'll need g++ or another C++ compiler.  I accidently let a C++
  requirement slip in a while back and found that almost everyone has
  such a compiler.  Windows (VC++) users: see the README-WIN32 for new
  compilation instructions.

o Applied patch from Axel Nennker (Axel.Nennker at t-systems.com) which
  adds a --without-nmapfe option to the configure script.  This si
  useful if your system doesn't have the proper libraries (eg GTK) or
  if you think GUIs are for sissies :).

o Removed arbitrary max_parallelism (-M) limitations, as suggested by
  William McVey ( wam at cisco.com ).

o Added DEC OSF to the platforms that require the BSDFIX() macro due
  to taking ip length and offset fields in host rather than network
  byte
  order.  Suggested by Dean Bennett (deanb at gbtn.net)

o Fixed an debug statement C ambiguity discovered by Kronos
  (kronos at kronoz.cjb.net)

For those of you running Linux/x86 w/a recent version of rpm
(www.rpm.org), you can install/upgrade to the newest version of
nmap/nmapfe by executing these commands as root:

rpm -vhU (nmap url)
where (nmap url) is one (or both) of these:

http://download.insecure.org/nmap/dist/nmap-3.10ALPHA2-1.i386.rpm
http://download.insecure.org/nmap/dist/nmap-frontend-3.10ALPHA2-1.i386.rpm

For the rest of you, source tarballs and source RPMs are always
available at: http://www.insecure.org/nmap/nmap_download.html

For the more paranoid (smart) members of the list, here are the md5
hashes:

b7e2a33d22afe8912ab33b8c58a2fb19  nmap-3.10ALPHA2-1.i386.rpm
e27797651052ff751e89d938bd516605  nmap-3.10ALPHA2-1.src.rpm
520c808838251029a0cc53811b8c4920  nmap-3.10ALPHA2.tgz
eb8cbeb15b3b33adc0d9d7fbbe6e3312  nmap-frontend-3.10ALPHA2-1.i386.rpm

These release notes should be signed with my PGP key, which is available at
http://www.insecure.org/fyodor_gpgkey.txt .
The key fingerprint is: 97 2F 93 AB 9C B0 09 80 D9 51 40 6B B9 BC E1 7E

Cheers,
Fyodor

Version: GnuPG v1.0.4 (GNU/Linux)
Comment: For info see http://www.gnupg.org

In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0208311821320.21850-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Message-ID: <86ofbib7h0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jason" == Jason Dagit <dagit at engr.orst.edu> writes:

Russell> What did, for me, was making a file, say, special.el:

Russell>    (setq default-major-mode 'text-mode) 
Russell>    (add-hook 'text-mode-hook 'turn-on-auto-fill)
 
Russell> and then using:
 
Russell>    emacs -l special.el message-file

Jason> That still didn't work for me...It sets it to text mode, but
Jason> auto-fill-mode is not set.  

Maybe something in your .emacs is interfering.  Try:

   emacs --no-init-file -l special.el message-file

What emacs are you using, btw?

   $ emacs --version

   under the terms of the GNU General Public License.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat Aug 31 23:29:56 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 23:29:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: gPhoto
In-Reply-To: <1030823683.1412.722.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
References: <200208311240.52765.hapibeli@attbi.com> <1030823683.1412.722.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <200208312329.57103.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I've compiled gphoto2 so I could download pictures from my digital 
camera and originally wanted some sort of GUI that worked with it. But 
after having had my camera for couple of months now and have take 
several 100 pictures I'm not sure what I would use a GUI for with 
"gphoto2". I only use "gphoto2" to download the pictures from my camera 
and that's it. Once I have all of the JPEG files on disk and can view 
them with a variety of utilities. 

My favorite "viewer" right now is the Konqueror browser in KDE 3. It has 
an "Image Gallery" feature that will scan through an entire 
subdirectory creating thumbnails of each image and generating an 
"images.html" file. The HTML file allows me to see each thumbnail and 
when I click on a thumbnail the corresponding JPEG file is opened in my 
browser.

I'm not saying a GUI wouldn't be nice but after initially thinking I 
needed a GUI with "gphoto2" I find I don't really one. I tend to take 
high resolution (4 megapixel) images which are too large to post on a 
website or send through email so I use a command-line utility called 
"convert" to scale my JPEG images down to a more reasonable size. With 
a simple shell script wrapper around "convert" I can scale entire 
directories of images with a single command.

I always like trying to things out with "gphoto2" and so I would like to 
hear from anyone that has a GUI working with it since I've only used it 
from the command-line.

Tony
